editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE THRICE ILLVSTRIOVS AND MOST EXCELLENT PRINCE, CHARLES, THE ONELY SONNE OF OVR SOVERAIGNE LORD THE KING.
div.p:
I Haue humbly ≈øought leaue of his mo≈øt Excellent MAIESTIE, to pre≈øent your Highne≈ø≈øe with this ∆≤olume of his MAIESTIES WORKES. I dur≈øt not but make the Suite; and his MAIESTIE could not well deny it. I will not ≈øay, that it had beene a peece of Iniustice in the KING to haue denyed you this right: But I dare ≈øay, it had beene a point of Sacriledge in a Churchman to haue ≈øtolne from you ≈øuch a portion
of your Inheritance, which con≈øi≈øts as much in the WORKES of his Royall ∆≤ertues, as in the wealth of his mighty Kingdomes. Ba≈øilius wrote de Jn≈øtitutione Principis to his Sonne Leo; Constantinus to his Sonne Romanus; Manuell to his Sonne Iohannes; and Charles the fift, to his Sonne Philip: The workes of the three former are extant both in Greeke and Latine. His Maiestie, after the Example of tho≈øe Emperours, and ≈øundry other Kings, wrote his ŒíŒëŒ£ŒôŒõŒôŒöŒüŒù-ŒîŒ©Œ°ŒüŒù to Prince Henry, your Highne≈ø≈øe mo≈øt worthy Brother: His part, by GOD his Prouidence, is falne to your Lot; and who may iu≈øtly detaine from you the re≈øt? The rule in Scripture is; that if the fir≈øt fruits be holy, ≈øo is the whole lumpe; and to whom the fir≈øt was giuen, to him all the re≈øt was due: To your Highnes therefore are the≈øe offered, as to the trew Heire and Inheritor of them. And that I may make you the better accompt of them; May it plea≈øe your Highne≈ø≈øe to vnder≈øtand, that of the≈øe Workes, ≈øome were out before; ≈øome other of them neuer ≈øaw light before; and others were almo≈øt lo≈øt and gone, or at lea≈øt abu≈øed by fal≈øe copies, to their owne di≈øgrace and his Maie≈øties great di≈øhonour. Now it being the duetie of all Deanes in their Churches, Di≈øper≈øa colligere; I thought it might ≈øort well with the nature of my place in the Chappel, wherein I haue had the Honour ≈øo many yeeres to ≈øerue his Maie≈øtie, to gather the≈øe things that were ≈øcattered, and to bring to light tho≈øe that too long had lien in darkenes, and to pre≈øerue in one body, what might ea≈øily haue bin lo≈øt in parts. In this Pre≈øentment, I mu≈øt humbly craue of your Highnes, not to be mi≈øtaken in the trew meaning and maner of it: For the≈øe Workes come not to you, as v≈øually Bookes doe to men of great Dignitie, for Patronage and Protection; for Protection is properly from iniurie; and that the Royall Author of them is be≈øt able to right: But to you they come partly for pre≈øeruation, and for that the Di≈øpo≈øition
of Nature hath made you more apt, and more principally for a Patterne, and that not vnfitly; ≈øince the Samplar is euer more ancient then the Exemplification: And as in the pre≈øeruation, the Sonne hath his aduantage by ≈øucceeding; ≈øo in the Patterne, the Father by preceding hath his Prerogatiue. Let the≈øe Workes therefore, mo≈øt Gracious Prince, lie before you as a Patterne; you cannot haue a better: Neither doeth the Honour of a good Sonne con≈øi≈øt in any thing more, then in immitating the good Pre≈øidents of a good Father; as we may very well perceiue by the Scripture phra≈øe, where the v≈øuall Encomium of good Kings is, that they walked in the wayes of their Fathers. Al men ≈øee, how like the Patterne GOD and Nature haue framed the outward Lineaments: and who knowes your Highnes wel, knowes al≈øo, that the inward Abilliments hold in the like proportion. The Philo≈øophers ≈øay, that Imitation proceeds from Inclination; And trewly, if your future Imitation be an≈øwerable to your forward Inclination, in Religion, Learning and ∆≤ertue; your Highne≈ø≈øe cannot come farre ≈øhort of your Patterne, nor yet of any of your Predece≈øsors that euer went before you: Which GOD grant together with the length of many good and happy Dayes.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p: AMongst the infinite number of great ∆≤olumes wherewith the world ≈øeemes, as it were, to bee wayed downe, there bee few of them that were written at once, or were at first publi≈øhed together. Writings as they con≈øist of ≈øundry natures; ≈øo they will beare a diuers maner of Edition. To ≈øet foorth an Art by pieces, is to ≈øhew you a body di≈ømembred; the one is no more vncomely, then the other is vnproper. To publi≈øh a Hi≈øtory before it be at an end, is to turne the Hower-gla≈øse before it bee runne out; neither of both will giue you a trew ta≈øte of the time. But writings of other Natures, Common places and Controuer≈øies, Meditations and Commentaries, as they are for the most part, accidentally taken vp, ≈øo they are as occa≈øionally ≈øet out: They craue no other birth into the world, then they had conceptions in our braines, ≈øingly by vs conceiued, and ≈øingly by them≈øelues ≈øet out.

The different maner of GOD his ≈øetting foorth of his owne Workes, may in≈øtruct vs in this point. His diuine Wi≈øedome held one cour≈øe in his Naturall Workes, an other in his Ceremonialls, Politicalls and Moralls. Jn his Naturalls he made a ma≈ø≈øe at once, which ≈øpeedily he diuer≈øified into diuers formes. Hee gaue a kinde of potentiall delineation of all things in that vniuer≈øall matter, which pre≈øently hee di≈øtingui≈øhed into diuers Species in
perfection: But in his Ceremonialls, hee takes another cour≈øe, he brings not them out of a Ma≈ø≈øe, but into a Ma≈ø≈øe: He doeth not out of a Totum produce the parts, but out of the parts make vp the whole. For example; Jn the Ceremonialls, fir≈øt he beginnes with Sacrifice, long after he followes with Circumci≈øion, then hee filleth a Tabernacle with them; at la≈øt makes them full vp in a Temple. Jn his Politicalls, hee beginnes with a paternall Gouernment in a family, proceeds to an Election of a Captaine in an Armie, as in Io≈øuah and the Judges, perfects it by way of Succe≈øsion in a ≈øetled Kingdome, as in Solomon and his Succe≈ø≈øors. Jn his Moralls, hee beginnes with the word out of his owne mouth, proceeds with the Tables written by his owne fingers, followes on with the fiue Bookes penned by Mo≈øes, till hee make vp the Canon perfect by a number of ≈øucceeding Prophets.

What we haue from GOD in a pre≈øident, it may wel be≈øeeme vs to practi≈øe; and ≈øince his Bookes came out ≈øo farre a≈øunder, it is no reproach to any man, though his Workes come not foorth together: for there is a rea≈øon for it in vs an≈øwerable in ≈øome proportion to that of the Workes of GOD, for workes of Nature haue their roote from within vs, and bring with them a radicall kinde of vertue, that neuer ≈øuffers them to rest, till they haue produced their fruite to perfect forme and perfection: Workes of deliberation and Art, haue their foundation from without vs, and giue vs occa≈øion to worke vpon them, as our phanta≈øies thinke fittest for the pre≈øent time: Hence proceeds it, that the workes of Nature haue ≈øo few errors in them, tho≈øe of Art ≈øo many; They of Nature ≈øo con≈øtant, they of Arte ≈øo variable; they of Nature ≈øo permanent, they of Art ≈øo ≈øoone peri≈øh; they of Nature ≈øo well accepted and approued of all, they of Art accepted or reiected, as it plea≈øeth the ≈øeuerall apprehen≈øions of men to conceiue of them.

Now, albeit the workes of men be of Errors ≈øo full, of nature ≈øo different, ≈øubiect to ≈øo many Jnterpretations, publi≈øhed at ≈øo diuers times; Yet hath it bene euer esteemed a matter commendable to collect them together, and incorporate them into one Body, that we may behold at once, what diuers Off-≈øprings haue proceeded
from one braine, and how various Conceptions the wit of man is able to afford the world. To instance in a few of them beginning a little higher then the writings of ordinarie Men. The ≈øeruants of Hezekiah are commended in Scripture for collecting together the Sentences of Solomon. Ie≈øus the ≈øonne of Sirach is prai≈øed for ≈øearching out the Copies of his Grandfathers workes: But principally Ezra is had in great honour for ≈øetting in order the whole Bookes of the Old Te≈øtament, and deuiding them into Chapters and ∆≤er≈øes, which before were caried along in a ≈øcroule, by a continuall Series, without any distinction at all. S. Iohn is reported to haue ≈øearched out the Copies of the three former Euangelists, and to haue added his owne for the fourth in that order, as now they are extant. And the Primitiue Church was curious to gather together the Epistles of the Holy Apostles; which, they being not able by rea≈øon of per≈øecution perfectly to performe in euery place, gaue occa≈øion to after-times, to call the authority of ≈øo many of them into question.

But to de≈øcend; How are we bound to tho≈øe, who haue laboured in ≈øetting out the Coun≈øells, and Works of the Fathers together? Jn≈øomuch, that we thinke our ≈øelues as much bound to Eu≈øebius and Hierom, and of later times to Peter Crab and Era≈ømus and diuers others, who haue laboured in that kinde, as wee doe almo≈øt to the Authors them≈øelues. Traian commended Plutark for gathering the Apothegmes of wi≈øe men together. Con≈øtantinus the ≈øonne of Leo, collected out of all Histories, both in the Ea≈øt and West, one Corpus Hi≈øtoricum, which they counted an inestimable Trea≈øure. Iu≈øtinian by the helpe of Tribonianus did the like in the Lawes. Gratian compiled the Decrees out of the Epistles of Popes, Councells and Fathers. Dama≈øcen collected into one body of Diuinitie, the Sentences of the Greeke Fathers; And Peter Lumbard 400. yeeres after him by his example did the like in the Latine Fathers. And how doe wee labour to recouer Bookes that are lost? The Bookes of Origen that amounted to ≈øixe thou≈øand, as Epiphanius witne≈øseth, were much laboured for by Eu≈øebius and others. The Bookes of Cicero
de Repub. were much ≈øought for by Cardinall Poole; and great ≈øummes of money haue bene ≈øpent to recouer the lo≈øt Decades of Liuie. Wherefore ≈øince it hath beene heretofore the practi≈øe of all aages, to collect the workes of Men of worth, and pre≈øerue them from peri≈øhing; to labour much in recouering tho≈øe that haue bene lo≈øt; to giue to euery childe the owne Father; to euery Booke the trew Author: (for there neuer had bene halfe ≈øo many birds to haue flowen about the world with fal≈øe feathers, if euery Author had ≈øet out his owne workes together in his owne time,) J hope then it ≈øhall not be now a matter of reproofe in a Seruant, to trauaile in the ≈øetting foorth of the Works of his Ma≈øter; and for giuing you that together, which before yee could hardly get a≈øunder; and for pre≈øeruing that in a Ma≈ø≈øe from peri≈øhing, that might ea≈øily be lo≈øt in a Mite.

But while I am collecting workes one way, I heare others ≈øcattering wordes as fa≈øt an other way, affirming, it had beene better his Maie≈øtie had neuer written any Bookes at all; and being written, better they had peri≈øhed with the pre≈øent, like Proclamations, then haue remayned to Po≈øterity: For ≈øay the≈øe Men, Little it befitts the Maie≈øty of a King to turne Clerke, and to make a warre with the penne, that were fitter to be fought with the Pike; to ≈øpend the powers of his ≈øo exqui≈øite an vnder≈øtanding vpon paper, which had they beene ≈øpent on powder, could not but haue preuayled ere this, for the Conque≈øt of a Kingdome. For a King, ≈øay they, to enter a Controuer≈øie with a Scholler, is, as if he ≈øhould fight a Combate with a Kerne; he doth no more de≈øcend from his Honour in the one, then he bringes vpon him≈øelfe Di≈øgrace by the other. And ≈øince that Booke-writing is growen into a Trade; It is as di≈øhonorable for a King to write bookes; as it is for him to be a Practitioner in a Profe≈ø≈øion. Jf a King will needs write; Let him write like a King, euery Lyne a Law, euery Word a Precept, euery Letter a Mandate. Jn good trewth, I haue had my eares ≈øo oft dung through with the≈øe Obiections and the like, as I know not whether I conceiued ami≈øse of my ≈øelfe or no, thinking I had more ability to an≈øwere the≈øe Calumnyes, then I had patience
to heare them: And therefore hauing ≈øo fit opportunity, J ≈øhall not let to deliuer my opinion; Whether it may ≈øorte with the Maie≈øtie of a King, to be a writer of Bookes, or no. First I could neuer reade, that there was any Law against it; and where we haue no Law, the best is to follow good Examples: And many Diuines are of opinion, that examples that are not contrary to any Precept, doe binde vs in practi≈øe, at least ≈øo farre; that though they doe not inforce vs to the doing, yet they warrant the deede when it is done; And if Examples will ≈øerue the turne, wee haue Examples enough.

First to beginne with the King of Kings God him≈øelfe, who as he doth all things for our good; So doeth he many things for our Jmitation. Jt plea≈øed his Diuine wi≈øedome to bee the fir≈øt in this Rancke, that we read of, that did euer write. Hee wrote, and the writing was the writing, ≈øaith Mo≈øes, of God; the maner was after the maner of engrauing; the matter was in Stone cut into two Tables, and the Tables were the worke of God written on both ≈øides. Diuines hold, that the Heart is the principall Seate of the Soule; which Soule of ours is the immediate worke of God, as the≈øe Tables were the immediate worke of his owne fingers. The Stone, the expre≈ø≈øe repre≈øent of the hardne≈øse of our heart; the engrauing the worke of God ≈øo deepely impre≈øsed, that it can neuer be blotted out; the writing, the writing of the Law in our hearts; In two Tables, for our double duty to God and Man; on both ≈øides to take vp our heart ≈øo wholly, that nothing contrary to tho≈øe Precepts ≈øhould euer haue any place in our Soules. And certainely from this little Library, that God hath erected within vs, is the foundation of all our Learning layd; So that people Ciuillized doe account them≈øelues depriued of one of the be≈øt abilities of nature, if they be not ≈øomewhat inabled by writing, to expre≈ø≈øe their mindes: And there is no Nation ≈øo bruti≈øh or Barbarous, that haue not inuented one kinde of Character or other, whereby to conuey to others their inward Conceptions. From the≈øe Tables of God, wee may come to the writing of our Ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour, which we may put in the next place, though not for order yet for Honour. His Diuine
Maiestie left behinde him no Monument of writing, written by his owne hand in any externall Booke; for he was to induce and bring in an other maner of the writing of the Law of Loue; not in Tables of ≈øtone; written not with incke and paper, but in the Tables of our fle≈øhly hearts written by the Spirit of the Liuing God: Yet did he once with his owne finger, write on the Pauement of the Temple of Ieru≈øalem. What he writ, J will not now di≈øcu≈ø≈øe. S. Ambro≈øe ≈øaith he wrote this Sentence: Fe≈øtucam in oculo fratris cernis, trabem in tuo non vides. Beda thinkes, he wrote that Sentence that he ≈øpake: He that is without ≈øinne, let him ca≈øt the fir≈øt ≈øtone at her. Haymo hath a pretty Conceit: He thinketh, he wrote certaine Characters in the Pauement, which the Accu≈øers beholding might ≈øee, as in a gla≈ø≈øe, their owne wickedne≈ø≈øe; and ≈øo blu≈øhing at it went their wayes. What euer it was, ≈øure we are, our Sauiour would haue fal≈øe accu≈øations written in dust, to bee troden vnder foote of them that pa≈øse by. But how≈øoeuer, I ≈øay, our Ble≈øsed Sauiour did leaue behind him no writing of his owne hand; Yet we may not deny, but that God in the old Te≈øtament and our Sauiour in the New, haue left vs many bookes of their owne inditements: For all the Bookes of holy Scripture were written by in≈øpiration; and the Prophets and Apo≈øtles were but their Amanuen≈øes, and writ onely as they were led and actuated by the Spirit of God: So that we may not make the Author of any of tho≈øe Bookes any other then God Him≈øelfe.

The old world before the flood wil afford vs no writings, neither did that aage require them; for the liues of Men of that aage were liuing Libraries, and la≈øted longer then the labors of Men doe in this aage: Yet S. Iude doeth in≈øinuate ≈øomewhat of the writings of Enoch, who though he were not in Stile a King, Yet there is no rea≈øon to contend with him for that Title; for his Dominion would beare it, ≈øtanding Heire-Apparent to the greater part of the world. Origen, Tertullian and Augu≈øtine report many things out of the ≈øuppo≈øititous writings that went vnder his name: And Io≈øephus and that Bero≈øus, that wee haue, tell vs, that hee erected
two pillars, the one of Stone, the other of Bricke, wherein he wrote of the two-fold destructions of the world, the one by Water, the other by Fire: But how≈øoeuer that be trew, it is very probable, he wrote ≈øomething of that matter, which though it peri≈øhed with that world; yet doubtle≈ø≈øe the memory thereof was pre≈øerued by Tradition vnto the dayes of the Apo≈øtles.

J will not here in≈øist vpon the writings of Mo≈øes, who was not onely a Prie≈øt, and a Prophet, but was, as him≈øelfe records, amongst the people a King, and was the fir≈øt that euer receiued authoritie from GOD to write in Diuinitie: Neither will J in≈øi≈øt vpon the Example of King Dauid, in who≈øe P≈øalmes and Himnes, are re≈øounded out the prai≈øes of GOD in all the Churches; for that J finde nothing that the≈øe men writ, but what they writ as the Scribes of GOD, acted, as I ≈øaid euen now, by GOD his Spirit, and not guided by their owne. Yet I ≈øuppo≈øe wee may ≈øafely collect thus much from them, that if GOD had thought it a matter derogatory to the Maie≈øtie of a King to bee a Writer, he would not haue made choice of tho≈øe, as his chiefe In≈øtruments in this kinde, who were principalls in that other Order. J would ea≈øily beleeue, that ≈øuch men as haue had the honour to be GOD his Pen-men, ≈øhould neuer vouch≈øafe to write any thing of their owne: for as we hold in a pious opinion, that the ble≈ø≈øed Virgine, hauing once conceiued by the holy Gho≈øt, would neuer after conceiue by man; So ≈øurely men, that had deliuered nothing but the conceptions of that Spirit, ≈øhould hardly be drawne euer to ≈øet out any of their owne labours. But we ≈øee the flat contrary both in Samuel and Solomon, the one the greate≈øt Iudge, the other the mo≈øt glorious King, that euer that Kingdome had. Samuel, who writ by GODS appointment, the greate≈øt part of tho≈øe two Bookes, that beare his name, writ al≈øo by his owne accord, a Booke contayning the Law of a King, or In≈øtitution of a Prince, whereby hee laboured to keepe the King as well from declining to Tyrannie, as the people from running into Libertie. Solomon, be≈øides the Bookes of Scripture, which remaine, writ many likewi≈øe of his owne accord, which are lo≈øt: For to ≈øay nothing of his 3000. Parables,
his 5000. How many are the wayes that men doe inuent to perpetuate their Memorie! In≈øomuch, that mortall-men haue made them≈øelues Gods, when they were dead, that they might be adored, as if they were aliue. Wherein, is the Impetus of Nature ≈øo ≈øtrong,

When the King had publi≈øhed his Ba≈øilicon-Doron, a Booke ≈øo ≈øingularly penned; that a Pomegranat is not ≈øo full of kernells, as that is of Excellent Coun≈øells: What applau≈øe had it in the world? How did it inflame mens minds to a loue and admiration of his Maie≈øtie beyond mea≈øure; In≈øomuch that comming out iust at the time his Maie≈øtie came in, it made the hearts of all his people as one Man, as much to Honour him for Religion and Learning, as to obey him for Title and Authoritie; and gaue vs then a ta≈øte, or rather the first fruits, of that we haue ≈øince reaped a plentifull Harue≈øt of, by his Maie≈øties mo≈øt prudent and Gracious Gouernment ouer vs. The like I may ≈øay of his Maie≈øties Demonologie; a rare peece for many Precepts and Experiments, both in Diuinitie and Naturall Philo≈øophie.
Jn the≈øe, there was nothing heard of, but Sunne-≈øhine and faire-weather; euery countenance ≈øweet and ≈ømiling vpon them: But as ≈øoone as his Maie≈øtie dealt against the Pope, tooke the Cardinall in hand, made the world ≈øee the v≈øurped power of the one, and Sophi≈øtry of the other; Good Lord, what a ≈øtirre we had; what roaring of the wilde Bulls of Ba≈øan, what a commotion in euery Countrey; Jn≈øomuch, that I thinke, there is ≈øcarce a People, Language or Nation in Chri≈øtendome, out of which his Maie≈øtie hath not receiued ≈øome an≈øwere or other; either by way of re≈øuting, or at lea≈øt by rayling: So that, had not the King contemned and made him≈øelfe ≈øport and recreation by ≈øuch kinde of Reuelling, rather then bene mooued to pa≈øsion; It could not haue bene but a marueilous perturbation to a Prince of ≈øo exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe and vnder≈øtanding. But what of all this? Shall wee wi≈øh his Maie≈øtie had not fought with bea≈øts at Ephe≈øus, ≈øtopped the roaring of the Bull, nor encountered the Cardinall? Trewly when J thinke vpon the wonderfull abu≈øes, and Hyperbolicall indignities his Maie≈øtie hath receiued from the≈øe men; I am ≈øomewhat of that minde: But when on the other ≈øide, J con≈øider his Maie≈øties zeale for to maintaine the cau≈øe of GOD and Right of Kings; his ≈øingular dexteritie to doe it; the ble≈øsing of GOD that hath followed vpon his ≈øo doing of it; I cannot but change my opinion, and bee of another minde. And the better to induce you to bee of my minde; I will make vnto you a trew Relation of his Maie≈øties entering into this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and then leaue it to your con≈øideration; whether there were not a Diuine hand, that led his into it, or no. Jt is the Speach of our Ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour, that there is nothing hid, that ≈øhall not be knowne; and what is ≈øpoken in darkene≈ø≈øe, ≈øhall be heard in the Light: This his Maie≈øtie as him≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øeth, found trew in the comming foorth of one of his Bookes; and I thinke it may bee found as trew in the comming foorth of ≈øome other of them. For after the Pope had put forth his Breues, and the Cardinall had ≈øent his Letters to the Archprie≈øt; the one to enioyne the People not to take the Oath of Allegiance, affirming they could not take it with ≈øafety of their Saluation;
the other to reproue the Arch-priest for that hee had taken it, and to draw him to a penitencie for ≈øo foule a Lap≈øe: His Maie≈øtie like as became a Prudent and a Religious Prince, thought it not meete, that the≈øe things ≈øhould pa≈øse for current, but that it was expedient his People ≈øhould know, that the taking of this Oath was ≈øo farre from endangering their Soules, as that it intended nothing but ciuill Obedience, and without touching any point of their con≈øcience, made the State ≈øecure of their Allegiance. To performe this worke, his Maie≈øtie thought the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter that then was, a very fit man, both for his ≈øingular Learning, as for that he had long laboured in an Argument not much of a diuers nature from this: Whereupon his Maie≈øtie calling for penne and incke, to giue my L. of Winche≈øter directions, how and in what maner to proceed in this Argument, I know not how it came to pa≈ø≈øe; but it fell out trew, that the Poet ≈øaith,
‚Äî Amphora coepit
In≈øtitui, currente rota, po≈øt vrceus exit. For the Kings Penne ranne ≈øo fa≈øt, that in the compa≈øse of ≈øixe dayes, his Maie≈øtie had accompli≈øhed that, which hee now calleth his Apologie; which when my Lord of Canterburie that then was, and my Lord of Elie had peru≈øed, being indeed deliuered by his Maie≈øtie but as briefe Notes, and in the nature of a Minute to bee explicated by the Bi≈øhop in a larger ∆≤olume; yet they thought it ≈øo ≈øufficient an An≈øwere both to the Pope and Cardinall, as there needed no other: Whereupon his Maie≈øtie was per≈øwaded, to giue way to the comming of it foorth, but was plea≈øed to conceale his Name: And ≈øo haue wee the Apologie beyond his Maie≈øties owne purpo≈øe or determination.

After that the Apologie was out, his Maie≈øtie diuer≈øe times would bee plea≈øed to vtter a Re≈øolution of his; that if the Pope and Cardinall would not rest in his an≈øwere, and ≈øit downe by it; take the Oath as it was intended for a point of Allegiance and Ciuill Obedience; Hee would publi≈øh the Apologie in his owne name with a Preface to all the Princes in Chri≈øtendome;
wherein hee would publi≈øh ≈øuch a Confe≈øsion of his Faith, per≈øwade the Princes ≈øo to vindicate their owne Power, di≈øcouer ≈øo much of the My≈øterie of Jniquitie vnto them; as the Popes Bulles ≈øhould pull in their hornes, and him≈øelfe wi≈øh he had neuer medled with this matter. The Cardinall contending against the Apologie, his Maie≈øtie confirmed his Re≈øolution, and with the like Celerity, in the compa≈ø≈øe of one weeke, wrote his Monitory-Preface: for as Hirtius ≈øaid of Cae≈øars Comentaries, Qua foelicitate they were done, let others iudge; but Qua celeritate, J can tell: And being ≈øo written, publi≈øhed it and the Apologie in his owne Name; and made good his word, ≈øent it to the Emperour and all the Kings and free Princes in Chri≈øtendome.
Now hauing made this Relation, wherein J haue deliuered nothing but trewth; Let me offer vnto you ≈øome few things worthy Con≈øideration.

Fir≈øt, that vpon the comming foorth of that Booke, there were no States, that di≈øauowed the Doctrine of it in that point of the Kings power; And the Venetians mainetained it in their writings, and put it in Execution; The Sorbons maintained it likewi≈øe in France.

Secondly, their owne writers, that oppo≈øed it, ≈øo ouerla≈øhed, as they were corrected and castigated of men of their owne Religion; Becanus his Booke corrected by the Cardinalles of Rome; Bellarmines Booke burnt in Paris; Suarez his An≈øwere burnt al≈øo in France. As for the Raylers, I leaue them to God his Iudgment, who≈øe hand hath bene vpon the mo≈øt of them.

Thirdly, his Maie≈øties Confe≈øsion of faith, hath bene ≈øo generally approued, as it hath conuerted many of their partie: And had it not bene (as J haue bene informed by diuer≈øe) for the Treati≈øe of Antichri≈øt, many more would ea≈øily haue bene induced, to ≈øub≈øcribe to all in that Preface.

Fourthly, Kings and Princes haue by his Maie≈øties Premonition, had a more cleare in≈øight, and a more perfect di≈øcouery into the Iniury offered them by the Pope in the point of their temporall Power, then euer they had; Jn≈øomuch, as that point was
neuer ≈øo throughly di≈øputed in Chri≈øtendome, as it hath bene by the occa≈øion of his Maie≈øties Booke.

Fiftly and lastly, for the point of Antichri≈øt; I haue heard many confe≈ø≈øe, that they neuer ≈øaw ≈øo much light giuen to that My≈øterie, neuer de≈øcerned ≈øo much trewth by the vniforme con≈øent of the Text, and ≈øtrength of Interpretation of places, as they haue done by his Maie≈øties Booke. So that, though Controuer≈øies be fitter ≈øubiects for Schollers ordinarily, then for Kings; Yet when there was ≈øuch a nece≈øsitie in vndertaking, and ≈øuch a ≈øucce≈ø≈øe being performed; I leaue it to the world to iudge, whether there were not a ≈øpeciall hand of GOD in it, or no. Now ≈øince I haue begunne with this point of Antichri≈øt, J will make bolde to proceed a little with his Maie≈øties Paraphra≈øe vpon the Reuelation, wherein that Treati≈øe of Antichri≈øt is principally grounded.

His Maie≈øties ≈øingular vnderstanding in all points of good Learning is not vnknowne: But yet aboue all other things, GOD hath giuen him an vnderstanding Heart in the Interpretation of that Booke, beyond the mea≈øure of other men: For this Paraphra≈øe, that leades the way to all the rest of his Maie≈øties Workes, was written by his Maie≈øtie before hee was twenty yeeres of aage; and therefore iustly in this ∆≤olume hath the first place, the rest following in order according to the time of their first penning. Anciently Kings drempt dreames, and ≈øaw vi≈øions; and Prophets expounded them: So with King Pharaoh and Io≈øeph in Egypt; So with Nabuchodono≈øor and Daniel in Babylon. Jn this aage, Prophets haue written ∆≤i≈øions, and Kings haue expounded them. GOD rai≈øed vp Prophets to deliuer his People from a temporall captiuitie in Egypt and Babylon, by the Jnterpretation of the one; And GOD hath in this aage ≈øtirred vp Kings to deliuer his People from a Spirituall Egypt and Babylon, by the Interpretation of the other. It is an ob≈øeruable thing, that GOD neuer made his People any great promi≈øe, but he added vnto his promi≈øe a famous Prophecie. Three great promi≈øes we reade of, that runne through all the Scriptures.
The first of the Me≈ø≈øiah; the ≈øecond of the land of Canaan; the third of the Kingdome of Heauen: To the≈øe three promi≈øes, are reduced all the Prophecies. Of the promi≈øe of the Me≈ø≈øiah, prophecied all the Prophets from the fall of the fir≈øt Adam, to the comming of the ≈øecond: Of the promi≈øe of the Land of Canaan, prophecied Iacob and Io≈øeph, and the rest, from the promi≈øe made to Abraham, to the po≈ø≈øe≈øsing of it by Io≈øuah and the children of I≈ørael: Of the promi≈øe of the Kingdome of Heauen, made by our Sauiour CHRIST', prophecied the Apo≈øtles; principally S. Paul, and S. Iohn in the Reuelation. Now though all were to lay hold on the promi≈øes; yet few were able to vnder≈øtand the Prophecies. And ≈øurely, though all the people of GOD are to lay hold on the promi≈øes of that Glorious Kingdome de≈øcribed in that Booke; yet few are able to vnder≈øtand the Prophecies therein contained, comprehending in them a perfect Hi≈øtory and State of the Church, euen from the de≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem, till the con≈øummation of the whole world. Yet this I thinke, I may ≈øafely ≈øay; That Kings haue a kinde of interest in that Booke beyond any other: for as the execution of the mo≈øt part of the Prophecies of that Booke is committed vnto them; So it may be, that the Interpretation of it, may more happily be made by them: And ≈øince they are the principall Instruments, that GOD hath de≈øcribed in that Booke to destroy the Kingdome of Antichri≈øt, to con≈øume his State and Citie; I ≈øee not, but it may ≈øtand with the Wi≈øedome of GOD, to in≈øpire their heart to expound it; into who≈øe handes hee hath put it to excute, vntill the LORD ≈øhall con≈øume both him and it with the Spirit of his mouth, and ≈øhall aboli≈øh it with the brightne≈ø≈øe of his comming: For from the day that S. Iohn writ the Booke to this pre≈øent houre; I doe not thinke that euer any King tooke ≈øuch paines, or was ≈øo perfect in the Reuelation, as his Maie≈øtie is; which will ea≈øily appeare by this Paraphra≈øe, by his Maie≈øties Meditation on the 20. Chap. and his Monitorie Preface. Jt was my purpo≈øe to haue past through all his Maie≈øties Books; to haue expre≈ø≈øed the Argument and the occa≈øion of their writing; But I find by that J haue already
≈øaid, I ≈øhould be ouer tedious vnto you. This therefore in generall; They are all worthy of a King, and to be kept to Po≈øterity: For if Ouid could imagine, that no time ≈øhould eate out the memory of his Metamorpho≈øeis, which were but fictions; J hope no time ≈øhall ≈øee an end of the≈øe Books, that carry in them ≈øo much diuine trewth and light. And as in this first worke of the Paraphra≈øe, his Maie≈øtie hath ≈øhewed his Piety; So in this la≈øt Pearle (I meane his Maie≈øties Speach in the Starr-Chamber) his Maie≈øtie hath ≈øhewed his Policy: The fir≈øt ≈øheweth, hee vnder≈øtands the Kingdome of GOD; this la≈øt, that hee as well apprehends the State of his Kingdomes in this World: The first ≈øheweth him to haue a large Portion in that of Heauen; and this la≈øt ≈øheweth him to haue a great Power and experience in the≈øe Kingdomes hee hath on earth. Therefore, let the≈øe men, that delight ≈øo much in Detraction and to vilify him, whom GOD hath exalted; and to ≈øhed his blood, who≈øe Soule GOD hath bound vp in the Bundle of life; Let them, J ≈øay, write what euer the Subtilty of the olde Serpent can put into their heads, or the Malice of Sathan infu≈øe into their hearts; Let them ≈øpeake, what the poy≈øon of A≈øpes is able to put into their lippes; they are not all able to make his Maie≈øtie to appeare le≈ø≈øe then he is, nor to ≈øhew, that euer they had of theirs a King ≈øo accompli≈øhed. It is trew, that wee haue not had many Kings in this Kingdome of our Profe≈øsion: But for tho≈øe we haue had, this Iland of ours neuer ≈øaw the like, either for partes of Nature, giftes of Learning or Graces of Piety.
The little time of life, that God lent to King Edward, must needs le≈ø≈øen his pray≈øes; But neuer did there appeare beginnings of more rare perfection, then in him.

The length of Queene Elizabeths dayes, together with the felicity of her time, was not only a Glory to her owne People, but a wonderment to the World, euen our Aduer≈øaries, as Mo≈øes ≈øaid, being Iudges. And pray≈øed be GOD, the pre≈øent time pa≈ø≈øeth a long with the like felicity and much more Securitie: for let me recount a little, for the Glory of GOD and encouragement of his
Maie≈øtie, to goe on in his happie Cour≈øe begunne, the Ble≈øsings of GOD we receiue by him; And then let our Aduer≈øaries tell vs, whether we be a mi≈øerable People or no, as ≈øome of late haue gone about to per≈øwade vs. Neither doe J ≈øtand in feare of any mans reprehen≈øion; for J will ≈øpeake nothing but trewth, and I haue my Pre≈øident from GOD his owne Booke; wherein the good Actes of euery good King are to their eternall prai≈øes trewly recounted.

First to beginne with Religion, as the Generall to the Armie: Of all Gods Ble≈øsings wee haue it without any alteration or change contynued vnto vs. His Maie≈øties fir≈øt Care was for the Confirmation of the Go≈øpell: for at his Maie≈øties fir≈øt comming in; who knowes not the endeauours of men, to haue made a change, either to the Papi≈øts, or to the Puritanes? His Maie≈øtie therefore, to quiet the State and Peace of the Church, called a Conference at Hampton-Court; where pa≈øsing ouer the one, as being neuer in his heart to giue the lea≈øt way vnto; He ≈øo tempered the other, as the Harmony hath bene the better euer ≈øince.

The Religion thus ratified; His Maie≈øties next Care was for the Tran≈ølation of the Bible, it being the ground of our Religion: His Maie≈øtie was de≈øirous his People ≈øhould haue it in as much perfection, as the Jndu≈øtrie and Labors of the best Learned were able to afford it them.

Hauing done what was nece≈ø≈øary for the Spirituall part of the Church, his Maie≈øtie tooke into con≈øideration the Temporal State thereof: No ≈øooner came the Parliament, but finding what ≈øpoile had bene made of the Lands thereof in the tyme of his Predece≈ø≈øors, by a libertie they had to take the Landes of the Church for a longer Terme then others could doe; Cut him≈øelfe off from that libertie, and equalled him≈øelfe to a common per≈øon in the taking of any State in the Churches Landes.

When his Maie≈øtie had done this in England, he looked backe into Scotland, and reforming the State of the Church there, as farre as in his Princely-Wi≈øedome he thought conuenient for the time; re≈øtored the Bi≈øhops there, as to their Spirituall Keies;
≈øo to their temporall E≈øtates, though it were to the great lo≈ø≈øe and dammage of his owne Reuennue and Crowne.

From Scotland his Maie≈øtie came to Ireland, that forlorne Kingdome both for Temporall and Spiritual e≈øtate, till be looked into it: There his Maie≈øtie hath reduced the Bi≈øhoppricks, not only to their old Rents; but added vnto them many new Reuennues; ≈øo that many places there are an≈øwerable to the be≈øt Liuings here: Neither hath his Care bene onely on the≈øe high places of the Church, but hath de≈øcended to the lowest in the ≈øame, hauing both protected the Benefices from being ray≈øed to any higher Taxe, and hindred all cour≈øes, that might giue his Cleargie mole≈øtation or trouble.

His Maie≈øties Bountie hath not bene wanting to Colledges and Ho≈øpitalls, hauing parted with his owne Tenures, to giue them power of larger Indowments; whereby there hath bene works of more ≈øumptuou≈ønes and co≈øt done in his Maie≈øties time, then there hath bene in any one aage before.

J may not forget one thing, that ≈øince his Maie≈øties comming to this Crowne, he hath neuer put into his Coffers the meane proffitts of any Eccle≈øia≈øticall liuing, but hath bene a Fidus-Depo≈øitarius, and euer giuen them to the next Jncumbent.

Let me de≈øcend a little from the≈øe workes of Piety to Peace. Neuer hath there bene ≈øo vniuer≈øall a Peace in Chri≈øtendome ≈øince the time of our Sauiour Chri≈øt, as in the≈øe his Dayes: And I dare ≈øay, as much, if not more, by the procurement of his Maie≈øtie, then by any other earthly meanes in this world. A Peace (to let forraigne partes pa≈ø≈øe) ≈øo entertayned at home; that in his Maie≈øties three Kingdomes, apt enough by con≈øtitution, and not vnaccu≈øtomed by practi≈øe to be at variance, there hath bene no Ciuill di≈ø≈øen≈øion at all. With Peace GOD hath giuen vs Plentie: So that, if Peace and Plenty haue not made vs too too wanton, I know not what wee want. Neither is there any crying out for lacke of Iu≈øtice in our Courtes; for neuer was there Iustice admini≈øtred with more liberty from the King, nor more vprightnes from the Judges; And yet in the free di≈øpen≈øation of Iu≈øtice,
Mercie did neuer more triumph. If this bee to bee mi≈øerable, J know not what on earth they call Happine≈ø≈øe: GOD continue the≈øe ≈øtill vnto vs; and then, let them call Happine≈ø≈øe, what they plea≈øe.
But I know wherefore all is mi≈øerable; becau≈øe there is no more Mercy ≈øhewed to their Catholiks.

J will put it as a Crowne vpon all his Maie≈øties Mercies: There was neuer King, that had ≈øo great a cau≈øe giuen him, that euer tooke ≈øo little bloode, extending his Mercy to all, that were not per≈øonall workers in that Powder-Plot: And before that you had hatched that Mon≈øter, neither was the per≈øon or pur≈øe of any your reputed Catholicks touched. And ≈øince that time, you may doe well to complaine of your Mi≈øeries; but the Church and Comonwealth both, doe trauaile and groane vnder the burthen of your di≈øobedience: But the worst J wi≈øh you, is, that at length by his Maie≈øties long Patience, you may bee drawne to Repentance; for as we are come out from you, lest we ≈øhould bee partakers of your plagues; ≈øo we pray for you, that you may come in to vs, that you may be participants of our felicities.

To Conclude this Preface: GOD hath giuen vs a Solomon, and GOD aboue all things gaue Solomon Wi≈øedome; Wi≈øedome brought him peace; Peace brought him Riches; Riches gaue him Glory. His wi≈øedome appeared in his wordes and Workes: his Peace, he pre≈øerued by the power of his Army: His riches he ray≈øed, as by his Reuennue, ≈øo by the Trade of his Nauie: His Glory did accrue from them all. Now, as in the≈øe, GOD exalted him beyond all the Kings that euer were, or ≈øhould be after him; So had he in other things Humiliations not farre behind the proportion of his Exaltations; the fearefullest fall, that the Scripture affords an Example of; the most vnchast life and immoderate exce≈ø≈øe of Women, that we read of; the weakest Posterity for Wi≈øedome and Gouernment, that we finde in all the Line of his Succe≈øsion. GOD would haue it ≈øo, that he ≈øhould no more be ≈øet out, as a Type of the Glory of his owne Sonne in the felicity of his State one way, then he would haue him propo≈øed as a patterne of Humane
frailty an other way. Therefore, though we may not approach him in his Typicall State; yet GODS Name be ble≈øsed, that hath giuen vs to goe farre beyond him in his per≈øonall Condition: For we haue already, ble≈ø≈øed be GOD, ≈øeene the Con≈øtancie and per≈øeuerance of his Maie≈øty in his Holy Profe≈øsion, without any Eclip≈øe or Shaddow of change, longer then we are well able to deduce the whole life and reigne of Solomon. We haue not the Daughter of Pharao an Idolatrous King; nor feare we ≈øtrange women to ≈øteale away his heart from the Seruice of GOD: But a Queene, as of a Royall, ≈øo of a Religious Stocke, profe≈øsing the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt with him; A Mirrour of trew Modestie, a Queene of Bounty, both beloued and admired of all his People: A Po≈øterity that we need not feare for folly in the one Sexe, nor for leuitie in the other; Both which made Solomon ≈øpeake ≈øo much, (as the Iewes ≈øay) in his Prouerbes, of a fooli≈øh ≈øonne, becau≈øe his owne was not wi≈øe, and of wanton Women, becau≈øe he feared the vanity of his owne Daughters. But GOD hath left his Maie≈øtie a Sonne; a Prince, as in outward Liniaments, ≈øo in inward Abiliments, (I need ≈øay no more) an Alter-Idem, a ≈øecond-Selfe; A Daughter, a Prince≈ø≈øe of that Piety, ≈øingular vertue and Modestie; as makes her both beloued at home and admired abroad. J haue done: Only I de≈øire the Readers of the≈øe Workes, to pray to GOD, that as he hath ≈øo farre aduanced vs, as to bestowe vpon vs, with the Heauenly Trea≈øures of his trewth, the riches of his earthly Iewels in ≈øo Sacred a King, ≈øo admired a Queene, ≈øo hopefull a Prince, ≈øo vertuous a Princes; He would for his Mercies ≈øake, for his Sonnes ≈øake, continue this the Light of his Countenance vpon vs in them and their Po≈øterity, till the comming of that Kingdome, which neuer ≈øhall haue end. AMEN.

div.head: THE EPISTLE TO THE WHOLE CHVRCH MILITANT, in what≈øoeuer part of the Earth.
div.p:
TO whom could I haue ≈øo fitly directed (Christian Readers) this Paraphra≈øe of mine vpon the Reuelation, as vnto you, who are the very and true po≈øteritie of tho≈øe Churches, to whom the Booke it ≈øelfe was dedicated, and for who≈øe instruction and comfort the ≈øaid Epistle was endited by the Holy Spirit, and written by that great Theologue IOHN the Apo≈øtle, whom our Master beloued deerely? J doubt not but it will ≈øeeme ≈øtrange to many, that any of my aage, calling, and literature, ≈øhould haue medled with ≈øo ob≈øcure, Theologicall, and high a ≈øubiect: But let my earnest de≈øire (by manifesting the Trueth,) as well to teach my ≈øelfe as others, ≈øerue for excu≈øe; con≈øidering al≈øo that where diuers others in our aage, haue medled with the interpretation of this Booke, pre≈øsing with preoccupied opinions, onely to wrest and conforme the meaning thereof to their particular and priuate pa≈øsions; J by the contrary prote≈øt, that all my trauailes tend to ≈øquare and conforme my opinions to the trew and ≈øincere meaning thereof: Which cau≈øes mooued me to vndertake this worke; not thereby to de≈øpi≈øe infinite others, who to the glory
of God, and great comfort of his Church, hath giuen it a great light already, but rather that by oft peru≈øing and dew con≈øidering therof, whereto this worke hath led mee, J might be the better acquainted with the meaning of this Booke, which J e≈øteeme a ≈øpeciall cannon against the Hereticall wall of our common aduer≈øaries the Papists: whom I would wi≈øh to know, that in this my Paraphra≈øe vpon it, J haue v≈øed nothing of my owne coniecture, or of the authoritie of others, but onely haue interpreted it, in that ≈øen≈øe which may best agree with the methode of the Epistle, and not bee contradictorie to it ≈øelfe: The meaning whereof I expound, partly by it ≈øelfe, and partly by other parts of the Scriptures, as the worke it ≈øelfe will beare witne≈ø≈øe: And therefore this one thing J must craue of our Aduer≈øaries, that they will not refute any part of my Interpretation, till they finde out a more probable them≈øelues, agreeing with the whole context, & cum ≈øerie temporum; and where their con≈øciences beare them witne≈ø≈øe that J ≈øpeake the Trueth, that they will yeeld vnto it, and glorifie God therein, and this is all the reward I craue for my paines. But of one thing I must forewarne you (Chri≈øtian Readers) to wit, that yee may vnder≈øtand, that it is for the making of the Di≈øcour≈øe more ≈øhort and facile, that I haue made IOHN to be the Speaker in all this Paraphra≈øe; and not that I am ≈øo pre≈øumptuou≈øly fooli≈øh, as to haue meant thereby, that my Paraphra≈øe is the onely trew and certaine expo≈øition of this Epi≈øtle, reiecting all others: For although through ≈øpeaking in his per≈øon, I am onely bounded and limitted to v≈øe one, and not diuers interpretations, of euery ≈øeuerall place; yet I condemne not others, but rather allow them to interpret it diuer≈øly, ≈øo being, it agree with the analogie of faith, with the methode of the Text, & cum ≈øerie temporum, as I ≈øaid before: for tho≈øe three being ob≈øerued, it may fall out that diuers, diuer≈øly expound one place, and yet all be according to the trueth, and very meaning of the Spirit of God, as may ea≈øily be proued by the Text it ≈øelfe: For in the 17. Chapter the Angel expounding to Iohn, the ≈øeuen heads of the bea≈øtes that came out of the Sea, hee ≈øaith the ≈øeuen heads which thou ≈øawest vpon the beast
are the ≈øeuen Hills, and they are al≈øo ≈øeuen Kings: Here ye ≈øee one thing is expounded in two very farre different fa≈øhions, and yet both true; And therefore let wi≈øe men take their choice in the≈øe things, ob≈øeruing alwayes the≈øe rules I haue ≈øpoken of; as ≈øpecially for example; This Hebrew word Arma geddon in the 16. Chapter and ≈øixt Phiale, although I expound it to ≈øignifie de≈øtruction by deceipt, as compo≈øed of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Gnarma & Geddon which may very well agree with the Hi≈øtory, becau≈øe it is the name of the place, ≈øaith Iohn, where the wicked being a≈øsembled together by the alluring and deceipt of Satan, and his three ≈øpirits of Diuels to make warre with the faithfull, were all de≈øtroyed by God, and ≈øo their de≈øtruction came, and was procured by deceipt; Yet others interpret it to ≈øignifie de≈øtruction by waters, as compo≈øed of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Harma & Geddon, which al≈øo may very well agree with the Historie. For waters indeed in this Booke ≈øignifie oft many people and Nations, as appeareth by the very Text in the 17. Chapter; And others take it to be an allu≈øion to the destruction that Io≈øhua made of Gods enemies vpon the hill of Mageddon, and therefore to bee compo≈øed of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Harr, which is called a Hill and Mageddon, which may al≈øo very well agree with the Historie.
And as J ≈øpeake of this, ≈øo J ≈øpeake the like of Gog and Magog in the 20. Chapter, and of all other ambiguous places in this Booke.

p.hi: Jt re≈øts then that what ye finde ami≈øse in this Paraphra≈øe, yee impute it to my lacke of yeeres and learning; and what ye find worthy to be allowed in it, that yee attribute the full prai≈øe thereof to GOD, to whom onely all prai≈øe appertaineth.

div.head: THE ARGVMENT OF THIS WHOLE EPISTLE.
div.p:
THIS Booke or Epi≈øtle of Reuelation, was called in doubt, a≈øwell for the incertaintie of the Author, as al≈øo for the canonicalne≈øse of the Booke it ≈øelfe, by ≈øundry of the ancients, and ≈øpecially by Eu≈øebe; For ≈øoluing whereof I need not to in≈øist, ≈øince it is both receiued now of all Christians, and al≈øo diuers of the Neoteriques, in ≈øpeciall Beza in his Preface vpon it, hath handled that matter ≈øufficiently already; So that this doubt onely rests now in men, that this Booke is ≈øo ob≈øcure and allegorique, that it is in a maner vnprofitable to be taught or interpreted; Whereunto I will ≈øhortly make an≈øwere, and then goe forward to ≈øet downe the methode of the ≈øame: And therefore to make a deduction from the beginning, let vs vnderstand in what ≈øeuerall or principall parts the whole Scriptures may be diuided in; and then which of them this Booke is. How ≈øoone Adam being made perfect in his Creation, and hauing the choi≈øe of Life and Death, Good and Euill, did by his horrible defection make choi≈øe of Death, and cast off Life, and by that meanes infected his whole posteritie with double ≈øinne, to wit, Originall and Actuall, God notwithstanding had ≈øuch a Loue to mankinde, as being his most Noble workeman≈øhip, and Creature, made to his owne Likene≈ø≈øe and Image, that he ≈øelected a Church amongst them, whom fir≈øt becau≈øe of their weakene≈ø≈øe and incredulitie, he with his owne mouth taught, and next in≈øtructed and rai≈øed vp notable men amongst them to be their Rulers, whom he endued with ≈øuch excellent gifts, as not onely their example in life preached, but al≈øo by Miracles they ≈øtrengthened and confirmed their Faith: But le≈øt this mini≈øtrie of men ≈øhould make them to depend onely vpon their mouthes, forgetting Him, and making Gods of them, he at length out of his owne mouth gaue them his Law, which he cau≈øed them to put in Writ, and retaine ≈øtill amongst them; And then le≈øt they ≈øhould forget and neglect the ≈øame, he rai≈øed vp godly Rulers, a≈ø well Temporall, as Spirituall, who by their holy liues and working of Miracles, reuiued and ≈øtrengthened the Law in their hearts.
But ≈øeeing, that notwith≈øtanding all this, they ca≈øt them≈øelues headlong in the gulfe of vices (≈øuch is the vnthankefull and repining Nature of Man,) hee rai≈øed vp Prophets, as especially Ieremie and Daniel, to accu≈øe them of their ≈øinnes, and by Vi≈øions to forewarne them of the times to come, whereby the godly might turne and arme them≈øelues, and the wicked might be made inexcu≈øable. And thus much for the Old Te≈øtament. But then God ≈øeeing that notwith≈øtanding this, there crept in ≈øuch a generall corruption amongst them, that ≈øcarce one might be found that bowed not his knee to Baal; Hee then by his vn≈øearchable Wi≈øedome incarnated his Eternall Sonne and Word THE LORD IESVS, who by his death and Pa≈ø≈øion accompli≈øhed the faith of the Fathers; who≈øe Saluation was by the beleeuing in him to come, as al≈øo made an open and patent way of Grace to all the world thereafter: And then as vpon a new world, and a new Church, Gods Fatherly care to Mankind was renued, but in a more fauourable forme, becau≈øe hee looked vpon the Merits of his deare Sonne: Then, fir≈øt Chri≈øt with his owne mouth did in≈øtruct men, and confirmed his Doctrine by Miracles, and ≈øecondly rai≈øed vp the Apo≈øtles to giue the Law of Faith, confirming it by their liues and Miracles: And la≈øt, that notwith≈øtanding this Defection was beginning to creepe in againe, hee inspired one of them, to wit, IOHN to write this Booke, that hee might thereby, euen as Ieremie and Daniel did in the old Law, a≈øwell rebuke them of their ≈øinnes, as by forewarning them, to arme them again≈øt the great tentations that were to come after. Then of it ≈øelfe it prooues, how profitable this Booke is for this aage, ≈øeeing it is the la≈øt Reuelation of Gods will and Prophe≈øie, that euer was, or ≈øhall bee in the World: For wee ≈øhall haue no more Prophe≈øies nor Miracles hereafter, but mu≈øt content our ≈øelues with the Law and Prophecies already giuen, as Chri≈øt in his Parable of Lazarus and the rich man teacheth. Now as to the Methode, this holy Epi≈øtle is directed to the ≈øeuen Churches of A≈øia Minor, whom hee names and writes to particularly in the fir≈øt three Chapters of the ≈øame, and vnder their Names to all their trew Succe≈ø≈øors, the whole Church Militant in the World. The whole matter may bee diuided in ≈øixe parts, to wit, The prai≈øe or di≈øprai≈øe of euery one of the≈øe Churches, according to their merits wherein they merit good or euill, what way they ought to reforme them≈øelues, and this is contained in the three fir≈øt Chapters: And to make them inexcu≈øable, in ca≈øe they ≈ølide againe, hee ≈øhewes the e≈øtate of the whole Church Militant in their time; he tells them what it ≈øhall be vntill the end of the World, and what it ≈øhalbe when it is Triumphant and immortall after the di≈ø≈øolution: The≈øe three la≈øt parts are declared by Vi≈øions in the re≈øt of the Epi≈øtle, fir≈øt the pre≈øent e≈øtate of the Church then, and what it ≈øhould be thereafter vnto the later day, is ≈øummarily declared by the fir≈øt ≈øixe of the ≈øeuen Seales: in the ≈øixt and ≈øeuenth Chapters, and afterwards more at large by the ≈øeuen Trumpets that came out of the ≈øeuenth Seale in the 8. 9. 10. 11. Chapters: And becau≈øe through Tirannie and abu≈øe of the Popedome, Poperie is the greate≈øt temptation ≈øince Chri≈øtes fir≈øt comming, or that ≈øhalbe vnto his last; therefore he ≈øpecially in≈øi≈øts more at large and cleerly, in the declaration and painting forth of the ≈øame, by Vi≈øion of the woman in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, and of the Bea≈øts that ro≈øe out of the ≈øea and the earth in the 12. 13. and 14. Chapters: And then to comfort men that might otherwi≈øe de≈øpaire, Chap. 15.16. becau≈øe of the
greatne≈ø≈øe of that temptation, he declares by the next following Vi≈øion of the Phials, what plagues ≈øhall light vpon the Pope and his followers: Next, he de≈øcribes him againe, Chap. 17.18.19. Chap. 20. farre clearer then any time before, and likewi≈øe his ruine, together with the ≈øorrow of the Earth, and ioy of Heauen therefore: And then to inculcate and ingraue the better the fore≈øaid Vi≈øions in the hearts and memories of Men, hee in a Vi≈øion makes a ≈øhort ≈øumme and recapitulation of them, to wit, of the pre≈øent estate of the Church then, and what it ≈øhould bee thereafter, vnto the Day of Iudgement, together with a ≈øhort de≈øcription of the ≈øaid Day: And la≈øt he de≈øcribes by a Vi≈øion, the glorious reward of them, who con≈øtantly per≈øi≈øt in the Trueth, re≈øisting all the temptations which he hath forespoken, To wit, he de≈øcribes the ble≈ø≈øed e≈øtate of the holy and Eternall Ieru≈øalem, and Church Triumphant, and ≈øo with a ≈øhort and pithie Conclu≈øion makes an end.

div.head: A PARAPHRASE VPON THE REVELATION OF THE APOSTLE S. IOHN.
CHAP. I.

p.hi: The Booke, the Writer, and the Inditer; the end and v≈øe thereof: The dedication of this Epistle to the Churches and Pastors, vnder the vi≈øion of the ≈øeuen Candlesticks and ≈øeuen Starres.

div.p:
GOD THE FATHER hath directed his Sonne and Word, IESVS CHRIST, to ≈øend downe an Angel or Mini≈øter, to me Iohn his ≈øeruant, and by him to reueale vnto mee certaine things which are ≈øhortly to come to pa≈ø≈øe, to the effect in time the cho≈øen may be forewarned by me; 2 Who haue borne witnes that the word of God is true, and that IESVS CHRIST is, and was a faithfull witne≈ø≈øe, and haue made true report of all I ≈øaw. 3 Happy are they that read and vnder≈øtand this Prophe≈øie, and conforme them≈øelues thereunto in time, for in very ≈øhort ≈øpace it will be fulfilled: 4 I am directed to declare the ≈øame, ≈øpecially to you the ≈øeuen Churches of A≈øia, with whom be grace and peace from the Eternall, the Father, and from the Holy Spirit: 5 And IESVS CHRIST, that faithfull witne≈ø≈øe, the fir≈øt borne of the dead, the Mightie King of the world, and head of his Church; Who for the loue he bare vs, hath made vs innocent by his blood in the worke of Redemption: 6 To him then we, whom hee hath made Spiritual Kings and Prie≈øts, in Honour and Holine≈ø≈øe, and ordained to ≈øerue and prai≈øe his Father, giue all glory and power for euer: ≈øo be it. 7 A≈ø≈øure your ≈øelues of his comming againe from Heauen in all glory, and all eyes ≈øhall ≈øee him; Yea the wicked ≈øhalbe compelled to acknowledge that it is euen very he, whom

So be it. 8 I am Eternall, ≈øaith the Lord, before whom, all things (which is or was) are pre≈øent, and I am only the worker of all, I who euer Was, and ≈øtill am, ≈øhall ≈øurely come againe according to my promi≈øe: 1. Cor. 2. And as I am Eternall and true, ≈øo I am Almighty, preordinating all things before all beginnings. 9 I Iohn, your brother in the fle≈øh, Iohn bani≈øhed to Pathmos for the trueth, writeth the Reuelation. and companion with you, a≈øwell in the ≈øeruice of Chri≈øt, as in the patient ≈øuffering of the Cro≈ø≈øe, being for that word of God and witne≈ø≈øing of Chri≈øt, whereof I ≈øpake, ≈øo per≈øecuted, that for ≈øafety of my life I was con≈øtrained to flie all alone to the ≈øolitarie Ile of Pathmos. 10 Then was I bereft in ≈øpirit vpon the Sunday, which is hallowed to the Lord: Then heard I behind me, turne about and take heed, the mighty voyce of the Lord as a Trumpet, becau≈øe he was to declare the e≈øtate of the battell of the Church Militant vnto me; 11 Saying the≈øe wordes, I am A and Œ©, to wit, the fir≈øt and the last, write thou in a Booke what thou ≈øee≈øt, and ≈øend it to the Seuen Churches in A≈øia, the names of which are the≈øe, Ephe≈øus, Smyrna, Pergamos, Thyatyra, Sardis, Philadelphia, and Laodicea: 12 And when I turned mee to ≈øee the voyce, Ver≈ø. 10. WRite then this to the Angel, or Pa≈øtour of the Church of Ephe≈øus: He that hath the ≈øeuen Starres, Chap. 1. v. 10. or ≈øeuen Pa≈øtours in his Right hand, or fauourable power, or protection, and who walkes among the ≈øeuen Golden Candlesticks, or watches ouer the ≈øeuen Churches, euen hee, I ≈øay, Chap. 1. ≈øayes thus vnto thee: 2 I know thy workes, thy trauaile and patience, & that thou ≈øuffre≈øt not the wicked to walke with thee, but ha≈øt learned them out, Fal≈øe apo≈øtles in the Church of Ephe≈øus. that call them≈øelues Apo≈øtles in the Church of Ephe≈øus, and are not, and ha≈øt tried them to be lyers: 3 Thou art al≈øo loaded with a great burden, and yet willingly ≈øu≈øtaine≈øt it, and for the loue of my Name ha≈øt thou trauailed much, and yet wearie≈øt not: 4 But in this I mu≈øt finde fault with thee, that thy former charitie is waxed cold: De≈øtruction to the Church of Ephe≈øus, except they repent. witne≈ø≈øe, was ≈ølaine among you, where Satan, to wit, many wicked remaine: 14 Yet haue I ≈øome few things to lay to your charge, to wit, That yee permit them to remaine among≈øt you, who retaine the doctrine of Balaam, 1. Cor. 10.14. who per≈øwade men to eate of things immolate to Idoles, and to commit fornication, and filthine≈ø≈øe in the fle≈øh: For the very ≈øame did Ba laam to Balac, to cau≈øe the I≈øraelites ≈øtumble. 15 Thou offende≈øt al≈øo in ≈øuffering ≈øome to be among≈øt you, who retaine the doctrine of the Nicolaitans which I hate. 16 Repent therefore in time, otherwi≈øe I will come again≈øt thee ≈øoone, and I will fight and ouercome them who are among≈øt you, with the ≈øword of my mouth, to wit, by the force of my word. 17 He that hath an eare, let him heare what the Spirit ≈øaith to the Churches: And to the Victour ≈øhall I giue to eate of that ≈øecret and hidden Manna, to wit, of Me the ≈øpirituall food of the faithfull, of whom that Manna which was hid in the Arke was a figure: And I will al≈øo giue him a White ≈øtone, or a Marke of his election and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe through imputation, and in it a New name written, to wit, his name ≈øhall be written vp in the Booke of life, which no man knoweth but he who receiues it; for no other may know the certaintie of ones Election, but onely he who is elected. 18 And to the Angel or Pa≈øtour of the Church of Thyatire, write, This ≈øaith the Sonne of God, who≈øe eyes are like flames of fire, and who≈øe feet are like to gli≈øtering bra≈ø≈øe: 19 I know thy workes, thy charitie, thy almes, and carefull helping of the weake, thy faith, thy patience, and ≈øhortly all thy workes; but in ≈øpeciall I prai≈øe thy great con≈øtancie and firme continuance, euen ≈øo, as thy la≈øt workes are better then the fir≈øt: 20 Yet ≈øome few things haue I to lay to thy charge, to wit, that thou ≈øuffere≈øt a woman, like to Iezebel in wickedne≈ø≈øe and Idolatrie, who calls her ≈øelfe a Prophete≈ø≈øe, to teach and ≈øeduce my ≈øeruants, to commit fornication and filthine≈ø≈øe of the fle≈øh, and to eate of things immolate vnto Idols: 21 Yet gaue I her a time to repent from her filthine≈ø≈øe, but ≈øhe would not. 22 Therefore loe I ≈øhall ca≈øt her into a bed, to wit, I ≈øhall de≈øtroy her in the puddle of her ≈øinnes, and I ≈øhall trouble with great affliction all them who commit adulterie, to wit, ≈øpirituall adulterie with her, if they repent not of their euill workes in time. 23 And I will kill and de≈øtroy her ≈øonnes, to wit, all the followers of her doctrine, that all the Churches and faithfull may know me to be the ≈øearcher out of the ≈øecrets of all hearts, and the iu≈øt renderer and recompencer of euery man according to his workes. 24 But I ≈øay vnto the re≈øt of you who are at Thyatire, who haue not receiued that fal≈øe doctrine, nor know not the depth nor ≈øecrets of Satan or wickedne≈ø≈øe, whereof the other fal≈øely did purge them≈øelues, I will not lay any other burthen vpon you, then that which already con≈øtantly yee beare: 25 But that which yee haue, holde it out valiantly vntill my comming againe. 26 For vnto him who is victour, and beares out to the end that burthen which I lay vpon him, I will giue power ouer Nations, to wit, hee ≈øhall triumph ouer the world: 27 And he ≈øhall rule them with an yron rod, and they ≈øhall be broken
like ve≈ø≈øels of earth, according as I haue receiued the power from my Father: 28 And I ≈øhall giue vnto him the Morning starre; for as the morning ≈øtarre ≈øhines brighter then the re≈øt, ≈øo ≈øhall he ≈øhine brighter in glory then his fellowes. 29 He that hath an eare, let him heare what the Spirit ≈øayth to the Churches.

div.head: CHAP. III.

p.hi: Admonition and exhortation to the Churches of Sardis, Philadelphia, and Laodicea.

div.p:
ANd to the Angel or Pa≈øtour of the Church of Sardis write thou, Thus ≈øayth he who hath the ≈øeuen Spirits of God, Sardis. to wit, hee with whom the holy Spirit is vn≈øeparably ioyned, and who hath the be≈øtowing of all the graces of Gods Spirit on the Elect, and hath the ≈øeuen Starres, to wit, who is the head of you the ≈øeuen Pa≈øtours, I know thy workes, for ye ≈øay ye liue, and yet are dead, for your faith is fruitle≈ø≈øe. 2 Be watchfull then, and ≈øleepe no longer in negligence and carele≈ø≈øe ≈øecuritie, but ≈øtrengthen againe that which is dying in you, to wit, reuiue your zeale and feruencie which is waxed cold, and almo≈øt quenched; for ≈øurely I haue not found your works ≈øo holy, and pure, as they are able to abide a triall before the face of God. 3 Remember then what thou ha≈øt once receiued & heard, that thou mai≈øt ob≈øerue the ≈øame and repent; but if thou watch not as I haue ≈øaid, I will come as a thiefe, for the day of triall ≈øhall come when ye looke lea≈øt for it, if ye be not alwayes, and at all times prepared: 4 Yet haue yee ≈øome few heads and notable per≈øons in Sardis, who haue not defiled their garments, to wit, corrupted their workes as the re≈øt haue done, and therefore they ≈øhall goe with me being made white, to wit, being made innocent by my merit, for they are worthy thereof: 5 And the Victour ≈øhall be clothed with a white garment of innocencie by imputation, neither ≈øhall I wipe his name out of the Booke of life, but ≈øhall auow him to be one of mine before my Father and his Angels. 6 He that hath an eare, let him heare what the Spirit ≈øayth to the Churches: 7 But to the Angelor Pa≈øtour of the Church of Philadelphia write thou, This ≈øayth hee who is onely holy and trew, Philadelphia. and who hath the key of Dauid, who openeth and no man ≈øhutteth, who ≈øhuts and no man openeth, as ≈øayes E≈øay; Chap. 22. for as Dauid was both King and Prophet, and was the figure of me, ≈øo I, as the veritie and end of that figure, am onely he, who hath the keyes of ab≈øolute condemning, or ab≈øoluting ≈øpiritually and eternally. 8 I know thy workes, and loe, I haue ≈øet an open doore before thee, to wit, I haue made the way of grace patent vnto thee, which doore no man can ≈øhut, becau≈øe I haue re≈øerued the ≈øecret power of election and reprobation onely to my ≈øelfe; and this fauour will I ≈øhew you, becau≈øe
yee retaine ≈øome good and vertuous things among≈øt you, and ha≈øt kept my Word, and ha≈øt not beene a≈øhamed of my Name, nor denyed the ≈øame; 9 Loe therefore I will make ≈øubiect vnto thee, the≈øe who are the Synagogue of Satan, to wit, tho≈øe who call them≈øelues Iewes, and are not, but lye: I ≈øhall make them (I ≈øay) come and adore before your feete, and they ≈øhall be compelled to know that I haue loued thee: 10 And this ≈øhall I do vnto thee, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt faithfully retained the tidings of my troubles and ≈øufferings, and therefore ≈øhal I deliuer thee al≈øo to trie the indwellers of the Earth. 11 Loe, I come ≈øhortly, therefore retaine ≈øurely to the end, that good which is in thee, le≈øt another doe receiue thy Crowne and reward: 12 For I will make the Victor a pillar in the Temple of my God, to wit, a ≈øpeciall and ≈øtedfa≈øt in≈øtrument in the Church, out of the which he ≈øhall neuer againe be ca≈øt foorth: for hee who once is elected, is neuer ca≈øt off; and I ≈øhall write on him, the Name of God, to wit, he ≈øhal beare the Marke and Seale of an Elect, and the name of the Citie of my God, which is new Ieru≈øalem, to wit, the holy and ble≈ø≈øed number of Saints and Angels which commeth downe from heauen from my God, to wit, is ≈øhortly and certeinly to come downe, by the generall compeiring at the latter day: And I ≈øhall al≈øo write on him mine owne Name, for I ≈øhall apply my generall redemption of mankinde to him, in ≈øpeciall, and ≈øo I ≈øhall write my new Name vpon him, to wit, of Redeemer and Sauiour, which name I haue lately acquired through my pa≈ø≈øion, death, and ri≈øing againe. 13 Hee that hath an eare, let him heare what the Spirit ≈øayth vnto the Churches. 14 And to the Angel or Pa≈øtour of the Church of Laodicea, Laodicea. write thou, Thus ≈øayth the Amen, to wit, he that is wholly and perfect holy, and true in all his promi≈øes, that ≈øaithfull Witne≈ø≈øe, who is the beginning of the workeman≈øhip of God, as well becau≈øe hee is that Word which did create all, and ≈øo is their beginning, for that they all receiued their beginning and being from him, as becau≈øe the vniting of the Manhood with the Godhead in his per≈øon is the mo≈øt excellent, and ≈øo the beginning, that is, the chiefe, or fir≈øt in preeminence of all the workes of God. 15 I know thy workes, ≈øayth hee, to wit, that thou art neither hote nor colde, would to God thou wert either hote or cold, to wit, either feruent and pure in the trueth, or altogether cold and ignorant, that is, ≈øeeing and confe≈ø≈øing thine ignorance and ≈ølackne≈ø≈øe, that thou mighte≈øt be in≈øtructed in the ≈øame: Iudgement again≈øt Laodicea. 16 But thou art lukewarme, and neither hote nor cold, and ≈øo inexcu≈øable; and therefore as lukewarme liquor prouokes vomit, ≈øo will I ≈øpew thee out of my mouth: 17 For thou ≈øaye≈øt and thinke≈øt thy ≈øelfe to be wealthy, and greatly enriched, and lacke nothing; but thou knowe≈øt not thy ≈øelfe to be ≈øpiritually in mi≈øerie and wretchedne≈ø≈øe, poore, blinde, and naked of the grace and fauour of God: 18 I would wi≈øh thee to buy of me gold purged by the fire, that thou may≈øt thereby be made truely rich; I meane, I would wi≈øh thee to conquer by true repentance and earne≈øt prayer, the Word and trueth of God; (which becau≈øe it can receiue no filth or ≈øpot, and is able to abide the triall, Dauid
properly in his P≈øalmes compares to golde purged by the fire) which will make thee rich in all ≈øpirituall graces: I would al≈øo wi≈øh thee to clothe thy ≈øelfe with a white garment, to wit, with innocencie and righteou≈ønes, that the ≈øhame of thy nakedne≈ø≈øe and vncleanne≈ø≈øe appeare not, and to anoint thine eyes with an eye-≈øalue, that thou may≈øt cleerly ≈øee from whence thou ha≈øt fallen: 19 But de≈øpaire thou not for the≈øe my ≈øharpe words, for tho≈øe whom I loue, I reprooue and fatherly cha≈øten: Take vp therefore againe zealou≈øly the right way to ≈øaluation, and repent thee earne≈øtly of thy former iniquities. 20 Loe I ≈øtand at the doore, and knocke; for I offer my ≈øelfe vnto you by my Amba≈ø≈øadours, and my word in their mouth, who≈øoeuer heareth my voice and openeth the doore, to wit, who≈øoeuer heareth my voice, and yeeldeth thereunto due obedience, to him will I come in, to wit, my holy Spirit ≈øhall enter into him, and I will ≈øup and be familiar with him, as he ≈øhall doe with me, and reuerence me with loue: 21 And I will make the Victour to ≈øit with me in my Throne, to wit, he ≈øhalbe partaker of my Glory, euen as I ≈øit with my Father in his Throne, and am in my manhood, in which I ouercame, exalted to ≈øit in glory at his right hand, equall in power, eternitie and glory with him. 22 Hee that hath an eare, let him heare what the Spirit ≈øayth to the Churches.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.

p.hi: The raui≈øhing of the Writer: The de≈øcription of the Maiestie of God in Heauen, compa≈ø≈øed about with Angels and Saints, vnder the figure of Saints and Elders.

div.p:
ANd when this ≈øpeech of IESVS was ended, I looked vp, Ezech. 1. and loe, I did ≈øee a doore opened in Heauen, to the effect that I might ≈øee and heare therein, the figuratiue repre≈øenting of tho≈øe things that were to come after: And that fir≈øt voice which ≈øpake vnto me before, lowd as a trumpet, and was the voice of IESVS CHRIST, ≈øpake vnto mee, and ≈øaid, Mount vp thither, for I am to ≈øhew thee tho≈øe things that are to be done hereafter. 2 Then was I immediatly bereft in ≈øpirit; for the eyes of my earthly and gro≈ø≈øe body, could not haue ≈øeene and comprehended tho≈øe heauenly and ≈øpirituall my≈øteries: And loe, I did ≈øee a Throne ≈øet in heauen, and did ≈øee one ≈øit thereon, to wit, GOD the Father in all Glory and Maie≈øtie: 3 And he that ≈øate thereon, was like in colour to the Ia≈øper and Sardine ≈øtones; greene as the Ia≈øper, to repre≈øent his euerla≈øting flouri≈øhing without decay; and fiery redde as the Sardine, to ≈øignifie his great brightne≈ø≈øe and con≈øuming power, who is the trier and ≈øeparater of the Elect from the reprobate: and the Rainebow, coloured like the Emerauld, did compa≈ø≈øe him round about, to te≈øtifie thereby, that as after the deluge
hee made the Rainebow a Sacrament of the promi≈øes made to Noah, ≈øo this Rainebow which now I did ≈øee compa≈ø≈øing his Throne, ≈øhould ≈øerue for a ≈øure Sacrament, that hee will neuer ≈øuffer his Elect to peri≈øh, but will alwayes, and at all times be compa≈ø≈øed, with a great care and watchfulnes ouer them: Greene it was as the Emerauld, to ≈øignifie the continuance without cea≈øing of his care; as the Emerauld comforteth the ≈øight, ≈øo is this Sacrament an vn≈øpeakeable comfort vnto the Elect in their trouble≈øome dayes. 4 And about his Throne were foure and twentie other ≈øeats, and I ≈øaw foure and twentie Elders or Eccle≈øia≈øticall Rulers ≈øitting thereupon, clothed with white garments, and hauing Crownes of Golde vpon their heads: The≈øe are the twelue Patriarkes, and then the twelue Apo≈øtles, [who for that they haue beene the ≈øpeciall teachers both of the olde and new Law, to the ≈øaluation, a≈øwell of Iewes as of Gentiles, are ≈øet in ≈øeates about his Throne for glory, and clothed with white garments for their innocencie and brightne≈ø≈øe] and crowned with crownes of golde in token of their victory ouer Satan and the fle≈øh, and of their glorious reward therefore. 5 And from his Throne went foorth thunder, lightening, and terrible voices, to repre≈øent the great ≈øeueritie and terriblenes of his Iudgements, denounced by the olde Law, and executed on the wicked: And there were ≈øeuen lampes of burning fire before his Throne, which is the infinite, mightie, and flaming bright holy Spirit, re≈øembling the loue and light of the new Law of the Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt. 6 And there was a ≈øea of gla≈ø≈øe like vnto Chri≈øtall before his Throne, for that as in a gla≈ø≈øe he cleerely ≈øees euen all the ≈øecrete≈øt actions and cogitations of all in the world, de≈øcribed here by the Sea, which is euer before his face; for nothing can be hid from his pre≈øence and pre≈øcience: And though in lu≈øtre and glaunce the world be like the liuely fountaines of waters, which are the faithfull, daily ≈øpringing and flowing with good workes by fruitfull faith, yet is it indeede without motion or liquor, dead and like gla≈ø≈øe, when≈øoeuer the Lord IEHOVAH doeth thunder his Iudgements vpon it: And in the midde≈øt of the Throne, and about the ≈øame, were foure bea≈øts; their foure hinder parts were in the mid≈øt of it, their ≈øhoulders bearing it vp, and their head and wings without and about the ≈øame; and the≈øe bea≈øts were full of eyes behind and before: The≈øe are the holy Cherubims, the highe≈øt degree of Angels, Ezech. 10.12. foure in number, as well becau≈øe of their foure qualities to execute his will, (as yee ≈øhall heare hereafter) as for that the Lord directs them when it plea≈øeth him, to all the foure corners of the world, and are as it were his foure windes to blow, that is, to execute either fauour or Iu≈øtice, in what≈øoeuer place he appointeth them; they are about his Throne, and as it were ≈øu≈øtaine the ≈øame; te≈øtifying thereby, that they are mo≈øt excellent of all others, & per
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the pillars or foot≈øtooles of his glory: Their number of eyes before and behind, ≈øignifie their certaine knowledge of things pa≈øt, as to come, committed to their charge, together with their continuall vigilancie to execute GODS commandements:
7 And the fir≈øt bea≈øt was like a Lion, the ≈øecond like a Calfe, the third was faced like a man, and the fourth was like a flying Eagle; hereby repre≈øenting their excellent qualities in the execution of the Lords decrees, to wit, great power, courage, patience, and ≈øtrength to trauell, how oft and how much they ≈øhould be commanded; great wi≈øedome and a wonderfull ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe in the execution thereof. 8 And euery one of the≈øe bea≈øts had ≈øixe wings in circuit, (The≈øe are the ≈øixe wings E≈øay ≈øpeaketh of:) E≈øay 6.8. two at their armes, to ≈øignifie their great celeritie in accompli≈øhing Gods commandements; two to couer their faces with, to te≈øtifie that the glory of God is ≈øo bright, and his Maie≈øtie ≈øo great, as the very Angels, his mo≈øt excellent creatures, are not able to behold the ≈øame; and two at their feete, as well to wipe the filth of the earth off them, after they haue beene here below, (teaching vs thereby, that although they be oft in the world, by the direction of their Creatour, yet cannot the world infect them with her ≈øinnefulne≈ø≈øe and corruptions) as al≈øo to let vs know, that they are ≈øo farre in glory aboue all men liuing in the earth, as it is impo≈ø≈øible to vs with corporall eyes, to behold the lea≈øt part of their glorious brightne≈ø≈øe without a vaile, euen as it is to them to behold the glory of the Almightie: And within they were all full of eyes, to repre≈øent their ince≈ø≈øant looking on God, which commeth from that inward and ine≈øtimable loue they beare vnto him; which al≈øo they expre≈ø≈øed in their continuall ≈øinging of the≈øe wordes, Holy, Holy, Holy, is that threefold Lord God Almightie, who euer was, now is, and ≈øhall come againe, repleni≈øhed with all fulne≈ø≈øe of glory and power: 9 And when the≈øe Bea≈øts were giuing all glory, honour, and thankes to him that ≈øate on the Throne, to him (I ≈øay) who liues eternally; 10 The foure and twentie Elders, as next in ranke, fell downe vpon their faces before him that ≈øate on the Throne, and adored Him who liues for euer, and ca≈øt downe their Crownes of golde at his feete, in token that they receiued them onely of him, ≈øaying, 11 Thou art onely worthy, O Lord, to be accounted glorious, honourable, and powerfull, for that thou hast created all things, and for thy will and plea≈øure haue they had their being, and were created. This glance did I ≈øee of the glory that is in heauen, at the receiuing of my Commi≈ø≈øion, contained in the following Vi≈øions which I did ≈øee of the things pre≈øent and to come, in the generall Church militant.

div.head: CHAP. V.

p.hi: The de≈øcription of the Booke, wherein was conteined all the Misteries which were reuealed to this Writer: Christs opening of them vnder the figure of a Lion, and of a Lambe: The prai≈øes giuen him by the Saints and Angels therefore, who offer without any Interce≈ø≈øour, euery one his owne thanke≈øgiuing, and prai≈øes to the Mediatour.

div.p:
