THen fir≈øt I did ≈øee in the Right hand of him that ≈øate on the Throne, Dan. 12.4. a Booke, the Booke wherein the≈øe my≈øteries are contained; E≈øay 24 11. and all the Booke was written vpon, a≈øwell on the backe as within; on the backe was written the≈øe Vi≈øions that I did ≈øee, Ezek. 2.10. and am pre≈øently to declare vnto you; within was written the plaine expo≈øition, and the very proper names of all things which the≈øe Vi≈øions did repre≈øent, which are inclo≈øed there, to ≈øignifie that the Lord hath not permitted me to manife≈øt the ≈øame to the world, for the time thereof is not come yet; which Booke was ≈øealed with ≈øeuen Seales, a≈øwell to keepe euery part thereof vnreuealed to any, as al≈øo to giue the greater certaintie, that the≈øe things ≈øhall come to pa≈ø≈øe, which are prophe≈øied therein. 2 And I ≈øaw a ≈øtrong Angel proclayming with a loud voice, Who is worthy to open this Booke, and to loo≈øe the Seales thereof? 3 But there could none be found worthy to doe it, neither in heauen nor in earth, nor beneath the earth, no not to looke on it, much le≈ø≈øe to open it: for neither Angel nor deuil either knows or dare meddle with the high my≈øteries of God, and things future, except ≈øo farre as plea≈øeth him to commit and reueale vnto them: 4 Then wept I very ≈øore that none could be found worthy to open and read that Booke, no not to looke vpon the ≈øame: for I was very ≈øorrowfull that I could not haue it reuealed vnto me: 5 At la≈øt one of the Elders ≈øaid vnto mee, Weepe not, Loe the Lion of the Tribe of Iuda hath preuailed, to wit, he who is come of Iuda, and hath admirable force in his fle≈øh, deriued from the Tribe of Iuda, by which he ouercame Sinne, Death, and Hell, and is the roote of Dauid, (for Dauid was his figure and fore-beer in the fle≈øh) is worthy and onely worthy to open the Booke, and loo≈øe the Seales thereof. 6 And then I tooke heed, and behold, I did ≈øee in the midde≈øt of the Throne, and the foure bea≈øts, a ≈øecond per≈øon of the Trinitie ≈øitting with God, and in the midde≈øt of the Elders, as a man and our brother, a Lambe ≈øtanding like as hee had bene ≈ølaine, to ≈øignifie that once indeed hee was ≈ølaine, but had ri≈øen againe, and had ≈øeuen Hornes and ≈øeuen Eyes, repre≈øenting the innumerable times, mighty and holy Spirit of God, which after his Re≈øurrection he ≈øent out through the whole earth to direct, in≈øtruct, and rule the ≈øame by his prouidence and power: 7 This Lambe then came and tooke the Booke out of the Right hand of him that did ≈øit on the Throne: 8 And ≈øo ≈øoone as he had taken the Booke in his hand, the≈øe foure bea≈øts, and the≈øe foure and
twentie Elders fell vpon their faces before the Lambe, and adored him, and euery one of them had in his hand Harpes, and golden Phials, full of ≈øweet odours; the≈øe are the prayers of the Saints, which the foure bea≈øts, comprehending all the degrees of Angels, and the foure and twentie Elders comprehending the whole Church, as well Militant as Triumphant, perceiuing that CHRIST is to reueale all the tentations which are to fall vpon the earth and Church, before the latter dayes; doe powre forth, a≈øwel on the Church triumphants part, thanke≈øgiuing, that by the reuealing or opening of the Booke, he armeth the Militant Church to re≈øi≈øt all the tentations contained therein, as al≈øo on the Church Militants part, to pray him to ha≈øten the end and di≈ø≈øolution; for the ha≈øtening whereof all creatures ≈øigh and grone to their Creator. Euery one of the≈øe bea≈øts and Elders, pre≈øents their owne praiers vnto him who ≈øits on the Throne, to teach vs, as he is Mediatour, and therefore our prayers mu≈øt be offered vnto him onely, that ≈øo there is no Interce≈ø≈øour betweene him and vs, but euery one of vs mu≈øt pre≈øent our owne prayers before him, after the example of the bea≈øts and Elders: The≈øe prayers were inclo≈øed in harpes, to ≈øignifie the ≈øweet and plea≈øing ≈øound, that faithfull prayers make in the eares of God; they were inclo≈øed in golden Phials, to teach vs that acceptable prayers mu≈øt come from an vndefiled heart, and pure as gold; and they them≈øelues are called incen≈øe, becau≈øe their ≈ømell is plea≈øant and ≈øweet like incen≈øe in the no≈øtrils of God. Exod. 30.7. This did the incen≈øe at the ≈øacrifice in the old Law ≈øignifie and figurate; and of this incen≈øe ≈øpeakes Dauid in his P≈øalmes. P≈øal. 141.2. 9 And they, to wit the foure and twenty Elders did ≈øing a new Canticle, for the matter of their Canticle, to wit, the accompli≈øhment of the My≈øterie of redemption is new, P≈øal. 144. and euer ought to be new and fre≈øh in the hearts of all them that would be accompted thankefull: Their ≈øong then was this; Thou art worthy, O Lord, to receiue the Booke, and open the Seales thereof, for thou ha≈øt bene ≈ølaine, though innocent; and by thy precious Blood ha≈øt redeemed vs to God thy Father, and ha≈øt cho≈øen vs out of all Tribes, tongues, people and nations, a≈øwell Iewes as Gentiles: 10 And thou ha≈øt made vs Kings and Prie≈øts ≈øpiritually to our God: And we ≈øhall reigne ouer the earth at the la≈øt and generall Iudgement, and as Kings, ≈øhall be participant of the glory of the holy and new Citie Ieru≈øalem. 11 Then I beheld and heard round about the Throne, the bea≈øts, and the Elders, the voyces of many Angels, to the number of many thou≈øand thou≈øands, Dan. 7.10. to wit, innumerable Legions of them, 12 Who ≈øaid all with a loud voice, The Lambe who was ≈ølaine, is worthy to haue all power, riches, wi≈øedome ≈øtrength, honour, glory and ble≈ø≈øing for euer. 13 I al≈øo heard all creatures in Heauen, in earth, and beneath the earth, and in the ≈øeas, euen all that are in them, I heard ≈øaying in one voyce vnto him that ≈øits vpon the Throne, and vnto the Lambe be Ble≈øsing, Glory, Honour and Power for euer, and euer. And the foure bea≈øtes ≈øaid, Amen, and the foure and twenty Elders fell on their faces, and adored him that liues for euer, and euer.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

p.hi: The opening of the fir≈øt ≈øixe Seales: The ≈øpreading of the Euangel, ≈øignified by the white hor≈øe, in the first ≈øeale: The great Per≈øecution by the red hor≈øe, in the ≈øecond: The number of diuers here≈øies by the blacke, in the third: The Popedome and Tyrannie thereof by the pale, in the fourth: The complaint of the Saints, and their deliuerance promi≈øed: Their ble≈ø≈øed e≈øtate in the meane time, in the fift: The day of Iudgement, and the terriblene≈øse thereof, in the ≈øixt.

div.p:
AFter this I looked to ≈øee when the Lambe opened the first Seale, and loe, I heard one of the foure bea≈øts, for they were appointed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt me in the time of the≈øe Vi≈øions, as the mo≈øt excellent creatures of God; and his voice was like a thunder, making me awake, with terrour to take heede to the≈øe great and terrible Prophe≈øies, which God was to declare vnto me, and hee ≈øaid, Come and ≈øee. 2 Then I looked and did ≈øee a white hor≈øe, and he that ≈øate on him had a bow in his hand, Zach. 1.8. Zach. 6.2, 3. and a Crowne giuen vnto him, and hee came foorth a Victour to winne and ouercome: This man comming on the white hor≈øe, was the comming and incarnation of our Bright and Innocent Sauiour, armed with a bow; for euer ≈øince his comming till now, and a ≈øpace hereafter, the dart and arrow of God, to wit, the holy Spirit by the preaching of the Go≈øpel doeth ≈øubdue, and bring the world vnder his ≈øubiection, and taketh vengeance of his enemies: His crowne is giuen to him by his Father, in token of his victory ouer the ≈øecond death, and as King of the Catholike Church to crowne the faithfull, Conuer≈øion of the Gentiles. and ≈øo he commeth foorth a Victour ouer Satan, and to ouercome by once, conuerting a great part of the world to the trew knowledge of God: This my≈øterie is already begunne, but is not yet accompli≈øhed. 3 And when he opened the ≈øecond Seale, 4 Loe, there came forth a red hor≈øe, and there was power giuen to him that ≈øate on him, to take away peace from the earth, that euery one might ≈ølay one another; and there was giuen him for that purpo≈øe a great ≈øword; for with the ≈øpreading of the Euangel and rooting of the trueth in the hearts of the nations, Per≈øecution of the body by the Ciuill ≈øword, in the ≈øecond Seale. Continuation of trew pa≈øtors after the Martyres. ≈øhall a bloody per≈øecution of Tyrants by the ciuil ≈øword, be ioyned; which is meant by the rider on the red hor≈øe: but notwith≈øtanding the Euangel ≈øhall ≈øpread and flouri≈øh, for ≈øuch is the power of God, re≈øi≈øting the pride of man, that vnder the Cro≈ø≈øe, the puritie of the trueth mo≈øt flouri≈øheth in the Church. 5 And when he opened the third Seale, the third Bea≈øt ≈øaid vnto me, Come and ≈øee: and loe, I did ≈øee a blacke hor≈øe, and hee that ≈øate vpon him had balances in his hand: 6 And I heard a voice from among the foure Bea≈øts, ≈øaying, A mea≈øure of Wheat for one peny, and three mea≈øures of Barley for one peny, but wine and oyle harme thou not: for after that this fir≈øt my≈øterie ≈øhall be accompli≈øhed, not onely dearth and famine ≈øhall en≈øue the contempt of the
trueth, but God ≈øhall permit Satan to tempt and vexe his Church with a cloud of diuers and dangerous here≈øies, which may be meant by the rider on the blacke hor≈øe, for the blackene≈ø≈øe and darkene≈ø≈øe of them, Here≈øies ment in the third Seale. ≈øhall ob≈øcure the light of the Go≈øpel; but yet God, to a≈ø≈øure vs that hee will neuer forget his owne, ≈øpeakes from his Throne, comforting vs thereby, that although (as the balances and mea≈øure ≈øignifies) good men ≈øhall be≈øcant, who are the fine wheat and barley of his harue≈øt, Luke 3. yet ≈øome ≈øhall there be that ≈øhall not bow their knee to Baal, no not in ≈øtraighter times that ≈øhall come after; and alwayes giues vs a≈ø≈øurance, that the word and trueth of God, which is an eternall Oyle and comfortable Vine, ≈øhall neuer be de≈øtroyed, nor any wayes corrupted, in ≈øpight of all the malice of Satan in his in≈øtruments. 7 And when hee opened the fourth Seale, the fourth Bea≈øt ≈øaid vnto me, Come and ≈øee. 8 Then I beheld, and loe, I did ≈øee a pale hor≈øe, and the name of him that ≈øate vpon him was Death: This is the greate≈øt and heauie≈øt plague; for after that the per≈øecutions and here≈øies ≈øhall take an ende, and that infirmitie and coldne≈ø≈øe haue cropen into the Church, The Popedom is meant by the pale hor≈øe in the fourth Seale, of here≈øie and ciuil tyranny. then ≈øhall God redouble his former plagues, by permitting Satan to erect a tyrannie compo≈øed of both the≈øe former plagues; for it ≈øhall be full of here≈øie like the one, and full of ciuill and temporall tyrannie like the other: and therefore becau≈øe it brings with it al maner of death, both of body and ≈øoule, the rider is iu≈øtly called Death, as the fountaine of all the ≈øorts of the ≈øame: and the palene≈ø≈øe of the hor≈øe is corre≈øpondent in all points to the qualitie of the rider; for as the rider is called Death, ≈øo the colour of palene≈ø≈øe repre≈øents the ≈øame: and as the riders qualities are compo≈øed of here≈øies and tyrannie, ≈øo the colour of pale is compo≈øed chiefly of blacke and red: And hell followed after him to the vtter damnation of him and his followers: And power was giuen him ouer the fourth part of the earth, to wit, the re≈øt who are not ouercome by the other three riders; for all they who were not marked by the white hor≈øe, nor killed in body by the red, nor killed in ≈øoule by the blacke, are killed both in body and ≈øoule by this la≈øt: And as he hath power of de≈øtroying thus, giuen him ouer the fourth part of the earth, ≈øo by foure plagues ≈øpecially doeth he execute the ≈øame, to wit, by Sword, Hunger, Death, and the Bea≈øts of the earth: The≈øe plagues allude to the plagues, mentioned in the Canticle of Mo≈øes; for this tyrannie ≈øhall begin with per≈øecution, Scarcitie of trew Pa≈øtors and wor≈øhipping. The cruelty of the Popes tyranny. this per≈øecution ≈øhall cau≈øe a hunger, and great ≈øcarcitie of the true wor≈øhip of God, this hunger ≈øhall breed a ≈øecond and eternall death, and this tyranny ≈øhall then end with a crueller and bloodier per≈øecution of the bodies then euer was before; which ≈øhall be ≈øo barbarous, that it is compared in this Vi≈øion to the execution, v≈øed by wilde bea≈øts vpon offenders, and ≈øhall ≈øpare no degree, ≈øexe nor aage, no more then bea≈øts doe. 9 But when he opened the fift Seale, I did ≈øee vnder the Altar, the ≈øoules of them that were ≈ølaine for the word of God, and for his Te≈øtimonie which they maintained: 10 And they cryed with a lowd voice, ≈øaying, How long wilt thou delay (O Lord) ≈øince thou art holy
and trew, to reuenge & iudge our blood vpon them that dwel on the earth; for this la≈øt per≈øecution did enter ≈øo fiercely into the world, and did make ≈øo great a number of Martyrs, that their ≈øoules lying vnder the Altar, to wit, in the ≈øafegard of IESVS CHRIST (who is the only Altar, Ho≈øe. 14.3. whereupon, and by whom it is onely lawfull to vs, Hebr. 13.15. to offer the ≈øacrifice of our hearts and lips, to wit, our humble prayers to God the Father) did pray, and their blood did cry to heauen, and craue at the hands of their Father a iu≈øt reuenge of their torments vpon the wicked, and therewith a ha≈øtening of the generall di≈ø≈øolution, for the deliuerie of their brethren who did remaine yet aliue. 11 Then white robes were giuen to euery one of them, and it was ≈øaid vnto them, and they were willed to re≈øt and haue patience for a ≈øhort ≈øpace, vnto the time the number of their fellow ≈øeruants to God, and brethren companions in the Cro≈ø≈øe, were fulfilled, who were al≈øo to be ≈ølaine as they were already: This ≈øurely ought to be a wonderfull and ine≈øtimable comfort to all the Church militant, ≈øince by this Seale wee are a≈ø≈øured, that both the ≈øoules of the Martyrs, ≈øo ≈øoone as their bodies are killed, ≈øhall immediatly be rewarded with perpetuall and bright glory in heauen, not going into any other place by the way, which is ≈øignified by the White robes; as al≈øo that ≈øo ≈øoone as their number ≈øhall be complete, which ≈øhall be within a ≈øhort ≈øpace, God ≈øhall then craue a full account at their per≈øecutors hands; and then as the one number ≈øhall receiue a full and eternall glory in body and ≈øoule, the other ≈øhall receiue a full torment in ≈øoule and body, to the cleere ≈øhining of his Iu≈øtice in the one, and his mercy in the other. 12 Then I tooke heed when he opened the ≈øixt, and loe, there was a great earthquake, Matth. 24.29. and the Sunne-beame blacke like ≈øackecloth made of haire, and the Moone became all bloody: 13 And the Starres fell from the heauens vpon the earth, euen as the figgetree lets her vnripe figges fall, being beaten by a mightie winde: 14 And the heauen went away like a ≈øcrole that is rolled together, and all the hilles and Iles were remooued from their places: 15 And the Kings of the Earth, the Nobles, the rich men, the Tribunes or commanders of the people, the mighty men, and all the ≈ølaues, a≈øwell as free-men, did hide them≈øelues in cauerns and vnder rockes of hills: Luke 23.30. 16 And they ≈øaid to the hilles and the rocks, Fall vpon vs, and hide vs from the ≈øight of him that ≈øits vpon the Throne, and from the wrath of the Lambe: 17 For that great day of his wrath is come, and who then may ≈øtand? This is the accompli≈øhment of that di≈ø≈øolution, craued and promi≈øed in the fift Seale. The≈øe terrible things, mentioned in the ≈øixt Seale, are the alterations and ≈øignes in the la≈øt time: the very ≈øame did our Ma≈øter Chri≈øt prophe≈øie, when he was walking on this Earth.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

p.hi: A proper and comfortable digre≈øsion, interiected of Gods care ouer the Elect, in the times of greatest temptations, ≈øignified by the Vi≈øions of the foure Angels, the Election and happie estate of the elected.

div.p:
BVt le≈øt I, or any other, ≈øhould doubt of the ≈øafegard and ≈øaluation of the Elect, thinking that the≈øe terrible plagues ≈øhould haue lighted vpon both good and bad indifferently, he repre≈øented vnto my ≈øight foure Angels, ≈øtanding on the foure corners of the earth, and retayning the foure winds in their hands, and ≈øtopping them, either to blow vpon the earth, the ≈øea, or any tree: 2 And I did ≈øee one Angel going vp from the ri≈øing of the Sunne, hauing the Seale of the liuing God, and hee cried with a loud voice to the foure Angels that had power giuen them to harme the earth, and the ≈øea, 3 Saying; Harme not the earth nor the ≈øea, nor the trees, vntill we haue marked the ≈øeruants of God on the forehead; The≈øe Angels, foure in number, becau≈øe they ≈øit vpon the foure corners of the earth, ready to execute Gods iudgements vpon euery part of the World, although they already had ≈øtayed the winds to blow, to wit, the progre≈ø≈øe of the Euangel vpon the earth, which is the world, vpon the Sea, which is the numbers of people, vpon the Trees, which are the Magi≈øtrates, Ciuill or Eccle≈øia≈øticall; Yet one Angel came from the ri≈øing of the Sunne, to wit, 2. Peter 1. Luke 1.7. Malach. 4. directed by CHRIST, who is comfortable like the Sunne-ri≈øing to his Elect, and is that Orient day-≈øpring, and Sunne of Righteou≈ønes, ri≈øing ouer all the faithfull, which is mentioned in the Scriptures; Who cries and forbids the≈øe foure Angels to doe any further temporall harme, while fir≈øt the cho≈øen be ≈øealed on the forehead, by that Seale which he beares with him for that effect, that the≈øe Angels might know them, being marked in ≈øo eminent a place, in the generall de≈øtruction, and ≈øo ≈øpare them, a≈ø≈øuring vs thereby, that he hath ≈øuch a care ouer his Elect, as he hath prouided for them before hand, euen as he did for Noah and Loth, and their families, in the time of the deluge and de≈øtruction of Sodome. 4 And I heard the number of them that were ≈øealed in I≈ørael, reckoned to be one hundred fourtie and foure Thou≈øand; for twelue thou≈øand were ≈øealed of euery one of the Tribes, which makes iu≈øtly that number. Out of euery one of the Tribes was a certaine number cho≈øen, to a≈ø≈øure vs, that a number of euery one of them ≈øhalbe ≈øaued: 9 And that I might be a≈ø≈øured that a number, a≈øwell of the Gentiles, as of the Iewes, ≈øhalbe ≈øaued, Loe, he ≈øhewed me a number ≈øo great, as I could not reckon the ≈øame, and it was compo≈øed of certaine out of euery Nation, Tribe, people and tongue: And they ≈øtood before the Throne, and in pre≈øence of the Lambe, clothed with white robes, hauing palmes in
their hands, in token of the victorie they obteined of their long≈øome battaile. 10 And they cried all with one voice, ≈øaying, Our health and our ≈øaluation commeth from our God that ≈øits on the Throne, and from his Lambe, to wit, their health came from God the Father, by the Mediation of his Sonne. 11 Then all the Angels ≈øtood round about the Throne, the Elders, and the foure bea≈øtes, and bowed them≈øelues downe vpon their faces, and adored God with thanke≈øgiuing, for his mercy to the cho≈øen, both of Iew and Gentile, and his Iu≈øtice vpon all the re≈øt, 12 Saying, Amen, in allowance of the things done, with full confe≈ø≈øion, that Ble≈øsing, Glory, Wi≈øedome, Thanke≈øgiuing, Honour, Vertue, and Power, belongs only and mo≈øt iu≈øtly to GOD, for euer and euer. 13 Then one of the Elders ≈øpake vnto me, and ≈øaid, What are the≈øe, and from whence are they come, who are clothed with white robes? 14 And I an≈øwered and ≈øaid, Thou knowe≈øt, my Lord. Then he ≈øaid vnto me, The≈øe are they who are pre≈øerued, and come from that great affliction, which was repre≈øented to thee in ≈øome of the Seales, and they haue wa≈øhed their garments, and made them white in the blood of the Lambe: for they, by vertue of his death, are made righteous by imputation, who≈øe blood is the onely and full purgation of vs, from our ≈øinnes: 15 And therefore they are before the Throne of GOD, and ≈øerue him day and night in his Temple, to wit, they, without any intermi≈ø≈øion, contemplate his Glory, and euer ≈øerue him by continuall thanke≈øgiuing, and prai≈øing his Name in Heauen, which is his eternall and cele≈øtiall Temple: and hee that ≈øits on the Throne ≈øhall dwell with them; for they ≈øhall neuer be ≈øeparated from his pre≈øence. 16 And they ≈øhall be no more an hungry, or thir≈øtie, nor the Sunne, or any heate ≈øhall trouble them: 17 For the Lambe who is in the midde≈øt of the Throne, to wit, coequall in power with his Father, he ≈øhall feed them and guide them to the liuely fountaines of waters, to wit, they ≈øhall feed of that Spirituall and liuely bread, and drinke of that Spirituall and liuely water, euen him≈øelfe; Iohn 4.14. which Water he promi≈øed to the Samaritane woman, at the well: And GOD ≈øhall wipe all teares from their eyes; for he ≈øhall both by the greatne≈ø≈øe of their pre≈øent ioyes, put quite out of their memories, all the ≈øorrow of their former troubles; and ≈øhall al≈øo giue them eternall ioy, which ≈øhall neuer be mixed with any kind of trouble or feare: ≈øo ≈øhall they not be mole≈øted with the vehemencie of the Sunne, or any other heate, which ≈øignifies great troubles, and ≈øorrow.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

p.hi: The opening of the ≈øeuenth Seale: The ≈øeuen Trumpets comming out of it: The effect of the prayers of the faithfull, ≈øignified by the vi≈øion of the fire of the Altar: Some per≈øecution, and ≈øome here≈øies, ≈øignified by haile mixt with blood and fire, in the first trumpet: The great per≈øecution by the hill of fire, in the ≈øecond: The number of here≈øies, by the ≈øtarres, falling into the fountaines of water, in the third: The vniuer≈øall infirmitie in the Church, in ≈øome things by the Sunne, Moone, and ≈øtarres darkened, in the fourth.

div.p:
ANd when hee opened the ≈øeuenth Seale, there was ≈øilence in heauen almo≈øt halfe an houre, a≈øwell to let mee know that hee had once already ≈øummarily declared the whole things which was to come after, as by ≈øilence a while to giue me occa≈øion to meditate vpon that vi≈øion which I had ≈øeene, to the effect that afterward I might the better vnder≈øtand the more particular rehear≈øall thereof, which now vnder another vi≈øion and forme, was to be declared vnto me by the opening of the ≈øeuenth Seale. 2 And I ≈øaw ≈øeuen Angels ≈øtanding before God, to execute what≈øoeuer thing it ≈øhould plea≈øe him to command them; and by his direction there were ≈øeuen Trumpets giuen vnto them, that by the≈øe Trumpets they might with one Maie≈øtie denounce to the world ≈øuch plagues, as they were by the command of God to powre foorth vpon it. 3 Then another Angel came and ≈øtood before the Altar, hauing a golden cen≈øer in his hand, and there was much incen≈øe giuen vnto him, that he might offer vp the prayers of the Saints vpon the golden Altar, that is before the Throne: 4 And the ≈ømoke of the incen≈øe, which is the prayers of the Saints, mounted vp from the hand of the Angel to the ≈øight of God: 5 Then the Angel tooke this new emptied cen≈øer, and filled it againe with the fire of the Altar, and did ca≈øt it downe on the earth, and there were thundrings, voices, lightenings and earthquakes: By this Angel and his proceedings, we are a≈ø≈øured and made certaine, that Chri≈øt ≈øhall euer be vigilant ouer his owne, and that ≈øpecially in ≈øtraighte≈øt times hee will heare their prayers, and euer renew them with ≈øome light of the Go≈øpel, by the working of his holy Spirit: And to a≈ø≈øure vs hereof, the vi≈øion of this Angel was ≈øhowne vnto me immediatly before, that by the ≈øeuen Trumpets he is to dilate the≈øe vi≈øions, ≈øhowen me in the former Seales: This Angel was Chri≈øt, he ≈øtood before the Altar: this Altar is likewi≈øe him≈øelfe, as I declared before: his ≈øtanding before it, meaneth, that by his office of Mediatour, hee was to doe as followes: He had a golden cen≈øer in his hand, for he keeps the cen≈øer wherein are contained the incen≈øe which the Saints giue him, to wit, their prayers, to be offered vp to God by his mediation, who is that golden and pure Altar, which is euer in the pre≈øence of God, and who≈øe reque≈øts are no
time refu≈øed, and therefore that incen≈øe and the ≈ømoke thereof, mounts vp to the ≈øight of God, to a≈ø≈øure vs that our prayers, being offered in that forme, are euer acceptable: The effect whereof doeth appeare, by the Angels filling againe the cen≈øer with the fire of the Altar, and ca≈øting it on the earth; wherewith is ioyned the noi≈øe ye heard of; for the≈øe prayers procure, that their Mediatour ≈øhall out of his golden boxe, to wit, out of his trea≈øure of power, ≈øend downe the fire of the Altar, to wit, the holy Spirit which remaineth with him, to make thunders, voices, lightnings and earthquakes, to wit, to giue againe the Law, by renewing the efficacie of the Go≈øpel, in the hearts of the faithfull, alluding to the giuing of the olde Law, whereof the≈øe fearefull noi≈øes were the fore-runners: This ≈øurely is the care and effect that our Ma≈øter in all trouble≈øome times renewes to ≈øtrengthen our weakene≈ø≈øe with. 6 And then the ≈øeuen Angels which had the ≈øeuen trumpets prepared them≈øelues to blow; for although they were before directed, yet were they not permitted to execute their office, no more then the foure Angels, who ≈øtayed the foure windes while Chri≈øt had ≈øtrengthened and armed his owne, as is ≈øaid, to a≈ø≈øure vs, that euer before any great temptation, hee will make the backes of the elect ready, and able to beare ≈øuch burthens as hee is to lay vpon them. 1. Cor. 10.13. 7 Then the fir≈øt Angel blew, and there was a great haile, and fire mixed with blood, and this ≈øtorme was ca≈øt downe vpon the earth; whereupon followed, that the third part of the trees was withered and burnt vp, and all greene gra≈ø≈øe was withered and burnt vp, for the fir≈øt plague which hath already begun to worke, ≈øhall be mixed partly of haile, which is here≈øie, for as haile ≈øhowers by the harme they doe to the corne, makes them to become deare, ≈øo here≈øie makes the true harue≈øt of the Lord to become ≈øcant: This haile or here≈øie, and ≈øpirituall per≈øecution, is ioyned with the ≈øword and per≈øecution of the fle≈øh, which is ≈øignified by the fire, and the blood: This fiery and two edged triall ≈øhall make the third part, to wit, a part, but not the greate≈øt number of trees, to wit, of renowmed men; and all greene gra≈ø≈øe, to wit, all them that are not wel founded and ≈øtrong in the trewth, (this greene gra≈ø≈øe is that ≈øort of profe≈ø≈øours, Marke 4. ver≈ø. 5, 6, 7. of whom Chri≈øt ≈øpake in the parable of the ≈øeed ≈øowen in ≈øandie, and thornie ground;) it ≈øhall make them (I ≈øay) to fall from the trewth, and ≈øo become withered and vnprofitable. 8 Then the ≈øecond Angel blew, and there fell as it had beene a great hill, all burning in fire; and this hill was ca≈øt into the ≈øea, and the third part of the ≈øea became blood: 9 And the third part of the liuing creatures in the ≈øea was ≈ølaine, and the third part of the ≈øhips therein did peri≈øh; for after that this former plague ≈øhall haue an end, and yet the world not turne them≈øelues from their iniquities, then the ≈øecond ≈øhall follow, which is the corporall plague of per≈øecution, ≈øignified by the red hor≈øe in the ≈øecond Seale, more amply dilated heere: This great heape of fiery per≈øecution, like a mountaine of fire, ≈øhall make the third part, or a certaine number of people and nations, which is ≈øignified by the ≈øeas or many waters, to ouerflow in
blood; for as it is ≈øaid of the ≈øame in the ≈øecond Scale, they ≈øhall ≈ølay one another, for euen among them≈øelues, to wit, among the wicked ≈øhalbe great blood≈øhed and warres; for the third, or a certaine number of all ≈øorts of liuing things ≈øhall die, to wit, no ≈øort of men ≈øhall be exempted from this trouble: But e≈øpecially a number, and not the greate≈øt part of the faithfull ≈øhalbe per≈øecuted, which is ≈øignified by the ≈øhips; for euen as ≈øhips on a ≈øtormie Sea ≈øeeke a hauen, ≈øo the faithfull among the wicked of the world, to≈ø≈øed here and there re≈øi≈øting euery waue, ≈øtriue in de≈øpight of many contrarious windes, to attaine to that hauen, where at la≈øt ca≈øting their Anchor, they are freed from all worldly tempe≈øts, and dwell there eternally in a perpetuall calmene≈ø≈øe. 10 Then the third Angel blew, and there fell from heauen a great Starre burning like a torch, and it fell vpon the third part of riuers and fountaines of waters, and the name of the ≈øtarre was Wormewood: and the third part of the riuers and fountaines were turned into wormewood, and many men died, for the bitterne≈ø≈øe of the waters: This is that ≈øame plague which is ≈øignified by the blacke hor≈øe and his rider, to wit, a cloud of defections, and Apo≈øtatical here≈øies, here ≈øignified by a great ≈øtarre burning like a torch: for it ≈øhall haue a great light, but like the light of a torch; for as the torch and candle-light is fal≈øe to the eye and makes the colours to appeare otherwi≈øe then they are, and is made dimme by the brightnes of the Sunne, ≈øo ≈øhall this light of fal≈øe doctrine maske iniquitie for a ≈øpace, and make it ≈øeeme to be the trueth, vnto the time the trew light of God obfu≈øcat and blinde it: The≈øe here≈øies ≈øhall be ≈øtronger in deceit, then tho≈øe before: for they ≈øhall ≈øeduce the very pa≈øtours and ≈øpirituall Magi≈øtrates, which is ≈øignified by the Starres falling in a part of the fountaines of waters: for the≈øe men are the worldly fountaines, whereout the re≈øt of the faithfull, by the buckets of their eares, draw that ≈øpring of heauenly liquor. 11 This ≈øtarre is called Wormewood, for as wormewood is a bitter hearbe, what greater bitterne≈ø≈øe can be to the ≈øoule of man, then to procure the wrath of the Almightie, through ≈øuch an horrible fall? and as it turned a part of the pa≈øtours, and made them to become of bitter qualitie like it ≈øelfe, ≈øo their bitterne≈ø≈øe did ≈ølay with the ≈øecond death, a great number of men; to wit, their di≈øciples and followers. 12 Then the fourth Angel blew, and the third part of the Sunne, the third part of the Moone, and third part of the Starres was ≈øtricken, ≈øo that the third part of them, to wit, of their light was ob≈øcured, and the third part of the day, and the third part of the night was ob≈øcured, to wit, the third part of their light was darkened: For after that one part of the pa≈øtours ≈øhall make horrible defection, it ≈øhall fall out that the whole Church vi≈øible, ≈øhalbe blinded with ≈øome errours, but not yet make a full defection, which is ≈øignified by the ob≈øcuring of a part of the light of the Sunne, Moone, and ≈øtarres, to wit, of all degrees of ≈øpirituall Magi≈øtrates; ≈øo that by their generall weakne≈ø≈øe in ≈øome points, a part of the meaning of the Go≈øpel ≈øhal be fal≈øly interpreted, which is meant by the light of the day, and of the
night: for as the cloud by day, and the pillar of fire by night did guide the people of I≈ørael through the de≈øart, to the land of Promi≈øe, ≈øo will this light ≈øhining, both day and night in our ≈øoules, conduct vs out through the wilderne≈ø≈øe of this world, to that ≈øpirituall land of promi≈øe, where we with our God ≈øhall gloriou≈øly reigne in all Eternitie: This fourth bla≈øt is al≈øo a part of the third Seale. 13 And I ≈øaw and heard an other Angel flying through the midde≈øt of heauen, and ≈øaying with a lowd voice, Woe, woe, woe to the inhabitants of the earth, for the harme that ≈øhalbe done vnto them by the la≈øt three bla≈øts of the Angels Trumpets: for the la≈øt three plagues ≈øhall be exceeding great, which, that I might the better note and take greater heed vnto, God wakens me vp and makes me ≈øee an Angel flying through the midde≈øt of heauen with celeritie, a≈øwell to forewarne the holy Angels and Saints of the≈øe three plagues, ≈øo farre in greatne≈ø≈øe aboue the re≈øt, as to ≈øignifie by his ≈øwift flying, that they are ha≈øtily and within ≈øhort ≈øpace to be put in execution: And the number of Woes, to wit, which he cries, are an≈øwerable to the number of plagues which are hereafter to be declared.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.head: ARGVMENT.
argument.p: In the fift Trumpet, the here≈øies cau≈øe a great blindne≈ø≈øe and ignorance, whereof commeth the Eccle≈øiasticall Papisticall orders, ≈øignified by the gra≈øhoppers breeding out of the ≈ømoake, and their power and qualities: Their King and head the Pope and his ≈øtyle: In the next Trumpet the beginning of his decay, ≈øignified by the loo≈øing of the foure Angels at Euphrates: The remedy he v≈øeth for the ≈øame by hounding out the Ie≈øuits, ≈øignified by the hor≈øe in the Vi≈øion: Their qualities ≈øignified by their brea≈øt-plates: The Popes and Turkes his gathering to destroy the Church, ≈øignified by a great armie of hor≈øe: The Pope is the plague for breaking of the first Table: and the Turke for breaking of the ≈øecond.

div.p:
THen the fift Angel blew, and I ≈øaw the ≈øtarre that fell out of heauen vpon earth (for it is to be noted, that all the≈øe plagues did fall out of heauen vpon the earth, to teach vs, Qu√≤d nullum malum est in ciuitate, quod non faciat Dominus, by his Iu≈øtice permitting, Amos 3.6. E≈øay 45.7. directing, ordering, and re≈øtrayning it) I did ≈øee it get the key of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit which was giuen vnto it; for this cloud of here≈øies ≈øpoken of in the third Trumpet and third Seale, by proce≈ø≈øe of time did breed this ba≈øtard tyrannie, whereof I ≈øpoke in the fourth Seale, and ≈øo it brought from hell by the opening of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, whereof it gate the keyes, to wit, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and deuice of Satan, it bred ≈øuch plagues as follow. 2 Fir≈øt, by opening of the pit, came foorth a great ≈ømoke like the ≈ømoke of a furnace, to wit, it did breed ≈øuch a darkene≈ø≈øe and ignorance in the minds of men, as the Sunne and the Aire were ob≈øcured, (to wit, the light of the trweth repre≈øented
by the darkening of the Sunne) and ≈øo in place of liuing vnder, and by the true and cleare aire of the trueth, the world ≈øhall liue vnder, and by the ba≈øtard and darke aire of fal≈øe doctrine. 3 And out of this ≈ømoake came Gra≈øhoppers vpon the earth: For this great blindne≈ø≈øe ≈øhall breed a multitude of diuers Orders of Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øons, as well Monkes and Friers, as others, but all agreeing in one hereticall Religion: The≈øe are gra≈øhoppers, becau≈øe they breed of that filthy ≈ømoke of here≈øies, euen as Gra≈øhoppers breed of corrupted aire; they are euer teaching fal≈øe doctrine with their mouth, which carries with it as great de≈øtruction to the ≈øoules of men, as the mouthes of Gra≈øhoppers doe to the greene gra≈ø≈øe and herbs, and the earth ≈øhalbe ouerloaden with multitudes of them, euen as Gra≈øhoppers ≈øometimes come in great heapes, and ouercharge the face of a whole countrey: And like power was giuen to them, as hath the earthly Scorpions: for as the Scorpions ≈øting is not felt ≈øore at fir≈øt, and is long in working, and impo≈ø≈øible to be healed, but by the oyle of a dead ≈øcorpion, ≈øo the poy≈øoning of the ≈øoule cannot be perceiued by the receiuer at the fir≈øt, but is long in operation, for by peece and peece they infect the world with here≈øies, and open not all their packe at fir≈øt; and the world ≈øhall neuer be freed from their here≈øies, vnto the vtter de≈øtruction of the≈øe fal≈øe teachers them≈øelues: 4 And it was ≈øaid vnto them, or they were forbidden to harme the gra≈ø≈øe, or any greene thing, or any tree, but onely the≈øe men that haue not the marke of God in their foreheads: for though earthly Gra≈øhoppers when they ≈øwarme in heapes, doe de≈øtroy all greene gra≈ø≈øe or trees, yet God ≈øhall ≈øo bridle the rage of the≈øe ≈øpirituall Gra≈øhoppers, that they ≈øhall haue no power to peruert the Elect of what≈øoeuer degree, or ≈øort, compared to greene gra≈ø≈øe and fruitful trees; but their power ≈øhall extend onely vpon them that beare not the marke or Seale of God vpon their forehead, and as withered and vnfruitfull ≈øticks are ready for the fire: 5 But they ≈øhall haue no power to ≈ølay them, to wit, they ≈øhall not di≈øcouer to the world their greate≈øt bla≈øphemies at the fir≈øt, as I ≈øaid before, but they ≈øhall torment them for the ≈øpace of fiue moneths, and their torment ≈øhalbe like the torment that a man ≈øuffers, being ≈øtinged by a ≈øcorpion, to wit, they ≈øhal by peece & peece infect them with ≈øpirituall poi≈øon; and as I haue ≈øaid already, they ≈øhall not feele the ≈ømart thereof, while the ≈øecond death make them to feele the ≈øame: This torment ≈øhall endure fiue moneths, that is the time limitted them by God, which alludes to the fiue moneths in Summer when Gra≈øhoppers are; This forme of ≈øpeech doeth declare the continuing of the Metaphore. 6 And in the≈øe daies men ≈øhal ≈øeeke death, and ≈øhall not finde the ≈øame, and men ≈øhall de≈øire to die, but death ≈øhall flie from them, for then beginnes the trouble≈øome times of the later dayes, the mi≈øerie whereof I heard our Ma≈øter, while he was yet on the earth, declare in the≈øe words that I haue now repeated. 7 And the figure of the≈øe locu≈øts, was like vnto the hor≈øe prepared for the war, to ≈øignifie that their forme of practi≈øe & policie, ≈øhalbe ≈øo worldly wi≈øe, that they ≈øhal lacke nothing
perteyning to the ≈øetting forth of their intents, more then a hor≈øe of ≈øeruice which is curiou≈øly barded, feated and prepared, for going forth to the battell. And they had crownes like crownes of gold vpon their heads; for they ≈øhall pretend to be holy like the Elders, who for their reward gate Crownes of pure gold ≈øet vpon their heads, as you heard before, and ≈øo ≈øhall outwardly glance in an hypocriticall holine≈ø≈øe; And their faces were like the faces of men, and the faces of men ≈øignifie rea≈øon, as man is a rea≈øonable creature: the likene≈ø≈øe then of their faces vnto men, ≈øignifies that they ≈øhall, by curious arguments, pretend rea≈øon to maintaine their fal≈øe doctrine, but it ≈øhall be but a counterfait re≈øembling of rea≈øon indeed, euen as their crownes are like vnto gold, but are not gold indeed. 8 And they haue haire like the haire of women: for as the haire of women is a ≈øpeciall part of their alluring beautie, ≈øo they haue ≈øuch alluring here≈øies whereby they make the way of heauen ≈øo ea≈øie by their helpe to whom≈øoeuer, how wicked ≈øoeuer they be, that will v≈øe the ≈øame, as they allure them to commit ≈øpirituall adulterie with them. And they haue teeth like Lions teeth: for as the Lion is ≈øtronger in the mouth, and ≈øo may doe greater harme with his teeth then any other bea≈øt, ≈øo all the≈øe that will not be per≈øwaded with their ≈øhewes prepared like hor≈øes for the warre, with their crownes like crownes of gold, with their faces like the faces of men, nor with their haire like the haire of women, they ≈øhall be per≈øecuted by the power of their mouth, to wit, by their threatnings and thundering cur≈øes. 9 And they had brea≈øt plates like brea≈øtplates of iron, for they ≈øhall haue to backe this their authoritie, the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Princes, who≈øe maintayning of them ≈øhall appeare vnto the world ≈øtrong as iron. And the ≈øound of their wings was like the ≈øound of chariots running with many hor≈øes vnto the warre: for as the gra≈ø≈øehoppers make in the hot time of the yere & the day, a great ≈øound with their wings, ≈øo the≈øe ≈øhalbe made ≈øo ≈øtrong and fearefull by their bre≈øtplates like iron, as what they, being in the height of their day ≈øhall decree, it ≈øhal haue ≈øuch a maie≈øtie and fearefulnes, as the terrible noi≈øe of many hor≈øes and chariots hurling to battel: 10 But they had tailes like the tailes of Scorpions, and there were ≈øtings in their tailes: for at their fir≈øt dealing with any, they appeare not harmeful to them that heare them, and beleeue them, but the effect and end of their practi≈øe is poi≈øon to the ≈øoule, and thereafter their tailes are like vnto the tailes of Scorpions, wherein is their ≈øting: And they had power to trouble and harme men the ≈øpace of fiue moneths: for as I ≈øhewed you before, that they ≈øhould torment men the ≈øpace of fiue moneths, to wit, a certaine ≈øpace appointed them; ≈øo now I a≈ø≈øure you to your comfort, that as gra≈ø≈øehoppers la≈øt but fiue moneths that are hotte≈øt, ≈øo the≈øe ≈øhall be like vnto gra≈ø≈øehoppers in that as well as in the re≈øt; for they ≈øhall remaine but for a certaine ≈øpace pre≈øcribed, and then ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed by the bla≈øt of Chri≈øts breath. 11 They haue al≈øo a King, but to rule ouer them, who is the Angel of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, and his name in Hebrew is Abaddon, and in Greeke Apollyon, for the≈øe by
the permi≈ø≈øion of Gods iu≈øtice, and working of Satan, ≈øhall haue at the la≈øt a Monarch to be their head, who ≈øhall be like vnto them≈øelues, the angel or me≈ø≈øenger comming, to wit, in≈øtructed and in≈øpired by Satan to bee his emba≈ø≈øadour, and to teach his fal≈øe doctrine to the counterfeit church, as well as the true Pa≈øtours are the Emba≈ø≈øadours of God to the true Church: He is called Abaddon or Apollyon, becau≈øe as hee is both a ≈øpirituall and ciuill Monarch, ≈øo he de≈øtroyes and killes both body and ≈øoule, as I tolde you in the fourth ≈øeale, where hee is called Death, for the ≈øame cau≈øe that hee is called heere De≈øtroyer. 12 One woe is pa≈øt, and loe two come after, for this which by the fift Trumpet is declared, is the fir≈øt of the three la≈øt and greate≈øt plagues, whereunto I wi≈øhed you to take ≈øpeciall heed; and therefore take good heed to the other two bla≈øts of the trumpets that follow. 13 Then the ≈øixt Angel blewe, and I heard a voice comming from among the foure hornes of the golden Altar that ≈øtands euer before the eyes of God, ≈øaying the≈øe words to the next Angel that had a Trumpet, Loo≈øe the≈øe foure Angels bound at the great water Euphrates. 14 Now the ≈øummons and warning being giuen by the ≈øixt bla≈øt of the trumpet of the ≈øixt and fearefull plague that was to come; this command of Chri≈øt (which is the voice here mentioned) comes to the ≈øixt Angel, commanding him to doe as ye now haue heard: For although the trumpet was alreadie blowen, yet the execution followes not, while Chri≈øt command and permit it; for the≈øe foure Angels mentioned here, are the ≈øame who were ≈øtanding before vpon the foure airths of the earth, ready to de≈øtroy the ≈øame, who were then, as you heard, ≈øtayed by Chri≈øt, while fir≈øt he had ≈øealed his owne; who now being all ≈øealed, becau≈øe this is the la≈øt plague that is to come vpon the world, except that of the con≈øummation; Chri≈øt therefore commands them to be loo≈øed, for they were before ≈øtayed, as it were bound, to the effect they might now put in execution the≈øe things which they were ready to doe: When they were ≈øtayed, it is ≈øaid they were bound at the great riuer Euphrates; alluding hereby to the hi≈øtory of Baltha≈øar in Daniel, for as Euphrates diuided Babylon from the Per≈øians and the A≈ø≈øyrians, which they cro≈ø≈øed when they ≈ølew Baltha≈øar, ≈øo this command of ≈øtay, giuen to the≈øe Angels by Chri≈øt, was that great riuer Euphrates, beyond the which they were bound, for they had no power to cro≈ø≈øe it, and to plague the world, while fir≈øt all his cho≈øen were ≈øealed, and that hee had loo≈øed and permitted them, as by this command here is done: 15 And ≈øo the≈øe foure Angels were loo≈øed, who were readie at the houre, the day, the moneth, and the yeere, to ≈ølay the third part of men, to wit, they were ready at the very moment pre≈øcribed to them by God, to de≈øtroy all men, except ≈øuch as were ≈øealed, ouer whom they had no power; and ≈øuch as were re≈øerued to the de≈øtruction of the la≈øt plague, to wit, the con≈øummation; and ≈øo the third part was left to them to de≈øtroy. Now followes the plague of the ≈øixt trumpet. 16 And fir≈øt I ≈øaw an armie of hor≈øemen, the number whereof were two hundred thou≈øand thou≈øand; for I
heard the number reckoned: this double great number ≈øignifies, that there ≈øhall be rai≈øed vp at one time, two great Monarchies and ≈øeats of Tyrants; one ruling in the Ea≈øt, and another in the We≈øt, who ≈øhal cruelly per≈øecute the Church. 17 And in this vi≈øion likewi≈øe I ≈øaw hor≈øes, who≈øe riders had bre≈øtplates of fire, of Hyacinth and brim≈øtone, and the heads of the hor≈øes were like the heads of Lions, and from their mouthes came fire, ≈ømoke, and brim≈øtone; noting, that with fiery rage, ≈ømokie pride, and pretences, and loath≈øome and wicked cour≈øes, the≈øe two Monarches, the one ≈øecular, the other Eccle≈øia≈øticall, ≈øhall conquer and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the greate≈øt part of the world: The≈øe hor≈øes are a part, yet not the lea≈øt part of the forces of one of the≈øe Monarches, in who≈øe de≈øcription it is mo≈øt in≈øi≈øted, becau≈øe he is the De≈øtroyer, of whom it is ≈øpoken in the fift Trumpet, where hee is named Abaddon: The≈øe hor≈øes and their riders are the la≈øt order and ≈øect of his Eccle≈øia≈øticall ≈øwarme: Their bre≈øtplates, to wit, their worldly defence is compo≈øed of fire, that is, per≈øecution of the body, for they ≈øhall haue greater credit at the hands of Princes, then all the≈øe gra≈øhoppers, ≈øpoken of in the fift Seale, and ≈øo ≈øhall v≈øe their forces to defend them≈øelues therewith: They are compo≈øed of the Hyacinth, for as this herbe is darke, and of a ≈ømoking colour and bitter to the ta≈øte, ≈øo ≈øhall they be defended and maintained by the craft of their darke and bitter here≈øies, (which in the third Trumpet are called Wormewood, as here they are called Hyacynth;) and they are compo≈øed of brim≈øtone, which ≈øignifieth the loath≈øomne≈ø≈øe and ≈øtench of ≈øinne, and the flame and force of hell fire, to wit, Satan the authour of the one, and ruler of the other, ≈øhall by all maner of craft defend them as his ≈øpeciall in≈øtruments, and the la≈øt vermine bred and come vp from the ≈ømoke of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit: And they ≈øhall not onely haue power to defend them≈øelues by the≈øe three meanes, but they ≈øhall al≈øo pur≈øue and per≈øecute the faithfull; which is meant by their hor≈øes heads like to the heads of Lions, that is, able to deuoure: The meanes whereby they deuoure, are the ≈øame whereby they defend them≈øelues, to wit, by the power of Princes, to per≈øecute the bodies by fal≈øe and hereticall bragges and ≈øleights, which are here called Smoake, and by the drifts and frauds of Satan in diuers fa≈øhions to deceiue and inflame the ≈øoule, which craft of Satan is here re≈øembled to brim≈øtone. 18 By the≈øe three plagues, are ≈ølaine the third part of men, to wit, by fire, ≈ømoake, and brim≈øtone, which came out of their mouthes, to wit, their malice and ≈øtrength ≈øhall be ≈øo great, as they ≈øhall v≈øe all meanes wherewith the third part of men ≈øhalbe de≈øtroyed, although the≈øe meanes ≈øhall not be v≈øed by them onely to worke this great de≈øtruction with. 19 For their ≈øtrength is not in their mouthes onely, (as ye haue pre≈øently heard) but it is al≈øo in their tailes; for their tailes are like the tailes of ≈øerpents, hauing ≈øtings whereby they doe harme: In this they ≈øhall be like vnto the gra≈øhoppers. 20 But not the le≈ø≈øe, the wicked ≈øhall be ≈øo hard hearted, as the re≈øt of them who were not de≈øtroyed by the plagues of this trumpet, ≈øhall not repent nor de≈øi≈øt from the workman≈øhip
of their hands, to wit, from Idolatry, and adoring of deuils, and of images, of golde, of ≈øiluer, of bra≈ø≈øe, of ≈øtone, and of wood, who neither can ≈øee, heare, nor goe, (whereof this hereticall Monarch is the puni≈øhment.) 21 Nor yet will they repent them nor de≈øi≈øt from breaking the ≈øecond Table, by ≈ølaughters, ≈øorceries, fornications & thefts, whereof that other Monarch, who onely per≈øecutes the body, is the reuenge, ≈øcourge, and plague.

div.head: CHAP. X.

p.hi: Iohn heares the explication of the≈øe mysteries, which was written vpon the backe of the Booke: It is not lawfull to him to manife≈øt it: By foreknowing things to come, which is ≈øignified by ≈øwallowing the booke, he is mooued to a great ioy in the instant time, but it turneth in great bitterne≈øse to him thereafter.

div.p:
THen I ≈øaw another ≈øtrong Angel comming downe from heauen; hee was clothed with a cloud, and at his head was the raine-bow, and his face was like the Sunne, and his feet like the pillars of fire: This ≈øtrong Angel was Chri≈øt, clothed with a cloude; for in a cloud hee a≈øcended, and in the clouds ≈øhall he come againe at the latter day: Which cloud was a guide to the people of I≈ørael by day, while they trauailed through the wilderne≈ø≈øe; and out of that cloud hee powres the raine and dew of his graces in abundance vpon his cho≈øen: His head was clothed with the rainebow, which ≈øignifies his couenant he made with his Elect, as ye heard before: His face was like the Sunne, and his feet like pillars of fire: yee heard the≈øe two de≈øcribed in the beginning of my Epi≈øtle. 2 And he had in his hand an open Booke; this was the Booke of the Euangel, or glad tidings: And he ≈øet his right foote or ≈øtronge≈øt on the Sea, to make ≈øtable that liquid Element ≈øo vn≈øtable of nature; and his left vpon the earth, which is ≈øooner made firme, by this to ≈øhew the power he hath ouer all things contained in them, who hath no power to pa≈ø≈øe the bounds and order which he hath pre≈øcribed vnto them; and therefore the earth is called his foot≈øtoole, by Dauid in his P≈øalmes. 3 And he cryed with a mighty voice like a roaring Lyon, for they were terrible things and great which hee was to denounce: 4 And when he had cryed, the ≈øeuen thunders ≈øpake their voices; The≈øe were the ≈øeuen Spirits of God, who by his direction did ≈øpeake, and I was to haue written what they did ≈øpeake, of purpo≈øe to haue ≈øet it downe with the re≈øt: But I heard a voice from heauen, ≈øaying, Seale what the ≈øeuen thunders haue ≈øpoken, but write them not: For the holy Spirit hauing declared vnto me by them, the expo≈øition of the ≈øixe trumpets, the voice of God commands me not to manife≈øt that vnto the world with the re≈øt, but by ≈øealing of it, to keepe it clo≈øe vnto the due time. 5 And the Angel, to wit, Chri≈øt,
whom I ≈øaw ≈øtanding on the ≈øea, and on the earth, lifted vp his hand towards heauen, 6 And ≈øwore by him that created heauen, the earth, the ≈øea, and all that is in them, that the time ≈øhould be no longer: 7 But in the dayes of the ≈øeuenth Angels voice, when he begins to blow, the my≈øterie of God ≈øhould be con≈øummate, according as he tolde to his ≈øeruants the Prophets: This oath he made to a≈ø≈øure me, that the world ≈øhould end immediatly after the accompli≈øhing of the≈øe things, mentioned in the ≈øixe Trumpets, and that the ≈øeuenth declares the things which are to be done at the con≈øummation; the forme whereof will be as hee hath declared to his Prophets. 8 Then that voice which I heard, ≈øpake to me from heauen, to wit, the voice of God the Father, ≈øpake againe vnto me, and ≈øaid, Goe and take that open booke which is in the hand of the Angel, who ≈øtands on the ≈øea and the earth: 9 And ≈øo I went vnto the Angel, and de≈øired him to giue me the booke: and hee an≈øwered, Take and ≈øwallow it, and it ≈øhall bring a bitterne≈ø≈øe vnto thy belly, but in thy mouth it ≈øhall be as ≈øweete as honie. 10 Then I tooke the booke, and found that which he ≈øaid to me of it, to be true; for indeed I thought it delightfull vnto me, to know the my≈øteries of God, by ≈øwallowing the booke, and ≈øo it was ≈øweet in my mouth; but ≈øo ≈øoon as by the dige≈øtion hereof I mu≈øt preach it to the world, and for that cau≈øe become to be hated, contemned, and per≈øecuted by the wicked, and ≈øee but a ≈ømall increa≈øe of my great labours, then ≈øurely it will be bitter to my belly, as it was to Ionas, and ≈øhall be to all the true preachers thereof thereafter. 11 Then he ≈øaid vnto me, Thou mu≈øt prophe≈øie againe before people, nations, tongues, and many kings for my children in Chri≈øt, to wit, my ≈øucce≈ø≈øours in doctrine, who ≈øhall be in the time of the≈øe plagues, ≈øhall haue the ≈øame commi≈ø≈øion to teach ouer againe the ≈øame Euangel, to the ≈øaluation of all the beleeuers: the≈øe ≈øhall haue ≈øuch boldne≈ø≈øe giuen vnto them, as they ≈øhall con≈øtantly declare their commi≈ø≈øion, not only before the people, but euen before many kings, and ≈øhall not be afraid of their faces.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.head: ARGVMENT.
argument.p: Babylon the Popes Empire, is the outward part of the Temple: The trew Church is in Sancto Sanctorum; but vnder the per≈øecution of the≈øe hypocrites for a certaine ≈øpace: Faithfull Pa≈øtours are ≈øent from time to time to witne≈ø≈øe the trewth: They are per≈øecuted, condemned, and ≈ølaine by Antichri≈øt: God rai≈øeth vp at the la≈øt ≈øtronger preachers, who ≈øhall de≈øcribe the Popedome, and foretell the de≈øtruction thereof: In the ≈øeuenth Trumpet is the day of Iudgement de≈øcribed.

div.p:
ANd then was a long reede like a rod giuen vnto me, and the Angel who gaue me the booke ≈øtood before me, and ≈øaid, Ari≈øe, and mea≈øure the Temple of God, and the Altar, and all them that adore in it, with that reede that is giuen thee: 2 But the court that is without the Temple, exclude thou,
and mea≈øure it not, for it is giuen vnto the Gentiles, who ≈øhall tread down the holy Citie for the ≈øpace of two and fourtie moneths. Now le≈øt I ≈øhould de≈øpaire of any profit which my ≈øucce≈ø≈øors could haue made in doctrine in their time, becau≈øe as it appeareth by the ≈øixt Trumpet, the whole world ≈øhould be ≈øubdued to the≈øe two Monarchies; Chri≈øt, a≈øwell to a≈ø≈øure me ≈øome ≈øhould ≈øtill remaine pure and vn≈øpotted, as al≈øo to ≈øhew mee, and by me to forewarne the Church, that this mo≈øt dangerous Monarch, called Apollyon, ≈øhould corporally ≈øucceede in the Church, and ≈øhould ≈øit in the Temple of God, giues me a reede for that cau≈øe, and commands me to mea≈øure the Temple, for he will ≈øaue all them that are of the true Church, for they are the inward parts of the Temple; and the re≈øt by rea≈øon of their hypocri≈øie, ≈øhalbe accounted of as Gentiles; and this diui≈øion ≈øhalbe made by my ≈øucce≈ø≈øours in doctrine, (of whom I ≈øpake already) for they by the mea≈øure and triall of the word, ≈øignified by the reede, ≈øhall ≈øeparate that holy Sanctum Sanctorum from the re≈øt of the outward Temple of God, to wit, the hypocriticall and Antichri≈øtian Church, which ≈øhall tread downe and per≈øecute the true Church, for the ≈øpace of two and fourtie moneths, or three yeeres and an halfe, for it is both one number. This ≈øpace pre≈øcribed by Chri≈øt, alludeth to Daniels prophecie of two times, a time, and halfe a time; for as Daniel meant thereby the halfe of his propheticall weeke, ≈øo Chri≈øt meanes by this, that the per≈øecution of this Destroyer, ≈øhall la≈øt the halfe, to wit, it ≈øhall reigne about the mid≈øt of the la≈øt aage of this whole weeke, which begins at his incarnation and fir≈øt comming, and ends at his la≈øt comming againe; which becau≈øe it is the la≈øt period, it is here compared to a weeke: 3 But I ≈øhall giue that holy towne to two witne≈ø≈øes of mine, who clothed with ≈øackecloth, ≈øhall prophe≈øie the ≈øpace of one thou≈øand two hundred and three≈øcore dayes; for the≈øe my ≈øucce≈ø≈øours he ≈øhall rai≈øe vp as witne≈ø≈øes, to wit, a ≈øufficient number of them, (for out of the mouth of two or three witne≈ø≈øes, euery word is confirmed) to witne≈ø≈øe that their doctrine is fal≈øe, who per≈øecute the Church which he ≈øhal giue vnto them, for he ≈øhall make them their patrons, to defend and feed them by the power of the true word, and they ≈øhall preach repentance to that counterfeit Church; and therefore they are ≈øaid to be clothed in ≈øackecloth. And to a≈ø≈øure vs to our great comfort, that in all the time of blindne≈ø≈øe, God ≈øhall euer be rai≈øing vp ≈øome of the≈øe two witne≈ø≈øes again≈øt the hypocriticall De≈øtroyer, and to comfort and confirme his true Church, it is ≈øaid, They ≈øhall prophe≈øie the number of dayes that yee haue heard, which is corre≈øpondent iu≈øtly to the moneths before mentioned, to wit, they ≈øhall not leaue off to witne≈ø≈øe, all the time of the Antichri≈øtian kingdome. 4 The≈øe witne≈øne≈ø≈øes, are two greene Oliues, who anoint the Elect with that holy oyle; and two Candle≈øtickes (as Chri≈øt ≈øaid, to enlighten the world with their brightne≈ø≈øe) who are ≈øet downe, and doe their office, in the pre≈øence of him, who is Lord and ruler of the earth. 5 And if any ≈øhal pre≈ø≈øe to harme them, fire ≈øhall come out of their mouthes, and deuoure their enemies;
for who≈øoeuer will doe them any hurt, him≈øelfe mu≈øt be ≈ølaine ≈øo, to wit, the holy Spirit, who is the fire in their mouth, ≈øhall accu≈øe and cau≈øe to be de≈øtroyed with the ≈øecond death, all them that either per≈øecute them, or will not heare, or obey their doctrine: 6 The≈øe witne≈ø≈øes haue power to ≈øhut heauen, that it raine not in the dayes of their prophe≈øie; and they haue power ouer the waters, to turne them into blood, and to ≈øtrike the earth with euery kinde of plague, ≈øo often as they plea≈øe; for hee ≈øhall authorize them and their me≈ø≈øage, with as ≈øure te≈øtimonies, as the ≈øhutting of the heauen, and ≈øtay of the raine was vnto Elias, ≈øo long as he fore≈øpake it ≈øhould be ≈øo; and as vnto Moy≈øes, the turning of the waters into blood, and the ≈øtriking of the earth of the land of Egypt, with diuers and ≈øundry plagues: 7 But the≈øe ≈øhall be witne≈ø≈øes, by their death as well as by their life: For how ≈øoone any of them ≈øhall haue runne that cour≈øe in the earth, which God hath appointed them, they ≈øhall be per≈øecuted, ouercome, and ≈ølaine by that bea≈øt, the Angel of that bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, and king of the locu≈øts, and that great towne & ≈øeat of the Monarchy ≈øhal publikely put them down, as malefactours: 8 So as their dead bodies or carkei≈øes ≈øhall lie in the ≈øtreets thereof: And this towne is ≈øpiritually called Sodom, becau≈øe of the ≈øpirituall adultery, to wit, Idolatrie that it ≈øhall commit and maintaine; and ≈øpiritually Egypt, becau≈øe it ≈øhall oppre≈ø≈øe and intollerably burthen the ≈øoules of the cho≈øen, euen as Egypt captiuated the bodies, and burthened the backes of the people of I≈ørael, and in that towne al≈øo was our Lord crucified; for where Chri≈øts members are put to death for their Ma≈øters cau≈øe, (as this towne and Kings therof ≈øhal do) there is Chri≈øt him≈øelfe crucified in effect, and his crucifying ≈øhalbe as wel imputed to them, as to Iudas who betrayed him: 9 And men of all tribes, peoples, tongues, and nations, ≈øhall ≈øee their carkei≈øes the ≈øpace of three dayes and a halfe, and they ≈øhall not be ≈øuffered to be buried in ≈øepulchres: 10 And the inhabitants of the earth ≈øhall be glad and reioyce for their ≈ølaughters, and ≈øhall ≈øend gifts one to another, in token of ioy, becau≈øe they are made quit of the≈øe two prophets, who tormented the indwellers of the earth; for the whole world, who are not in Sancto Sanctorum, ≈øhall not onely ≈øuffer, but allow that the≈øe witne≈ø≈øes be not onely ≈ølaine, but al≈øo be ≈øo cruelly v≈øed an contemned, as not to be ≈øuffered to be buried among≈øt others: And the whole earth ≈øhall reioyce at their death; becau≈øe that euen as Achab blamed Elias for troubling of I≈ørael, ≈øo ≈øhall the world thinke the≈øe witne≈ø≈øes trouble≈øome vnto them, becau≈øe they di≈øcouer vnto them their ≈øhamefulne≈ø≈øe, and call them to the repentance thereof. 11 And thus ≈øhall they be contemned for the ≈øpace of three dayes and a halfe, to wit, of three yeeres and a halfe; which ≈øignifies, that during the ≈øpace of the Antichri≈øts reigne, they ≈øhall be thus v≈øed; but after the ≈øpace of three dayes and an halfe, the Spirit of life comming from God, ≈øhall enter into them, and they ≈øhall be ≈øet vpon their feete, and a great feare ≈øhall fall vpon them that did ≈øee them before: 12 And they heard a great voice from the heauen, ≈øaying vnto them, Come
vp bither, then they a≈øcended vp into heauen, and their enemies ≈øaw them doe ≈øo; for although that during the flouri≈øhing of this hereticall and bypocriticall Monarchie, the trew Pa≈øtours no ≈øooner appeared, then they were put to death, yet at the la≈øt this Monarchie ≈øhall begin to decay, when the three yeeres, or the three dayes and an halfe thereof ≈øhall be expired: and then ≈øhall the Spirit of life from God, to wit, the holy Spirit ≈øent from God, worke mightier in the latter Pa≈øtours of the≈øe dayes, ≈øo as in them ≈øhall the by-pa≈øt Martyrs be reuiued, and their doctrine ≈øhall take roote in the hearts of many, and their rea≈øons ≈øhalbe ≈øo pithie, as the Antichri≈øtian ≈øect, and the re≈øt of the world ≈øhall know as perfectly that they ≈øhall preuaile, as if they heard God call them to heauen, to reward them there for their victory: Neither ≈øhall they haue power of their liues, for God ≈øhall mooue the hearts of many to defend them in ≈øuch glory and ≈øafetie, as if they were mounting vp to heauen in a cloud, and they not able to hinder them. 13 And then at that time ≈øhall be a great earthquake, to wit, great tumults among nations, and the tenth part of the citie ≈øhall fall: This citie is diuided in tenne parts, to ≈øhew it is the ≈øame Monarchie that ≈øhall afterwards be de≈øcribed by a bea≈øt with ten heads: And by the falling of the tenth part thereof, is meant, that diuers nations ≈øhall ≈øhake off the yoke of that Monarchie, and ≈øo a part of the ≈øtrength of that citie ≈øhall decay; and there was ≈ølaine in that earthquake, ≈øeuen thou≈øand men, to wit, a great number of men ≈øhal be ≈ølaine in the≈øe tumults, and the re≈øt were afraid, and gaue glory vnto the God of Heauen, for the≈øe tumults and iudgements of God, ≈øhall by their terrours reduce ≈øome to the knowledge of the trewth. 14 The ≈øecond woe is pa≈øt, for the≈øe are the plagues of the ≈øixt Trumpet, and loe, the third woe comes ≈øoone; for next followes the declaration of the≈øe dayes, wherein the con≈øummation ≈øhall be, fir≈øt of that Antichri≈øtian kingdome, and next of the whole earth; take therefore good heede vnto the third woe, for it is the la≈øt. 15 Then the ≈øeuenth Angel blew, and there were great voices in heauen, ≈øaying, The kingdomes of the world are made the kingdomes of our Lord, and of his Chri≈øt, who ≈øhall reigne for euer and euer. This ioyfull cry was in heauen, becau≈øe the dayes were come wherein the day of Iudgement ≈øhould be, and ≈øo the power was to be taken from the kings of the earth, who were enemies to the Saints, and Chri≈øt was hereafter to be the great, ≈øole, and immediate King ouer all. 16 Then the foure and twentie Elders, who ≈øate vpon ≈øeats in the ≈øight and pre≈øence of God, for ioy that the ≈øaluation of their brethren was at hand, did fall vpon their faces, and adored God, ≈øaying, 17 We thanke thee Lord God Almightie, who is, and who was, and who art pre≈øently to come againe, becau≈øe now thou art to make thy great power manife≈øt, and art to begin thy glorious Kingdome. 18 And the Gentiles waxed wrathfull, for all the wicked now perceiue, that neither their force nor craft can auaile; for thy wrath is now come which none may re≈øi≈øt, and the time of the dead is come, for now all the dead are to be iudged, and thou art to reward thy
≈øeruants the Prophets, and all the Saints, and all that feare thy Name, ≈ømall or great, and thou art to de≈øtroy them that de≈øtroy the earth, by the per≈øecuting of thy Saints, and defiling it with euery ≈øort of vice. 19 Then the Temple of God was open in heauen, that the Arke of his couenant might be ≈øeene, which was within it: God now did ≈øhew the Arke of his couenant, to a≈ø≈øure all the Saints that he would now haue mind of his promi≈øe, and according thereto would pre≈øently ≈øend downe Chri≈øt to Iudge the earth, as was done then in all terrour; which is ≈øignified by lightning, voices, thunder, and earthquakes, which then were made; and a great haile, which ≈øignifies the de≈øtruction of the earth, as ≈øhowres of haile of all others, are the mo≈øt harmefull and de≈øtroying.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

p.hi: A new vi≈øion: The deuils malice against Chri≈øt and his Church: The Church by Gods prouidence e≈øcapes his furie: Shee is ≈øecret, and lies hid for a ≈øpace: The deuill rai≈øeth vp here≈øies and per≈øecutions to de≈øtroy her; but all that cannot preuaile; whereupon he goeth to rai≈øe vp her great enemie the Pope.

div.p:
NOw as this ≈øeuenth Seale, wherein the≈øe ≈øeuen Trumpets were (which ye haue pre≈øently heard declared) was no other thing, but the more ample dilating of the ≈øixe former Seales, (as I did ≈øhew before) ≈øo this vi≈øion which I am next to declare vnto you, is nothing el≈øe but a cleerer ≈øetting forth, and fore-warning of the≈øe times, which are mo≈øt perillous for the Church of all them which are to come after, e≈øpecially of the three la≈øt woes. 1 And there was a great ≈øigne, and a woonderfull vi≈øion ≈øeene in heauen, to wit, a woman clothed with the Sunne, and the Moone was vnder her feete, and ≈øhe had a crowne of twelue ≈øtarres vpon her head, 2 And ≈øhe was great with childe, and ≈øhee was ≈øo neere her childbirth, as ≈øhe was alreadie crying, and was ≈øore pained with the trauell to be deliuered of her childe: 3 And there was al≈øo another ≈øigne, and woonder ≈øeene in heauen; A great red dragon hauing ≈øeuen heads, and ten hornes, and vpon his head ≈øeuen diamonds: 4 And his taile drew the third part of the ≈øtarres of heauen with him, and did ca≈øt them downe to the earth: This dragon ≈øtood before the woman, awaiting to deuoure her birth ≈øo ≈øoone as ≈øhee was deliuered of it: 5 But ≈øhe brought forth a manchilde, who was to rule all nations with a rod of yron, and her ≈øonne was caught vp to God, and his Throne: 6 But the woman fled into the wilderne≈ø≈øe, where ≈øhe hath a place prepared by God, that ≈øhe might be fedde there the ≈øpace of one thou≈øand two hundred three≈øcore dayes. 7 And there was a great battell ≈øtroken in heauen, for Michael and his Angels fought again≈øt the dragon and his angels: 8 And the dragon and his angels
could not obtaine the victorie, but by the contrary their place was no more found in heauen: 9 And ≈øo that great dragon, to wit, that olde ≈øerpent who is called the deuill and Satan, who ≈øeduceth the whole face of the earth, was ca≈øt downe to the earth, and all his angels were ca≈øt downe with him. 10 And I heard a voice in heauen, ≈øaying, Now is wrought the health, the vertue, and the kingdome of our God, and the power of his Chri≈øt; for the accu≈øer of our brethren is ca≈øt downe, who day and night accu≈øed them in the ≈øight of our God: 11 For they that fought with him, haue ouercome him, for the loue they beare vnto the Lambe and his blood, and to the word of his Te≈øtimonie, and haue prodigally giuen their liues euen vnto death for that cau≈øe: 12 Therefore reioyce ye heauens, and yee that dwell therein; but woe to the inhabitants of the earth, and the ≈øea, for the deuill is come downe to you, and he is full of great wrath, becau≈øe he hath but a ≈øhort ≈øpace to reigne. 13 And when the dragon ≈øaw him≈øelfe ca≈øt down vpoÃÑ the earth, he pur≈øued the woman who had borne the manchild: 14 But there was giuen to the woman two great Eagle wings, that ≈øhee might flee from the ≈øight of the ≈øerpent into the wildernes, to the place that was there appointed for her to be nouri≈øhed for a time & times, and halfe a time. 15 Then the ≈øerpent did ca≈øt out of his mouth after the woman to ouertake her, a water like a great flood, to carry her away perforce: 16 But the earth helped the woman, and opened her mouth, and ≈øwallowed vp by the way the great flood which the dragon had ca≈øt out of his mouth: This part of the Vi≈øion was to declare vnto me, that how≈øoeuer the Church, which is ≈øignified here by a woman, (for ≈øhe is the ≈øpou≈øe of CHRIST, who is her head, her husband, and her glory, obeying him with a reuerent loue, and yet weake and infirme like to a woman) how ≈øoone, I ≈øay, the Church ≈øhining in all brightne≈ø≈øe and innocencie, which is repre≈øented by her garment of the Sunne, and treading vnder feete, and contemning the world and the vanities thereof, here ≈øignified by the Moone, being vnder her feet; a Planet that hath no proper, but a borrowed light, and ≈øubiect to all mutabilitie, like the world, and being crowned with the ≈øhining glory of the twelue Patriarches and Prophets, and the twelue holy Apo≈øtles, ≈øucceeding them in the vnitie of doctrine, and therefore are called here a Crowne of twelue ≈øtarres vpon her head; How ≈øoone, I ≈øay, that ≈øhe thus arayed did bring forth CHRIST in the fle≈øh, who is that man-child, who rules the Gentiles with an Iron rod, as Dauid ≈øaith in his P≈øalmes: That great red and ancient Dragon, for in our fir≈øt forefather he vttered his malice, to wit, the diuell, who is ruler of infinite numbers of men, which is ≈øignified by his ≈øeuen heads, and ≈øeuen diadems, or Crownes vpon them, and who hath innumerable meanes and in≈øtruments to be executors of his malicious will, which is ≈øignified by the tenne hornes, alluding to Daniel; and who is ≈øo mighty in deceipt, that he doeth not onely allure the infidels to follow him, but euen a part of the Pa≈øtours, and the vi≈øible Church to their de≈øtruction, which is ≈øignified by his drawing after him with his taile as followers
of his inti≈øements, the third part of the Starres of heauen, and ca≈øting them to the earth: This dragon hauing waited to de≈øtroy her birth, and for earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe gaping for it before it was borne, and not able to preuaile, but by the contrary ≈øeeing CHRITS ri≈øing from the dead, and then his a≈øcending into heauen, which is ≈øignified by the Childs pulling vp to GOD and his Throne, and ≈øeeing the Church to flouri≈øh, though vnder per≈øecution, which is ≈øignified by her flying to a place in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, which God had prepared for her, where thereafter ≈øhe mu≈øt lurke for the ≈øpace of the dayes ye heard reckoned, to wit, the Church ≈øhalbe vnknowne, and as it were vnregarded, and no man ≈øhall know how it ≈øhalbe ≈øu≈øtained; for GOD ≈øhall nouri≈øh it the ≈øpace of the Antichri≈øts kingdome, which is the number of dayes ye heard counted before: The Dragon, I ≈øay, hauing found this, that both CHRIST and his Church did e≈øcape his hands, and not onely that, but that him≈øelfe al≈øo by the vertue of CHRISTS renewing of vs, was no moreable to accu≈øe the Saints of God, as he did in time of the old Law, ≈øince now we are made righteous, which is ≈øignified by the battell in heauen, where GOD, to declare that none is like vnto him, made CHRIST, here called Michael, (who≈øe name imports, Who is like GOD) with his Angels, to fight and ouercome the diuel and his angels, and to ca≈øt them on the earth; Satan, I ≈øay, finding him≈øelfe thus debarred from further accu≈øing of the Saints, hauing found that he ≈øhould neuer haue place to doe that in any time thereafter; as on the one part it reioyced all the Angels and Saints in heauen, for their bretherens cau≈øe on the earth, as is witne≈ø≈øed by the ≈øong that the voyce did ≈øing in Heauen, prai≈øing God therefore, and extolling the deed of Michael and his Angels, who fought ≈øo earne≈øtly for the Saints on earth, as if they had bene mortall, they would not haue ≈øpared their liues in that cau≈øe for their ≈øakes, whom CHRIST had redeemed with his blood, and of who≈øe clection he had borne witne≈ø≈øe to his Father; ≈øo on the other part it enraged the Dragon, ≈øo that he became the crueller tempter of men vpon the earth, a≈øwell for that his place of accu≈øing in heauen was taken away, by the my≈øterie of the redemption which is ≈øignified by this fight, as for that he knew within ≈øhort ≈øpace he was by CHRISTS ≈øecond comming, to be ca≈øt downe from the earth into hell, there to be chained in eternall captiuitie and mi≈øery, euen as by the fir≈øt comming he was ca≈øt from the heauen, which is ≈øignified by the la≈øt part of the Song, ≈øo as he pur≈øueth the Church with here≈øie and ciuil powers, which both are ≈øignified by the floods of waters which he ≈øpewed out of his mouth, after that the Eagle wings were giuen the woman to flie to that place appointed for her in the wildernes, where ≈øhe mu≈øt remaine the number of dayes ye haue heard, to wit, after that God had giuen his Church a ≈øufficient ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe to e≈øchew the rage of Satan, and to lurke the ≈øpace of Antichri≈øts raigne, which la≈øteth three times or three yeeres and a halfe, that is, a time prefixed by GOD, and vnknowne to men, as ye haue ≈øundry times heard already. But ≈øeeing that all this vani≈øheth, as if the earth had
≈øwallowed and dried vp that flood ≈øuddenly. 17 The Dragon therefore or the diuel, became more wrathfull and enraged then before again≈øt the woman, or the Church, and went about by ≈øome other way, to make warre again≈øt the re≈øt of the womans ≈øeed, who kept the Commandements of GOD, and had the te≈øtimonies of CHRIST to GOD the Father, that they were cho≈øen and called, for the≈øe are onely the true po≈øteritie of the Church, to wit, the ≈øucce≈ø≈øours in grace, faith, and trewth. 18 And I ≈øtood vpon the Sea ≈øhore, I meane, it ≈øeemed to me that I ≈øtood vpon the Sea ≈øhore, becau≈øe I did wait to ≈øee come out of it, which repre≈øented all peoples and nations, ≈øuch powers, as Satan would imploy to fight again≈øt the Church; for the declaring whereof this Vi≈øion was ≈øhewen vnto me, and whereof the≈øe two la≈øt great wonders were but the introduction, that by the≈øe things pa≈øt, as the roote, I might the better vnder≈øtand the branches, which are to bud forth thereof as followeth.
