p.hi: The Popes ari≈øing: His de≈øcription: His ri≈øing cau≈øed by the ruine of the fourth Monarchie the Romane Empire: The ri≈øing of the fal≈øe and Papisticall Church; her de≈øcription; her conformitie with her Monarch the Pope: The great reuerence borne to the Pope by many nations, and not onely to him, but to his Legates: A generall defection ≈øo great, as there ≈øhall not be an other vi≈øible Church, but the Popedome: Of the first Pope who did take to him≈øelfe all their blasphemous and arrogant ≈øtyles.

div.p:
ANd then I ≈øaw a bea≈øt ri≈øing out of the Sea, to wit, from among the number of Nations and peoples; I ≈øaw a Monarchie cho≈øen and erected vp by this Dragon the deuil, and it had ≈øeuen heads and tenne hornes, and tenne diadems vpon the tenne hornes: the ≈øignification of the≈øe heads and hornes, was declared vnto me by an Angel, as ye ≈øhall heare in the place conuenient hereafter, Chap. 17. and vpon the≈øe heads was the name of blasphemie: for they by the per≈øecution of the Saints, and adoring fal≈øe gods, ≈øhall both by word and deed bla≈øpheme the name of the Eternall. 2 This bea≈øt or Monarchie, Daniel 7. is the fourth King or Monarchie wherof Daniel prophe≈øied, to wit, euen that Monarchie which pre≈øently reignes, and hath the power of the other three reuiued in it, for it is farre greater then they: And therefore as that Monarchie of the Leopard, gat that name becau≈øe of the ≈øwiftnes of the conque≈øt: and that of the Lion, becau≈øe of the mightines and cruelty therof: and that of the Beare, becau≈øe of the ≈øtrength and long ≈øtanding thereof; ≈øo this is called like the Leopard, to wit, in ≈øhape, whereof commeth her agilitie: headed like a Lion, becau≈øe his ≈øtrength is in the head, as ye heard already: and legged like a beare, becau≈øe
in the Beares legges con≈øi≈øts his greate≈øt ≈øtrength, and durablene≈ø≈øe; this proportion ≈øignifies, that this Monarchie is farre greater then all the re≈øt, and all their powers are reuiued in it, as I ≈øaid before. 3 And I perceiued that one of the heads of the bea≈øt, had bene deadly wounded, but the wound thereof was healed, and the whole earth followed this bea≈øt with a great wondering; this was to ≈øignifie vnto me, that it was not of this bea≈øt that I was ordained to forewarne you, for the wor≈øt of this bea≈øt is almo≈øt pa≈øt already, and this Monarchie ≈øhall be within ≈øhort ≈øpace de≈øtroyed, but this bea≈øt or Monarchie is ≈øhewen vnto me, becau≈øe out of the ruines thereof ≈øhall ri≈øe in that ≈øame Seate where it was, that hereticall Monarchie whereof I am to forewarne you, which is ≈øignified by the deadly wound it gat on the head which was healed againe: for as the Phaenix reuiues of her owne a≈øhes (as prophane ≈øtories make mention) ≈øo out of the a≈øhes of this Empire ≈øhall ri≈øe and be reuiued an other, which ≈øhall grow ≈øo mighty, that the whole earth that is without Sanctum Sanctorum, ≈øhall with ama≈øement reuerence, obey and follow it, as ye heard pre≈øently declared. 4 And they adored the Dragon who gaue power to the Bea≈øt, for they ≈øhall giue them≈øelues ouer to the workes of darkenes, which is to ≈øerue, and adore the diuel, who rai≈øed vp this bea≈øt to make warre again≈øt the ≈øeed of the woman, Chap. 12. as ye heard before. And they al≈øo adored the diuel in his in≈øtrument, by reuerencing that Bea≈øt and Monarchie erected by him: and they ≈øaid, Who is like vnto the Bea≈øt, or who may fight with him? for this Monarchie ≈øhall be ≈øo ≈øtrong in worldly power, as the world ≈øhall thinke it ≈øo farre in ≈øtrength aboue all other powers, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to ouercome it, e≈øpecially, that the little ≈øtone which was cut without hands out of the mountaine mentioned by Daniel, Daniel 2. ≈øhall euer de≈øtroy it, which notwith≈øtanding at the la≈øt ≈øhall brui≈øe it in pieces. 5 And there was a mouth giuen vnto it to ≈øpeake great things and bla≈øphemies; It is ≈øaid in Daniel, Daniel 7.11. that his mouth ≈øhall ≈øpeake in magnificencie, and vtter words again≈øt the Soueraigne, to wit, this Monarchie and King thereof, ≈øhall extoll him≈øelfe farre aboue all liuing creatures, and ≈øhal v≈øurpe farre higher Styles then euer were heard of before, by the which, and by his fal≈øe doctrine together, he ≈øhall ≈øo derogate from the honour of GOD, and v≈øurpe ≈øo all power onely proper vnto him, as it ≈øhall bee great wordes again≈øt him, and bla≈øphemie of his Name. And there was power giuen him to doe, to wit, GOD ≈øhall permit his Tyrannie to encrea≈øe, and per≈øecute the Saints the ≈øpace of two and fourtie moneths: This ≈øpace was mentioned vnto me, to let me know thereby, that this Monarchie ri≈øen out of the ruines of the other, Chap. 11. is the ≈øame which is meant by that Citie, whereof ye heard alreadie in the ≈øixt Trumpet, which per≈øecuted the two Witne≈ø≈øes; for the ≈øame ≈øpace is a≈ø≈øigned to her there, and con≈øequently it is that ≈øame ≈øeate and Monarchie which is meant by the angel of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, Chap. 9. called Apollyon in the fift Trumpet: by the Rider on the pale hor≈øe, Chap. 6. called Death, in the fourth Seale, and al≈øo ob≈øcurely meant in
the ≈øixt Trumpet by the halfe of that great ho≈øte of hor≈øemen, Chap. 9. of the which halfe the armed hor≈øe which I ≈øaw in the vi≈øion, was a part of the power, who≈øe head and Monarchie was the plague for idolatry, as ye heard; which Monarchie, together with the other (of whom yee al≈øo heard ob≈øcurely in that place, as the plague of the ≈øinnes again≈øt the ≈øecond Table) to wit, this great bea≈øt here mentioned, and the other reuealed, a vowed and open enemie of Chri≈øts Church, ≈øhall both gather their forces to fight again≈øt it in that battell of the great day of the Lord, Chap. 16. whereof ye ≈øhal heare in the owne place: Then this bea≈øt, according to the power which was giuen him, opened his mouth in bla≈øphemies again≈øt God, and ≈øpake iniurious words again≈øt his Name, his Tabernacle, to wit, his Sanctum Sanctorum, which is the Church militant, and them that dwell in heauen; for his reigne ≈øhall be ≈øo great, that hee ≈øhall not onely bla≈øpheme the Name of God, in ≈øuch ≈øort as ye heard alreadie, and per≈øecute the members of Chri≈øt that ≈øhall be on the earth in his dayes, but likewi≈øe vpbraid with calumnies the ≈øoules of the Saints departed: 7 And for that effect he was permitted by God to make warre again≈øt the Saints; and hee gaue him power to ouercome them corporally, and to rule ouer all tribes, tongues, and nations; ≈øo great ≈øhall his Monarchie and power be: 8 And ≈øo all the in-dwellers of the earth ≈øhal adore him, to wit, a great part of them ≈øhall reuerence him, who≈øe names are not writen in the booke of life, which is the Lambes that was ≈ølaine, which booke was written before the foundation of the world was laide; for the≈øe are alwayes excepted from bowing their knees to Baal, who were prede≈øtinate by Chri≈øt to ≈øaluation before all beginnings. 9 He who hath an eare, let him heare and take heede vnto this ≈øentence that followeth, to wit, 10 If any man leade in captiuitie, in captiuitie ≈øhall he be led againe: if any man ≈ølay with the ≈øword, with the ≈øword ≈øhall hee be ≈ølaine againe: then ≈øince ye are a≈ø≈øured, that God in his good time ≈øhall iu≈øtly mete to their tyrannie, the ≈øame mea≈øure that they ≈øhall mete to his Church, let not your hearts in your affliction, through de≈øpaire of Gods reuenge, (becau≈øe of his long ≈øuffering) ≈øwarue from the bold and plaine profe≈ø≈øing of his trueth; for in this ≈øhall the patience and con≈øtant faith of the Saints or the cho≈øen, be tried. 11 And then I ≈øaw another bea≈øt ri≈øe vp vpon the earth, and it had two hornes like vnto the Lambe, but it ≈øpake like the dragon, for le≈øt this Monarchie ≈øhould be taken to be a ruler onely ouer the body, and that I might vnder≈øtand the contrary, to wit, that he was ≈øpecially a ≈øpirituall tyrant ouer the ≈øoules and con≈øciences of men, this other bea≈øt was ≈øhewen vnto me, which repre≈øenteth the hereticall kingdome of the gra≈øhoppers, whereof Apollyon was made King in the fift Trumpet; Chap. 9. and it v≈øeth the coloured authoritie of Chri≈øt, by pretending two ≈øwords, or two keyes, as receiued from Chri≈øt, which is ≈øignified by the two hornes like the Lambes, but the end whereof it v≈øeth that authoritie, is to get obedience to that fal≈øe doctrine which it teacheth, ≈øignified by ≈øpeaking like the dragon or deuil. 12 It is this fal≈øe and hypocriticall Church then, which doeth exerci≈øe all
the power of the former bea≈øt, to wit, teacheth the Kings of this Monarchy and ≈øeat, by what meanes they ≈øhall allure and compell the people to obey their commands; and this Church ≈øhall al≈øo enti≈øe the earth and the inhabitants of the ≈øame, to wit, all nations which beleeue the fal≈øe doctrine that it teacheth, to adore this other bea≈øt, who≈øe deadly wound was healed; for it ≈øhall per≈øwade them that this hereticall Monarchie ought for con≈øcience ≈øake to be obeyed by all per≈øons, in what≈øoeuer it commandeth, as if it could not erre: 13 And to per≈øwade men thereof, it makes great ≈øignes or wonders, yea euen cau≈øeth fire to fall out of heauen vpon earth in the ≈øight of men; vpon whom, becau≈øe they ≈øhall ≈øwarue from the loue of the trewth to beleeue lies, God ≈øhall iu≈øtly by the meanes of this fal≈øe Church, as his in≈øtrument of reuenge, ≈øend a ≈øtrong illu≈øion and deceit, with great efficacie of miracles and woonders, 2. Then ≈øince you ≈øee that this defection ≈øhall be ≈øo generall, beware of euery one that ≈øhall ≈øay, Lord, Lord, thereby to deceiue you, for you ≈øee by this, that fal≈øe prophets ≈øhall for a time ≈øo triumph, as they ≈øhall vaunt them≈øelues to be the trew Church, becau≈øe there ≈øhall be no other Church vi≈øible at that time, although there ≈øhall euer be≈øome that ≈øhall not bow their knee to Baal; for the woman ≈øhall not be deuoured by the dragon, 1. Kings. 19. Chap. 12. but hid and nouri≈øhed in the wilderne≈ø≈øe out of ≈øight for a ≈øpace, as ye heard before. Retaine well in memorie the≈øe words, for the time ≈øhall come in the latter dayes, that this doctrine ≈øhall be thornes in the eyes of many. 18 Now, as to the number of the bea≈øt here is wi≈øedome, let him that is endued with knowledge number it, for the number of the bea≈øt or Monarchie, is the number of the man, to wit, of the fir≈øt Monarch of this ≈øeat, who ≈øhall fir≈øt v≈øurpe all the≈øe ≈øtyles of bla≈øphemie, and who in the fourth Monarchie ≈øhall reuiue a ≈øpirituall ≈øupremacie and tyrannie; and his number, to wit, the date of yeeres that he ≈øhall begin to reigne, in reckoning from the time of this Reuelation, is ≈øixe hundred ≈øixtie and ≈øixe. Benedictus the 2. Platine.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII.

p.hi: The happie estate of the faithfull in the meane time of the Popes Tyrannie: His destruction: The faithfull onely are all ≈øaued.

div.p:
NOw ≈øo ≈øoone as the tyrannicall gouernment of the≈øe two bea≈øts, to wit, the fal≈øe church and their king had bene declared by this la≈øt Vi≈øion vnto me, euen as before, after the denouncing of the fearefulle≈øt plagues, the happy e≈øtate of Chri≈øt and his Church was declared to comfort me, as ye heard before; ≈øo now the plagues that are to be wrought by this ≈øpirituall Tyrannie being declared, the e≈øtate of Chri≈øt and his followers in the meane time is next ≈øet forth as followeth. Then I did looke, and loe I ≈øaw the Lambe ≈øtanding vpon Mount Sion, and with him a hundred fourtie and foure thou≈øand, hauing the Name of his Father written vpon their foreheads: for in the meane time that this Tyrannie was raging on the earth, this Lambe Chri≈øt was ≈øtanding vpon Mount Sion, to wit, vpon his holy place, out of which he promi≈øed ≈øaluation to the faithfull, as Dauid ≈øaith, and is accompanied with this great number of faithfull, which number was compo≈øed of twelue thou≈øand of euery Tribe, as ye heard before; but this number comprehends in this place all the faithfull, a≈øwell of Gentiles as of Iewes, although it ≈øeeme to be vnder≈øtood of the Iewes onely, which is done for continuing of the Metaphore, becau≈øe as Sanctum Sanctorum, which was a part of the materiall Temple of Ieru≈øalem, did ≈øignifie before
all the faithfull, as ye haue heard, ≈øo now this number of Iewes here, ≈øignifies the faithfull, both of Gentiles and Iewes, as I haue ≈øaid, who now are de≈øcribed here making publike profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, by bearing his marke on their forehead, an eminent part, euen as the wicked beare on their forehead the Character of their king, the angel of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit: The≈øe faithfull followers of Chri≈øt did beare now his Marke, to te≈øtifie thereby, that they were pre≈øerued by it, euen in the very time that this Tyrannie was raging all the fa≈øte≈øt. 2 And I heard a voyce from heauen like the ≈øound of many waters in greatne≈ø≈øe, and like the roaring of the thunder in terriblene≈ø≈øe; And I al≈øo heard the voyce of many harpers playing on their harpes, 3 And ≈øinging as it were a New-≈øong, before the Throne, and before the foure Bea≈øts, and the Elders, and none could learne that Song, except the≈øe hundred foure and fourtie thou≈øand, to wit, the≈øe who are bought from the earth: for they who were bought and redeemed by the precious Blood of Chri≈øt, from among the re≈øt of the world, and ≈øo were no more of their number, were onely able to learne and vnder≈øtand the≈øe voyces, for vnto them onely it apperteineth: Where fir≈øt God promi≈øed, that he ≈øhould ≈øhortly de≈øtroy that Tyrannie, (which voyce of God is here de≈øcribed by re≈øembling it to the ≈øound of many waters, as Dauid doeth, and to the roaring of the thunder;) And where next the thankes thereof is giuen by the Saints and Angels in ≈øinging the prai≈øes of God, as earne≈øtly, and cheerefully, as if it were but a New-≈øong, and to repre≈øent the harmonie thereof, they ≈øing to the concords of the harpes and in≈øtruments in the pre≈øence of God ≈øitting in his Maie≈øtie, and compa≈ø≈øed about with the foure Bea≈øtes, and foure and twentie Elders, of whom ye heard mention made before. 4 The≈øe attendants on the Lambe, are the≈øe who are not defiled with women, to wit, not guiltie of ≈øpirituall adulterie, for they are Virgines, as Chri≈øt called them in the parable of the Lampes: the≈øe follow the Lambe whither≈øoeuer he goeth, for they goe not a≈øtray from his foot≈øteps, neither to the right, nor the left hand, and tho≈øe are they who are bought from among men, and are the acceptable fir≈øt fruits vnto their Father, and his Lambe. 5 And in their mouthes was found no guile, for they are inculpable before the Throne of God, becau≈øe the Lambe hath fully payd their debts for them. 6 Then I did ≈øee another Angel flying through the midde≈øt of heauen, hauing the Eternall Euangel in his hand, that he might preach the ≈øame to all the inhabitants of the earth, euen to all nations, tribes, tongues, and peoples: for euen as ye heard before in the ≈øixt Trumpet, of the reuiuing againe of the two Witne≈ø≈øes, who were ≈ølaine by this tyrannicall and hereticall Monarchie, ≈øo now the ≈øame was declared vnto me by this Angel, who when this Tyrannie is in the greate≈øt pride, as ye haue heard, flies through the midde≈øt of heauen to be publikely heard and ≈øeene by all, hauing with him the≈øe eternall glad tidings to preach them to all the earth, to wit, God ≈øhall in the end of this Tyrannie, while it is yet triumphing, rai≈øe vp and ≈øend his Angels or me≈ø≈øengers,
who ≈øhall publikely teach the trewth, and refute the errours of this tyrannie before the eyes of the Sunne and the Moone, to the ≈øaluation of a part of euery countrey, and to double condemnation of the re≈øt through making them inexcu≈øable, who wil not turne in time. 7 And their exhortation ≈øhalbe this, which then I heard the Angel ≈øay with a lowd voyce; Feare God, and render him all glory, for the day of his iudgement comes at hand, adore him therefore who made heauen and earth, and ≈øeas, and fountaines of water, to wit, all things, good and euill: and the particular applications that the≈øe Witne≈ø≈øes ≈øhall make of this generall doctrine, to the times of corruption that they ≈øhall be in, ≈øhall be this that I heard two Angels folowing declare, of whom the fir≈øt ≈øaid; 8 It is fallen, It is fallen, Babylon that great City, becau≈øe ≈øhe gaue to al nations to drinke of the Vine of wrath, of her fornication or ≈øpiritual adulterie, to wit, that great Monarchie called Babylon, becau≈øe it leades and keepes the ≈øoules of men in ≈øpirituall thraldome, euen as the Monarchie of Babylon led, and kept the people of I≈ørael in a corporall captiuitie, that Monarchie, I ≈øay, ≈øhall be ≈øuddenly de≈øtroyed: for it is to be noted, that as there is no di≈øtinction of times in the pre≈øence of God, but all things are pre≈øent vnto him, ≈øo he and his Angels calleth oftentimes that thing done, that is ≈øhortly and certainly to be done thereafter, which forme of ≈øpeach ye wil ≈øundry times heare thus v≈øed hereafter; That Monarchie, I ≈øay then, ≈øhall ≈øhortly be de≈øtroyed, and that iu≈øtly, becau≈øe ≈øhe hath abu≈øed a great part of the earth, by inti≈øing them to be ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe (as if they were drunken,) and to embrace her errours and idolatries or ≈øpirituall whoredome: For as men are enti≈øed by whores to leaue their owne ≈øpou≈øe, and enter in to them, ≈øo ≈øhall they per≈øwade the nations to leaue their ≈øocietie with their ≈øpou≈øe IESVS CHRIST, and onely ≈øettle their ≈øaluation vpon her, and for the committing of this ≈øpirituall whoredome, this Monarchie is here called Shee, Chap. 17. and afterward the great Whore, and the rea≈øon that they ≈øhall giue why they make this warning, ≈øhall be in the≈øe words, which I heard the third Angel proclaime, to wit, 9 For who≈øoeuer ≈øhall adore this Bea≈øt any longer, or his image, or take his character on his forehead, or his hand, as ye heard before, 10 He ≈øhall for his iu≈øt reward and puni≈øhment, drinke of the Wine of the wrath of God, yea of the pure and immixed wine thereof, powred out in the cup of his wrath: And he ≈øhalbe tormented with fire and brim≈øtone, to wit, he ≈øhall be ca≈øt into hell, the torments whereof they doe ≈øignifie, and that in the pre≈øence of the holy Angels, for they ≈øhall beare witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt him in the ≈øight of the Lambe: for the Lambe ≈øhall iudge and condemne him: 11 And the ≈ømoake of his torments ≈øhall mount vp in all worlds to come, to wit, he ≈øhalbe vnce≈ø≈øantly tormented for euer: For all the≈øe that adore the Bea≈øt and his image, and hath the character of his name, ≈øhall not haue re≈øt day nor night, to wit, they ≈øhalbe perpetually tormented without any relea≈øe or reliefe. 12 And in the≈øe dayes when the Witne≈ø≈øes ≈øhalbe making this exhortation, in the≈øe things ≈øhall the con≈øtancie of the Saints or
faithfull be tried, and by this triall ≈øhall they be knowne and di≈øcerned, that ob≈øerue and retaine the Commandements of God, and the faith of Ie≈øus the Sauiour. 13 Then I heard a voice from heauen, ≈øaying to me, Write, Ble≈ø≈øed are the dead that die for the Lords cau≈øe hereafter, ≈øo ≈øayes the Spirit, for they re≈øt from their trauails, and their workes follow them: This voyce from heauen did by the≈øe wordes declare vnto me, that the≈øe Witne≈ø≈øes who ≈øhould make this exhortation that ye haue heard, ≈øhould be per≈øecuted therefore by that ≈øpirituall Babylon; but that the≈øe ≈øhould be happie≈øt, who lo≈øt their liues for ≈øo good a cau≈øe, for the confirmation whereof the holy Spirit ≈øayes, Yea, and ≈øubioynes the rea≈øon, to wit, becau≈øe both they re≈øt from the≈øe continuall labours and troubles, that they were alwayes ≈øubiect vnto in the earth, and in recompen≈øe thereof their workes follow them: for as faith is the onely leader of men to heauen, and ≈øo goes before them; ≈øo according to the greatne≈ø≈øe and honour of their calling in earth, if they di≈øcharge it well, they are rewarded in heauen with a mea≈øure of glory conformed thereunto; and ≈øo their workes follow them, to obtaine that mea≈øure in that place wherof they were already a≈ø≈øured by the meanes of faith in Chri≈øt onely. For although the Sunne, and the Moone, and the ≈øtarres be all bright lampes and lights of the heauen, yet are they not all alike bright, but the brightne≈ø≈øe of euery one of them is different from the other; Alwayes let vs a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues, that although our mea≈øures ≈øhall be vnequall, yet from the greate≈øt to the lea≈øt, all the ve≈ø≈øels of mercie ≈øhall enioy in all fulne≈ø≈øe, as much glory as they ≈øhalbe able to containe, and the vnequalitie of the mea≈øure ≈øhalbe, becau≈øe they are notable euery one of them to containe alike in quantitie; and the like ≈øhalbe done with the mea≈øures of paines to the reprobate in hell. 14 Then I beheld, and loe I ≈øaw a white cloud, and vpon the cloud ≈øate one like a man, hauing on his head a crowne of gold, and in his hand a ≈øharpe ≈øickle: 15 And an other Angel came out of the temple, & cried with a lowd voice to him that ≈øate vpon the cloud, Thru≈øt in thy ≈øickle to reape, for the houre of thy reaping is come, and the harue≈øt of the earth is withered for ripene≈ø≈øe, and readine≈ø≈øe to be cut: He who was like the Sunne of man, and was ≈øitting on a white cloud, was Chri≈øt in a bright cloud of glory, crowned with a Crowne of victory; all that was ≈øpoken of him here, was to declare to me, that the la≈øt dayes wherein his comming againe ≈øhalbe, ≈øhall be next following, to the reuealing of Babylon, by the reuiuing of the witne≈ø≈øes, as ye heard in the end of the ≈øixt Trumpet; 16 At what time Chri≈øt ≈øhall gather his harue≈øt of the elect together, as I heard him≈øelfe ≈øay while he was yet on earth among vs. 17 Then another Angel came forth of the Temple that is in heauen, and he had an other ≈øharp ≈øickle in his hand: 18 And an other Angel came from the Altar, who had power ouer the fire, and he cried with a lowd voice to him that had the other ≈øharpe ≈øickle, ≈øaying, Put downe thy ≈øharpe ≈øickle, and gather the clu≈øters of the Vine-trees, for the grapes are ripe. 19 Then the Angel put downe his ≈øickle on the earth, and gathered the Vines of the
earth, and ca≈øt them in the winepre≈ø≈øe of the wrath of God: For ≈øo ≈øoone as Chri≈øt hath gathered his harue≈øt together, then the reprobate are fully to be de≈øtroyed, as is declared here by the Anges command, who came from the Altar, to wit, as directed by Chri≈øt. Thi ‚Ä¢ Angel had power ouer the fire, to wit, he had direction to de≈øtroy, as he commanded, the me≈ø≈øenger of Gods plagues, who had the ≈øickle to doe it, who at his command cut the Vines and ca≈øt them in the great Winepre≈ø≈øe of Gods wrath, to wit, de≈øtroyed the reprobate in the abundance of the writh of God: 20 And the Winepre≈ø≈øe was troden without the Citie, and the blood came out of the Winepre≈ø≈øe, euen to the hor≈øe bridles, and ≈øpred to the bounds of one thou≈øand and ≈øixe hundred furlongs. This is ≈øurely a great comfort to all the cho≈øen, that notwith≈øtanding all the re≈øt of the world, except ≈øuch as are Chri≈øtes harue≈øt, whom he hath gathered together in the holy Citie, the re≈øt, I ≈øay, ≈øhalbe de≈øtroyed in ≈øuch a great number, as their blood ≈øhall of deepene≈ø≈øe come to the hor≈øe bridles, and ouerflow the whole land of Canaan, whereof the number of furlongs, or eight parts of miles, ye heard, is the length; Yet though it ouerflow the whole earth, which is ≈øignified by Canaan, it ≈øhalbe without the holy Citie which is in the midde≈øt of the land, to wit, although the trew Church ≈øhalbe in the midde≈øt of the world, as Ieru≈øalem was in Canaan, yet that de≈øtruction ≈øhall not make a haire of one of their heads to fall, but it ≈øhalbe without them, and they fully exempted from it, as the land of Go≈øhen was from the plagues of Egypt.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

p.hi: The faithfull prai≈øeth God for the Popes destruction, and their deliuerance: The plagues which are to light on him and his followers, is to be declared by the powring forth of the ≈øeuen Phials.

div.p:
THen I ≈øaw another ≈øigne in heauen, great and wonderfull, to wit, ≈øeuen Angels hauing the ≈øeuen la≈øt plagues, for by them is fulfilled the wrath of God; for the Spirit of God, hauing already declared vnto me the generall de≈øtruction of the whole world, which is without the holy citie, hee next declared vnto me, vnto my greater comfort, the particular plagues that are to light vpon ≈øpirituall Babylon, as a iu≈øt recompen≈øe of her ≈øinnes, and of the plagues that ≈øhee is to loade the earth withall; and the≈øe are the ≈øeuen hinmo≈øt which are in the hands of the ≈øeuen Angels, of whom there is here mention made. 2 And I ≈øaw as it had beene a gla≈ø≈øie Sea mixed with fire, and they that had wonne the victory ouer the bea≈øt, and ouer his image, or emba≈ø≈øadours, and his character and the number of his name, to wit, from that time that the la≈øt bea≈øt ro≈øe out of the ruines of the other, I ≈øaw the≈øe victours (I ≈øay) ≈øtanding aboue, or vpon this ≈øea of gla≈ø≈øe,
and they had the harpes of God: For now hauing declared on the one part how vnhappie the ≈øtate of Babylon ≈øhall be by the ≈øeuen la≈øt plagues, which ≈øhall fall vpon it; ≈øo on the other part, by the≈øe who ≈øtand on the ≈øea of gla≈ø≈øe mixed with fire, he declared vnto me what ≈øhould be the ble≈ø≈øed e≈øtate of the cho≈øen at that time that the≈øe plagues ≈øhall fall vpon Babylon, to wit, of the≈øe victours; for they ≈øhall reueale the Antichri≈øt and deface him, they ≈øhall hen behold the re≈øt of the world, which is here ≈øignified by the ≈øea of gla≈øe, and they ≈øhall haue the harpes of God, to wit, the prai≈øes of God in their mouthes, becau≈øe he hath mixed this gla≈ø≈øie ≈øea with fire, to wit, hath de≈øtroyed and made his iudgements to fall vpon this wicked world, as their ≈øorg which followes will declare: 3 And they ≈øung the ≈øong of Mo≈øes the ≈øeruant of God, & the ≈øong of the Lambe: It was called the ≈øong of Mo≈øes, as well becau≈øe they did ≈øing the prai≈øes of Gods iu≈øtice vpon this gla≈ø≈øie Sea, to the reuenge of the blood of his cho≈øen, as Mo≈øes ≈øayth in the very la≈øt wordes of his Canticle; as becau≈øe Mo≈øes prai≈øed God for the deliuerance of his people, from the corporall thraldome of Egypt; and the ≈øong of the Lambe, becau≈øe they prai≈øed him for doing the like, by relieuing the Church from the thraldome of the ≈øpirituall Egypt in the times of the Euangel: and their ≈øong was this; Great and wonderfull are thy workes, O Lord God Almightie, iu≈øt in puni≈øhment, and trew, for the performance of thy promi≈øes are thy wayes, O King, and defender of all thy Saints and trew followers: 4 Who will notfeare, O Lord, and glorifie thy Name, ≈øince thou art onely perfectly holy, for all nations ≈øhall come at the latter day, and adore before thee, ≈øince thy iudgements are now made manife≈øt, and lighted vpon the earth. 5 And next after this, I ≈øaw the≈øe particular plagues euery one, (for the which the Saints did thus prai≈øe God, as followeth) for I did looke, and I ≈øaw the Temple of the Tabernacle of the Te≈øtimonie in heauen opened; the like of this ye heard was done in the beginning of the ≈øeuenth Trumpet, and for the ≈øame cau≈øe it was al≈øo done here, to wit, to ≈øhew the Arke of the couenant which was therein, for thereby God did witne≈ø≈øe, that hee was now mindfull of his promi≈øe by the ≈øending out of the≈øe ≈øeuen Angels, and ≈øeuen plagues, which were now to be executed. 6 And out of this Temple came ≈øeuen Angels, for from the remembrance of his Arke and Couenant proceeded their direction, and they were clothed with pure and white linnen, for innocencie and puritie, and girded about their brea≈øts with gold, for honour and glory. 7 And one of the foure bea≈øts gaue the≈øe Angels ≈øeuen Phials of golde, full of the wrath of God that liues eternally, and for all worlds to come: The≈øe Angels are thus arayed, and the≈øe golden and precious Phials of the wrath of God, are giuen them by one of the foure bea≈øts, the mo≈øt excellent creatures of God, all to teach vs, that as the≈øe plagues ≈øhall be mo≈øt bitter to Babylon and her followers, ≈øo ≈øhall they be mo≈øt ≈øweet to all the cho≈øen for their deliuerance; for they are to light vpon the wicked, and no wayes to harme any of the holy Citie. 8 And the Temple in heauen was filled
with the ≈ømoake comming from the Maie≈øtie of God, and from his vertue and power: And there could none go in into the Temple while the ≈øeuen plagues of the ≈øeuen Angels were fulfilled, to teach vs that no fle≈øh, how guiltle≈ø≈øe ≈øoeuer it be, can compeare before God, when in his wrathfull face he is clothed with iu≈øtice, but onely when with a cheerefull countenance, clothed with mercy, he ≈øtretcheth foorth his hands vnto vs.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

p.hi: By the fir≈øt Phyale the Popes followers are plagued with ≈øundry new and vnknowen di≈øea≈øes: By the ≈øecond Phiale all kinde of plagues, Juch as ≈øword, famine, and pestilence light vpon the nations that acknowledge him: By the third, are diuers Popes rai≈øed vp at one time, who ≈øtriuing for the ≈øeats, fight among them≈øelues, and ≈øo they are iustly recompen≈øed for ≈øhedding the blood of the Saints: By the fourth, the reuerence of him begins to waxe colde in the hearts of men: By the fift, his abu≈øes begin to be di≈øcouered: By the fixt, his forces decay, which he perceiuing, houndeth out the Ie≈øuits, to gather all his forces to destroy the faithfull, with whom God fights to his de≈øtruction: By the ≈øeuenth, the latter day is de≈øcribed, and the Popedome rent a≈øunder.

div.p:
THen I heard a voice out of the Temple, ≈øaying to the≈øe ≈øeuen Angels, Goe powre foorth in great abundance vpon the earth, the ≈øeuen Phials of the wrath of God; for now they were to be ≈øhewen, and to be de≈øcribed vnto me. 2 Then the fir≈øt Angel went to worke, and powred foorth his Phiale on the earth, and there fell a great and grieuous ≈øore vpon all them that had the character of the bea≈øt, or adored his image: The≈øe plagues which were ≈øhewed to me, were onely ordained to light on Babylon, (as I ≈øaid before) and therefore they mete vnto her with the mea≈øure that ≈øhee ≈øhall mea≈øure others with, to wit, they ≈øhall plague her and her followers with the like plagues that ≈øhe ≈øhall plague others with, corre≈øponding a≈øwell in number as in qualitie: they al≈øo haue allu≈øion to the plagues of Egypt, becau≈øe ≈øhe is called ≈øpiritually Egypt, (as yee heard in the ≈øixt Trumpet) and ≈øo by this fir≈øt plague is ≈øignified, that as ≈øhee per≈øecuted the faithfull, and killed them, (as is declared in the ≈øixt Trumpet) and as Mo≈øes made a ≈øcabbe to come vpon all the Egyptians for Pharaohs ≈øake, ≈øo ≈øhall there fall a pe≈øtilent and pernicious ≈øore vpon all his followers, to wit, they ≈øhall be troubled with diuers new and horrible di≈øea≈øes. 3 Then the ≈øecond Angel powred foorth his Phiale vpon the ≈øea, and the ≈øea was made by it like the blood of a dead body, and euery liuing thing in the≈øea died; for as that bea≈øt ≈øhould fir≈øt ≈øo trouble the≈øea, to wit, the peoples and nations, with per≈øecuting all them who wil not adore her, and by her abu≈øe cau≈øe the world to become dead to all good workes and
fruitfull faith, as is declared by the vi≈øion where I ≈øaw her ri≈øe out of the ≈øea; and as Mo≈øes turned the redde ≈øea into a corrupted blood, with drowning the Egyptians, (which is here called the blood of a carrion) by the which all the fi≈øhes therein were poi≈øoned, ≈øo ≈øhal the nations and the peoples, which are the followers and partakers of Babylon, be troubled with warres within and without, and with all kinde of plagues, ≈øuch as pe≈øtilence, and famine, and ≈øuch others. 4 Then the third Angel powred foorth his phiale vpon the Riuers and fountaines of water, and they became blood; for as this fal≈øe Church and gra≈øhoppers did corporally ≈øucceed to the fountaines of waters, to wit, the trew Pa≈øtours, (as ye heard in the third Trumpet) and did a≈ø≈øi≈øt their King Apollyon, to per≈øecute bloodily the liuely fountaines of waters, or trew Pa≈øtours, who yet remained vncorrupted, as ye heard in the ≈øixt Trumpet; and as Moy≈øes made all the riuers and fountaines of waters in Egypt to become blood, ≈øo ≈øhall the teachers and heads of this fal≈øe Church, be diuided among them≈øelues, yea there ≈øhall be in three or foure diuers places, three or foure diuers per≈øons, and euery one of them ≈øhall claime to be king of the locu≈øts; which que≈øtion ≈øhall be decided by the cruell and bloodie edge of the ≈øword: And therefore to ≈øhew me how iu≈øtly that great per≈øecutor of the Saints, is now made to be the per≈øecutor of him≈øelfe, diuided in diuers per≈øons, 5 I heard the Angel of the waters, to wit, the third Angel, who powred the≈øe plagues vpon the waters, v≈øe the≈øe words; Iu≈øt art thou, O Lord, who is, who was, and holy for that thou ha≈øt iudged the≈øe things; 6 Becau≈øe euen as they, to wit, the≈øe corrupt, filthie, and fal≈øe fountaines of waters, haue ≈øhed the blood of thy Saints and Prophets; ≈øo ha≈øt thou now giuen them of blood to drinke, for they are worthy of ≈øuch a reward. 7 Then I heard the voice of one from the Sanctuarie, for confirmation hereof, ≈øaying; Certainely, O Lord God, trew and iu≈øt are thy Iudgements, for thou ha≈øt perfourmed thy promi≈øe, and ha≈øt iu≈øtly recompen≈øed them. 8 Then the fourth Angel powred foorth his phiale vpon the Sunne, and power was giuen vnto him to afflict men with fire; for euen as the Sunne was darkened in the fourth Trumpet, to wit, the ≈øpeciall teachers did begin to fall from the ≈øinceritie of the trewth, enticed thereunto, though not by Apollyon him≈øelfe, (for hee was not yet ri≈øen) yet by the qualities whereof hee is compo≈øed, and therefore is he here puni≈øhed for the ≈øame: And as Mo≈øes troubled by the hote Ea≈øterne winde the land of Egypt by the breeding of gra≈øhoppers, ≈øo ≈øhall the fierie ≈øpirit of God in the mouthes of his witne≈ø≈øes, ≈øo trouble Babylon with the burning ≈øunne of Gods trewth, as men ≈øhall be troubled with a great heat, to wit, ≈øhe and her followers ≈øhall be tormented and vexed therewith. 9 But they bla≈øphemed the name of God who had power ouer the≈øe plagues, and repented not, that they might giue him glory; for ≈øuch is the nature of the wicked, and ≈øo hardened are their hearts, that the ≈øame ≈øcourges and afflictions which make the godly turne them≈øelues to God, and ≈øo are the ≈øauour of life vnto them to their eternall
≈øaluation, they by the contrary make the wicked to runne from euill vnto wor≈øe, and ≈øo are the ≈øauour of death vnto them to their iu≈øt and eternall condemnation. 10 Then the fifth Angel powred forth his phiale euen vpon the very throne of the bea≈øt, and his kingdome was made darke, and they, to wit, he and his followers gnawed their tongues for dolour: for as this bea≈øt did breed and was nouri≈øhed by the ≈ømoake and darkene≈ø≈øe that came foorth of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, whereof he is the Angel and me≈ø≈øenger, as was declared in the fift Trumpet: And as Mo≈øes made a great darkene≈ø≈øe to come vpon the land of Egypt, ≈øo now after the witne≈ø≈øes reuealing him, which yee heard ≈øignified by the heat in the fourth phiale, ≈øhall follow, that this kingdome ≈øhall become ob≈øcure by the light of the trewth, and ≈øhall come to be de≈øpi≈øed by many, whereby he and his followers ≈øhall be mooued to a great rage, which I meant by gnawing their tongues for dolour. 11 And they bla≈øphemed the God of heauen for their dolours and griefes, and repented them not of their workes: for as I ≈øaid before, neither corporall puni≈øhments, ≈øignified by ≈øores, nor ≈øpirituall, ≈øignified by dolours, can moue them to repent, but to a greater ob≈øtinacie and rage, as ye ≈øhall ≈øee by their actions, immediatly after the powring foorth of the ≈øixt phiale vpon the great water Euphrates, 12 Then the ≈øixt Angel powred foorth his phiale vpon the great riuer of Euphrates, and the waters thereof were dried vp, that the pa≈ø≈øage of the Kings, comming from the Ea≈øt might be prepared, ≈øo as that bea≈øt by the meanes of many people (≈øignified by waters) did tyrannize ouer the Church of God; and as Mo≈øes by Aarons rod made a dry and ≈øafe pa≈ø≈øage through the Red-≈øea to the people of I≈ørael, Exod. 14. ≈øo God by this plague dries vp that great water Euphrates, which compa≈ø≈øeth Babylon, during his will, to wit, he makes now the power of this Monarchie to decay, and layes it open to inua≈øion and de≈øtruction, as ye ≈øhall heare: This water was dried to make pa≈ø≈øage for the Kings comming from the Sun ri≈øing, alluding to Daniel, as I ≈øhewed in the ≈øixt Trumpet: for euen as the Per≈øians and Medes came from the Ea≈øt, Chap. 9. cro≈ø≈øed Euphrates, ouercame Babylon and ≈ølew Baltha≈øar King thereof, ≈øo immediately after that the Witne≈ø≈øes haue begun to reueale ≈øpirituall Babylon, as is declared in the fourth phiale, and that thereupon hath followed, that the kingdome thereof is become darke, as is declared in the fift phiale; then ≈øhall follow, that God ≈øhall prepare the de≈øtruction thereof, by drying Euphrates', whereupon ≈øhall en≈øue, that ≈øuch in≈øtruments as God ≈øhall appoint, directed by that Sunne ri≈øing, to wit, Chri≈øt (as ye heard in the ≈øixt Seale) ≈øhall de≈øtroy that King, and ≈øacke that great Citie, to the perpetuall confu≈øion of all her followers, as ye wil heare more clearely declared hereafter. 13 And then I ≈øaw from the mouth of the dragon, and from the mouth of the bea≈øt, and from the mouth of the fal≈øe prophet, three vncleane≈øpirits come foorth like to froggs; for this is all the repentance that the≈øe three phials ≈øhall worke in the heart of Babylon, as I ≈øaid before, to wit, for the la≈øt remedie, the diuel or dragon ≈øhall inuent him a fre≈øh order of
Eccle≈øia≈øticall factours and Agents, as the diuels la≈øt brood: The≈øe are the ≈øame that I called hor≈øe, in the vi≈øion in the ≈øixt Trumpet, three in number to corre≈øpond to their threefold armour, as ye heard in the ≈øaid Trumpet, becau≈øe there came out of their mouthes three ≈øorts of per≈øecutions and de≈øtructions; And them≈øelues came out of three mouthes, out of the dragons, becau≈øe the diuel is the inuenter of them, out of the bea≈øts, becau≈øe the bea≈øt or King of Locu≈øts commands ouer them, directs and employes them for the ≈øtanding of his kingdome, as the la≈øt refuge when now he ≈øees the decay thereof euidently comming on, out of his fal≈øe prophets or fal≈øe Churches, becau≈øe it authori≈øes them for the afore≈øaid effects: The≈øe vncleane ≈øpirits and teachers of fal≈øe and hereticall doctrines and wicked policies, re≈øembling frogges, as well for that they are bred of an old, filthy, and corrupted fal≈øe doctrine, which for a long ≈øpace haue blinded the world before their comming, as frogges breed of rotten and ≈ølimie corruption; as al≈øo for that they goe craftily about to vndermine and condemne all Eccle≈øia≈øticall orders preceding them, as vnperfect and vnprofitable, becau≈øe their kingdome is darkene≈ø≈øe; But how≈øoeuer they thus craftily in≈øinuate them≈øelues in the fauours of the people, ≈øurely their doctrine is nothing el≈øe, but the very ≈øame filthy puddle of vncleane and wicked here≈øies and impieties, taught by the gra≈øhoppers before, euen as the yong frogges grow like the former. 14 For they are ≈øpirits of diuels, to wit, wicked and craftie like them, doing myracles of deceipt, for they ≈øhall wonderfully deceiue men; and they goe to all the Kings of the earth, and to the whole world, to gather them together to the battell of that day of God Almightie; for they ≈øhall haue ≈øuch credit of a great part of the Princes of the earth, as I al≈øo ≈øhewed you in the ≈øixt Trumpet, as they ≈øhall gather great forces together, as the la≈øt brood of the diuel, as I told you before, to fight again≈øt his Church, who notwith≈øtanding ≈øhall ouercome them, as will after more clearely be declared. 15 Happy are they then that ≈øwarue not, nor de≈øpaire in the meane time, but awake and keepe their garments cleane and vndefiled from the generall corruption, le≈øt otherwi≈øe they walke naked, not clothed with the garment of righteou≈ønes, and ≈øo their ≈øhamefull parts, or naturall inclination to euill be di≈øcouered: For loe I come as a thiefe, for no man ≈øhall know the houre, no time of my comming. 16 And the place whereunto the≈øe vncleane ≈øpirits gathered the Kings to this battell again≈øt Gods Church, in Hebrew is called Armageddon: for by deceipt they a≈ø≈øembled the Kings and nations to their owne de≈øtruction. 17 Then the ≈øeuenth Angel powred out his phiale in the aire, and there came forth a great voyce from the Temple in heauen, euen from the Throne, ≈øaying, It is done. 18 Then was heard great ≈øounds, and lightnings and thunders, and there was a great earthquake, and ≈øuch in greatne≈ø≈øe was neuer ≈øeene ≈øince men were vpon the face of the earth; for euen as the aire was troubled and ob≈øcured by ≈ømoke of hell, out of the which the king of Locu≈øtes, bred in the fir≈øt Seale, and as Mo≈øes made haile
in great abundance to fall on Egypt, which Meteore doeth breed in the aire; ≈øo God hauing ≈øtricken the battell again≈øt Babylon, and her followers, and hauing ouercome them, as ye heard in the ≈øixt Seale; now followeth immediatly the la≈øt plague of the con≈øummation by the aire; for in the aire ≈øhall that great noi≈øe be heard, which is the fore-runner of that Great day, mo≈øt comfortable to the trew Church, but mo≈øt terrible to all the re≈øt of the world, which day is proclaimed by the voice of God from his Temple, wherein was his Couenant, declaring the con≈øummation in the≈øe words ye heard; and as the great noi≈øe ≈øignifies the ≈øame, ≈øo in ≈øpeciall doeth the great earthquake, as Chri≈øt him≈øelfe prophe≈øying thereof, doeth declare. 19 And that Citie was rent in ≈øunder in three parts, and that iu≈øtly, becau≈øe ≈øhe de≈øtroyed the third part of the earth, as ye heard in the ≈øixt Trumpet: and the Cities of the nations fell, becau≈øe they dranke the cup of her abominations: And great Babylon and her ≈øinnes, came then in memorie before God; for then he was to make her drinke the cup full of his wrath, to her vtter de≈øtruction. 20 And all the I≈øles fled, and the mountaines were no more found, for no deepenes of Seas, nor inacce≈ø≈øiblenes of mountaines ≈øhall haue power to ≈øaue the wicked, from the fearefull and terrible iudgements of that great and la≈øt day: This doeth al≈øo ≈øignifie the latter day, as ye heard before. 21 And a great haile to the greatne≈ø≈øe of talents fell vpon men, but they bla≈øphemed God for the plague of haile, for it was exceeding great; This great haile ≈øignifieth al≈øo a great de≈øtruction at the latter day, as ye heard in the ≈øeuenth Trumpet, but yet the wicked ≈øhall be ≈øo ≈øtiffenecked, as euen at their la≈øt breath, their malice and ob≈øtinacie ≈øhall rather encrea≈øe then dimini≈øh, as is declared here by mens bla≈øpheming of God for the plague of the haile.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.

p.hi: The Angel expounded to Iohn this vi≈øion of the Pope, de≈øcribes him at large, and clearely declares the authors, and maner of his destruction.

div.p:
BVt becau≈øe that the≈øe plagues, and Babylon whereupon they lighted, did ≈øeeme ob≈øcure vnto me, therefore one of the ≈øeuen Angels who powred forth their phials ful of plagues, did ≈øay vnto me, Here then, I will ≈øhew vnto thee more plainely the condemnation of this great Whore, and what ≈øhee is that ≈øitteth vpon many waters; 2 With whom the Kings of the earth haue committed ≈øpirituall adulterie, and with the wine of who≈øe whoredome the inhabitants of the earth, to wit, a great number of nations, who are not of the Elect, are made drunke, as you heard before. 3 Then he bereft me in Spirit, as I told you in the beginning of this Epi≈øtle, to the
wildernes, which ≈øignifies the Genteli≈øme, as ≈øaith E≈øay; for ≈øhe and her followers are Gentiles in effect, as ye heard in the ≈øixt Trumpet: And as our Master ≈øayes, All the≈øe that gather not with vs, they ≈øcatter; for no more is there a midde≈øt betwixt God and the diuell, nor betwixt the rewards thereof, heauen and hell; and as one of the≈øe two Ma≈øters we mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie follow, ≈øo of the ≈øame nece≈ø≈øitie to one of the≈øe two places mu≈øt we goe. And then I ≈øaw in the wildernes a woman, euen Babylon that whore, ≈øitting on a ≈øcarlet coloured and bloody bea≈øt, euen as ≈øhee was ≈øitting before in the likene≈ø≈øe of a man vpon a pale hor≈øe, in the fourth Seale: And this bea≈øt was full of bla≈øphemie, and had ≈øeuen heads and tenne hornes, as ye heard before. 4 And the woman was clothed with purple and ≈øcarlet and pretious ≈øtones and pearles, and had in her hand a golden Cup; for this Monarchie and the Monarch thereof, ≈øhall a≈øwell be corporally clothed with the≈øe colours, and decked with pretious ≈øtones; as al≈øo, the≈øe colours which are fine≈øt of all others, and the≈øe pretious ≈øtones ≈øignifie, that this Monarchie and the ≈øeat thereof, ≈øhalbe mo≈øt glorious and glauncing to the eyes of the world, as I ≈øaid before, which ≈øhall not onely be the trew Church by appearance of outward glory, but euen retaine many of the generall points of religion, which is ≈øignified by her golden Cup; but this Cup was full of abhominations, and of the vncleanne≈ø≈øe of her ≈øpirituall whoredomes: For albeit in many points ≈øhe ≈øhal retaine the trewth, which ≈øhall abu≈øe men, and allure them to her, yet ≈øhall ≈øhe mixe and poy≈øon this trewth with her owne abominable and hereticall inuentions, and traditions, and with the vncleanne≈ø≈øe of her ≈øpirituall adulterie, whereof ye haue heard before. 5 And on her forehead was written a my≈øterie, Babylon the great, to wit, ≈øpirituall Babylon, as ye heard before, the mother of the whoredomes and the abhominations of the earth; for from her ≈øhall proceed the greate≈øt, and in a maner, the onely chiefe abu≈øes and here≈øies, coloured and clothed with the ≈øhew and title of Chri≈øtiantie, with the which the≈øe, who ≈øhall outwardly ≈øay, Lord, Lord, ≈øhall euer be infected with, vntill the con≈øummation, and as a mother, ≈øhe ≈øhall not onely breed, but ≈øhalbe the chiefe nouri≈øher and maintainer of them; And this is called a my≈øterie, becau≈øe although this abu≈øe ≈øhall be publike, as is ≈øignified by being written on her forehead, yet none ≈øhall con≈øider the abu≈øe thereof, but onely ≈øuch, who≈øe eyes it ≈øhall plea≈øe God to illuminate for that effect. 6 And I ≈øaw the woman drunken with the blood of the Saints, and of the Martyrs, and witne≈ø≈øes of Ie≈øus the Sauiour, to wit, ≈øhe ≈øhall greedily and cruelly ≈øhed their blood without all mea≈øure, rea≈øon or pitie, as yee haue often heard before: And when I thus ≈øaw her, I wondered at her marueilou≈øly, and I could not coniecture the meaning of the ≈øeuen heads and ten hornes that the bea≈øt had, on whom ≈øhe ≈øate. 7 And the Angel who had now ≈øhewen her vnto me, as ye now haue heard, ≈øeeing me thus wonder, ≈øayes vnto me, Marueile not, for I will reueale vnto thee the my≈øterie of this woman, and of the bea≈øt ≈øhee rideth vpon, which hath ≈øeuen heads
and ten hornes: 8 This bea≈øt that thou ha≈øt ≈øeene (or Monarchie) was, (for it is the fourth Monarchie, which is very great and flouri≈øhing) and is not, for it is now ≈øo farre decayed, that in a maner it is not, and it is to ri≈øe againe out of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, as yee heard in the fift Trumpet, how foone the wound of the head ≈øhall be healed, whereof ye heard before, and it ≈øhall goe to perdition, as ye often haue heard already, and the in-dwellers of the earth ≈øhall wonder, who≈øe names are not written in the booke of life, before the foundation of the world was laide; of this wondering yee heard before; they ≈øhall wonder (I ≈øay) at this bea≈øt, which was, to wit, in great power, and is not, to wit, in a maner, as ye pre≈øently heard, and yet is, I meane doeth ≈øtand, though farre decayed from the former greatne≈ø≈øe: 9 Take good heede vnto this that I declare vnto thee, for herein ≈øhall the trew wi≈øedome of men be tried, to wit, in knowing by this my de≈øcription, what particular Empire and Tyrannie I ≈øpeake of: And the ≈øeuen heads of this bea≈øt ≈øignifie, a≈øwell ≈øeuen materiall hilles, whereupon the ≈øeate of this Monarchie is ≈øituated, as al≈øo ≈øeuen kings, or diuers formes of Magi≈øtrates that this Empire hath had, and is to haue hereafter; 10 Fiue of them haue beene alreadie, one is pre≈øently, and makes the ≈øixt, another ≈øhall follow it, and make the ≈øeuenth, but it is not yet come; and when it comes, it ≈øhall remaine but a very ≈øhort ≈øpace. 11 And this bea≈øt which was, to wit, ≈øo great, and is not, for now it is decaying, as thou pre≈øently ha≈øt heard it, is the eight, and yet one of the ≈øeuen; for this bea≈øt which ro≈øe out of the ruines of the fourth Monarchie, as ye heard before, in re≈øpect it v≈øeth an hereticall Tyrannie ouer the con≈øciences of men, by that new forme of Empire, is different from any of the re≈øt, and ≈øo is the eight, and yet becau≈øe this forme of gouernment ≈øhall haue the ≈øame ≈øeate which the re≈øt had, and v≈øe as great Tyrannie, and greater vpon the world, and ≈øhall v≈øe the ≈øame forme in ciuill gouernment, which one of the ≈øeuen v≈øed, therefore becau≈øe it is ≈øo like them, I call it one of the ≈øeuen. 12 And the tenne hornes which thou ≈øawe≈øt, ≈øignifie tenne Kings, to wit, the great number of ≈øubalterne Magi≈øtrates in all the Prouinces vnder that Monarchy, who haue not yet receiued their kingdome; for vnder all the diuers ≈øorts of gouernments that ≈øhall be in it, except the la≈øt and hereticall ≈øort, the≈øe ≈øubalterne powers ≈øhall be but in the ranke of ≈øubiects, but they ≈øhall take their kingly power with the bea≈øt, to wit, at the very time that this Apollyon ≈øhall ri≈øe out of the a≈øhes of the fourth bea≈øt or Monarchie, the kings of the earth ≈øhall become his ≈ølaues and ≈øubalterne Magi≈øtrates, whereas the ≈øubiects were onely the power of that Monarchie before: ≈øo as the hornes or powers of this bea≈øt, were but of ≈øubiects before it was wounded, but after the healing of it, the worldly kings and rulers ≈øhall become the powers and hornes of it. 13 The≈øe ≈øhall haue one coun≈øell, and ≈øhall giue their ≈øtrength and power to the bea≈øt, to wit, the≈øe kings ≈øhal all willingly yeeld obedience to Babylon, and ≈øhall employ their whole forces for the maintenance of that Monarchie, and the per≈øecution of the Saints: 14 For they
≈øhal fight with the Lambe in his members, albeit all in vaine, for in the end the Lambe ≈øhall ouercome them, becau≈øe he is Lord of lords, and King of all kings, and the≈øe that are with him and followeth him, are called Cho≈øen and Faithfull. 15 He al≈øo ≈øaid vnto me, The waters that thou ≈øaw this Whore ≈øit vpon, are the peoples, multitudes, nations, and tongues that haue ≈øubiected them≈øelues to her Empire: 16 But as touching the≈øe ten hornes thou ≈øaw, thus farre I foretell vnto thee, although that for a time the≈øe kings ≈øhall be ≈ølaues and ≈øeruants to Babylon, and ≈øhall be her in≈øtruments to per≈øecute the Saints, the time ≈øhall come before the con≈øummation, that they ≈øhall hate the Whore, who abu≈øed them ≈øo ≈øtrongly and long, and ≈øhall make her to be alone, for they ≈øhall withdraw from her their Subiects, the nations that were her ≈øtrength, and ≈øhall make her naked, for they ≈øhall di≈øcouer the my≈øterie of her abominations, and ≈øhall eate her fle≈øh, and burne her with fire, to wit, they ≈øhall ≈øpoile her of her riches, power and glory, and ≈øo de≈øtroy her. 17 But doe not thou wonder at this, for God gaue them in their hearts, to wit, permitted them to be abu≈øed by her for a ≈øpace, that they might doe what plea≈øed her, and con≈øent to all her vnlawfull policies and pretences, and giue their kingdomes vnto this bea≈øt, vntill the words of God might be accompli≈øhed, to wit, they ≈øhall ≈øubmit their very Crownes, and take the right thereof from her, vnto the fulne≈ø≈øe of times here prophecied: At what time God ≈øhall rai≈øe them vp, as ye heard, to de≈øtroy Babylon; for the hearts of the greate≈øt kings, as well as of the ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øubiects, are in the hands of the Lord, to be his in≈øtruments, and to turne them as it ≈øhall plea≈øe him to employ them. 18 And this woman, or Whore which thou ≈øawe≈øt, is that great citie and ≈øeate of this Bea≈øt or Monarchie, which beareth rule ouer the kings of the earth, as thou ha≈øt heard alreadie: But although it be one ≈øeat, yet diuers and a great number of kings or heads thereof, ≈øhall ≈øucceed into it, one to another, all vpholding an hereticall religion, and fal≈øe wor≈øhip of God, and one forme of gouernment, as the fourth Monarchie did, out of the which this did ≈øpring, as ye haue heard.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.

p.hi: The ≈øorrow of the earth for the destruction of the Popedome: The profite that worldly men had by his ≈øtanding: The great riches and wealth of that Church: The Pope by his Pardons makes merchandi≈øe of the ≈øoules of men: Heauen and the Saints reioyce at his destruction, albeit the earth and the worldlings lament for the ≈øame.

div.p:
ANd then I ≈øaw another Angel comming downe from heauen, hauing great power, ≈øo that the earth ≈øhined with his glory, for ≈øo ≈øoone as God, by one of the ≈øeauen Angels who had the phials, had more plainely de≈øcribed vnto mee this woman ≈øitting on the bea≈øt, then he did before, hee now appointeth this other Angel, who is Chri≈øt, to declare vnto me, and proclaime to the world (as is ≈øignified by his comming downe to the earth for that cau≈øe) the iu≈øt condemnation of Babylon according to her ≈øinnes. 2 And hee cryed out with a loude voyce, ≈øaying, It is fallen, It is fallen, Babylon that great Citie, and it is made the dwelling place of vncleane ≈øpirits, and the habitation of all vncleane and hatefull fowles, to wit, it ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed, and that great Citie, the ≈øeate of that Monarchie, ≈øhall be de≈øolate for euer, euen as it was prophe≈øied of Ieru≈øalem; 3 Becau≈øe all nations haue drunke of the Vine of her whoredome, and the kings of the earth haue committed whoredome with her, and the Merchants of the earth are become rich by the great wealth of her delights, in ≈øo great a worldly glory and pompe did that Monarchie ≈øhine. 4 And I heard another voyce from heauen, to wit, the voyce of the holy Spirit, ≈øaying, Goe foorth from her my people, to wit, all the cho≈øen, le≈øt ye be participants of her ≈øinnes, and of the plagues which are to fall vpon her for them: For if but outwardly ye haunt with her, and ≈øeeme to beare with her abominations, yee ≈øhall bee accounted guiltie of her ≈øinnes; for if ye will haue Chri≈øt to profe≈ø≈øe you publikely at the latter day, before his Father and his Angels, and reward both your body and ≈øoule with eternall felicitie, yee mu≈øt not bee a≈øhamed to ≈øerue him both in body and ≈øoule before men: And this warning I giue you before-hand to make you inexcu≈øable, who will otherwi≈øe doe: 5 For her ≈øinnes are come to ≈øuch a height, as they haue touched the heauen, and God is mindfull of them; then not onely haunt not with her, as I haue ≈øaid, (for it is not enough not to doe euil) but, 6 Ray≈øe your ≈øelues vp again≈øt her, and render the like that ≈øhe hath done to you, yea pay her with the double of her owne workes, and in the cup which ≈øhe propined vnto others, render her the double, to wit, trouble, and de≈øtroy her by all meanes, and in all things, euen as ≈øhe troubled and de≈øtroyed others before; and according to her pride and wantonne≈ø≈øe, recompence her with torment, woe, and wailing: 7 For ≈øhe ≈øayes in her mind, I fit a Queene,
or am a ≈øtabled Monarch, neither am I a widow, or ≈øhall euer bee de≈øolate, nor ≈øhall euer ≈øee dolour, or ta≈øte de≈øtruction. 8 And therefore becau≈øe ≈øhe thus builds her felicitie vpon her worldly ≈øtrength, by worldly in≈øtruments ≈øhall ≈øhee bee plagued, with death, with dolour, with hunger, and burnt with fire, to wit, after ≈øuffering all ≈øorts of torments, ≈øhee ≈øhall in the end be vtterly de≈øtroyed, for ≈øtrong is the Lord God, who ≈øhall condemne her. 9 And then ≈øhall the kings of the earth, who were her hornes, and had committed whoredome and riotou≈øne≈ø≈øe with her before, weepe and lament for pittie, when they ≈øee the ≈ømoake of her burning; for although ≈øome of them≈øelues ≈øhall be the de≈øtroyers, as ye heard before, yet ≈øhall her de≈øtruction be ≈øo great, as their hearts ≈øhall pittie the worke of their hands, when they ≈øhall ≈øee the great ≈ømoake of her de≈øtruction. 10 And they ≈øhall ≈øtand farre off from her torment, to wit, her torment ≈øhall put them in memorie of their guiltine≈ø≈øe of her ≈øinnes, which ≈øhall afray them wonderfully, and ≈øhall ≈øay in great admiration, Alas, Alas, for that great Citie Babylon, that ≈øtrong Citie, who≈øe iudgement and de≈øtruction is all come in one howre, and at once. 11 And the Merchants of the earth ≈øhall weepe and mourne for her, becau≈øe their merchandi≈øe wil no more bee bought, for her pompe ≈øhall make the Merchants rich, by getting readie ≈øale of all fine wares, 12 Such as gold, ≈øiluer, precious ≈øtones, pearles, fine linnen, purple, ≈øilke, and ≈øcarlet for her garments, and all kind of ve≈ø≈øels to doe her idolatrous ≈øeruice, of Iuorie, co≈øtly wood, bra≈ø≈øe, iron, or marble ≈øtone; 13 Cynamome, and all kind of odours for her Church, with oyntments, and incen≈øe for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, and the fine flower of wheat, and all kind of victuals and cattell, and ≈øheepe for her ≈øumptuous banquets, and hor≈øe, and Chariots, and ≈ølaues for her triumphes, and proce≈ø≈øions, and ≈øoules of men; for ≈øhee ≈øhall haue many that ≈øhall be Merchants vnto her of the ≈øoules of men, by ≈øelling for mony, Pardons giuen by that Monarch, which ≈øhall bee thought to haue power to ≈øaue, redeeme and free mens ≈øoules: but ye ≈øhal heare more ≈øhortly of this hereafter. 14 And the fruits of the de≈øire of thy ≈øoule, O Babylon, ≈øhall goe from thee, to wit, thy ioyes and delights ≈øhall all turne to ≈øorrow, and all fat and faire things are gone from thee, to wit, thou ≈øhalt leaue all profit and plea≈øure, neither ≈øhalt thou euer find them any more, for thou ≈øhalt be de≈øtroyed for euer. 15 And ≈øo the Merchants of the≈øe ≈øtuffes, being made rich by the buying and ≈øelling of them, they ≈øhall ≈øtand afarre off from thy torments, and weepe, and waile, 16 ≈øaying, Alas, Alas; for that great Citie that was clothed with fine linnen, purple, and ≈øcarlet, and was of ≈øo gli≈øtering a pompe, as was gilded with gold, and decked with pretious ≈øtones and pearles: 17 For loe now how in one houre all her riches and pompe is evani≈øhed, and all the gouernours and owners of ≈øhips, and all the multitudes of men in the ≈øhips, and all the marriners in them, and all the≈øe who gaine their liuing vpon the ≈øea, ≈øhal ≈øtand afarre off for feare, 18 And cry, ≈øeeing the ≈ømoke of her burning, ≈øaying with a great admiration, Who was like in power or
≈øhining glorie to this Citie? 19 And for pittie of her decay, and ≈øorow for wanting by that meanes, the carrying to her from all other countries all ≈øorts of merchandi≈øe, they ≈øhall ca≈øt du≈øt and a≈øhes vpon their heades, and ≈øay, Alas, Alas for that great Citie, wherein was made rich all the≈øe that had ≈øhippes vpon the ≈øea, by the prices and trade ≈øhee made vs haue, and now ≈øhe is made de≈øolate in one houre: 20 But although the earthly men bee ≈øorrowfull for her fall, as yee haue heard, becau≈øe they want their earthly commodities and plea≈øures thereby, which ≈øhe who≈øe religion was earthly, to wit, founded vpon mens traditions and inuentions, and maintained by earthly pompe and power, did make them enioy; yet reioyce yee heauens for her fall, and ye holy Apo≈øtles and Prophets be glad thereof; for God, in puni≈øhing her hath reuenged your cau≈øe. 21 Then for confirmation of this Prophe≈øie of her de≈øtruction, I ≈øawe a ≈øtrong Angel take a great ≈øtone like a mil≈øtone, and ca≈øt it in the ≈øea, ≈øaying, Euen with ≈øuch a force ≈øhall Babylon that great Citie be ca≈øten downe, and the very place thereof ≈øhall no more be found, as Ieremy prophe≈øied of corporall Babylon. 22 And the ≈øound of harpers, and mu≈øitians, and players on pipes and trumpets ≈øhall no more be heard in thee; for no ioy nor mirth ≈øhall any more bee in that Monarchie, or the ≈øeate thereof, nor no crafte≈ø-man of any craft ≈øhall bee found in thee, neither ≈øhall the grinding of the mill be heard any more in thee; for that Citie, or ≈øeate and Monarchie ≈øhall no more bee inhabited: 23 And the light of a candle ≈øhal be no more found in thee, and the voice of the husband and the wife ≈øhall no more be heard in thee; for as it ≈øhall not be inhabited any more by the wicked, ≈øo neither ≈øhall the godly dwell therein; ≈øo accur≈øed ≈øhall it be, ≈øo as the lampes of the fiue virgins ≈øhall not burne there, neither ≈øhall Chri≈øt and his ≈øpou≈øe, the true Church any more be there, although that during the ≈øtanding of that Monarchie, ≈øome cho≈øen, though few and ≈øecret, were, and at all times ≈øhall be, euen within that City, the ≈øeate thereof, who≈øe merchants were the great men of the earth, and with who≈øe witchcrafts all nations were≈øeduced. 24 And the blood of the Prophets, and of the Saints was found in her, and of all them that were ≈ølaine vpon the earth, to wit, this plague of de≈øtruction ≈øhall iu≈øtly fall vpon her, a≈øwell for that ≈øhe made her me≈ø≈øengers or emba≈ø≈øadours, who are great in power, (as yee heard before) to bee the ≈øellers of her Pardons, Prayers, Sacraments, Merits, and euen of the ≈øinnes, and ≈øoules of men, as ye haue pre≈øently heard; and ≈øo by that meanes and the like, bewitched, as it were, and abu≈øed many nations; as al≈øo for that ≈øhee had cruelly per≈øecuted and murthered the Saints, ≈øo as the blood of all the Saints ≈øince Abel, who willingly ≈øacrificed their liues for the loue of Gods trewth, and for the te≈øtimonie of his Sonne, ≈øhall be layd vpon her head, and imputed vnto her, in following, fulfilling, and exceeding the rage of former Tyrants, oppre≈ø≈øing and per≈øecuting the Church of God.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.

p.hi: The Saints prai≈øe God for ioy that the Pope is de≈øtroyed: The glorious forme of Chri≈øtes ≈øecond comming ≈øet downe at large: The Pope and his Church is condemned for euer.

div.p:
THen according to the voyces ≈øpeaking to the heauen, and Prophets and Apo≈øtles there, to wit, that they ≈øhould reioyce as much for the fall of Babylon, as the vnregenerate men did lament therefore, as ye haue heard; according, I ≈øay, to this exhortation, I heard the voyce of a great multitude in heauen, ≈øaying, Hallelu-iah, which is if ye interpret it, Prai≈øe God with a lowde voyce, Saluation, honour, glorie, and power is onely with our Lord God: 2 For true and iu≈øt are his Iudgements, and he hath condemned that great Whore, who hath defiled the earth with her whoredome, and he with his hand hath reuenged vpon her the blood of his ≈øeruants: 3 Then for the ≈øecond time they ≈øaid, Hallelu-iah; for the ≈ømoake of her de≈øtruction goeth vp in all worlds to come, for ≈øhe ≈øhall neuer ri≈øe againe, but ≈øhalbe burned with a perpetuall fire. 4 And likewi≈øe for thanke≈øgiuing for the ≈øame, the foure and twentie Elders fell downe vpon their faces before God, and adored him, and the foure Bea≈øts al≈øo adored God ≈øitting vpon his Throne, and all the bea≈øts and Elders ≈øaid with one voyce, Amen, Hallelu-iah. 5 And I heard a voyce come from the Throne, to wit, from one of the foure bea≈øtes that ≈øupported it, ≈øaying, Prai≈øe our God all ye his Seruants, and all ye that feare him, ≈ømall and great. 6 And then conformely to that direction I heard, as it had bene the ≈øound or voyce of a great multitude, and as it had bene the ≈øound of many waters, and as the ≈øound of great thunders, to wit, the voyce of all the Creatures in heauen, who≈øe ≈øound in greatnes might be compared to the noi≈øe of many waters, or to the roaring of the thunder, and they ≈øaid all in one Voyce, Hallelu-iah, becau≈øe our Lord God Almightie hath now reigned by de≈øtroying Babylon, and her followers. 7 Let vs therefore reioyce and be glad, and render him all glory: for the Marriage of the Lambe is come, to wit, the latter Day is at hand, and his wife hath made her≈øelfe ready for him, to wit, his Church is now purified from among the wicked. 8 And it was giuen vnto her to clothe her≈øelfe with pure and bright linnen, which is the iu≈øtification of the Saints; for as fine linnen is a pure bright, white, and pretious ≈øtuffe, ≈øo are the Saints clothed with that pretious vndefiled, and glorious garment of righteou≈ønes through imputation; And this our garment of Iu≈øtification, with the which we ≈øhalbe clothed at the latter day, mu≈øt onely come of his righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, ≈øo (as ye pre≈øently heard,) it mu≈øt be giuen vs by him; for as of our ≈øelues we cannot thinke a good thought, ≈øo can we merit nothing but eternall death, and when we haue done all the good workes we
can, we mu≈øt thinke our ≈øelues but improfitable ≈øeruants, as Chri≈øt him≈øelfe ≈øaid. 9 Then the ≈øame voyce, to wit, the voyce of the Angel that ≈øhewed me the≈øe things, ≈øaid to me, Write and leaue in record to all po≈øterities: Happie are they that are called to the Supper of the Lambes marriage, whereof thou thy ≈øelfe heard him ≈øpeake parabolically; for tho≈øe who are called, ≈øhall neuer againe be ca≈øt off, but are cho≈øen for euer. And he ≈øaid vnto me, the≈øe words of God are trew which I bad thee write, to leaue to po≈øteritie, that God him≈øelfe hath giuen this comfortable promi≈øe, which I haue ≈øpecially willed thee to witne≈ø≈øe to thy Brethren, becau≈øe it will come to pa≈ø≈øe in the later dayes, that this whoring and hereticall Babylon, ≈øhall di≈øwade all her followers from tru≈øting this promi≈øe, and ≈øo driue men to an vncertaintie of their Election. 10 And I fell downe at this Angels feete to haue adored him (≈øo all fle≈øh is giuen of it ≈øelfe, to adore ≈øome vi≈øible thing which is idolatry, ≈øuch is the corruption of our fle≈øh, if it be not holden vp by grace from aboue,) but he did reproue me, and ≈øaid, Beware thou doe it not: For although I be a more excellent creature of God then thou art, yet am I but thy fellow ≈øeruant, and ≈øo one of thy brethren, bearing the te≈øtimony of IESVS in heauen, to be his ≈øeruant and creature, as thou doe≈øt in earth: Adore therefore God onely, for no creature mu≈øt either be prayed to, or adored, nor no mediation can come, but by Chri≈øt onely, and thinke mee not a God for prophe≈øying thus vnto thee, (for the witne≈ø≈øing of Chri≈øt is the Spirit of prophe≈øie) for that gift is common to others, a≈øwell as to mee, and it is the ≈øame Spirit of prophe≈øie, albeit not the ≈øame gift of it that foretells things to come, which giues grace to all the Elect, to beare trew and con≈øtant record of Chri≈øt. 11 Then I ≈øaw thereafter the forme of the day of Iudgement; for I ≈øaw the Heauens open, and loe, a white hor≈øe came downe from them, (of this white hor≈øe yee heard in the fir≈øt Seale) and hee that ≈øate vpon him, to wit, Chri≈øt, was called faithfull and trew, for by giuing Iudgement, hee was now to performe his promi≈øe; and hee was al≈øo called, Hee that iustly iudgeth, and fighteth, for hee was pre≈øently to iudge the world, and to condemne perpetually all the reprobate: 12 And his eyes were like the flames of fire, (as yee heard in the beginning of this Epi≈øtle) and on his head were many diademes, for now he was to reigne eternally ouer all the kingdomes of the earth, as the Elders did ≈øing in the ≈øeuenth Trumpet; and he had a Name written vpon him, which no man did know but him≈øelfe; for the my≈øterie of his Name of Redemptor is ≈øo profound, as no creature is able to comprehend it by wi≈øedome; and therefore I heard him≈øelfe ≈øay, that no Angel, no not him≈øelfe in ≈øo farre as he is man, did foreknow the day of his la≈øt comming, which ≈øhall be the fulfilling of that my≈øterie. 13 And he was clothed with a garment dipt in blood, wherewith the garments of the ≈øoules of Martyrs are wa≈øhed, as ye heard in the fift Seale, and he is named, The word of God, as I did ≈øhew you in the beginning of my Euangel. 14 And the ho≈øtes of Angels and Saints in heauen, followed
him vpon white hor≈øes clothed in white, and pure linnen, whereof yee heard alreadie: 15 And from his mouth came foorth a ≈øharpe ≈øword, as ye heard in the beginning of this Epi≈øtle, that he might ≈øtrike the Gentiles therewith; for hee ≈øhall rule them with a rod of yron, as Dauid ≈øayth, and he treadeth, to wit, giueth command and power to tread the lake or ≈øea of the vine of the fury and wrath of God Almightie, as ye heard in the ≈øeuenth Trumpet: 16 And he hath vpon his garment, and vpon his thigh, as the ≈øtronge≈øt part of his body, this name written, The King of kings, and Lord of lords. 17 And I ≈øaw an Angel ≈øtanding in the Sunne, that there he might be ≈øeene publikely of all, and that the Whole world might take heed to that which he was to proclaime, and he cried with a loude voice to all the fowles flying through the midde≈øt of heauen, Come and gather your ≈øelues to the ≈øupper of the Lord; 18 To eate the fle≈øh of Kings, of Tribunes, of mightie men, of hor≈øes and of their riders: in ≈øhort, come eate the fle≈øh of all free-men and ≈ølaues, great and ≈ømall: This was to declare, that the day of Iudgement was come, wherein ≈øhould that de≈øtruction en≈øue, ≈øignified by fowles eating their fle≈øh, (becau≈øe fowles v≈øe to eate the fle≈øh of dead men vnburied) which ≈øhould ouerwhelme all ≈øorts of men, excepting alwayes the≈øe that were marked, who were ≈øundry times excepted before, as ye heard. 19 Then I ≈øaw that bea≈øt, to wit, Babylon, together with the kings of the earth who tooke her part, and their armies gathered together, to make warre with him that ≈øate vpon the white hor≈øe, and with his armie: 20 But the Bea≈øt was taken, together with the fal≈øe prophet, or fal≈øe Church, which by her fal≈øe miracles ≈øeduced the nations that did beare the Character of the Bea≈øt, and adored his image, as ye heard before, and they were both ca≈øt quicke in the lake of fire burning with brim≈øtone: 21 And the re≈øt were ≈ølaine by the ≈øword which came out of his mouth, that ≈øate vpon the hor≈øe, and the fowles were filled with their fle≈øh; for how ≈øoone Chri≈øt ≈øhall come to Iudgement, then ≈øhall all the enemies of God be de≈øtroyed, and ≈øo full victory obtained of this battell, whereof yee heard in the ≈øixt Trumpet, and ≈øixt phiale, and ≈øhall heare farther hereafter: And chiefly Babylon, and the fal≈øe Church ≈øhall be ca≈øt into hell, becau≈øe they merit double puni≈øhment for the abu≈øing of men, although they ≈øhall not al≈øo want their damnation that followeth them, as is ≈øignified by their ≈ølaughter with the ≈øword of his mouth, whereof yee heard in the beginning of this Epi≈øtle, and by the fowles eating their fle≈øh, as ye pre≈øently perceiue.
