p.hi: The ≈øumme and recapitulation of all the former vi≈øions, to wit, the fir≈øt e≈øtate of the Church in all puritie after Chri≈øt: The here≈øies, and ≈øpecially the Popedome that followed: The de≈øtruction thereof, in their greate≈øtrage: The latter day: The ≈øaluation of the Elect, and condemnation of all others.

div.p:
THe Spirit of God hauing now ≈øhewen vnto me the e≈øtate of the Church militant, with the ≈øpeciall temptations and troubles of the ≈øame, from the death of Chri≈øt to the con≈øummation of the world, and their ioyfull deliuerance and victory at that time, by the fir≈øt ≈øixe Seales; and next more amply by the ≈øeuenth Seale, wherin were the ≈øeuen trumpets; and thirdly, her greate≈øt temptations and troubles, more cleerely and at large, by the vi≈øion of the woman, per≈øecuted by the Dragon; and la≈øtly, the cleere and ample de≈øcription, and damnation of Babylon, that great per≈øecuter, the ≈øorrow of the earth, and ioy of heauen therefore: This vi≈øion now that ye ≈øhall pre≈øently heare, was next ≈øhewen vnto me, to ≈øerue for a ≈øumme as it were, and a ≈øhort recapitulation of the whole Prophecie, ≈øo often reiterated before; which is here diuided in three parts: Fir≈øt, the happy e≈øtate of Chri≈øtes Church, though not in the eyes of the world, from his fir≈øt comming to a long time after, as was declared by the fir≈øt Seale: Next, the grieuous troubles and temptations, vnto the which ≈øhee ≈øhall be ≈øubiect thereafter, as was declared by the third and fourth Seale; and by the third, fourth, fift, and ≈øixt bla≈øtes of the Trumpets: And thirdly, the de≈øtruction of all her enemies, her ioyfull deliuerance, and the con≈øummation, as was declared by the ≈øixt Seale, the ≈øeuenth Trumpet, the ≈øeuenth phiale, and the comming downe of the white hor≈øe, which in my la≈øt words before the≈øe, yee heard de≈øcribed: But ≈øpecially in this vi≈øion is declared, the puni≈øhment at the latter day of the deuill him≈øelfe, before the de≈øtruction onely of his in≈øtruments, being mentioned, as ye formerly heard. The vi≈øion then was this; 1 I ≈øaw an Angel come downe from heauen, and he had the key of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, and a great chaine in his hand: 2 And hee tooke the dragon, to wit, the ancient ≈øerpent, who is the deuill and Satan, to wit, the Tempter, and bound him for the ≈øpace of a thou≈øand yeres: 3 And did ca≈øt him in the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, and clo≈øed him in there, that it ≈øhould not be opened, that he might come foorth and ≈øeduce the nations, till the ≈øpace of a thou≈øand yeeres were completed and pa≈øt, for thereafter he mu≈øt be loo≈øed for a ≈øhort ≈øpace. 4 Then I ≈øaw ≈øeats, and per≈øons ≈øitting vpon them, and iudgment or power of iudging was giuen vnto them: And I al≈øo ≈øaw the ≈øoules of them who were beheaded, or otherwi≈øe put to death, for the te≈øtimonie of Chri≈øt, and the word of God, and adored not the Bea≈øt, nor tooke his image, neither his character on their foreheads,
nor on their hands: The≈øe ≈øhal liue and reigne with Chri≈øt, the ≈øpace of the thou≈øand yeres ye heard: 5 But the re≈øt of the dead ≈øhal not reuiue, till the ≈øpace of the≈øe yeres be complete: This is the fir≈øt re≈øurrectioÃÑ. 6 Ble≈ø≈øed and holy is he that is partaker of the fir≈øt re≈øurrection; for ouer ≈øuch the ≈øecond death ≈øhal haue no power, but they ≈øhalbe Prie≈øts of God and Chri≈øt, & ≈øhal reigne with him for euer. This is the fir≈øt part of the diui≈øion, wherof I pre≈øently told you, to wit, Chri≈øt by his pa≈ø≈øion did bind the deuill, who before was raging in the world, and clo≈øed him in hell by the remouing of the vaile of blindnes from the whole earth, which remained ≈øo the ≈øpace of a thou≈øand yeres, to wit, a long ≈øpace, & all that time the deuil remained bound and ca≈øten into hell by Chri≈øt, who only hath power of it; ≈øo as in all that ≈øpace, the nations were not ≈øeduced: for the efficacie of here≈øies was not yet cropen in, and the Saints and Church vi≈øible ≈øhal ≈øo increa≈øe, albeit in the mid≈øt of per≈øecution all this time, and ≈øo retaine the purity of the trewth, as by the glory of their con≈øtancie, and patience in the time of their per≈øecution, they ≈øhall as it were reigne ouer the earth, and by their Martyrdome be Iudges therof; for it is called Chri≈øts reigning and the Saints vpon the earth, when his word, and trew profe≈ø≈øours thereof, ≈øhine vi≈øibly therein, as I haue ≈øaid: and the≈øe were they who adored not the bea≈øt, to wit, they are the elect, who were prede≈øtinate before all beginnings, to be pre≈øerued from all infections and here≈øies, which is generally repre≈øented by this part of them, that the bea≈øt or Babylon ≈øhal rai≈øe and maintaine, as the greate≈øt and mo≈øt perillous that euer ≈øhall be rai≈øed by Satan: And the honourable ≈øitting of the Saints and ≈øoules of Martyrs was ≈øhewed to me, to a≈ø≈øure me, that how ≈øoone the ≈øoule of any faithfull man is parted from the body, it a≈øcendeth immediatly vnto heauen, there abiding in all glory, the reioyning againe of his glorified body at the latter day, coniunctly to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe all glory in heauen eternally; like as by the contrary, the reprobate ≈øoule, how ≈øoone it parteth from the body of the wicked, goes down immediatly to hell, there abiding in all torment, the knitting again with his cur≈øed body at the latter day, there iointly to be ≈øubiect to eternall paine; neither is there any re≈øting place by the way for any of them: and the re≈øt of the dead, to wit, all the wicked, ≈øhal not be reuiued while this ≈øpace be complete; for the wicked ≈øhall neither during this ≈øpace, nor at any time thereafter, ta≈øte of the regeneration, which is the fir≈øt re≈øurrection, and ≈øecond birth, as Chri≈øt ≈øaid to Nicodemus: and therfore, as I ≈øaid already, Ble≈ø≈øed and happy are they who are partakers of the fir≈øt re≈øurrection, for the ≈øecond death, to wit, hell, ≈øhall haue no power of them, but they ≈øhall be Prie≈øts of God and Chri≈øt, and reigne with him the≈øe thou≈øand yeeres, to wit, they ≈øhal eternally in heauen offer vp that Eucharisticall Sacrifice of prai≈øe to God, and ≈øo be ioyned in fellow≈øhip with the cho≈øen, which were vpon the earth in that afore≈øaid time. This fir≈øt part of this vi≈øion is begun alreadie; now followeth the next part. 7 And when the≈øe happy dayes are expired, then ≈øhal the deuill be loo≈øed out of his pri≈øon: 8 And he ≈øhal go forth with greater liberty to ≈øeduce the nations which are in the four airths
of the earth, to wit, he ≈øhal not only, after the ≈øpreding of many here≈øies, cau≈øe a general blindnes & defection, but al≈øo make a great per≈øecution vpon the faithful Church, by gathering Gog and Magog to battell again≈øt them, who≈øe number is like the ≈øand of the ≈øea, to wit, after innumerable troubles, at la≈øt he ≈øhall gather to the great day of the battell of the Lord (of the which ye heard in the ≈øixt Trumpet, and ≈øixt phiale, and la≈øt immediately before this Vi≈øion) Gog and Magog, to wit, two great ≈øeates of Monarchies and Tyrannies ouer the Church, who both at one time ≈øhall ri≈øe in the latter dayes, and both at another time ≈øhalbe de≈øtroyed by the bla≈øt of Chri≈øtes breath, as ye ≈øhall heare; whereof the one is the auowed, and profe≈ø≈øed enemie of GOD, and his CHRIST, but the other is Babylon, the hypocriticall and mo≈øt dangerous aduer≈øary: Of the≈øe two ye heard in the ≈øixt Trumpet, and ≈øo the≈øe two, although pride, and enuie, ≈øhall ≈øtill keepe a rooted malice betwixt them, yet they ≈øhall both with innumerable forces, make warre again≈øt the trew Church, as Herod and Pilate did band them≈øelues again≈øt Chri≈øt, notwith≈øtanding the particular di≈ølikes which were betwixt them: It is the≈øe and their forces that mu≈øt fight again≈øt the Saints at Arma-geddon, as ye heard in the ≈øixt phiale, and the ≈øpecial drawers on of this battell ≈øhalbe the three frogs, who are the la≈øt vermin, bred of the ≈ømoake of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, as ye al≈øo heard in the ≈øaid phiale. 9 The≈øe great forces then went vp vpon the earth; for the diuel rai≈øed them out of the bottomle≈ø≈øe pit, and they ≈øpread them≈øelues vpon the breadth of the earth, ≈øo great was their number, and compa≈ø≈øed the Tents or dwellings of the Saints, and the holy Citie; for they were prepared to inuade the trew Church on all ≈øides, and by all meanes, but the fire came downe from heauen and deuoured them; for God by his Almighty power, euen when their power was greate≈øt, and nothing ≈øo like, as an apparant rooting out of all the faithfull, in rebus desperatis, did miraculou≈øly confound all the aduer≈øaries of his Church: And now comes in the third and la≈øt part of this Vi≈øion, to wit, the de≈øcription of the Con≈øummation: 10 For I did ≈øee the diuel, who ≈øeduced the≈øe wicked, ca≈øt into a lake of fire and brim≈øtone, to wit, in hell, out of the which he ≈øhall neuer come againe, where al≈øo the beast, and the fal≈øe prophet were, as ye heard before; Here now I ≈øaw the diuel puni≈øhed eternally, to my greater comfort, for troubling the Church, where before I ≈øaw onely his in≈øtruments puni≈øhed, as I ≈øaid in the beginning of this Vi≈øion: and he and his in≈øtruments ≈øhall be tormented there day and night, to wit, ince≈ø≈øantly for euer and euer. 11 Then I ≈øaw a great white Throne, and one ≈øitting thereupon in all glory and brightne≈ø≈øe, to wit, IESVS CHRIST, now comming from heauen, to iudge the earth: and from his ≈øight fled the earth and the heauen, and their place was not found; for the whole earth, and much of the heauen ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed and renewed at his la≈øt comming. 12 And I ≈øaw all the dead, great and ≈ømall, ≈øtanding in GOD his ≈øight; for then is the re≈øurrection of the dead, who at that time mu≈øt be iudged: And the bookes were opened,
to wit, the coun≈øels, and ≈øecrets of all mens hearts; and another booke, to wit, the booke of Life was opened, to the effect that all tho≈øe who≈øe names were written into it, to wit, prede≈øtinated and elected for ≈øaluation before all beginnings, might there be ≈øelected for eternall Glory: And the dead were iudged out of the≈øe things which were written in the bookes, according to their workes; for as God is a Spirit, ≈øo iudgeth he the thoughts of man, and ≈øo by faith onely iu≈øtifies him, which notwith≈øtanding is done according to his workes, becau≈øe they, as the fruits of faith, cannot be ≈øeparated from it, and beare witne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øame to men in the earth. 13 And the Sea gaue vp all the dead ≈øhe had; for all the dead mu≈øt then ri≈øe, as I haue ≈øhewed already; And death and hell gaue vp all they had, for not onely the bodies, but euen the ≈øoules of the wicked ≈øhalbe iudged there, and euery one was iudged according to his workes, as I pre≈øently did ≈øhew you. 14 And hell and death were ca≈øten in the Lake of fire, which is the ≈øecond death, to wit, hell and death ≈øhall then be clo≈øed vp for euer within them≈øelues, and ≈øhall neuer againe come forth to trouble the Saints; for death, which is the la≈øt enemie, ≈øhallbe aboli≈øhed from holy Ieru≈øalem for euer. 15 And who≈øoeuers name is not found written in the booke of Life, is ca≈øten into the Lake of fire; for not onely the publike euill doers, but euen who≈øoeuer is not prede≈øtinate for ≈øaluation, ≈øhall at that time be ca≈øten into hell, for there is no midway; but who≈øoeuer gathereth not with Chri≈øt, he ≈øcattereth, as I ≈øhew before.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.

p.hi: A large and glorious de≈øcription of the Church Triumphant in Heauen: and of all the members of that holy and Eternall Ieru≈øalem.

div.p:
NOw the Spirit of God hauing by this la≈øt vi≈øion made a ≈øumme and recapitulation of all the former, as yee haue heard, he, by this following and la≈øt vi≈øion, declareth, and gloriou≈øly de≈øcribeth the reward of all them, who con≈øtantly per≈øeuere vnto the end, in the trew ≈øeruice of God, notwith≈øtanding all the a≈ø≈øaults of Sathan, which ye haue heard dilated: the reward was then, to be eternall inheritours of holy Ieru≈øalem, as yee ≈øhall pre≈øently heare. 1 For I ≈øaw a new heauen and a new earth: it is ouer this new heauen and new earth that the faithfull ≈øhould reigne kings, and prie≈øts for euer, as yee heard before: And the fir≈øt heauen, and the fir≈øt earth went away, neither was the ≈øea any more; for all ≈øhall be burnt with fire at the con≈øummation, which fire ≈øhall renew them, and take away their corruption and mutablitie, releeuing them from the ≈øeruitude of death, to the liberty of the glory of the ≈øonnes of God; who notwith≈øtanding ≈øhall not dwel there but in heauen. 2 And euen I Iohn ≈øaw the holy new City
Ieru≈øalem comming downe from heauen, made ready of God like a bride, that is decked for her bridegroome: For this holy Church triumphant ≈øhal come downe in all ≈øhining glorie to meete Chri≈øt her hu≈øband, when hee ≈øhall haue iudged the world, (as ye haue heard before) to bee incorporated and ioyned with him for euer. 3 And I heard a mighty voyce from heauen, ≈øaying, for confirmation of this happy coniunction; Loe the Tabernacle of God, and his dwelling place is with men, and hee will now dwell with them for euer, and they ≈øhall be his people, and he ≈øhall be a God with them, and their God: 4 And God ≈øhall wipe all teares from their eyes; for they ≈øhall feele no more any ≈øorow, as ye haue often heard before, and death ≈øhall be no more, neither ≈øhal any ≈øorow, crying, or dolour euer be in that Church triumphant; for the fir≈øt are gone away, and all the≈øe things then ≈øhall haue an end. 5 And then hee that ≈øate vpon the Throne, to wit, God the Father, ≈øaid, Loe, I make new or renew all things, and he ≈øaid vnto me, Write, and leaue in record what thou ha≈øt ≈øeene: for ≈øurely the≈øe words are faithfull and trew, and ≈øhall come certainely to pa≈ø≈øe. 6 And he al≈øo ≈øaid vnto me, It is done, for when the≈øe things ≈øhall come to pa≈ø≈øe, then is the full accompli≈øhment of all things, I am A and Œ©, to wit, the beginning, and the ending of all things: For as I made the Creation, ≈øo ≈øhall I cau≈øe the Con≈øummation. And I ≈øhall giue to him that thir≈øteth, of the fountaine of water of life, freely, or for nothing, to wit, he will grant ≈øaluation to all them who cal vpon him for it, and that for nothing; for it coÃÑmeth of his free mercie, and not of any merit in vs: How fooli≈øh then are they to be accompted, who contemning that ≈øaluation which they may obtaine for the crauing, buie with their ≈øiluer a counterfeit ≈øaluation from Babylon, as ye heard before? 7 And he that ouercommeth Satan and his owne fle≈øh ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe all, to wit, he ≈øhall be a full inheritour of Gods kingdome, and I ≈øhall be a God to him, and he ≈øhall be a ≈øonne to me: 8 But for all them who are fearefull and vnbeleeuing, not hauing a ≈øure confidence and tru≈øt in my promi≈øes, and for execrable men, and murtherers, and fornicators, and ≈øorcerers, and idolaters, and all lyers, for all the≈øe ≈øorts of men, I ≈øay, there is place appointed in that lake, which burneth with fire and brim≈øtone, which is the ≈øecond death. 9 Then there came vnto me one of the≈øe ≈øeuen Angels, which had the ≈øeuen phials ful of the ≈øeuen la≈øt plagues, and he ≈øayd vnto me, Come and I will ≈øhew vnto thee the Bride, which is the Wife of the Lambe: for this Angel was directed to ≈øhewe mee the glorie of this holy Hieru≈øalem, the Church triumphant, not to ≈øatisfie my curio≈øity therewith, but that I might leaue in record to all po≈øterities to come, not as a hearer onely, but as an Oculatus testis, what glorious, and eternall reward did abide all the faithfull. 10 And ≈øo he tooke me vp in the Spirit to a high and great Mountaine; for it became well, that ≈øo glorious a ≈øight ≈øhould be ≈øhewen vpon ≈øo eminent a place, and there hee did ≈øhew mee a great Citie, to wit, that holy Ieru≈øalem, comming downe from heauen, and from God, as ye heard before. 11 And it had the glory of God in it, and
the light or brightne≈ø≈øe of it, was like vnto the glittering of a mo≈øt pretious ≈øtone, yea euen like the greene Iasper in flouri≈øhing eternitie, and like the cleare Cristall in ≈øhining brightne≈ø≈øe; 12 And this Citie had a great and high wall, to hold out all them who had not the marke of the Lambe, as ye ≈øhall heare after, and to protect the Citizens from all bla≈øtes of troubles, for all teares will then bee wipte from their eyes, as ye heard before; And this Citie had al≈øo twelue gates, and in them twelue Angels, and their names were written vpon them, which were the names of the twelue Tribes of the ≈øonnes of I≈ørael. 13 And there were three gates towards the Ea≈øt, three towards the We≈øt, three towards the South, and three towards the North, to ≈øignifie that out of all parts and places of the world, and what≈øoeuer thy vocation be, if thou call to God with an vpright heart, thou ≈øhalt find that the entrance into the Citie, is equally di≈øtributed about the ≈øame. 14 And the wall of the Citie had twelue foundations, whereupon were written the twelue names of the Apo≈øtles of the Lambe: The≈øe twelue Angels of the twelue gates, and twelue foundations of the wall, are the foure and twentie Elders, of whom ye heard in the beginning of this my Epi≈øtle; the twelue Angels of the twelue gates, are the twelue Patriarkes, who were the fir≈øt teachers of the way, and ≈øo the guides to this holy Ieru≈øalem; for by the Law which they repre≈øent, we mu≈øt fir≈øt beginne to know the trewth, and to know our ≈øelues: and the twelue foundations are we, the twelue Apo≈øtles, for vpon our doctrine is that wall founded which hedgeth in the Saints in an eternall ≈øecuritie, and debarreth all others. 15 And the Angel who ≈øpake with me, had a golden reed in his hand, to mea≈øure therewith the Citie, and the gates, and the walles of the ≈øame, thereby to ≈øignifie the iu≈øt proportion and ≈øymmetrie, that ≈øhall be among all the parts of this holy Citie. 16 And this Citie was foure≈øquare, becau≈øe of the gates towards the foure parts of the earth, to receiue indifferently the commers out of any of them, as yee heard before; And it was alike long and broad, to ≈øignifie the infinite bounds thereof: and hee mea≈øured the Citie with his reed, and it came to twelue thou≈øand furlongs: this number al≈øo expre≈ø≈øeth the great bounds of this Citie; for it is here v≈øed for a number of perfection, as ≈øundry times before: And this Citie was alike in length, breadth and height, for all the parts of it were alike large. 17 And the Angel did mea≈øure the wall of it, and it was an hundred and foure and fourtie cubites of height: this number is corre≈øpondent to the number of Saints, who were ≈øtanding with the Lambe on Mount Sion, as ye heard before; and the mea≈øure wherewith this was mea≈øured, was the mea≈øure of the man, which is the mea≈øure of the Angel; This Citie is mea≈øured with the mea≈øure of CHRIST, God and man, to teach vs that he is onely the Architectour of this Spirituall Citie, which he mea≈øureth by his cubites, and not by the cubites of any man. 18 And the fabricke of the wall of the Citie, was compo≈øed of Iasper, to ≈øignifie that the wall thereof ≈øhall ≈øtand eternally: and the Citie it ≈øelfe was of pure
gold, and like to cleere gla≈ø≈øe, whereon no filth will remaine. 19 And the twelue foundations of the Citie were decked with all kind of precious ≈øtones: the fir≈øt foundation was of Ia≈øper, the ≈øecond of Saphire, the third of Chalcedonie, the fourth of Emerald, 20 The fift of a Sardonix, the ≈øixt of a Sardius, the ≈øeuenth of a Chry≈øolite, the eight of a Berill, the ninth of a Topaze, the tenth of a Chry≈øophra≈øus, the eleuenth of an Hyacinth, the twelfth of an Amethi≈øt: The≈øe twelue ≈øundry ≈øtones, one for euery one of the foundations, ≈øignifie, that we, the twelue Apo≈øtles, who are the≈øe twelue foundations (as ye heard) ≈øhall euery one receiue a diuers reward and crowne of glory, according to the greatne≈ø≈øe and excellencie of our labours in the earth: the≈øe twelue precious ≈øtones allude al≈øo to the twelue precious ≈øtones in Aarons bre≈øtplate. 21 And the twelue gates were of twelue pearles, and euery gate of a ≈øundry pearle; (this ≈øignifies the like of the Patriarches) and the Market place of the Citie was of pure golde, and like the gli≈øtering gla≈ø≈øe, ≈øignifying thereby, as by an euident token, that ≈øeeing the Market place (which is the commone≈øt place of euery towne) of this ≈øpirituall City, is of ≈øo fine and bright ≈øtuffe, that no ba≈øe, and vncleane thing ≈øhall be in any part thereof: 22 And I ≈øaw no Temple in it, for the Lord God Almightie, euen the Lambe, is the Temple of it, for no other ≈øhall be there wherein God mu≈øt be prai≈øed, but the per≈øon of Chri≈øt, in whom all the faithfull ≈øhall be incorporated, as I ≈øaid before. 23 And this Citie ≈øhall neede no Sunne nor Moone to ≈øhine in it, for the glory of God hath made it bright, and the Lambe is the lampe thereof; for as it is no corporall paradi≈øe nor dwelling place on earth, which is heere ≈øpoken of, ≈øo is no part of the glory thereof earthly, but cele≈øtiall and ≈øpirituall: 24 And the Gentiles which are ≈øaued, ≈øhall walke in that light, and the kings of the earth ≈øhall bring their glory vnto that citie; for all the faithfull kings ≈øhall re≈øigne all their worldly glory in that citie, and receiue a new and incorruptible glory from the Lambe, who is the light thereof: 25 And the gates thereof ≈øhall not be ≈øhut in the day time; for there ≈øhall neuer be any ≈øu≈øpicion of trouble there, for which cau≈øe worldly cities often ≈øhut their gates, and the night ≈øhall neuer be there, but an eternall brightne≈ø≈øe through all. 26 And the honour and the glory of the nations ≈øhall be brought into her, for all their worldly glory ≈øhalbe nothing in re≈øpect of the glory of this City. 27 And there ≈øhall nothing enter into this Citie that defileth or is defiled, nor no man that committeth any abominable deed, or that ≈øpeakes lies, but onely the≈øe ≈øhall haue entrance into this holy City, who≈øe names are written in the Lambe his booke of Life, as ye heard before.

div.head: THE MEDITATION.
div.p: AS of all Bookes the holy Scripture is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for the in≈øtruction of a Chri≈øtian, and of all the Scriptures, the Booke of the REVELATION is mo≈øt meete for this our la≈øt aage, The nece≈ø≈øitie of the knowledge of the Reuelation. as a Prophe≈øie of the latter times: ≈øo haue I ≈øelected or cho≈øen out this place thereof, as mo≈øt proper for the action we haue in hand pre≈øently. A ≈øumme of the 20. Chap. of the Reuelation. For after the Apo≈øtle IOHN had prophe≈øied of the latter times, in the nineteenth Chapter afore-going, he now in this twentieth Chapter gathered vp a ≈øumme of the whole, wherein are expre≈ø≈øed three heads or principall points.
1. Fir≈øt, the happie e≈øtate of the Church, from Chri≈øts dayes, to the dayes of the defection or falling away of the Antichri≈øt, in the fir≈øt ≈øixe ver≈øes of this 20. Chapter.
2 Next, the defection or falling away it ≈øelfe, in this place that I haue in hand, to wit, the ≈øeuenth, eight, ninth, and tenth ver≈øes.
3 Thirdly, the generall puni≈øhment of the wicked in the great day of Iudgement, from the tenth ver≈øe vnto the end of the Chapter.

The Apo≈øtle his meaning in this place then is this, The meaning of this pre≈øent text. That after that Satan then had bene bound a thou≈øand yeeres, which did appeare by his di≈øcour≈øe afore-going, of the Saints triumphing in the earth, hee ≈øhall at la≈øt breake forth againe loo≈øe, and for a ≈øpace rage in the earth more then euer before: but yet ≈øhall in the end be ouercome and confounded for euer..

It re≈øteth now, knowing the ≈øumme, that we come to the expo≈øition or meaning of the Ver≈øes; The order ob≈øerued in handling this text. and fir≈øt expound or lay open by way of a Paraphra≈øe the hardne≈ø≈øe of the words, next declare the meaning of them, and thirdly note what we ≈øhould learne of all.

div.head: THE FIRST PART.
div.p: AS touching the wordes in them for order ≈øake, wee may note: 1 Fir≈øt Satan his loo≈øing: 2 next his doing, after he is loo≈øed: 3 and la≈øt his vnhappie ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

Then for the fir≈øt, Satan in his in≈øtruments is loo≈øed to trouble the Church. by Satan is meant not onely the Dragon, enemie to Chri≈øt and his Church, but al≈øo with him all the in≈øtruments in whom he ruleth, and by whom he ruleth, and by whom he vttereth his cruell and crafty intentions, ≈øpecially the Antichri≈øt and his Clergie, ioyned with the Dragon before in the 16. Chap. ver≈øe 17. and called the bea≈øt, and the fal≈øe prophet. For as Chri≈øt and his Church are called after one Name, Chri≈øt, by rea≈øon of their mo≈øt ≈øtrait and neere vnion, and heauenly effects flowing there from, 1. Cor. 12.12. So Satan and his ≈øinagogue are here rightly called Satan, The thou≈øand yeeres. by rea≈øon of their vnion, and cur≈øed effects flowing therefrom. The≈øe thou≈øand yeeres, are but a number certaine for an vncertaine, which phra≈øe or maner of ≈øpeaking, is often v≈øed by the Spirit of God in the Scriptures, meaning a great number of yeeres.

Moreouer, The pri≈øon whereout Satan is loo≈øed. the pri≈øon whereout he is loo≈øed, is the hels, which by the Spirit of God are called his pri≈øon, for two cau≈øes: 1 One, becau≈øe during the time of this world, at times appointed by God, he is debarred from walking on the earth, 2. Pet. 2.4. Finally, he is loo≈øed by interruption or hindering, and for the mo≈øt part, The loo≈øing of Satan. to the iudgement of men, abolition or ouerthrow of the ≈øincere preaching of the Go≈øpel, the true v≈øe of the Sacraments, which are ≈øeales and pledges of the promi≈øes contained therein, and lawfull exerci≈øe of Chri≈øtian di≈øcipline, whereby both Word and Sacraments are maintained in purity, called in the fir≈øt ver≈øe the great chaine, whereby the diuell
is bound and ≈øignified by the white hor≈øe, gouerned by the Lambe. Chap. 6. ver≈øe 2. So the meaning of all this 7. ver≈øe is this: The diuel, hauing bene bound, and his power in his in≈øtruments hauing bene re≈øtrained for a long ≈øpace, by the preaching of the Go≈øpel, at the la≈øt he is loo≈øed out of hell by the rai≈øing vp of ≈øo many new errors and notable euill in≈øtruments, e≈øpecially the Antichri≈øt and his Clergie, who not onely infect the earth a new, but rule al≈øo ouer the whole, through the decrea≈øe of trew doctrine, and the number of the faithfull following it, and the dayly increa≈øe of errours, and nations following them, and beleeuing lies hating the trewth, and taking plea≈øure in vnrighteou≈ønes, 2. The≈ø≈ø. 2.11, 12. And thus farre for Satan his loo≈øing.

Now to the next, his doing after he is loo≈øed. Satan fir≈øt deceaueth, then allures to follow him, and in the end maketh all his to take armour again≈øt the Church. Fir≈øt he goeth out to ≈øeduce or beguile the nations that are into the foure corners of the earth, and they become his, though in certaine degrees his tyrannie and trauaile appeareth, and bur≈øteth out in ≈øome more then in others: For as all that doe good, are in≈øpired of God thereto, and doe vtter the ≈øame in certaine degrees, according vnto the mea≈øure of grace granted vnto them: ≈øo all that doe euill, are in≈øpired by Satan, and doe vtter the ≈øame in diuers degrees, according as that vncleane ≈øpirit taketh po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in them, and by diuers obiects and meanes, allureth them to doe his will, ≈øome by ambition, ≈øome by enuie, ≈øome by malice, and ≈øome by feare, and ≈øo forth: and this is the fir≈øt worke.

Secondly, he gathereth Gog and Magog to battell, Gog and Magog. in number like the ≈øand of the Sea, and ≈øo he and his inclined to battell and blood≈øhed, haue mightie armies, and in number many, inflamed with crueltie. The ≈øpecial heads and rulers of their armies, or rather rankes of their confederats, to goe to battel and to fight, are twaine, here named Gog and Magog; Gog in Hebrew is called Hid, and Magog Reuealed, to ≈øignifie that in two ≈øorts of men chiefly Satan ≈øhall vtter him≈øelfe, to wit, hypocrites, and auowed or open enemies to God: It is ≈øaid then that Satan ≈øhall in the latter times rule a new ouer the world, who ≈øhall ≈øtirre vp the nations vnder the banners of the≈øe two enemies to God, the hypocriticall and open, to ≈øpread them≈øelues in great multitudes vpon the earth.

Thirdly, they ≈øhall a≈øcend vpon the plaine of the earth, pre≈øumptuou≈øly and proudly, bragging of their number and force, and thinking none ≈øhall be able to re≈øi≈øt their rage: They ≈øhall compa≈ø≈øe and be≈øiege the campes of the Saints, and beloued Citie, that is, the handfull of the faithfull beloued of the Lord, again≈øt whome, tru≈øting in their vntellable number, like the ≈øand of the ≈øea, they ≈øhall make a cruell and vnce≈ø≈øable warre.

The elect are called Saints and beloued, The Elect are the Saints and beloued Citie of God. becau≈øe they are in the loue of God ≈øelected and ≈øeuered out, and by grace engraffed in Chri≈øt, in whom they are counted and found iu≈øtified, ≈øanctified, worthy of loue and endle≈ø≈øe glorie: Their faithfull fellow≈øhip is compared to Tents, and to a Citie beloued, to ≈øignifie their continuall warfare in the earth again≈øt Satan
and ≈øinne, with all his in≈øtruments: their mutual amitie, and friendly coniunction in loue among them≈øelues, and ioyning together to maintaine the good cau≈øe that their God hath clad them with: but chiefly to ≈øignifie the mightie and al-≈øufficient protection or defence in pro≈øperity and aduer≈øity, flowing from God for their iu≈øt aide again≈øt all powers that can pur≈øue, whereby they al≈øo become faire as the Moone, pure as the Sunne, terrible as an armie with banners, Cant. 1.6, 9. Yea as a defenced Citie, and yron pillar and wals of Bra≈ø≈øe again≈øt the whole earth, Ierem. 1.18.

The ≈øumme then of Satan his doing after he is loo≈øed, The ≈øumme of Satan his doing after he is loo≈øed. is this: hee ≈øhall deceiue the nations: he ≈øhall gather an infinite number of hypocrites and open enemies together, inflamed with crueltie, and the≈øe ≈øhall in pridefull pre≈øumption fiercely bend them≈øelues again≈øt the cho≈øen of God, and his trewth profe≈ø≈øed by them. But what at la≈øt ≈øhall the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe be? ≈øurely mo≈øt vnhappy: for fire ≈øhall come downe from heauen and deuoure them, and the diuell that deceiued them, and all his in≈øtruments, chiefly the Bea≈øt and fal≈øe Prophet ≈øhall be ca≈øt in a lake of fire and brim≈øtone, The vnhappy ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of Satan. and ≈øhall bee tormented day and night ince≈ø≈øantly for euer and euer: that is, how greatly ≈øoeuer their brags be, how neere ≈øoeuer they ≈øhall appeare to be to obtaine their purpo≈øe, God from heauen, as the pallace and throne, wherefrom hee giueth proofe of his mercie towards his owne, and of his iu≈øtice toward his enemies, ≈øhall ≈øend plagues and de≈øtruction, as well ordinary, as extraordinarie vpon them: Ordinarie, by reuealing their wickedne≈ø≈øe by the thundring mouthes of trew pa≈øtors, which is oft called fire in the Scriptures: Extraordinarie, by all corporall plagues to their vtter de≈øtruction, and vntellable torment for euer in the hels. Thus farre for the expo≈øition or paraphra≈øe of the words.

div.head: THE SECOND PART.
div.p:
NOw followeth the interpretation of the ≈øentence according to the order v≈øed in the fir≈øt part. The putitie of the Go≈øpel induring, ≈øtayeth the Antechri≈øt his ri≈øing. And fir≈øt we mu≈øt know what time the≈øe thou≈øand or many yeres was in, and when, and how Satan was loo≈øed. This time is to be found in the ≈øixt Chapter, in the opening of the fir≈øt three ≈øeales of the ≈øecret booke of God his prouidence by the Lambe, to wit, the time when the white, red, and blacke hor≈øes had their cour≈øe in the world: And to ≈øpeake more plainely, the Diuell his power did lurke, which is called his binding, and the Go≈øpel did flouri≈øh in a rea≈øonable puritie many hundreth yeeres after Chri≈øt, as the Eccle≈øia≈øticall hi≈øtories beare witne≈ø≈øe: For in great puritie the Go≈øpel did continue long, which is ≈øignified by the cour≈øe of the white hor≈øe, albeit the profe≈ø≈øors were vnder the cro≈ø≈øe ≈øignified by the red hor≈øe, and troubled wonderfully by heretickes, ≈øignified by the blacke hor≈øe, by wormewood that fell in the Fountaines of waters in the third trumpet, and by waters that the dragon ≈øpewed out of his mouth, in the vi≈øion of the Dragon and the woman, chap. 12. This time did endure
from Chri≈øt a ≈øpace after Augu≈øtine his dayes, when the bloodie Sword of per≈øecution cea≈øing, the whole Church began to be defiled with diuers here≈øies, which comming vnto a mature and ripe heape, did produce or bring foorth the Antechri≈øt, ≈øignified by the pale hor≈øe in the fourth ≈øeale, by the king of the Locu≈øts in the fift trumpet, by Babylon in the 11 and 18. Chapter, by the ≈øecond Bea≈øt ri≈øing out of the ≈øea in the 13. Chapter, and by the woman clad with ≈øcarlet in the 17. chapter. The ari≈øings of the here≈øies, and the Antichri≈øt breeding of their ≈ømoake, is in this place called the loo≈øing of Satan.

Now followeth after this his loo≈øing, what he doeth: The Go≈øpel being hid, the Antichri≈øt beginneth to breed & tend to his height. He deceiueth the nations vniuer≈øally: he gathereth Gog and Magog with vntellable armies to fight, he climeth vpon the plaine of the earth, he compa≈ø≈øeth the tents of the Saints, and the beloued Citie about: The≈øe are his doings.

Now becau≈øe the≈øe actions are mo≈øt liuely declared in other places of the ≈øame booke, I will ≈øhortly alleadge them to make the matter cleere by conference of places, expounding euery one another. div.head: THE FIRST PART.
div.p:

The cau≈øes moouing Dauid, pa≈ø≈øing all others, I note two: One internall, the other, external: the internall was a feruent and zealous mind in Dauid fully di≈øpo≈øed to extoll the glorie of God that had called him to be King, as he ≈øaith him≈øelfe. The externall was a notable victorie newly obtained by the power of God ouer and again≈øt the Phili≈øtines, olde and pernitious enemies to the people of God, expre≈ø≈øed in the la≈øt part of the 14. chapter preceding. div.head: THE SECOND PART.
div.p:
NOw followes ≈øecondly the per≈øons who did concurre with Dauid in this action: Three rankes of per≈øons concurre with Dauid in this worke. The Spirit noteth three rankes of them. In the fir≈øt are the Elders of I≈ørael: In the next, are the captaines ouer thou≈øands: In the third; are the Prie≈øts and Leuites, of whom ≈øummarily I will ≈øpeake. And without all que≈øtion, godly and zealous Dauid would neuer haue committed the guard of his per≈øon, nor the fighting of Gods battailes to the enemies of God, or men of warre, of who≈øe godline≈ø≈øe and vertue he neuer had proofe: See then their names and prai≈øe, 1. Chron. 11.26. The third ranke of Prie≈øts and Leuites are ≈øet downe in the ≈øame chapter, ver≈ø. 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11. So men of all e≈øtates were pre≈øent in this godly worke. For becau≈øe ye were not there at the fir≈øt, the Lord our God made a breach among vs: for we ≈øought him not in due order. And thus farre for the ≈øecond part concerning per≈øons: Wherein we may learne, fir≈øt, that a godly king findes, as his heart wi≈øheth, godly e≈øtates concurring with him. Next a godly king of his godly fore≈øight in choo≈øing good vnder-rulers, reapeth this profit and plea≈øure, that as hee goeth before, ≈øo they with zealous hearts doe follow.

div.head: THE THIRD PART.
div.p:
THe ≈øumme of this ioyfull conuoy may be dige≈øted in three actions, The Arke is tran≈øported with ioy to Ieru≈øalem. which are the≈øe: The tran≈øporting of the Arke; the harmony of mu≈øicall in≈øtruments; and Dauids dancing and reioycing before it. He built a Tabernacle for the Arke in mount Sion, & tran≈øported it therunto, to ≈øignify his thankfulnes for the many victories God had put in his hands: and this tran≈øporting was the occa≈øion of all this ≈øolemnitie and reioycing that followed thereupon. The ≈øignification of the Arke of the Couenant. As to the Arke it ≈øelfe, we know it was built by Moy≈øes at the coÃÑmand of God, in the wildernes of Sinai. This Arke was made of Shittim wood, which admits no corruption: It was of mo≈øt comely ≈øhape and forme, two cubits and a halfe in length, a cubit and a halfe in height, and a cubit and a halfe in breadth, ouerlaid within and without with pure beaten gold, and was not only a figure of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our perfect Sauiour, in whom
all the promi≈øes of God, are yea and Amen, 2. Corinth. 1.20. and in whom as a ≈øure Arke, all abundance of Gods ble≈ø≈øings are placed, that out of his fulne≈ø≈øe we may all receiue grace vpon grace, Iohn 1.16. ≈øeeing he is made vnto vs of God, wi≈øedome, righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, ≈øanctification and redemption, 1. Corinth. 1.30. but al≈øo a ≈øure pledge of Gods continuall pre≈øence in Chri≈øt with his people, to ble≈ø≈øe them with all maner of ble≈ø≈øings. And to ≈øignifie this purpo≈øe more particularly, within the Arke was placed the Tables of the Couenant, and Law written by God, (for which cau≈øe al≈øo it was called the Arke of the Couenant) Rom. 10.4. to teach them in Chri≈øt promi≈øed, the perfection of the whole Law to be found, for all that beleeue in him. Aboue the Arke was a couer or lid called The Mercie Seate, and aboue the lid the figures of two Cherubins, couering with their wings the Mercie Seat: betwixt the which two, the liuing God did louingly ≈øpeake to the in≈øtruction and comfort of his people, to a≈ø≈øure them that all Gods mercifull dealings with man (either in communicating his knowledge to them: or in ≈øending his Angels mini≈øtring Spirits for their comfort,) Heb. 1.14. Ioh. 1.4, 11. hath the ground and foundation in CHRIST IESVS eternally. This Arke then being a ≈øure Sacrament of Gods fauour towards them, and a Couenant of IESVS CHRIST, wherein corporally Gods mercifull promi≈øes did in≈øue; followes the third part, the forme of doing v≈øed therein by the≈øe per≈øons. Generally, the action was to bring vp the Arke of the Couenant of the Lord, from the hou≈øe of Obed Edom with ioy, and to be placed in the Tabernacle built for it by the King in Mount Sion. The forme of doing v≈øed by euery per≈øon, is: The Prie≈øts offer Bullocks and Rammes, becau≈øe that God ble≈ø≈øed the worke; The King clad in a linnen garment, dances and playes before the Arke: Chenaniah the chiefe of the ≈øingers with his fellowes, prai≈øes God with P≈øalmes, and all the e≈øtates in I≈ørael, bring the Arke of the Couenant with ≈øhowting, ≈øound of Cornet, Trumpet, cymbals, violes, and harpes, and place it in the citie of Dauid. Briefly then, Dauid vpon his victories doeth tran≈øport to his hou≈øe the ≈øame, to te≈øtifie hereby his care to receiue Gods fauour towards him and his people: Not thinking it enough to haue once or twi≈øe proofe thereof; but al≈øo to procure a continuance by the pre≈øence of his holy Arke, e≈øteeming this the worthie≈øt trophee or triumph, he could make or erect for his notable victories: A triumph indeed farre ≈øurpa≈øsing the Egyptian Piramides, the Grecian trophees, or yet the Romane triumphall chariots. As to the harmonie and mu≈øicall in≈øtruments that accompanied this holy Arke, I tru≈øt no man is ignorant of the cu≈øtome that was among the Iewes, in prai≈øing. God with all kind of in≈øtruments, as Dauids P≈øalmes innumerable times beare witne≈ø≈øe. But in ca≈øe ≈øome would demand wherefore the Church of God ≈øhould more extraordinarily reioyce at one time, then at another, ≈øeeing we are a≈ø≈øured that all Gods actions towards vs, are for our weale, either ≈øpiritually or corporally, ≈øuppo≈øe wee cannot at euery time comprehend it: I an≈øwere, that although I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe that ≈øentence to bee mo≈øt
orthodoxe, yet mu≈øt I al≈øo confe≈ø≈øe, that when≈øoeuer it ≈øhall plea≈øe God to manife≈øt by outward ≈øignes to the world, as at one time more then another the great loue to his Church, by ≈øome notable worke for their deliuerance; We are then of duty bound in the highe≈øt degree to prai≈øe God, as well for confirming of the weake ones among≈øt vs, as for ≈øtopping of the mouthes, and da≈øhing of the proud wicked without vs, to make the glory of his Name, as farre as in vs lieth, to re≈øound: The manifold examples of the Saints of God through the whole Scriptures prooue this more then euidently, be≈øides the examples of the prayers of ≈øundry of the godly, who for the glory of his Name, more then for their particular weale, haue prayed him to giue publike te≈øtimonie of his loue towards them: So did Mo≈øes, Io≈øhua, Dauid, Elias, Elizeus, and innumerable others of the Prophets and ≈øeruants of God. As to the dancing of Dauid: dancing, playing, and ≈øuch like actions we know are of them≈øelues indifferent, and good or euil according to their v≈øe, and the intention of the v≈øer; and therefore being v≈øed at this time with a comely zeale, for the ≈øetting foorth of Gods glory, are not onely to be borne with and excu≈øed, but euen mo≈øt highly to be pray≈øed and commended, although that Michal di≈øpray≈øed the ≈øame. Moreouer, it is to be marked that Dauid in this doing, did nothing without the ≈øpecial motion of the ≈øpirit of God, as an extraordinarie worke, which ≈øo fully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed his ≈øoule at this pre≈øent, that forgetfull, as it were, of the actions of his bodie; hee gaue his whole per≈øon ouer to be gouerned as it plea≈øed him, alwayes ≈øeeking in all, the honour and glorie of his God, without re≈øpect to him≈øelfe: Chri≈øt is the ground of all true Religion. And thus farre for the third part: Whereof wee haue to note fir≈øt in the Arke: The ground of all true and ancient religion, and the body of the whole ≈øeruice of God that brings ≈øaluation, is to bee ≈øituate in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt onely, as is plainely ≈øet downe, Act. 4.12. Ioh. 14.6. 1. Cor. 2.11. 1. Ioh. 1.7. Next, that they which will be ≈øaued by this Arke, mu≈øt beare this Arke in their heart by faith, in their mouth by open confe≈ø≈øion, Rom. 1. and in their actions confirming their whole doing in their calling to his will, Matth. 7.21, 22, 23. Thirdly, that they who are ≈øincerely ioyned with Chri≈øt, reioyce in the bearing of Chri≈øt, and count it their highe≈øt ioy to be occupied continually in his bearing.

div.head: THE FOVRTH PART.
div.p:
AS to the per≈øon of Michal, Michals hypocri≈øie. ≈øhee was Sauls daughter, and Dauids wife, a woman appearandly euill brought vp by amo≈øt wicked father; which the Spirit of God will ≈øignifie, by calling her Sauls daughter as ≈øhe was in hypocri≈øie his daughter in deed, as well as by nature: yet ≈øhee was ioyned with the body of the Church vi≈øible, which is ≈øignified by the ≈øtile giuen her, when ≈øhe was called Dauids wife: And ≈øo ≈øhe was outwardly a per≈øon ioyned by mariage in ≈øocietie with the Church, yet in effect a lurking hypocrite
within the bowels of the ≈øame. Such kinde of folkes (hypocrites I meane) are a malum nece≈ø≈øarium in≈øeparably and continually ioyned with the trew Church, neuer to be ≈øifted while the Ma≈øter of the Harue≈øt come with the fanne in his hand.

div.head: THE FIFT PART.
div.p: HEr doings are, being quiet in her lodging, Michals doings. al the time of her hu≈øbands great and publike reioycing with the people not comming out; for not being able, as appeareth, to counterfeit finely euough a di≈ø≈øimulate ioyfull countenance: And therefore looking out at a window, ≈øhee ≈øpies her husband dancing before the Arke, incontinent interprets ≈øhee this indifferent action in malam partem, as not being touched with a true feeling of the cau≈øe of his ioy, and ≈øo de≈øpi≈øes ≈øhe his doing in her minde, as onely proceeding of a la≈øciuious wantonne≈ø≈øe. A marueilous ca≈øe; ≈øhee that before of naturall loue to her husband did pre≈øerue him, although to her owne great perill, from the hands of her owne father Saul, cannot now abide to ≈øee him v≈øe aright that indifferent action, which ≈øhe her ≈øelfe (I doubt not) did oft through licentiou≈ønes abu≈øe. By this we may note the nature of the hypocrites, and interiour enemies of the Church, who although in their particulars not concerning Religion, there will be none in ≈øhew more friendly to the godly then they; yet how ≈øoone matters of Religion or concerning the honour of God, comes in hand, O then are they no longer able to containe or bridle their pa≈ø≈øions, euen as here Michal defended her husband, euen in the particulars betwixt him and her owne father; but his dancing before the Arke to the honour of God ≈øhe could no wi≈øe abide.

div.head: His Maie≈øties owne Sonnet.
div.l: THe nations banded gain≈øt the Lord of might
Prepar'd a force, and ≈øet them to the way:
Mars dre≈øt him≈øelfe in ≈øuch an awfull plight,
The like whereof was neuer≈øeene they ≈øay:
They forward came in mon≈øtrous aray,
Both Sea and land be≈øet vs euery where:
Bragges threatned vs a ruinous decay,
What came of that? the i≈ø≈øue did declare.
The windes began to to≈ø≈øe them here and there,
The Seas begun in foming waues to ≈øwell:
The number that e≈øcap'd, it fell them faire:
The re≈øt were ≈øwallowed vp in gulfes of hell:
But how were all the≈øe things miraculous done?
God laught at them out of his heauenly throne.

div.head: DAEMONOLOGIE, IN FORME OF A DIALOGVE, Diuided into three Bookes,
div.byline: WRITTEN BY THE HIGH AND MIGHTIE PRINCE, IAMES by the Grace of GOD King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.

div.head: ¬∂ THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
THe fearefull abounding at this time in this Countrey, of the≈øe detestable ≈ølaues of the Diuel, the Witches or enchaunters, hath mooued mee (beloued Reader) to di≈øpatch in po≈øt, this following Treati≈øe of mine, not in any wi≈øe (as J protest) to ≈øerue for a ≈øhew of my learning and ingine, but onely (moued of con≈øcience) to prea≈ø≈øe thereby, ≈øo farre as I can, to re≈øolue the doubting hearts of many; both that ≈øuch a≈ø≈øaults of Satan are mo≈øt certainely practi≈øed, and that the instruments thereof, merits most ≈øeuerely to be puni≈øhed: again≈øt the damnable opinions of two principally in our aage, whereof the one called Scot, an Engli≈øhman, is not a≈øhamed in publike Print to deny, that there can be ≈øuch a
thing as Witch-craft: and ≈øo maintaines the old errour of the Sadduces in denying of ≈øpirits; The other called Wierus, a German Phy≈øition, ≈øets out a publike Apologie for all the≈øe craft≈ø-folkes, whereby, procuring for their impunitie, he plainely bewrayes him≈øelfe to haue bene one of that profe≈øsion. And for to make this Treati≈øe the more plea≈øant and facill, J haue put it in forme of a Dialogue, which I haue diuided into three Bookes: The first ≈øpeaking of Magie in generall, and Necromancie in ≈øpeciall: The ≈øecond, of Sorcerie and Witch-craft: and the third, containes a di≈øcour≈øe of all the≈øe kinds of ≈øpirits, and Spectres that appeares and troubles per≈øons, together with a conclu≈øion of the whole worke. My intention in this labour, is onely to prooue two things, as I haue already ≈øaid: The one, that ≈øuch diueli≈øh artes haue bene and are: The other, what exact triall and ≈øeuere puni≈øhment they merit: and therefore rea≈øon I, What kinde of things are po≈øsible to be performed in the≈øe Arts, and by what naturall cau≈øes they may be, not that I touch euery particular thing of the Diuels power, for that were infinite: but onely to ≈øpeake ≈øchola≈øtickely, (≈øince this cannot be ≈øpoken in our language) J rea≈øon vpon genus leauing ≈øpecies, and differentia to bee comprehended therein: As for example, ≈øpeaking of the power of Magiciens, in the fir≈øt booke and ≈øixt Chapter, I ≈øay, that they can ≈øuddenly cau≈øe be brought vnto them, all kinds of daintie di≈øhes, by their familiar ≈øpirit; ≈øince as a thiefe he delights to ≈øteale, and as a ≈øpirit he can ≈øubtilly and ≈øuddenly ynough tran≈øport the ≈øame. Now vnder this genus, may be comprehended all particulars, depending thereupon; ≈øuch as the bringing Wine out of a wall (as wee haue heard oft to haue bene practi≈øed) and ≈øuch others; which particulars, are ≈øufficiently prooued by the rea≈øons of the generall. And ≈øuch like in the ≈øecond booke of Witch-craft in ≈øpeciall, and fift Chapter, J ≈øay, and proue by diuers Arguments, that Witches can by the power of their master, cure or cast on di≈øea≈øes: Now by the≈øe ≈øame rea≈øons, that proues their power by the Diuell of di≈øea≈øes in generall, is a≈øwell proued their power in ≈øpecial; as of weakning the nature of ≈øome men, to make them vnable for women, and
making it to abound in others, more then the ordinary cour≈øe of nature would permit: And ≈øuch like in all other particular ≈øickne≈øses. But one thing I will pray thee to ob≈øerue in all the≈øe places, where I rea≈øon vpon the diuels power, which is the different ends and ≈øcopes, that God as the fir≈øt cau≈øe, and the diuell as his in≈øtrument and ≈øecond cau≈øe, ≈øhoots at in all the≈øe actions of the diuel, (as Gods hang-man:) For where the diuels intention in them is euer to peri≈øh, either the ≈øoule, or the body, or both of them, that he is ≈øo permitted to deale with; God by the contrary, drawes euer out of that euill, glory to him≈øelfe, either by the wracke of the wicked in his iu≈øtice, or by the triall of the patient, and amendment of the faithful, being wakened vp with that rod of correction. Hauing thus declared vnto thee then, my full intention in this Treati≈øe, thou wilt ea≈øily excu≈øe, I doubt not, a≈øwel my pretermitting, to declare the whole particular rites and ≈øecrets of the≈øe vnlawfull arts; as al≈øo their infinit and wonderfull practi≈øes, as being neither of them pertinent to my purpo≈øe: the rea≈øon whereof, is giuen in the hinder end of the first Chapter of the third booke: and who likes to be curious in the≈øe things, he may reade, if he will heare of their practi≈øes, Bodinus Daemonomanie, collected with greater diligence, then written with iudgement, together with their confe≈øsions, that haue been at this time apprehended. If he would know what hath bene the opinion of the Ancients, concerning their power, he ≈øhall ≈øee it well de≈øcribed by Hyperius & Hemmingius, two late Germane writers; Be≈øides innumerable other neotericke Theologues, that write largely vpon that ≈øubject: And if he would know what are the particular rites, and curio≈øities of the≈øe blacke Arts (which is both vnnece≈ø≈øary and perillous) he will finde it in the fourth Booke of Cornelius Agrippa, and in Wierus, whom-of J ≈øpake. And ≈øo wi≈øhing my paines in this Treati≈øe (beloued Reader) to be effectuall, in arming all them that reade the ≈øame, again≈øt the≈øe aboue mentioned errours, and recommending my good will to thy friendly acceptation, J bid thee heartily fare-well.

argument.head: ARGVMENT.
argument.p: Proued by the Scripture, that the≈øe vnlawfull arts in genere, haue bene and may be put in practi≈øe.

div.stage: PHILOMATHES and EPISTEMON rea≈øon the matter.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: IAm ≈øurely very glad to haue met with you this day: for I am of opinion, that ye can better re≈øolue me of ≈øome thing, whereof I ≈øtand in great doubt, nor any other whomwith I could haue met.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: In what I can, that ye like to ≈øpeir at me, I will willingly and freely tell my opinion, and if I proue it not ≈øufficiently, I am heartily content that a better rea≈øon carry it away then.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What thinke ye of the≈øe ≈øtrange newes, which now onely furni≈øhes purpo≈øe to all men at their meeting: I meane of the≈øe Witches?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Surely they are wonderfull: And I thinke ≈øo cleare and plaine confe≈ø≈øions in that purpo≈øe, haue neuer fallen out in any aage or countrey.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: No que≈øtion if they be true, but thereof the Doctours doubts.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: What part of it doubt ye of?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Euen of all, for ought I can yet perceiue: and namely, that there is ≈øuch a thing as Witch-craft or Witches, and I would pray you to re≈øolue me thereof if ye may: for I haue rea≈øoned with ≈øundrie in that matter, and yet could neuer be ≈øatisfied therein.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I ≈øhall with good will doe the be≈øt I can: But I thinke it the difficiller, ≈øince ye deny the thing it ≈øelfe in generall: for as it is ≈øaid in the Logicke ≈øchooles, Contra negantem principia non e≈øt disputandum. Alwaies for that part, that Witch-craft, and Witches haue beene, and are, the former part is clearely prooued by the Scriptures, and the la≈øt by daily experience and confe≈ø≈øions.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I know ye wil alleadge me Sauls Pythoni≈ø≈øe: but that as appeares will not make much for you.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Not onely that place, but diuers others: But I maruell why that ≈øhould not make much for me?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: The rea≈øons are the≈øe, fir≈øt yee may con≈øider, that Saul beeing troubled in ≈øpirit, and hauing fa≈øted long before, as the text te≈øtifieth, and being come to a woman that was bruted to haue ≈øuch knowledge, and that to enquire ≈øo important newes, he hauing ≈øo guilty a con≈øcience for his hainous offences, and ≈øpecially, for that ≈øame vnlawfull curio≈øitie, and horrible defection‚ñ™ and then the woman crying out vpon the ≈øuddaine in great admiration, for the vncouth ≈øight that ≈øhe alledged to haue ≈øeene, di≈øcouering him to be the King, though di≈øgui≈øed, and denied by him before: it was no wonder, I ≈øay, that his ≈øen≈øes being thus di≈øtracted, hee could not perceaue her faining of her voice, he being him≈øelfe in another chalmer, and ≈øeeing nothing. Next, what could be, or was rai≈øed? The ≈øpirit of Samuel? prophane, and again≈øt all Theologie: the deuill in his likene≈ø≈øe? as vnappeirant, that either God would permit him to come in the ≈øhape of his Saints, (for then could neuer the Prophets in tho≈øe dayes haue beene ≈øure, what ≈øpirit ≈øpake to them in their vi≈øions) or then that he could fore-tell what was to come thereafter; for Prophecie proceedeth onely of GOD: and the diuell hath no knowledge of things to come.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
Yet if ye will marke the words of the text, yee will finde clearely, that Saul ≈øaw that apparition: for giuing you that Saul was in another chalmer, at the making of the circles and coniurations, needfull for that purpo≈øe (as none of that craft wil permit any others to behold at that time) yet it is euident by the text, that how ≈øoone that once that vncleane ≈øpirit was fully ri≈øen, ≈øhe called in vpon Saul: For it is ≈øaid in the text, that Saul knew him to be Samuel, which could not haue beene, by the hearing tell onely of an olde man with a mantill, ≈øince there was many moe old men dead in I≈ørael nor Samuel: And the common weid of that whole countrey was mantils. As to the next, that it was not the ≈øpirit of Samuel, I grant: In the prouing whereof ye need not to in≈øi≈øt, ≈øince all Chri≈øtians of what≈øoeuer religion agrees vpon that: and none but either mere ignorants, or Necromanciers, or Witches doubts thereof. And that the deuill is permitted at
≈øometimes to put him≈øelfe in the likene≈ø≈øe of the Saints, it is plaine in the Scriptures, 1. Cor. 11.14. where it is ≈øaid, that Satan can transforme him≈øelfe into an Angel of light. Neither could that bring any inconuenience with the vi≈øions of the Prophets, ≈øince it is mo≈øt certaine, that God will not permit him ≈øo to deceiue his owne: but onely ≈øuch, as fir≈øt wilfully deceiue them-≈øelues, by running vnto him, whom God then ≈øuffers to fall in their owne ≈ønares, and iu≈øtly permits them to be illuded with great efficacie of deceit, becau≈øe they would not beleeue the trueth (as Paul ≈øayth.) And as to the diuels foretelling of things to come, it is true that he knowes not all things future; but yet that hee knowes part, the tragicall euent of this hi≈øtorie declares it, (which the wit of woman could neuer haue fore-≈øpoken) not that hee hath any pre≈øcience, which is onely proper to God; or yet knowes any thing by looking vpon God, as in a mirrour (as the good Angels doe) hee being for euer debarred from the fauourable pre≈øence and countenance of his Creatour, but onely by one of the≈øe two meanes: either, as being worldly wi≈øe, and taught by a continuall experience, euer ≈øince the Creation, iudges by likelyhood of things to come, according to the like that hath pa≈ø≈øed before, and the naturall cau≈øes, in re≈øpect of the vici≈ø≈øitude of all things worldly: or el≈øe by Gods imploying of him in a turne, and ≈øo fore≈øeene thereof, as appeares to haue beene in this, 1. King. 22. whereof we finde the very like in Micheas propheticke di≈øcour≈øe to king Achab. But to prooue this my fir≈øt propo≈øition, that there can be ≈øuch a thing as Witch-craft and Witches, there are many moe places in the Scriptures then this, as I ≈øaid before. As fir≈øt in the Lawe of GOD, Exod. 22. it is plainely prohibited: But certaine it is, that the Law of God ≈øpeakes nothing in vaine, neither doeth it lay cur≈øes, or enioyne puni≈øhments vpon ≈øhadowes, condemning that to be ill, which is not in e≈ø≈øence or being, Exod. 7. & 2. as we call it. Secondly, it is plaine, where wicked Pharaobs Wi≈øe-men imitated a number of Mo≈øes miracles, to harden the tyrants heart thereby. Thirdly, ≈øaid not Samuel to Saul, that di≈øobedience is as the ≈øinne of Witch-craft? 1 Sam. 15. To compare it to a thing that were not, it were too too ab≈øurd. Acts 8. Acts 16. Fourthly, was not Simon Magus a man of that craft? And fiftly, what was ≈øhe that had the ≈øpirit of Python? be≈øide innumerable other places that were irke≈øome to recite.

p.hi: What kind of ≈øinne the practi≈øers of the≈øe vnlawfull arts commit. The diui≈øion of the≈øe arts: And what are the meanes that allure any to practi≈øe them.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: BVt I thinke it very ≈øtrange, that God ≈øhould permit any man-kind (≈øince they beare his owne Image) to fall in ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe and filthie a defection.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Although man in his Creation was made to the image of the Creator, Gene. 1. yet through his fall hauing once lo≈øt it, it is but re≈øtored againe in a part by grace onely to the elect: So all the re≈øt falling away from God, are giuen ouer into the hands of the diuell that enemy, to beare his image; and being once ≈øo giuen ouer, the greate≈øt and the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt impretie is the plea≈øante≈øt, and mo≈øt delightfull vnto them.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But may it not ≈øuffice him to haue indirectly the rule, and procure the perdition of ≈øo many ≈øoules by alluring them to vices, and to the following of their owne appetites, ≈øuppo≈øe hee abu≈øe not ≈øo many ≈øimple ≈øoules, in making them directly acknowledge him for their ma≈øter?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: No ≈øurely, for he v≈øes euery man, whom of he hath the rule, according to their complexion and knowledge: and ≈øo, whom hee findes mo≈øt ≈øimple, he plainelie≈øt di≈øcouers him≈øelfe vnto them: For he being the enemie of mans ≈øaluation, v≈øes all the meanes hee can to intrappe them ≈øo farre in his ≈ønares, as it may bee vnable to them thereafter (≈øuppo≈øe they would) to rid them≈øelues out of the ≈øame.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Then this ≈øinne is a ≈øinne again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: It is in ≈øome, but not in all.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: How that? Are not all the≈øe that runne directly to the diuell in one Categorie?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: God forbid, for the ≈øinne again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt hath two branches: The one, a falling backe from the whole ≈øeruice of God, and a refu≈øall of all his precepts: The other is the doing of the fir≈øt with knowledge, knowing that they doe wrong again≈øt their owne con≈øcience, Hebr. 6.10. and the te≈øtimonie of the holy Spirit, hauing once had a ta≈øte of the ≈øweetnes of Gods mercies: Now in the fir≈øt of the≈øe two, all ≈øorts of Necromancers, Enchanters or Witches, are compre hended, but in the la≈øt, none but ≈øuch as erre with this knowledge that I haue ≈øpoken of.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Then it appeares that there are more ≈øorts nor one, that are directly profe≈ø≈øours of his ≈øeruice ‚Ä¢ and if ≈øo be, I pray you tell me how many and what are they?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: There are principally two ≈øorts, whereunto all the parts of that vnhappy Art are redacted; whereof the one is called Magie or Necromancie, the other Sorcerie or Witch-craft.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What I pray you? and how many are the meanes, whereby the diuell allures per≈øons in any of the≈øe ≈ønares?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Euen by the≈øe three pa≈ø≈øions that are within our ≈øelues: Curio≈øitie in great ingines: thir≈øt of reuenge, for ≈øome tortes deepely apprehended: or greedy appetite of geare, cau≈øed through great pouertie. As to the fir≈øt of the≈øe, Curio≈øitie, it is onely the inticement of Magicians or Necromanciers: and the other two are the allurers of the Sorcerers or Witches, for that old and craftie ≈øerpent being a Spirit, he ea≈øily ≈øpies our affections, and ≈øo conformes him≈øelfe thereto, to deceiue vs to our wracke.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: The ≈øignifications and etymologies of the words of Magie and Necromancie. The difference betwixt Necromancie and Witchcraft: What are the entre≈øsis, and beginnings, that bring any to the knowledge thereof.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: I Would gladly fir≈øt heare, what thing it is that ye call Magie or Necromancie.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: This word Magi in the Per≈øian tongue, imports as much as to be a contemplatour or Interpretour of Diuine and heauenly ≈øciences, which being fir≈øt v≈øed among the Chaldees, through their ignorance of the true diuinitie, was e≈øteemed and reputed among≈øt them, as a principall vertue: And therfore, was named vniu≈øtly with an honourable ≈øtile, which name the Greekes imitated, generally importing all the≈øe kindes of vnlawfull artes: And this word Necromancie is a Greeke word, compounded of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which is to ≈øay, the prophecie by the dead. This la≈øt name is giuen, to this blacke and vnlawfull ≈øcience, by the figure Synechdoche, becau≈øe it is a principall part of that arte, to ≈øerue them≈øelues with dead carca≈øes in their diuinations.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What difference is there betwixt this arte, and Witch-craft?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Surely, the difference vulgare put betwixt them, is very merry, and in a maner true; for they ≈øay, that the Witches are ≈øeruants onely, and ≈ølaues to the diuel; but the Necromanciers are his Ma≈øters and commanders.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: How can that be true, that any men being ≈øpecially addicted to his ≈øeruice, can be his commanders?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Yea they may be; but it is onely ≈øecundum quid: For it is not by any power that they can haue ouer him, but ex pacto allanerlie; whereby he obliges him≈øelfe in ≈øome trifles to them, that he may on the other part obteine the fruition of their body and ≈øoule, which is the onely thing he huntes for.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: A very in-aequitable contract for≈øooth: But I pray you di≈øcour≈øe vnto me, what is the effect and ≈øecrets of that arte.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
That is an ouer large field ye giue me: yet I ≈øhall doe my goodwill, the mo≈øt ≈øummarly that I can, to runne through the principall points thereof. As there are two ≈øorts of folkes, that may be enti≈øed to this art, to
wit, learned or vnlearned: ≈øo is there two meanes, which are the fir≈øt ≈øteerers vp and feeders of their curio≈øitie, thereby to make them to giue them≈øelues ouer to the ≈øame: Which two meanes, I call the diuels ≈øchoole, and his rudiments. The learned haue their curio≈øitie wakened vp, and fed by that which I cal his ≈øchole: this is the Astrologie iudiciar, For diuers men hauing attained to a great perfection in learning, and yet remayning ouerbare (alas) of the Spirit of regeneration and fruits thereof, finding all naturall things common, a≈øwell to the ≈øtupide pedants, as vnto them, they a≈ø≈øay to vendicate vnto them a greater name, by not onely knowing the cour≈øe of things heauenly, but likewi≈øe to clime to the knowledge of things to come thereby: Which, at the fir≈øt face appearing lawfull vnto them, in re≈øpect the ground thereof ≈øeemeth to proceed of naturall cau≈øes onely, they are ≈øo allured thereby, that finding their practi≈øe to proue trew in ≈øundry things, they ≈øtudy to know the cau≈øe thereof, and ≈øo mounting from degree to degree, vpon the ≈ølipperie and vncertaine ≈øcale of curio≈øitie; they are at la≈øt enti≈øed, that where lawfull artes or ≈øciences faile, to ≈øatisfie their re≈øtle≈ø≈øe minds, euen to ≈øeeke to that blacke and vnlawfull ≈øcience of Magie: Where, finding at the fir≈øt, that ≈øuch diuers formes of circles and coniurations rightly ioyned thereunto, will rai≈øe ≈øuch diuers formes of ≈øpirits, to re≈øolue them of their doubts, and attributing the doing thereof, to the power in≈øeparably tied, or inherent in the circles, and many wordes of God, confu≈øedly wrapped in, they blindly glory of them≈øelues, as if they had by their quickne≈ø≈øe of ingine, made a conque≈øt of Plutoes dominion, and were become Emperours ouer the Stygian habitacles: Where, in the meane time (mi≈øerable wretches) they are become in very deed, bond≈ølaues to their mortall enemie: and their knowledge, for all that they pre≈øume thereof, is nothing increa≈øed, except in knowing euill, and the horrors of hell for puni≈øhment thereof, Gene. 3. as Adams was by the eating of the forbidden tree.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: The de≈øcription of the rudiments and Schoole, which are the entre≈ø≈øes to the arte of Magie: And in ≈øpeciall the differences betwixt A≈øtronomie and A≈øtrologie: Diui≈øion of A≈øtrologie in diuers parts.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: BVt I pray you likewi≈øe forget not to tell what are the diuels rudiments.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: His rudiments, I call fir≈øt in generall, all that which is called vulgarly the vertue of word, herbe, and ≈øtone, which is v≈øed by vnlawfull charmes, without naturall cau≈øes; as likewi≈øe all kinde of practicques, freites, or other like extraordinary actions, which cannot abide the trew touch of naturall rea≈øon.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I would haue you to make that plainer, by ≈øome particular examples; for your propo≈øition is very generall.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I meane either by ≈øuch kinde of Charmes as commonly daft wiues v≈øe, for healing offor≈øpoken goods, for pre≈øeruing them from euill eyes, by knitting roun trees, or ≈øundrie≈øt kinde of hearbes, to the haire or tailes of the goods: by curing the worme, by ≈øtemming of blood, by healing of Hor≈øe-crookes, by turning of the riddle, or doing of ≈øuch like innumerable things by words, without applying any thing, meete to the part offended, as Mediciners doe: Or el≈øe by ≈øtaying married folkes, to haue naturally adoe with other (by knitting ≈øo many knots vpon a point at the time of their marriage,) And ≈øuch like things, which men v≈øe to practi≈øe in their merrine≈ø≈øe: For fra vnlearned men (being naturally curious, and lacking the trew knowledge of God) finde the≈øe practi≈øes to proue trew, as ≈øundrie of them will doe, by the power of the diuell for deceiuing men, and not by any inherent vertue in the≈øe vaine words and freites; and being de≈øirous to winne a reputation to them≈øelues in ≈øuch like turnes, they either (if they be of the ≈øhamefa≈øter ≈øort) ≈øeeke to be learned by ≈øome that are experimented in that Arte, (not knowing it to be euill at the fir≈øt) or el≈øe being of the gro≈ø≈øer ≈øort, runne directly to the diuel for ambition or de≈øire of gaine, and plainely contract with him thereupon.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But me thinkes the≈øe meanes which ye call the Schoole and rudiments of the diuel, are things lawfull, and haue bene approued for ≈øuch in all times and aages: as in ≈øpeciall, this ≈øcience of A≈øtrologie, which is one of the ≈øpeciall members of the Mathematiques.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
There are two things which the learned haue ob≈øerued from the beginning, in the ≈øcience of the heauenly Creatures, the Planets, Starres, and ≈øuch like: The one is their cour≈øe and ordinarie motions, which for that cau≈øe is called Astronomia, Which word is a compound of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that is to ≈øay, the law of the Starres: And this Art indeed is one of the members of the Mathematiques, and not onely lawfull, but mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary and commendable: The other is called Astrologia, being compounded of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which is to ≈øay, the word and preaching of the Starres: Which is diuided into two parts: The fir≈øt, by knowing thereby the powers of ≈øimples, and ≈øickne≈ø≈øes, the cour≈øe of the ≈øea≈øons and the weather, being ruled by their influence; which part depending vpon the former, although it bee not of it ≈øelfe a part of Mathematiques: yet it is not vnlawfull, being moderately v≈øed, ≈øuppo≈øe not ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie and commendable as the former. The ≈øecond part is to tru≈øt ≈øo much to their influences, as thereby to foretell what common-weales ≈øhall flouri≈øh or decay: what per≈øons ≈øhall be fortunate or vnfortunate: what ≈øide ≈øhall winne in any battell: what man ≈øhal obtaine victorie at ≈øingular combate: what way, and of what aage ≈øhall men die: what hor≈øe ≈øhall winne at match-running: and diuers ≈øuch like incredible things, wherein Cardanus, Cornelius Agrippa, and diuers others haue more curiou≈øly then profitably written at large. Of this roote la≈øt ≈øpoken of,
≈øprings innumerable branches; ≈øuch as the knowledge by the natiuities; the Cheiromancie, Geomancie, Hydromancie, Arithmancie, Phy≈øiognomie, and a thou≈øand others, which were much practi≈øed, and holden in great reuerence by the Gentiles of old: And this la≈øt part of A≈øtrologie whereof I haue ≈øpoken, which is the root of their branches, was called by them pars fortunae. This part now is vtterly vnlawfull to be tru≈øted in, or practi≈øed among≈øt Chri≈øtians, as leaning to no ground of naturall rea≈øon: and it is this part which I called before the Diuels ≈øchoole.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But yet many of the learned are of the contrarie opinion.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I grant, yet I could giue my rea≈øons to fortifie and maintaine my opinion, if to enter into this di≈øputation it would not draw me quite off the ground of our di≈øcour≈øe, be≈øides the mi≈ø-≈øpending of the whole day thereupon: One word onely I will an≈øwere to them, and that in the Scriptures (which mu≈øt be an infallible ground to all true Chri≈øtians,) That in the Prophet Ieremie it is plainely forbidden, to beleeue or hearken vnto them that prophe≈øie and fore-≈øpeake by the cour≈øe of the Planets and Stars.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: How farre the v≈øing of Charmes is lawfull or vnlawfull. The de≈øcription of the formes of Circles and Coniurations: And what cau≈øeth the Magicians them≈øelues to be wearie thereof.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: WEL, ye haue ≈øaid farre inough in that argument. But how prooue yee now that the≈øe Charmes or vnnaturall practiques are vnlawfull: For ≈øo many hone≈øt and merry men and women haue publikely practi≈øed ≈øome of them, that I think if ye would accu≈øe them all of Witch-craft, ye would affirme more nor ye will be beleeued in.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
I ≈øee if you had taken good tent (to the nature of that word, wherby I named it,) ye would not haue beene in this doubt, nor mi≈øtaken mee ≈øo farre as ye haue done: For although, as none can be ≈øcholers in a ≈øchoole, and not be ≈øubiect to the ma≈øter thereof: ≈øo none can ≈øtudie and put in practi≈øe (for ≈øtudie the alone, and knowledge, is more perillous nor offen≈øiue; and it is the practi≈øe onely that makes the greatne≈ø≈øe of the offence;) the Circles and Art of Magie, without committing an horrible defection from God: And yet as they that reade and learne their rudiments, are not the more ≈øubiect to any ≈øchoole-ma≈øter, if it plea≈øe not their parents to put them to the ≈øchoole thereafter: So they who ignorantly prooue the≈øe practiques, which I call the Diuels rudiments, vnknowing them to be baits, ca≈øt out by him, for trapping ≈øuch as God will permit to fall into his hands, this kinde of folkes I ≈øay, no doubt, are to be iudged the be≈øt of, in re≈øpect they v≈øe no inuocation nor helpe of him (by their knowledge at lea≈øt) in
the≈øe turnes, and ≈øo haue neuer entred them≈øelues into Satans ≈øeruice; Yet to ≈øpeake trewly for mine owne part (I ≈øpeake but for my ≈øelfe) I de≈øire not to make ≈øo neere riding: For in my opinion our enemie is ouer craftie, and wee ouer weake (except the greater grace of God) to a≈ø≈øay ≈øuch hazards, wherein he prea≈øes to trap vs.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Ye haue rea≈øon for≈øooth: for as the common prouerbe ≈øayth; They that ≈øup keile with the deuill, haue need of long ≈øpoones: But now I pray you goe forward in the de≈øcribing of this arte of Magie.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Fra they be come once vnto this perfection in euill, in hauing any knowledge (whether learned or vnlearned) of this blacke arte; they then begin to be wearie of the rai≈øing of their Mai≈øter, by coniured circles, being both ≈øo difficile and perillous, and ≈øo come plainely to a contract with him, wherein is ≈øpecially contained formes and effects.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But I pray you or euer you goe further, di≈øcour≈øe me ≈øomewhat of their circles and coniurations; and what ≈øhould be the cau≈øe of their wearying thereof: For it ≈øhould ≈øeeme that that forme ≈øhould be le≈ø≈øe fearefull yet, then the direct haunting and ≈øocietie, with that foule and vncleane Spirite.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
I thinke yee take me to be a Witch my ≈øelfe, or at the lea≈øt would faine ≈øweare your ≈øelfe prenti≈øe to that craft: Alwayes as I may, I ≈øhal ≈øhortly ≈øatisfie you, in that kinde of coniurations, which are contained in ≈øuch bookes, which I call the Deuils Schoole: There are foure principall parts: the per≈øons of the coniurers; the action of the coniuration; the words and rites v≈øed to that effect; and the Spirits that are coniured. Ye mu≈øt fir≈øt remember to lay the ground, that I tolde you before, which is, that it is no power inherent in the circles, or in the holine≈ø≈øe of the names of God bla≈øphemou≈øly v≈øed; nor in what≈øoeuer rites or ceremonies at that time v≈øed, that either can rai≈øe any infernall ≈øpirit, or yet limitate him perforce within or without the≈øe circles. For it is he onely, the father of all lies, who hauing fir≈øt of all pre≈øcribed that forme of doing, feining him≈øelfe to be commanded and re≈øtrained thereby, will be loth to pa≈ø≈øe the boundes of the≈øe iniunctions; as wel thereby to make them glory in the impiring ouer him (as I ≈øaid before:) as likewi≈øe to make him≈øelfe ≈øo to be tru≈øted in the≈øe little things, that he may haue the better commoditie thereafter, to deceiue them in the end with a tricke once for all; I meane the euerla≈øting perdition of their ≈øoule and body. Then laying this ground, as I haue ≈øaid, the≈øe coniurations mu≈øt haue fewe or moe in number of the per≈øons coniurers (alwayes pa≈ø≈øing the ≈øingular number) according to the qualitie of the circle, and forme of apparition. Two principall things cannot well in that errand be wanted: holy-water (whereby the deuill mockes the Papi≈øts) and ≈øome pre≈øent of a liuing thing vnto him. There are likewi≈øe certaine ≈øea≈øons, dayes and houres, that they ob≈øerue in this purpo≈øe: The≈øe things being all ready and prepared, circles are made triangular, quadrangular, round, double or ≈øingle, according to the forme of apparition that they
craue. But to ≈øpeake of the diuers formes of the circles, of the innumerable characters and cro≈ø≈øes that are within and without, and out-through the ≈øame, of the diuers formes of apparitions, that that craftie ≈øpirit illudes them with, and of all ≈øuch particulars in that action, I remit it to ouermany that haue bu≈øied their heads in de≈øcribing of the ≈øame; as being but curious, and altogether vnprofitable. And this farre onely I touch, that when the coniured Spirit appeares, which will not be while after many circum≈øtances, long prayers, and much muttring and murmuring of the coniurers; like a Papist Prie≈øt, di≈øpatching a hunting Ma≈ø≈øe: how ≈øoone I ≈øay, he appeares, if they haue mi≈ø≈øed one iote of all their rites; or if any of their feet once ≈ølyde ouer the circle through terrour of his fearefull apparition, hee payes him≈øelfe at that time in his owne hand, of that due debt which they ought him; and otherwi≈øe would haue delayed longer to haue payed him: I meane, hee carries them with him body and ≈øoule. If this be not now a iu≈øt cau≈øe to make them weary of the≈øe formes of coniuration, I leaue it to you to iudge vpon, con≈øidering the long ≈øomne≈ø≈øe of the labour, the preci≈øe keeping of dayes and houres (as I haue ≈øaid) the terriblene≈ø≈øe of apparition, and the pre≈øent perill that they ≈øtand in, in mi≈ø≈øing the lea≈øt circum≈øtance or freite, that they ought to ob≈øerue: And on the other part, the deuill is glad to mooue them to a plaine and ≈øquare dealing with him, as I ≈øaid before.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: The Deuils contract with the Magicians: The diui≈øion there of in two parts: What is the difference betwixt Gods miracles and the Deuils.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: INdeed there is cau≈øe enough, but rather to leaue him at all, then to runne more plainely to him, if they were wi≈øe hee dealt with: But goe forward now, I pray you, to the≈øe turnes, fra they become once deacons in this craft.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
From time that they once plainely begin to contract with him: The effect of their contract con≈øi≈øts in two things: in formes and effects, as I began to tell already, were it not ye interrupted me: (for although the contract be mutual, I ≈øpeake fir≈øt of that part, wherein the diuel obliges him≈øelfe to them) By formes, I meane in what ≈øhape or fa≈øhion he ≈øhall come vnto them, when they call vpon him; And by effects, I vnder≈øtand, in what ≈øpeciall ≈øorts or ≈øeruices he binds him≈øelfe to bee ≈øubiect vnto them. The qualitie of the≈øe formes and effects, is le≈ø≈øe or greater, according to the skill and art of the Magician: For as to the formes, to ≈øome of the ba≈øer ≈øort of them he obliges him≈øelfe to appeare at their calling vpon him, by ≈øuch a proper name which he ≈øhewes vnto them, either in likenes of a Dog, a Cat, an Ape, or ≈øuch-like other bea≈øt; or el≈øe to an≈øwere by a
voice onely. The effects, are to an≈øwere to ≈øuch demands, as concerne curing of di≈øea≈øes, their owne particular menagerie, or ≈øuch other ba≈øe things as they require of him.
