But to the mo≈øt curious ≈øort, in the formes hee will oblige him≈øelfe, to enter into a dead bodie, and there out of to giue ≈øuch an≈øweres, of the euent of battels, of matters concerning the e≈øtate of commonwealths, and ≈øuch like other great que≈øtions: yea, to ≈øome he will bee a continuall attender, in forme of a Page: Hee will permit him≈øelfe to bee coniured, for the ≈øpace of ≈øo many yeeres, either in a tablet or a ring, or ≈øuch like thing, which they may ea≈øily cary about with them: Hee giues them power to ≈øell ≈øuch wares to others, whereof ≈øome will be dearer, and ≈øome better cheape, according to the lying or true ≈øpeaking of the Spirit that is coniured therein: Not but that in very deed, all deuils mu≈øt be lyars; but ≈øo they abu≈øe the ≈øimplicitie of the≈øe wretches, that become their ≈øcholers, that they make them beleeue, that at the fall of Lucifer, ≈øome Spirits fell in the aire, ≈øome in the fire, ≈øome in the water, ≈øome in the land, in which Elements they ≈øtill remaine. Whereupon they build, that ≈øuch as fell in the fire, or in the aire, are trewer then they, who fell in the water, or in the land, which are all but meere trattles, and forged by the authour of all deceite. For they fell not by weight, as a ≈øolide ≈øub≈øtance, to ≈øticke in any one part; but the principall part of their fall, con≈øi≈øting in quality, by the falling from the grace of God, wherein they were created, they continued ≈øtil thereafter, and ≈øhall doe while the latter day, in wandring through the world, as Gods hang-men, to execute ≈øuch turnes as hee employes them in: And when any of them are not occupied in that, returne they mu≈øt to their pri≈øon in hell (as it is plaine in the miracle that CHRIST wrought at Gennezareth) therein at the latter day to be all enclo≈øed for euer: Matth. 8. and as they deceiue their Schollers in this, ≈øo doe they, in imprinting in them the opinion, that there are ≈øo many Princes, Dukes, and Kings among≈øt them, euery one commanding fewer or moe Legions, and impiring in diuers artes, and quarters of the earth: For though that I will not deny that there be a forme of order among≈øt the Angels in Heauen, and con≈øequently, was among≈øt them before their fall; yet, either that they bruike the ≈øame ≈øen≈øine; or that God will permit vs to know by damned diuels, ≈øuch heauenly my≈øteries of his, which he would not reueale to vs, neither by Scripture nor Prophets, I thinke no Chri≈øtian will once thinke it. But by the contrary of all ≈øuch my≈øteries, as he hath clo≈øed vp with his Seale of ≈øecrecie; it becommeth vs to be contented with an humble ignorance, they being things not nece≈ø≈øary for our ≈øaluation. But to returne to the purpo≈øe, as the≈øe formes, wherein Satan obliges him≈øelfe to the greate≈øt of the Magicians, are wonderfull curious; ≈øo are the effects corre≈øpondent vnto the ≈øame: For he will oblige him≈øelfe to teach them artes and ≈øciences, which he may ea≈øily doe, being ≈øo learned a knaue as he is, to carry them newes from any part of the world, which the agilitie of a Spirit may ea≈øily performe: to reueale to them the ≈øecrets of any per≈øons,
≈øo being they be once ≈øpoken, for the thought none knowes but GOD; except ≈øo farre as ye may ghe≈ø≈øe by their countenance, as one who is doubtle≈øly learned enough in the Phy≈øiognomie: Yea, hee will make his Schollers to creepe in credite with Princes, by fore-telling them many great things; part true, part fal≈øe: For if all were fal≈øe, hee would tyne credite at all handes; but alwayes doubt≈øome, as his Oracles were. And he will al≈øo make them to plea≈øe Princes, by faire banquets and daintie di≈øhes, carried in ≈øhort ≈øpace fra the farthe≈øt part of the world: For no man doubts but he is a thiefe, and his agilitie (as I ≈øpake before) makes him to come with ≈øuch ≈øpeed. Such like, he wil guard his Schollers with faire armies of hor≈øemen and footmen in appearance, Ca≈øtles and forts, Which all are but impre≈ø≈øions in the aire, ea≈øily gathered by a Spirit, drawing ≈øo neere to that ≈øub≈øtance him≈øelfe: As in like maner he will learne them many Iuglarie trickes at Cardes, dice, and ≈øuch like, to deceiue mens ≈øen≈øes thereby, and ≈øuch innumerable fal≈øe practiques, which are proued by ouer-many in this aage; as they who are acquainted with that Italian called SCOTO yet liuing, can report: And yet are all the≈øe things but deluding of the ≈øen≈øes, and no wayes true in ≈øub≈øtance; as were the fal≈øe miracles wrought by King Pharaos Magicians, for counterfeiting Moy≈øes: For that is the difference betwixt GODS miracles and the diuels, GOD is a creatour, what he makes appeare in myracle, it is ≈øo in effect: As Moy≈øes Rod being ca≈øten downe, was no doubt turned into a naturall Serpent: where as the diuel (as Gods Ape) counterfetting that by his Magicians, made their wandes to appeare ≈øo, onely to mens outward ≈øen≈øes: as kythed in effect by their being deuoured by the other; For it is no wonder, that the diuel may delude our ≈øen≈øes, ≈øince we ≈øee by common proofe, that ≈øimple Iugglars wil make an hundreth things ≈øeeme both to our eyes and eares otherwayes then they are. Now as to the Magicians part of the contract, it is in a word that thing which I ≈øaid before, the diuel hunts for in all men.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Surely ye haue ≈øaid much to mee in this art, if all that you haue ≈øaid be as trew as wonderfull.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: For the trewth in the≈øe actions, it wil be ea≈øily confirmed, to any that plea≈øes to take paine vpon the reading of diuers authenticke hi≈øtories, and the enquiring of daily experiences. And as for the trewth of their po≈ø≈øibilitie, that they may be, and in what maner, I tru≈øt I haue alledged nothing whereunto I haue not ioyned ≈øuch probable rea≈øons, as I leaue to your di≈øcretion, to weigh and con≈øider: One word onely I omitted, concerning the forme of making of this contract, which is either written with the Magicians owne blood: or el≈øe being agreed vpon (in termes his ≈øcholema≈øter) touches him in ≈øome part, though peraduenture no marke remain, as it doeth with all Witches.

argument.head: ARG.
argument.p: The rea≈øon why the art of Magie is vnlawfull: What puni≈øhment they merit, And who may be accounted guilty of that crime.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: SVrely, ye haue made this art to appeare very mon≈øtrous and dete≈øtable. But what I pray you ≈øhal be ≈øaid to ≈øuch as maintaine this arte to bee lawfull, for as euill as you haue made it?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I ≈øay, they ≈øauour of the panne them≈øelues, or at lea≈øt little better; and yet I would be glad to heare their rea≈øons.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: There are two principally, that euer I heard v≈øed; be≈øide that which is founded vpon the common Prouerbe (that the Necromancers command the deuill, which ye haue already refuted.) The one is grounded vpon a receiued cu≈øtome: The other vpon an authoritie, which ≈øome think infallible. Vpon cu≈øtome, we ≈øee that diuer≈øe Chri≈øtian Princes and Magi≈øtrates ≈øeuere puni≈øhers of Witches, will not onely ouer-≈øee Magicians to liue within their dominions; but euen ≈øometimes delight to ≈øee them prooue ≈øome of their practicques. The other rea≈øon is, that Moy≈øes beeing brought vp (as it is expre≈øly ≈øaid in the Scriptures) in all the ≈øciences of the Egyptians; whereof no doubt, this was one of the principals; and hee notwith≈øtanding of this art, plea≈øing God, as he did, con≈øequently that art profe≈ø≈øed by ≈øo godly a man, could not be vnlawfull.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
As to the fir≈øt of your rea≈øons, grounded vpon cu≈øtome: I ≈øay, an euill cu≈øtome can neuer be accepted for a good law, for the ouer great ignorance of the word in ≈øome Princes and Magi≈øtrates, and the contempt thereof in others, mooues them to ≈øinne heauily again≈øt their office in that point. As to the other rea≈øon, which ≈øeemes to be of greater weight, if it were formed in a Syllogi≈øme; it behooued to be in many termes, and full of fallacies (to ≈øpeake in termes of Logicque:) for fir≈øt, that that generall propo≈øition, affirming Moy≈øes to be taught in all the ≈øciences of the Egyptians, ≈øhould conclude that he was taught in Magie, I ≈øee no nece≈ø≈øitie: For we mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that the Spirit of God there, ≈øpeaking of ≈øciences, vnder≈øtands them that are lawfull; for except they be lawfull, they are but abu≈øiu√® called ≈øciences, and are but ignorances, indeed: Nam homo pictus, nonest homo. Secondly, giuing that he had beene taught in it, there is great difference betwixt knowledge and practi≈øing of a thing, as I ≈øaid before: For God knoweth all things, being alwaies good, and of our ≈øinne and our infirmitie proceedeth our ignorance. Thirdly, giuing that he had both ≈øtudied and practi≈øed the ≈øame (which is more then mon≈øtrous to bee beleeued by any Chri≈øtian) yet we know well inough, that before that euer the Spirit of God began to call Moy≈øes, he was fled out of Egypt, being fourtie yeeres of aage, for the ≈ølaughter of an Egyptian, and in his good father Iethroes land,
fir≈øt called at the fierie bu≈øh, hauing remained there other fourtie yeeres in exile: ≈øo that ≈øuppo≈øe hee had beene the wickedde≈øt man in the world before, he then became a changed and regenerate man, and very little of olde Moy≈øes remained in him. Abraham was an Idolater in Vr of Chaldaea, before he was called: And Paul beeing called Saul, was a mo≈øt ≈øharpe per≈øecutour of the Saints of God, while that name was changed.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What puni≈øhment then thinke ye merit the≈øe Magicians and Necromancers?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: The like no doubt, that Sorcerers and Witches merit; and rather ≈øo much greater, as their errour proceedes of the greater knowledge, and ≈øo drawes neerer to the ≈øinne again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt. And as I ≈øay of them, ≈øo ≈øay I the like of all ≈øuch as con≈øult, enquire, entertaine, and ouer≈øee them, which is ≈øeene by the mi≈øerable ends of many that aske coun≈øell of them: For the deuill hath neuer better tidings to tell to any, then hee told to Saul: neither is it lawfull to v≈øe ≈øo vnlawful in≈øtruments, were it neuer for ≈øo good a purpo≈øe: Actes 3. For that axiome in Theologie is mo≈øt certaine and infallible, Nunquam faciendum e≈øt malum, vt bonum inde eueniat.

p.hi: The de≈øcription of Sorcerie and Witcheraft in ≈øpeciall.
Proued by the Scripture, that ≈øuch a thing can be: And the rea≈øons refuted of all ≈øuch as would call it but an imagination and Melancholicque humour.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: NOW, ≈øince ye haue ≈øatisfied mee now ≈øo fully, concerning Magie or Necromancie, I wil pray you to doe the like in Sorcerie or Witchcraft.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: That field is likewi≈øe very large, and although in the mouthes and pennes of many, yet few knowe the trewth thereof, ≈øo well as they beleeue them≈øelues, as I ≈øhall ≈øo ≈øhortly as I can, make you (God willing) as ea≈øily to perceiue.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But I pray you before ye goefurther, let mee interrupt you here with a ≈øhort digre≈ø≈øion, which is, that many can ≈øcarcely beleeue that there is ≈øuch a thing as Witchcraft: Who≈øe rea≈øons I will ≈øhortly alleage vnto you, that yee may ≈øatisfie mee as well in that, as yee haue done in the re≈øt. For fir≈øt, whereas the Scripture ≈øeemes to prooue Witchcraft to bee, by diuers examples, and ≈øpecially by fundrie of the ≈øame, which ye haue alleaged; it is thought by ≈øome, that the≈øe places ≈øpeake of Magicians and Necromancers onely, and not of Witches: As in ≈øpeciall, the≈øe wi≈øe men of Pharaohs, that counterfeited Moy≈øes myracles, were Magicians ≈øay they, and not Witches: As likewi≈øe that Pythoni≈ø≈øe that Saul con≈øulted with: And ≈øo was Simon Magus in the new Te≈øtament, as that very ≈øtile imports. Secondly, where ye would oppone the dayly practicque, and confe≈ø≈øion of ≈øo many, that is thought likewi≈øe to be but very Melancholicque imaginations of ≈øimple rauing creatures. Thirdly, if Witches had ≈øuch power of Witching of folkes to death, (as they ≈øay they haue) there had bene none left aliue long ≈øince in the world but they; at the lea≈øt, no good or godly per≈øon of what≈øoeuer e≈øtate, could haue e≈øcaped their diuelrie.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
Your three rea≈øons, as I take, are grounded: the fir≈øt of them negatiu√® vpon the Scripture: The ≈øecond affirmatiu√® vpoÃÑ Phi≈øick: And the third vpon the certaine proofe of experience. As to your fir≈øt, it is mo≈øt trew indeede, that all the≈øe wi≈øe men of Pharaoh were Magicians of arte: As likewi≈øe it appeares well, that the Pythoni≈ø≈øe, with whom Saul con≈øulted, was of that ≈øame profe≈ø≈øion: and ≈øo was Simon Magus. But ye omitted to ≈øpeake of the Lawe of God, wherein are all Magicians, Diuiners, Enchanters, Sorcerers, Witches, and what≈øoeuer of that kind that con≈øult with the deuill, plainely prohibited, and alike threatned again≈øt. And be≈øides that, ≈øhe who had the Spirit of Python, in the Actes, Acts 16. who≈øe Spirit was put to ≈øilence by the Apo≈øtle, could be no other thing but a very Sorcerer or Witch, if ye admit the vulgar di≈øtinction, to be in a maner trew, whereof I ≈øpake in the beginning of our conference: For that ≈øpirit whereby ≈øhe conque≈øted ≈øuch gaine to her Ma≈øters, was not at her rai≈øing or commanding, as ≈øhee plea≈øed to appoint, but ≈øpake by her tongue, as well publikely as priuately: whereby ≈øhe ≈øeemed to draw nearer to the ≈øort of Demoniakes or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, if that coniunction betwixt them, had not beene of her owne con≈øent; as it appeared by her, not being tormented therewith, and by her conque≈øting of ≈øuch gaine to her Ma≈øters (as I haue alreadie ≈øaid.) As to your ≈øecond rea≈øon grounded vpon Phy≈øicke, in attributing their confe≈ø≈øions or apprehen≈øions, to a naturall melancholique humour, any that plea≈øe phy≈øically to con≈øider vpon the naturall humour of melancholly, according to all the Phy≈øicians, that euer writ thereupon, they ≈øhall find that that will be ouer≈øhort a cloake to couer their knauery with: For as the humour of Melancholly in the ≈øelfe is blacke, heauie and terrene, ≈øo are the ≈øymptomes thereof, in any per≈øons that are ≈øubiect thereunto, leanne≈ø≈øe, palene≈ø≈øe, de≈øire of ≈øolitude, and if they come to the highe≈øt degree thereof, meere folly and Manie: whereas by the contrary, a great number of them that euer haue beene conuict or confe≈ø≈øours of Witchcraft, as may be pre≈øently ≈øeene by many that haue at this time confe≈ø≈øed; they are by the contrary, I ≈øay, ≈øome of them rich and worldly wi≈øe, ≈øome of them fat or corpulent in their bodies, and mo≈øt part of them altogether giuen ouer to the plea≈øures of the fle≈øh, continuall haunting of companie, and all kinde of merrine≈ø≈øe, both lawfull and vnlawful, which are things directly contrary to the ≈øymptomes of melancholly, whereof I ≈øpake; and further experience daily prooues, how loth they are to confe≈ø≈øe without torture, which witne≈ø≈øeth their guiltine≈ø≈øe; where by the contrary, the Melancholiques neuer ≈øpare to bewray them≈øelues, by their continuall di≈øcour≈øes, feeding thereby their humor in that which they thinke no crime. As to your third rea≈øon, it ≈øcar≈øely merits an an≈øwere: for if the deuill their ma≈øter were not bridled, as the Scriptures teach vs, ≈øuppo≈øe there were no men nor women to bee his in≈øtruments, he could finde wayes enough without any helpe of others to wracke all mankinde; whereunto he employes his whole ≈øtudy, and goeth about like a roaring Lyon (as Peter ≈øayth) to that effect, but the limits of his
power were ≈øet downe before the foundations of the world were laide, which he hath not power in the lea≈øtiote to tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe. But be≈øide all this, there is ouer great a certaintie to prooue that they are, by the daily experience of the harmes that they doe, both to men, and what≈øoeuer thing men po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, whom God will permit them to be the in≈øtruments, ≈øo to trouble or vi≈øite, as in my di≈øcour≈øe of that arte, ye ≈øhall heare clearely prooued.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: The Etymologie and ≈øignification of that word Sorcerie: The fir≈øt entre≈ø≈øe and prenti≈øhip of them that giue them≈øelues to that craft.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: COme on then I pray you, and returne where ye left.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
This word of Sorcerie is a Latine word, which is taken from ca≈øting of the lot, and therefore he that v≈øeth it, is called Sortiarius √† ≈øorte: As to the word of Witchcraft, it is nothing but a proper name giuen in our language: The cau≈øe wherefore they were called Sortiarij, proceeded of their practiques, ≈øeeming to come of lot or chance, ≈øuch as the turning of the riddle, the knowing of the forme of prayers, or ≈øuch like tokens, if a per≈øon di≈øea≈øed would liue or die: And in generall, that name was giuen them for v≈øing of ≈øuch charmes, and freits, as that Craft teacheth them. Many points of their craft and practicques are common betwixt the Magicians and them: for they ≈øerue both one Ma≈øter, although in diuers fa≈øhions. And as I deuided the Necromancers into two ≈øortes, learned and vnlearned; ≈øo mu≈øt I deny them in other two, rich and of better accompt; poore and of ba≈øer degree. The≈øe two degrees now of per≈øons, that practi≈øe this Craft, an≈øwere to the pa≈ø≈øions in them, which (I tolde you before) the Diuell v≈øed as meanes to entice them to his ≈øeruice: for ≈øuch of them as are in great mi≈øerie and pouertie, he allures to follow him, by promi≈øing vnto them great riches, and worldly commoditie: Such as though rich, yet burne in a de≈øperate de≈øire of reuenge, he allures them by promi≈øes, to get their turne ≈øatisfied to their hearts contentment. It is to be noted now, that that olde and craftie enemie of ours, a≈ø≈øailes none, though touched with any of the≈øe two extremities, except he fir≈øt finde an entre≈ø≈øe ready for him, either by the great ignorance of the per≈øon he deales with, ioyned with an euill life, or el≈øe by their carele≈øne≈ø≈øe and contempt of God: And finding them in an vtter de≈øpaire, for one of the≈øe two former cau≈øes that I haue ≈øpoken of, he prepares the way by feeding them craftely in their humour, and filling them further and further with de≈øpaire, while hee finde the time proper to di≈øcouer him≈øelfe vnto them: At which time, either vpon their walking ≈øolitarie in the fieldes, or el≈øe lying pan≈øing in their bed, but alwaies without the company of any other, hee either by a voyce, or in likene≈ø≈øe
of a man inquires of them, what troubles them, and promi≈øeth them, a ≈øuddaine and certaine way of remedie, vpon condition on the other part, that they follow his adui≈øe, and doe ≈øuch things as he will require of them: Their mindes being prepared before-hand, as I haue alreadie ≈øpoken, they ea≈øily agreed vnto that demand of his, and ≈øyne ≈øets an other tryi≈øt, where they may meete againe: At which time, before hee proceede any further with them, hee fir≈øt per≈øwades them to addict them≈øelues to his ≈øeruice, which being ea≈øily obtained, he then di≈øcouers what he is vnto them, makes them to renounce their God and Bapti≈øme directly, and giues them his marke vpon ≈øome ≈øecret place of their bodie, which remaines ≈øoare vnhealed, while his next meeting with them, and thereafter euer in≈øen≈øible, how≈øoeuer it be nipped or pricked by any, as is daily prooued, to giue them a proofe thereby, that as in that doing, he could hurt and heale them; ≈øo all their ill and well doing thereafter, mu≈øt depend vpon him: And be≈øides that, the intolerable dolour that they feele in that place, where he hath marked them, ≈øerues to waken them, and not to let them re≈øt, while their next meeting againe: fearing le≈øt otherwaies they might either forget him, being as new Prenti≈øes, and not well enough founded yet, in that fiendly follie: or el≈øe remembring of that horrible promi≈øe they made him at their la≈øt meeting, they might skunner at the ≈øame, and prea≈ø≈øe to call it backe. At their third meeting, he makes a ≈øhew to be carefull to performe his promi≈øes, either by teaching them waies how to get them≈øelues reuenged, if they be of that ≈øort: or el≈øe by teaching them le≈ø≈øons, how by mo≈øt vile and vnlawfull meanes, they may obtaine gaine, and wordly commoditie, if they be of the other ≈øort.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: The Witches actions diuided into two parts: The actions proper to their owne per≈øons: Their actions toward others: The forme of their conuentions, and adoring of their Ma≈øter.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p:
YEe haue ≈øaid now enough of their initiating in that order, It re≈øts then that yee di≈øcour≈øe vpon their practi≈øes, fra they be pa≈ø≈øed Prenti≈øes: for I would faine heare what is po≈ø≈øible to them to performe in very deed. Although they ≈øerue a common Ma≈øter with the Necromancers, (as I haue before ≈øaid) yet ≈øerue they him in another forme: For as the meanes are diuers, which allure them to the≈øe vnlawful Arts of ≈øeruing the deuill; ≈øo by diuers waies v≈øe they their practi≈øes, an≈øwering to the≈øe meanes, which fir≈øt the deuill v≈øed as in≈øtruments in them, though all tending to one end, to wit, the enlarging of Satans tyrannie, and cro≈ø≈øing of the propagation of the Kingdome of CHRIST, ≈øo farre as lyeth in the po≈ø≈øibilitie, either of the one or
other ≈øort, or of the deuill their ma≈øter: For where the Magicians, as allured by curio≈øitie, in the mo≈øt part of their practi≈øes, ≈øeeke principally the ≈øati≈øfying of the ≈øame, and to winne to them≈øelues a popular honour and e≈øtimation; the≈øe Witches on the other part, being inticed, either for the de≈øire of reuenge, or of worldly riches, their whole practi≈øes are either to hurt men and their goods, or what they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, for ≈øatisfying of their cruell mindes in the former, or el≈øe by the wracke in what≈øoeuer ≈øort, of any whom God will permit them to haue power of, to ≈øatisfie their greedie de≈øire in the la≈øt point.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: In two parts their actions may be diuided; the actions of their owne per≈øons, and the actions proceeding from them towards any other: And this diui≈øion being well vnder≈øtood, will ea≈øily re≈øolue you, what is po≈ø≈øible to them to doe: For although all that they confe≈ø≈øe is no lie vpon their part, yet doubtle≈øly, in my opinion, a part of it is not indeede, according as they take it to be: And in this I meane by the actions of their owne per≈øons: For as I ≈øaid before, ≈øpeaking of Magie, that the diuell illudes the ≈øen≈øes of the≈øe ≈øchollers of his, in many things, ≈øo ≈øay I the like of the≈øe Witches.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Then I pray you fir≈øt to ≈øpeake of that part of their owne per≈øons, and ≈øyne ye may come next to their actions towards others.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
To the effect that they may performe ≈øuch ≈øeruices of their fal≈øe Ma≈øter, as he employes them in, the deuill as Gods Ape, counterfeits in his ≈øeruants this ≈øeruice and forme of adoration, that God pre≈øcribed and made his ≈øeruants to practi≈øe: For as the ≈øeruants of God publikely v≈øe to conveene for ≈øeruing of him, ≈øo makes he them in great numbers to conveene (though publikely they dare not) for his ≈øeruice. As none conveenes to the adoration and wor≈øhipping of God, except they be marked with his Seale, the Sacrament of Bapti≈øme: So none ≈øerues Satan, and conveenes to the adoring of him, that are not marked with that marke, whereof I alreadie ≈øpake. As the Mini≈øter ≈øent by God teacheth plainely at the time of their publike conuentions, how to ≈øerue him in ≈øpirit and trewth; ≈øo that vnclean ≈øpirit, in his owne per≈øon teacheth his di≈øciples at the time of their conueening, how to worke all kind of mi≈øchiefe, and craues coumpt of all their horrible and dete≈øtable proceedings pa≈ø≈øed, for aduancement of his ≈øeruice: Yea that hee may the more vinely counterfeit and ≈øcorne God, he oft times makes his ≈ølaues to conueene in the≈øe very places, which are de≈øtinate and ordained for the conveening of the ≈øeruants of God (I meane by Churches) But this farre, which I haue yet ≈øaid, I not onely take it to be trew in their opinions, but euen ≈øo to be indeed: For the forme that he v≈øed in counterfaiting God among≈øt the Gentiles, makes me ≈øo to thinke: As God ≈øpake by his Oracles, ≈øpake he not ≈øo by his? As God had a≈øwell bloodie Sacrifices, as others without blood, had not he the like? As God had Churches ≈øanctified to his ≈øeruice, with Altars, Prie≈øts, Sacrifices, Ceremonies and Prayers; had he not the like polluted to his ≈øeruice? As God gaue re≈øpon≈øes by
Vrim and Thummim, gaue he not his re≈øpon≈øes by the intralles of bea≈øts, by the ≈øinging of fowles, and by their actions in the aire? As God by vi≈øions, dreames, and exta≈øies reuealed what was to come, and what was his will vnto his ≈øeruants; v≈øed hee not the like meanes to forewarne his ≈ølaues of things to come? Yea euen as God loued cleanene≈ø≈øe, hated vice and impuritie, and appointed puni≈øhments therefore; v≈øed he not the like (though fal≈øly I grant, and but in e≈øchewing the le≈ø≈øe inconuenience, to draw them vpon a greater) yet di≈ø≈øimuled he not, I ≈øay, ≈øo farre as to appoint his prie≈øts to keepe their bodies cleane and vndefiled, before their asking re≈øpon≈øes of him? And fained he not God, to be a protectour of euery vertue, and a iu≈øt reuenger of the contrarie? This rea≈øon then mooues mee, that as he is that ≈øame diuell, and as crafty now as he was then, ≈øo will he not ≈øpare as pertly in the≈øe actions that I haue ≈øpoken of, concerning the Witches per≈øons: but further, Witches of times confe≈ø≈øe, not only his conueening in the Church with them, but his occupying of the Pulpit; Yea, their forme of adoration, to be the ki≈ø≈øing of his hinder parts: Which though it ≈øeeme ridiculous, yet may it likewi≈øe be trew, ≈øeeing we reade that in Calicute, he appearing in forme of a Goat-bucke, hath publikely that vn-hone≈øt homage done vnto him, by euery one of the people: So ambitious is he, and greedy of honour (which procured his fall) that he will euen imitate God in that part, where it is ≈øaid, that Moy≈øes could ≈øee but the hinder parts of God, Exod. 33. for the brightne≈ø≈øe of his glory: And yet that ≈øpeech is ≈øpoken but „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ

p.hi: What are the wayes po≈øsible, whereby the Witches may transport them≈øelues to places farre di≈øtant: And what are impo≈øsible and meere illu≈øions of Satan: And the rea≈øons thereof.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: BVt by what way ≈øay they, or thinke yee it po≈ø≈øible they can come to the≈øe vnlawfull conuentions?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
There is the thing which I e≈øteeme their ≈øen≈øes to be deluded in, and though they lie not in confe≈ø≈øing of it, becau≈øe they thinke it to be trew, yet not to be ≈øo in ≈øub≈øtance or effect: for they ≈øay, that by diuers meanes they may conueene, either to the adoring of their Ma≈øter, or to the putting in practi≈øe any ≈øeruice of his, committed vnto their charge: one way is naturall, which is naturall riding, going, or ≈øailing, at what houre their ma≈øter comes and aduerti≈øes them: and this way may be ea≈øily beleeued; another way is ≈øome what more ≈øtrange, and yet it is po≈ø≈øible to bee trew: which is, by being caried by the force of the ≈øpirit which is their conducter, either aboue the earth, or aboue the Sea ≈øwiftly, to the place where they are to meete: which I am per≈øwaded to bee likewi≈øe po≈øsible, in re≈øpect that as Habakkuk was carried by the Angel in that forme, to the den where Daniel lay; ≈øo thinke I, the diuell will be readie to imitate God,
as well in that as in other things: Apocrypha of Bel and the Dragon. which is much more po≈ø≈øible to him to doe, being a Spirit, then to a mighty wind, being but a naturall Meteore, to tran≈øport from one place to another, a ≈øolide body, as is commonly and daily ≈øeene in practi≈øe: But in this violent forme they cannot be caried, but a ≈øhort bounds, agreeing with the ≈øpace that they may retaine their breath: for if it were longer, their breath could not remaine vnextingui≈øhed, their body being caried in ≈øuch a violent and forcible maner; as by example: If one fall off a ≈ømall height, his life is but in perill, according to the hard or ≈øoft lighting: but if one fall from an high and ≈øtay rocke, his breath will be forcibly bani≈øhed from the body, before he can win to the earth, as is oft ≈øeene by experience: And in this tran≈øporting they ≈øay them≈øelues, that they are inui≈øible to any other, except among≈øt them≈øelues, which may al≈øo be po≈ø≈øible in my opinion: For if the deuill may forme what kinde of impre≈ø≈øions he plea≈øes in the aire, (as I haue ≈øaid before, ≈øpeaking of Magie) why may hee not farre ea≈øilier thicken and ob≈øcure ≈øo the aire, that is next about them, by contracting it ≈øtraite together, that the beames of any other mans eyes cannot pierce thorow the ≈øame, to ≈øee them? But the third way of their comming to their conuentions, is that, wherein I thinke them deluded: for ≈øome of them ≈øay, that being transformed in the likene≈ø≈øe of a little bea≈øt or foule, they will come and pierce through what≈øoeuer hou≈øe or Church, though all ordinarie pa≈ø≈øages be clo≈øed, by what≈øoeuer open the aire may enter in at: And ≈øome ≈øay, that their bodies lying ≈øtill, as in an exta≈øie, their ≈øpirits will be raui≈øhed out of their bodies, and caried to ≈øuch places; and for verifying thereof, will giue euident tokens, as well by witne≈ø≈øes that haue ≈øeene their body lying ≈øencele≈ø≈øe in the meane time, as by naming per≈øons whom-with they met, and giuing tokens what purpo≈øe was among≈øt them, whom otherwi≈øe they could not haue knowen: for this forme of iourneying, they affirme to v≈øe mo≈øt, when they are tran≈øported from one countrey to another.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p:
Surely I long to heare your owne opinion of this: for they are like old wiues trattles about the fire. The rea≈øons that mooue me to thinke that the≈øe are meere illu≈øions, are the≈øe: Fir≈øt, for them that are transformed in likene≈ø≈øe of bea≈øts or foules, can enter through ≈øo narrow pa≈ø≈øages, although I may ea≈øily beleeue that the diuell could by his workman≈øhip vpon the aire, make them appeare to be in ≈øuch formes, either to them≈øelues, or to others: yet how he can contract a ≈øolide body within ≈øo little roome, I thinke it is directly contrary to it ≈øelfe; for to be made ≈øo little, and yet not dimini≈øhed; to be ≈øo ≈øtraitly drawen together, and yet feele no paine, I thinke it is ≈øo contrary to the qualitie of a naturall bodie, and ≈øo like to the little tran≈øub≈øtantiate god in the Papi≈øts Ma≈ø≈øe, that I can neuer beleeue it: So to haue a quantitie, is ≈øo proper to a ≈øolide body, that as all Philo≈øophers conclude, it cannot be any more without one, then a ≈øpirit can haue one: Actes 12. For when Peter came out of the pri≈øon, and the doores all locked; it was not by any coÃÑtracting of his body in ≈øo little roome, but by the giuing
place of the doore, though vne≈øpied by the Gaylors: And yet is there no compari≈øon, when this is done, betwixt the power of God, and of the diuel. As to their forme of exta≈øie and ≈øpirituall tran≈øporting, it is certaine the ≈øoules going out of the body, is the onely definition of naturall death: and who are once dead, God forbid we ≈øhould thinke that it ≈øhould lie in the power of all the diuels in hell, to re≈øtore them to their life againe; although he can put his owne ≈øpirit in a dead body, which the Necromancers commonly practi≈øe, as ye haue heard. For that is the office properly belonging to God; and be≈øides that, the ≈øoule once parting from the body, cannot wander any longer in the world, but to the owne re≈øting place mu≈øt it goe immediately, abiding the coniunction of the body againe, at the latter day. And what Chri≈øt or the Prophets did miraculou≈øly in this ca≈øe, it can in no Chri≈øtian mans opinion, be made common with the diuel. As for any tokens that they giue for prouing of this, it is very po≈ø≈øible to the diuels craft, to per≈øwade them to the≈øe meanes: for he being a ≈øpirit, may he not ≈øo raui≈øh their thoughts, and dull their ≈øen≈øes, that their body lying as dead, he may obiect to their ≈øpirits, as it were in a dreame, and (as the Poets write of Morpheus) repre≈øent ≈øuch formes of per≈øons, of places, and other circum≈øtances, as he plea≈øes to illude them with? Yea, that he may deceiue them with the greater efficacie, may he not at that ≈øame in≈øtant by fellow angels of his, illude ≈øuch other per≈øons ≈øo in that ≈øame fa≈øhion, whom-with hee makes them to beleeue that they mette, that all their reports and tokens, though ≈øeuerally examined, may euery one agree with another? And that what≈øoeuer actions, either in hurting men or bea≈øts, or what≈øoeuer other thing that they fal≈øly imagine, at that time to haue done, may by him≈øelfe or his marrowes, at that ≈øame time be done indeed; ≈øo as if they would giue for a token of their being raui≈øhed at the death of ≈øuch a per≈øon within ≈øo ≈øhort ≈øpace thereafter, whom they beleeue to haue poi≈øoned, or witched at that in≈øtant, might he not at that ≈øame houre, haue ≈ømitten that ≈øame per≈øon, by the permi≈ø≈øion of GOD, to the farther deceiuing of them, and to mooue others to beleeue them? And this is ≈øurely the likelye≈øt way, and mo≈øt according to rea≈øon, which my iudgement can finde out in this, and what≈øoeuer other vnnaturall points of their confe≈ø≈øion: And by the≈øe meanes ≈øhall we ≈øaile ≈øurely, betwixt Charybdis and Scylla, in e≈øchewing the not beleeuing of them altogether on the one part, le≈øt that draw vs to the errour, that there is no Witches: and on the other part in beleeuing of it, make vs to e≈øchew the falling into innumerable ab≈øurdities, both mon≈øtrou≈øly again≈øt all Theologie diuine, and Philo≈øophie humane.

p.hi: Witches actions towards others: Why there are more women of that craft then men: What things are po≈øsible to them to effectuate by the power of their ma≈øter: The rea≈øons thereof: What is the ≈øurest remedy of the harmes done by them.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: FOr≈øooth your opinion in this, ≈øeemes to cary mo≈øt rea≈øon with it; and ≈øince ye haue ended then the actions belonging properly to their owne per≈øons, ≈øay forward now to their actions v≈øed towards others.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: In their actions v≈øed towards others, three things ought to be con≈øidered: Fir≈øt, the maner of their con≈øulting thereupon: Next, their part as in≈øtruments: And la≈øt, their ma≈øters part, who puts the ≈øame in execution. As to their con≈øultations thereupon, they v≈øe them ofte≈øt in the Churches, where they conueene for adoring, at what time their ma≈øter enquiring at them what they would be at, euery one of them propones vnto him, what wicked turne they would haue done, either for obtaining of riches, or for reuenging them vpon any whom they haue malice at; who granting their demaund, as no doubt willingly he will, ≈øince it is to doe euill, hee teacheth them the meanes whereby they may doe the ≈øame: As for little trifling turnes that women haue adoe with, he cau≈øeth them to ioynt dead corp≈øes, and to make powders thereof, mixing ≈øuch other things there among≈øt, as he giues vnto them.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But before ye goe further, permit me, I pray you, to interrupt you one word, which ye haue put me in memorie of, by ≈øpeaking of Women; What can be the cau≈øe that there are twentie women giuen to that craft, where there is one man?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: The rea≈øon is ea≈øie, for as that ≈øexe is frailer then man is, ≈øo is it ea≈øier to be intrapped in the≈øe gro≈ø≈øe ≈ønares of the diuell, as was ouer-well prooued to be trew, by the Serpents deceiuing of Eua at the beginning, which makes him the homelier with that ≈øexe ≈øen≈øine.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Returne now where ye left.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
To ≈øome others at the≈øe times he teacheth, how to make pictures of waxe or clay, that by the roa≈øting thereof, the per≈øons that they beare the name of, may be continually melted or dried away by continuall ≈øickene≈ø≈øe: To ≈øome he giues ≈øuch ≈øtones or ponders, as will helpe to cure or ca≈øt on di≈øea≈øes: And to ≈øome hee teacheth kindes of vncouth poy≈øons, which Mediciners vnder≈øtand not (for he is farre cunninger then man, in the knowledge of all the occult proprieties of nature) not that any of the≈øe meanes which he teacheth them (except the poy≈øons which are compo≈øed of things naturall,) can of them≈øelues helpe any thing to the≈øe turnes, that they are employed in, but onely being GODS ape, as well in that, as in all other things; Euen as God by his Sacraments which are earthly of them≈øelues,
workes a heauenly effect, though no wayes by any cooperation in them: And as Chri≈øt by clay and ≈øpettle wrought together, Iohn 9. opened the eyes of the blinde man, ≈øuppo≈øe there was no vertue in that which he outwardly applied, ≈øo the diuel will haue his outward meanes to be ≈øhewes as it were of his doing, which hath no part or cooperation in his turnes with him, how farre that euer the ignorants be abu≈øed in the contrarie. And as to the effects of the≈øe two former parts; to wit, the con≈øultations and the outward meanes, they are ≈øo wonderfull, as I dare not alleadge any of them, without ioyning a ≈øufficient rea≈øon of the po≈ø≈øibilitie thereof; For leauing all the ≈ømall trifles among wiues, and to ≈øpeake of the principall points of their craft, for the common trifles thereof, they can doe without conuerting well enough by them≈øelues, the≈øe principall points, I ≈øay, are the≈øe; They can make men or women to loue or hate other, which may be very po≈ø≈øible to the diuel to effectuate, ≈øeeing he being a ≈øubtile ≈øpirit, knowes well enough how to per≈øwade the corrupted affection of them whom God wil permit him ≈øo to deale with: They can lay the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe of one vpon another, which likewi≈øe is very po≈ø≈øible vnto him: For ≈øince by Gods permi≈ø≈øion, he laide ≈øickene≈ø≈øe vpon Iob, why may he not farre ea≈øilier lay it vpon any other; For as an old practitian, hee knowes well enough what humour domines mo≈øt in any of vs, and as a ≈øpirit he can ≈øubtillie waken vp the ≈øame, making it peccant, or to abound, as hee thinkes meet for troubling of vs, when God will ≈øo permit him: And for the taking off of it, no doubt he will be glad to relieue ≈øuch of pre≈øent paine, as he may thinke by the≈øe meanes to per≈øwade to be catched in his euerla≈øting ≈ønares and fetters. They can bewitch and take the life of men or women, by roa≈øting of the Pictures, as I ≈øpake of before, which likewi≈øe is verie po≈ø≈øible to their ma≈øter to performe: for although (as I ≈øaid before) that in≈øtrument of waxe haue no vertue in that turne doing, yet may he not very well, euen by the ≈øame mea≈øure, that his coniured ≈ølaues melts that waxe at the fire, may hee not, I ≈øay, at the≈øe ≈øame times, ≈øubtily, as a ≈øpirit, ≈øo weaken and ≈øcatter the ≈øpirits of life of the patient, as may make him on the one part, for faintne≈ø≈øe, to ≈øweat out the humour of his bodie, and on the other part, for the not concurrence of the≈øe ≈øpirits, which cau≈øes his dige≈øtion, ≈øo debilitate his ≈øtomacke, that this humour radicall continually, ≈øweating out on the one part, and no new good ≈øucke being put in the place thereof, for lacke of dige≈øtion on the other, he at la≈øt ≈øhall vani≈øh away, euen as his picture will doe at the fire? And that knaui≈øh and cunning workeman, by troubling him, onely at ≈øometimes, makes a proportion, ≈øo neere betwixt the working of the one and the other, that both ≈øhall end as it were at one time. They can rai≈øe ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts in the aire, either vpon Sea or land, though not vniuer≈øally, but in ≈øuch a particular place and pre≈øcribed bounds, as GOD will permit them ≈øo to trouble: Which likewi≈øe is very ea≈øie to be di≈øcerned from any other naturall tempe≈øts that are Meteores, in re≈øpect of the ≈øudden and violent rai≈øing thereof, together with the
≈øhort induring of the ≈øame. And this is likewi≈øe very po≈ø≈øible to their ma≈øter to doe, hee hauing ≈øuch affinitie with the aire, as being a ≈øpirit, and hauing ≈øuch power of the forming and moouing thereof, as yee haue heard me alreadie declare: Ephe≈ø. 2. For in the Scripture, that ≈øtile of the Prince of the aire, is giuen vnto him. They can make folkes to become Phrenticque or Maniacque, which likewi≈øe is very po≈ø≈øible to their ma≈øter to doe, ≈øince they are but naturall ≈øickne≈ø≈øes: and ≈øo he may lay on the≈øe kindes, as well as any others. They can make ≈øpirits, either to follow and trouble per≈øons, or haunt certaine hou≈øes, and affray oftentimes the inhabitants, as hath bene knowne to bee done by our Witches at this time. And likewi≈øe they can make ≈øome to bee po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with ≈øpirits, and ≈øo to become very Daemoniacques: and this la≈øt ≈øort is very po≈ø≈øible likewi≈øe to the diuel their ma≈øter to doe, ≈øince he may ea≈øily ≈øend his owne angels to trouble in what forme he plea≈øes, any whom God will permit him ≈øo to v≈øe.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But will God permit the≈øe wicked in≈øtruments by the power of the deuill their ma≈øter, to trouble by any of the≈øe meanes, any that beleeue in him?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: No doubt, for there are three kindes of folkes whom God will permit ≈øo to be tempted or troubled; the wicked for their horrible ≈øinnes, to puni≈øh them in the like mea≈øure; the godly that are ≈øleeping in any great ≈øinnes or infirmities, and weakne≈ø≈øe in faith, to waken them vp the fa≈øter by ≈øuch an vncouth forme: and euen ≈øome of the be≈øt, that their patience may be tried before the world, as Iobs was: For why may not God v≈øe any kinde of extraordinary puni≈øhment, when it plea≈øes him; as well as the ordinarie rods of ≈øickene≈ø≈øe or other aduer≈øities?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Who then may be free from the≈øe deuili≈øh practi≈øes?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: No man ought to pre≈øume ≈øo farre as to promi≈øe any impunitie to him≈øelfe: for God hath before all beginnings, praeordinated, as well the particular ≈øorts of plagues, as of benefites for euery man, which in the owne time he ordaines them to be vi≈øited with, and yet ought we not to be the more afraide for that, of any thing that the diuell and his wicked in≈øtruments can doe again≈øt vs: for we daily fight again≈øt the diuell in a hundreth other wayes: And therefore, as a valiant captaine affraies no more being at the combate, nor ≈øtayes from his purpo≈øe for the rummi≈øhing ≈øhot of a Canon, nor the ≈ømall clacke of a Pi≈øtolet, ≈øuppo≈øe he be not certaine what may light vpon him; Euen ≈øo ought we boldly to goe forward in fighting again≈øt the diuell without any greater terrour, for the≈øe his rare≈øt weapons, nor for the ordinary whereof we haue daily the proofe.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Is it not lawfull then, by the helpe of ≈øome other Witch, to cure the di≈øea≈øe that is ca≈øten on by that craft?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: No wayes lawfull; for I gaue you the rea≈øon thereof in that axiome of Theologie, which was the la≈øt words I ≈øpake of Magie.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: How then may the≈øe di≈øea≈øes be lawfull cured?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
Only by earne≈øt prayer vnto God, by amendment of their liues,
and by ≈øharpe pur≈øuing euery one, according to his calling of the≈øe in≈øtruments of Satan, who≈øe puni≈øhment to the death will be a ≈øalutarie ≈øacrifice for the patient. And this is not onely the lawfull way, but likewi≈øe the mo≈øt ≈øure: For by the deuils meanes, can neuer the deuill be casten out, Marke 3. as Chri≈øt ≈øayth. And when ≈øuch a cure is v≈øed, it may well ≈øerue for a ≈øhort time, but at the la≈øt, it will doubtle≈øly tend to the vtter perdition of the patient, both in body and ≈øoule.

p.hi: What ≈øort of folkes are least or mo≈øt ≈øubiect to receiue harme by Witchcraft: What power they haue to harme the Magistrate, and vpon what re≈øpects they haue any power in pri≈øon: And to what end may or will the deuill appeare to them therein: Vpon what respects the deuill appeares in ≈øundry ≈øhapes to ≈øundry of them at any time.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: BVt who dare take vpon him to puni≈øh them, if no man can be ≈øure to be free from their vnnaturall inua≈øions?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Wee ought not the more of that re≈øtraine from vertue, that the way wherby we clime thereunto be ≈øtraight and perillous: But be≈øides that, as there is no kinde of per≈øons ≈øo ≈øubiect to receiue harme of them, as the≈øe that are of infirme and weake faith (which is the be≈øt buckler again≈øt ≈øuch inua≈øions:) ≈øo haue they ≈øo ≈ømall power ouer none, as ouer ≈øuch as zealou≈øly and earne≈øtly pur≈øue them, without ≈øparing for any wordly re≈øpect.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Then they are like the Pe≈øt, which ≈ømites the≈øe ≈øickare≈øt, that flies it farthe≈øt, and apprehends deeplie≈øt the perill thereof.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: It is euen ≈øo with them: for neither is it able to them to v≈øe any fal≈øe cure vpon a patient, except the patient fir≈øt beleeue in their power, and ≈øo hazard the tin≈øell of his owne ≈øoule, nor yet can they haue le≈ø≈øe power to hurt any, nor ≈øuch as contemne mo≈øt their doings, ≈øo being it comes of faith, and not of any vaine arrogancie in them≈øelues.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But what is their power again≈øt the Magi≈øtrate?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Le≈ø≈øe or greater, according as he deales with them: for if hee be ≈ølothfull towards them, God is very able to make them in≈øtruments to waken and puni≈øh his ≈ølouth: but if he be the contrary, hee according to the iu≈øt Law of God, and allowable law of all nations, will be diligent in examining and puni≈øhing of them: God will not permit their ma≈øter to trouble or hinder ≈øo good a worke.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But fra they be once in hands and firmance, haue they any further power in their craft?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
That is according to the forme of their detention: If they be but apprehended and deteined by any priuate per≈øon, vpon other priuate re≈øpects, their power no doubt either in e≈øcaping, or in doing hurt, is no
le≈ø≈øe nor euer it was before: But if on the other part, their apprehending and detention be by the lawfull Magi≈øtrate, vpon the iu≈øt re≈øpects of their guiltine≈ø≈øe in that craft, their power is then no greater then before that euer they medled with their ma≈øter: For where God begins iu≈øtly to ≈øtrike by his lawfull Lieutenants, it is not in the deuils power to defraud or bereaue him of the office, or effect of his powerfull and reuenging Scepter.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But will neuer their Ma≈øter come to vi≈øite them, fra they be once apprehended and put in firmance?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: That is according to the e≈øtate that the≈øe mi≈øerable wretches are in: For if they be ob≈øtinate in ≈øtill denying, he will not ≈øpare, when hee findes time to ≈øpeake with them, either if he finde them in any comfort, to fill them more and more with the vaine hope of ≈øome manner of reliefe; or el≈øe if he finde them in a deepe de≈øpaire, by all meanes to augment the ≈øame, and to per≈øwade them by ≈øome extraordinarie meanes to put them≈øelues downe, which very commonly they doe: But if they bee penitent and confe≈ø≈øe, God will not permit him to trouble them any more with his pre≈øence and allurements.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: It is not good v≈øing his coun≈øell I ≈øee then: But I would earne≈øtly know when he appeares to them in pri≈øon, what formes v≈øes hee then to take?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Diuers formes, euen as hee v≈øes to doe at other times vnto them: For as I told you, ≈øpeaking of Magie, he appeares to that kind of crafte≈ø-men ordinarily in a forme, according as they agree vpon it among them≈øelues; Or if they be but prenti≈øes, according to the qualitie of their circles or coniurations: Yet to the≈øe capped creatures, he appeares as hee plea≈øes, and as he findes meete≈øt for their humors: For euen at their publicke conuentions, hee appeares to diuers of them in diuers formes, as we haue found by the difference of their confe≈ø≈øions in that point: For he deluding them with vaine impre≈ø≈øions in the aire, makes him≈øelfe to ≈øeeme more terrible to the gro≈ø≈øer ≈øort, that they may thereby be mooued to feare and reuerence him the more: and le≈ø≈øe mon≈øtrous and vncouth like againe to the craftier ≈øort, le≈øt otherwi≈øe they might ≈øturre and skunner at his vgline≈ø≈øe.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: How can he then be felt, as they confe≈ø≈øe they haue done him, if his body be but of aire?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I heare little of that among≈øt their confe≈ø≈øions, yet may hee make him≈øelfe palpable, either by a≈ø≈øuming any dead bodie, and v≈øing the mini≈øterie thereof, or el≈øe by deluding as well their ≈øence of feeling as ≈øeeing; which is not impo≈ø≈øible to him to doe, ≈øince all our ≈øen≈øes, as wee are ≈øo weake, and euen by ordinarie ≈øickne≈ø≈øes will be oftentimes deluded.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But I would ≈øpeere one word further yet, concerning his appearing to them in pri≈øon, which is this: May any other that chances to be pre≈øent at that time in the pri≈øon, ≈øee him as well as they?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Sometimes they will, and ≈øometimes not, as it plea≈øes God.

argument.head: ARG.
argument.p: Two formes of the diuels vi≈øible conuer≈øing in the earth, with the rea≈øons wherefore the one of them was commonest in the time of Papi≈øtrie, and the other ≈øen≈øine. Tho≈øe that deny the power of the diuell, denie the power of God, and are guilty of the errour of the Sadduces.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: HAth the Diuell then power to appeare to any other, except to ≈øuch as are his ≈øworne di≈øciples; e≈øpecially ≈øince all Oracles, and ≈øuch like kinds of illu≈øions were taken away and aboli≈øhed by the comming of CHRIST?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Although it be true indeede, that the brightne≈ø≈øe of the Go≈øpel at his comming, ≈øcaled the cloudes of all the≈øe gro≈ø≈øe errours in the Gentili≈øme; yet that the≈øe abu≈øing ≈øpirits, cea≈øe not ≈øen≈øine at ≈øometimes to appeare, daily experience teaches vs. Indeed this difference is to be marked betwixt the formes of Satans conuer≈øing vi≈øibly in the world: For of two different formes thereof, the one of them by the ≈øpreading of the Euangel, and conque≈øt of the white hor≈øe, in the ≈øixt Chapter of the Reuelation, is much hindred and become rather there-through: This his appearing to any Chri≈øtians, troubling of them outwardly, or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing of them con≈øtrainedly: The other of them is become commoner and more v≈øed ≈øen≈øine, I meane by their vnlawfull artes, whereupon our whole purpo≈øe hath beene. This wee finde by experience in this I≈øle to be true: For as wee know, moe gho≈øts and ≈øpirits were ≈øeene, nor tongue can tell, in the time of blind Papistrie in the≈øe countries, where now by the contrarie, a man ≈øhall ≈øcarcely all his time heare once of ≈øuch things; and yet were the≈øe vnlawful artes farre rarer at that time, and neuer were ≈øo much heard of, nor ≈øo rife as they are now.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What ≈øhould be the cau≈øe of that?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: The diuers nature of our ≈øinnes procures at the Iu≈øtice of God, diuers ≈øorts of puni≈øhments an≈øwering thereunto: and therefore as in the time of Papistrie, our fathers erring gro≈ø≈øely, and through ignorance, that mi≈øt of errours ouer≈øhadowed the Diuell to walke the more familiarly among≈øt them, and as it were by barnely and affraying terrours, to mocke and accu≈øe their barnely errours; by the contrarie, we now being ≈øound of Religion, and in our life rebelling to our profe≈ø≈øion, God iu≈øtly by that ≈øinne of rebellion, as Samuel calleth it, accu≈øeth our life ≈øo wilfully fighting again≈øt our profe≈ø≈øion.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Since ye are entred now to ≈øpeake of the appearing of ≈øpirits, I would be glad to heare your opinion in that matter: for many denie that any ≈øuch ≈øpirits can appeare in the≈øe daies, as I haue ≈øaid.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
Doubtle≈ø≈øe who denieth the power of the Diuell, would likewi≈øe
denie the power of God, if they could for ≈øhame. For ≈øince the Diuel is the very contrarie oppo≈øite to God, there can bee no better way to know God, then by the contrarie; as by the ones power (though a creature) to admire the power of the great Creatour: by the fal≈øhood of the one to con≈øider the trewth of the other: by the iniu≈øtice of the one, to con≈øider the Iu≈øtice of the other: And by the cruelty of the one, to con≈øider the mercifulne≈ø≈øe of the other: And ≈øo foorth in all the re≈øt of the e≈ø≈øence of God, and qualities of the Diuell. But I feare indeed, there bee ouer many Sadduces in this world, that denie all kindes of Spirits: For conuicting of who≈øe errour, there is cau≈øe inough if there were no more, that God ≈øhould permit at ≈øometimes Spirits vi≈øibly to kyith.

p.hi: The de≈øcription of all the≈øe kinds of Spirits that trouble men or women. The conclu≈øion of the whole Dialogue.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: The diui≈øion of Spirits in foure principall kindes: The de≈øcription of the fir≈øt kinde of them, called Spectra & vmbrae mortuorum: What is the best way to be free of their trouble.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: I Pray you now then goe forward in telling what ye thinke fabulous, or may be trowed in that ca≈øe.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
That kind of the diuels coÃÑuer≈øing in the earth, may be diuided in foure different kindes, whereby he affraieth and troubleth the bodies of men: For of the abu≈øing of the ≈øoule, I haue ≈øpoken alreadie. The fir≈øt is, where ≈øpirits trouble ≈øome hou≈øes or ≈øolitarie places: The ≈øecond, where Spirits follow vpon certaine per≈øons, and at diuers houres trouble them: The third, when they enter within them, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them: The fourth is the≈øe kinde of Spirits that are called vulgarly the Fairie: Of the three former kinds, ye heard already, how they may artificially be made by Witchcraft to trouble folke; now it re≈øtes to ≈øpeake of their naturall comming as it were, and not rai≈øed by Witchcraft. But generally I mu≈øt forewarne you of one thing before I enter in this purpo≈øe: that is, that although in my di≈øcour≈øing of them, I deuide them in diuers kinds, ye mu≈øt notwith≈øtanding thereof note my phra≈øe of ≈øpeaking in that: For doubtle≈ølie they are in effect, but all one kinde of Spirits, who for abu≈øing the more of mankinde, take on the≈øe ≈øundrie ≈øhapes, and v≈øe diuers formes of outward actions, as if ≈øome were of nature better then other. Now I returne to my purpo≈øe: As to the fir≈øt kinde of the≈øe ≈øpirits, that were called by the ancients by diuers names, according as their actions were: For if they were Spirits that haunted ≈øome hou≈øes, by appearing in diuers and horrible formes, and making great dinne, they were
called Lemures or Spectra: If they appeared in likene≈ø≈øe of any defunct to ≈øome friends of his, they were called vmbraemortuorum: And ≈øo innumerable ≈øtiles they got, according to their actions, as I haue ≈øaid alreadie; as we ≈øee by experience, how many ≈øtiles they haue giuen them in our language in the like maner. Of the appearing of the≈øe Spirits, we are certified by the Scriptures, E≈øay 13. Iere. 50. where the Prophet E≈øay 13. and 34. Chap. threatning the de≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem, declares, that it ≈øhall not onely be wracked, but ≈øhall become ≈øo great a ≈øolitude, as it ≈øhall be the habitacle of Howlets, and of Zijm and Ijm, which are the proper Hebrew names for the≈øe Spirits. The cau≈øe why they haunt ≈øollitarie places, it is by rea≈øon, that they may affray and brangle the more the faith of ≈øuch as them alone hauntes ≈øuch places: For our nature is ≈øuch, as in companies we are not ≈øo ≈øoone moued to any ≈øuch kind of feare, as being ≈øollitarie, which the diuel knowing well enough, he will not therefore a≈ø≈øaile vs but when wee are weake: And be≈øides that, God will not permit him ≈øo to di≈øhonour the ≈øocieties and companies of Chri≈øtians, as in publicque times and places to walke vi≈øiblie among≈øt them: On the other part, when he troubles certaine hou≈øes that are dwelt in, it is a ≈øure token either of gro≈ø≈øe ignorance, or of ≈øome gro≈ø≈øe and ≈ølanderous ≈øinnes among≈øt the inhabitants thereof, which God by that extraordinarie rod puni≈øhes.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But by what way or pa≈ø≈øage can the≈øe Spirits enter into the≈øe hou≈øes, ≈øeeing they alledge that they will enter, doore and window being ≈øteiked?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: They will choo≈øe the pa≈ø≈øage for their entre≈ø≈øe, according to the forme that they are in at that time: For if they haue a≈ø≈øumed a dead bodie, whereinto they lodge them≈øelues, they can ea≈øily enough open without dinne any doore or window, and enter in thereat; And if they enter as a Spirit onely, any place where the aire may come in at, is large enough an entrie for them: For as I ≈øaid before, a Spirit can occupie no quantitie.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And will God then permit the≈øe wicked Spirits to trouble the re≈øt of a dead bodie, before the re≈øurrection thereof? Or if hee will ≈øo, I thinke it ≈øhould be of the reprobate onely.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
What more is the re≈øt troubled of a dead bodie, when the diuell caries it out of the graue to ≈øerue his turne for a ≈øpace, nor when the Witches take it vp and ioynts it, or when as Swine wortes vp the graues? The re≈øt of them that the Scripture ≈øpeakes of, is not meaned by a locall remaining continually in one place, but by their re≈øting from their trauailes and mi≈øeries of this world, while their latter coniunction againe with the ≈øoule at that time, to receiue full glorie in both: And that the diuel may v≈øe as well the mini≈øtrie of the bodies of the faithfull in the≈øe ca≈øes, as of the vnfaithfull, there is no inconuenience; for his haunting with their bodies after they are dead, can no-waies defile them, in re≈øpect of the ≈øoules ab≈øence: And for any di≈øhonour it can be vnto them, by what rea≈øon can it be greater, then the hanging, heading, or many ≈øuch ≈øhamefull deaths, that good
men will ≈øuffer? For there is nothing in the bodies of the faithfull, more worthie of honour, or freer from corruption by nature, nor in the≈øe of the vnfaithfull, while time they be purged and glorified in the latter Day, as is daily ≈øeene by the vilde di≈øea≈øes and corruptions, that the bodies of the faithfull are ≈øubiect vnto, as ye will ≈øee clearely proued, when I ≈øpeake of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and Daemoniacques.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Yet there are ≈øundry that affirme to haue haunted ≈øuch places, where the≈øe ≈øpirits are alledged to be; and could neuer heare nor ≈øee any thing.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I thinke well: for that is onely re≈øerued to the ≈øecret knowledge of God, whom he will permit to ≈øee ≈øuch things, and whom not.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But where the≈øe ≈øpirits haunt and trouble any hou≈øes, what is the be≈øt way to bani≈øh them?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: By two meanes may onely the remeid of ≈øuch things be procured: The one is ardent prayer to God, both of the≈øe per≈øons that are troubled with them, and of that Church whereof they are: The other is the purging of them≈øelues by amendment of life, from ≈øuch ≈øinnes, as haue procured that extraordinarie plague.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And what meane then the≈øe kindes of ≈øpirits, when they appeare in the ≈øhadow of a per≈øon newly dead, or to die, to his friends?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: When they appeare vpon that occa≈øion, they are called Wraithes in our language: Among≈øt the Gentiles the diuell v≈øed that much, to make them beleeue that it was ≈øome good ≈øpirit that appeared to them then, either to forewarne them of the death of their friend, or el≈øe to di≈øcouer vnto them the will of the defunct, or what was the way of his ≈ølaughter, as it is written in the booke of the hi≈øtories prodigious: and this way he ea≈øily deceiued the Gentiles, becau≈øe they knew not God: and to that ≈øame effect is it, that he now appeares in that maner to ≈øome ignorant Chri≈øtians: for hee dares not ≈øo illude any that knoweth that, neither can the ≈øpirit of the defunct returne to his friend, or yet an Angel v≈øe ≈øuch formes.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And are not our war-woolfes one ≈øort of the≈øe ≈øpirits al≈øo, that haunt and trouble ≈øome hou≈øes or dwelling places?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
There hath indeede beene an olde opinion of ≈øuch like things; for by the Greekes they were called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which ≈øignifieth men-wolfes: But to tell you ≈øimply my opinion in this, if any ≈øuch thing hath beene, I take it to haue proceeded but of a naturall ≈øuper-abundance of Melancholy, which as we reade, that it hath made ≈øome thinke them≈øelues pitchers, and ≈øome hor≈øes, and ≈øome one kinde of bea≈øt or other, ≈øo ≈øuppo≈øe I that it hath ≈øo viciat the imagination and memory of ≈øome, as per lucida interualla, it hath ≈øo highly occupied them, that they haue thought them≈øelues very Woolfes indeed at the≈øe times and ≈øo haue counterfeited their actions in going on their hands and feete, prea≈ø≈øing to deuoure women and barnes, fighting and ≈ønatching with all the towne dogges, and in v≈øing ≈øuch like other bruti≈øh actions, and ≈øo to become bea≈øts by a ≈øtrong apprehen≈øion, as
Nebuchad-nezzar was ≈øeuen yeeres: Daniel 4. but as to their hauing and hiding of their hard and ≈øchelly ≈øluiches, I take that to be but eiked, by vncertaine report, the author of all lies.

p.hi: The de≈øcription of the next two kinds of Spirits, whereof the one followes outwardly, the other po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes inwardly the per≈øons that they trouble: That ≈øince all prophecies and vi≈øions are now cea≈øed, all ≈øpirits that appeare in the≈øe formes are euill.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: COme forward now to the re≈øt of the≈øe kinds of ≈øpirits.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: As to the next two kindes, that is, either the≈øe that outwardly trouble and follow ≈øome per≈øons, or el≈øe inwardly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them, I wil conioine them in one, becau≈øe as well the cau≈øes are alike in the per≈øons that they are permitted to trouble; as al≈øo the wayes whereby they may be remedied and cured.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: What kinde of per≈øons are they that v≈øe to be ≈øo troubled?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Two kindes in ≈øpeciall; either ≈øuch as being guiltie of grieuous offences, God puni≈øhes by that horrible kinde of ≈øcourge; or el≈øe being per≈øons of the be≈øt nature peraduenture, that ye ≈øhall finde in all the countrey about them, God permits them to be troubled in that ≈øort, for the triall of their patience, and wakening vp of their zeale, for admoni≈øhing of the beholders, not to tru≈øt ouer-much in them≈øelues, ≈øince they are made of no better ≈øtuffe, and peraduenture blotted with no ≈ømaller ≈øinnes (as Chri≈øt ≈øaid, Luke 13. ≈øpeaking of them vpon whom the Tower of Sylo fell:) And for giuing likewi≈øe to the ≈øpectators, matter to prai≈øe God, that they meriting no better, are yet ≈øpared from being corrected in that fearefull forme.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: The≈øe are good rea≈øons for the part of GOD, which apparantly moonues him ≈øo to permit the Diuell to trouble ≈øuch per≈øons: But ≈øince the Diuell hath euer a contrarie re≈øpect in all the actions that GOD imployes him in, which is I pray you the end and marke he ≈øhootes at in this turne?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: It is to obtaine one of two things thereby, if he may: The one is the tin≈øell of their life, by inducing them to ≈øuch perillous places, at ≈øuch time as he either followes or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes them, which may procure the ≈øame, and ≈øuch like, ≈øo farre as GOD will permit him, by tormenting them to weaken their bodie, and ca≈øt them into incurable di≈øea≈øes: The other thing that he prea≈ø≈øes to obtaine by troubling of them, is the tin≈øell of their ≈øoule, by inti≈øing them to mi≈øtru≈øt & bla≈øpheme God, either for the intolerablene≈ø≈øe of their torments, Iob 1. as hee a≈ø≈øayed to haue done with Iob; or el≈øe for his promi≈øing vnto them to leaue the troubling of them, in ca≈øe they would ≈øo doe, as is knowen by experience at this ≈øame time by the confe≈ø≈øion of a young one that was ≈øo troubled.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p:
Since ye haue ≈øpoken now of both the≈øe kinds of ≈øpirits comprehending them in one, I mu≈øt now goe backe againe in ≈øpeering ≈øome que≈øtions
of euery one of the≈øe kindes in ≈øpeciall. And fir≈øt for the≈øe that follow certaine per≈øons, ye know that there are two ≈øorts of them: One ≈øorte that trouble and torment the per≈øons that they haunt with: Another ≈øort that are ≈øeruiceable vnto them in all kind of their nece≈ø≈øaries, and omit neuer to forewarne them of any ≈øuddaine perill that they are to bee in: And ≈øo in this ca≈øe, I would vnder≈øtand whether both the≈øe ≈øorts be but wicked and damned ≈øpirits, or if the la≈øt ≈øort be rather Angels, (as ≈øhould appeare by their actions) ≈øent by God to a≈ø≈øi≈øt ≈øuch as hee ≈øpecially fauours: For it is written in the Scriptures, Gene. 32. 1. Kings 6. P≈øal. 34. that God ≈øends legions of Angels to guard and watch ouer his elect.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I know well inough where fra that errour which ye alledge hath proceeded; For it was the ignorant Gentiles that were the fountaine thereof, Who for that they knew not God, they forged in their owne imaginations, euery man to be ≈øtil accompanied with two ≈øpirits, whereof they called the one genius bonus, the other genius malus: the Greekes called them „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ : whereof the former they ≈øaide, per≈øwaded him to all the good hee did; the other enti≈øed him to all the euill. But prai≈øed bee GOD, wee that are Chri≈øtians, and walke not among≈øt the Cymmerian coniectures of man, know well inough, that it is the good Spirit of GOD onely, who is the fountaine of all goodne≈ø≈øe, that per≈øwades vs to the thinking or doing of any good, and that it is our corrupted fle≈øh and Satan, that inti≈øeth vs to the contrarie: And yet the Diuell for confirming in the heades of ignorant Chri≈øtians, that errour fir≈øt maintained among the Gentiles, he whiles among the fir≈øt kind of ≈øpirits that I ≈øpeake of, appeared in time of Papi≈øtrie and blindne≈ø≈øe, and haunted diuers hou≈øes, without doing any euill, but doing as it were nece≈ø≈øarie turnes vp and downe the hou≈øe: and this ≈øpirit they called Brownie in our language, who appeared like a rough-man: yea, ≈øome were ≈øo blinded, as to beleeue that their hou≈øe was all their ≈øon≈øier, as they called it, that ≈øuch ≈øpirits re≈øorted there.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But ≈øince the diuels intention in all his actions, is euer to doe euill, what euill was there in that forme of doing, ≈øince their actions outwardly were good?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Was it not euill inough to deceiue ≈øimple ignorants, in making them to take him for an Angel of light, and ≈øo to account of Gods enemy as of their particular friend? where by the contrary, all we that are Chri≈øtians, ought a≈ø≈øuredly to know, that ≈øince the comming of Chri≈øt in the fle≈øh, and e≈øtabli≈øhing of his Church by the Apo≈øtles, al miracles, vi≈øions, prophecies, & appearances of Angels or good ≈øpirits, are cea≈øed; which ≈øerued only for the fir≈øt ≈øowing of faith, and planting of the Church: Where now the Church being e≈øtabli≈øhed, and the white Hor≈øe whereof I ≈øpake before, hauing made his conque≈øt, the Law and Prophets are thought ≈øufficient to ≈øerue vs, or make vs inexcu≈øable, as Chri≈øt ≈øaith in his parable of Lazarus and the rich man.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: The de≈øcription of a particular ≈øort of that kinde of following Spirits, called Incubi and Succubi: And what is the rea≈øon wherefore the≈øe kinds of Spirits haunt most the Northerne and barbarous parts of the world.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: THe next que≈øtion that I would ≈øpeere, is likewi≈øe concerning this fir≈øt of the≈øe two kinds of Spirits that ye haue conioyned; and it is this: ye know how it is commonly written and reported, that among≈øt the re≈øt of the ≈øorts of Spirits that follow certaine per≈øons, there is one more mon≈øtrous nor all the re≈øt, in re≈øpect as it is alleaged, they conuer≈øe naturally with them whom they trouble and haunt with: and therefore I would know in two things your opinion herein: Fir≈øt, if ≈øuch a thing can be: and next if it be, whether there be a difference of ≈øexes among≈øt the≈øe Spirits or not?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: That abhominable kinde of the diuels abu≈øing of men or women, was called of old, Incubi and Succubi, according to the difference of the ≈øexes that they conuer≈øed with. By two meanes this great kinde of abu≈øe might po≈ø≈øibly be performed: The one, when the diuel onely as a Spirit, and ≈øtealing out the ≈øperme of a dead bodie, abu≈øes them that way, they not graithly ≈øeeing any ≈øhape, or feeling any thing, but that which hee ≈øo conueyes in that part, as we reade of a Mona≈øterie of Nunnes which were burnt for their being that way abu≈øed: The other meane is, when he borrowes a dead body and ≈øo vi≈øibly, and as it ≈øeemes vnto them naturally as a man conuer≈øes with them. But it is to be noted, that in what≈øoeuer way he v≈øeth it, that ≈øperme ≈øeemes intollerably cold to the per≈øon abu≈øed: For if he ≈øteale out the nature of a quicke per≈øon, it cannot be ≈øo quickly caried, but it will both tine the ≈øtrength and heate by the way, which it could neuer haue had for lacke of agitation, which in the time of procreation is the procurer and wakener vp of the≈øe two naturall qualities: And if he occupying the dead bodie as his lodging, expell the ≈øame out thereof in the due time, it mu≈øt likewi≈øe be cold by the participation with the qualities of the dead body whereout of it comes. And whereas ye enquire if the≈øe Spirits be diuided in ≈øexes or not, I thinke the rules of Philo≈øophie may ea≈øily re≈øolue a man of the contrary: For it is a ≈øure principle of that Art, that nothing can be diuided in ≈øexes, except ≈øuch liuing bodies as mu≈øt haue a naturall ≈øeed to genere by: But we know Spirits haue no ≈øeed proper to them≈øelues, nor yet can they gender one with an other.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: How is it then, that they ≈øay ≈øundrie mon≈øters haue bene gotten by that way?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
The≈øe tales are nothing but Aniles fabulae: For that they haue no nature of their owne, I haue ≈øhewed you alreadie: And that the cold nature
of a dead bodie, can worke nothing in generation, it is more nor plaine, as being alreadie dead of it ≈øelfe, as well as the re≈øt of the bodie is, wanting the naturall heate, and ≈øuch other naturall operation, as is nece≈ø≈øarie for working that effect, and in ca≈øe ≈øuch a thing were po≈ø≈øible (which were vtterly again≈øt all the rules of nature) it would breed no mon≈øter, but onely ≈øuch a naturall off-≈øpring, as would haue come betwixt that man or woman and that other abu≈øed per≈øon, in ca≈øe they both being aliue had had a doe with other: For the Diuels part therein, is but the naked carrying or expelling of that ≈øub≈øtance; and ≈øo it could participate with no quality of the ≈øame. Indeede, it is po≈ø≈øible to the craft of the Diuell to make a womans belly to ≈øwell after he hath that way abu≈øed her, which hee may doe either by ≈øtirring vp her owne humour, or by hearbes, as wee ≈øee beggers daily doe: And when the time of her deliuery ≈øhould come to make her thoil great dolours, like vnto that naturall cour≈øe, and then ≈øubtilly to ≈ølip in the Mid-wiues hands, ≈øtocks, ≈øtones, or ≈øome mon≈øtrous barne brought from ≈øome other place: but this is more reported and gue≈ø≈øed at by others, nor beleeued by me.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But what is the cau≈øe that this kinde of abu≈øe is thought to bee mo≈øt common in ≈øuch wilde parts of the world, as Lap-land, and Fin-land, or in our North I≈øles of Orknay and Schet-land?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Becau≈øe where the Diuell findes greate≈øt ignorance and barbaritie, there a≈ø≈øailes he gro≈ø≈øelie≈øt, as I gaue you the rea≈øon wherfore there were moe Witches of women-kinde nor men.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Can any be ≈øo vnhappie as to giue their willing con≈øent to the Diuels vile abu≈øing them in this forme?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Yea, ≈øome of the Witches haue confe≈ø≈øed, that he hath per≈øwaded them to giue their willing con≈øent thereunto, that hee may thereby haue them feltred the ≈øikarer in his ≈ønares: but as the other compelled ≈øort is to be pitied and prayed for, ≈øo is this mo≈øt highly to be puni≈øhed and dete≈øted.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Is it not the thing which we call the Mare, which takes folkes ≈øleeping in their beds, a kinde of the≈øe ≈øpirits, whereof ye are ≈øpeaking?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: No, that is but a naturall ≈øickene≈ø≈øe, which the Mediciners haue giuen that name of Incubus vnto, ab incubando, becau≈øe it being a thicke fleume, falling into our brea≈øt vpon the heart, while we are ≈øleeping, intercludes ≈øo our vitall ≈øpirits, and takes all powerfrom vs, as makes vs think that there were ≈øome vnnaturall burden or ≈øpirit, lying vpon vs, and holding vs downe.

p.hi: The de≈øcription of the Daemoniackes and po≈øse≈ø≈øed: By what rea≈øon the Papi≈øts may haue power to cure them.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: WEll, I haue tolde you now all my doubts, and ye haue ≈øati≈øfied me therein, concerning the fir≈øt of the≈øe two kindes of ≈øpirits that yee haue conioyned: now I am to enquire onely two things at you concerning the la≈øt kinde, I meane the Daemoniackes. The fir≈øt is, whereby ≈øhall the≈øe po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed folkes be di≈øcerned fra them that are troubled with a naturall Phren≈øie or Manie: The next is, how can it be that they can be remedied by the Papi≈øts Church, whom we counting as Heretiques, it ≈øhould appeare that one diuell ≈øhould not ca≈øt out another, Matth. 12. Marke 3. for then would his kingdome be diuided in it ≈øelfe, as Chri≈øt ≈øaid.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
As to your fir≈øt que≈øtion; there are diuers ≈øymptomes, whereby that heauie trouble may be di≈øcerned from a naturall ≈øickene≈ø≈øe, and ≈øpecially three, omitting the diuers vaine ≈øignes that the Papi≈øts attribute vnto it: Such as the raging at holy water, their fleeing abacke from the Cro≈ø≈øe, their not abiding the hearing of God named, and innumerable ≈øuch like vaine things that were alike fa≈øhious and feckles to recite: But to come to the≈øe three ≈øymptomes then, whereof I ≈øpake, I account the one of them to be the incredible ≈øtrength of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed creature, which will farre exceede the ≈øtrength of ≈øixe of the wighte≈øt and wode≈øt of any other men that are not ≈øo troubled: The next is the boldening vp ≈øo farre of the patients brea≈øt and belly, with ≈øuch an vnnaturall ≈øturring and vehement agitation within them, and ≈øuch an ironie hardne≈ø≈øe of his ≈øinewes ≈øo ≈øtiffely bended out, that it were not po≈ø≈øible to pricke out as it were the skinne of any other per≈øon ≈øo farre; ≈øo mightily workes the diuell in all the members and ≈øen≈øes of his body, hee being locally within the ≈øame, ≈øuppo≈øe of his ≈øoule and affections thereof, hee haue no more power then of any other mans: The la≈øt is, the ≈øpeaking of ≈øundry languages, which the patient is knowen, by them that were acquainted with him, neuer to haue learned, and that with an vncouth and hollow voice, and all the time of his ≈øpeaking, a greater motion being in his brea≈øt then in his mouth: But fra this la≈øt ≈øymptome is excepted ≈øuch, as are altogether in the time of their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing bereft of all their ≈øen≈øes, being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with a dumbe and blind ≈øpirit, whereof Chri≈øt relieued one, in the 12. of Matthew. And as to your next demand, it is fir≈øt to be doubted if the Papi≈øts, or any not profe≈ø≈øing the onely true Religion, can relieue any of that trouble: and next, in ca≈øe they can, vpon what re≈øpect it is po≈ø≈øible vnto them. As to the former, vpon two rea≈øons it is grounded: fir≈øt that it is knowen ≈øo many of them to be counterfeit, which wyle the Clergie inuents for confirming of their
rotten Religion: The next is, that by experience we finde, that few who are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed indeed, are fully cured by them; but rather the diuell is content to relea≈øe the bodily hurting of them, for a ≈øhort ≈øpace, thereby to obtaine the perpetuall hurt of the ≈øoules of ≈øo many that by the≈øe fal≈øe miracles may be induced or confirmed in the profe≈ø≈øion of that erroneous Religion; euen as I told you before that he doeth in the fal≈øe cures or ca≈øting off of di≈øea≈øes by Witches. As to the other part of the argument in ca≈øe they can, which rather (with reuerence of the learned thinking otherwi≈øe) I am induced to beleeue, by rea≈øon of the faithfull report that men ≈øound of Religion, haue made according to their ≈øight thereof, I thinke if ≈øo be I ≈øay the≈øe may be the re≈øpects, whereupon the Papi≈øts may haue that power. Chri≈øt gaue a commi≈ø≈øion and power to his Apo≈øtles to ca≈øt out diuels, which they according thereunto put in execution: the rules he bade them ob≈øerue in that action, was fa≈øting and prayer; and the action it ≈øelfe to be done in his name. This power of theirs proceeded not then of any vertue in them, but onely in him who directed them; as was clearely prooued by Iudas his hauing as great power in that commi≈ø≈øion, as any of the re≈øt. It is ea≈øie then to be vnder≈øtood that the ca≈øting out of diuels, is by the vertue of fa≈øting and prayer, and in calling of the Name of God, ≈øuppo≈øe many imperfections be in the per≈øon that is the in≈øtrument, as Chri≈øt him≈øelfe teacheth vs of the power that fal≈øe prophets ≈øhall haue to ca≈øt out diuels. It is no wonder then, the≈øe re≈øpects of this action being con≈øidered, that it may be po≈ø≈øible to the Papi≈øts, though erring in ≈øundry points of Religion to accompli≈øh this, if they v≈øe the right forme pre≈øcribed by Chri≈øt herein: For what the wor≈øe is that action that they erre in other things; more then their Bapti≈øme is the wor≈øe that they erre in the other Sacrament, and haue eiked many vaine freittes to the Bapti≈øme it ≈øelfe.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Surely it is no little wonder that God ≈øhould permit the bodies of any of the faithfull to be ≈øo di≈øhonoured, as to be adwelling place to that vncleane ≈øpirit.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: There is it which I told right now, would proue and ≈øtrengthen my argument of the diuels entring into the dead bodies of the faithfull: For if he is permitted to enter into their liuing bodies, euen when they are ioyned with the ≈øoule; how much more will God permit him to enter into their dead carions, which is no more man, Marke 7. but the filthie and corruptible cai≈øe of man? For as Chri≈øt ≈øaith, It is not any thing that enters within man that defiles him, but onely that which proceedes and commeth out of him.

argument.head: ARGV.
argument.p: The de≈øcription of the fourth kinde of Spirits, called the Phairie: What is po≈øsible therein, and what is but illu≈øions. How farre this Dialogue entreates of all the≈øe things, and to what end.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: NOw I pray you come on to that fourth kinde of Spirits.

sp.speaker: EPI.
