sp.p: That fourth kinde of Spirits, which by the Gentiles was called Diana, and her wandering court, and among≈øt vs was called the Phairie (as I told you) or our good neighbours, was one of the ≈øorts of illu≈øions that was rife≈øt in the time of Papi≈øtrie: for although it was holden odious to prophe≈øie by the diuel, yet whom the≈øe kinde of Spirits caried away, and informed, they were thought to be ≈øon≈øie≈øt and of be≈øt life. To ≈øpeake of the many vaine trattles founded vpon that illu≈øion, How there was a King and Queene of Phairie, of ≈øuch a iolly court and traine as they had, how they had a teynd, and duetie, as it were, of all goods, how they naturally rode and went, eate and dranke, and did all other actions like naturall men and women, I thinke it liker Virgils Campi Ely≈øij, nor any thing that ought to be beleeued by Chri≈øtians, except in generall, that as I ≈øpake ≈øundrie times before, the diuell illuded the ≈øen≈øes of ≈øundrie ≈øimple creatures, in making them beleeue that they ≈øaw and heard ≈øuch things as were nothing ≈øo indeed.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But how can it be then, that ≈øundrie Witches haue gone to death with that confe≈ø≈øion, that they haue bene tran≈øported with the Phairie to ≈øuch a hill, which opening, they went in, and there ≈øaw a faire Queene, who being now lighter, gaue them a ≈øtone that had ≈øundrie vertues, which at ≈øundrie times hath bene produced in iudgement?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I ≈øay that, euen as I ≈øaid before of that imaginar raui≈øhing of the Spirit foorth of the bodie: For may not the diuel obiect to their fanta≈øie, their ≈øen≈øes being dulled, and as it were a≈øleepe, ≈øuch hilles and hou≈øes within them, ≈øuch gli≈øtering courtes and traines, and what≈øoeuer ≈øuch like wherewith he plea≈øeth to delude them, and in the meane time their bodies being ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe, to conuey in their hand any ≈øtone or ≈øuch like thing, which he makes them to imagine to haue receiued in ≈øuch a place.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But what ≈øay ye to their foretelling the death of ≈øundrie per≈øons, whom they alleage to haue ≈øeene in the≈øe places? that is, a ≈øoothdreame (as they ≈øay) ≈øince they ≈øee it walking.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
I thinke that either they haue not bene ≈øharpely enough examined, that gaue ≈øo blunt a rea≈øon for their prophe≈øie, or otherwi≈øe, I thinke it likewi≈øe as po≈ø≈øible that the diuel may prophe≈øie to them when he deceiues their imaginations in that ≈øort, as well as when hee plainely ≈øpeakes vnto them at other times: for their prophe≈øying, is but by a kind of vi≈øion,
as it were, wherein he commonly counterfeites God among the Ethnicks, as I told you before.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I would know now whether the≈øe kinds of Spirits may onely appeare to Witches, or if they may al≈øo appeare to any other.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: They may doe to both; to the innocent ≈øort, either to affray them, or to ≈øeeme to be a better ≈øort of folkes nor vncleane Spirits are; and to the Witches to be a colour of ≈øafetie for them, that ignorant Magi≈øtrates may not puni≈øh them for it, as I told euen now: But as the one ≈øort, for being perforce troubled with them ought to be pitied, ≈øo ought the other ≈øort (who may be di≈øcerned by their taking vpon them to prophe≈øie by them,) that ≈øort, I ≈øay, ought as ≈øeuerely to be puni≈øhed as any other Witches, and rather the more, that they goe di≈ø≈øemblingly to worke.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And what makes the ≈øpirits haue ≈øo different names from others?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Euen the knauerie of that ≈øame diuell; who as he illudes the Necromancers with innumerable feined names for him and his angels, as in ≈øpeciall, making Satan, Beelzebub, and Lucifer, to bee three ≈øundry ≈øpirits, where wee finde the two former, but diuers names giuen to the Prince of all the rebelling Angels by the Scripture; as by Chri≈øt, the Prince of all the diuels is called Beelzebub in that place, which I alleaged again≈øt the power of any hereticques to ca≈øt out diuels. By Iohn in the Reuelation, the old tempter is called Satan the Prince of all the euill Angels: And the la≈øt, to wit, Lucifer, is but by allegorie taken from the day Starre (≈øo named in diuers places of the Scriptures) becau≈øe of his excellencie (I meane the Prince of them) in his creation before his fall; euen ≈øo I ≈øay hee deceiues the Witches, by attributing to him≈øelfe diuers names; as if euery diuers ≈øhape that he transformes him≈øelfe in, were a diuers kinde of ≈øpirit.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But I haue heard many moe ≈øtrange tales of this Phairie, nor ye haue yet told me.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: As well I doe in that, as I did in all the re≈øt of my di≈øcour≈øe: For becau≈øe the ground of this conference of ours, proceeded of your ≈øpeering at me at our meeting: if there was ≈øuch a thing as Witches or ≈øpirits: and if they had any power: I therefore haue framed my whole di≈øcour≈øe, onely to proue that ≈øuch things are and may be, by ≈øuch number of examples as I ≈øhew to be po≈ø≈øible by rea≈øon, and keepe me from dipping any further in playing the part of a Dictionarie, to tell what euer I haue read or heard in that purpo≈øe, which both would exceede faith, and rather would ≈øeeme to teach ≈øuch vnlawfull artes, nor to di≈øallow and condemne them, as it is the duetie of all Chri≈øtians to doe.

p.hi: Of the tryall and puni≈øhment of Witches: What ≈øort of accu≈øation ought to be admitted against them: What is the cau≈øe of the increa≈øing ≈øo farre of their number in this aage.

sp.speaker: PHILOMATHES.
sp.p: THen to make an end of our conference, ≈øince I ≈øee it drawes late, what forme of puni≈øhment thinke yee merite the≈øe Magicians and Witches? For I ≈øee that ye account them to be all alike guiltie.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: They ought to be put to death according to the Law of God, the ciuill and imperiall Law, and municipall Law of all Chri≈øtian nations.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But what kinde of death I pray you?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: It is commonly v≈øed by fire, but that is an indifferent thing to be v≈øed in euery countrey, according to the Law or cu≈øtome thereof.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: But ought no ≈øexe, aage nor rancke to be exempted?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: None at all (being ≈øo v≈øed by the lawfull magi≈øtrate) for it is the highe≈øt point of Idolatry, wherein no exception is admitted by the law of God.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Then barnes may not be ≈øpared.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Yea; not a haire the le≈ø≈øe of my conclu≈øion: For they are not that capable of rea≈øon as to pacti≈øe ≈øuch things: And for any being in company and not reueiling thereof, their le≈ø≈øe and ignorant aage will no doubt excu≈øe them.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: I ≈øee ye condemne them all that are of the coun≈øell of ≈øuch craftes.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: No doubt, for as I ≈øaid, ≈øpeaking of Magie, the con≈øulters, tru≈øters in, ouer-≈øeers, interteiners or ≈øtirrers vp of the≈øe craftes-folkes, are equally guiltie with them≈øelues that are the practi≈øers.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Whether may the Prince then, or ≈øupreame Magi≈øtrate, ≈øpare or ouer-≈øee any that are guilty of that craft, vpon ≈øome great re≈øpects knowen to him?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: The Prince or Magi≈øtrate for further trials cau≈øe, may continue the puni≈øhing of them ≈øuch a certaine ≈øpace as he thinkes conuenient: But in the end to ≈øpare the life, and not to ≈øtrike when God bids ≈øtrike, and ≈øo ≈øeuerely puni≈øh in ≈øo odious a fault and trea≈øon again≈øt God, it is not onely vnlawfull, but doubtle≈ø≈øe no le≈ø≈øe ≈øinne in that Magi≈øtrate, nor it was in Saules ≈øparing of Agag; 1. Sam. 15. and ≈øo comparable to the ≈øinne of Witch-craft it ≈øelfe, as Samuel alledged at that time.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Surely then, I thinke ≈øince this crime ought to be ≈øo ≈øeuerely puni≈øhed, Iudges ought to beware to condemne any, but ≈øuch as they are ≈øure are guiltie, neither ≈øhould the clattering report of a carling ≈øerue in ≈øo weightie a ca≈øe.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: Iudges ought indeede to beware whom they condemne: for it is as great a crime (as Salomon ≈øaith,) To condemne the innocent, Prou. 17. as to let the guiltie e≈øcape free; neither ought the report of any one infamous per≈øon, be admitted for a ≈øufficient proofe, which can ≈øtand of no law.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And what may a number then of guilty per≈øons confe≈ø≈øions, worke again≈øt one that is accu≈øed?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: The A≈ø≈øi≈øe mu≈øt ≈øerue for interpretour of our law in that re≈øpect: But in my opinion, ≈øince in a matter of trea≈øon again≈øt the Prince, barnes or wiues, or neuer ≈øo diffamed per≈øons, may of our law ≈øerue for ≈øufficient witne≈ø≈øes and proofes; I thinke ≈øurely that by a farre greater rea≈øon, ≈øuch witne≈ø≈øes may be ≈øufficient in matters of high trea≈øon again≈øt God: For who but Witches can be prooues, and ≈øo witne≈ø≈øes of the doings of Witches?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Indeed, I trow they will be loath to put any hone≈øt man vpon their coun≈øell: But what if they accu≈øe folke to haue bene pre≈øent at their Imaginar conuentions in the ≈øpirit, when their bodies lye ≈øencele≈ø≈øe, as ye haue ≈øaid?

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I thinke they are not a haire the le≈ø≈øe guiltie: For the Diuel dur≈øt neuer haue borrowed their ≈øhadow or ≈øimilitude to that turne, if their con≈øent had not beene at it: And the con≈øent in the≈øe turnes is death of the lawe.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Then Samuel was a Witch: For the diuell re≈øembled his ≈øhape, and played his per≈øon in giuing re≈øpon≈øe to Saul.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p:
Samuel was dead as well before that; and ≈øo none could ≈ølaunder him with medling in that vnlawful arte. For the cau≈øe why, as I take it, that God will not permit Satan to v≈øe the ≈øhapes of ≈øimilitudes of any innocent per≈øons at ≈øuch vnlawfull times, is, that God will not permit that any innocent per≈øons ≈øhalbe ≈ølandered with that vile defection: for then the diuell would finde waies anew, to calumniate the be≈øt. And this wee haue in proofe by them that are carried with the Phairie, who neuer ≈øee the ≈øhadowes of any in that Court, but of them that thereafter are tryed to haue beene brethren and ≈øi≈øters of that craft: And this was likewi≈øe prooued by the confe≈ø≈øion of a young La≈ø≈øe, troubled with ≈øpirits, laid on her by Witchcraft: that although ≈øhe ≈øaw the ≈øhapes of diuers men and women troubling her, and naming the per≈øons whom the≈øe ≈øhadowes repre≈øent: yet neuer one of them are found to be innocent, but all clearely tryed to bee mo≈øt guiltie, and the mo≈øt part of them confe≈ø≈øing the ≈øame. And be≈øides that, I thinke it hath beene ≈øeldome heard tell of, that any, whom per≈øons guiltie of that crime accu≈øed, as hauing knowen them to be their marrowes by eye-≈øight, and not by heare-≈øay, but ≈øuch as were ≈øo accu≈øed of Witchcraft, could not be clearely tried vpon them, were at the lea≈øt publikely knowen to be of a very euill life and reputation: ≈øo iealous is God I ≈øay, of the fame of them that are innocent in ≈øuch cau≈øes. And be≈øides that, there are two other good helps that may be v≈øed for their triall: The one is, the finding of their marke, and the trying the in≈øen≈øiblenes therof: The other
is their fleeting on the water: for as in a ≈øecret murther, if the dead carka≈ø≈øe bee at any time thereafter handled by the murtherer, it will gu≈øh out of bloud, as if the bloud were crying to the heauen for reuenge of the murtherer, God hauing appointed that ≈øecret ≈øupernaturall ≈øigne, for triall of that ≈øecret vnnaturall crime, ≈øo it appeares that God hath appointed (for a ≈øupernaturall ≈øigne of the mon≈øtrous impietie of Witches) that the water ≈øhall refu≈øe to receiue them in her bo≈øome, that haue ≈øhaken off them the ≈øacred water of Bapti≈øme, and wilfully refu≈øed the benefite thereof: No, not ≈øo much as their eyes are able to ≈øhed teares (threaten and torture them as ye plea≈øe) while fir≈øt they repent (God not permitting them to di≈ø≈øemble their ob≈øtinacie in ≈øo horrible a crime) albeit the women-kind e≈øpecially, be able otherwayes to ≈øhed teares at euery light occa≈øion when they will, yea, although it were di≈ø≈øemblingly like the Crocodiles.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: Well, wee haue made this conference to la≈øt as long as lei≈øure would permit: and to conclude then, ≈øince I am to take my leaue of you, I pray God to purge this countrey of the≈øe diuelli≈øh practi≈øes: for they were neuer ≈øo rife in the≈øe parts, as they are now.

sp.speaker: EPI.
sp.p: I pray God that ≈øo be too. But the cau≈øes are ouer-manife≈øt, that make them to be ≈øo rife: For the great wickednes of the people on the one part, procures this horrible defection, whereby God iu≈øtly puni≈øheth ≈øinne by a greater iniquitie: and on the other part, the con≈øummation of the world, and our deliuerance drawing neere, makes Satan to rage the more in his in≈øtruments, knowing his kingdome to be ≈øo neere an end. And ≈øo farewell for this time.

lg.head: SONNET.
lg.l: GOD giues not Kings the ≈øtile of Gods in vaine,

div.head: TO HENRY MY DEAREST SONNE, AND NATVRAL SVCCESSOVR.
div.p:
VVHom-to can ≈øo rightly appertaine this Booke of instructions to a Prince in all the points of his calling, a≈øwell generall, as a Christian towards God; as particular, as a King towards his people? Whom-to, I ≈øay, can it ≈øo iustly appertaine, as vnto you my dearest Sonne? Since J the authour thereof, as your naturall Father, must be carefull for your godly and vertuous education, as my eldest Sonne, and the first fruits of Gods ble≈øsing towards mee in my posteritie: and as a King must timou≈øly prouide for your trayning vp in all the points of a Kings Office; ≈øince yee are my naturall and lawfull ≈øucce≈ø≈øour therein: that being rightly informed hereby, of the waight of your burthen, ye may in time beginne to con≈øider, that being borne to be a king, ye are rather borne to onus, then honos: not excelling all your people ≈øo farre in ranke and honour, as in daily care and hazardous paines-taking, for the dutifull administration of that great office, that God hath laide vpon your ≈øhoulders. Laying ≈øo a ju≈øt ≈øymmetrie and proportion, betwixt the height of your honourable place, and the heauie waight of your great charge: and con≈øequently,
in ca≈øe of failing, which God forbid, of the ≈øadne≈ø≈øe of your fall, according to the proportion of that height. J haue therefore for the greater ea≈øe to your memory, and that yee may at the first, cast vp any part that yee haue to doe with, deuided this Treati≈øe in three parts. The fir≈øt teacheth you your duetie towards God as a Christian: the next, your duetie in your Office as a King: and the third informeth you how to behaue your ≈øelfe in indifferent things, which of them-≈øelues are neither right nor wrong, but according as they are rightly or wrong v≈øed; and yet will ≈øerue according to your behauiour therein, to augment or empaire your fame and authoritie at the handes of your people. Receiue and welcome this Booke then, as a faithfull Praeceptour and coun≈øellour vnto you: which, becau≈øe my affaires will not permit mee euer to bee pre≈øent with you, J ordaine to bee a re≈øident faithfull admoni≈øher of you: And becau≈øe the houre of death is vncertaine to mee, as vnto all fle≈øh, J leaue it as my Testament and latter will vnto you. Chargeing you in the pre≈øence of GOD, and by the fatherly authoritie J haue ouer you, that yee keepe it euer with you, as carefully, as Alexander did the Iliads of Homer. Yee will finde it a iust and impartiall coun≈øellour; neither flattering you in any vice, nor importuning you at vnmeete times. Jt will not come vn-called, neither ≈øpeake vn≈øpeered at: and yet conferring with it when yee are at quiet, yee ≈øhall ≈øay with Scipio, that yee are nunquam min√ªs ≈øolus, qu√†m cum ≈øolus. To conclude then, J charge you, as euer yee thinke to de≈øerue my Fatherly ble≈øsing, to follow and put in practi≈øe, as farre as lyeth in you, the praecepts hereafter following. And if yee follow the contrary cour≈øe, I take the Great GOD to record, that this Booke ≈øhall one day bee a witne≈ø≈øe betwixt mee and you; and ≈øhall procure to bee ratified in Heauen, the cur≈øe that in that ca≈øe here I giue vnto you. For I protest before that Great GOD, I had rather not bee a Father, and childle≈ø≈øe, then bee a Father of wicked children. But hoping, yea, euen promi≈øing vnto my ≈øelfe, that GOD, who in his great ble≈øsing ≈øent you vnto mee; ≈øhall in the
≈øame ble≈øsing, as hee hath giuen mee a Sonne; ≈øo make him a good and a godly Sonne; not repenting him of his Mercie ≈øhewed vnto mee, I end, with my earnest prayer to GOD, to worke effectually into you, the fruites of that ble≈øsing, which here from my heart I be≈øtow vpon you.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: CHaritable Reader, it is one of the golden Sentences, which Chri≈øt our Sauiour vttered to his Apostles, that there is nothing ≈øo couered, Luk. 12. that ≈øhal not be reuealed, neither ≈øo hidde, that ≈øhall not be knowen: and what≈øoeuer they haue ≈øpoken in darkene≈ø≈øe, ≈øhould be heard in the light: and that which they had ≈øpoken in the eare in ≈øecret place, ≈øhould be publikely preached on the tops of the hou≈øes: And ≈øince he hath ≈øaid it, most trew mu≈øt it be, fince the authour thereof is the fountaine and very being of trewth: which ≈øhould mooue all godly and honest men, to be very warie in all their ≈øecrete≈øt actions, and what≈øoeuer midde≈ø≈øes they v≈øe for attaining to their mo≈øt wi≈øhed ends; le≈øt otherwi≈øe how auowable ≈øoeuer the marke be, whereat they aime, the midde≈ø≈øes being di≈øcouered to be ≈øhamefull whereby they climbe, it may turne to the di≈øgrace both of the good worke it ≈øelfe, and of the authour thereof; ≈øince the deepe≈øt of our ≈øecrets, cannot be hidde from that all-≈øeeing eye and penetrant light, piercing through the bowels of very darkene≈øse it ≈øelfe.

But as this is generally trew in the actions of all men, ≈øo is it more ≈øpecially trew in the affaires of Kings: for Kings being publike per≈øons, by rea≈øon of their office and authority, are as it were ≈øet (as it was ≈øaid of old) vpon a publike ≈øtage, in the ≈øight of all the people; where all the beholders eyes are attentiuely bent to looke and pry in the least circum≈øtance of their ≈øecretest drifts: Which ≈øhould make Kings the more carefull not to harbour the ≈øecrete≈øt thought in their minde, but ≈øuch as in the owne time they ≈øhall not be a≈øhamed openly to auouch; a≈ø≈øuring them≈øelues that Time the mother of Veritie, will in the due ≈øea≈øon bring her owne daughter to perfection.

The trew practi≈øe hereof, I haue as a King oft found in my owne per≈øon, though I thanke God, neuer to my ≈øhame, hauing laide my count, euer to walke as in the eyes of the Almightie, examining euer ≈øo the ≈øecretest of my drifts, before I gaue them cour≈øe, as how they might ≈øome day bide the touchstone of a publike triall. And amongst there≈øt of my ≈øecret actions, which haue (vnlooked for of me) come to publike knowledge, it hath ≈øo fared with my „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , directed to my elde≈øt ≈øon; which I wrote for exerci≈øe of mine owne ingyne, and instruction of him, who is appointed by God (I hope) to ≈øit on my Throne after me: For the purpo≈øe and matter thereof being onely fit for a King, as teaching him his office; and the per≈øon whomfor it was ordained, a Kings heire, who≈øe ≈øecret coun≈øellor and faithfull admoni≈øher it must be, I thought it no wayes conuenient nor comely, that either it ≈øhould to all be
proclaimed, which to one onely appertained (and specially being a me≈ø≈øenger betwixt two ≈øo coniunct per≈øons) or yet that the mould whereupon he ≈øhould frame his future behauiour, when hee comes both vnto the perfection of his yeeres, and po≈øse≈øsion of his inheritance, ≈øhould before the hand be made common to the people, the ≈øubiect of his future happy gouernment. And therefore for the more ≈øecret and clo≈øe keeping of them, I onely permitted ≈øeuen of them to be printed, the Printer being fir≈øt ≈øworne for ≈øecrecie: and the≈øe ≈øeuen I disper≈øed amongst ≈øome of my trustie≈øt ≈øeruants, to be keeped clo≈øely by them, le≈øt in ca≈øe by the iniquitie or wearing of time, any of them might haue beene lo≈øt, yet ≈øome of them might haue remained after me, as witne≈øses to my Sonne, both of the hone≈øt integritie of my heart, and of my fatherly affection and naturall care towards him. But ≈øince contrary to my intention and expectation, as I haue alreadie ≈øaid, this Booke is now vented, and ≈øet foorth to the publike view of the world, and con≈øequently ≈øubiect to euery mans cen≈øure, as the current of his affection leades him, I am now forced, as well for re≈øisting to the malice of the children of enuie, who like wa≈øpes ≈øucke venome out of euery whol≈øome herbe; as for the ≈øatisfaction of the godly hone≈øt ≈øort, in any thing that they may mistake therein, both to publi≈øh and ≈øpread the true copies thereof, for defacing of the fal≈øe copies that are alreadie ≈øpread, as I am enformed; as likewi≈øe by this Preface, to cleare ≈øuch parts thereof, as in re≈øpect of the conci≈øed ≈øhortne≈øse of my Style, may be mi≈ø-interpreted therein.

To come then particularly to the matter of my Booke, there are two ≈øpeciall great points, which (as I am informed) the malicious ≈øort of men haue detracted therein; and ≈øome of the honest ≈øort haue ≈øeemed a little to mistake: whereof the first and greatest is, that ≈øome ≈øentences therein ≈øhould ≈øeeme to furni≈øh grounds to men, to doubt of my ≈øinceritie in that Religion, which I haue euer constantly profe≈ø≈øed: the other is, that in ≈øome parts thereof I ≈øhould ≈øeeme to nouri≈øh in my minde, a vindictiue re≈øolution again≈øt England, or at the lea≈øt, ≈øome principals there, for the Queene my mothers quarrell.

The first calumnie (mo≈øt grieuous indeed) is grounded vpon the ≈øharpe and bitter wordes, that therein are v≈øed in the de≈øcription of the humors of Puritanes, and ra≈øh-headie Preachers, that thinke it their honour to contend with Kings, and perturbe whole kingdomes. The other point is onely grounded vpon the ≈øtrait charge. I giue my Sonne, not to heare nor ≈øuffer any vnreuerent ≈øpeeches or bookes against any of his parents or progenitors: wherein I doe alledge my owne experience anent the Queene my mother; affirming, that I neuer found any that were of perfit aage the time of her reigne here, ≈øo ≈øtedfa≈øtly trew to me in all my troubles, as the≈øe that con≈øtantly kept their allegiance to her in her time. But if the charitable Reader will adui≈øedly con≈øider, both the methode and matter of my Treati≈øe, he will ea≈øily iudge, what wrong I haue ≈øu≈øtained by the carping at both: For my Booke, ≈øuppo≈øe very ≈ømall, being diuided in three ≈øeuerall parts; the first part thereof onely treats of a Kings duety towards God in Religion, wherein I haue ≈øo clearely made profe≈øsion of my Religion, calling it the Religion wherein I was brought vp, and euer made profe≈øsion of, and wi≈øhing him euer to continue in the ≈øame, as the onely trew forme of Gods wor≈øhip; that I would haue thought my ≈øincere plainne≈ø≈øe in that fir≈øt part vpon that ≈øubiect, ≈øhould haue ditted the mouth of the mo≈øt enuious Momus, that euer
hell did hatch, from barking at any other part of my booke vpon that ground, except they would alledge me to be contrarie to my ≈øelfe, which in ≈øo ≈ømall a volume would ≈ømell of too great weakene≈ø≈øe, and ≈øliprine≈ø≈øe of memory. And the ≈øecond part of my booke, teaches my Sonne how to v≈øe his Office, in the admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice and Politicke Gouernment: The third onely containing a Kings outward behauiour in indifferent things; what agreeance and conformitie hee ought to keepe betwixt his outward behauiour in the≈øe things, and the vertuous qualities of his minde; and how they ≈øhould ≈øerue for trun≈øh-men, to interprete the inward dispo≈øition of the minde, to the eyes of them that cannot ≈øee farther within him, and therefore mu≈øt onely iudge of him by the outward appearance: So as if there were no more to be looked into, but the very methode and order of the booke, it will ≈øufficiently cleare me of that fir≈øt and grieuou≈øe≈øt imputation, in the point of Religion: ≈øince in the fir≈øt part, where Religion is onely treated of, I ≈øpeake ≈øo plainely. And what in other parts I ≈øpeake of Puritanes, it is onely of their morall faults, in that part where I ≈øpeake of Policie: declaring when they contemne the Law and ≈øouereigne authoritie, what exemplare puni≈øhment they de≈øerue for the ≈øame. And now as to the matter it ≈øelfe whereupon this ≈øcandall is taken, that I may ≈øufficiently ≈øatisfie all honest men, and by a iu≈øt Apologie rai≈øe vp a bra≈øen wall or bulwarke again≈øt all the darts of the enuious, I will the more narrowly rip vp the words, whereat they ≈øeeme to be ≈øomewhat ≈øtomacked.

Fir≈øt then, as to the name of Puritanes, I am not ignorant that the style thereof doeth properly belong onely to that vile ≈øect amongst the Anabapti≈øts, called the Family of loue; becau≈øe they thinke them≈øelues onely pure, and in a maner without ≈øinne, the onely trwe Church, and onely worthy to be participant of the Sacraments, and all the re≈øt of the world to be but abomination in the ≈øight of God. Of this ≈øpeciall ≈øect I principally meane, when I ≈øpeake of Puritans; diuers of them, as Browne, Penry and others, hauing at ≈øundrie times come into Scotland, to ≈øow their popple amongst vs (and from my heart I wi≈øh, that they had left no ≈øchollers behinde them, who by their fruits will in the owne time be manifested) and partly indeede, I giue this ≈øtyle to ≈øuch brain-≈øicke and headie Preachers their di≈øciples and followers, as refu≈øing to be called of that ≈øect, yet participate too much with their humours, in maintaining the aboue mentioned errours; not onely agreeing with the generall rule of all Anabapti≈øts, in the contempt of the ciuill Magi≈øtrate, and in leaning to their owne dreams and reuelations; but particularly with this ≈øect, in accounting all men profane that ≈øweare not to all their fanta≈øies, in making for euery particular que≈øtion of the policie of the Church, as great commotion, as if the article of the Trinitie were called in controuer≈øie, in making the ≈øcriptures to be ruled by their con≈øcience, and not their con≈øcience by the Scripture; and he that denies the lea≈øt iote of their grounds, ≈øit tibi tanquam ethnicus & publicanus; not worthy to enioy the benefite of breathing, much le≈ø≈øe to participate with them of the Sacraments: and before that any of their grounds be impugned, let King, people, Law and all be trode vnder foote: Such holy warres are to be preferred to an vngodly peace: no, in ≈øuch ca≈øes Chri≈øtian Princes are not onely to be re≈øi≈øted vnto, but not to be prayed for, for prayer must come of Faith; and it is reuealed to their con≈øciences, that GOD will heare no prayer for ≈øuch a Prince. Iudge then, Chri≈øtian Reader, if I wrong this ≈øort of people, in giuing them the ≈øtile of that ≈øect, who≈øe errours they imitate: and ≈øince they are contented
to weare their liuerie let them not be a≈øhamed to borrow al≈øo their name. It is onely of this kinde of men, that in this booke I write ≈øo ≈øharply; and whom I wi≈øh my Sonne to puni≈øh, in-ca≈øe they refu≈øe to obey the Law, and will not cea≈øe to ≈øturre vp a rebellion: Whom against I haue written the more bitterly, in respect of diuers famous libels, and iniurious ≈øpeaches ≈øpred by ≈øome of them, not onely di≈øhonourably inuectiue against all Christian Princes, but euen reprochfull to our profe≈øsion and Religion, in respect they are come out vnder coulour thereof: and yet were neuer an≈øwered but by Papists, who generally medle a≈øwell against them, as the religion it ≈øelfe; whereby the skandale was rather doubled, then taken away. But on the other part, I protest vpon mine honour, I meane it not generally of all Preachers, or others, that like better of the ≈øingle forme of policie in our Church, then of the many Ceremonies in the Church of England: that are per≈øwaded, that their Bi≈øhops ≈ømell of a Papall ≈øupremacie, that the Surpli≈øe, the cornerd cap, and ≈øuch like, are the outward badges of Popi≈øh errours. No, I am ≈øo farre from being contentious in the≈øe things (which for my owne part I euer esteemed as indifferent) as I doe equally loue and honour the learned and graue men of either of the≈øe opinions. It can no wayes become me to pronounce ≈øo lightly a ≈øentence, in ≈øo old a controuer≈øie. Wee all (God be prai≈øed) doe agree in the grounds; and the bitterne≈øse of men vpon ≈øuch questions, doeth but trouble the peace of the Church; and giues aduantage and entry to the Papists by our diui≈øion: But towards them, I onely v≈øe this proui≈øion, that where the Law is otherwayes, they may content them≈øelues ≈øoberly and quietly with their owne opinions, not re≈øisting to the authoritie, nor breaking the Law of the Countrey; neither aboue all, ≈øturring any rebellion or ≈øchi≈øme: but po≈ø≈øe≈øsing their ≈øoules in peace, let them prea≈ø≈øe by patience, and well grounded rea≈øons, either to per≈øwade all the rest to like of their iudgements; or where they ≈øee better grounds on the other part, not to bee a≈øhamed peaceably to incline thereunto, laying a≈øide all praeoccupied opinions.

And that this is the onely meaning of my Booke, and not any coldne≈ø≈øe or cracke in Religion, that place doeth plainely witne≈ø≈øe, where, after I haue ≈øpoken of the faults in our Eccle≈øiasticall e≈øtate I exhort my ≈øonne to be beneficiall vnto the good-men of the Mini≈øtrie; prai≈øing God there, that there is pre≈øently a ≈øufficient number of good men of them in this kingdome: and yet are they all knowne to be again≈øt the forme of the Engli≈øh Church. Yea, ≈øo farre I am in that place from admitting corruption in Religion, as I wi≈øh him in promoouing them, to v≈øe ≈øuch caution, as may pre≈øerue their e≈øtate from creeping to corruption; euer v≈øing that forme through the whole Booke, where euer I ≈øpeake of bad Preachers, terming them ≈øome of the Mini≈øters, and not Mini≈øters or Mini≈øtrie in generall. And to conclude this point of Religion, what indifferencie of Religion can Momus call that in mee, where, ≈øpeaking of my ≈øonnes marriage (in ca≈øe it plea≈øed God before that time to cut the threed of my life) I plainly forewarne him of the inconuenients that were like to en≈øew, inca≈øe he ≈øhould marry any that be of a different profe≈øsion in Religion from him: notwithstanding that the number of Princes profe≈øsing our Religion be ≈øo ≈ømall, as it is hard to fore≈øee, how he can be that way, meetly matched according to his ranke.

And as for the other point, that by ≈øome parts in this booke, it ≈øhould appeare, that I doe nouri≈øh in my minde, a vindictiue re≈øolution again≈øt England, or ≈øome principals there; it is ≈øurely more then wonderfull vnto me, vpon what grounds they can
haue gathered ≈øuch conclu≈øions. For as vpon the one part, Ineither by name nor de≈øcription poynt out England in that part of my di≈øcour≈øe; ≈øo vpon the other, I plainly bewray my meaning to be of Scotti≈øh-men, where I conclude that purpo≈øe in the≈øe termes: That the loue I beare to my Sonne, hath mooued me to be ≈øo plaine in this argument: for ≈øo that I di≈øcharge my con≈øcience to him in vttering the verity, I care not what any traitour or trea≈øon-allower doe thinke of it. And Engli≈øh-men could not thereby be meant, ≈øince they could be no traitours, where they ought no alleageance. I am not ignorant of a wi≈øe and princely apophthegme, which the ≈øame Queene of England vttered about the time of her owne Coronation. But the drift of that di≈øcour≈øe doth fully cleare my intention, being onely grounded vpon that precept to my Sonne, that he ≈øhould not permit any vnreuerent detracting of his praedece≈ø≈øours; bringing in that purpo≈øe of my mother onely for an example of my experience anent Scotti≈øhmen, without v≈øing any per≈øwa≈øion to him of reuenge. For a Kings giuing of any fault the dew ≈øtile, inferres no reduction of the faulters pardon. No, I am by a degree nearer of kinne vnto my mother then he is, neither thinke I my ≈øelfe, either that vnworthie, or that neere my end, that I neede to make ≈øuch a Dauidicall te≈øtament; ≈øince I haue euer thought it the dewtie of a worthie Prince, rather with a pike, then a penne, to write his iu≈øt reuenge: But in this matter I haue no delite to be large, wi≈øhing all men to iudge of my future proiects, according to my by-pa≈øt actions.

Thus hauing as much in≈øi≈øted in the clearing of the≈øe two points, as will (I hope) giue ≈øufficient ≈øatisfaction to all hone≈øt men, and leauing the enuious to the foode of their owne venome; I will heartily pray thee, louing Reader, charitably to conceiue of my hone≈øt intention in this Booke. I know the greatest part of the people of this whole I≈øle, haue beene very curious for a ≈øight thereof: ≈øome for the loue they beare me, either being particularly acquainted with me, or by a good report that perhappes they haue heard of me; and therefore longed to ≈øee any thing, that proceeded from that authour whom they ≈øo loued and honoured; ≈øince bookes are viue Idees of the authours minde. Some onely for meere curio≈øitie, that thinke it their honour to know all new things, were curious to glut their eyes therewith, onely that they might vaunt them to haue ≈øeene it: and ≈øome fraughted with cau≈øle≈ø≈øe enuie at the Authour, did greedily ≈øearch out the booke, thinking their ≈øtomacke jit ynough, for turning neuer ≈øo whole≈øome foode into noy≈øome and infectiue bumours: So as this their great concurrence in curiofitie (though proceeding from farre different complexions) hath enforced the vn-timous divulgating of this Booke, farre contrarie to my intention, as I haue alreadie ≈øaid. To which Hydra of diuer≈øly-enclined ≈øpectatours, I haue no targe to oppone but plainene≈ø≈øe, patience, and ≈øinceritie: plainene≈ø≈øe, for re≈øoluing and ≈øatisfying of the first ≈øort; patience, for to beare with the ≈øhallowne≈ø≈øe of the next; and ≈øinceritie, to defie the malice of the third with-all. Though I cannot plea≈øe all men therein, I am contented, ≈øo that Ionely plea≈øe the vertuous ≈øort: and though they al≈øo finde not euery thing therein, ≈øo fully to an≈øwere their expectation, as the argument would ≈øeeme to require; although I would wi≈øh them mode≈øtly to remember, that God hes not be≈øtowed all his gifts vpon one, but parted them by a iu≈øtice distributiue; and that many eyes ≈øee more then one; and that the varietie of mens mindes is ≈øuch, that tot capita tot≈øen≈øus; yea, and that euen the very faces, that God hath by nature brought foorth in the world, doe euery one in ≈øome of their particular lineaments, differ from
any other: yet in trewth it was not my intention in handling of this purpo≈øe (as it is ea≈øie to perceiue) fully to ≈øet downe heere all ≈øuch grounds, as might out of the be≈øt writers haue beene alledged, and out of my owne inuention and experience added, for the perfite in≈øtitution of a King: but onely to giue ≈øome ≈øuch precepts to my owne Sonne, for the gouernement of this kingdome, as was meetest for him to be instructed in, and be≈øt became me to be the informer of.

If I in this Booke haue beene too particularly plaine, impute it to the nece≈øsitie of the ≈øubiect, not ≈øo much being ordained for the in≈øtitution of a Prince in generall, as I haue ≈øaid, as containing particular precepts to my Sonne in ≈øpeciall: whereof he could haue made but a generall v≈øe, if they had not contained the particular di≈øea≈øes of this kingdome, with the be≈øt remedies for the ≈øame, which it became me best as a King, hauing learned both the theoricke and practicke thereof, more plainely to expre≈ø≈øe, then any ≈øimple ≈øchoole man, that onely knowes matters of kingdomes by contemplation.

But if in ≈øome places it ≈øeeme too ob≈øcure, impute it to the ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe thereof, being both for the re≈øpect of my ≈øelfe, and of my Sonne, con≈øtrained there-unto: my owne re≈øpect, for fault of lea≈øure, being ≈øo continually occupied in the affaires of my office, as my great burthen, and re≈øtle≈ø≈øe fa≈øhery is more then knowen, to all that knowes or beares of me: for my Sonnes re≈øpect, becau≈øe I know by my ≈øelf, that a Prince ≈øo long as he is young, wil be ≈øo caried away with ≈øome ≈øort of delight or other, that he cannot patiently abide the reading of any large volume: and when he comes to a ful maturity of aage, he mu≈øt be ≈øo bu≈øied in the actiue part of his charge, as he will not be permitted to be≈øtow many houres vpon the coÃÑtemplatiue part therof: So as it was neither fit for him, nor po≈øsible for me, to haue made this Treati≈øe any more ample then it is. Indeed I am litle beholden to the curio≈øitie of ≈øome, who thinking it too large alreadie (as appears) for lacke of lei≈øure to copy it, drew ≈øome notes out of it, for ≈øpeeds ≈øake; putting in the one halfe of the purpo≈øe, and leauing out the other: not vnlike the man that alledged that part of the P≈øalme, non e≈øt Deus, but left out the praeceeding words, Dixit in≈øipiens in corde ≈øuo. And of the≈øe notes, making a little pamphlet (lacking both my methode and halfe of my matter) entituled it, for≈øooth, the Kings Te≈øtament, as if I had eiked a third Te≈øtament of my owne to the two that are in the holy Scriptures. It is trew that in a place thereof, for affirmation of the purpo≈øe I am ≈øpeaking of to my Sonne, I bring my ≈øelfe in there, as ≈øpeaking vpon my Te≈øtament: for in that ≈øen≈øe, euery record in write of a mans opinion in anything (in respect that papers out-liue their authours) is as it were a Te≈øtament of that mans will in that ca≈øe: and in that ≈øen≈øe it is, that in that place I call this Treati≈øe a Testament. But from any particular ≈øentence in a booke, to giue the booke it ≈øelfe a title, is as ridiculous, as to ≈øtyle the booke of the P≈øalmes, the booke of Dixit in≈øipiens, becau≈øe with the≈øe wordes one of them doeth begin.

Well, leauing the≈øe new baptizers and blockers of other mens books, to their owne follies, Ireturne to my purpo≈øe, anent the ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of this booke, ≈øu≈øpecting that all my excu≈øes for the ≈øhortne≈øse thereof, ≈øhall not ≈øatisfie ≈øome, e≈øpecially in our neighbour countrey: who thought, that as I haue ≈øo narrowly in this Treati≈øe touched all the principall ≈øickne≈øses in our kingdome, with ouertures for the remedies thereof, as I ≈øaid before: ≈øo looked they to haue found ≈øomething therein, that ≈øhould haue touched the ≈øickne≈øses of their ≈øtate, in the like ≈øort. But they will ea≈øily excu≈øe me thereof, if they
will con≈øider the forme I haue v≈øed in this Treati≈øe; wherein I onely teach my Son, out of my owne experience, what forme of gouernment is fittest for this kingdome: and in one part thereof ≈øpeaking of the borders, I plainely there doe excu≈øe my ≈øelfe, that I will ≈øpeake nothing of the ≈øtate of England, as a matter wherein I neuer had experience. I know indeed, no kingdome lackes her owne di≈øea≈øes, and likewi≈øe what interest I haue in the pro≈øperitie of that ≈øtate: for although I would be ≈øilent, my blood and di≈øcent doeth ≈øufficiently proclaime it. But notwith≈øtanding, ≈øince there is a lawfull Queene there pre≈øently reigning, who hath ≈øo long with ≈øo great wi≈øedome and felicitie gouerned her kingdomes, as (I mu≈øt in trew ≈øinceritie confe≈ø≈øe) the like hath not beene read nor heard of, either in our time, or ≈øince the dayes of the Romane Emperour Augu≈øtus; it could no wayes become me, farre inferiour to her in knowledge and experience, to be a bu≈øie-body in other princes matters, and to fi≈øh in other folkes waters, as the prouerbe is: No, I hope by the contrary (with Gods grace) euer to keepe that Christian rule, To doe as I would be done to: and I doubt nothing, yea euen in her name I dare promi≈øe, by the bypast experience of her happy gouernment, as I haue already ≈øaid, that no good ≈øubiect ≈øhall be more carefull to enforme her of any corruptions ≈øtollen in in her ≈øtate, then ≈øhee ≈øhall be zealous for the di≈øcharge of her con≈øcience and honour, to ≈øee the ≈øame purged, and restored to the ancient integritie; and further during her time, becomes me least of any to meddle in.

And thus hauing re≈øolued all the doubts, ≈øo farre as I can imagine, may be moued against this Treati≈øe; it onely re≈øts to pray thee (charitable Reader) to interprete fauourably this birth of mine, according to the integritie of the author, and not looking for perfection in the worke it ≈øelfe. As for my part, I onely glory thereof in this point, that I trust no ≈øort of vertue is condemned, nor any degree of vice allowed in it: and that (though it be not perhaps ≈øo gorgeou≈øly decked, and richly attired as it ought to be) it is at the least rightly proportioned in all the members, without any menstrous deformitie in any of them: and ≈øpecially that ≈øince it was fir≈øt written in ≈øecret, and is now publi≈øhed, not of ambition, but of a kinde of nece≈øsitie; it must be taken of all men, for the trew image of my very minde, and forme of the rule, which I haue pre≈øcribed to my ≈øelfe and mine; Which as in all my actions I haue bitherto prea≈ø≈øed to expre≈ø≈øe, ≈øo farre as the nature of my charge, and the condition of time would permit me: ≈øo beareth it a di≈øcouery of that which may be looked for at my hand, and whereto euen in my ≈øecret thoughts, I haue engaged my ≈øelfe for the time to come. And thus in a firme tru≈øt, that it ≈øhall plea≈øe God, who with my being and Crowne, gaue me this minde, to maintaine and augment the ≈øame in me and my po≈øteritie, to the di≈øcharge of our con≈øcience, the maintenance of our Honour, and weale of our people, I bid thee heartily farewell.

div.head: OF A KINGS CHRISTIAN DVETIE TO WARDS GOD.
THE FIRST BOOKE.
div.p:
AS he cannot be thought worthy to rule and command others, that cannot rule and dantone his owne proper affections and vnrea≈øonable appetites, ≈øo can hee not be thought worthie to gouerne a Chri≈øtian people, The trew ground of good gouernment. knowing and fearing God, that in his owne per≈øon and heart, feareth not and loueth not the Diuine Maie≈øtie. Neither can any thing in his gouernment ≈øucceed well with him, (deui≈øe and labour as he li≈øt) as comming from a filthie ≈øpring, if his per≈øon be vn≈øanctified: for (as that royal Prophet ≈øaith) Except the Lord build the hou≈øe, P≈øal. 127 1. they labour in vaine that build it: except the Lord keepe the City, the keepers watch it in vaine: in re≈øpect the ble≈ø≈øing of God hath onely power to giue the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe thereunto: and as Paul ≈øaith, he planteth, 1. Cor. 3.6. Apollos watereth; but it is God onely that giueth the increa≈øe. Therefore (my Sonne) fir≈øt of all things, learne to know and loue that God, whom-to ye haue a double obligation; Double bond of a Prince to God. fir≈øt, for that he made you a man; and next, for that he made you a little GOD to ≈øit on his Throne, and rule ouer other men. Remember, that as in dignitie hee hath erected you aboue others, ≈øo ought ye in thankfulne≈ø≈øe towards him, goe as farre beyond all others. A moate in anothers eye, is a beame into yours: a blemi≈øh in another, is a leprou≈øe byle into you: and a veniall ≈øinne (as the Papi≈øts call it) in another, is a great crime into you. Thinke not therefore, that the highne≈ø≈øe of your dignitie, The greatne≈ø≈øe of the fault of a Prince. dimmi≈øheth your faults (much le≈ø≈øe giueth you a licence to ≈øinne) but by the contrary your fault ≈øhall be aggrauated, according to the height of your dignitie; any ≈øinne that ye commit, not being a ≈øingle ≈øinne procuring but the fall of one; but being an exemplare
≈øinne, and therefore drawing with it the whole multitude to be guiltie of the ≈øame. Remember then, that this gli≈øtering worldly glorie of Kings, The trew glorie of Kings. is giuen them by God, to teach them to prea≈ø≈øe ≈øo to gli≈øter and ≈øhine before their people, in all workes of ≈øanctification and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, that their per≈øons as bright lampes of godline≈ø≈øe and vertue, may, going in and out before their people, giue light to all their ≈øteps. Remember al≈øo, that by the right knowledge, and feare of God (which is the beginning of Wi≈øedome, Prou 9.10. as Salomon ≈øaith) ye ≈øhall know all the things nece≈ø≈øarie for the di≈øcharge of your duetie, both as a Chri≈øtian, and as a King; ≈øeeing in him, as in a mirrour, the cour≈øe of all earthly things, whereof hee is the ≈øpring and onely moouer.

Now, the onely way to bring you to this knowledge, The meanes to know God. is diligently to reade his word, and earne≈øtly to pray for the right vnder≈øtanding thereof. Search the Scriptures, ≈øayth Chri≈øt, for they beare te≈øtimonie of me: and, Iohn 5.39. the whole Scripture, ≈øaith Paul, is giuen by in≈øpiration of God, and is profitable to teach, 2. Tim. 3.16.17. to conuince, to correct, and to instruct in righteou≈øne≈øse; that the man of God may be ab≈øolute, being made perfite vnto all good workes. And mo≈øt properly of any other, belongeth the reading thereof vnto Kings, Deut. 17. ≈øince in that part of Scripture, where the godly Kings are fir≈øt made mention of, that were ordained to rule ouer the people of God, there is an expre≈ø≈øe and mo≈øt notable exhortation and commandement giuen them, to reade and meditate in the Law of God. I ioyne to this, the carefull hearing of the doctrine with attendance and reuerence: for, faith commeth by hearing, Rom. 10.17. ≈øayth the ≈øame Apo≈øtle. But aboue all, beware ye wre≈øt not the word to your owne appetite, as ouer many doe, making it like a bell to ≈øound as ye plea≈øe to interprete: but by the contrary, frame all your affections, to follow preci≈øely the rule there ≈øet downe.

The whole Scripture chiefly containeth two things: a command, Wherein chiefely the whole Scripture con≈øi≈øteth. and a prohibition, to doe ≈øuch things, and to ab≈øtaine from the contrary. Obey in both; neither thinke it enough to ab≈øtaine from euill, and do no good; nor thinke not that if yee doe many good things, it may ≈øerue you for a cloake to mixe euill turnes therewith. And as in the≈øe two points, the whole Scripture principally con≈øi≈øteth, Two degrees of the ≈øeruice of God. ≈øo in two degrees ≈øtandeth the whole ≈øeruice of God by man: interiour, or vpward; exteriour, or downward: the fir≈øt, by prayer in faith towards God; the next, by workes flowing therefra before the world: which is nothing el≈øe, but the exerci≈øe of Religion towards God, and of equitie towards your neighbour.

As for the particular points of Religion, I need not to dilate them; I am no hypocrite, follow my foot≈øteps, A regardable paterne. and your owne pre≈øent education therein. I thanke God, I was neuer a≈øhamed to giue account of my profe≈ø≈øion, how≈øoeuer the malicious lying tongues of ≈øome haue traduced me: and if my con≈øcience had not re≈øolued me, that all my Religion pre≈øently profe≈ø≈øed by me and my kingdome, was grounded vpon the plaine wordes of the Scripture, without the which all points of Religion are
≈øuperfluous, as any thing contrary to the ≈øame is abomination, I had neuer outwardly auowed it, for plea≈øure or awe of any fle≈øh.
And as for the points of equitie towards your neigbour (becau≈øe that will fall in properly, vpon the ≈øecond part concerning a Kings office) I leaue it to the owne roume.

For the fir≈øt part then of mans ≈øeruice to his God, Religion. which is Religion, that is, the wor≈øhip of God according to his reuealed will, it is wholly grounded vpon the Scripture, as I haue alreadie ≈øaid, quickened by faith, and con≈øerued by con≈øcience: For the Scripture, I haue now ≈øpoken of it in generall, but that yee may the more readily make choice of any part thereof, for your in≈øtruction or comfort, remember ≈øhortly this methode.

The whole Scripture is dyted by Gods Spirit, The methode of Scripture. thereby, as by his liuely word, to in≈øtruct and rule the whole Church militant to the end of the word: It is compo≈øed of two parts, the Olde and New Te≈øtament: The ground of the former is the Lawe, which ≈øheweth our ≈øinne, and containeth iu≈øtice: the ground of the other is Chri≈øt, who pardoning ≈øinne containeth grace. The ≈øumme of the Law is the tenne Commandements, more largely delated in the bookes of Mo≈øes, Of the Law. interpreted and applied by the Prophets; and by the hi≈øtories, are the examples ≈øhewed of obedience or di≈øobedience thereto, and what praemium or poena was accordingly giuen by God: But becau≈øe no man was able to keepe the Law, nor any part thereof, it plea≈øed God of his infinite wi≈øedome and goodne≈ø≈øe, to incarnate his only Sonne in our nature, for ≈øatisfaction of his iu≈øtice in his ≈øuffering for vs; that ≈øince we could not be ≈øaued by doing, we might at lea≈øt, bee ≈øaued by beleeuing.

The ground therefore of the word of grace, Of Grace. is contained in the foure hi≈øtories of the birth, life, death, re≈øurrection and a≈øcention of Chri≈øt: The larger interpretation and v≈øe thereof, is contained in the Epi≈øtles of the Apo≈øtles: and the practi≈øe in the faithfull or vnfaithfull, with the hi≈øtorie of the infancie and fir≈øt progre≈ø≈øe of the Church is contained in their Actes.

Would ye then know your ≈øinne by the Lawe? V≈øe of the Law. reade the bookes of Mo≈øes containing it. Would ye haue a commentarie thereupon? Reade the Prophets, and likewi≈øe the bookes of the Prouerbes and Eccle≈øiastes, written by that great patterne of wi≈øedome Salomon; which will not only ≈øerue you for in≈øtruction, how to walke in the obedience of the Lawe of God, but is al≈øo ≈øo full of golden ≈øentences, and morall precepts, in all things that can concerne your conuer≈øation in the world, as among all the prophane Philo≈øophers and Poets, ye ≈øhall not finde ≈øo rich a ≈øtorehou≈øe of precepts of naturall wi≈øedome, agreeing with the will and diuine wi≈øedome of God. Would ye ≈øee how good men are rewarded, and wicked puni≈øhed? looke the hi≈øtoricall parts of the≈øe ≈øame bookes of Mo≈øes, together with the hi≈øtories of Io≈øhua, the Iudges, Ezra, Nehemiah, E≈øther, and Iob: but e≈øpecially the bookes of the Kings and Chronicles, wherewith ye ought to bee familiarly
acquainted: for there ≈øhall yee ≈øee your ≈øelfe, as in a myrrour, in the catalogue either of the good or the euill Kings.

Would yee know the doctrine, life, and death of our Sauiour Chri≈øt? V≈øe of the Go≈øpel. reade the Euangeli≈øts. Would ye bee more particularly trained vp in his Schoole? meditate vpon the Epi≈øtles of the Apo≈øtles. And would ye be acquainted with the practi≈øes of that doctrine in the per≈øons of the primitiue Church? Ca≈øt vp the Apo≈øtles Actes. And as to the Apocryphe bookes, I omit them, becau≈øe I am no Papi≈øt, as I ≈øaid before; and indeed ≈øome of them are no wayes like the dytement of the Spirit of God.

But when ye reade the Scripture, How to reade the Scripture. reade it with a ≈øanctified and cha≈øte heart: admire reuerently ≈øuch ob≈øcure places as ye vnder≈øtand not, blaming onely your owne capacitie: read with delight the plaine places, and ≈øtudie carefully to vnder≈øtand tho≈øe that are ≈øomewhat difficile: prea≈ø≈øe to bee a good textuarie; for the Scripture is euer the be≈øt interpreter of it ≈øelfe; but prea≈ø≈øe not curiou≈øly to ≈øeeke out farther then is contained therein; for that were ouer vnmannerly a pre≈øumption, to ≈øtriue to bee further vpon Gods ≈øecrets, then he hath will ye be; for what hee thought needfull for vs to know, that hath he reuealed there: And delyte mo≈øt in reading ≈øuch parts of the Scripture, as may be≈øt ≈øerue for your in≈øtruction in your calling; reiecting fooli≈øh curio≈øities vpon genealogies and contentions, Tit. 3.9. which are but vaine, and profite not, as Paul ≈øaith.

Now, as to Faith, which is the nouri≈øher and quickner of Religion, Faith the nouri≈øher of Religion. as I haue alreadie ≈øaid, It is a ≈øure per≈øwa≈øion and apprehen≈øion of the promi≈øes of God, applying them to your ≈øoule: and therefore may it iu≈øtly be called, the golden chaine that linketh the faithfull ≈øoule to Chri≈øt: And becau≈øe it groweth not in our garden, but is the free gift of God, Philip. 1.29. as the ≈øame Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, it mu≈øt be nouri≈øhed by prayer, Which is nothing el≈øe, but a friendly talking with God.

As for teaching you the forme of your prayers, Prayer, and whence to learne the be≈øt forme thereof. the P≈øalmes of Dauid are the meete≈øt ≈øchoole-ma≈øter that ye can be acquainted with (next the prayer of our Sauiour, which is the onely rule of prayer) whereout of, as of mo≈øt rich and pure fountaines, ye may learne all forme of prayer nece≈ø≈øarie for your comfort at all occa≈øions: And ≈øo much the fitter are they for you, then for the common ≈øort, in re≈øpect the compo≈øer thereof was a King: and therefore be≈øt behoued to know a Kings wants, and what things were meete≈øt to be required by a King at Gods hand for remedie thereof.

V≈øe often to pray when ye are quiete≈øt, Seuerall exerci≈øe of prayer. e≈øpecially forget it not in your bed how oft ≈øoeuer ye doe it at other times: for publike prayer ≈øerueth as much for example, as for any particular comfort to the ≈øupplicant.

In your prayer, bee neither ouer ≈øtrange with God, What rule or regard to be v≈øed in prayer. like the ignorant common ≈øort, that prayeth nothing but out of bookes, nor yet ouer homely with him, like ≈øome of the vaine Phari≈øaicall puritanes, that thinke they rule him vpon their fingers: The former way will breede an vncouth coldne≈ø≈øe in you towards him, the other will breede in you a contempt of
him. But in your prayer to God ≈øpeake with all reuerence: for if a ≈øubiect will not ≈øpeake but reuerently to a King, much le≈ø≈øe ≈øhould any fle≈øh pre≈øume to talke with God as with his companion.

Craue in your prayer, not onely things ≈øpirituall, but al≈øo things temporall, What to craue of God. ≈øometimes of greater, and ≈øometimes of le≈ø≈øe con≈øequence; that yee may lay vp in ≈øtore his grant of the≈øe things, for confirmation of your faith, and to be an arles-peny vnto you of his loue. Pray, as yee finde your heart moueth you, pro re nata: but ≈øee that yee ≈øute no vnlawfull things, as reuenge, Rom. 14.23. lu≈øt, or ≈øuch like: for that prayer can not come of faith: and what≈øoeuer is done without faith, is ≈øinne, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith.

When ye obtaine your prayer, How to interpret the i≈ø≈øue of prayer. thanke him ioyfully therefore: if otherwaies, beare patiently, prea≈ø≈øing to winne him with importunitie, as the widow did the vnrighteous Iudge: and if notwith≈øtanding thereof yee be not heard, a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelfe, God fore≈øeeth that which yee aske is not for your weale: and learne in time, ≈øo to interprete all the aduer≈øities that God ≈øhall ≈øend vnto you; ≈øo ≈øhall yee in the midde≈øt of them, not onely be armed with patience, but ioyfully lift vp your eyes from the pre≈øent trouble, to the happie end that God will turne it to. And when ye finde it once ≈øo fall out by proofe, arme your ≈øelfe with the experience thereof again≈øt the next trouble, a≈ø≈øuring your ≈øelfe, though yee cannot in time of the ≈øhowre ≈øee through the cloude, yet in the end ≈øhall ye find, God ≈øent it for your weale, as ye found in the former.

And as for con≈øcience, Con≈øcience the con≈øeruer of Religion. which I called the con≈øeruer of Religion, It is nothing el≈øe, but the light of knowledge that God hath planted in man, which euer watching ouer all his actions, as it beareth him a ioyfull te≈øtimonie when he does right, ≈øo choppeth it him with a feeling that hee hath done wrong, when euer he committeth any ≈øinne. And ≈øurely, although this con≈øcience be a great torture to the wicked, yet is it as great a comfort to the godly, if we will con≈øider it rightly. For haue wee not a great aduantage, that haue within our ≈øelues while wee liue here, a Count-booke and Inuentarie of all the crimes that wee ≈øhall bee accu≈øed of, The inuentarie of our life. either at the houre of our death, or at the Great day of Iudgement; which when wee plea≈øe (yea though we forget) will chop, and remember vs to looke vpon it; that while we haue lea≈øure and are here, we may remember to amend; and ≈øo at the day of our triall, compeare with new and white garments wa≈øhed in the blood of the Lambe, Reu 7.14. as S. Iohn ≈øaith. Aboue all then, my Sonne, labour to keepe ≈øound this con≈øcience, which many prattle of, but ouer few feele: e≈øpecially be carefull to keepe it free from two di≈øea≈øes, wherewith it v≈øeth oft to be infected; The di≈øea≈øes of con≈øcience. to wit, Leapro≈øie, and Super≈øtition: the former is the mother of Athei≈øme, the other of Here≈øies. By a leaprou≈øe con≈øcience, I meane a cauterized con≈øcience, 1. Tim. 4.2. as Paul calleth it, being become ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe of ≈øinne, through ≈øleeping in a carele≈ø≈øe ≈øecuritie, as King Dauids was after his murther and adulterie, euer til he was wakened by the Prophet Nathans ≈øimilitude. And by ≈øuper≈øtition, I meane, when one re≈øtraines him≈øelfe to any
other rule in the ≈øeruice of God, then is warranted by the word, the onely trew ≈øquare of Gods ≈øerucie.

As for a pre≈øeruatiue again≈øt this Leapro≈øie, Pre≈øeruatiue again≈øt lepro≈øie of con≈øcience. remember euer once in the foure and twentie houres, either in the night, or when yee are at greate≈øt quiet, to call your ≈øelfe to account of all your la≈øt dayes actions, either wherein ye haue committed things yee ≈øhould not, or omitted the things ye ≈øhould doe, either in your Chri≈øtian or Kingly calling: and in that account, let not your ≈øelfe be ≈ømoothed ouer with that flattering „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which is ouerkindly a ≈øickne≈ø≈øe to all mankind: but cen≈øure your ≈øelfe as ≈øharply, as if ye were your owne enemie: For if ye iudge your ≈øelfe, ye ≈øhall not be iudged, 1. Cor. 11.31. as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith: and then according to your cen≈øure, reforme your actions as farre as yee may, e≈øchewing euer wilfully and wittingly to contrare your con≈øcience: For a ≈ømall ≈øinne wilfully committed, with a deliberate re≈øolution to breake the bridle of con≈øcience therein, is farre more grieuous before God, then a greater ≈øinne committed in a ≈øuddaine pa≈ø≈øion, when con≈øcience is a≈øleepe. La≈øt account. Remember therefore in all your actions, of the great account that yee are one day to make: in all the dayes of your life, euer learning to die, and liuing euery day as it were your la≈øt; Omnem crede diem tibi diluxi≈ø≈øe ≈øupremum. Horat. lib. 1. Epi≈øt.

And therefore, I would not haue you to pray with the Papi≈øts, to be pre≈øerued from ≈øuddaine death, but that God would giue you grace ≈øo to liue, as ye may euery houre of your life be ready for death: ≈øo ≈øhall ye attaine to the vertue of trew fortitude, neuer being afraid for the horrour of death, Trew fortitude. come when he li≈øt: And e≈øpecially, beware to offend your con≈øcience with v≈øe of ≈øwearing or lying, ≈øuppo≈øe but in ie≈øt; for others are but an v≈øe, Fooli≈øh v≈øe of oathes. and a ≈øinne cloathed with no delight nor gaine, and therefore the more inexcu≈øable euen in the ≈øight of men: and lying commeth al≈øo much of a vile v≈øe, which bani≈øheth ≈øhame: Therfore beware euen to deny the trewth, which is a ≈øort of lie, that may be≈øt be e≈øchewed by a per≈øon of your ranke. For if any thing be asked at you that yee thinke not meete to reueale, if yee ≈øay, that que≈øtion is not pertinent for them to aske, who dare examine you further? and v≈øing ≈øometimes this an≈øwere both in trew and fal≈øe things that ≈øhall be asked at you, ≈øuch vnmanerly people will neuer be the wi≈øer thereof.

And for keeping your con≈øcience ≈øound from that ≈øickene≈ø≈øe of ≈øuper≈øtition, Again≈øt ≈øuper≈øtition. yee mu≈øt neither lay the ≈øafetie of your con≈øcience vpon the credit of your owne conceits, nor yet of other mens humors, how great doctors of Diuinitie that euer they be; but yee mu≈øt onely ground it vpon the expre≈ø≈øe Scripture: for con≈øcience not grounded vpon ≈øure knowledge, is either an ignorant fanta≈øie, or an arrogant vanitie. Beware therefore in this ca≈øe with two extremities: the one, to beleeue with the Papi≈øts, the Churches authority, better then your owne knowledge; the other, to leane with the Anabapti≈øts, to your owne conceits and dreamed reuelations.

But learne wi≈øely to di≈øcerne betwixt points of ≈øaluation and indifferent
things, Difference of internall and externall things. betwixt ≈øub≈øtance and ceremonies; and betwixt the expre≈ø≈øe commandement and will of God in his word, and the inuention or ordinance of man; ≈øince all that is nece≈ø≈øarie for ≈øaluation is contained in the Scripture: For in any thing that is expre≈ø≈øely commanded or prohibited in the booke of God, ye cannot be ouer preci≈øe, euen in the lea≈øt thing; counting euery ≈øinne, not according to the light e≈øtimation and common v≈øe of it in the world, but as the booke of God counteth of it. But as for all other things not contained in the Scripture, ≈øpare not to v≈øe or alter them, as the nece≈ø≈øitie of the time ≈øhall require. Account of things externall. And when any of the ≈øpirituall officebearers in the Church, ≈øpeake vnto you any thing that is well warranted by the word, reuerence and obey them as the heraulds of the mo≈øt high God: but, if pa≈ø≈øing that bounds, they vrge you to embrace any of their fanta≈øies in the place of Gods word, or would colour their particulars with a pretended zeale, acknowledge them for no other then vaine men, exceeding the bounds of their calling; and according to your office, grauely and with authoritie redact them in order againe.

To conclude then, Conclu≈øion. both this purpo≈øe of con≈øcience, and the fir≈øt part of this booke, keepe God more ≈øparingly in your mouth, but abundantly in your heart: be preci≈øe in effect, but ≈øociall in ≈øhew: kythe more by your deedes then by your wordes, the loue of vertue and hatred of vice: and delight more to be godly and vertuous indeed, then to be thought and called ≈øo; expecting more for your prai≈øe and reward in heauen, then heere: and apply to all your outward actions Chri≈øts command, to pray and giue your almes ≈øecretly: So ≈øhal ye on the one part be inwardly garni≈øhed with trew Chri≈øtian humilitie, not outwardly (with the proud Phari≈øie) glorying in your godline≈ø≈øe; but ≈øaying, as Chri≈øt commandeth vs all, when we haue done all that we can, Luke 10.17. Inutiles ≈øerui ≈øumus: And on the other part, yee ≈øhall e≈øchew outwardly before the world, the ≈øu≈øpition of filthie proude hypocri≈øie, and deceitfull di≈ø≈øimulation.

div.head: OF A KINGS DVETIE IN HIS OFFICE.
THE SECOND BOOKE.
div.p:
BVT as ye are clothed with two callings, ≈øo mu≈øt ye be alike careful for the di≈øcharge of them both: that as yee are a good Chri≈øtian, ≈øo yee may be a good King, di≈øcharging your Office (as I ≈øhewed before) in the points of Iu≈øtice and Equitie: The Office of a King. which in two ≈øundrie waies ye mu≈øt doe: the one, in e≈øtabli≈øhing and executing, Plato in Polit. (which is the life of the Law) good Lawes among your people: I≈øocr, in Sym. the other, by your behauiour in your owne per≈øon, and with your ≈øeruants, to teach your people by your example: for people are naturally inclined to counterfaite (like apes) their Princes maners, Plate in Polis. according to the notable ≈øaying of Plato, expre≈ø≈øed by the Poet ‚Äî
‚Äî Componitur orbis
Regis ad exemplum, nec ≈øic inflectere ≈øen≈øus
Humanos edicta valent, qu√†m vitaregentis.

For the part of making, and executing of Lawes, con≈øider fir≈øt the trew difference betwixt a lawfull good King, and an v≈øurping Tyran, and yee ≈øhall the more ea≈øily vnder≈øtand your duetie herein: Difference of a King and a Tyran. for contraria iuxta ≈øe po≈øita magis eluce≈øcunt. The one acknowledgeth him≈øelfe ordained for his people, hauing receiued from God a burthen of gouernment, Plato in Polit. whereof he mu≈øt be countable: the other thinketh his people ordined for him,
Ari≈øt. 5. Polit. a prey to his pa≈ø≈øions and inordinate appetites, as the fruites of his magnanimitie: And therefore, as their ends are directly contrarie, ≈øo are their whole actions, as meanes, whereby they prea≈ø≈øe to attaine to their endes. A good King, thinking his highe≈øt honour to con≈øi≈øt in the due di≈øcharge of his calling, emploieth all his ≈øtudie and paines, to procure and maintaine,
Xen. 8. Cyr. by the making and execution of good Lawes, the well-fare and peace of his people; and as their naturall father and kindly Ma≈øter,
Cic. lib. 5. de Rep. thinketh his greate≈øt contentment ≈øtandeth in their pro≈øperitie, and his greate≈øt ≈øuretie in hauing their hearts, ≈øubiecting his owne priuate affections and appetites to the weale and ≈øtanding of his Subiects, euer thinking the common intere≈ø≈øe his chiefe≈øt particular: where by the contrarie, an v≈øurping Tyran,
thinking his greate≈øt honour and felicitie to con≈øi≈øt in attaining per fas, vel nefas,
Ari≈øt. 5. Polit. Tacit. 4. hi≈øt. to his ambitious pretences, thinketh neuer him≈øelfe ≈øure, but by the di≈ø≈øention and factions among his people, and counterfaiting the Saint while he once creepe in credite, will then (by inuerting all good Lawes to ≈øerue onely for his vnrulie priuate affections) frame the common-weale euer to aduance his particular: building his ≈øuretie vpon his peoples mi≈øerie: and in the end (as a ≈øtep-father and an vncouth hireling) make vp his owne hand vpon the ruines of the Republicke. And according to their actions, The i≈ø≈øue and rewards of a good King. ≈øo receiue they their reward: For a good King (after a happie and famous reigne) dieth in peace, lamented by his ≈øubiects, and admired by his neighbours; and leauing a reuerent renowne behinde him in earth, obtaineth the Crowne of eternall felicitie in heauen.
Cic. 6. de Rep. And although ≈øome of them (which falleth out very rarelie) may be cut off by the trea≈øon of ≈øome vnnaturall ≈øubiects, yet liueth their fame after them, and ≈øome notable plague faileth neuer to ouertake the committers in this life, be≈øides their infamie to all po≈øterities hereafter: The i≈ø≈øue of Tyrans, Ari≈øt. 5. Polit. Where by the contrarie, a Tyrannes mi≈øerable and infamous life, armeth in end his owne Subiects to become his burreaux: I≈øocr in Sym. and although that rebellion be euer vnlawfull on their part, yet is the world ≈øo wearied of him, that his fall is little meaned by the re≈øt of his Subiects, and but ≈ømiled at by his neighbours. And be≈øides the infamous memorie he leaueth behind him here, and the endle≈ø≈øe paine hee ≈øu≈øtaineth hereafter, it oft falleth out, that the committers not onely e≈øcape vnpuni≈øhed, but farther, the fact will remaine as allowed by the Law in diuers aages thereafter. It is ea≈øie then for you (my Sonne) to make a choi≈øe of one of the≈øe two ≈øorts of rulers, by following the way of vertue to e≈øtabli≈øh your ≈øtanding; yea, inca≈øe ye fell in the high way, yet ≈øhould it be with the honourable report, and iu≈øt regrate of all hone≈øt men.

And therefore to returne to my purpo≈øe anent the gouernement of your Subiects, Anent the making of Lawes. by making and putting good Lawes to execution; I remit the making of them to your owne di≈øcretion, as ye ≈øhall finde the nece≈ø≈øitie of new-ri≈øing corruptions to require them: for, ex malis moribus bonae leges natae ≈øunt: be≈øides, that in this countrey, wee haue alreadie moe good Lawes then are well execute, and am onely to in≈øi≈øt in your forme of gouernment anent their execution. Onely remember, that as Parliaments haue bene ordained for making of Lawes, ≈øo ye abu≈øe not their in≈øtitution, in holding them for any mens particulars: The authoritie and trew v≈øe of Parliaments. For as a Parliament is the honourable≈øt and highe≈øt iudgement in the land (as being the Kings head Court) if it be well v≈øed, which is by making of good Lawes in it; ≈øo is it the in-iu≈øte≈øt Iudgement-≈øeat that may be,
L. 12. Tab. being abu≈øed to mens particulars: irreuocable decreits again≈øt particular parties, being giuen therein vnder colour of generall Lawes, and oft-times th'E≈øtates not knowing them≈øelues whom thereby they hurt. And therefore hold no Parliaments, but for nece≈ø≈øitie of new Lawes, which would be but ≈øeldome: for few Lawes and well put in execution, are be≈øt in a well ruled common-weale. As for
the matter of fore-faltures, which al≈øo are done in Parliament, it is not good tigging with the≈øe things; but my aduice is,
Cic. 3 de leg. pro D. ≈ø. & pro Se≈øt. ye fore-fault none but for ≈øuch odious crimes as may make them vnworthie euer to be re≈øtored againe: And for ≈ømaller offences, ye haue other penalties ≈øharpe enough to be v≈øed again≈øt them.

And as for the execution of good Lawes, whereat I left, Anent the execution of Lawes. remember that among the differences that I put betwixt the formes of the gouernment of a good King, and an v≈øurping Tyran; I ≈øhew how a Tyran would enter like a Saint while he found him≈øelfe fa≈øt vnder-foot, and then would ≈øuffer his vnrulie affections to bur≈øt foorth. A iu≈øt ≈øeneritic to be v≈øed at the fir≈øt. Sen. de cl. Ar. 7. pol. Therefore be yee contrare at your fir≈øt entrie to your Kingdome, to that Quinquennium Neronis, with his tender hearted wi≈øh, Vellem ne≈øcirem literas, in giuing the Law full execution again≈øt all breakers thereof but exception.
