Remit euery thing to the ordinary iudicature, for e≈øchewing of confu≈øion: but let it be your owne craft, to take a ≈øharpe account of euery man in his office.

And next the Lawes, Reading of hi≈øtories. I would haue you to be well ver≈øed in authentick hi≈øtories, and in the Chronicles of all nations, but ≈øpecially in our owne hi≈øtories (Ne ≈øis peregrinus domi) the example whereof mo≈øt neerely concernes you: I meane not of ≈øuch infamous inuectiues, as Buchanans or Knoxes Chronicles: and if any of the≈øe infamous libels remaine vntill your dayes, v≈øe the Law vpon the keepers thereof: For in that point I would haue you a Pythagori≈øt, Plat. in Menon. to thinke that the very ≈øpirits of the≈øe archibellou≈øes of rebellion, haue made tran≈øition in them that hoardes their bookes,
Ari≈øt. 1 Rhet. Polit. 1. Plut. in Timo. Cic. 2. de Or. or maintaines their opinions; puni≈øhing them, euen as it were their authours ri≈øen againe. But by reading of authenticke hi≈øtories and Chronicles, yee ≈øhall learne experience by Theoricke, applying the bypa≈øt things to the pre≈øent e≈øtate, Eccle≈ø. 1. quia nihil nouum ≈øub ≈øole: ≈øuch is the continuall volubilitie of things earthly, according to the roundne≈ø≈øe of the world, and reuolution of the heauenly circles: which is expre≈ø≈øed by the wheeles in Ezechiels vi≈øions, Ezech. 1. and counterfeited by the Poets in rota Fortunae. And likewi≈øe by the knowledge of hi≈øtories, yee ≈øhall knowe how to behaue your ≈øelfe to all Emba≈ø≈øadours and ≈øtrangers; being able
to di≈øcour≈øe with them vpon the e≈øtate of their owne countrey. And among al prophane hi≈øtories, I mu≈øt not omit mo≈øt ≈øpecially to recommend vnto you, the Commentaries of Cae≈øar; both for the ≈øweete flowing of the ≈øtile, as al≈øo for the worthine≈ø≈øe of the matter it ≈øelfe: For I haue euer beene of that opinion, that of all the Ethnick Emperors, or great Captaines that euer were, he hath farthe≈øt excelled, both in his practi≈øe, and in his precepts in martiall affaires.

Embrace trew magnanimitie, not in beeing vindictiue, Of magnanimitie. Ari≈øt. 4. eth. Sen. de cl. which the corrupted iudgements of the world thinke to be trew Magnanimitie; but by the contrarie, in thinking your offendour not worthie of your wrath,
Cic. 1. off. Virg. 6. Aen. empyring ouer your owne pa≈ø≈øion, and triumphing in the commaunding your ≈øelfe to forgiue: husbanding the effects of your courage and wrath, to be rightly employed vpon repelling of iniuries within, by reuenge taking vpon the oppre≈ø≈øours; and in reuenging iniuries without, by iu≈øt warres vpon forraine enemies. And ≈øo, where ye finde a notable iniurie, ≈øpare not to giue cour≈øe to the torrents of your wrath. The wrath of a King, Prou. 20. is like to the roaring of a Lyon.

Fo≈øter trew Humilitie, in banni≈øhing pride, Of humilitie. not onely towards God (con≈øidering yee differ not in ≈øtuffe, but in v≈øe, and that onely by his ordinance, from the ba≈øe≈øt of your people) but al≈øo towards your Parents.
Plat. 4. de Leg. Xen. 2. de dict. & fact. Soc. And if it fall out that my Wife ≈øhall out-liue me, as euer ye thinke to purcha≈øe my ble≈ø≈øing, honour your mother: ≈øet Beer≈øheba in a throne on your right hand: offend her for nothing, much le≈ø≈øe wrong her: remember her Quae longa decem tulerit fastidia men≈øes; and that your fle≈øh and blood is made of hers: and beginne not, like the young lordes and lairdes, your fir≈øt warres vpon your Mother; but prea≈ø≈øe earne≈øtly to de≈øerue her ble≈ø≈øing. Neither deceiue your ≈øelfe with many that ≈øay, they care not for their Parents cur≈øe, ≈øo they de≈øerue it not. O inuert not the order of nature, by iudging your ≈øuperiours, chiefly in your owne particular! But a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelfe, the ble≈ø≈øing or cur≈øe of the Parents, hath almo≈øt euer a Propheticke power ioyned with it: and if there were no more, honour your Parents, Exod. 20. for the lengthning of your owne
dayes, Exod. 20. Xen. 1. & 3. Cyr. as GOD in his Law promi≈øeth. Honour al≈øo them that are in loco Parentum vnto you, ≈øuch as your gouernours, vp-bringers, and Praeceptours: be thankefull vnto them and reward them, which is your dewtie and honour.

But on the other part, let not this trew humilitie ≈øtay your high indignation to appeare, Cic. ad Q frat. when any great oppre≈ø≈øours ≈øhall prae≈øume to come in your pre≈øence; then frowne as ye ought: And in-ca≈øe they v≈øe a colour of Law in oppre≈ø≈øing their poore ones, as ouer-many doe; that which ye cannot mend by Law,
Ari≈øt. 5 pol. mend by the withdrawing of your countenance from them: and once in the yeere cro≈ø≈øe them, when their erands come in your way, Matth. 18. recompencing the oppre≈ø≈øour, according to Chri≈øts parable of the two debtours.

Keepe trew Con≈øtancie, Of Con≈øtancie. Ari≈øt. 4. aeth. Thuc. 3.6. Cic. 1. Of. & ad Qf. Brut. ad Cic. not onely in your kindene≈ø≈øe towards hone≈øt men; but being al≈øo inuicti animi again≈øt all aduer≈øities: not with that Stoicke in≈øen≈øible ≈øtupiditie, wherewith many in our dayes, prea≈ø≈øing to winne honour, in imitating that ancient ≈øect, by their incon≈øtant behauiour in their owne liues, belie their profe≈ø≈øion. But although ye are not a ≈øtocke, not to feele calamities; yet let not the feeling of them, ≈øo ouer-rule and doazen your rea≈øon, as may ≈øtay you from taking and v≈øing the be≈øt re≈øolution for remedie, that can be found out.

And principally, Anent reporters. I≈øocr. ad Ph. in Panath. & de per. Cic. ad Q. fr. Plut. de curio≈ø. exerci≈øe trew Wi≈øedome; in di≈øcerning wi≈øely betwixt trew and fal≈øe reports: Fir≈øt, con≈øidering the nature of the per≈øon reporter; Next, what entre≈ø≈øe he can haue in the weale or euill of him, of whom hee maketh the report; Thirdly, the likely-hood of the purpo≈øe it ≈øelfe; And la≈øt, the nature and by-pa≈øt life of the dilated per≈øon: and where yee finde a tratler, away with him. And although it bee true, that a Prince can neuer without ≈øecrecie doe great things, yet it is better ofttimes to try reports, then by credulitie to fo≈øter ≈øu≈øpicion vpon an hone≈øt
man. For ≈øince ≈øu≈øpition is the Tyrants ≈øickene≈ø≈øe,
I≈øoc. de pac. Cic. 3. O≈ø. as the fruites of an euill Con≈øcience, poti√πs in alteram partem peccato: I meane, in not mi≈øtru≈øting one, whom-to no ≈øuch vnhone≈øtie was knowne before. But as for ≈øuch as haue ≈ølipped before, former experience may iu≈øtly breed praeuention by fore-≈øight.

div.head: OF A KINGS BEHAVIOVR IN INDIFFERENT THINGS.
THE THIRD BOOKE.
div.p: Be carefull then, my Sonne, ≈øo to frame all your indifferent actions and outward behauiour, as they may ≈øerue for the furtherance and forth-≈øetting of your inward vertuous di≈øpo≈øition.

The whole indifferent actions of a man, Two ≈øorts of them. I deuide in two ≈øorts: in his behauiour in things nece≈ø≈øary, as food, ≈øleeping, raiment, ≈øpeaking, writing, and ge≈øture; and in things not nece≈ø≈øary, though conuenient and lawfull, as pa≈øtimes or exerci≈øes, and v≈øing of company for recreation.

As to the indifferent things nece≈ø≈øary, Fir≈øt ≈øort, and how they be indifferent. although that of them≈øelues they cannot bee wanted, and ≈øo in that ca≈øe are not indifferent; as likewi≈øe inca≈øe they bee not v≈øed with moderation, declining ≈øo to the extremitie, which is vice; yet the qualitie and forme of v≈øing them, may ≈ømell of vertue or vice, and be great furtherers to any of them.

To beginne then at the things nece≈ø≈øarie; one of the publicke≈øt indifferent actions of a King, and that manie≈øt, e≈øpecially ≈øtrangers, will narrowly
take heed to; is his maner of refection at his Table, and his behauiour thereat. Therefore, as Kings v≈øe oft to eate publickly, Formes at the Table. Xen. in Cyr. it is meete and honourable that ye al≈øo doe ≈øo, as well to e≈øchew the opinion that yee loue not to haunt companie, which is one of the markes of a Tyrant; as likewi≈øe, that your delight to eate priuatlie, be not thought to be for priuate ≈øati≈øfying of your gluttonie; which ye would be a≈øhamed ≈øhould bee publicklie ≈øeene. Let your Table bee honourably ≈øerued; but ≈øerue your appetite with few di≈øhes, as yong Cyrus did: which both is hole≈øomme≈øt,
Xen. 1. Cyr. and free≈øt from the vice of delicacie, which is a degree of gluttonie. Plut. in Apoth. And v≈øe mo≈øt to eate of rea≈øonablie-groffe, and common-meates; a≈øwell for making your bodie ≈øtrong and durable for trauell at all occa≈øions, either in peace or in warre: as that yee may bee the heartlier receiued by your meane Subiects in their hou≈øes, when their cheare may ≈øuffice you: which otherwayes would be imputed to you for pride and daintine≈ø≈øe, and breed coldne≈ø≈øe and di≈ødaine in them. Let all your food bee ≈øimple,
Sen. ep. 96. without compo≈øition or ≈øauces; which are more like medecines then meate. The v≈øing of them was counted among≈øt the ancient Romanes a filthie vice of delicacie; becau≈øe they ≈øerue onely for plea≈øing of the ta≈øte, and not for ≈øatisfying of the nece≈ø≈øitie of nature;
Sen. de con≈øol. ad Alb. Iuuen. ≈øat. 2. abhorring Apicius their owne citizen, for his vice of delicacie and mon≈øterous gluttonie. Like as both the Grecians and Romanes had in dete≈øtation the very name of Philoxenus,
Ari≈øt. 4 eth. for his filthie wi≈øh of a Crane-craig. And therefore was that ≈øentence v≈øed among≈øt them, again≈øt the≈øe artificiall fal≈øe appetites,
Xen. de dict. & fact. Socr. Laert. in Socr. Cic. 5. Tu≈ø. Plat. 6. de Leg. Plin. l. 14. optimum condimentum fames. But beware with v≈øing exce≈ø≈øe of meat and drinke; and chiefly, beware of drunkenne≈ø≈øe, which is a bea≈øtlie vice, namely in a King: but ≈øpecially beware with it, becau≈øe it is one of tho≈øe vices that increa≈øeth with aage. In the forme of your meate-eating, bee neither vnciuill, like a gro≈ø≈øe Cynicke; nor affectatlie mignarde, like a daintie dame; but eate in a manlie, round, and hone≈øt fa≈øhion.
Cic. 1. Off. It is no wayes comely to di≈øpatch affaires, or to be pen≈øiue at meate: but keepe then an open and cheerefull countenance, cau≈øing to reade plea≈øant hi≈øtories vnto you, that profite may be mixed with plea≈øure: and when ye are not di≈øpo≈øed, entertaine plea≈øant, quicke, but hone≈øt di≈øcour≈øes.

But albeit ordinarie times would commonly bee kept in meate and ≈øleepe; yet v≈øe your ≈øelfe ≈øome-times ≈øo, Be≈øt forme of diet. Pla. 6. de leg. that any time in the foure and twentie houres may bee alike to you for any of them; that thereby your diet may be accommodate to your affaires, and not your affaires to your diet: not therefore v≈øing your ≈øelfe to ouer great-≈øoftne≈ø≈øe and delicacie in your ≈øleepe, more then in your meate; and ≈øpecially in-ca≈øe yee haue adoe with the warres.

Let not your Chalmer be throng and common in the time of your re≈øt, Formes in the Chalmer. a≈øwell for comeline≈ø≈øe as for e≈øchewing of carrying reports out of the ≈øame. Let them that haue the credite to ≈øerue in your Chalmer,
Val. 2. Cur. 4. be tru≈øtie and ≈øecret; for a King will haue need to v≈øe ≈øecrecie in many things: but yet behaue your ≈øelfe ≈øo in your greate≈øt ≈øecrets, as yee neede not bee a≈øhamed, ≈øuppo≈øe they were all proclaimed at the mercate cro≈ø≈øe:
Pla. 6. de leg. But ≈øpecially ≈øee that tho≈øe of your Chalmer be of a ≈øound fame, and without blemi≈øh.

Take no heede to any of your dreames, Dreames not to be taken heede to. for all prophecies, vi≈øions, and propheticke dreames are accompli≈øhed and cea≈øed in Chri≈øt: And therefore take no heede to freets either in dreames, or any other things; for that errour proceedeth of ignorance, and is vnworthy of a Chri≈øtian, who ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øured, Rom. 14. Titus 1. Omnia e≈øse pura puris, as Paul ≈øayth; all dayes and meates being alike to Chri≈øtians.

Next followeth to ≈øpeake of raiment, Of apparell. the on-putting whereof is the ordinarie action that followeth next to ≈øleepe. I≈øocr. de reg. Be al≈øo moderate in your raiment, neither ouer ≈øuperfluous, like a debo≈øhed wa≈øter; nor yet ouer ba≈øe, like a mi≈øerable wretch; not artificially trimmed and decked, like a Courtizane, nor yet ouer ≈øluggi≈øhly clothed, like a countrey clowne; not ouer lightly like a Candie ≈øouldier, or a vaine young Courtier; nor yet ouer grauely,
Cic. 1. Offic. like a Mini≈øter: but in your garments be proper, cleanely, comely and hone≈øt, wearing your clothes in a carele≈ø≈øe, yet comely forme: keeping in them a midde forme, inter Togatos & Paludatos, betwixt the grauitie of the one, and lightne≈ø≈øe of the other: thereby to ≈øignifie, that by your calling yee are mixed of both the profe≈ø≈øions; Plat. de rege. Togatus, as a Iudge making and pronouncing the Law; Paludatus, by the power of the ≈øword: as your office is likewi≈øe mixed, betwixt the Eccle≈øia≈øticall and ciuill e≈øtate: For a King is not mer√® laicus, as both the Papi≈øts and Anabapti≈øts would haue him, to the which error al≈øo the Puritanes incline ouer farre. But to returne to the purpo≈øe of garments, they ought to be v≈øed according to their fir≈øt in≈øtitution by God, which was for three cau≈øes: fir≈øt to hide our nakedne≈ø≈øe and ≈øhame; next and con≈øequently, to make vs more comely; and thirdly, to pre≈øerue vs from the iniuries of heate and colde. If to hide our nakedne≈ø≈øe and ≈øhamefull parts, then the≈øe naturall parts ordained to be hid, ≈øhould not be repre≈øented by any vndecent formes in the cloathes: and if they ≈øhould helpe our comeline≈ø≈øe, they ≈øhould not then by their painted preened fa≈øhion, ≈øerue for baites to filthie lecherie, as fal≈øe haire and fairding does among≈øt vncha≈øt women: and if they ≈øhould pre≈øerue vs from the iniuries of heat and colde, men ≈øhould not, like ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe ≈øtones, contemne God, in lightlying the ≈øea≈øons, glorying to conquere honour on heate and colde. And although it be prai≈øe-worthy and nece≈ø≈øarie in a Prince, to be patiens algoris & aestus, when he ≈øhall haue adoe with warres vpon the fields; yet I thinke it meeter that ye goe both cloathed and armed, then naked to the battell, except you would make you light for away-running: and yet for cowards, metus addit alas. And ≈øhortly,
in your cloathes keepe a proportion, a≈øwell with the ≈øea≈øons of the yeere, as of your aage: in the fa≈øhions of them being carele≈ø≈øe, v≈øing them according to the common forme of the time, ≈øome-times richlier,
Cic. 1. Off. ≈øome-times meanlier cloathed, as occa≈øion ≈øerueth, without keeping any preci≈øe rule therein: For if your mind be found occupied vpon them, Ar. ad. Alex. it wil be thought idle otherwaies, and ye ≈øhall bee accounted in the number of one of the≈øe compti iuuenes; which wil make your ≈øpirit and iudgment to be le≈ø≈øe thought of. But ≈øpecially e≈øchew to be effeminate in your cloathes, in perfuming, preening, or ≈øuch like: and faile neuer in time of warres to bee galliarde≈øt and braue≈øt, both in cloathes and countenance. And make not a foole of your ≈øelfe in di≈øgui≈øing or wearing long haire or nailes, which are but excrements of nature, and bewray ≈øuch mi≈øu≈øers of them, to bee either of a vindictiue, or a vaine light naturall. E≈øpecially, make no vowes in ≈øuch vaine and outward things, as concerne either meate or cloathes.

Let your ≈øelfe and all your Court weare no ordinarie armour with your cloathes, but ≈øuch as is knightly and honourable; What ordinarie armour to be worne at Court. I meane rapier≈øwordes, and daggers: For tuilye≈øome weapons in the Court, betokens confu≈øion in the countrey. And therefore banni≈øh not onely from your Court, all traiterous offen≈øiue weapons, forbidden by the Lawes, as guns and ≈øuch like (whereof I ≈øpake alreadie) but al≈øo all traiterous defen≈øiue armes, as ≈øecrets, plate-≈øleeues, and ≈øuch like vn≈øeene armour: For, be≈øides that the wearers thereof, may be pre≈øuppo≈øed to haue a ≈øecret euill intention, they want both the v≈øes that defen≈øiue armour is ordained for; which is, to be able to holde out violence, and by their outward glaun≈øing in their enemies eyes, to ≈øtrike a terrour in their hearts: Where by the contrary, they can ≈øerue for neither, being not onely vnable to re≈øi≈øt, but dangerous for ≈øhots, and giuing no outward ≈øhowe again≈øt the enemie; beeing onely ordained, for betraying vnder tru≈øt, whereof hone≈øt men ≈øhould be a≈øhamed to beare the outward badge, not re≈øembling the thing they are not. And for an≈øwere again≈øt the≈øe arguments, I know none but the olde Scots fa≈øhion; which if it be wrong, is no more to be allowed for ancientne≈ø≈øe, then the olde Ma≈ø≈øe is, which al≈øo our forefathers v≈øed.

The next thing that yee haue to take heed to, Of language and ge≈øture. Ari≈øt. 3. ad Theod. Cic. in orat. ad Q. frat. & ad Bren. is your ≈øpeaking and language; whereunto I ioyne your ge≈øture, ≈øince action is one of the chiefe≈øt qualities, that is required in an oratour: for as the tongue ≈øpeaketh to the eares, ≈øo doeth the ge≈øture ≈øpeake to the eyes of the auditour. In both your ≈øpeaking and your ge≈øture, v≈øe a naturall and plaine forme,
Cic. 1. Offic. not fairded with artifice: for (as the French-men ≈øay) Rien contre-faict fin: but e≈øchew all affectate formes in both.

In your language be plaine, hone≈øt, naturall, comely, cleane, ≈øhort, Id. cod. and ≈øententious, e≈øchewing both the extremities, a≈øwell in not v≈øing any ru≈øticall corrupt leide, as booke-language, and pen and inke-horne termes:
and lea≈øt of all mignard and effoeminate tearmes. But let the greate≈øt part of your eloquence con≈øi≈øt in a naturall, cleare, and ≈øen≈øible forme of the deliuerie of your minde, Cic. ad Q. frat. & ad Brut. builded euer vpon certaine and good grounds; tempering it with grauitie, quickene≈ø≈øe, or merine≈ø≈øe, according to the ≈øubiect, and occa≈øion of the time; not taunting in Theologie, nor alleadging and prophaning the Scripture in drinking purpo≈øes, as ouer many doe.

Remember al≈øo,
Id. 1. Off. Formes in rea≈øoning. to put a difference betwixt your forme of language in rea≈øoning, and your pronouncing of ≈øentences, or declaratour of your wil in iudgement, or any other waies in the points of your office: For in the former ca≈øe, yee mu≈øt rea≈øon plea≈øantly and patiently, not like a king, but like a priuate man and a ≈øcholer; otherwaies, your impatience of contradiction will be interpreted to be for lacke of rea≈øon on your part. Where in the points of your office, ye ≈øhould ripely adui≈øe indeede, before yee giue foorth your ≈øentence: but fra it be giuen foorth, the ≈øuffering of any contradiction dimini≈øheth the maie≈øtie of your authoritie, In iudgment. I≈øoc. ad Nic. Cic. ad Q. frat. and maketh the proce≈ø≈øes endle≈ø≈øe. The like forme would al≈øo bee ob≈øerued by all your inferiour Iudges and Magi≈øtrates.

Now as to your writing, Of writing, and what ≈øtile fitteth a Prince. which is nothing el≈øe, but a forme of en-regi≈øtrate ≈øpeech; v≈øe a plaine, ≈øhort, but ≈øtately ≈øtile, both in your Proclamations and mi≈ø≈øiues, e≈øpecially to forraine Princes. And if your engine ≈øpur you to write any workes, either in ver≈øe or in pro≈øe, I cannot but allow you to practi≈øe it: but take no long≈øome workes in hand, for di≈øtracting you from your calling.

Flatter not your ≈øelfe in your labours,
Cic. 1. Off. but before they bee ≈øet foorth, let them fir≈øt bee priuily cen≈øured by ≈øome of the be≈øt skilled men in that craft, that in the≈øe workes yee meddle with. And becau≈øe your writes will remaine as true pictures of your minde, to all po≈øterities; let them bee free
of all vncomeline≈ø≈øe and vn-hone≈øtie: and according to Horace his coun≈øell ‚Äî Nonum
que premantur in annum. De arte Poetica. I meane both your ver≈øe and your pro≈øe; letting fir≈øt that furie and heate, wherewith they were written, coole at lea≈øure; and then as an vncouth iudge and cen≈øour, reui≈øing them ouer againe, before they bee publi≈øhed, ‚Äî quia ne≈øcit vox mi≈ø≈øa reuerti. Idem eod.

If yee would write worthily, choo≈øe ≈øubiects worthie of you, that bee not full of vanitie, but of vertue; e≈øchewing ob≈øcuritie, and delighting euer to bee plaine and ≈øen≈øible. And if yee write in ver≈øe, remember that it is not the principall part of a Poeme to rime right, and flowe well with many pretie wordes: but the chiefe commendation of a Poeme is, that when the ver≈øe ≈øhall bee ≈øhaken ≈øundrie in pro≈øe, Ar. de art. Poet. it ≈øhall bee found ≈øo rich in quicke inuentions, and poeticke flowers, and in faire and pertinent compari≈øons; as it ≈øhall retaine the lu≈øtre of a Poeme, although in pro≈øe. And I would al≈øo adui≈øe you to write in your owne language: for there is nothing left to be ≈øaide in Greeke and Latine alreadie; and ynew of poore ≈øchollers would match you in the≈øe languages; and be≈øides that, it be≈øt becommeth a King to purifie and make famous his owne tongue; wherein he may goe before all his ≈øubiects; as it ≈øetteth him well to doe in all hone≈øt and lawfull things.

And among≈øt all vnnece≈ø≈øarie things that are lawfull and expedient, Of the exerci≈øe of the bodie. Xen. 1. Cyr. I thinke exerci≈øes of the bodie mo≈øt commendable to be v≈øed by a young Prince, in ≈øuch hone≈øt games or pa≈øtimes, as may further abilitie and maintaine health: For albeit I graunt it to be mo≈øt requi≈øite for a King to exerci≈øe his engine, which ≈øurely with idlene≈ø≈øe will ru≈øte and become blunt; yet certainely bodily exerci≈øes and games are very commendable;
Plat. 6. de leg. Ar. 7. & 8. pol. Cic. 1. Off. as well for banni≈øhing of idlene≈ø≈øe (the mother of all vice) as for making his bodie able and durable for trauell, which is very nece≈ø≈øarie for a King. But from this count I debarre all rough and violent exerci≈øes, as the footeball; meeter for laming, then making able the v≈øers thereof: as likewi≈øe ≈øuch tumbling trickes as only ≈øerue for Comoedians and Balladines, to win their bread with. Pl. eod. But the exerci≈øes that I would haue you to v≈øe (although but moderately, not making a craft of them) are running, leaping, wra≈øtling, fencing, dancing, and playing at the caitch or tenni≈øe, archerie, palle maille, and ≈øuch like other faire and plea≈øant field-games. Xen. in Cyr. I≈ø. deiug. And the honourable≈øt and mo≈øt commendable games that yee can v≈øe, are on hor≈øebacke: for it becommeth a Prince be≈øt of any man, to be a faire and good hor≈øe-man. V≈øe therefore to ride and danton great and couragious hor≈øes; that I may ≈øay of you, as Philip ≈øaid of great Alexander his ≈øonne, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Plut. in Alex. And ≈øpecially v≈øe ≈øuch games on hor≈øe-backe, as may teach you to handle your armes thereon; ≈øuch as the tilt, the ring, and low-riding for handling of your ≈øword.

I cannot omit heere the hunting, namely with running hounds; Of hunting. which is the mo≈øt honourable and noble≈øt ≈øorte thereof: for it is a theeui≈øh forme
of hunting to ≈øhoote with gunnes and bowes; and grey hound hunting is not ≈øo martiall a game: But becau≈øe I would not be thought a partiall prai≈øer of this ≈øport,
In Cyn. 1. Cyr. & de rep. Lac. Cic. 1. Offic. I remit you to Xenophon, an olde and famous writer, who had no minde of flattering you or me in this purpo≈øe: and who al≈øo ≈øetteth downe a faire paterne, Cyropoedia. for the education of a yong king, vnder the ≈øuppo≈øed name of Cyrus.

As for hawking I condemne it not, but I mu≈øt prai≈øe it more ≈øparingly, Of hawking. becau≈øe it neither re≈øembleth the warres ≈øo neere as hunting doeth, in making a man hardie, and skilfully ridden in all grounds, and is more vncertaine and ≈øubiect to mi≈øchances; and (which is wor≈øt of all) is there-through an extreme ≈øtirrer vp of pa≈ø≈øions: But in v≈øing either of the≈øe games,
Ari≈øt. 10. Eth. ob≈øerue that moderation, that ye ≈ølip not therewith the houres appointed for your affaires, which ye ought euer preci≈øely to keepe; remembring that the≈øe games are but ordained for you, in enabling you for your office, for the which ye are ordained.

And as for ≈øitting hou≈øe-pa≈øtimes, Of hou≈øe-games. wherewith men by driuing time, ≈øpurre a free and fa≈øt ynough running hor≈øe (as the prouerbe is) although they are not profitable for the exerci≈øe either of minde or body,
Ari≈øt. 8. pol. yet can I not vtterly condemne them; ≈øince they may at times ≈øupply the roome, which being emptie, would be patent to pernicious idlene≈ø≈øe, quia nihil pote≈øt e≈øse vacuum. Dan. de lu≈ø. al. I will not therefore agree with the curio≈øitie of ≈øome learned men in our aage, in forbidding cardes, dice, and other ≈øuch like games of hazard; although otherwayes ≈øurely I reuerence them as notable and godly men: For they are deceiued therein, in founding their argument vpon a mi≈øtaken ground, which is, that the playing at ≈øuch games, is a kind of ca≈øting of lot, and therefore vnlawfull; wherein they deceiue them≈øelues: For the ca≈øting of lot was v≈øed for triall of the trewth in any ob≈øcure thing, that otherwayes could not be gotten cleared; and therefore was a ≈øort of prophecie: whereby the contrary, no man goeth to any of the≈øe playes, to cleare any ob≈øcure trewth, but onely to gage ≈øo much of his owne money, as hee plea≈øeth, vpon the hazard of the running of the cardes or dice, a≈øwell as he would doe vpon the ≈øpeede of a hor≈øe or a dog, or any ≈øuch like gaigeour: And ≈øo, if they be vnlawfull, all gaigeours vpon vncertainties mu≈øt likewayes be condemned: Not that thereby I take the defence of vaine carders and dicers, that wa≈øte their moyen, and their time (whereof fewe con≈øider the pretiou≈øne≈ø≈øe) vpon prodigall and continuall playing:
Cic. 1. Offic. no, I would rather allow it to be di≈øcharged, where ≈øuch corruption cannot be e≈øchewed. But only I cannot condemne you at ≈øome times, when ye haue no other thing adoe (as a good King will be ≈øeldome) and are wearie of reading, or euill di≈øpo≈øed in your per≈øon, and when it is foule and ≈øtormie weather; then, I ≈øay, may ye lawfully play at the cardes or tables: For as to dicing, I thinke it becommeth be≈øt debo≈øhed ≈øouldiers to play at, on the head of their drums, being onely ruled by hazard, and ≈øubiect to knaui≈øh cogging. And as for the che≈ø≈øe, I thinke it ouer fond,
becau≈øe it is ouer-wi≈øe and Philo≈øophicke a folly: For where all ≈øuch light playes, are ordained to free mens heades for a time, from the fa≈øhions thoughts on their affaires; it by the contrarie filleth and troubleth mens heades, with as many fa≈øhious toyes of the play, as before it was filled with thoughts on his affaires.

But in your playing, I would haue you to keepe three rules: fir≈øt, Rules in playing. or ye play, con≈øider yee doe it onely for your recreation, and re≈øolue to hazard the lo≈ø≈øe of all that ye play: and next, for that cau≈øe play no more then yee care to ca≈øt among Pages: and la≈øt, play alwaies faire play preci≈øely, that ye come not in v≈øe of tricking and lying in iea≈øt: otherwi≈øe, if yee cannot keepe the≈øe rules, my coun≈øell is that yee allutterly ab≈øtaine from the≈øe playes: For neither a madde pa≈ø≈øion for lo≈ø≈øe, nor fal≈øhood v≈øed for de≈øire of gaine, can be called a play.

Now, it is not onely lawfull, but nece≈ø≈øarie, What choi≈øe of companie. that yee haue companie meete for euery thing yee take on hand, a≈øwell in your games and exerci≈øes, as in your graue and earne≈øt affaires:
I≈øoc. de reg. Cic. 1. Off. But learne to di≈øtingui≈øh time according to the occa≈øion, choo≈øing your companie accordingly. Conferre not with hunters at your coun≈øell, nor in your coun≈øell affaires: nor di≈øpatch not affaires at hunting or other games. And haue the like re≈øpect to the ≈øea≈øons of your aage, v≈øing your ≈øortes of recreation and companie therefore, agreeing thereunto: For it becommeth be≈øt, as kindlie≈øt, euery aage to ≈ømell of their owne qualitie,
Ar. 2. ad Theod. in≈øolence and vnlawful things beeing alwaies e≈øchewed: and not that a colt ≈øhould draw the plough, and an olde hor≈øe run away with the harrowes. But take heede ≈øpecially, that your companie for recreation, be cho≈øen of hone≈øt per≈øons, not defamed or vicious, mixing filthie talke with merrine≈ø≈øe, Corrumpunt bonos mores colloquia praua. And chiefly ab≈øtaine from haunting before your mariage, Men. the idle companie of dames, which are nothing el≈øe, but irritamenta libidinis. Bee warre likewaies to abu≈øe your ≈øelfe, in making your ≈øporters your coun≈øellers: and delight not to keepe ordinarily in your companie, Comoedians or Balladines: for the Tyrans delighted mo≈øt in them,
Pl. 3. de rep. Ar. 7. & 8. pol. Sen. 1. ep. Dyon. glorying to bee both authors and actors of Comoedies and Tragedies them≈øelues: Wherupon the an≈øwere that the poet Philoxenus di≈ødainefully gaue to the Tyran of Syracu≈øe there-anent, is now come in a prouerbe, reduc me in latomias. Suidas. And all the ru≈øe that Nero made of him≈øelfe when he died, was Qualis artifexpereo? Suet. in Ner. meaning of his skill in men≈øtrally, and playing of Tragoedies: as indeede his whole life and death, was all but one Tragoedie.

Delight not al≈øo to bee in your owne per≈øon a player vpon in≈øtruments; e≈øpecially on ≈øuch as commonly men winne their liuing with: nor yet to be fine of any mechanicke craft: 1. Sep.
Leur esprit s'en fuit au bout des doigts, ≈øaith Du Bartas: who≈øe workes, as they are all mo≈øt worthie to bee read by any Prince, or other good Chri≈øtian; ≈øo would I e≈øpecially wi≈øh you to bee well ver≈øed in them. But ≈øpare not ≈øome-times by merie company,
to be free from importunitie; for ye ≈øhould be euer mooued with rea≈øon, which is the onely qualitie whereby men differ from bea≈øts; and not with importunitie:
Curt. 8. For the which cau≈øe (as al≈øo for augmenting your Maie≈øtie) ye ≈øhall not be ≈øo facile of acce≈ø≈øe-giuing at all times, as I haue beene;
Liu. 35. Xen. in. Age≈ø. Cit. ad Q frat. and yet not altogether retired or locked vp, like the Kings of Per≈øia: appointing al≈øo certaine houres for publicke audience.

And ≈øince my tru≈øt is, that God hath ordained you for moe Kingdomes then this (as I haue oft alreadie ≈øaid) prea≈ø≈øe by the outward behauiour as well of your owne per≈øon, A ≈øpeciall good rule in gouernment. as of your court, in all indifferent things, to allure piece and piece, the re≈øt of your kingdomes, to follow the fa≈øhions of that kingdome of yours, that yee finde mo≈øt ciuill, ea≈øie≈øt to be ruled, and mo≈øt obedient to the Lawes: for the≈øe outward and indifferent things will ≈øerue greatly for allurements to the people, to embrace and follow vertue. But beware of thrawing or con≈øtraining them thereto; letting it bee brought on with time, and at lei≈øure; ≈øpecially by ≈øo mixing through alliance and daily conuer≈øation, the inhabitants of euery kingdom with other, as may with time make them to grow and welde all in one: Which may ea≈øily be done betwixt the≈øe two nations, being both but one Ile of Britaine, and alreadie ioyned in vnitie of Religion and language. The fruitfull effects of the vnion. So that euen as in the times of our ance≈øtours, the long warres and many bloodie battels betwixt the≈øe two countreys, bred a naturall and hereditarie hatred in euery of them, again≈øt the other: the vniting and welding of them hereafter in one, by all ≈øort of friend≈øhip, commerce, and alliance, will by the contrary produce and maintaine a naturall and in≈øeparable vnitie of loue among≈øt them. Alreadie kything in the happy amitie. As we haue already (prai≈øe be to God) a great experience of the good beginning hereof, and of the quenching of the olde hate in the hearts of both the people; procured by the meanes of this long and happy amitie, betweene the Queene my deare≈øt ≈øi≈øter and me; which during the whole time of both our Reignes, hath euer beene inuiolably ob≈øerued.

And for conclu≈øion of this my whole Treati≈øe, Conclu≈øion in forme of abridge of the whole Treati≈øe. remember my Sonne, by your trew and con≈øtant depending vpon God, to looke for a ble≈ø≈øing to all your actions in your office: by the outward v≈øing thereof, to te≈øtifie the inward vprightne≈ø≈øe of your heart; and by your behauiour in all indifferent things, to ≈øet foorth the viue image of your vertuous di≈øpo≈øition; and in re≈øpect of the greatne≈ø≈øe and weight of your burthen, to be patient in hearing, keeping your heart free from praeoccupation, ripe in concluding,
Thuc. 6. Dion. 52. and con≈øtant in your re≈øolution: For better it is to bide at your re≈øolution, although there were ≈øome defect in it, then by daily changing, to effectuate nothing: taking the paterne thereof from the microco≈øme of your owne body; wherein ye haue two eyes, ≈øignifying great fore≈øight and prouidence, with a narrow looking in all things; and al≈øo two eares, ≈øignifying patient hearing, and that of both the parties: but ye haue but one tongue, for pronouncing a plaine, ≈øen≈øible, and vniforme ≈øentence; and but one head, and one heart, for keeping a con≈øtant & vniforme re≈øolution,
according to your apprehen≈øion: hauing two hands and two feete, with many fingers and toes for quicke execution, in employing all in≈øtruments meet for effectuating your deliberations.

But forget not to dige≈øt euer your pa≈ø≈øion, before ye determine vpon any thing, ≈øince Ira furor breuis e≈øt:
Hir. lib. 1. epist. vttering onely your anger according to the Apo≈øtles rule, Ira≈øcimini, ≈øed ne peccetis: taking plea≈øure, not only to reward, Ephe≈ø. 4. but to aduance the good, which is a chiefe point of a Kings glory (but make none ouer-great,
Ari≈øt. 5. pol. Dion. 52. but according as the power of the countrey may beare) and puni≈øhing the euill; but euery man according to his owne offence: not puni≈øhing nor blaming the father for the ≈øonne,
Plat. 9. de leg. nor the brother for the brother; much le≈ø≈øe generally to hate a whole race for the fault of one: for noxa caput ≈øequitur.

And aboue all, let the mea≈øure of your loue to euery one, be according to the mea≈øure of his vertue; letting your fauour to be no longer tyed to any, then the continuance of his vertuous di≈øpo≈øition ≈øhall de≈øerue: not admitting the excu≈øe vpon a iu≈øt reuenge, to procure ouer≈øight to an iniurie: For the fir≈øt iniurie is committed again≈øt the partie; but the parties reuenging thereof at his owne hand, is a wrong committed again≈øt you, in v≈øurping your office, whom to onely the ≈øword belongeth, for reuenging of all the iniuries committed again≈øt any of your people.

Thus hoping in the goodnes of God, that your naturall inclination ≈øhall haue a happy ≈øympathie with the≈øe prƒôcepts, making the wi≈øe-mans ≈øcholema≈øter, which is the example of others, to bee your teacher, according to that old ver≈øe, Foelix quem faciunt aliena pericula cautum; e≈øchewing ≈øo the ouer-late repentance by your owne experience, which is the ≈øchoole-ma≈øter of fooles; I wil for end of all, require you my Sonne, as euer ye thinke to de≈øerue my fatherly ble≈ø≈øing, to keepe continually before the eyes of your minde, the greatne≈ø≈øe of your charge:
Plat. in pol. Cic. 5. d ‚Ä¢ re ‚Ä¢ . making the faithfull and due di≈øcharge thereof, the principal butt ye ≈øhoot at in all your actions: counting it euer the principall, and all your other actions but as acce≈ø≈øories, to be emploied as midde≈ø≈øes for the furthering of that principall. And being content to let others excell in other things, let it be your chiefe≈øt earthly glory, to excell in your owne craft: according to the worthy coun≈øel and charge of Anchi≈øes to his po≈øteritie, in that ≈øublime and heroicall Poet, wherein al≈øo my dicton is included;
Virg 6. Aeu.

Credo equidem, & viuos ducent de marmore vultus,

De≈øcribent radio, & ≈øurgentia ≈øydera dicent.
Tu, regere imperio populos, Romane, memento

div.head: THE TREW LAW OF FREE MONARCHIES: OR THE RECIPROCK AND MVTVALL DVETIE BETWIXT A FREE KING, AND HIS naturall Subiects.
AN ADVERTISEMENT TO THE READER.
div.p:
ACcept, J pray you (my deare countreymen) as thankefully this Pamphlet that J offer vnto you, as louingly it is written for your weale. J would be loath both to be fa≈øchious, and fectle≈ø≈øe: And therefore, if it be not ≈øententious, at lea≈øt it is ≈øhort. Jt may be yee mi≈ø≈øe many things that yee looke for in it: But for excu≈øe thereof, con≈øider rightly that I onely lay downe herein the trew grounds, to teach you the right-way, without wasting time vpon refuting the aduer≈øaries. And yet I trust, if ye will take narrow tent, ye ≈øhall finde mo≈øt of their great gunnes payed home againe, either with contrary conclu≈øions, or tacite obiections, ≈øuppo≈øe in a dairned forme, and indirectly: For my intention
is to instruct, and not irritat, if J may e≈øchew it. The profite I would wi≈øh you to make of it, is, as well ≈øo to frame all your actions according to the≈øe grounds, as may confirme you in the cour≈øe of honest and obedient Subiects to your King in all times comming, as al≈øo, when ye ≈øhall fall in purpo≈øe with any that ≈øhall prai≈øe or excu≈øe the by-past rebellions that brake foorth either in this countrey, or in any other, ye ≈øhall herewith bee armed against their Sirene ≈øongs, laying their particular examples to the ≈øquare of the≈øe grounds. Whereby yee ≈øhall ≈øoundly keepe the cour≈øe of righteous Judgement, decerning wi≈øely of euery action onely according to the qualitie thereof, and not according to your preiudged conceits of the committers: So ≈øhall ye, by reaping profit to your ≈øelues, turne my paine into plea≈øure. But least the whole Pamphlet runne out at the gaping mouth of this Preface, if it were any more enlarged; I end, with committing you to God, and me to your charitable cen≈øures.

div.head: THE TREW LAW OF FREE MONARCHIES: OR The Reciprock and mutuall duetie betwixt a free King and his naturall Subiects.
div.p:
AS there is not a thing ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie to be knowne by the people of any land, next the knowledge of their God, as the right knowledge of their alleageance, according to the forme of gouernement e≈øtabli≈øhed among them, e≈øpecially in a Monarchie (which forme of gouernment, as re≈øembling the Diuinitie, approacheth neare≈øt to perfection, as all the learned and wi≈øe men from the beginning haue agreed vpon; Vnitie being the perfection of all things,) So hath the ignorance, and (which is wor≈øe) the ≈øeduced opinion of the multitude blinded by them, who thinke them≈øelues able to teach and in≈øtruct the ignorants, procured the wracke and ouerthrow of ≈øundry flouri≈øhing Common-wealths; and heaped heauy calamities, threatning vtter de≈øtruction vpon others. And the ≈ømiling ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, that vnlawfull rebellions haue oftentimes had again≈øt Princes in aages pa≈øt (≈øuch hath bene the mi≈øery, and iniquitie of the time) hath by way of practi≈øe ≈øtrengthned many in their errour: albeit there cannot be a more deceiueable argument; then to iudge ay the iu≈øtne≈ø≈øe of the cau≈øe by the euent thereof; as hereafter ≈øhalbe proued more at length. And among others, no Common-wealth, that euer hath bene ≈øince the beginning, hath had greater need of the trew knowledge of this ground, then this our ≈øo long di≈øordered, and di≈øtracted Common-wealth hath: the misknowledge hereof being the onely ≈øpring, from whence haue flowed ≈øo many endle≈ø≈øe calamities, mi≈øeries, and confu≈øions, as is better felt by many, then the cau≈øe thereof well knowne, and deepely con≈øidered. The naturall zeale therefore, that I beare to this my natiue countrie, with the great pittie I haue to ≈øee the ≈øo-long di≈øturbance thereof for lacke of the trew knowledge of this ground (as I haue ≈øaid before) hath compelled me at la≈øt to breake ≈øilence, to di≈øcharge my
con≈øcience to you my deare country men herein, that knowing the ground from whence the≈øe your many endle≈ø≈øe troubles haue proceeded, as well as ye haue already too-long ta≈øted the bitter fruites thereof, ye may by knowledge, and e≈øchewing of the cau≈øe e≈øcape, and diuert the lamentable effects that euer nece≈ø≈øarily follow thereupon. I haue cho≈øen then onely to ≈øet downe in this ≈øhort Treati≈øe, the trew grounds of the mutuall duetie, and alleageance betwixt a free and ab≈øolute Monarche, and his people; not to trouble your patience with an≈øwering the contrary propo≈øitions, which ≈øome haue not bene a≈øhamed to ≈øet downe in writ, to the poy≈øoning of infinite number of ≈øimple ≈øoules, and their owne perpetuall, and well de≈øerued infamie: For by an≈øwering them, I could not haue e≈øchewed whiles to pick, and byte wel ≈øaltly their per≈øons; which would rather haue bred contentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe among the readers (as they had liked or mi≈øliked) then ≈øound in≈øtruction of the trewth: Which I prote≈øt to him that is the ≈øearcher of all hearts, is the onely marke that I ≈øhoot at herein.

Fir≈øt then, I will ≈øet downe the trew grounds, whereupon I am to build, out of the Scriptures, ≈øince Monarchie is the trew paterne of Diuinitie, as I haue already ≈øaid: next, from the fundamental Lawes of our owne Kingdome, which neare≈øt mu≈øt concerne vs: thirdly, from the law of Nature, by diuers ≈øimilitudes drawne out of the ≈øame: and will conclude ≈øyne by an≈øwering the mo≈øt waighty and appearing incommodities that can be obiected.

The Princes duetie to his Subiects is ≈øo clearely ≈øet downe in many places of the Scriptures, and ≈øo openly confe≈ø≈øed by all the good Princes, according to their oath in their Coronation, as not needing to be long therein, I ≈øhall as ≈øhortly as I can runne through it.

Kings are called Gods by the propheticall King Dauid, I ≈øal. 82.6. becau≈øe they ≈øit vpon GOD his Throne in the earth, and haue the count of their admini≈øtration to giue vnto him. P≈øal. 101. P≈øal. 101. 2. King. 18. 2. Chron. 29. 2. King. 22. and 23.2. chro. 34. & 35. P≈øal. 72. 1. King 3. Their office is, To minister Iustice and Iudgement to the people, as the ≈øame Dauid ≈øaith: To aduance the good, and puni≈øh the euill, as he likewi≈øe ≈øaith: To establi≈øh good Lawes to his people, and procure obedience to the ≈øame, as diuers good Kings of Iudah did: To procure the peace of the people, as the ≈øame Dauid ≈øaith: To decide all controuer≈øies that can ari≈øe among them, as Salomon did: To be the Mini≈øter of God for the weale of them that doe well, and as the mini≈øter of God, Rom. 13. to take vengeance vpon them that doe euill, as S. Paul ≈øaith. And finally, 1. Sam. 8. As a good Pa≈øtour, to goe out and in before his people as is ≈øaid in the fir≈øt of Samuel: Ierem. 29. That through the Princes prosperitie, the peoples peace may be procured, as Ieremie ≈øaith.

And therefore in the Coronation of our owne Kings, as well as of euery Chri≈øtian Monarche they giue their Oath, fir≈øt to maintaine the Religion pre≈øently profe≈ø≈øed within their countrie, according to their lawes, whereby it is e≈øtabli≈øhed, and to puni≈øh all tho≈øe that ≈øhould pre≈ø≈øe to alter, or di≈øturbe the profe≈ø≈øion thereof; And next to maintaine all the lowable and good Lawes made by their predece≈ø≈øours: to ≈øee them put in execution,
and the breakers and violaters thereof, to be puni≈øhed, according to the tenour of the ≈øame: And la≈øtly, to maintaine the whole countrey, and euery ≈øtate therein, in all their ancient Priuiledges and Liberties, as well again≈øt all forreine enemies, as among them≈øelues: And ≈øhortly to procure the weale and flouri≈øhing of his people, not onely in maintaining and putting to execution the olde lowable lawes of the countrey, and by e≈øtabli≈øhing of new (as nece≈ø≈øitie and euill maners will require) but by all other meanes po≈ø≈øible to fore-≈øee and preuent all dangers, that are likely to fall vpon them, and to maintaine concord, wealth, and ciuilitie among them, as a louing Father, and careful watchman, caring for them more then for him≈øelfe, knowing him≈øelfe to be ordained for them, and they not for him; and therefore countable to that great God, who placed him as his lieutenant ouer them, vpon the perill of his ≈øoule to procure the weale of both ≈øoules and bodies, as farre as in him lieth, of all them that are committed to his charge. And this oath in the Coronation is the cleare≈øt, ciuill, and fundamentall Law, whereby the Kings office is properly defined.

By the Law of Nature the King becomes a naturall Father to all his Lieges at his Coronation: And as the Father of his fatherly duty is bound to care for the nouri≈øhing, education, and vertuous gouernment of his children; euen ≈øo is the king bound to care for all his ≈øubiects. As all the toile and paine that the father can take for his children, will be thought light and well be≈øtowed by him, ≈øo that the effect thereof redound to their profite and weale; ≈øo ought the Prince to doe towards his people. As the kindly father ought to fore≈øee all inconuenients and dangers that may ari≈øe towards his children, and though with the hazard of his owne per≈øon pre≈ø≈øe to preuent the ≈øame; ≈øo ought the King towards his people. As the fathers wrath and correction vpon any of his children that offendeth, ought to be by a fatherly cha≈øti≈øement ≈øea≈øoned with pitie, as long as there is any hope of amendment in them; ≈øo ought the King towards any of his Lieges that offend in that mea≈øure. And ≈øhortly, as the Fathers chiefe ioy ought to be in procuring his childrens welfare, reioycing at their weale, ≈øorrowing and pitying at their euill, to hazard for their ≈øafetie, trauell for their re≈øt, wake for their ≈øleepe; and in a word, to thinke that his earthly felicitie and life ≈øtandeth and liueth more in them, nor in him≈øelfe; ≈øo ought a good Prince thinke of his people.

As to the other branch of this mutuall and reciprock band, is the duety and alleageance that the Lieges owe to their King: the ground whereof, I take out of the words of Samuel, dited by Gods Spirit, when God had giuen him commandement to heare the peoples voice in choo≈øing and annointing them a King. And becau≈øe that place of Scripture being well vnder≈øtood, is ≈øo pertinent for our purpo≈øe, I haue in≈øert herein the very words of the Text.

list.item: 9 NOw therefore hearken to their voice: howbeit yet testifie vnto them, and ≈øhew them the maner of the King, that ≈øhall raigne ouer them.
10 So Samuel tolde all the wordes of the Lord vnto the people that asked a King of him.

11 And he ≈øaid, This ≈øhall be the maner of the King that ≈øhall raigne ouer you: he will take your ≈øonnes, and appoint them to his Charets, and to be his hor≈øemen, and ≈øome ≈øhall runne before his Charet.

12 Al≈øo, hee will make them his captaines ouer thou≈øands, and captaines ouer fifties, and to eare his ground, and to reape his haruest, and to make instruments of warre, and the things that ≈øerue for his charets:
13 Hee will al≈øo take your daughters, and make them Apothicaries, and Cookes, and Bakers.
14 And hee will take your fields, and your vineyards, and your best Oliue trees, and giue them to his ≈øeruants.
15 And he will take the tenth of your ≈øeed, and of your Vineyards, and giue it to his Eunuches, and to his ≈øeruants.
16 And he will take your men ≈øeruants, and your maid ≈øeruants, and the chiefe of your yong men, and your a≈ø≈øes, and put them to his worke.
17 He will take the tenth of your ≈øheepe: and ye ≈øhall be his ≈øeruants.
18 And ye ≈øhall cry out at that day, becau≈øe of your King, whom ye haue cho≈øen you: and the Lord God will not beare you at that day.
19 But the people would not heare the voice of Samuel, but did ≈øay: Nay, but there ≈øhalbe a King ouer vs.
20 And we al≈øo will be like all other Nations, and our King ≈øhall iudge vs, and goe out before vs, and fight our battels.

div.p:
That the≈øe words, and di≈øcour≈øes of Samuel were dited by Gods Spirit, it needs no further probation, but that it is a place of Scripture; ≈øince the whole Scripture is dited by that in≈øpiration, as Paul ≈øaith: which ground no good Chri≈øtian will, or dare denie. Whereupon it mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily follow, that the≈øe ≈øpeeches proceeded not from any ambition in Samuel, as one loath to quite the reines that he ≈øo long had ruled, and therefore de≈øirous, by making odious the gouernment of a King, to di≈ø≈øwade the people from their farther importunate crauing of one: For, as the text proueth it plainly, he then conueened them to giue them a re≈øolute grant of their demand, as God by his owne mouth commanded him, ≈øaying, Hearken to the voice of the people. And to pre≈ø≈øe to di≈ø≈øwade them froÃÑ that, which he then came to grant vnto them, were a thing very impertinent in a wi≈øe man; much more in the Prophet of the mo≈øt high God. And likewi≈øe, it well appeared in all the cour≈øe of his life after, that his ≈øo long refu≈øing of their ≈øute before came not of any ambition in him: which he well proued in praying, & as it were importuning God for the weale of Saul. Yea, after God had declared his reprobation vnto him, yet he de≈øi≈øted not, while God him≈øelfe was wrath at his praying,
and di≈øcharged his fathers ≈øuit in that errand. And that the≈øe words of Samuel were not vttered as a prophecie of Saul their fir≈øt Kings defection, it well appeareth, as well becau≈øe we heare no mention made in the Scripture of any his tyrannie and oppre≈ø≈øion, (which, if it had beene, would not haue been left vnpainted out therein, as well as his other faults were, as in a trew mirrour of all the Kings behauiours, whom it de≈øcribeth) as likewi≈øe in re≈øpect that Saul was cho≈øen by God for his vertue, and meet qualities to gouerne his people: whereas his defection ≈øprung after-hand from the corruption of his owne nature, & not through any default in God, whom they that thinke ≈øo, would make as a ≈øtep-father to his people, in making wilfully a choi≈øe of the vnmeete≈øt for gouerning them, ≈øince the election of that King lay ab≈øolutely and immediatly in Gods hand. But by the contrary it is plaine, and euident, that this ≈øpeech of Samuel to the people, was to prepare their hearts before the hand to the due obedience of that King, which God was to giue vnto them; and therefore opened vp vnto them, what might be the intollerable qualities that might fall in ≈øome of their kings, thereby preparing them to patience, not to re≈øi≈øt to Gods ordinance: but as he would haue ≈øaid; Since God hath granted your importunate ≈øuit in giuing you a king, as yee haue el≈øe committed an errour in ≈øhaking off Gods yoke, and ouer-ha≈øtie ≈øeeking of a King; ≈øo beware yee fall not into the next, in ca≈øting off al≈øo ra≈øhly that yoke, which God at your earne≈øt ≈øuite hath laid vpon you, how hard that euer it ≈øeeme to be: For as ye could not haue obtained one without the permi≈ø≈øion and ordinance of God, ≈øo may yee no more, fro hee be once ≈øet ouer you, ≈øhake him off without the ≈øame warrant. And therefore in time arme your≈øelues with patience and humilitie, ≈øince he that hath the only power to make him, hath the onely power to vnmake him, and ye onely to obey, bearing with the≈øe ≈øtraits that I now fore≈øhew you, as with the finger of God, which lieth not in you to take off.
And will ye con≈øider the very wordes of the text in order, as they are ≈øet downe, it ≈øhall plainely declare the obedience that the people owe to their King in all re≈øpects.

Fir≈øt, God commandeth Samuel to doe two things: the one, to grant the people their ≈øuit in giuing them a king; the other, to forewarne them, what ≈øome kings will doe vnto them, that they may not thereafter in their grudging and murmuring ≈øay, when they ≈øhal feele the ≈ønares here fore-≈øpoken; We would neuer haue had a king of God, in ca≈øe when we craued him, hee had let vs know how wee would haue beene v≈øed by him, as now we finde but ouer-late. And this is meant by the≈øe words:

p.hi: Now therefore hearken vnto their voice: howbeit yet testifie vnto them, and ≈øhew them the maner of the King that ≈øhall rule ouer them.

div.p: And next, Samuel in execution of this commandement of God, hee likewi≈øe doeth two things.

Fir≈øt, hee declares vnto them, what points of iu≈øtice and equitie their king will breake in his behauiour vnto them: And next he putteth them
out of hope, that wearie as they will, they ≈øhall not haue leaue to ≈øhake off that yoke, which God through their importunitie hath laide vpon them. The points of equitie that the King ≈øhall breake vnto them, are expre≈ø≈øed in the≈øe words:
11 He will take your ≈øonnes, and appoint them to his Charets, and to be his hor≈øemen, and ≈øome ≈øhall run before his Charet.
12 Al≈øo he will make them his captaines ouer thou≈øands, and captaines ouer fifties, and to eare his ground, and to reape his harue≈øt, and to make in≈øtruments of warre, and the things that ≈øerue for his charets.
13 He will al≈øo take your daughters, and make them Apothecaries, and Cookes, and Bakers.

The points of Iu≈øtice, that hee ≈øhall breake vnto them, are expre≈ø≈øed in the≈øe wordes:
14 Hee will take your fields, and your vineyards, and your best Oliue trees, and giue them to his ≈øeruants.
15 And he will take the tenth of your ≈øeede, and of your vineyards, and giue it to his Eunuches and to his ≈øeruants: and al≈øo the tenth of your ≈øheepe.

As if he would ≈øay; The be≈øt and noble≈øt of your blood ≈øhall be compelled in ≈ølaui≈øh and ≈øeruile offices to ≈øerue him: And not content of his owne patrimonie, will make vp a rent to his owne v≈øe out of your be≈øt lands, vineyards, orchards, and ≈øtore of cattell: So as inuerting the Law of nature, and office of a King, your per≈øons and the per≈øons of your po≈øteritie, together with your lands, and all that ye po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe ≈øhal ≈øerue his priuate v≈øe, and inordinate appetite.

And as vnto the next point (which is his fore-warning them, that, weary as they will, they ≈øhall not haue leaue to ≈øhake off the yoke, which God thorow their importunity hath laid vpon them) it is expre≈ø≈øed in the≈øe words:
18 And yee ≈øhall crie out at that day, becau≈øe of your King whom yee haue cho≈øen you: and the Lord will not heare you at that day.

As he would ≈øay; When ye ≈øhall finde the≈øe things in proofe that now I fore-warne you of, although you ≈øhall grudge and murmure, yet it ≈øhal not be lawful to you to ca≈øt it off, in re≈øpect it is not only the ordinance of God, but al≈øo your ≈øelues haue cho≈øen him vnto you, thereby renouncing for euer all priuiledges, by your willing con≈øent out of your hands, whereby in any time hereafter ye would claime, and call backe vnto your ≈øelues againe that power, which God ≈øhall not permit you to doe. And for further taking away of all excu≈øe, and retraction of this their contract, after their con≈øent to vnder-lie this yoke with all the burthens that hee hath declared vnto them, he craues their an≈øwere, and con≈øent to his propo≈øition: which appeareth by their an≈øwere, as it is expre≈ø≈øed in the≈øe words:
19 Nay, but there ≈øhalbe a King ouer vs.
20 And we al≈øo will be like all other nations: and our king ≈øhall iudge vs, and goe out before vs and fight our battels.

As if they would haue ≈øaid; All your ≈øpeeches and hard conditions ≈øhall not skarre vs, but we will take the good and euill of it vpon vs, and we will
be content to beare what≈øoeuer burthen it ≈øhal plea≈øe our King to lay vpon vs, a≈øwell as other nations doe. And for the good we will get of him in fighting our battels, we will more patiently beare any burthen that ≈øhall plea≈øe him to lay on vs.

Now then, ≈øince the erection of this Kingdome and Monarchie among the Iewes, and the law thereof may, and ought to bee a paterne to all Chri≈øtian and well founded Monarchies, as beeing founded by God him≈øelfe, who by his Oracle, and out of his owne mouth gaue the law thereof: what liberty can broiling ≈øpirits, and rebellious minds claime iu≈øtly to again≈øt any Chri≈øtian Monarchie; ≈øince they can claime to no greater libertie on their part, nor the people of God might haue done, and no greater tyranny was euer executed by any Prince or tyrant, whom they can obiect, nor was here fore-warned to the people of God, (and yet all rebellion countermanded vnto them) if tyrannizing ouer mens per≈øons, ≈øonnes, daughters and ≈øeruants; redacting noble hou≈øes, and men, and women of noble blood, to ≈ølaui≈øh and ≈øcruile offices; and extortion, and ≈øpoile of their lands and goods to the princes owne priuate v≈øe and commoditie, and of his courteours, and ≈øeruants, may be called a tyrannie?

And that this propo≈øition grounded vpon the Scripture, may the more clearely appeare to be trew by the practi≈øe often prooued in the ≈øame booke, we neuer reade, that euer the Prophets per≈øwaded the people to rebell again≈øt the Prince, how wicked ≈øoeuer he was.

When Samuel by Gods command pronounced to the ≈øame king Saul, 1. Sam. 15. that his kingdome was rent from him, and giuen to another (which in effect was a degrading of him) yet his next action following that, was peaceably to turne home, and with floods of teares to pray to God to haue ≈øome compa≈ø≈øion vpon him.

And Dauid, notwith≈øtanding hee was inaugurate in that ≈øame degraded Kings roome, not onely (when he was cruelly per≈øecuted, for no offence; but good ≈øeruice done vnto him) would not pre≈øume, hauing him in his power, skantly, but with great reuerence, to touch the garment of the annoynted of the Lord, and in his words ble≈ø≈øed him: but likewi≈øe, 1. Sam. 2 4. 2. Sam. 1. when one came to him vanting him≈øelfe vntrewly to haue ≈ølaine Saul, hee, without forme of proces, or triall of his guilt, cau≈øed onely for guiltine≈ø≈øe of his tongue, put him to ≈øodaine death.

And although there was neuer a more mon≈øtrous per≈øecutor, and tyrant nor Achab was: yet all the rebellion, that Elias euer rai≈øed again≈øt him, was to flie to the wildernes: where for fault of ≈øu≈øtentation, he was fed with the Corbies. And I thinke no man will doubt but Samuel, Dauid, and Elias, had as great power to per≈øwade the people, if they had liked to haue employed their credite to vproares & rebellions again≈øt the≈øe wicked kings, as any of our ≈øeditious preachers in the≈øe daies of what≈øoeuer religion, either in this countrey or in France, had, that bu≈øied them≈øelues mo≈øt to ≈øtir vp rebellion vnder cloake of religion. This farre the only loue of veritie, I prote≈øt, without
hatred at their per≈øons, haue mooued me to be ≈øomewhat ≈øatyricke.

And if any will leane to the extraordinarie examples of degrading or killing of kings in the Scriptures, thereby to cloake the peoples rebellion, as by the deed of Iehu, and ≈øuch like extraordinaries: I an≈øwere, be≈øides that they want the like warrant that they had, if extraordinarie examples of the Scripture ≈øhall bee drawne in daily practi≈øe; murther vnder trai≈øt as in the per≈øons of Ahud, and Iael; theft, as in the per≈øons of the I≈øraelites comming out of Egypt; lying to their parents to the hurt of their brother, as in the per≈øon of Iacob, ≈øhall all be counted as lawfull and allowable vertues, as rebellion again≈øt Princes. And to conclude, the practi≈øe through the whole Scripture prooueth the peoples obedience giuen to that ≈øentence in the law of God: Thou ≈øhalt not rayle vpon the Iudges, neither ≈øpeake euill of the ruler of thy people.

To end then the ground of my propo≈øition taken out of the Scripture, let two ≈øpeciall, and notable examples, one vnder the law, another vnder the Euangel, Ier. 27. conclude this part of my alleageance. Vnder the lawe, Ieremie threatneth the people of God with vtter de≈øtruction for rebellion to Nabuchadnezar the king of Babel: who although he was an idolatrous per≈øecuter, a forraine King, a Tyrant, and v≈øurper of their liberties; yet in re≈øpect they had once receiued and acknowledged him for their king, he not only commandeth them to obey him, Iere. 29. but euen to pray for his pro≈øperitie, adioyning the rea≈øon to it; becau≈øe in his pro≈øperitie ≈øtood their peace.

And vnder the Euangel, that king, whom Paul bids the Romanes obey and ≈øerue for con≈øcience ≈øake, Iere. 13. was Nero that bloody tyrant, an infamie to his aage, and a mon≈øter to the world, being al≈øo an idolatrous per≈øecuter, as the King of Babel was. If then Idolatrie and defection from God, tyranny ouer their people, and per≈øecution of the Saints, for their profe≈ø≈øion ≈øake, hindred not the Spirit of God to command his people vnder all highe≈øt paine to giue them all due and heartie obedience for con≈øcience ≈øake, giuing to Cae≈øar that which was Cae≈øars, and to God that which was Gods, as Chri≈øt ≈øaith; and that this practi≈øe throughout the booke of God agreeth with this lawe, which he made in the erection of that Monarchie (as is at length before deduced) what ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe pre≈øumption is it to any Chri≈øtian people now adayes to claime to that vnlawfull libertie, which God refu≈øed to his owne peculiar and cho≈øen people? Shortly then to take vp in two or three ≈øentences, grounded vpon all the≈øe arguments, out of the lawe of God, the duetie, and alleageance of the people to their lawfull king, their obedience, I ≈øay, ought to be to him, as to Gods Lieutenant in earth, obeying his commands in all things, except directly again≈øt God, as the commands of Gods Mini≈øter, acknowledging him a Iudge ≈øet by GOD ouer them, hauing power to iudge them, but to be iudged onely by GOD, whom to onely hee mu≈øt giue count of his iudgement; fearing him as their Iudge; louing him as their father; praying for him as their protectour; for his continuance, if
he be good; for his amendement, if he be wicked; following and obeying his lawfull commaunds, e≈øchewing and flying his fury in his vnlawfull, without re≈øi≈øtance, but by ≈øobbes and teares to God, according to that ≈øentence v≈øed in the primitiue Church in the time of the per≈øecution.

Now, as for the de≈øcribing the alleageance, that the lieges owe to their natiue King, out of the fundamentall and ciuill Lawe, e≈øpecially of this countrey, as I promi≈øed, the ground mu≈øt fir≈øt be ≈øet downe of the fir≈øt maner of e≈øtabli≈øhing the Lawes and forme of gouernement among vs; that the ground being fir≈øt right laide, we may thereafter build rightly thereupon. Although it be trew (according to the affirmation of tho≈øe that pryde them≈øelues to be the ≈øcourges of Tyrants) that in the fir≈øt beginning of Kings ri≈øing among Gentiles, in the time of the fir≈øt aage, diuers commonwealths and ≈øocieties of men choo≈øed out one among them≈øelues, who for his vertues and valour, being more eminent then the re≈øt, was cho≈øen out by them, and ≈øet vp in that roome, to maintaine the weake≈øt in their right, to throw downe oppre≈ø≈øours, and to fo≈øter and continue the ≈øocietie among men; which could not otherwi≈øe, but by vertue of that vnitie be wel done: yet the≈øe examples are nothing pertinent to vs; becau≈øe our Kingdome and diuers other Monarchies are not in that ca≈øe, but had their beginning in a farre contrary fa≈øhion.

For as our Chronicles beare witne≈ø≈øe, this Ile, and e≈øpecially our part of it, being ≈øcantly inhabited, but by very few, and they as barbarous and ≈øcant of ciuilitie, as number, there comes our fir≈øt King Fergus, with a great number with him, out of Ireland, which was long inhabited before vs, and making him≈øelfe ma≈øter of the countrey, by his owne friend≈øhip, and force, as well of the Ireland-men that came with him, as of the countrey-men that willingly fell to him, hee made him≈øelfe King and Lord, as well of the whole landes, as of the whole inhabitants within the ≈øame. Thereafter he and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, a long while after their being Kinges, made and e≈øtabli≈øhed their lawes from time to time, and as the occa≈øion required. So the trewth is directly contrarie in our ≈øtate to the fal≈øe affirmation of ≈øuch ≈øeditious writers, as would per≈øwade vs, that the Lawes and ≈øtate of our countrey were e≈øtabli≈øhed before the admitting of a king: where by the contrarie ye ≈øee it plainely prooued, that a wi≈øe king comming in among barbares, fir≈øt e≈øtabli≈øhed the e≈øtate and forme of gouernement, and thereafter made lawes by him≈øelfe, and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øours according thereto.

The kings therefore in Scotland were before any e≈øtates or rankes of men within the ≈øame, before any Parliaments were holden, or lawes made: and by them was the land di≈øtributed (which at the fir≈øt was whole theirs) ≈øtates erected and decerned, and formes of gouernement deui≈øed and e≈øtabli≈øhed: And ≈øo it followes of nece≈ø≈øitie, that the kings were the authors and makers of the Lawes, and not the Lawes of the kings. And to prooue this my a≈ø≈øertion more clearly, it is euident by the rolles of our Chancellery
(which containe our elde≈øt and fundamentall Lawes) that the King is Dominus omnium bonorum, and Dominus directus totius Dominij, the whole ≈øubiects being but his va≈ø≈øals, and from him holding all their lands as their ouer-lord, who according to good ≈øeruices done vnto him, chaungeth their holdings from tacke to few, from ward to blanch, erecteth new Baronies, and vniteth olde, without aduice or authoritie of either Parliament, or any other ≈øubalterin iudiciall ≈øeate: So as if wrong might bee admitted in play (albeit I grant wrong ≈øhould be wrong in all per≈øons) the King might haue a better colour for his plea≈øure, without further rea≈øon, to take the land from his lieges, as ouer-lord of the whole, and doe with it as plea≈øeth him, ≈øince all that they hold is of him, then, as fooli≈øh writers ≈øay, the people might vnmake the king, and put an other in his roome: But either of them as vnlawful, and again≈øt the ordinance of God, ought to be alike odious to be thought, much le≈ø≈øe put in practi≈øe.

And according to the≈øe fundamentall Lawes already alledged, we daily ≈øee that in the Parliament (which is nothing el≈øe but the head Court of the king and his va≈ø≈øals) the lawes are but craued by his ≈øubiects, and onely made by him at their rogation, and with their aduice: For albeit the king make daily ≈øtatutes and ordinances, enioyning ≈øuch paines thereto as hee thinkes meet, without any aduice of Parliament or e≈øtates; yet it lies in the power of no Parliament, to make any kinde of Lawe or Statute, without his Scepter be to it, for giuing it the force of a Law: And although diuers changes haue beene in other countries of the blood Royall, and kingly hou≈øe, the kingdome being reft by conque≈øt from one to another, as in our neighbour countrey in England, (which was neuer in ours) yet the ≈øame ground of the kings right ouer all the land, and ≈øubiects thereof remaineth alike in all other free Monarchies, as well as in this: For when the Ba≈øtard of Normandie came into England, and made him≈øelfe king, was it not by force, and with a mighty army? Where he gaue the Law, and tooke none, changed the Lawes, inuerted the order of gouernement, ≈øet downe the ≈øtrangers his followers in many of the old po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øours roomes, as at this day well appeareth a great part of the Gentlemen in England, beeing come of the Norman blood, and their old Lawes, which to this day they are ruled by, are written in his language, and not in theirs: And yet his ≈øucce≈ø≈øours haue with great happine≈ø≈øe enioyed the Crowne to this day; Whereof the like was al≈øo done by all them that conque≈øted them before.

And for conclu≈øion of this point, that the king is ouer-lord ouer the whole lands, it is likewi≈øe daily proued by the Law of our hoordes, of want of Heires, and of Ba≈øtardies: For if a hoord be found vnder the earth, becau≈øe it is no more in the keeping or v≈øe of any per≈øon, it of the law pertains to the king. If a per≈øon, inheritour of any lands or goods, dye without any ≈øort of heires, all his landes and goods returne to the king. And if a ba≈øtard die vnrehabled without heires of his bodie (which rehabling onely lyes in the kings hands) all that hee hath likewi≈øe returnes to the king.
And as ye ≈øee it manife≈øt, that the King is ouer-Lord of the whole land: ≈øo is he Ma≈øter ouer euery per≈øon that inhabiteth the ≈øame, hauing power ouer the life and death of euery one of them: For although a iu≈øt Prince will not take the life of any of his ≈øubiects without a cleare law; yet the ≈øame lawes whereby he taketh them, are made by him≈øelfe, or his predece≈ø≈øours; and ≈øo the power flowes alwaies from him ≈øelfe; as by daily experience we ≈øee, good and iu≈øt Princes will from time to time make new lawes and ≈øtatutes, adioyning the penalties to the breakers thereof, which before the law was made, had beene no crime to the ≈øubiect to haue committed. Not that I deny the old definition of a King, and of a law; which makes the king to bee a ≈øpeaking law, and the Law a dumbe king: for certainely a king that gouernes not by his lawe, can neither be countable to God for his admini≈øtration, nor haue a happy and e≈øtabli≈øhed raigne: For albeit it be trew that I haue at length prooued, that the King is aboue the law, as both the author and giuer of ≈øtrength thereto; yet a good king will not onely delight to rule his ≈øubiects by the lawe, but euen will conforme him≈øelfe in his owne actions thereuneto, alwaies keeping that ground, that the health of the common-wealth be his chiefe lawe: And where he ≈øees the lawe doubt≈øome or rigorous, hee may interpret or mitigate the ≈øame, le≈øt otherwi≈øe Summum ius bee ≈øumma iniuria: And therefore generall lawes, made publikely in Parliament, may vpon knowen re≈øpects to the King by his authoritie bee mitigated, and ≈øu≈øpended vpon cau≈øes onely knowen to him.

As likewi≈øe, although I haue ≈øaid, a good king will frame all his actions to be according to the Law; yet is hee not bound thereto but of his good will, and for good example-giuing to his ≈øubiects: For as in the law of ab≈øtaining from eating of fle≈øh in Lenton, the king will, for examples ≈øake, make his owne hou≈øe to ob≈øerue the Law; yet no man will thinke he needs to take a licence to eate fle≈øh. And although by our Lawes, the bearing and wearing of hag-buts, and pi≈øtolets be forbidden, yet no man can find any fault in the King, for cau≈øing his traine v≈øe them in any raide vpon the Borderers, or other malefactours or rebellious ≈øubiects. So as I haue alreadie ≈øaid, a good King, although hee be aboue the Law, will ≈øubiect and frame his actions thereto, for examples ≈øake to his ≈øubiects, and of his owne freewill, but not as ≈øubiect or bound thereto.

Since I haue ≈øo clearely prooued then out of the fundamentall lawes and practi≈øe of this country, what right & power a king hath ouer his land and ≈øubiects, it is ea≈øie to be vnder≈øtood, what allegeance & obedience his lieges owe vnto him; I meane alwaies of ≈øuch free Monarchies as our king is, and not of electiue kings, and much le≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch ≈øort of gouernors, as the dukes of Venice are, who≈øe Ari≈øtocratick and limited gouernment, is nothing like to free Monarchies; although the malice of ≈øome writers hath not beene a≈øhamed to mis-know any difference to be betwixt them. And if it be not lawfull to any particular Lordes tenants or va≈ø≈øals, vpon what≈øoeuer
pretext, to controll and di≈øplace their Ma≈øter, and ouer-lord (as is clearer nor the Sunne by all Lawes of the world) how much le≈ø≈øe may the ≈øubiects and va≈ø≈øals of the great ouer-lord the KING controll or di≈øplace him? And ≈øince in all inferiour iudgements in the land, the people may not vpon any re≈øpects di≈øplace their Magi≈øtrates, although but ≈øubaltern: for the people of a borough, cannot di≈øplace their Prouo≈øt before the time of their election: nor in Eccle≈øia≈øticall policie the flocke can vpon any pretence di≈øplace the Pa≈øtor, nor iudge of him: yea euen the poore Schoolema≈øter cannot be di≈øplaced by his ≈øchollers: If the≈øe, I ≈øay (whereof ≈øome are but inferiour, ≈øubaltern, and temporall Magi≈øtrates, and none of them equall in any ≈øort to the dignitie of a King) cannot be di≈øplaced for any occa≈øion or pretext by them that are ruled by them: how much le≈ø≈øe is it lawfull vpon any pretext to controll or di≈øplace the great Prouo≈øt, and great Schoole-ma≈øter of the whole land: except by inuerting the order of all Law and rea≈øon, the commanded may be made to command their commander, the iudged to iudge their Iudge, and they that are gouerned, to gouerne their time about their Lord and gouernour.

And the agreement of the Law of nature in this our ground with the Lawes and con≈øtitutions of God, and man, already alledged, will by two ≈øimilitudes ea≈øily appeare. The King towards his people is rightly compared to a father of children, and to a head of a body compo≈øed of diuers members: For as fathers, the good Princes, and Magi≈øtrates of the people of God acknowledged them≈øelues to their ≈øubiects. And for all other well ruled Common-wealths, the ≈øtile of Pater patriae was euer, and is commonly v≈øed to Kings. And the proper office of a King towards his Subiects, agrees very wel with the office of the head towards the body, and all members thereof: For from the head, being the ≈øeate of Iudgement, proceedeth the care and fore≈øight of guiding, and preuenting all euill that may come to the body or any part thereof. The head cares for the body, ≈øo doeth the King for his people. As the di≈øcour≈øe and direction flowes from the head, and the execution according thereunto belongs to the re≈øt of the members, euery one according to their office: ≈øo is it betwixt a wi≈øe Prince, and his people. As the iudgement comming from the head may not onely imploy the members, euery one in their owne office, as long as they are able for it; but likewi≈øe in ca≈øe any of them be affected with any infirmitie mu≈øt care and prouide for their remedy, in-ca≈øe it be curable, and if otherwi≈øe, gar cut them off for feare of infecting of the re≈øt: euen ≈øo is it betwixt the Prince, and his people. And as there is euer hope of curing any di≈øea≈øed member by the direction of the head, as long as it is whole; but by the contrary, if it be troubled, all the members are partakers of that paine, ≈øo is it betwixt the Prince and his people.

And now fir≈øt for the fathers part (who≈øe naturall loue to his children I de≈øcribed in the fir≈øt part of this my di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øpeaking of the dutie that Kings owe to their Subiects) con≈øider, I pray you what duetie his children
owe to him, & whether vpoÃÑ any pretext what≈øoeuer, it wil not be thought mon≈øtrous and vnnaturall to his ≈øons, to ri≈øe vp again≈øt him, to control him at their appetite, and when they thinke good to ≈øley him, or to cut him off, and adopt to them≈øelues any other they plea≈øe in his roome: Or can any pretence of wickednes or rigor on his part be a iu≈øt excu≈øe for his children to put hand into him? And although wee ≈øee by the cour≈øe of nature, that loue v≈øeth to de≈øcend more then to a≈øcend, in ca≈øe it were trew, that the father hated and wronged the children neuer ≈øo much, will any man, endued with the lea≈øt ≈øponke of rea≈øon, thinke it lawfull for them to meet him with the line? Yea, ≈øuppo≈øe the father were furiou≈øly following his ≈øonnes with a drawen ≈øword, is it lawfull for them to turne and ≈øtrike againe, or make any re≈øi≈øtance but by flight? And for the ≈øimilitude of the head and the body, it may very well fall out that the head will be forced to garre cut off ≈øome rotten member (as I haue already ≈øaid) to keepe the re≈øt of the body in integritie: but what ≈øtate the body can be in, if the head, for any infirmitie that can fall to it, be cut off, I leaue it to the readers iudgement.

So as (to conclude this part) if the children may vpon any pretext that can be imagined, lawfully ri≈øe vp again≈øt their Father, cut him off, & choo≈øe any other whom they plea≈øe in his roome; and if the body for the weale of it, may for any infirmitie that can be in the head, ≈øtrike it off, then I cannot deny that the people may rebell, controll, and di≈øplace, or cut off their king at their owne plea≈øure, and vpon re≈øpects moouing them. And whether the≈øe ≈øimilitudes repre≈øent better the office of a King, or the offices of Ma≈øters or Deacons of crafts, or Doctors in Phy≈øicke (which iolly compari≈øons are v≈øed by ≈øuch writers as maintaine the contrary propo≈øition) I leaue it al≈øo to the readers di≈øcretion.

And in ca≈øe any doubts might ari≈øe in any part of this treati≈øe, I wil (according to my promi≈øe) with the ≈øolution of foure principall and mo≈øt weightie doubts, that the aduer≈øaries may obiect, conclude this di≈øcour≈øe. And fir≈øt it is ca≈øten vp by diuers, that employ their pennes vpon Apologies for rebellions and trea≈øons that euery man is borne to carry ≈øuch a naturall zeale and duety to his common-wealth, as to his mother; that ≈øeeing it ≈øo rent and deadly wounded, as whiles it will be by wicked and tyrannous Kings, good Citizens will be forced, for the naturall zeale and duety
they owe to their owne natiue countrey, to put their hand to worke for freeing their common-wealth from ≈øuch a pe≈øt.

Whereunto I giue two an≈øweres: Fir≈øt, it is a ≈øure Axiome in Theologie, that euill ≈øhould not be done, that good may come of it: The wickedne≈ø≈øe therefore of the King can neuer make them that are ordained to be iudged by him, to become his Iudges. And if it be not lawfull to a priuate man to reuenge his priuate iniury vpon his priuate aduer≈øary (≈øince God hath onely giuen the ≈øword to the Magi≈øtrate) how much le≈ø≈øe is it lawfull to the people, or any part of them (who all are but priuate men, the authoritie being alwayes with the Magi≈øtrate, as I haue already proued) to take vpon them the v≈øe of the ≈øword, whom to it belongs not, again≈øt the publicke Magi≈øtrate, whom to onely it belongeth.

Next, in place of relieuing the common-wealth out of di≈øtre≈ø≈øe (which is their onely excu≈øe and colour) they ≈øhall heape double di≈øtre≈ø≈øe and de≈øolation vpon it; and ≈øo their rebellion ≈øhall procure the contrary effects that they pretend it for: For a king cannot be imagined to be ≈øo vnruly and tyrannous, but the common-wealth will be kept in better order, notwith≈øtanding thereof, by him, then it can be by his way-taking. For fir≈øt, all ≈øudden mutations are perillous in common-wealths, hope being thereby giuen to all bare men to ≈øet vp them≈øelues, and flie with other mens feathers, the reines being loo≈øed to all the in≈øolencies that di≈øordered people can commit by hope of impunitie, becau≈øe of the loo≈øene≈ø≈øe of all things.

And next, it is certaine that a king can neuer be ≈øo mon≈øtrou≈øly vicious, but hee will generally fauour iu≈øtice, and maintaine ≈øome order, except in the particulars, wherein his inordinate lu≈øtes and pa≈ø≈øions cary him away; where by the contrary, no King being, nothing is vnlawfull to none: And ≈øo the olde opinion of the Philo≈øophers prooues trew, That better it is to liue in a Common-wealth, where nothing is lawfull, then where all things are lawfull to all men; the Common-wealth at that time re≈øembling an vndanted young hor≈øe that hath ca≈øten his rider: For as the diuine Poet DV BARTAS ≈øayth, Better it were to ≈øuffer ≈øome di≈øorder in the e≈øtate, and ≈øome ≈øpots in the Common-wealth, then in pretending to reforme, vtterly to ouerthrow the Republicke.

The ≈øecond obiection they ground vpon the cur≈øe that hangs ouer the common-wealth, where a wicked king reigneth: and, ≈øay they, there cannot be a more acceptable deed in the ≈øight of God, nor more dutiful to their common-weale, then to free the countrey of ≈øuch a cur≈øe, and vindicate to them their libertie, which is naturall to all creatures to craue.
