Whereunto for an≈øwere, I grant indeed, that a wicked king is ≈øent by God for a cur≈øe to his people, and a plague for their ≈øinnes: but that it is lawfull to them to ≈øhake off that cur≈øe at their owne hand, which God hath laid on them, that I deny, and may ≈øo do iu≈øtly. Will any deny that the king of Babel was a cur≈øe to the people of God, as was plainly fore-≈øpoken and threatned vnto them in the prophecie of their captiuitie? And what was Nero to
the Chri≈øtian Church in his time? And yet Ieremy and Paul (as yee haue el≈øe heard) commanded them not onely to obey them, but heartily to pray for their welfare.

It is certaine then (as I haue already by the Law of God ≈øufficiently proued) that patience, earne≈øt prayers to God, and amendment of their liues, are the onely lawful meanes to moue God to relieue them of that heauie cur≈øe. As for vindicating to them≈øelues their owne libertie, what lawfull power haue they to reuoke to them≈øelues againe tho≈øe priuiledges, which by their owne con≈øent before were ≈øo fully put out of their hands? for if a Prince cannot iu≈øtly bring backe againe to him≈øelf the priuiledges once be≈øtowed by him or his predece≈ø≈øors vpon any ≈øtate or ranke of his ≈øubiects; how much le≈ø≈øe may the ≈øubiects reaue out of the princes hand that ≈øuperioritie, which he and his Predece≈ø≈øors haue ≈øo long brooked ouer them?

But the vnhappy iniquitie of the time, which hath oft times giuen ouer good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to their trea≈øonable attempts, furni≈øheth them the ground of their third obiection: For, ≈øay they, the fortunate ≈øucce≈ø≈øe that God hath ≈øo oft giuen to ≈øuch enterpri≈øes, prooueth plainely by the practi≈øe, that God fauoured the iu≈øtne≈ø≈øe of their quarrell.

To the which I an≈øwere, that it is trew indeed, that all the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of battels, as well as other worldly things, lyeth onely in Gods hand: And therefore it is that in the Scripture he takes to him≈øelfe the ≈øtyle of God of Ho≈øts. But vpon that generall to conclude, that hee euer giues victory to the iu≈øt quarrell, would prooue the Philistims, and diuers other neighbour enemies of the people of God to haue oft times had the iu≈øt quarrel again≈øt the people of God, in re≈øpect of the many victories they obtained again≈øt them. And by that ≈øame argument they had al≈øo iu≈øt quarrell again≈øt the Arke of God: For they wan it in the field, and kept it long pri≈øoner in their countrey. As likewi≈øe by all good Writers, as well Theologues, as other, the Duels and ≈øingular combats are di≈øallowed; which are onely made vpon pretence, that GOD will kith thereby the iu≈øtice of the quarrell: For wee mu≈øt con≈øider that the innocent partie is not innocent before God: And therefore God will make oft times them that haue the wrong ≈øide reuenge iu≈øtly his quarrell; and when he hath done, ca≈øt his ≈øcourge in the fire; as he oft times did to his owne people, ≈øtirring vp and ≈øtrengthening their enemies, while they were humbled in his ≈øight, and then deliuered them in their hands. So God, as the great Iudge may iu≈øtly puni≈øh his Deputie, and for his rebellion again≈øt him, ≈øtir vp his rebels to meet him with the like: And when it is done, the part of the in≈øtrument is no better then the diuels part is in tempting and torturing ≈øuch as God committeth to him as his hangman to doe: Therefore, as I ≈øaid in the beginning, it is oft times a very deceiueable argument, to iudge of the cau≈øe by the euent.

And the la≈øt obiection is grounded vpon the mutuall paction and ad≈øtipulation (as they call it) betwixt the King and his people, at the time of his coronation: For there, ≈øay they, there is a mutuall paction, and contract
bound vp, and ≈øworne betwixt the king, and the people: Whereupon it followeth, that if the one part of the contract or the Indent bee broken vpon the Kings ≈øide, the people are no longer bound to keepe their part of it, but are thereby freed of their oath: For (≈øay they) a contract betwixt two parties, of all Law frees the one partie, if the other breake vnto him.

As to this contract alledged made at the coronation of a King, although I deny any ≈øuch contract to bee made then, e≈øpecially containing ≈øuch a clau≈øe irritant as they alledge; yet I confe≈ø≈øe, that a king at his coronation, or at the entry to his kingdome, willingly promi≈øeth to his people, to di≈øcharge honorably and trewly the office giuen him by God ouer them: But pre≈øuming that thereafter he breake his promi≈øe vnto them neuer ≈øo inexcu≈øable; the que≈øtion is, who ≈øhould bee iudge of the breake, giuing vnto them, this contractwere made vnto them neuer ≈øo ≈øicker, according to their alleageance. I thinke no man that hath but the ≈ømalle≈øt entrance into the ciuill Law, will doubt that of all Law, either ciuil or municipal of any nation, a contract cannot be thought broken by the one partie, and ≈øo the other likewi≈øe to be freed therefro, except that fir≈øt a lawfull triall and cognition be had by the ordinary Iudge of the breakers thereof: Or el≈øe euery man may be both party and Iudge in his owne cau≈øe; which is ab≈øurd once to be thought. Now in this contract (I ≈øay) betwixt the king and his people, God is doubtles the only Iudge, both becau≈øe to him onely the king mu≈øt make count of his admini≈øtration (as is oft ≈øaid before) as likewi≈øe by the oath in the coronation, God is made iudge and reuenger of the breakers: For in his pre≈øence, as only iudge of oaths, all oaths ought to be made. Then ≈øince God is the onely Iudge betwixt the two parties contractors, the cognition and reuenge mu≈øt onely appertaine to him: It followes therefore of nece≈ø≈øitie, that God mu≈øt fir≈øt giue ≈øentence vpon the King that breaketh, before the people can thinke them≈øelues freed of their oath. What iu≈øtice then is it, that the partie ≈øhall be both iudge and partie, v≈øurping vpon him≈øelfe the office of God, may by this argument ea≈øily appeare: And ≈øhall it lie in the hands of headle≈ø≈øe multitude, when they plea≈øe to weary off ≈øubiection, to ca≈øt off the yoake of gouernement that God hath laid vpon them; to iudge and puni≈øh him, whom-by they ≈øhould be iudged and puni≈øhed; and in that ca≈øe, wherein by their violence they kythe them≈øelues to be mo≈øt pa≈ø≈øionate parties, to v≈øe the office of an vngracious Iudge or Arbiter? Nay, to ≈øpeake trewly of that ca≈øe, as it ≈øtands betwixt the king and his people, none of them ought to iudge of the others breake: For con≈øidering rightly the two parties at the time of their mutuall promi≈øe, the king is the one party, and the whole people in one body are the other party. And therfore ≈øince it is certaine, that a king, in ca≈øe ≈øo it ≈øhould fal out, that his people in one body had rebelled again≈øt him, hee ≈øhould not in that ca≈øe, as thinking him≈øelfe free of his promi≈øe and oath; become an vtter enemy, and practi≈øe the wreake of his whole people and natiue country: although he ought iu≈øtly to puni≈øh the principall authours and bellowes of that vniuer≈øall rebellion:
how much le≈ø≈øe then ought the people (that are alwaies ≈øubiect vnto him, and naked of all authoritie on their part) pre≈ø≈øe to iudge and ouerthrow him? otherwi≈øe the people, as the one partie contracters, ≈øhall no ≈øooner challenge the king as breaker, but hee a≈ø≈øoone ≈øhall iudge them as breakers: ≈øo as the victors making the tyners the traitors (as our prouerbe is) the partie ≈øhall aye become both iudge and partie in his owne particular, as I haue alreadie ≈øaid.

And it is here likewi≈øe to be noted, that the duty and alleageance, which the people ≈øweareth to their prince, is not only bound to them≈øelues, but likewi≈øe to their lawfull heires and po≈øterity, the lineall ≈øucce≈ø≈øioÃÑ of crowns being begun among the people of God, and happily continued in diuers chri≈øtian common-wealths: So as no obiection either of here≈øie, or what≈øoeuer priuate ≈øtatute or law may free the people from their oath-giuing to their king, and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, e≈øtabli≈øhed by the old fundamentall lawes of the kingdome: For, as hee is their heritable ouer-lord, and ≈øo by birth, not by any right in the coronation, commeth to his crowne, it is a like vnlawful (the crowne euer ≈øtanding full) to di≈øplace him that ≈øucceedeth thereto, as to eiect the former: For at the very moment of the expiring of the king reigning, the neare≈øt and lawful heire entreth in his place: And ≈øo to refu≈øe him, or intrude another, is not to holde out vncomming in, but to expell and put out their righteous King. And I tru≈øt at this time whole France acknowledgeth the ≈øuper≈øtitious rebellion of the liguers, who vpon pretence of here≈øie, by force of armes held ≈øo long out, to the great de≈øolation of their whole countrey, their natiue and righteous king from po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing of his owne crowne and naturall kingdome.

Not that by all this former di≈øcour≈øe of mine, and Apologie for kings, I meane that what≈øoeuer errors and intollerable abominations a ≈øouereigne prince commit, hee ought to e≈øcape all puni≈øhment, as if thereby the world were only ordained for kings, & they without controlment to turne it vp≈øide down at their plea≈øure: but by the contrary, by remitting them to God (who is their onely ordinary Iudge) I remit them to the ≈øoreit and ≈øharpe≈øt ≈øchoolema≈øter that can be deui≈øed for them: for the further a king is preferred by God aboue all other ranks & degrees of men, and the higher that his ≈øeat is aboue theirs, the greater is his obligation to his maker. And therfore in ca≈øe he forget him≈øelfe (his vnthankfulnes being in the ≈øame mea≈øure of height) the ≈øadder and ≈øharper will his correction be; and according to the greatnes of the height he is in, the weight of his fall wil recoÃÑpen≈øe the ≈øame: for the further that any per≈øon is obliged to God, his offence becomes and growes ≈øo much the greater, then it would be in any other. Ioues thunderclaps light oftner and ≈øorer vpon the high & ≈øtately oakes, then on the low and ≈øupple willow trees: and the highe≈øt bench is ≈øliddrie≈øt to ≈øit vpon. Neither is it euer heard that any king forgets him≈øelfe towards God, or in his vocation; but God with the greatne≈ø≈øe of the plague reuengeth the greatnes of his ingratitude: Neither thinke I by the force and argument
of this my di≈øcour≈øe ≈øo to per≈øwade the people, that none will hereafter be rai≈øed vp, and rebell again≈øt wicked Princes. But remitting to the iu≈øtice and prouidence of God to ≈øtirre vp ≈øuch ≈øcourges as plea≈øeth him, for puni≈øhment of wicked kings (who made the very vermine and filthy du≈øt of the earth to bridle the in≈øolencie of proud Pharaoh) my onely purpo≈øe and intention in this treati≈øe is to per≈øwade, as farre as lieth in me, by the≈øe ≈øure and infallible grounds, all ≈øuch good Chri≈øtian readers, as beare not onely the naked name of a Chri≈øtian, but kith the fruites thereof in their daily forme of life, to keepe their hearts and hands free from ≈øuch mon≈øtrous and vnnaturall rebellions, when≈øoeuer the wickedne≈ø≈øe of a Prince ≈øhall procure the ≈øame at Gods hands: that, when it ≈øhall plea≈øe God to ca≈øt ≈øuch ≈øcourges of princes, and in≈øtruments of his fury in the fire, ye may ≈øtand vp with cleane handes, and vn≈øpotted con≈øciences, hauing prooued your ≈øelues in all your actions trew Chri≈øtians toward God, and dutifull ≈øubiects towards your King, hauing remitted the iudgement and puni≈øhment of all his wrongs to him, whom to onely of right it appertaineth.

But crauing at God, and hoping that God ≈øhall continue his ble≈ø≈øing with vs, in not ≈øending ≈øuch fearefull de≈øolation, I heartily wi≈øh our kings behauiour ≈øo to be, and continue among vs, as our God in earth, and louing Father, endued with ≈øuch properties as I de≈øcribed a King in the fir≈øt part of this Treati≈øe. And that ye (my deare countreymen, and charitable readers) may pre≈ø≈øe by all meanes to procure the pro≈øperitie and welfare of your King; that as hee mu≈øt on the one part thinke all his earthly felicitie and happine≈ø≈øe grounded vpon your weale, caring more for him≈øelfe for your ≈øake then for his owne, thinking him≈øelfe onely ordained for your weale; ≈øuch holy and happy emulation may ari≈øe betwixt him and you, as his care for your quietnes, and your care for his honour and pre≈øeruation, may in all your actions daily ≈øtriue together, that the Land may thinke them≈øelues ble≈ø≈øed with ≈øuch a King, and the king may thinke him≈øelfe mo≈øt happy in ruling ouer ≈øo louing and obedient ≈øubiects.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
AS euery humane body (deare Countrey men) how whole≈øome ≈øoeuer, is notwith≈øtanding ≈øubiect, or at lea≈øt naturally inclined to ≈øome ≈øorts of di≈øea≈øes, or infirmities: ≈øo is there no Common-wealth, or Body-politicke, how well gouerned, or peaceable ≈øoeuer it be, that lackes the owne popular errors, and naturally inclined corruptions: and therefore is it no wonder, although this our Countrey and Common-wealth, though peaceable, though wealthy, though long flouri≈øhing in both, be amongst the rest, ≈øubiect to the owne naturall infirmities. We are of all Nations the people most louing, and mo≈øt reuerently obedient to our Prince, yet are we (as time hath often borne witne≈ø≈øe) too ea≈øie to be ≈øeduced to make Rebellion vpon very ≈ølight grounds. Our fortunate and oft proued valour in warres abroad, our heartie and reuerent obedience to our Princes at home, hath bred vs a long, and a thrice happie peace: Our peace hath bread wealth: And peace and wealth hath brought forth a generall ≈øluggi≈øhne≈ø≈øe, which makes vs wallow in all ≈øorts of idle delights, and ≈øoft delicacies, the fir≈øt
≈øeeds of the ≈øubuer≈øion of all great Monarchies. Our Cleargie are become negligent and lazie, Our Nobilitie and Gentrie prodigall, and ≈øold to their priuate delights, Our Lawyers couetous, Our Common people prodigall and curious; and generally all ≈øorts of people more carefull for their priuate ends, then for their mother the Common-wealth.

For remedie whereof, it is the Kings part (as the proper Phi≈øician of his Politicke-bodie) to purge it of all tho≈øe di≈øea≈øes, by Medicines meete for the ≈øame: as by a certaine milde, and yet iust forme of gouernment, to maintaine the Publicke quietne≈øse, and preuent all occa≈øions of Commotion: by the example of his owne Per≈øon and Court, to make vs all a≈øhamed of our ≈øluggi≈øh delicacie, and to ≈øtirre vs vp to the practi≈øe againe of all hone≈øt exerci≈øes, and Martiall ≈øhadowes of Warre; As likewi≈øe by his, and his Courts moderatene≈øse in Apparell, to make vs a≈øhamed of our prodigalitie: By his quicke admonitions and carefull ouer≈øeeing of the Cleargie, to waken them vp againe, to be more diligent in their Offices: By the ≈øharpe triall, and ≈øeuere puni≈øhment of the partiall, couetous and bribing Lawyers, to reforme their corruptions: And generally by the example of his owne Per≈øon, and by the due execution of good Lawes, to reforme and aboli≈øh, piece and piece, the≈øe olde and euill grounded abu≈øes: For this will not be Opus vnius diei, but as euery one of the≈øe di≈øea≈øes, must from the King receiue the owne cure proper for it, ≈øo are there ≈øome ≈øorts of abu≈øes in Common-wealths, that though they bee of ≈øo ba≈øe and contemptible a condition, as they are too low for the Law to looke on, and to meane for a King to interpone his authoritie, or bend his eye vpon; yet are they corruptions, a≈øwell as the greatest of them. So is an Ant an Animal, a≈øwell as an Elephant: ≈øo is a Wrenne Auis, a≈øwell as a Swanne, and ≈øo is a ≈ømall dint of the Tooth-ake, a di≈øea≈øe a≈øwell as the fearefull Plague is. But for the≈øe ba≈øe ≈øorts of corruption in Common-wealths, not onely the King, or any inferiour Magi≈øtrate, but Quilibet √® populo may ≈øerue to be a Phi≈øician, by di≈øcouering and impugning the error, and by per≈øwading reformation thereof.

And ≈øurely in my opinion, there cannot bee a more ba≈øe, and yet hurtfull, corruption in a Countrey, then is the vile v≈øe (or rather abu≈øe) of taking Tobacco in this Kingdome, which hath mooued mee, ≈øhortly to di≈øcouer the abu≈øes thereof in this following little Pamphlet.

Jf any thinke it a light Argument, ≈øo is it but a toy that is be≈øtowed vpon it. And ≈øince the Subiect is but of Smoke, J thinke the fume of an idle braine, may ≈øerue for a ≈øufficient batterie against ≈øo fumous and feeble an enemie. Jf my grounds bee found trew, it is all J looke for; but if they cary the force of per≈øwa≈øion with them, it is all J can wi≈øh, and more then I can expect. My onely care is, that you, my deare Countrey-men, may rightly conceiue euen by this ≈ømallest trifle, of the ≈øinceritie of my meaning in greater matters, neuer to ≈øpare any paine, that may tend to the procuring of your weale and pro≈øperitie.

div.head: A COVNTERBLASTE TO TOBACCO.
div.p: THat the manifold abu≈øes of this vile cu≈øtome of Tobacco taking, may the better be e≈øpied, it is fit, that fir≈øt you enter into con≈øideration both of the fir≈øt originall thereof, and likewi≈øe of the rea≈øons of the fir≈øt entry thereof into this Countrey. For certainely as ≈øuch cu≈øtomes, that haue their fir≈øt in≈øtitution either from a godly, nece≈ø≈øary, or honourable ground, and are fir≈øt brought in, by the meanes of ≈øome worthy, vertuous, and great Per≈øonage, are euer, and mo≈øt iu≈øtly, holden in great and reuerent e≈øtimation and account, by all wi≈øe, vertuous, and temperate ≈øpirits: So ≈øhould it by the contrary, iu≈øtly bring a great di≈øgrace into that ≈øort of cu≈øtomes, which hauing their originall from ba≈øe corruption and barbaritie, doe in like ≈øort, make their fir≈øt entry into a Countrey, by an incon≈øiderate and childi≈øh affectation of Noueltie, as is the trew ca≈øe of the fir≈øt inuention of Tobacco taking, and of the fir≈øt entry thereof among vs. For Tobacco being a common herbe, which (though vnder diuers names) growes almo≈øt euery where, was fir≈øt found out by ≈øome of the barbarous Indians, to be a Pre≈øeruatiue or Antidote again≈øt the Pocks, a filthy di≈øea≈øe, wherunto the≈øe barbarous people are (as all men know) very much ≈øubiect, what through the vncleanely and adu≈øt con≈øtitution of their bodies, and what through the intemperate heate of their Climate: ≈øo that as from them was fir≈øt brought into Chri≈øtendome, that mo≈øt dete≈øtable di≈øea≈øe; ≈øo from them likewi≈øe was brought this v≈øe of Tobacco, as a ≈øtinking and vn≈øauourie Antidote, for ≈øo corrupted and execrable a maladie, the ≈øtinking ≈øuffumigation whereof they yet v≈øe again≈øt that di≈øea≈øe, making ≈øo one canker or venime to eate out another.

And now good Countrey-men, let vs (I pray you) con≈øider, what honour or policy can mooue vs to imitate the barbarous and bea≈øtly maners of the wilde, godle≈ø≈øe, and ≈ølaui≈øh Indians, e≈øpecially in ≈øo vile and ≈øtinking a cu≈øtome? Shall we that di≈ødaine to imitate the maners of our neighbour
France (hauing the ≈øtile of the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Kingdome) and that cannot endure the ≈øpirit of the Spaniards (their King being now comparable in largene≈ø≈øe of Dominions, to the great Emperour of Turkie) Shall wee, I ≈øay, that haue bene ≈øo long ciuill and wealthy in Peace, famous and inuincible in Warre, fortunate in both, we that haue bene euer able to aide any of our neighbours (but neuer deafed any of their eares with any of our ≈øupplications for a≈ø≈øi≈øtance) ≈øhall wee, I ≈øay, without blu≈øhing aba≈øe our ≈øelues ≈øo farre, as to imitate the≈øe bea≈øtly Indians, ≈ølaues to the Spaniards, refu≈øe to the world, and as yet aliens from the holy Couenant of God? Why doe we not as well imitate them in walking naked as they doe? in preferring gla≈ø≈øes, feathers, and ≈øuch toyes, to gold and precious ≈øtones, as they doe? yea why doe we not denie God and adore the diuel, as they doe?

Now to the corrupted ba≈øene≈ø≈øe of the fir≈øt v≈øe of this Tobacco, doeth very well agree the fooli≈øh and groundle≈ø≈øe fir≈øt entry thereof into this Kingdome. It is not ≈øo long ≈øince the fir≈øt entry of this abu≈øe among≈øt vs here, as this pre≈øent aage cannot yet very well remember, both the fir≈øt Authour, and the forme of the fir≈øt introduction of it among≈øt vs. It was neither brought in by King, great Conquerour, nor learned doctour of Phi≈øicke.

With the report of a great di≈øcouery for a Conque≈øt, ≈øome two or three Sauage men, were brought in, together with this Sauage cu≈øtome. But the pitie is, the poore wilde barbarous men died, but that vile barbarous cu≈øtome is yet aliue, yea in fre≈øh vigor: ≈øo as it ≈øeemes a miracle to me, how a cu≈øtome ≈øpringing from ≈øo vile a ground, and brought in by a father ≈øo generally hated, ≈øhould be welcomed vpon ≈øo ≈ølender a warrant. For if they that fir≈øt put it in practi≈øe here, had remembred for what re≈øpect it was v≈øed by them from whence it came, I am ≈øure they would haue bene loath, to haue taken ≈øo farre the imputation of that di≈øea≈øe vpon them as they did, by v≈øing the cure thereof: For Sanis non e≈øt opus medico, and counterpoi≈øons are neuer v≈øed, but where poi≈øon is thought to precede.

But ≈øince it is trew, that diuers cu≈øtomes ≈ølightly grounded, and with no better warrant entred in a Common-wealth, may yet in the v≈øe of them thereafter, prooue both nece≈ø≈øary and profitable; it is therefore next to bee examined, if there be not a full Sympathie and true Proportion, betweene the ba≈øe ground and fooli≈øh entrie, and the loath≈øome and hurtfull v≈øe of this ≈øtinking Antidote.

I am now therefore heartily to pray you to con≈øider, fir≈øt vpon what fal≈øe and erroneous grounds you haue fir≈øt built the generall good liking thereof; and next, what ≈øinnes towards God, and fooli≈øh vanities before the world you commit, in the dete≈øtable v≈øe of it.

As for the≈øe deceitfull grounds, that haue ≈øpecially moued you to take a good and great conceit thereof, I ≈øhall content my ≈øelfe to examine here onely foure of the principals of them; two founded vpon the Theoricke of a deceiueable apparance of rea≈øon, and two of them vpon the mi≈øtaken practicke of generall experience.

Fir≈øt, it is thought by you a ≈øure Aphori≈øme in the Phy≈øickes, That the braines of all men, beeing naturally cold and wet, all drie and hote things ≈øhould be good for them; of which nature this ≈øtinking ≈øuffumigation is, and therefore of good v≈øe to them. Of this argument, both the propo≈øition and a≈ø≈øumption are fal≈øe, and ≈øo the conclu≈øion cannot but be voyd of it ≈øelfe. For as to the Propo≈øition, That becau≈øe the braines are colde and moi≈øt, therefore things that are hote and dry are be≈øt for them, it is an inept con≈øequence: For man beeing compounded of the foure Complexions, (who≈øe fathers are the foure Elements) although there be a mixture of them all in all the parts of his body, yet mu≈øt the diuers parts of our Microco≈øme or little world within our ≈øelues, be diuer≈øly more inclined, ≈øome to one, ≈øome to another complexion, according to the diuer≈øitie of their v≈øes, that of the≈øe di≈øcords a perfect harmonie may be made vp for the maintenance of the whole body.

The application then of a thing of a contrary nature, to any of the≈øe parts, is to interrupt them of their due function, and by con≈øequence hurtfull to the health of the whole bodie. As if a man, becau≈øe the Liuer is hote (as the fountaine of blood) and as it were an ouen to the ≈øtomacke, would therefore apply and weare clo≈øe vpon his Liuer and ≈øtomacke a cake of lead; he might within a very ≈øhort time (I hope) bee ≈øu≈øteined very good cheape at an Ordinarie, be≈øide the clearing of his con≈øcience from that deadly ≈øinne of gluttonie. And as if, becau≈øe the Heart is full of vitall ≈øpirits, and in perpetuall motion, a man would therefore lay a heauie pound ≈øtone on his brea≈øt, for ≈øtaying and holding downe that wanton palpitation, I doubt not but his brea≈øt would be more brui≈øed with the weight therof, then the heart would be comforted with ≈øuch a di≈øagreeable and contrarious cure. And euen ≈øo is it with the braines: For if a man, becau≈øe the braines are cold and humide, would therefore v≈øe inwardly by ≈ømells, or outwardly by application, things of hot and dry qualitie, all the gaine that he could make thereof would onely be to put him≈øelfe in a great forwardnes for running mad, by ouerwatching him≈øelfe, the coldne≈ø≈øe and moi≈øtne≈ø≈øe of our braine being the onely ordinary meanes that procure our ≈øleepe and re≈øt. Indeed I doe not deny, but when it falls out that any of the≈øe, or any part of our bodie growes to be di≈øtempered, and to tend to an extremitie, beyond the compa≈ø≈øe of Natures temperate mixture, that in that ca≈øe cures of contrary qualities, to the intemperate inclination of that part, being wi≈øely prepared and di≈øcreetly mini≈øtred, may be both nece≈ø≈øary and helpfull for ≈øtrengthning and a≈ø≈øi≈øting Nature in the expul≈øion of her enemies: for this is the trew definition of all profitable Phi≈øicke.
But fir≈øt the≈øe Cures ought not to be v≈øed, but where there is need of them, the contrary whereof, is daily practi≈øed in this generall v≈øe of Tobacco by all ≈øorts and complexions of people.

And next, I denie the Minor of this argument, as I haue already ≈øaid, in regard that this Tobacco, is not ≈øimply of a dry and hote qualitie; but rather
hath a certain venemous facultie ioyned with the heat therof, which makes it haue an Antipathy again≈øt nature, as by the hateful ≈ømel therof doth well appeare. For the no≈øe being the proper Organ and conuoy of the ≈øen≈øe of ≈ømelling to the braines, which are the only fountaine of that ≈øen≈øe, doth euer ≈øerue vs for an infallible witne≈ø≈øe, whether that odour which we ≈ømell, be healthfull or hurtfull to the braine, (except when it fals out that the ≈øen≈øeit ≈øelfe is corrupted and abu≈øed through ≈øome infirmitie, and di≈øtemper in the braine.) And that the ≈øuffumigation thereof cannot haue a drying quality, it needs no further probation, then that it is a ≈ømoke, all ≈ømoke and vapour, being of it ≈øelfe humide, as drawing neere to the nature of the aire, and ea≈øie to be re≈øolued againe into water, whereof there needs no other proofe but the Meteors, which being bred of nothing el≈øe but of the vapors and exhalations ≈øucked vp by the Sun out of the earth, the ≈øea, and waters, yet are the ≈øame ≈ømoakie vapors turned and transformed into raines, ≈ønowes, deawes, hoare fro≈øts, and ≈øuch like waterie Meteors, as by the contrary the rainie cloudes are often transformed and euaporated in blu≈øtering windes.

The ≈øecond Argument grounded on a ≈øhew of rea≈øon is, That this filthy ≈ømoake, a≈øwell through the heat and ≈øtrength thereof, as by a naturall force and quality, is able and fit to purge both the head and ≈øtomack of rhewmes and di≈øtillations, as experience teacheth, by the ≈øpitting & auoiding fleame, immediatly after the taking of it. But the fallacie of this Argument may ea≈øily appeare, by my late preceding de≈øcription of the Meteors. For euen as the ≈ømoakie vapours ≈øucked vp by the Sunne, and ≈øtayed in the lowe≈øt and cold Region of the aire, are there contracted into clouds, and turned into raine and ≈øuch other watery Meteors: So this ≈øtinking ≈ømoake being ≈øucked vp by the no≈øe, & impri≈øoned in the cold and moy≈øt braines, is by their cold and wet facultie, turned and ca≈øt forth againe in waterie di≈øtillations, and ≈øo are you made free and purged of nothing, but that wherewith you wilfully burdened your ≈øelues: and therefore are you no wi≈øer in taking Tobacco for purging you of di≈øtillations, then if for preuenting the Cholicke you would take all kind of windie meats and drinkes; and for preuenting of the Stone, you would take all kinde of meates and drinkes that would breed grauell in the kidneys, and then when you were forced to auoide much winde out of your ≈øtomacke, and much grauell in your Vrine, that you ≈øhould attribute the thanke therof to ≈øuch nouri≈øhments, as bred tho≈øe within you, that behooued either to be expelled by the force of Nature, or you to haue bur≈øt at the broad ≈øide, as the Prouerbe is.

As for the other two rea≈øons founded vpon experience, the fir≈øt of which is, That the whole people would not haue taken ≈øo generall a good liking thereof, if they had not by experience found it very ≈øoueraigne and good for them: For an≈øwere thereunto, how ea≈øily the mindes of any people, wherewith God hath repleni≈øhed this world may be drawen to the fooli≈øh affectation of any noueltie, I leaue it to the di≈øcreet iudgement of any man that is rea≈øonable.

Doe we not daily ≈øee, that a man can no ≈øooner bring ouer from beyond the ≈øeas any new forme of apparell, but that he cannot be thought a man of ≈øpirit, that would not pre≈øently imitate the ≈øame? And ≈øo from hand to hand it ≈øpreads, till it be practi≈øed by all, not for any commodity that is in it, but only becau≈øe it is come to be the fa≈øhion. For ≈øuch is the force of that naturall ≈øelfe-loue in euery one of vs, and ≈øuch is the corruption of enuy bred in the bre≈øt of euery one, as we cannot be content vnle≈ø≈øe wee imitate euery thing that our fellowes doe, and ≈øo prooue our ≈øelues capable of euery thing whereof they are capable, like Apes, counterfeiting the maners of others, to our owne de≈øtruction. For let one or two of the greate≈øt Ma≈øters of Mathematicks in any of the two famous Vniuer≈øities, but con≈øtantly affirme any cleare day, that they ≈øee≈øome ≈øtrange apparition in the skies; they wil I warrant you be ≈øeconded by the greate≈øt part of the ≈øtudents in that profe≈ø≈øion: So loth will they be, to be thought inferior to their fellowes, either in depth of knowledge or ≈øharpnes of ≈øight: And therfore the generall good liking and imbracing of this fooli≈øh cu≈øtome, doth but only proceed from that affectation of noueltie, and popular errour, whereof I haue already ≈øpoken.

The other argument drawn from a mi≈øtaken experience, is but the more particular probation of this generall, becau≈øe it is alledged to be found trew by proofe, that by the taking of Tobacco diuers and very many doe finde them≈øelues cured of diuers di≈øea≈øes; as on the other part, no man euer receiued harme thereby. In this argument there is fir≈øt a great mi≈øtaking, and next a mon≈øtrous ab≈øurditie: For is it not a very great mi≈øtaking, to take non cau≈øam pro cau≈øa, as they ≈øay in the Logickes? becau≈øe peraduenture when a ≈øicke man hath had his di≈øea≈øe at the height, hee hath at that in≈øtant taken Tobacco, and afterward his di≈øea≈øe taking the naturall cour≈øe of declining, and con≈øequently the Patient of recouering his health, O then the Tobacco for≈øooth, was the worker of that miracle. Be≈øide that, it is a thing wel known to all Phy≈øicians, that the apprehen≈øion and conceit of the patient, hath by wakening and vniting the vitall ≈øpirits, and ≈øo ≈øtrengthening nature, a great power and vertue to cure diuers di≈øea≈øes. For an euident proofe of mi≈øtaking in the like ca≈øe, I pray you what fooli≈øh boy, what ≈øilly wench, what olde doting wife, or ignorant countrey clowne, is not a Phy≈øician for the toothach, for the cholicke, and diuers ≈øuch common di≈øea≈øes? Yea, will not euery man you meet withall, teach you a ≈øundry curefor the ≈øame, & ≈øweare by that meane either him≈øelfe, or ≈øome of his neere≈øt kin≈øemen and friends was cured? And yet I hope no man is ≈øo fooli≈øh as to beleeue them. And all the≈øe toyes do only proceed fro the mi≈øtaking Non cau≈øam pro cau≈øa, as I haue already ≈øaid, and ≈øo if a man chance to recouer one of any di≈øea≈øe, after hee hath taken Tobacco, that mu≈øt haue the thanks of all. But by the contrary, if a man ≈ømoke him≈øelfe to death with it (and many haue done) O then ≈øome other di≈øea≈øe mu≈øt beare the blame for that fault. So doe old harlots thanke their harlotrie for their many yeeres, that cu≈øtome being healthfull (≈øay they) ad purgandos Renes, but neuer haue mind how many die of the Pockes
in the flower of their youth. And ≈øo doe olde drunkards thinke they prolong their dayes, by their ≈øwinelike diet, but neuer remember how many die drowned in drinke before they be halfe olde.

And what greater ab≈øurditie can therebe, then to ≈øay that one cure ≈øhall ≈øerue for diuers, nay, coÃÑtrarious ≈øorts of di≈øea≈øes? It is an vndoubted ground among all Phy≈øicians, that there is almo≈øt no ≈øort either of nouri≈øhment or medicine, that hath not ≈øome thing in it di≈øagreeable to ≈øome part of mans bodie, becau≈øe as I haue alreadie ≈øaid, the nature of the temperature of euery part, is ≈øo different from another, that according to the olde prouerbe, That which is good for the head, is euill for the necke and the ≈øhoulders: For euen as a ≈øtrong enemy, that inuades a town or fortre≈ø≈øe, although in his ≈øiege thereof, he do belay and compa≈ø≈øe it round about, yet he makes his breach and entry, at ≈øome one or fewe ≈øpeciall parts thereof, which hee hath tried and found to be weake≈øt and lea≈øt able to re≈øi≈øt; ≈øo ≈øickenes doth make her particular a≈ø≈øault, vpon ≈øuch part or parts of our body, as are weake≈øt and ea≈øie≈øt to be ouercome by that ≈øort of di≈øea≈øe, which then doth a≈ø≈øaile vs, although all the re≈øt of the body by Sympathie feele it ≈øelfe to be as it were belayed, and be≈øieged by the affliction of that ≈øpeciall part, the griefe and ≈ømart thereof being by the ≈øen≈øe of feeling di≈øper≈øed through all the re≈øt of our members. And therefore the skilfull Phy≈øician pre≈ø≈øes by ≈øuch cures to purge and ≈øtrengthen that part which is afflicted, as are only fit for that ≈øort of di≈øea≈øe, and doe be≈øt agree with the nature of that infirme part; which being abu≈øed to a di≈øea≈øe of another nature, would proue as hurtfull for the one, as helpfull for the other. Yea, not onely will a skilfull and wary Phy≈øician becarefull to v≈øe no cure but that which is fit for that ≈øort of di≈øea≈øe, but he will al≈øo con≈øider all other circum≈øtances, & make the remedies ≈øutable therunto; as the temperature of the clime where the Patient is, the con≈øtitution of the Planets, the time of the Moone, the ≈øea≈øon of the yeere, the aage and complexion of the Patient, and the pre≈øent ≈øtate of his body, in ≈øtrength or weaknes: For one cure mu≈øt not euer be v≈øed for the ≈øelfe≈øame di≈øea≈øe, but according to the varying of any of the fore≈øaid circum≈øtances, that ≈øort of remedy mu≈øt be v≈øed which is fitte≈øt for the ≈øame. Where by the contrary in this ca≈øe, ≈øuch is the miraculous omnipotencie of our ≈øtrong ta≈øted Tobacco, as it cures al ≈øorts of di≈øea≈øes (which neuer any drugge could do before) in all per≈øons, and at all times. It cures all maner of di≈øtillations, either in the head or ≈øtomacke (if you beleeue their Axiomes) although in very deed it doe both corrupt the braine, and by cau≈øing ouer quicke dige≈øtion, fill the ≈øtomacke full of crudities. It cures the gowt in the feet, and (which is miraculous) in that very in≈øtant when the ≈ømoke thereof, as light, flies vp into the head, the vertue therof, as heauy, runs down to the litle toe. It helps all ≈øorts of agues. It makes a man ≈øober that was drunk. It refre≈øhes a weary man, and yet makes a man hungry. Being taken when they goe to bed, it makes one ≈øleepe ≈øoundly, and yet being taken when a man is ≈øleepie and drow≈øie, it will, as they ≈øay, awake his braine, and quicken his vnder≈øtanding.
As for curing of the Pockes, it ≈øerues for that v≈øe but among the pockie Indian ≈ølaues. Here in England it is refined, and will not deigne to cure here any other then cleanly and gentlemanly di≈øea≈øes. O omnipotent power of Tobacco! And if it could by the ≈ømoake thereof cha≈øe out deuils, as the ≈ømoake of Tobias fi≈øh did (which I am ≈øure could ≈ømell no ≈øtronglier) it would ≈øerue for a precious Relicke, both for the ≈øuper≈øtitious Prie≈øts, and the in≈øolent Puritanes, to ca≈øt out deuils withall.

Admitting then, and not confe≈ø≈øing, that the v≈øe thereof were healthful for ≈øome ≈øorts of di≈øea≈øes; ≈øhould it be v≈øed for all ≈øickne≈ø≈øes? ≈øhould it be v≈øed by all men? ≈øhould it be v≈øed at all times? yea ≈øhould it be v≈øed by able, yong, ≈øtrong, healthful men? Medicine hath that vertue, that it neuer leaues a man in that ≈øtate wherein it finds him: it makes a ≈øicke man whole, but a whole man ≈øicke: And as Medicine helps nature being taken at times of nece≈ø≈øitie, ≈øo being euer and continually v≈øed, it doeth but weaken, weary, and weare nature. What ≈øpeake I of Medicine? Nay let a man euery houre of the day, or as oft as many in this countrey v≈øe to take Tobacco, let a man I ≈øay, but take as oft the be≈øt ≈øorts of nouri≈øhments in meate and drinke that can be deui≈øed, he ≈øhall with the continuall v≈øe thereof weaken both his head and his ≈øtomacke: all his members ≈øhall becomefeeble, his ≈øpirits dull, and in the end, as a drow≈øie lazie belly-god, he ≈øhall euani≈øh in a Lethargie.

And from this weakene≈ø≈øe it proceeds, that many in this kingdome haue had ≈øuch a continuall v≈øe of taking this vn≈øauorie ≈ømoake, as now they are not able to forbeare the ≈øame, no more then an old drunkard can abide to be long ≈øober, without falling into an incurable weakne≈ø≈øe and euill con≈øtitution: for their continuall cu≈øtome hath made to them, habitum, alteram naturam: ≈øo to tho≈øe that from their birth haue beene continually nouri≈øhed vpon poi≈øon and things venemous, whol≈øome meats are only poi≈øonable.

Thus hauing, as I tru≈øt, ≈øufficiently an≈øwered the mo≈øt principall arguments that are v≈øed in defence of this vile cu≈øtome, it re≈øts only to informe you what ≈øinnes and vanities you commit in the filthy abu≈øe thereof. Fir≈øt, are you not guiltie of ≈øinnefull and ≈øhamefull lu≈øt? (for lu≈øt may be as well in any of the ≈øen≈øes as in feeling) that although you be troubled with no di≈øea≈øe, but in perfect health, yet can you neither be merry at an Ordinary, nor la≈øciuious in the Stewes, if you lacke Tobacco to prouoke your appetite to any of tho≈øe ≈øorts of recreation, lu≈øting after it as the children of I≈ørael did in the wilderne≈ø≈øe after Quailes? Secondly it is, as you v≈øe or rather abu≈øe it, a branch of the ≈øinne of drunkennes, which is the root of all ≈øinnes: for as the only delight that drunkards take in wine is in the ≈øtrength of the ta≈øte, and the force of the fume therof that mounts vp to the braine: for no drunkards loue any weake, or ≈øweet drinke: ≈øo are not tho≈øe (I meane the ≈øtrong heate and the fume) the onely qualities that make Tobacco ≈øo delectable to all the louers of it? And as no man likes ≈øtrong heady drinke the fir≈øt day (becau≈øe nemo repent√® fit turpi≈øsimus) but by cu≈øtome is piece and piece allured, while in the ende, a drunkard will haue as great a thir≈øt to be drunke, as a ≈øober
man to quench his thir≈øt with a draught when he hath need of it: So is not this the very ca≈øe of all the great takers of Tobacco? which therefore they them≈øelues doe attribute to a bewitching qualitie in it. Thirdly, is it not the greate≈øt ≈øinne of all, that you the people of all ≈øorts of this kingdome, who are created and ordeined by God, to be≈øtow both your per≈øons and goods, for the maintenance both of the honour and ≈øafety of your King and Common wealth, ≈øhould di≈øable your ≈øelues in both? In your per≈øons hauing by this continuall vile cu≈øtome brought your ≈øelues to this ≈øhamefull imbecilitie, that you are not able to ride or walke the iourney of a Iewes Sabboth, but you mu≈øt haue a reekie cole brought you from the next poore hou≈øe to kindle your Tobacco with? whereas he cannot be thought able for any ≈øeruice in the warres, that cannot endure oftentimes the want of meat, drinke, and ≈øleepe, much more then mu≈øt he endure the want of Tobacco. In the times of the many glorious and victorious battailes fought by this Nation, there was no word of Tobacco: but now if it were time of warres, and that you were to make ≈øome ≈øudden Caualcado vpon your enemies, if any of you ≈øhould ≈øeeke lei≈øure to ≈øtay behinde his fellow for taking of Tobacco, for my part I ≈øhould neuer be ≈øory for any euill chance that might befall him. To take a cu≈øtome in any thing that cannot be left againe, is mo≈øt harmeful to the people of any land. Mollicies and delicacie were the wracke and ouerthrow, fir≈øt of the Per≈øian, and next of the Romane Empire. And this very cu≈øtome of taking Tobacco (whereof our pre≈øent purpo≈øe is) is euen at this day accounted ≈øo effeminate among the Indians them≈øelues, as in the market they will offer no price for a ≈ølaue to be ≈øold, whom they find to be a great Tobacco taker.

Now how you are by this cu≈øtome di≈øabled in your goods, let the Gentry of this land beare witne≈ø≈øe, ≈øome of them be≈øtowing three, ≈øome foure hundred pounds a yeere vpon this precious ≈øtinke, which I am ≈øure might be be≈øtowed vpon many farre better v≈øes. I read indeed of a knaui≈øh Courtier, who for abu≈øing the fauour of the Emperor Alexander Seuerus his ma≈øter, by taking bribes to intercede, for ≈øundry per≈øons in his ma≈øters eare, (for whoÃÑ he neuer once opened his mouth) was iu≈øtly choked with ≈ømoke, with this doome, Fumo pereat, qui fumum vendidit: but of ≈øo many ≈ømokebuyers, as are at this pre≈øent in this kingdome, I neuer read nor heard.

And for the vanities committed in this filthy cu≈øtome, is it not both great vanitie and vncleanne≈ø≈øe, that at the table, a place of re≈øpect, of cleanline≈ø≈øe, of mode≈øtie, men ≈øhould not be a≈øhamed, to ≈øit to≈ø≈øing of Tobacco pipes, and puffing of the ≈ømoke of Tobacco one to another, making the filthy ≈ømoke and ≈øtinke thereof, to exhale athwart the di≈øhes, and infect the aire, when very often, men that abhorre it are at their repa≈øt? Surely ≈ømoke becomes a kitchin farre better then a dining chamber, and yet it makes a kitchin al≈øo oftentimes in the inward parts of men, ≈øoyling and infecting them, with an vnctuous and oily kind of ≈øoote, as hath bene found in ≈øome great Tobacco takers, that after their death were opened. And not onely
meat time, but no other time nor action is exempted from the publike v≈øe of this vnciuill tricke: ≈øo as if the wiues of Diepe li≈øt to conte≈øt with this Nation for good maners, their wor≈øt maners would in all rea≈øon be found at lea≈øt not ≈øo di≈øhone≈øt (as ours are) in this point. The publike v≈øe whereof, at all times, and in all places, hath now ≈øo farre preuailed, as diuers men very ≈øound both in iudgement and complexion, haue beene at la≈øt forced to take it al≈øo without de≈øire, partly becau≈øe they were a≈øhamed to ≈øeeme ≈øingular, (like the two Philo≈øophers that were forced to ducke them≈øelues in that raine water, and ≈øo become fooles as well as the re≈øt of the people) and partly to be as one that was content to eate Garlick (which he did not loue) that he might not be troubled with the ≈ømell of it, in the breath of his fellowes. And is it not a great vanitie, that a man cannot heartily welcome his friend now, but ≈øtraight they mu≈øt be in hand with Tobacco: No it is become in place of a eure, a point of good fellow≈øhip, and hee that will refu≈øe to take a pipe of Tobacco among his fellowes, (though by his owne election hee would rather feele the ≈øauour of a Sinke) is accounted peeui≈øh and no good company, euen as they doe with tipling in the colde Ea≈øterne countreys. Yea the Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe cannot in a more manerly kind, entertaine her ≈øeruant, then by giuing him out of her faire hand a pipe of Tobacco. But herein is not only a great vanity, but a great contempt of Gods good giftes, that the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of mans breath, being a good gift of God, ≈øhould be wilfully corrupted by this ≈øtinking ≈ømoke, wherin I mu≈øt coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe, it hath too ≈øtrong a vertue; and ≈øo that which is an ornament of nature, & can neither by any artifice be at the fir≈øt acquired, nor once lo≈øt be recouered againe, ≈øhalbe filthily corrupted with an incurable ≈øtinke, which vile qualitie is as directly contrary to that wrong opinion which is holden of the whole≈øomne≈ø≈øe therof, as the venime of putrifaction is contrary to the vertue Pre≈øeruatiue.

Moreouer, which is a great iniquitie, and again≈øt all humanitie, the hu≈øband ≈øhal not be a≈øhamed, to reduce therby his delicate, whol≈øom, & cleane complexioned wife to that extremity, that either ≈øhe mu≈øt al≈øo corrupt her ≈øweet breath therwith, or els re≈øolue to liue in a perpetual ≈øtinking torment.

Haue you not rea≈øon then to be a≈øhamed, and to forbeare this filthie noueltie, ≈øo ba≈øely grounded, ≈øo fooli≈øhly receiued, and ≈øo gro≈ø≈øely mi≈øtaken in the right v≈øe thereof? In your abu≈øe thereof ≈øinning again≈øt God, harming your ≈øelues both in per≈øons and goods, and raking al≈øo thereby the markes and notes of vanitie vpon you; by the cu≈øtome thereof making your ≈øelues to be wondered at by all forreine ciuill Nations, and by all ≈øtrangers that come among you, to be ≈øcorned and contemned: A cu≈øtome loath≈øome to the eye, hatefull to the no≈øe, harmefull to the braine, dangerous to the lungs, and in the blacke ≈øtinking fume thereof, neere≈øt re≈øembling the horrible Stigian ≈ømoake of the pit that is bottomle≈ø≈øe.

div.head: A DISCOVRSE OF THE MANER OF THE DISCOVERIE OF THE POWDERTREASON, JOYNED WITH THE EXAMINATION OF SOME OF THE PRISONERS.
div.p:
THere is a time when no man ought to keepe ≈øilence. For it hath euer bene held as a generall rule, and vndoubted Maxime, in all well gouerned Common-wealthes (whether Chri≈øtian, and ≈øo guided by the diuine light of Gods word; or Ethnicke, and ≈øo led by the glimmering twi-light of Nature) yet how≈øoeuer their profe≈ø≈øion was, vpon this ground haue they all agreed, That when either their Religion, their King, or their countrey was in any extreme hazard, no good countreyman ought then to withhold either his tongue or his hand, according to his calling and facultie, from ayding to repell the iniurie, repre≈ø≈øe the violence, and auenge the guilt vpon the authors thereof. But if euer any people had ≈øuch an occa≈øion mini≈øtred vnto them, It is ≈øurely this people now, nay this whole I≈øle, and all the re≈øt belonging to this great and glorious Monarchie. For if in any heatheni≈øh republique, no priuate man could thinke his life more happily and gloriou≈øly be≈øtowed, then in the defence of any one of the≈øe three, That is, either pro Aris, pro Focis, or pro Patre patriae; And that the endangering of any one of the≈øe, would at once ≈øtirre the whole body of the Common-wealth, not any more as diuided members, but as a ≈øolide and indiuiduall lumpe: How much more ought we the trewly Chri≈øtian people that inhabite this vnited and trewly
happy I≈øle, In≈øula fortunata. vnder the wings of our gracious and religious Monarch? Nay, how infinitely greater cau≈øe haue we to feele and re≈ø≈øent our ≈øelues of the ≈ømart of that wound, not onely intended and execrated (not con≈øecrated) for the vtter extingui≈øhing of our trew Chri≈øtian profe≈ø≈øion, nor ioyntly therwith onely for the cutting off of our Head and father Politike, Sed vt nefas i≈øtud & ≈øacrilegio≈øum parricidium omnibus modis ab≈øolutum reddi po≈øsit? And that nothing might be wanting for making this ≈øacrilegious parricide a patterne of mi≈øchiefe, and a crime (nay, a mother or ≈øtorehou≈øe of all crimes) without example, they ≈øhould haue ioyned the de≈øtruction of the bodie to the head, ≈øo as Grex cum Rege, Arae cum focis, Lares cum Penatibus, ≈øhould all at one thunderclap haue beene ≈øent to heauen together: The King our head, the Queene our fertile mother, and tho≈øe young and hopefull Oliue plants, not theirs but ours: Our reuerend Clergie, our honourable Nobilitie, the faithfull Councellors, the graue Iudges, the greate≈øt part of the worthy Knights and Gentry, a≈øwell as of the wi≈øe≈øt Burge≈ø≈øes; The whole Clerkes of the Crowne, Coun≈øaile, Signet, Seales, or of any other principall Iudgement ≈øeate. All the learned Lawyers, together with an infinite number of the Common people: Nay, their furious rage ≈øhould not onely haue lighted vpon rea≈øonable and ≈øen≈øible creatures without di≈øtinction either of degree, ≈øexe or aage; But euen the in≈øen≈øible ≈øtockes and ≈øtones ≈øhould not haue bin free of their fury. The hal of Iu≈øtice; The hou≈øe of Parliament, The Church v≈øed for the Coronation of our Kings; The Monuments of our former Princes; The Crowne and other markes of Royaltie; Al the Records, a≈øwell of Parliament, as of euery particular mans right, with a great number of Charters and ≈øuch like, ≈øhould all haue bene comprehended vnder that fearefull Chaos. And ≈øo the earth as it were opened, ≈øhould haue ≈øent foorth of the bottome of the Stygian lake ≈øuch ≈øulphured ≈ømoke, furious flames, and fearefull thunder, as ≈øhould haue by their diabolicall Dome≈øday de≈øtroyed and defaced, in the twinkling of an eye, not onely our pre≈øent liuing Princes and people, but euen our in≈øen≈øible Monuments re≈øerued for future aages. So as not only our ≈øelues that are mortall, but the immortall Monuments of our ancient Princes and Nobility, that haue beene ≈øo preciou≈øly pre≈øerued from aage to aage, as the remaining Trophees of their eternal glory, and haue ≈øo long triumphed ouer enuious time, ≈øhould now haue beene all con≈øumed together; and ≈øo not onely we, but the memory of vs and ours, ≈øhould haue beene thus extingui≈øhed in an in≈øtant. The trew horror therefore of this dete≈øtable deuice, hath ≈øtirred mee vp to bethinke my ≈øelfe, wherein I may be≈øt di≈øcharge my con≈øcience in a cau≈øe ≈øo generall and common, if it were to bring but one ≈øtone to the building, or rather with the Widow one mite to the common boxe. But ≈øince to ≈øo hatefull and vnheard-of inuention, there can be no greater enemy then the ≈øelfe, the ≈øimple trewth thereof being once publikely knowen; and that there needes no ≈øtronger argument to bring ≈øuch a plot in vniuer≈øal dete≈øtatioÃÑ, then the certainty that ≈øo mon≈øtrous a thing could once be deui≈øed, nay coÃÑcluded vpon,
wrought in, in full readine≈ø≈øe, and within twelue houres of the execution: My threefold zeale to tho≈øe ble≈ø≈øings, whereof they would haue ≈øo violently made vs all widowes, hath made me re≈øolue to ≈øet downe here the trew Narration of that mon≈øtrous and vnnaturall intended Tragedie, hauing better occa≈øion by the meanes of my ≈øeruice and continuall attendance in Court, to know the trewth thereof, then others that peraduenture haue it onely by relation at the third or fourth hand. So that whereas tho≈øe wor≈øe then Catilines, thought to haue extirped vs and our memories; Their infamous memory ≈øhall by the≈øe meanes remaine to the end of the world, vpon the one part: and vpon the other, Gods great and merciful deliuerance of his Anoynted and vs all, ≈øhall remaine in neuer-dying Records. And God graunt that it may be in marble tables of Thankefulne≈ø≈øe engrauen in our hearts.

WHile this Land and whole Monarchie flouri≈øhed in a mo≈øt happie and plentifull PEACE, as well at home as abroad, ≈øu≈øtained and conducted by the≈øe two maine Pillars of all good Gouernement, PIETIE and IVSTICE, no forreine grudge, nor inward whi≈øpering of di≈øcontentment any way appearing; The King being vpon his returne from his hunting exerci≈øe at Roy≈øton, vpon occa≈øion of the drawing neere of the Parliament time, which had beene twi≈øe prorogued already, partly in regard of the ≈øea≈øon of the yeere, and partly of the Terme; As the winds are euer ≈øtille≈øt immediatly before a ≈øtorme; and as the Sunne blenks often hotte≈øt to foretell a following ≈øhowre: So at that time of greate≈øt calme did this ≈øecretly-hatched thunder beginne to ca≈øt foorth the fir≈øt fla≈øhes, and flaming lightnings of the approching tempe≈øt. For the Saturday of the weeke immediatly preceding the Kings returne, which was vpon a Thur≈øday (being but tenne dayes before the Parliament) The Lord Mountegle, ≈øonne and heire to the Lord Morley, A letter deliuered to the Lord Mountegle. being in his owne lodging ready to goe to ≈øupper at ≈øuen of the clocke at night, one of his foot-men (whom he had ≈øent of an errand ouer the ≈øtreet) was met by an vnknowen man of a rea≈øonable tall per≈øonage, who deliuered him a Letter, charging him to put it in my Lord his ma≈øters hands: which my Lord no ≈øooner receiued, but that hauing broken it vp, and perceiuing the ≈øame to bee of an vnknowen and ≈øomewhat vnlegible hand, and without either date or ≈øub≈øcription; did call one of his men vnto him for helping him to reade it. But no ≈øooner did he conceiue the ≈øtrange contents thereof, although hee was ≈øomewhat perplexed what con≈øtruction to make of it (as whether of a matter of con≈øequence, as indeed it was, or whether ≈øome fooli≈øh deui≈øed Pa≈øquil by ≈øome of his enemies, to skarre him from his attendance at the Parliament) yet did he as a mo≈øt dutifull and loyall Subiect, conclude not to conceale it, what euer might come of it. Whereupon, notwith≈øtauding the latene≈ø≈øe and darkne≈ø≈øe of the night in that ≈øea≈øon of the yeere, he pre≈øently repaired to his Maie≈øties Pallace at Whitehall, and there deliuered the ≈øame
to the Earle of Salisbury his Maie≈øties principall Secretarie. Reuealed to the Earle of Salisbury. Whereupon the ≈øaid Earle of Salisbury hauing read the Letter, and heard the maner of the comming of it to his hands, did greatly encourage and commend my Lord for his di≈øcretion, telling him plainly, that what≈øoeuer the purpo≈øe of the Letter might proue hereafter, yet did this accident put him in mind of diuers aduerti≈øements he had receiued from beyond the Seas, wherewith he had acquainted a≈øwell the King him≈øelfe, as diuers of his Priuie Coun≈øellors, concerning ≈øome bu≈øine≈ø≈øe the Papi≈øts were in, both at home and abroad, making preparations for ≈øome combination among≈øt them again≈øt this Parliament time, for enabling them to deliuer at that time to the King ≈øome petition for toleration of Religion: Purpo≈øe of the Papi≈øts for deliuering a petition to his Maie≈øtie, to craue toleration of Religion. which ≈øhould bee deliuered in ≈øome ≈øuch order and ≈øo well backed, as the King ≈øhould be loth to refu≈øe their reque≈øts; like the ≈øturdie beggars crauing almes with one open hand, but carying a ≈øtone in the other, in ca≈øe of refu≈øall. And therefore did the Earle of Salisbury conclude with the Lord Mountegle, that he would in regard of the Kings ab≈øence impart the ≈øame Letter to ≈øome more of his Maie≈øties Councell; whereof my L. Mountegle liked well: onely adding this reque≈øt by way of prote≈øtation, That what≈øoeuer the euent hereof might proue, it ≈øhould not be imputed to him, as proceeding from too light and too ≈øuddaine an apprehen≈øion, that he deliuered this Letter, being onely mooued thereunto for demon≈øtration of his ready deuotion, and care for pre≈øeruation of his Maie≈øtie and the State. And thus did the Earle of Salisbury pre≈øently acquaint the Lord Chamberlaine with the ≈øaid letter: The Lord Chamberlaine made priuie to the Letter by the Earle of Salubury. Whereupon they two in pre≈øence of the Lord Mountegle, calling to mind the former intelligence already mentioned, which ≈øeemed to haue ≈øome relation with this Letter; The tender care which they euer caried to the pre≈øeruation of his Maie≈øties per≈øon, made them apprehend, that ≈øome perillous attempt did thereby appeare to be intended again≈øt the ≈øame, which did the more neerly concerne the ≈øaid L. Chamberlaine to haue a care of, in regard that it doth belong to the charge of his Office to ouer≈øee as well all places of A≈ø≈øembly where his Maie≈øty is to repaire, as his Highne≈ø≈øe owne priuate hou≈øes. And therfore did the ≈øaid two Coun≈øailors conclude, That they ≈øhould ioyne vnto them≈øelues three more of the Councell, to wit, the Lord Admiral, the Earles of Worcester and Northampton, to be al≈øo particularly acquainted with this accident, who hauing all of them concurred together to the re-examination of the Contents of the ≈øaid Letter, they did conclude, That how ≈ølight a matter it might at the fir≈øt appeare to bee, yet was it not ab≈øolutely to be contemned, in re≈øpect of the care which it behooued them to haue of the pre≈øeruation of his Maie≈øties per≈øon: But yet re≈øolued for two rea≈øons, Thought meet by the Councellors to acquaint the King with the Letter. fir≈øt to acquaint the King him≈øelfe with the ≈øame before they proceeded to any further inqui≈øition in the matter, a≈øwell for the expectation and experience they had of his Maie≈øties fortunate Iudgement in clearing and ≈øoluing of ob≈øcure riddles and doubtful my≈øteries; as al≈øo becau≈øe the more time would in the meane while be giuen for the Practi≈øe to ripen,
if any was, whereby the Di≈øcouery might be the more cleere and euident, and the ground of proceeding thereupon more ≈øafe, iu≈øt, and ea≈øie. And ≈øo according to their determination did the ≈øayd Earle of Salisbury repaire to the King in his Gallery vpon Friday, being Athallow day, in the afternoone, Vpon Alhallow day the Earle of Sa≈øuburie ≈øhewed the Letter to the King. which was the day after his Maie≈øties arriuall, and none but him≈øelfe being pre≈øent with his Highne≈ø≈øe at that time, where without any other ≈øpeach or iudgement giuing of the Letter, but onely relating ≈øimply the forme of the deliuery thereof, he pre≈øented it to his Maie≈øtie. The contents whereof follow.

p.hi: MY Lord, Out of the loue I beare to ≈øome of your friends, I haue a care of your pre≈øeruation. Therefore I would adui≈øe you, as you tender your life, to deui≈øe ≈øome excu≈øe to ≈øhift off your attendance at this Parliament. For God and man haue concurred to puni≈øh the wickedne≈ø≈øe of this Time. And thinke not ≈ølightly of this Aduerti≈øement, but retire your ≈øelfe into your Countrey, where you may expect the euent in ≈øafety. For though there be no apparance of any ≈øtirre, yet I ≈øay, they ≈øhal receiue a terrible Blow this Parliament, and yet they ≈øhall not ≈øee who burts them. This coun≈øell is not to be contemned, becau≈øe it may doe you good, and can doe you no harme; for the danger is past ≈øo ≈øoone as you haue burnt the Letter. And I hope God will giue you the grace to make good v≈øe of it: To who≈øe holy protection I commend you.

div.p:
The King no ≈øooner read the Letter, but after a little pau≈øe, His Maie≈øties iudgement of the Letter. and then reading it ouer againe, he deliuered his iudgement of it in ≈øuch ≈øort, as hee thought it was not to be contemned, for that the Style of it ≈øeemed to bee more quicke and pithie, then is v≈øuall to be in any Pa≈øquil or libel (the ≈øuperfluities of idle braines:) But the Earle of Salisbury perceiuing the King to apprehend it deepelier then he looked for, knowing his nature, told him that he thought by one ≈øentence in it, that it was like to be written by ≈øome foole or madman, reading to him this ≈øentence in it, For the danger is past as ≈øoone as you haue burnt the Letter; which hee ≈øaid, was likely to bee the ≈øaying of a foole: for if the danger was pa≈øt ≈øo ≈øoone as the Letter was burnt, then the warning behooued to bee of little auayle, when the burning of the Letter might make the danger to be e≈øchewed. But the King by the contrary con≈øidering the former ≈øentence in the Letter, That they ≈øhould receiue a terrible Blow at this Parliament, and yet ≈øhould not ≈øee who hurt them, Ioyning it to the ≈øentence immediatly following, already alledged, did therupon coniecture, That the danger mentioned, ≈øhould bee ≈øome ≈øuddaine danger by blowing vp of Powder: For no other In≈øurrection, Rebellion, or what≈øoeuer other priuate and de≈øperate Attempt could bee committed or attempted in time of Parliament, and the Authours thereof vn≈øeene, except onely it were by a blowing vp of Powder, which might bee performed by one ba≈øe knaue in a darke corner; whereupon he was moued to interprete and con≈øtrue the latter Sentence in the Letter (alledged by the Earle of Salisburie) again≈øt all ordinarie ≈øence and con≈øtruction in Grammar,
as if by the≈øe words, For the danger is past as ≈øoone as you haue burned the Letter, ≈øhould be clo≈øely vnder≈øtood the ≈øuddaintie and quickene≈ø≈øe of the danger, which ≈øhould be as quickly perfourmed and at an end, as that paper ≈øhould be of blea≈øing vp in the fire; turning that word of as ≈øoone, to the ≈øen≈øe of, as quickly: And therefore wi≈øhed, that before his going to the Parliament, His Maie≈øties opinion for ≈øearching of the vnder roume: of the Parliament Hou≈øe. the vnder roumes of the Parliament hou≈øe might be well and narrowly ≈øearched. But the Earle of Salisbury wondering at this his Maie≈øties Commentary, which he knew to be ≈øo farre contrary to his ordinary and naturall di≈øpo≈øition, who did rather euer ≈øinne vpon the other ≈øide; in not apprehending nor tru≈øting due Aduerti≈øements of Practi≈øes and Perils when hee was trewly enformed of them, whereby hee had many times drawen him≈øelfe into many de≈øperate dangers: and interpreting rightly this extraordinary Caution at this time to proceede from the vigilant care hee had of the whole State, more then of his owne Per≈øon, which could not but haue all peri≈øhed together, if this de≈øignement had ≈øucceeded: Hee thought good to di≈ø≈øemble ≈øtill vnto the King, that there had beene any iu≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øuch apprehen≈øion: And ending the purpo≈øe with ≈øome merrie iea≈øt vpon this Subiect, as his cu≈øtome is, tooke his leaue for that time.

But though he ≈øeemed ≈øo to neglect it to his Maie≈øtie; yet his cu≈øtomable and watchfull care of the King and the State ≈øtill boyling within him, And hauing with the ble≈ø≈øed Virgine Marie laid vp in his heart the Kings ≈øo ≈øtrange iudgement and con≈øtruction of it; He could not be at re≈øt til he acquainted the fore≈øaid Lords what had pa≈ø≈øed betweene the King and him in priuat: Wherupon they were all ≈øo earne≈øt to renew againe the memory of the ≈øame purpo≈øe to his Maie≈øtie, as it was agreed that he ≈øhould the next day, being Saturday, repaire to his Highne≈ø≈øe: which hee did in the ≈øame priuie Gallery, and renewed the memory thereof, the L. Chamberlaine then being pre≈øent with the King. The determination to ≈øearch the Parliament hou≈øe and the roumes vnder it. At what time it was determined, that the ≈øaid Lord Chamberlaine ≈øhould, according to his cu≈øtome and Office, view all the Parliament Hou≈øes, both aboue and below, and con≈øider what likelihood or appearance of any ≈øuch danger might po≈ø≈øibly be gathered by the ≈øight of them: But yet, as well for ≈øtaying of idle rumours, as for beeing the more able to di≈øcerne any my≈øterie, the nearer that things were in readine≈ø≈øe, his iourney thither was ordeined to bee deferred till the afternoone before the ≈øitting downe of the Parliament, which was vpon the Munday following. At what time hee (according to this conclu≈øion) went to the Parliament hou≈øe accompanied with my Lord Mountegle, beeing in zeale to the Kings ≈øeruice earne≈øt and curious to ≈øee the euent of that accident whereof hee had the fortune to be the fir≈øt di≈øcouerer: where, hauing viewed all the lower roumes, Wood and Coale found by the Lord Chamberlaine in the Vault. hee found in the Vault vnder the vpper Hou≈øe great ≈øtore and proui≈øion of Billets, Faggots, and Coales: And enquiring of Whyneard Keeper of the Wardrobe, to what v≈øe hee had put tho≈øe lower roumes and cellars: he told him, That Thomas Percie had hired
both the Hou≈øe, and part of the Cellar or Vault vnder the ≈øame, and that the Wood and Coale therein was the ≈øaid Gentlemansowne proui≈øion: Whereupon the Lord Chamberlaine, ca≈øting his eye a≈øide, perceiued a fellow ≈øtanding in a corner there, calling him≈øelf the ≈øaid Percies man, and keeper of that hou≈øe for him, but indeed was Guido Fawkes,
Guido Fawkes bearing the name of Percies man. the owner of that hand which ≈øhould haue acted that mon≈øtrous Tragedie.

The Lord Chamberlaine looking vpon all things with a heedfull indeed, yet in outward appearance with but a carele≈ø≈øe and rackle≈ø≈øe eye (as became ≈øo wi≈øe and diligent a mini≈øter) hee pre≈øently addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe to the King in the ≈øaid priuie Gallery, wherein the pre≈øence of the Lord Trea≈øurer, the Lord Admirall, the Earles of Worcester, Northampton, and Salisbury, The Lord Chamberlaines report and iudgement of what he had ob≈øerued in the ≈øearch. hee made his report, what hee had ≈øeene and ob≈øerued there; noting that Mountegle had told him, That he no ≈øooner heard Thomas Percy named to be the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øour of that hou≈øe, but con≈øidering both his backwardnes in Religion, and the old dearene≈ø≈øe in friend≈øhip betweene him≈øelfe and the ≈øaid Percy, hee did greatly ≈øu≈øpect the matter, and that the Letter ≈øhould come from him. The ≈øaid Lord Chamberlaine al≈øo tolde, That he did not wonder a little at the extraordinary great proui≈øion of wood and coale in that hou≈øe, where Thomas Percie had ≈øo ≈øeldome occa≈øion to remaine; As likewi≈øe it gaue him in his minde that his man looked like a very tall and de≈øperate fellow.

This could not but encrea≈øe the Kings former apprehen≈øion and iealou≈øie: whereupon hee in≈øi≈øted (as before) that the Hou≈øe was narrowly to bee ≈øearched, and that tho≈øe Billets and Coales would be ≈øearched to the bottome, it beeing mo≈øt ≈øu≈øpicious that they were layed there onely for couering of the powder. Of this ≈øame minde al≈øo were all the Coun≈øailours then pre≈øent: Di≈øputation about the maner of the further ≈øearch. But vpon the fa≈øhion of making of the ≈øearch was it long debated: For vpon the one ≈øide they were all ≈øo iealous of the Kings ≈øafety, that they all agreed, that there could not be too much caution v≈øed for preuenting his danger. And yet vpon the other part they were all extreme loath and daintie, that in ca≈øe this Letter ≈øhould proue to bee nothing but the euaporation of an idle braine; then a curious ≈øearch beeing made, and nothing found, ≈øhould not onely turne to the generall ≈øcandall of the King and the State, as being ≈øo ≈øu≈øpicious of euery light and friuolous toy, but likewi≈øe lay an ill fauoured imputation vpon the Earle of Northumberland one of his Maie≈øties greate≈øt Subiects and Coun≈øailors, this Tho. Percie being his kin≈øman, and mo≈øt confident familiar. And the rather were they curious vpon this point, knowing how far the King dete≈øted to be thought ≈øu≈øpitious or iealous of any of his good Subiects, though of the meane≈øt degree. And therefore though they all agreed vpon the maine ground, which was to prouide for the ≈øecuritie of the Kings Per≈øon, yet did they much differ in the circum≈øtances, by which this action might be be≈øt caried with lea≈øt dinne and occa≈øion of ≈ølaunder. But the King him≈øelfe ≈øtill per≈øi≈øting that there were diuers ≈øhrewd appearances, and that
a narrow ≈øearch of tho≈øe places could preiudge no man that was innocent, hee at la≈øt plainely re≈øolued them, That either mu≈øt all the partes of tho≈øe roumes bee narrowly ≈øearched, and no po≈ø≈øibilitie of danger left vnexamined, or el≈øe hee and they all mu≈øt re≈øolue not to meddle in it at all, but plainly to goe the next day to the Parliament, and leaue the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to Fortune, which he beleeued they would be loth to take vpon their con≈øciences: for in ≈øuch a ca≈øe as this, Agreed that the ≈øearch ≈øhould be vnder colour of ≈øeeking for Wardrobe ≈øtuffe mi≈ø≈øed by Whynniard. an halfe doing was wor≈øe then no doing at all. Whereupon it was at la≈øt concluded, That nothing ≈øhould bee left vn≈øearched in tho≈øe Hou≈øes: And yet for the better colour and ≈øtay of rumour, in ca≈øe nothing were found, it was thought meet, that vpon a pretence of Whyneards mi≈ø≈øing ≈øome of the Kings ≈øtuffe or Hangings which he had in keeping, all tho≈øe roumes ≈øhould be narrowly ripped for them. And to this purpo≈øe was Sir Thomas Kneuet (a Gentleman of his Maie≈øties priuie Chamber) employed, being a Iu≈øtice of Peace in Westminster, and one, of who≈øe ancient fidelitie both the late Queene and our now Soueraigne haue had large proofe: who according to the tru≈øt committed vnto him, went about the midnight next after, to the Parliament-hou≈øe, accompanied with ≈øuch a ≈ømall number as was fit for that errand. But before his entry in the hou≈øe,
Fawkes found at midnight without the hou≈øe. finding Thomas Percies alleaged man ≈øtanding without the doores, his cloathes and bootes on at ≈øo dead a time of the night, he re≈øolued to apprehend him, as hee did, and thereafter went forward to the ≈øearching of the hou≈øe, where after he had cau≈øed to be ouerturned ≈øome of the Billets and Coales, he fir≈øt found one of the ≈ømall Barrels of Powder, and after all the re≈øt, to the number of thirty ≈øixe Barrels, great and ≈ømall: And thereafter ≈øearching the fellow, whom he had taken, found three matches, and all other in≈øtruments fit for blowing vp the Powder, readie vpon him, which made him in≈øtantly confe≈ø≈øe his owne guiltine≈ø≈øe, declaring al≈øo vnto him, That if hee had happened to be within the hou≈øe when hee tooke him, as he was immediatly before (at the ending of his worke) hee would not haue failed to haue blowen him vp, hou≈øe and all.

Thus after Sir Thomas had cau≈øed the wretch to bee ≈øurely bound, and well guarded by the company hee had brought with him, hee him≈øelfe returned backe to the Kings Palace, and gaue warning of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to the Lord Chamberlaine, and Earle of Salisburie, who immediatly warning the re≈øt of the Councell that lay in the hou≈øe, as ≈øoone as they could get them≈øelues ready, came, with their fellow Coun≈øellers, to the Kings Bedchamber, being at that time neere foure of the clocke in the morning. And at the fir≈øt entry of the Kings Chamber doore, Vpon Sir Thomas Kneuets returne the Councel warned. the Lord Chamberlaine, being not any longer able to conceale his ioy for the preuenting of ≈øo great a danger, told the King in a confu≈øed ha≈øte, that all was found and di≈øcouered, and the Traitor in hands and fa≈øt bound.

Then, order beeing fir≈øt taken for ≈øending for the re≈øt of the Councell that lay in the Towne, The pri≈øoner him≈øelfe was brought into the hou≈øe, where in re≈øpect of the ≈øtrangenes of the accident, no man was ≈øtayed from
the ≈øight or ≈øpeaking with him. And within a while after, the Council did examine him; Who ≈øeeming to put on a Romane re≈øolution, did both to the Councill, and to euery other per≈øon that ≈øpake with him that day, appeare ≈øo con≈øtant and ≈øetled vpon his grounds, as wee all thought wee had found ≈øome new Mutius Scaeuola borne in England. For notwith≈øtanding the horrour of the fact, the guilt of his con≈øcience, his ≈øudden ≈øurpri≈øing, the terrour which ≈øhould haue bene ≈øtroken in him by comming into the pre≈øence of ≈øo graue a Councill, and the re≈øtle≈ø≈øe and confu≈øed que≈øtions that euery man all that day did vexe him with; Yet was his countenance ≈øo farre from being deiected, as he often ≈ømiled in ≈øcornefull maner, not onely auowing the Fact, but repenting onely, with the ≈øaid Scaeuola, his failing in the execution thereof, whereof (he ≈øaid) the diuel and not God, was the di≈øcouerer: An≈øwering quickly to euery mans obiection, ≈øcoffing at any idle que≈øtions which were propounded vnto him, and ie≈øting with ≈øuch as he thought had no authoritie to examine him. All that day could the Councill get nothing out of him touching his Complices, refu≈øing to an≈øwere to any ≈øuch que≈øtions which hee thought might di≈øcouer the plot, and laying all the blame vpon him≈øelfe; Whereunto he ≈øaid hee was mooued onely for Religion and con≈øcience ≈øake, denying the King to be his lawfull Soueraigne, or the Anoynted of God, in re≈øpect he was an hereticke, and giuing him≈øelfe no other name then Iohn Iohn≈øon, ≈øeruant to Thomas Percie. But the next morning being caried to the Tower, hee did not there remaine aboue two or three dayes, being twi≈øe or thri≈øe in that ≈øpace reexamined, and the Racke onely offered and ≈øhewed vnto him, when the maske of his Romane fortitude did vi≈øibly beginne to weare and ≈ølide off his face; And then did hee beginne to confe≈ø≈øe part of the trewth, and thereafter to open the whole matter, as doeth appeare by his depo≈øitions immediatly following.

div.head: THE TREW COPIE OF THE DECLARATION OF GVIDO FAWKES, TAKEN IN THE PRESENCE OF THE Coun≈øellers, who≈øe names are vnder written.
div.p:
I Confe≈ø≈øe, that a practi≈øe in generall was fir≈øt broken vnto me, again≈øt his Maie≈øtie for reliefe of the Catholique cau≈øe, and not inuented or propounded by my ≈øelfe. And this was fir≈øt propounded vnto mee about Ea≈øter la≈øt was twelue moneth beyond the Seas, in the Low-Countreys of the Archdukes obei≈øance, by Thomas Winter, who came thereupon with mee
into England, and there wee imparted our purpo≈øe to three other Gentlemen more, namely, Robert Catesby, Thomas Percie, and Iohn Wright; who all fiue con≈øulting together of the meanes how to execute the ≈øame, and taking a vow among our ≈øelues for ≈øecrecie; Catesby propounded to haue it performed by Gunpowder, and by making a Myne vnder the vpper Hou≈øe of Parliament: which place wee made choice of the rather, becau≈øe Religion hauing bene vniu≈øtly ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed there, it was fitte≈øt that Iu≈øtice and puni≈øhment ≈øhould be executed there.

This being re≈øolued among≈øt vs, Thomas Percy hired an hou≈øe at We≈øtmin≈øter for that purpo≈øe, neere adioyning to the Parliament Hou≈øe, and there we begun to make our Myne about the 11. of December 1604.

The fiue that fir≈øt entred into the worke, were Thomas Percy, Robert Catesby, Thomas Winter, Iohn Wright, and my ≈øelfe: and ≈øoone after wee tooke another vnto vs, Chri≈øtopher Wright, hauing ≈øworne him al≈øo, and taken the Sacrament for ≈øecrecie.

When we came to the very foundation of the wall of the Hou≈øe, which was about three yards thicke, and found it a matter of great difficultie, wee tooke vnto vs another Gentleman, Robert Winter, in like maner with oath and Sacrament as afore≈øaid.

It was about Chri≈øtmas when we brought our Myne vnto the Wal, and about Candlemas we had wrought the Wall halfe through: And while≈øt they were in working, I ≈øtood as Sentinell to de≈øcrie any man that came neere, whereof I gaue them warning, and ≈øo they cea≈øed vntill I gaue notice againe to proceed.
All we ≈øeuen lay in the Hou≈øe, and had ≈øhot and powder, being re≈øolued to die in that place before we ≈øhould yeeld or be taken.

As they were working vpon the wall, they heard a ru≈øhing in a cellar of remoouing of coales, whereupon we feared wee had bene di≈øcouered: and they ≈øent mee to goe to the cellar, who finding that the coales were a ≈øelling, and that the cellar was to be let, viewing the commoditie thereof for our purpo≈øe, Percy went and hired the ≈øame for yeerely rent.

Wee had before this prouided and brought into the Hou≈øe twentie barrels of powder, which we remooued into the cellar, and couered the ≈øame with billets and faggots, which were prouided for that purpo≈øe.

About Ea≈øter, the Parliament being prorogued till October next, wee di≈øper≈øed our ≈øelues, and I retired into the Low countreys by aduice and direction of the re≈øt, a≈øwell to acquaint Owen with the particulars of the plot, as al≈øo le≈øt by my longer ≈øtay I might haue growne ≈øu≈øpicious, and ≈øo haue come in que≈øtion.

In the meane time Percy hauing the key of the cellar, layd in more powder and wood into it. I returned about the beginning of September next, and then receiuing the key againe of Percy, wee brought in more powder and billets to couer the ≈øame againe, and ≈øo I went for a time into the countrey till the 30. of October.

It was further re≈øolued among≈øt vs, that the ≈øame day that this acte ≈øhould haue bene performed, ≈øome other of our confederates ≈øhould haue ≈øurpri≈øed the per≈øon of the Lady ELIZABETH the Kings elde≈øt daughter, who was kept in Warwick≈øhire at the Lord Haringtons hou≈øe, and pre≈øently haue proclaimed her Queene, hauing a proiect of a Proclamation ready for that purpo≈øe, wherein wee made no mention of altering of Religion, nor would haue auowed the deed to be ours, vntill we ≈øhould haue had power ynough to make our partie good, and then wee would haue auowed both.

Concerning duke CHARLES the Kings ≈øecond ≈øonne, we had ≈øundry con≈øultations how to ≈øeize on his per≈øon: But becau≈øe wee found no meanes how to compa≈ø≈øe it (the duke being kept neere London, where we had not forces ynough) wee re≈øolued to ≈øerue our turne with the Lady ELIZABETH.
