div.p: ANd in regard that before this di≈øcour≈øe could be ready to goe to the Pre≈ø≈øe, Thomas Winter being apprehended, and brought to the Tower, made a confe≈ø≈øion in ≈øub≈øtance agreeing with this former of Fawkes, onely larger in ≈øome circum≈øtances: I haue thought good to in≈øert the ≈øame likewi≈øe in this place, for the further clearing of the matter, and greater benefit of the Reader.

div.head: THOMAS WINTERS CONFESSION, TAKEN THE XXIII. OF NOVEMBER 1605. IN THE PRESENCE OF the Coun≈øellors, who≈øe names are vnder-written.
div.p: NOt out of hope to obtaine pardon: for, ≈øpeaking of my temporall part, I may ≈øay, The fault is greater then can bee forgiuen; nor affecting hereby the title of a good Subiect; for I mu≈øt redeeme my countrey from as great a danger, as I haue hazarded the bringing of her into, before I can purcha≈øe any ≈øuch opinion, Onely at your Honours command I will briefly ≈øet downe mine owne accu≈øation, and how farre I haue proceeded in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; which I ≈øhall the faithfullier doe, ≈øince I ≈øee ≈øuch cour≈øes are not plea≈øing to Almightie God, and that all, or the mo≈øt materiall parts haue bene already confe≈ø≈øed.

I remained with my brother in the countrey, from Alhallontyde vntill the beginning of Lent, in the yeere of our Lord 1603. the fir≈øt yeere of the Kings reigne: about which time ma≈øter Catesby ≈øent thither, intreating me to come to London, where hee and other my friends would be glad to ≈øee me. I de≈øired him to excu≈øe me: for I found my ≈øelfe not very well di≈øpo≈øed; and (which had happened neuer to mee before) returned the me≈ø≈øenger without my company. Shortly I receiued another letter, in any wi≈øe to come. At the ≈øecond ≈øummons I pre≈øently came vp, and found him with ma≈øter Iohn Wright at Lambeth, where he brake with me, how nece≈ø≈øary it was not to for≈øake our countrey (for he knew I had then a re≈øolution to goe ouer) but to deliuer her from the ≈øeruitude in which ≈øhee remained, or at lea≈øt to a≈ø≈øi≈øt her with our vttermo≈øt endeuours. I an≈øwered, That I had often hazarded my life vpon farre lighter termes, and now would not refu≈øe any good occa≈øion, wherein I might doe ≈øeruice to the Catholicke cau≈øe; but for my ≈øelfe I knew no meane probable to ≈øucceed. He ≈øaid that he had bethought him of a way at one in≈øtant to deliuer vs from all our bonds, and without any forraine helpe to replant againe the Catholicke Religion; and with all told mee in a word, It was to blow vp the Parliament hou≈øe with Gunpowder; for, ≈øaid he, in that place haue they done vs all the mi≈øchiefe, and perchance God hath de≈ø≈øeigned that place for their puni≈øhment. I wondered at the ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe of the conceipt, and told him that trew it was, this ≈øtrake at the root, and would breed a confu≈øion fit to beget new alterations; But if it ≈øhould not take effect (as mo≈øt of this nature mi≈øcaried)
the ≈øcandall would be ≈øo great which Catholicke Religion might hereby ≈øu≈øtaine, as not onely our enemies, but our friends al≈øo would with good rea≈øon condemne vs. He told me, The nature of the di≈øea≈øe required ≈øo ≈øharpe a remedie, and asked me if I would giue my con≈øent. I told him, yes, in this or what els ≈øoeuer; if he re≈øolued vpon it, I would venture my life. But I propo≈øed many difficulties, As want of an hou≈øe, and of one to cary the Myne, noy≈øe in the working, and ≈øuch like. His an≈øwere was, Let vs giue an attempt, and where it faileth, pa≈ø≈øe no further. But fir≈øt, quoth hee, Becau≈øe wee will leaue no peaceable and quiet way vntryed, you ≈øhall goe ouer, and informe the Con≈øtable of the ≈øtate of the Catholickes here in England, intreating him to ≈øollicite his Maie≈øtie at his comming hither, that the penall Lawes may be recalled, and wee admitted into the rancke of his other Subiects; withall, you may bring ouer ≈øome confident Gentleman, ≈øuch as you ≈øhall vnder≈øtand be≈øt able for this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and named vnto mee ma≈øter Fawkes. Shortly after, I pa≈ø≈øed the Sea, and found the Con≈øtable at Bergen neere Dunkirke, where, by helpe of ma≈øter Owen I deliuered my me≈ø≈øage; Who≈øe an≈øwere was, that hee had ≈øtrict command from his Ma≈øter, to doe all good Offices for the Catholickes, and for his owne part hee thought him≈øelfe bound in con≈øcience ≈øo to doe, and that no good occa≈øion ≈øhould be omitted, but ≈øpake to him nothing of this matter.

Returning to Dunkirck with ma≈øter Owen, wee had ≈øpeach whether hee thought the Con≈øtable would faithfully helpe vs, or no. He ≈øaid he beleeued nothing le≈ø≈øe, and that they ≈øought onely their owne ends, holding ≈ømall account of Catholicks. I told him that there were many Gentlemen in England, who would not for≈øake their countrey vntill they had tried the vttermo≈øt, & rather venture their liues, then for≈øake her in this mi≈øerie. And to adde one more to our number, as a fit man both for coun≈øel and execution of what≈øoeuer we ≈øhould re≈øolue, wi≈øhed for ma≈øter Fawkes, whom I had heard good commendations of: hee told mee the Gentleman de≈øerued no le≈ø≈øe, but was at Bru≈ø≈øels, and that if he came not, as happily he might, before my departure, he would ≈øend him ≈øhortly after into England. I went ≈øoone after to O≈øtend, where ≈øir William Stanley as then was not, but came two daies after. I remained with him three or foure daies, in which time I asked him, if the Catholicks in England ≈øhould do any thing to helpe them≈øelues, whether he thought the Archduke would ≈øecond them? He an≈øwered, No, for all tho≈øe parts were ≈øo de≈øirous of peace with England, as they would endure no ≈øpeach of other enterpri≈øe: neither were it fit, ≈øaid hee, to ≈øet any proiect afoot, now the Peace is vpon concluding. I told him there was no ≈øuch re≈øolution, and ≈øo fell to di≈øcour≈øe of other matters, vntill I came to ≈øpeake of ma≈øter Fawkes, who≈øe company I wi≈øhed ouer into England. I asked of his ≈øufficiencie in the warres, and told him wee ≈øhould need ≈øuch as hee, if occa≈øion required; hee gaue very good commendations of him. And as wee were thus di≈øcour≈øing, and I ready to depart for Newport,
and taking my leaue of Sir William, Ma≈øter Fawkes came into our companie, newly returned, and ≈øaluted vs. This is the Gentleman, ≈øaid Sir William, that you wi≈øhed for, and ≈øo we embraced againe. I told him ≈øome good friends of his wi≈øhed his companie in England, and that if hee plea≈øed to come to Dunkircke, wee would haue further conference, whither I was then going: ≈øo taking my leaue of them both, I departed. About two dayes after came Ma≈øter Fawkes to Dunkirck, where I told him that we were vpon a re≈øolution to doe ≈øomewhat in England, if the Peace with Spaine helped vs not, but had as yet re≈øolued vpon nothing; ≈øuch or the like talke wee pa≈ø≈øed at Graueling, where I lay for a winde, and when it ≈øerued came both in one Pa≈ø≈øage to Greenwich, neere which place wee tooke a paire of Oares, and ≈øo came vp to London, and came to Ma≈øter Catesby whom wee found in his lodging; hee welcommed vs into England, and asked mee what newes from the Con≈øtable. I told him, good words, but I feared the deedes would not an≈øwere: This was the beginning of Ea≈øter Terme, and about the midde≈øt of the ≈øame Terme, (whether ≈øent for by Ma≈øter Catesby, or vpon ≈øome bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of his owne) vp came Ma≈øter Thomas Percy. The fir≈øt word hee ≈øpake (after hee came into our company) was, Shall we alwayes (Gentlemen) talke, and neuer doe any thing? Ma≈øter Catesby took him a≈øide, and had ≈øpeach about ≈øomewhat to be done, ≈øo as fir≈øt we might all take an oath of ≈øecrecie, which wee re≈øolued within two or three dayes to doe: ≈øo as there we met behind S. Clements, Ma≈øter Catesby, Ma≈øter Percy, Ma≈øter Wright, Ma≈øter Guy Fawkes, and my ≈øelfe; and hauing vpon a Primer giuen each other the oath of ≈øecrecie, in a chamber where no other bodie was, wee went after into the next roome and heard Ma≈ø≈øe, and receiued the ble≈ø≈øed Sacrament vpon the ≈øame. Then did Ma≈øter Catesby di≈øclo≈øe to Ma≈øter Percy, and I together with Iacke Wright, tell to Ma≈øter Fawkes the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe for which wee tooke this oath, which they both approued. And then was M. Percy ≈øent to take the hou≈øe, which M. Catesby in mine ab≈øence, had learned did belong to one Ferris, which with ≈øome difficultie in the end he obtained, and became, as Ferris before was, Tenant to Whynniard. M. Fawkes vnderwent the name of M. Percies man, calling him≈øelfe Iohn≈øon, becau≈øe his face was the mo≈øt vnknowen, and receiued the keyes of the hou≈øe, vntill wee heard that the Parliament was adiourned to the ≈øeuenth of Februarie: At which time we all departed ≈øeuerall wayes into the countrey, to meete againe at the beginning of Michaelmas Terme. Before this time al≈øo it was thought conuenient to haue a hou≈øe that might an≈øwere to M. Percies, where we might make proui≈øion of powder and wood for the Mine, which beeing there made ready, ≈øhould in a night be conueyed by boate to the hou≈øe by the Parliament, becau≈øe wee were loath to foile that with often going in and out. There was none that we could deui≈øe ≈øo fit as Lambeth, where Ma≈øter Catesby often lay, and to bee keeper thereof (by M. Catesbies choice) we receiued into the number, Keyes, as a tru≈øtie hone≈øt man: this was about a moneth before Michaelmas.

Some fortnight after towards the beginning of the Terme, M. Fawkes and I came to M. Catesby at Morecrofts, where we agreed that now was time to beginne and ≈øet things in order for the Mine. So as Ma≈øter Fawkes went to London, and the next day ≈øent for me to come ouer to him: when I came, the cau≈øe was, for that the Scotti≈øh Lords were appointed to ≈øit in conference of the Vnion in Ma≈øter Percies hou≈øe. This hindered our beginning vntill a fortnight before Chri≈øtmas, by which time both Ma≈øter Percie and Ma≈øter Wright were come to London, and wee again≈øt their comming had prouided a good part of the powder: ≈øo as wee all fiue entred with tooles fit to beginne our worke, hauing prouided our ≈øelues of Baked-meates, the le≈ø≈øe to need ≈øending abroad. We entred late in the night, and were neuer ≈øeene ≈øaue onely Ma≈øter Percies man, vntill Chri≈øtmas Eue, In which time we wrought vnder a little Entry to the wall of the Parliament hou≈øe, and vnderpropped it, as we went, with wood.

While≈øt we were together, we began to fa≈øhion our bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and di≈øcour≈øed what we ≈øhould doe after this deed was done. The fir≈øt que≈øtion was how we might ≈øurprize the next heire, the Prince haply would bee at the Parliament with the King his Father, how ≈øhould wee then bee able to ≈øeaze on the Duke? This burthen Ma≈øter Percie vndertooke, that by his acquaintance, hee, with another Gentleman would enter the Chamber without ≈øu≈øpition, and hauing ≈øome doozen others at ≈øeuerall doores to expect his comming, and two or three on hor≈øebacke at the Court gate to receiue him, hee would vndertake (the blow beeing giuen, vntill which hee would attend in the Dukes Chamber) to carrie him ≈øafe away: for hee ≈øuppo≈øed mo≈øt of the Court would bee ab≈øent, and ≈øuch as were there not ≈øu≈øpecting, or vnprouided for any ≈øuch matter. For the Lady ELIZABETH, it were ea≈øie to ≈øurprize her in the Countrey, by drawing friends together at an hunting neere the Lord Haringtons, and A≈øhbie, M. Catesbies hou≈øe, being not farre off was a fit place for preparation.
The next was for money and hor≈øes, which if wee could prouide in any rea≈øonable mea≈øure (hauing the Heire apparant) and the fir≈øt knowledge by foure or fiue dayes, was oddes ≈øufficient.

Then what Lords we ≈øhould ≈øaue from the Parliament, which was fir≈øt agreed in generall as many as we could that were Catholickes, or ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed: but after we de≈øcended to ≈øpeake of particulars.

Next, what forraine Princes wee ≈øhould acquaint with this before, or ioyne with after. For this point wee agreed, that fir≈øt wee could not enioyne Princes to that ≈øecrecie, nor oblige them by oath, ≈øo to be ≈øecure of their promi≈øe: be≈øides, we knew not whether they will approue the proiect or di≈ølike it: And if they doe allow thereof, to prepare before, might beget ≈øu≈øpition, and not to prouide vntill the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe were acted, the ≈øame letter that caried newes of the thing done, might as well intreate their helpe and furtherance. Spaine is too ≈ølow in his preparations to hope any good from in the fir≈øt extremities, and France too neere and too dangerous,
who with the ≈øhipping of Holland, we feared of all the world might make away with vs.

But while we were in the middle of the≈øe di≈øcour≈øes, we heard that the Parliament ≈øhould bee anew adiourned vntill after Michaelmas, vpon which tidings we broke off both di≈øcour≈øe and working vntill after Chri≈øtmas. About Candlemas we brought ouer in a boate the powder, which we had prouided at Lambeth, and laide it in M. Percies hou≈øe, becau≈øe wee were willing to haue all our danger in one place.

We wrought al≈øo another fortnight in the Mine again≈øt the ≈øtone wall, which was very hard to beate thorow; at which time we called in Kit Wright, and neare to Ea≈øter, as we wrought the third time, opportunitie was giuen to hire the Cellar, in which we re≈øolued to lay the powder, and leaue the Mine.

Now by rea≈øon that the charge of maintaining vs all ≈øo long together, be≈øides the number of ≈øeuerall hou≈øes, which for ≈øeuerall v≈øes had beene hired, and buying of powder &c. had layen heauie on M. Catesby alone to ≈øupport; it was nece≈ø≈øarie for him to call in ≈øome others to ea≈øe his charge, and to that ende de≈øired leaue, that hee, with M. Percy, and a third, whom they ≈øhould call, might acquaint whom they thought fit and willing to the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe: for many, ≈øaid hee, may be content that I ≈øhould know, who would not therefore that all the company ≈øhould be acquainted with their names: to this we all agreed.

After this Ma≈øter Fawkes laid into the Cellar (which hee had newly taken) a thou≈øand of Billets, and fiue hundred of Faggots, and with that couered the Powder, becau≈øe we might haue the Hou≈øe free, to ≈øuffer any one to enter that would. Ma≈øter Catesby wi≈øhed vs to con≈øider, whether it were not now nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øend M. Fawkes ouer, both to ab≈øent him≈øelfe for a time, as al≈øo to acquaint Sir William Stanley and M. Owen with this matter. Wee agreed that he ≈øhould (prouided that hee gaue it them with the ≈øame othe that wee had taken it before) videlicet, to keepe it ≈øecret from all the world. The rea≈øon why we de≈øired Sir William Stanley ≈øhould be acquainted herewith was, to haue him with vs ≈øo ≈øoone as he could: And for M. Owen, hee might holde good corre≈øpondencie after with forreine Princes. So M. Fawkes departed about Ea≈øter for Flanders, and returned the latter end of Augu≈øt. He tolde me that when he arriued at Bru≈ø≈øels, Sir William Stanley was not returned from Spaine, ≈øo as hee vttered the matter onely to Owen, who ≈øeemed well plea≈øed with the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, but tolde him that furely Sir William would not be acquainted with any plot, as hauing bu≈øine≈ø≈øe now afoot in the Court of England; but he him≈øelfe would be alwayes readie to tell it him, and ≈øend him away ≈øo ≈øoone as it were done.

About this time did M. Percy and M. Catesby meete at the Bathe, where they agreed that the company being yet but few, M. Catesby ≈øhould haue the others authoritie to call in whom hee thought be≈øt; By which authoritie hee called in after, Sir Euerard Digby, though at what time I know not,
and la≈øt of all M. Francis Tre≈øham. The fir≈øt promi≈øed, as I heard M. Catesby ≈øay, fifteene hundred pounds; the ≈øecond two thou≈øand pounds; M. Percy him≈øelfe promi≈øed all that hee could get of the Earle of Northumberlands rents, which was about foure thou≈øand pounds, and to prouide many galloping hor≈øes to the number of ten.

Meane while M. Fawkes and my ≈øelfe alone bought ≈øome new Powder, as ≈øu≈øpecting the fir≈øt to be danke, and conueyed it into the Cellar, and ≈øet it in order, as wee re≈øolued it ≈øhould ≈øtand. Then was the Parliament anew prorogued vntill the fift of Nouember, ≈øo as we all went downe vntil ≈øome ten dayes before, when M. Catesby came vp with M. Fawkes to an hou≈øe by Enfield Chace called White-webbes, whither I came to them, and M. Catesby willed me to enquire whether the yong Prince came to the Parliament: I tolde him that I heard that his Grace thought not to be there. Then mu≈øt wee haue our Hor≈øes ≈øaid M. Catesby beyond the water, and proui≈øion of more company to ≈øurpri≈øe the Prince, and leaue the Duke alone.

Two dayes after being Sunday at night, in came one to my chamber, and told me that a letter had beene giuen to my L. Mountegle to this effect, That he wi≈øhed his Lord≈øhips ab≈øence from the Parliament, becau≈øe a blow would there be giuen; which letter he pre≈øently caried to my L. of Salisbury.

On the morrow I went to White-webbes, and told it M. Catesby, a≈ø≈øuring him withall that the matter was di≈øclo≈øed; and wi≈øhing him in any ca≈øe to for≈øake his Countrey. He told me he would ≈øee further as yet, and re≈øolued to ≈øend M. Fawkes to trie the vttermo≈øt, prote≈øting if the part belonged to him≈øelfe, he would trie the ≈øame aduenture.
On Wedne≈øday Ma≈øter Fawkes went and returned at night, of which we were very glad.

Thur≈øday I came to London, and Friday Ma≈øter Catesby, Ma≈øter Tre≈øham and I met at Barnet, where wee que≈øtioned how this Letter ≈øhould be ≈øent to my L. Mountegle, but could not conceiue, for Ma≈øter Tre≈øham for≈øware it, whom we onely ≈øu≈øpected.

On Saturday night I met M. Tre≈øham againe in Lincolnes Inne walkes: wherein he tolde ≈øuch ≈øpeeches, that my Lord of Salisbury ≈øhould v≈øe to the King, as I gaue it lo≈øt the ≈øecond time, and repeated the ≈øame to M. Catesby, who hereupon was re≈øolued to be gone, but ≈øtayed to haue M. Percy come vp, who≈øe con≈øent herein wee wanted. On Sunday M. Percy being dealt with to that end, would needs abide the vttermo≈øt triall.

This ≈øu≈øpicion of all hands put vs into ≈øuch confu≈øion, as M. Catesby re≈øolued to goe downe into the countrey the Munday that M. Percy went to Syon, and M. Percy re≈øolued to follow the ≈øame night, or early the next morning. About fiue of the clocke being Tue≈øday, came the yonger Wright to my Chamber, and tolde me that a Nobleman called the L. Mountegle, ≈øaying, Ari≈øe, and come along to E≈ø≈øex hou≈øe, for I am going to call vp my L. of Northumberland, ≈øaying withall, The matter is di≈øcouered Goe backe M. Wright (quoth I) and learne what you can about E≈ø≈øex gate. Shortly hee
returned and ≈øaid, Surely all is lo≈øt: for Lepton is got on hor≈øebacke at E≈øsex doore, and as he parted, he asked if their Lord≈øhips would haue any more with him: and being an≈øwered No, is rode fa≈øt vp Fleet≈øtreete as hee can ride. Goe you then (quoth I) to M. Percy, for ≈øure it is for him they ≈øeeke, and bid him be gone, I will ≈øtay and ≈øee the vttermo≈øt. Then I went to the Court gates, and found them ≈øtraitly guarded, ≈øo as no body could enter. From thence I went downe towards the Parliament hou≈øe, and in the middle of Kings-≈øtreet, found the Guard ≈øtanding that would not let me pa≈ø≈øe. And as I returned I heard one ≈øay, There is a Trea≈øon di≈øcouered, in which the King and the Lords ≈øhould haue beene blowen vp. So then I was fully ≈øatisfied that all was knowen, and went to the Stable where my gelding ≈øtood, and rode into the countrey. Ma≈øter Catesby had appointed our meeting at Dunchurch, but I could not ouertake them vntill I came to my brothers, which was Wedne≈øday night. On Thur≈øday wee tooke the Armour at my Lord Wind≈øores, and went that night to one Stephen Littletons hou≈øe, where the next day (being Friday) as I was early abroad to di≈øcouer, my man came to me, and ≈øaid, that an heauie mi≈øchance had ≈øeuered all the company, for that M. Catesby, M. Rookwood, and M. Grant, were burned with Gunpowder vpon which ≈øight the re≈øt di≈øper≈øed. Ma≈øter Littleton wi≈øhed me to flie, and ≈øo would hee. I told him I would fir≈øt ≈øee the body of my friend and bury him, what≈øoeuer befell me. When I came, I found M. Catesby rea≈øonable well, Ma≈øter Percy, both the Wrights, M. Rookwood, and Ma≈øter Grant. I asked them what they re≈øolued to doe: they an≈øwered, We meane here to die. I ≈øaid againe, I would take ≈øuch part as they did. About eleuen of the clocke came the company to be≈øet the hou≈øe, and as I walked into the court, I was ≈øhot into the ≈øhoulder, which lo≈øt me the v≈øe of mine arme: the next ≈øhot was the elder Wright ≈øtricken dead, after him the yonger M. Wright, and fourthly Ambro≈øe Rookwood ≈øhot. Then ≈øaid M. Catesby to me, (≈øtanding before the doore they were to enter) Stand by me Tom, and we will die together. Sir (quoth I) I haue lo≈øt the v≈øe of my right arme, and I feare that will cau≈øe me to be taken. So as wee ≈øtood clo≈øe together, M. Catesby, M. Percy, and my ≈øelfe, they two were ≈øhot (as farre as I could gue≈ø≈øe with one Bullet) and then the company entred vpon me, hurt me in the Belly with a Pike, and gaue me other wounds, vntill one came behinde, and caught holde of both mine armes.

postscript.head: The names of tho≈øe that were fir≈øt in the Trea≈øon, and laboured in the Mine.

list.head: Tho≈øe that were made acquainted with it, though not per≈øonally labouring in the Mine, nor in the Cellar.

div.p:
BVt here let vs leaue Fawkes in a lodging fit for ≈øuch a gue≈øt, and taking time to adui≈øe vpon his con≈øcience; and turne our ≈øelues to that part of the Hi≈øtorie, which concernes the fortune of the re≈øt of his partakers in that abominable Trea≈øon. The newes was no ≈øooner ≈øpred abroad that morning, which was vpon a Tue≈øday, the 5. of Nouember, and the fir≈øt day de≈øigned for that Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament; The newes (I ≈øay) of this ≈øo ≈øtrange and vnlooked for accident, was no ≈øooner diuulged, but ≈øome of tho≈øe Con≈øpiratours, namely Winter, and the two brothers of Wrights thought it high time for them to ha≈øten out of the towne (for Catesby was gone the night before, and Percy at foure of the clocke in the morning the ≈øame day of the Di≈øcouerie) and all of them held their cour≈øe, with more ha≈øte then good ≈øpeed to Warwick Shire toward Couentry, where the next day morning being Wedne≈øday, and about the ≈øame houre that Fawks was taken in We≈øtmin≈øter, one Graunt a gentleman hauing a≈ø≈øociated vnto him ≈øome others of his opinion, all violent Papi≈øts and ≈øtrong Recu≈øants, came to a Stable of one Benocke a rider of great
Hor≈øes, The taking of the hor≈øes out of the ≈øtable at Warwicke by Granut and others. and hauing violently broken vp the ≈øame, caried along with them all the great Hor≈øes that were therein, to the number of ≈øeuen or eight, belonging to diuers Noblemen and Gentlemen of that Countrey, who had put them into the Riders hands to be made fit for ther ≈øeruice. And ≈øo both that company of them which fledde out of London, as al≈øo Graunt and his complices met all together at Dunchurch at Sir Euerard Digby his lodging the Tue≈øday at night, after the di≈øcouerie of this treacherous Attempt: The which Digby had likewi≈øe for his part appointed a match of hunting to haue beene hunted the next day, The hunting match appointed by Sir Euerard Digby. which was Wedne≈øday, though his mind was Nimrod-like vpon a farre other maner of hunting, more bent vpon the blood of rea≈øonable men then bruite bea≈øts.

This company and helli≈øh ≈øocietie thus conuened, finding their purpo≈øe di≈øcouered, Their going into armes after the Plot di≈øcouered. and their treacherie preuented, did re≈øolue to runne a de≈øperate cour≈øe, and ≈øince they could not preuaile by ≈øo priuate a Blow, to practi≈øe by a publike rebellion, either to attaine to their Intents, or at lea≈øt to ≈øaue them≈øelues in the throng of others. And therefore gathering all the company they could vnto them, and pretending the quarrell of Religion, hauing intercepted ≈øuch proui≈øion of Armour, Hor≈øes, and Powder, as the time could permit, thought by running vp and downe the Countrey both to augment peece and peece their number (dreaming to them≈øelues that they had the vertue of a Snow-ball, which being little at the fir≈øt, and tumbling downe from a great hill groweth to a great quantitie, by encrea≈øing it ≈øelfe with the Snow that it meeteth by the way) and al≈øo that they beginning fir≈øt this braue ≈øhewe in one part of the Countrey, ≈øhould by their Sympathy and example ≈øtirre vp and encourage the re≈øt of their Religion in other parts of England to ri≈øe, as they had done there. But when they had gathered their force to the greate≈øt, Their number neuer aboue foure≈øcore. they came not to the number of foure≈øcore, and yet were they troubled all the houres of the day to keepe and containe their own ≈øeruants from ≈øtealing from them; who (notwith≈øtanding of all their care) daily left them, being farre inferiour to Gedeons ho≈øte in number, but farre more in faith or iu≈øtne≈ø≈øe of quarrell.

And ≈øo after that this Catholicke troupe had wandered a while through Warwicke-≈øhire to Worce≈øter-≈øhire, and from thence to the edge and borders of Stafford-≈øhire, this gallantly armed band had not the honour at the la≈øt to be beaten with a Kings Lieutenant or extraordinary Commi≈øsioner ≈øent downe for the purpo≈øe, Their flight. but onely by the ordinary Shiriffe of Worce≈øter-≈øhire were they all beaten, killed, taken and di≈øper≈øed. Wherein yee haue to note this following circum≈øtance ≈øo admirable, and ≈øo liuely di≈øplaying the greatne≈ø≈øe of Gods iu≈øtice, as it could not be concealed without betraying in a maner the glory due to the Almighty for the ≈øame.

Although diuers of the Kings Proclamations were po≈øted downe after the≈øe Traitors with all the ≈øpeed po≈ø≈øible, declaring the odiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of that bloodie attempt, the nece≈ø≈øitie to haue had Percie pre≈øerued aliue, if it had beene po≈ø≈øible, and the a≈ø≈øembly together of that rightly-damned crew,
now no more darned Con≈øpirators, but open and auowed Rebels: yet the farre di≈øtance of the way (which was aboue an hundred miles) together with the extreme deepene≈ø≈øe thereof, ioyned al≈øo with the ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe of the day, was the cau≈øe that the heartie and louing affections of the Kings good Subiects in tho≈øe partes preuented the ≈øpeed of his Proclamations: For vpon the third day after the flying downe of the≈øe Rebels, Ouertaken at Holbeech, in Stafford ≈øhire, Stephen Littletons hou≈øe. which was vpon the Friday next after the di≈øcouerie of their Plot, they were mo≈øt of them all ≈øurprized by the Shiriffe of Worce≈øter-≈øhire at Holbeach, about the noone of the day, and that in manner following.

Graunt, of whom I haue made mention before for taking the great hor≈øes, who had not all the preceding time ≈øtirred from his owne hou≈øe till the next morning after the attempt ≈øhould haue bene put in execution, he then laying his accompt without his Ho≈øt (as the prouerbe is) that their Plot had, without failing, receiued the day before their hoped-for ≈øucce≈ø≈øe; Tooke, or rather ≈øtole out tho≈øe hor≈øes (as I ≈øaid before) for enabling him, and ≈øo many of that ≈øoule-le≈ø≈øe ≈øociety that had ≈øtill remained in the Countrey neere about him, to make a ≈øudden ≈øurprize vpon the Kings elder daughter, the Lady ELIZABETH, hauing her re≈øidence nere by that place,
Grant attempt to ≈øurprize the Lady Elizabeth. whom they thought to haue v≈øed for the colour of their treacherous de≈ø≈øigne (His Maie≈øtie her father, her mother, and male children being all de≈øtroyed aboue.) And to this purpo≈øe al≈øo had that Nimrod, Digby, prouided his hunting match again≈øt that ≈øame time, that numbers of people beeing flocked together vpon the pretence thereof, they might the ea≈øilier haue brought to pa≈ø≈øe the ≈øudden ≈øurpri≈øe of her per≈øon.

Now the violent taking away of tho≈øe hor≈øes long before day, did ≈øeeme to bee ≈øo great a ryot in the eyes of the Common-people, that knew of no greater my≈øtery: And the bold attempting thereof did ingender ≈øuch a ≈øu≈øpition of ≈øome following Rebellion in the hearts of the wi≈øer ≈øort, as both great and ≈ømall beganne to ≈øtirre and arme them≈øelues, vpon this vnlooked-for accident: Among whom Sir Fulke Greuill the Elder, Knight, as became one both ≈øo ancient in yeeres and good reputation, and by his Office, beeing Deputie Lieutenant of Warwicke-≈øhire, though vnable in his bodie, yet by the zeale and trew feruencie of his mind, did fir≈øt apprehend this fore≈øaid Ryot to be nothing but the ≈øparkles and ≈øure indices of a following Rebellion; whereupon both ≈øtoutly and hone≈øtly hee tooke order to get into his owne hands, the Munition and Armour of all ≈øuch Gentlemen about him, as were either ab≈øent from their owne hou≈øes, or in doubtfull guard; and al≈øo ≈øent ≈øuch direction to the Townes about him, as thereupon did follow the ≈øtriking of Winter by a poore Smith, who had likewi≈øe beene taken by tho≈øe vulgar people, but that he was re≈øcued by the re≈øt of his company, who perceiuing that the Countrey before them had notice of them, ha≈øtened away with lo≈ø≈øe in their owne ≈øight, ≈øixteene of their followers being taken by the towne≈ø-men, and ≈øent pre≈øently to the Shiriffe at Warwicke, and from thence to London.

But before twelue or ≈øixteene houres pa≈øt, Catesby, Percy, the Winters, Wrights, Rookewood and the re≈øt, bringing then the a≈ø≈øurance that their maine Plot was failed and bewrayed, whereupon they had builded the golden mountaines of their glorious hopes: They then tooke their la≈øt de≈øperate re≈øolution to flocke together in a troupe, and wander, as they did, for the rea≈øons aforetold. But as vpon the one part, the zealous duety to their God and their Souereigne was ≈øo deepely imprinted in the hearts of all the meane≈øt and poore≈øt ≈øort of the people (although then knowing of no further my≈øterie then ≈øuch publike mi≈øbehauiours, as their owne eyes taught them) as notwith≈øtanding of their faire ≈øhewes and pretence of their Catholicke cau≈øe, no creature, man or woman through all the Countrey, would once ≈øo much as giue them willingly a cuppe of drinke, or any ≈øort of comfort or ≈øupport, but with execrations dete≈øted them: So on the other part, the Sheriffes of the Shires, where-through they wandered, conuening their people with all ≈øpeed po≈ø≈øible, hunted as hotly after them, as the euilne≈ø≈øe of the way, and the vnprouidedne≈ø≈øe of their people vpon that ≈øudden could permit them. And ≈øo at la≈øt after Sir Richard Verney, Shiriffe of Warwicke-≈øhire, had carefully and ≈øtreightly beene in cha≈øe of them to the confines of his Countie, part of the meaner ≈øort being al≈øo apprehended by him: Sir Richard Wal≈øh Shiriffe of Worce≈øter-≈øhire did likewi≈øe duetifully and hotely pur≈øue them thorow his Shire; And hauing gotten ≈øure triall of their taking harbour at the hou≈øe aboue-named, hee did ≈øend Trumpetters and Me≈ø≈øengers to them, commaunding them in the Kings name to render vnto him, his Maie≈øties mini≈øter; and knowing no more at that time of their guilt then was publikely vi≈øible, did promi≈øe vpon their duetifull and obedient rendring vnto him, to intercede at the Kings handes for the ≈øparing of their liues: who receiued onely from them this ≈øcornefull an≈øwere (they being better witne≈ø≈øes to them≈øelues of their inward euill con≈øciences) That hee had need of better a≈øsi≈øtance, then of tho≈øe few numbers that were with him, before hee could bee able to command or comptroll them.

But here fell the wonderous worke of Gods Iu≈øtice, The preparation to a≈ø≈øault the hou≈øe. That while this me≈ø≈øage pa≈ø≈øed betweene the Shiriffe and them, The Shiriffes and his peoples zeale beeing iu≈øtly kindled and augmented by their arrogant an≈øwere, and ≈øo they preparing them≈øelues to giue a furious a≈ø≈øault; and the other partie making them≈øelues readie within the hou≈øe to performe their promi≈øe by a defence as re≈øolute; It plea≈øed God that in the mending of the fire in their chamber, one ≈ømall ≈øparke ≈øhould flie out, and light among le≈ø≈øe then two pound weight of Powder, which was drying a little from the chimney; which being thereby blowen vp, ≈øo maymed the faces of ≈øome of the principall Rebels, and the hands and ≈øides of others of them (blowing vp with it al≈øo a great bag full of Powder, which notwith≈øtanding neuer tooke fire) as they were not only di≈øabled and di≈øcouraged hereby from any further re≈øi≈øtance, in re≈øpect Catesby him≈øelfe, Rookwood, Grant, and diuers
others of greate≈øt account among them,
Catesby who was the fir≈øt inuentor of this Trea≈øon in generall, and of the maner of working the ≈øame by powder, in ≈øpeciall, him≈øelfe now fir≈øt maimed with the blowing vp of powder, and next he and Percy both killed with one ≈øhot proceeding from powder. were thereby made vnable for defence: but al≈øo wonderfully ≈øtroken with amazement in their guiltie con≈øciences, calling to memory how God had iu≈øtly puni≈øhed them with that ≈øame In≈øtrument, which they ≈øhould haue v≈øed for the effectuating of ≈øo great a ≈øinne, according to the olde Latine, ≈øaying, In quo peccamus, in eodem plectimur; as they pre≈øently (≈øee the wonderfull power of Gods Iu≈øtice vpon guiltie con≈øciences) did all fall downe vpon their knees, praying GOD to pardon them for their bloody enterpri≈øe; And thereafter giuing ouer any further debate, opened the gate, ≈øuffered the Sheriffes people to ru≈øh in furiou≈øly among them, and de≈øperately ≈øought their owne pre≈øent de≈øtruction; The three ≈øpecials of them ioyning backes together, Catesby, Percy, and Winter, whereof two with one ≈øhot, Catesby and Percy were ≈ølaine, and the third, VVinter, taken and ≈øaued aliue.

And thus the≈øe re≈øolute and high a≈øpiring Catholikes, who dreamed of no le≈ø≈øe then the de≈øtruction of Kings and kingdomes, and promi≈øed to them≈øelues no lower e≈øtate then the gouernment of great and ancient Monarchies, were mi≈øerably defeated, and quite ouerthrowen in an in≈øtant, falling in the pit which they had prepared for others; and ≈øo fulfilling that ≈øentence which his Maie≈øtie did in a maner prophecie of them in his Oration to the Parliament: ≈øome pre≈øently ≈ølaine, others deadly wounded, ≈øtripped of their clothes, left lying mi≈øerably naked, and ≈øo dying rather of cold, then of the danger of their wounds; and the re≈øt that either were whole, or but lightly hurt, taken and led pri≈øoners by the Sheriffe the ordinary mini≈øter of Iu≈øtice, to the Gaole, the ordinarie place euen of the ba≈øe≈øt malefactors, where they remained till their ≈øending vp to London, being met with a huge confluence of people of all ≈øorts, de≈øirous to ≈øee them as the rare≈øt ≈øort of Mon≈øters; fooles to laugh at them, women and children to wonder, all the common people to gaze, the wi≈øer ≈øort to ≈øatisfie their curio≈øity in ≈øeeing the outward ca≈øes of ≈øo vnheard of a villeny: & generally all ≈øorts of people to ≈øatiate and fill their eyes with the ≈øight of them, whom in their hearts they ≈øo farre admired and dete≈øted: ≈øeruing ≈øo for a fearfull and publike ≈øpectacle of Gods fierce wrath and iu≈øt indignation.

What hereafter will be done with them, is to be left to the Iu≈øtice of his Maie≈øtie and the State: Which as no good Subiect needes to doubt will be performed in the owne due time by a publike and an exemplarie puni≈øhment: So haue we all that are faithfull and humble Subiects, great cau≈øe to pray earne≈øtly to the Almighty, that it will plea≈øe him who hath the hearts of all Princes in his hands, to put it in his Maie≈øties heart to make ≈øuch a conclu≈øion of this Tragedie to the Traitors, but Tragicomedie to the King and all his trew Subiects; as thereby the glory of God and his trew Religion may be aduanced, the future ≈øecuritie of the King and his e≈øtate procured and prouided for, all hollow and vnhone≈øt hearts di≈øcouered & preuented, & this horrible attempt (lacking due epitheres) to be ≈øo iu≈øtly auenged, That where they thought by one Catholike indeed & vniuer≈øall blow
to accompli≈øh the wi≈øh of that Romane tyrant, who wi≈øhed all the bodies in Rome to haue but one necke, and ≈øo by the violent force of Powder to breake vp as with a Pettard our triple locked peacefull gates of Ianus, which (God be thanked) they could not compa≈ø≈øe by any other meanes; they may iu≈øtly be ≈øo recompen≈øed for their trewly viperous intended parricide, As Aeneas Syl
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
doth notably write concerning the murther of K. Iames the fir≈øt of Scotland, and the following puni≈øhment of the traitours, whereof him≈øelfe was an eye witne≈ø≈øe. Hi≈øt. de Europa, cap. 46. as the ≈øhame and infamie that otherwi≈øe would light vpon this whole Nation, for hauing vnfortunately hatched ≈øuch cockatrice egges, may be repaired by the execution of famous and honourable Iu≈øtice vpon the offendors; and ≈øo the kingdome purged of them, may hereafter perpetually flouri≈øh in peace and pro≈øperitie, by the happy coniunction of the hearts of all hone≈øt and trew Subiects, with their iu≈øt and religious Soueraigne.

And thus whereas they thought to haue effaced our memories, the memory of them ≈øhall remaine (but to their perpetuall infamie) and wee (as I ≈øaid in the beginning) ≈øhall with all thankefulne≈ø≈øe eternally pre≈øerue the memory of ≈øo great a benefite. To which let euery good Subiect ≈øay AMEN.

div.head: Triplici nodo, triplex cuneus. OR AN APOLOGIE FOR THE OATH OF ALLEGIANCE.
AGAINST THE TWO BREVES OF POPE PAVLVS QVINTVS, AND THE late Letter of Cardinall BELLARMINE to G. BLACKVVEL the Arch-prie≈øt.
div.p: VVHat a mon≈øtrous, rare, nay neuer heard-of Treacherous attempt, was plotted within the≈øe few yeeres here in England, for the de≈øtruction of Mee, my Bed-fellow, and our po≈øteritie, the whole hou≈øe of Parliament, and a great number of good Subiects of all ≈øorts and degrees; is ≈øo famous already through the whole world by the infamie thereof, as it is needle≈ø≈øe to bee repeated or publi≈øhed any more; the horrour of the ≈øinne it ≈øelfe doeth ≈øo lowdly proclaime it. For if tho≈øe Gen. 4.10. crying ≈øinnes, (whereof mention is made in the Scripture) haue that epithet giuen them for their publique infamie, and for procuring as it were with a lowd cry from heauen a iu≈øt vengeance and recompen≈øe, and yet tho≈øe ≈øinnes are both old and too common, neither the world, nor any one Countrey being euer at any time cleane voyd of them: If tho≈øe ≈øinnes (I ≈øay) are ≈øaid in the Scripture to cry ≈øo lowd; What then mu≈øt this ≈øinne doe, plotted without cau≈øe, infinite in crueltie, and ≈øingular from all examples? What proceeded hereupon is likewi≈øe notorious to the whole world; our Iu≈øtice onely taking hold vpon the offenders, and that in as honourable and publique a forme of Triall, as euer was v≈øed in this Kingdome.

2. For although the onely rea≈øon they gaue for plotting ≈øo heinous an attempt, was the zeale they caried to the Romi≈øh Religion; yet were neuer any other of that profe≈øsion the wor≈øe v≈øed for that cau≈øe, as by our gracious Proclamation immediatly after the di≈øcouery of the ≈øaid fact doeth plainly appeare: onely at the next ≈øitting downe againe of the Parliament, there were Lawes made, ≈øetting downe ≈øome ≈øuch orders as were thought fit for preuenting the like mi≈øchiefe in time to come. Among≈øt which a forme of OATH was framed to be taken by my Subiects, whereby they ≈øhould make a cleare profe≈ø≈øion of their re≈øolution, faithfully to per≈øi≈øt in their obedience vnto mee, according to their naturall allegiance; To the end that I might hereby make a ≈øeparation, not onely betweene all my good Subiects in generall, and vnfaithfull Traitors, that intended to withdraw them≈øelues from my obedience; But ≈øpecially to make a ≈øeparation betweene ≈øo many of my Subiects, who although they were otherwi≈øe Popi≈øhly affected, yet retained in their hearts the print of their naturall duetie to their Soueraigne; and tho≈øe who being caried away with the like fanaticall zeale that the Powder-Traitors were, could not conteine them≈øelues within the bounds of their naturall Allegiance, but thought diuer≈øitie of religion a ≈øafe pretext for all kinde of trea≈øons, and rebellions again≈øt their Soueraigne. Which godly and wi≈øe intent, God did ble≈ø≈øe with ≈øucce≈ø≈øe accordingly: For very many of my Subiects that were Popi≈øhly affected, a≈øwell Prie≈øts, as Layicks, did freely take the ≈øame Oath: whereby they both gaue me occa≈øion to thinke the better of their fidelitie, and likewi≈øe freed them≈øelues of that heauie ≈ølander, that although they were fellow profe≈ø≈øors of one Religion with the powder-Traitors, yet were they not ioyned with them in trea≈øonable cour≈øes again≈øt their Soueraigne; whereby all quietly minded Papi≈øts were put out of de≈øpaire, and I gaue a good proofe that I intended no per≈øecution again≈øt them for con≈øcience cau≈øe, but onely de≈øired to be ≈øecured of them for ciuill obedience, which for con≈øcience cau≈øe they were bound to performe.

3. But the diuel could not haue deui≈øed a more malicious tricke for interrupting this ≈øo calme and clement a cour≈øe, then fell out by the ≈øending hither, and publi≈øhing a Breue of the Popes, countermanding all them of his profe≈ø≈øion to take this Oath; Thereby ≈øowing new ≈øeeds of ielou≈øie betweene me and my Popi≈øh Subiects, by ≈øtirring them vp to di≈øobey that lawfull commandement of their Soueraigne, which was ordeined to bee taken of them as a pledge of their fidelitie; And ≈øo by their refu≈øall of ≈øo iu≈øt a charge, to giue mee ≈øo great and iu≈øt a ground for puni≈øhment of them, without touching any matter of con≈øcience: throwing them≈øelues needle≈øly into one of the≈øe de≈øperate ≈øtraits; either with the lo≈ø≈øe of their liues and goods to renounce their Allegiance to their naturall Soueraigne; or el≈øe to procure the condemnation of their ≈øoules by renouncing the Catholicke faith, as he alleadgeth.

4. And on the other part, although di≈øparitie of Religion (the Pope
being head of the contrary part) can permit no intelligence nor intercour≈øe of me≈ø≈øengers betweene mee and the Pope: yet there being no denounced warre betweene vs, he hath by this action broken the rules of common ciuilitie and iu≈øtice betweene Chri≈øtian Princes, in thus condemning me vnheard, both by accounting me a per≈øecutor, which cannot be but implied by exhorting the Papi≈øts to endure Martyrdome; as likewi≈øe by ≈øo ≈øtraitly commanding all tho≈øe of his profe≈ø≈øion in England, to refu≈øe the taking of this Oath; thereby refu≈øing to profe≈ø≈øe their naturall obedience to me their Soueraigne. For if he thinke him≈øelfe my lawfull Iudge, wherefore hath he condemned me vnheard? And, if he haue nothing to doe with me and my gouernment (as indeed he hath not) why doeth he mittere falcem in alienam me≈ø≈øem, to meddle betweene me and my Subiects, e≈øpecially in matters that meerely and onely concerne ciuill obedience? And yet could Pius Quintus in his greate≈øt fury and auowed quarrell again≈øt the late Queene, doe no more iniurie vnto her; then hee hath in this ca≈øe offered vnto mee, without ≈øo much as a pretended or an alleadged cau≈øe. For what difference there is, betweene the commanding Subiects to rebell, and loo≈øing them from their Oath of Allegiance as Pius Quintus did; and the commanding of Subiects not to obey in making profe≈ø≈øion of their Oath of their dutifull Allegiance, as this Pope hath now done: no man can ea≈øily di≈øcerne.

5. But to draw neere vnto his Brene, wherein certainely hee hath taken more paines then he needed, by ≈øetting downe in the ≈øaid Breue the whole body of the Oath at length; whereas the onely naming of the Title thereof might as well haue ≈øerued, for any an≈øwere hee hath made thereunto (making Vna litura, that is, the flat and generall condemnation of the whole Oath to ≈øerue for all his refutation.) Therein hauing as well in this re≈øpect as in the former, dealt both vndi≈øcreetly with me, and iniuriou≈øly with his owne Catholickes. With mee; in not refuting particularly what ≈øpeciall words he quarrelled in that Oath; which if hee had done, it might haue beene that for the fatherly care I haue not to put any of my Subiects to a needle≈ø≈øe extremitie, I might haue beene contented in ≈øome ≈øort to haue reformed or interpreted tho≈øe wordes. With his owne Catholickes: for either if I had ≈øo done, they had beene thereby fully ea≈øed in that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; or at lea≈øt if I would not haue conde≈øcended to haue altered any thing in the ≈øaide Oath, yet would thereby ≈øome appearance or ≈øhadow of excu≈øe haue beene left vnto them for refu≈øing the ≈øame not as ≈øeeming thereby to ≈øwarue from their Obedience and Allegiance vnto mee, but onely beeing ≈øtayed from taking the ≈øame vpon the ≈øcrupulous tenderne≈ø≈øe of their con≈øciences, in regard of tho≈øe particular words which the Pope had noted and condemned therein.
And now let vs heare the words of his thunder.

div.head: POPE PAVLVS THE FIFT, to the ENGLISH Catholickes.
div.p: WElbeloued Sonnes, The Pope his fir≈øt Breue. Salutation and Apo≈øtolicall Benediction. The tribulations and calamities, which yee haue continually ≈øu≈øtained for the keeping of the Catholike Faith, haue alwayes afflicted vs with great griefe of minde. But for as much as we vnder≈øtand that at this time all things are more grieuous, our affliction hereby is wonderfully increa≈øed. For wee haue heard how you are compelled, by mo≈øt grieuous puni≈øhments ≈øet before you, to goe to the Churches of Heretikes, to frequent their a≈ø≈øemblies, to be pre≈øent at their Sermons. Truely wee doe vndoubtedly beleeue, that they which with ≈øo great constancie and fortitude, haue hitherto indured most cruell per≈øecutions and almost infinite mi≈øeries, that they may walke without ≈øpot in the Law of the Lord; will neuer ≈øuffer them≈øelues to be defiled with the communion of tho≈øe that haue for≈øaken the diuine Law. Yet notwithstanding, being compelled by the zeale of our Pastorall Office, and by our Fatherly care which we doe continually take for the ≈øaluation of your ≈øoules, we are inforced to admoni≈øh and de≈øire you, that by no meanes you come vnto the Churches of the Heretickes, or heare their Sermons, or communicate with them in their Rites, le≈øt you incurre the wrath of God: For the≈øe things may ye not doe without indamaging the wor≈øhip of God, and your owne ≈øaluation. As likewi≈øe you cannot, without mo≈øt euident and grieuous wronging of Gods Honour, bind your ≈øelues by the Oath, which in like maner we haue heard with very great griefe of our heart is admini≈øtred vnto you, of the tenor vnder-written. viz.

I A. B. doe trewly and ≈øincerely acknowledge, The Oath. profe≈ø≈øe, te≈øtifie and declare in my con≈øcience before God and the world, That our Soueraigne Lord King IAMES, is lawfull King of this Realme, and of all other his Maie≈øties Dominions and Countreyes: And that the Pope neither of him≈øelfe, nor by any authority of the Church or Sea of Rome, or by any other meanes with any other, hath any power or authoritie to depo≈øe the King, or to di≈øpo≈øe of any of his Maie≈øties Kingdomes or Dominions, or to authorize any forreigne Prince to inuade or annoy him or his Countreys, or to di≈øcharge any of his Subiects of their Allegiance and obedience to his Maie≈øtie, or to giue Licence or leaue to any of them to beare Armes, rai≈øe tumults, or to offer any violence or hurt to his Maie≈øties Royall Per≈øon, State or Gouernment, or to any of his Maie≈øties ≈øubiects within his Maie≈øties Dominions. Al≈øo I doe ≈øweare from my heart, that, notwith≈øtanding any declaration or ≈øentence of Excommunication, or depriuation made or granted, or to be
made or granted, by the Pope or his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, or by any Authoritie deriued, or pretended to be deriued from him or his Sea, again≈øt the ≈øaid King, his heires or ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, or any ab≈øolution of the ≈øaid ≈øubiects from their obedience; I will beare faith and trew Allegiance to his Maie≈øtie, his heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, and him and them will defend to the vttermo≈øt of my power, again≈øt all con≈øpiracies and attempts what≈øoeuer, which ≈øhalbe made again≈øt his or their Per≈øons, their Crowne and dignitie, by rea≈øon or colour of any ≈øuch ≈øentence, or declaration, or otherwi≈øe, and will doe my be≈øt endeuour to di≈øclo≈øe and make knowne vnto his Maie≈øtie, his heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, all Trea≈øons and traiterous con≈øpiracies, which I ≈øhall know or heare of, to be again≈øt him or any of them. And I doe further ≈øweare, That I doe from my heart abhorre, dete≈øt and abiure as impious and Hereticall, this damnable doctrine and po≈øition, That Princes which be excommunicated or depriued by the Pope, may be depo≈øed or murthered by their Subiects or any other what≈øoeuer. And I doe beleeue, and in con≈øcience am re≈øolued, that neither the Pope nor any per≈øon what≈øoeuer, hath power to ab≈øolue me of this Oath, or any part therof; which I acknowledge by good and full authoritie to bee lawfully mini≈øtred vnto mee, and doe renounce all Pardons and Di≈øpen≈øations to the contrarie. And all the≈øe things I doe plainely and ≈øincerely acknowledge and ≈øweare, according to the≈øe expre≈ø≈øe words by mee ≈øpoken, and according to the plaine and common ≈øen≈øe and vnder≈øtanding of the ≈øame words, without any Equiuocation, or mentall eua≈øion, or ≈øecret re≈øeruation what≈øoeuer. And I do make this Recognition and acknowledgment heartily, willingly, and trewly, vpon the trew faith of a Chri≈øtian. So helpe me GOD.

Which things ≈øince they are thus; it must euidently appeare vnto you by the words them≈øelues, That ≈øuch an Oath cannot be taken without hurting of the Catholike Faith, and the ≈øaluation of your ≈øoules; ≈øeeing it conteines many things which are flat contrary to Faith and ≈øaluation. Wherefore wee doe admoni≈øh you, that you doe vtterly ab≈øtaine from taking this and the like Oathes: which thing wee doe the more earne≈øtly require of you, becau≈øe wee haue experience of the con≈øtancie of your faith, which is tried like gold in the fire of perpetuall tribulation. Wee doe well know, that you will cheerefully vnder-goe all kinde of cruell torments what≈øoeuer, yea and con≈øtantly endure death it ≈øelfe, rather then you will in any thing offend the Maie≈øtie of GOD. And this our confidence is confirmed by tho≈øe things, which are dayly reported vnto vs, of the ≈øingular vertue, valour, and fortitude which in the≈øe la≈øt times doeth no le≈ø≈øe ≈øhine in your Martyrs, then it did in the fir≈øt beginning of the Church. Stand therefore, your loynes being girt about with veritie, and hauing on the bre≈øt-plate of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, taking the ≈øhield of Faith, be ye ≈øtrong in the Lord, and in the power of his might; And let nothing hinder you. Hee which will crowne you, and doeth in Heauen behold your conflicts, will fini≈øh the good worke which hee hath begun in you. You know how hee hath promi≈øed his di≈øciples, that hee will neuer leaue them Orphanes: for hee is faithfull which hath promi≈øed. Hold fa≈øt therefore his correction, that is, being rooted and grounded in Charitie, what≈øoeuer ye doe,
what≈øoeuer ye indeuour, doe it with one accord, in ≈øimplicitie of heart, in meekene≈ø≈øe of Spirit, without murmuring or doubting. For by this doe all men know that we are the di≈øciples of CHRIST, if we haue loue one to another. Which charitie, as it is very greatly to be de≈øired of all faithfull Christians; So certainely is it altogether nece≈ø≈øary for you, most ble≈øsed ≈øonnes. For by this your charitie, the power of the diuel is weakened, who doeth ≈øo much a≈øsaile you, ≈øince that power of his is especially vpheld by the contentions and di≈øagreement of our ≈øonnes. Wee exhort you therefore by the bowels of our Lord IESVS CHRIST, by who≈øe loue we are taken out of the iawes of eternall death; That aboue all things, you would haue mutuall charitie among you. Surely Pope Clement the eight of happy memory, hath giuen you most profitable precepts of practi≈øing brotherly charitie one to another, in his Letters in forme of a Breue, to our welbeloued ≈øonne M. George Arch priest of the Kingdome of England, dated the 5. day of the moneth of October 1602. Put them therefore diligently in practi≈øe, and be not hindered by any difficultie or doubtfulne≈ø≈øe. We command you that ye doe exactly ob≈øerue the words of tho≈øe letters, and that yee take and vnder≈øtand them ≈øimply as they ≈øound, and as they lie; all power to interpret them otherwi≈øe, being taken away. In the meane while, we will neuer cea≈øe to pray to the Father of Mercies, that he would with pitie behold your afflictions and your paines; And that he would keepe and defend you with his continuall protection: whom wee doe gently greet with our Apostolicall Benediction. Dated at Rome at S. Marke, vnder the Signet of the Fi≈øherman, the tenth of the Calends of October, 1606. the ≈øecond yeere of our Popedome.

div.head: THE ANSWERE TO THE FIRST BREVE.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, the Pope expre≈ø≈øeth herein his ≈øorrow, for that per≈øecution which the Catholiques ≈øu≈øtaine for the faiths ≈øake. Wherein, be≈øides the maine vntrewth whereby I am ≈øo iniuriou≈øly v≈øed, I mu≈øt euer auow and maintaine, as the trewth is according to mine owne knowledge, that the late Queene of famous memory, neuer puni≈øhed any Papi≈øt for Religion, but that their owne puni≈øhment was euer extorted out of her hands again≈øt her will, by their owne misbehauiour, which both the time and circum≈øtances of her actions will manife≈øtly make proofe of. For before Pius Quintus his excommunication giuing her ouer for a prey, and ≈øetting her Subiects at libertie to rebell, it is well knowne ≈øhe neuer medled with the blood or hard puni≈øhment of any Catholique, nor made any rigorous Lawes again≈øt them. And ≈øince that time, who li≈øt to compare with an indifferent eye, the manifold intended inua≈øions again≈øt her whole Kingdome,
the forreine practi≈øes, the internall publike rebellions, the priuate plots and machinations, poy≈øonings, murthers, and all ≈øorts of deui≈øes, & quid non? daily ≈øet abroach; and all the≈øe wares continually fo≈øtered and fomented from Rome; together with the continuall corrupting of her Subiects, as well by temporall bribes, as by faire and ≈øpecious promi≈øes of eternall felicitie; and nothing but booke vpon booke publikely ≈øet foorth by her fugitiues, for approbation of ≈øo holy de≈øignes: who li≈øt, I ≈øay, with an indifferent eye, to looke on the one part, vpon tho≈øe infinite and intollerable temptations, and on the other part vpon the iu≈øt, yet moderate puni≈øhment of a part of the≈øe hainous offendors; ≈øhall ea≈øily ≈øee that that ble≈ø≈øed defunct LADIE was as free from per≈øecution, as they ≈øhall free the≈øe helli≈øh In≈øtruments from the honour of martyrdome.

5. But now hauing ≈øacrificed (if I may ≈øo ≈øay) to the Manes of my late Predece≈ø≈øour, I may next with Saint PAVL iu≈øtly vindicate mine owne fame, from tho≈øe innumerable calumnies ≈øpread again≈øt me, in te≈øtifying the trewth of my behauiour toward the Papi≈øts: wherein I may trewly affirme, That what≈øoeuer was her iu≈øt and mercifull Gouernement ouer the Papi≈øts in her time, my Gouernement ouer them ≈øince hath ≈øo farre exceeded hers, in Mercie and Clemencie, as not onely the Papi≈øts them≈øelues grewe to that height of pride, in confidence of my mildne≈ø≈øe, as they did directly expect, and a≈ø≈øuredly promi≈øe to them≈øelues libertie of Con≈øcience, and equalitie with other of my Subiects in all things; but euen a number of the be≈øt and faithfullie≈øt of my ≈øayde Subiects, were ca≈øt in great feare and amazement of my cour≈øe and proceedings, euer progno≈øticating and iu≈øtly ≈øu≈øpecting that ≈øowre fruite to come of it, which ≈øhewed it ≈øelfe clearely in the Powder-Trea≈øon. How many did I honour with Knighthood, of knowen and open Recu≈øants? How indifferently did I giue audience, and acce≈ø≈øe to both ≈øides, be≈øtowing equally all fauours and honours on both profe≈ø≈øions? How free and continuall acce≈ø≈øe, had all rankes and degrees of Papi≈øts in my Court and company? And aboue all, how frankely and freely did I free Recu≈øants of their ordinarie paiments? Be≈øides, it is cuident what ≈øtrait order was giuen out of my owne mouth to the Iudges, to ≈øpare the execution of all Prie≈øts, (notwith≈øtanding their conuiction,) ioyning thereunto a gracious Proclamation, whereby all Prie≈øts, that were at libertie, and not taken, might goe out of the countrey by ≈øuch a day: my generall Pardon hauing beene extended to all conuicted Prie≈øtes in pri≈øon: whereupon they were ≈øet at libertie as good Subiects: and all Prie≈øts that were taken after, ≈øent ouer and ≈øet at libertie there. But time and paper will faile me to make enumeration of all the benefits and fauours that I be≈øtowed in generall and particular vpon Papi≈øts: in recounting whereof, euery ≈øcrape of my penne would ≈øerue but for a blot of the Popes ingratitude and iniu≈øtice, in meating me with ≈øo hard a mea≈øure for the ≈øame. So
as I thinke I haue ≈øufficiently, or at lea≈øt with good rea≈øon wiped the Magno cum anims moerore, &c. teares from the Popes eyes, for complaining vpon ≈øuch per≈øecution, who if hee had beene but politickely wi≈øe, although hee had had no re≈øpect to Iu≈øtice and Veritie, would haue in this complaint of his, made a difference betweene my pre≈øent time, and the time of the late Queene: And ≈øo by his commending of my moderation, in regard of former times, might haue had hope to haue mooued me to haue continued in the ≈øame clement cour≈øe: For it is a trew ≈øaying, that alledged kindne≈ø≈øe vpon noble mindes, doeth euer worke much. And for the maine vntrewth of any per≈øecution in my time, it can neuer bee prooued, that any were, or are put to death ≈øince I came to the Crowne for cau≈øe of Con≈øcience; except that now this di≈øcharge giuen by the Pope to all Catholiques to take their Oath of Allegiance to me, be the cau≈øe of the due puni≈øhment of many: which if it fall out to be, let the blood light vpon the Popes head, who is the onely cau≈øe thereof.

As for the next point contained in his Breue concerning his di≈øcharge of all Papi≈øts to come to our Church, or frequent our rites and ceremonies, I am not to meddle at this time with that matter, becau≈øe my errand now onely is to publi≈øh to the world the Iniurie and Iniu≈øtice done vnto me, in di≈øcharging my ≈øubiects to make profe≈ø≈øion of their obedience vnto mee. The intendement of this di≈øcour≈øe. Now as to the point where the Oath is quarrelled, it is ≈øet downe in fewe, but very weighty wordes; to wit, That it ought to be cleare vnto all Catholiques, that this Oath cannot bee taken with ≈øafetie of the Catholique Faith, and of their ≈øoules health, ≈øince it containeth many things that are plainely and directly contrarie to their faith and ≈øaluation. To this, the old ≈øaying fathered vpon the Philo≈øopher, may very fitly bee applied, Multa dicit, ≈øed pauca probat; nay indeed, Nihil omnino probat: For how the profe≈ø≈øion of the naturall Allegiance of Subiects to their Prince can be directly oppo≈øite to the faith and ≈øaluation of ≈øoules, is ≈øo farre beyond my ≈øimple reading in Diuinitie, as I mu≈øt thinke it a ≈øtrange and new A≈ø≈øertion, to proceede out of the mouth of that pretended generall Pa≈øtor of all Chri≈øtian ≈øoules. I reade indeede, and not in one, or two, or three places of Scripture, that Subiects are bound to obey their Princes for con≈øcience ≈øake, whether they were good or wicked Princes. So ≈øaid the people to Io≈øh. 1.17. Io≈øhua, As wee obeyed Mo≈øes in all things, ≈øo will wee obey thee. So the Iere. 27.12. Prophet commanded the people to obey the King of Babel, ≈øaying, Put your neckes vnder the yoke of the King of Babel, and ≈øerue him and his people, that yee may liue. So were the children of I≈ørael, vnto Exod. 5.1. Pharaoh, de≈øiring him to let them goe: ≈øo to Ezra 1.3. Cyrus, obtaining leaue of him to returne to build the Temple: and in a word, the Apo≈øtle willed all men Rom. 13 5. to bee ≈øubiect to the higher powers for con≈øcience ≈øake. Agreeable to the Scriptures did the Fathers teach.
Augu≈øt. in P≈øalm. 124. Augustine ≈øpeaking of Iulian, ≈øaith, Iulian was an vnbeleeuing Emperour: was hee not an Apostata, an Oppre≈ø≈øour, and an Idolater? Chri≈øtian Souldiers ≈øerued that vnbeleeuing Emperour: when they came to the cau≈øe of CHRIST, they would acknowledge
no Lord, but him that is in heauen. When hee would haue them to wor≈øhip Idoles and to ≈øacrifice, they preferred GOD before him: But when hee ≈øaid, Goe forth to fight, inuade ≈øuch a nation, they pre≈øently obeyed. They di≈øtingui≈øhed their eternall Lord from their temporall, and yet were they ≈øubiect euen vnto their temporall Lord, for his ≈øake that was their eternall Lord and Master. Tertull. ad Scap. Tertullian ≈øayth, A Chri≈øtian is enemie to no man, much le≈ø≈øe to the Prince, whom hee knoweth to bee appointed of God; and ≈øo of nece≈øsitie must loue, reuerence and honour him, and wi≈øh him ≈øafe with the whole Romane Empire, ≈øo long as the world ≈øhall la≈øt: for ≈øo long ≈øhall it endure. Wee honour therefore the Emperour in ≈øuch ≈øort, as is lawfull for vs, and expedient for him, as a man, the next vnto God, and obtaining from God what≈øoeuer hee hath, and onely inferiour vnto God. This the Emperour him≈øelfe would: for ≈øo is hee greater then all, while hee is inferiour onely to the trew God.
Iu≈øt. Martyr. Apol. 2. ad. Ant. Imperat. Iu≈øtine Martyr; Wee onely adore the Lord, and in all other things cheerefully performe ≈øeruice to you, profe≈øsing that you are Emperours and Princes of men.

In≈øomuch as that of Ephe≈øus repeated it foure ≈øeuerall times, That they were ≈øummoned by the Emperours Oracle, becke, charge and commaund, and betooke them≈øelues to his Godline≈ø≈øe: Vide Epistola ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ general ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Conc. Ephe≈ø. ad Augu≈øt. be≈øeeching him, that the Decrees made again≈øt Ne≈øtorius and his followers, might by his power haue their full force and validitie, as appeareth manife≈øtly in the Epi≈øtle of the generall Councell of Ephe≈øus written ad Augustos. I al≈øo reade that Chri≈øt≈øaid, His 2 Iohn 18 36. kingdome was not of this world, bidding, Giue to 3 Matt. 22.21. Ce≈øar what was Ce≈øars, and to God what was Gods. And I euer held it for an infallible Maxime in Diuinitie, That temporall obedience to a temporall Magi≈øtrate, did nothing repugne to matters of faith or ≈øaluation of ≈øoules: But that euer temporall obedience was again≈øt faith and ≈øaluation of ≈øoules, as in this Breue is alledged, was neuer before heard nor read of in the Chri≈øtian Church. And therefore I would haue wi≈øhed the Pope, before hee had ≈øet downe this commandement to all Papi≈øts here, That, ≈øince in him is the power by the infabillity of his ≈øpirit, to make new Articles of Faith when euer it ≈øhall plea≈øe him, he had fir≈øt ≈øet it downe for an Article of Faith, before he had commanded all Catholikes to beleeue and obey it. I will then conclude the an≈øwere to this point in a Dilemma.
Either it is lawfull to obey the Soueraigne in temporall things, Que≈øtion. or not.

If it be lawfull (as I neuer heard nor read it doubted of) then why is the Pope ≈øo vniu≈øt, and ≈øo cruell towards his owne Catholikes, as to command them to di≈øobey their Soueraignes lawfull commandement?

If it be vnlawfull, why hath hee neither expre≈ø≈øed any one cau≈øe or rea≈øon thereof, nor yet will giue them leaue (nay rather hee ≈øhould command and per≈øwade them in plaine termes) not to liue vnder a King whom vnto they ought no obedience?

And as for the vehement exhortation vnto them to per≈øeuere in con≈øtancie, An≈øwere to the Popes exhortation. and to ≈øuffer Martyrdome and all tribulation for this cau≈øe; it requireth no other an≈øwere then onely this, That if the ground be good whereupon hee hath commaunded them to ≈øtand, then exhortation to con≈øtancie is nece≈ø≈øarie: but if the ground be vniu≈øt and naught (as indeed it is, and I haue in part already proued) then this exhortation of his can worke no other effect, then to make him guilty of the blood of ≈øo many of his ≈øheepe, whom hee doeth thus wilfully ca≈øt away; not onely to the needle≈ø≈øe lo≈ø≈øe of their liues, and ruine of their families, but euen to the laying on of a perpetuall ≈ølander vpon all Papi≈øts; as if no zealous Papi≈øt could be a trew ≈øubiect to his Prince; and that the profe≈ø≈øion of that Religion, and the Temporall obedience to the Ciuill Magi≈øtrate, were two things repugnant and incompatible in them≈øelues. Famae vires acquirit eundo. But euill information, and vntrew reports (which being caried ≈øo farre as betweene this and Rome,
cannot but increa≈øe by the way) might haue abu≈øed the Pope, and made him di≈øpatch this Breue ≈øo ra≈øhly: For that great Citie, Queene of the World, and as them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe,
Eu≈øebius, Oecumenius and Leo hold, that by Babylon, in 1. Pet. 5.13. Rome is meant, as the Rhemi≈øts them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe. my≈øtically Babylon, cannot but be ≈øo full of all ≈øorts of Intelligencies. Be≈øides, all complainers (as the Catholikes here are) be naturally giuen to exaggerate their owne griefes, and multiply thereupon: So that it is no wonder, that euen a iu≈øt Iudge ≈øitting there, ≈øhould vpon wrong information, giue an vnrighteous ≈øentence; as ≈øome of their owne partie doe not ≈øticke to confe≈ø≈øe, That Pius Quintus was too ra≈øhly caried vpon wrong information, to pronounce his thunder of Excommunication vpon the late Queene. And it may be, the like excu≈øe ≈øhall hereafter be made for the two Breues, which See the Relation of the whole proceedings again≈øt the Traitours, Garnet and his confederates. Clemens Octauus ≈øent to ENGLAND immediatly before her death, for debarring me of the Crowne, or any other that either would profe≈ø≈øe, or any wayes tolerate the profe≈ø≈øours of our Religion; contrary to his manifold vowes and prote≈øtations, ≈øimul & eodem tempore, and as it were, deliuered vno & eodem ≈øpiritu, to diuers of my mini≈øters abroad, profe≈ø≈øing ≈øuch kindne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øhewing ≈øuch forwardne≈ø≈øe to aduance me to this Crowne. The Catholikes opinion of the Brene. Nay, the mo≈øt part of Catholikes here, finding this Breue when it came to their handes to bee ≈øo farre again≈øt Diuinitie, Policie, or naturall ≈øen≈øe, were firmely per≈øwaded that it was but a counterfeit Libell, deui≈øed in hatred of the Pope; or at the farthe≈øt, a thing ha≈øtily done vpon wrong information, as was before ≈øaid. Of which opinion were not onely the ≈øimpler ≈øort of Papi≈øts, but euen ≈øome among≈øt them of be≈øt account, both for learning and experience; whereof the Archprie≈øt him≈øelfe was one: But for ≈øoluing of this obiection, the Pope him≈øelfe hath taken new paines by ≈øending foorth a ≈øecond Breue, onely for giuing faith and confirmation to the former; That whereas before, his ≈øinne might haue beene thought to haue proceeded from ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe and mi≈ø-information, he will now wilfully and willingly double the ≈øame; whereof the Copy followeth.

div.head: TO OVR BELOVED SONNES the Engli≈øh Catholikes, Paulus P.P.∆≤ tus.
div.p: It is reported vnto vs, that there are found certaine amongst you, who when as we haue ≈øufficiently declared by our Letters, dated the la≈øt yeere on the tenth of the Calends of October in the forme of a Breue, that yee cannot with ≈øafe Con≈øcience take the Oath, which was then required of you; and when as wee haue further ≈øtraitly commanded you, that by no meanes yee ≈øhould take it: yet there are ≈øome, I ≈øay, among you, which dare now affirme, that ≈øuch Letters concerning the forbidding of the Oath were not written of our owne accord, or of our owne proper will, but rather for the re≈øpect and at the in≈øtigation of other men. And for that cau≈øe the ≈øame men doe goe about to per≈øwade you, that our commands in the ≈øaid Letters are not to be regarded. Surely this newes did trouble vs; and that ≈øo much the more, becau≈øe hauing had experience of your obedience (most dearely beloued ≈øonnes) who to the end ye might obey this holy Sea, haue godlily and valiantly contemned your riches wealth, honour, libertie, yea and life it ≈øelfe; wee ≈øhould neuer haue ≈øuspected that the trewth of our Apostolike Letters could once be called into question among you, that by this pretence ye might exempt your ≈øelues from our Commandements. But we doe herein perceiue the ≈øubtiltie and craft of the enemie of mans ≈øaluation, and we doe attribute this your backwardne≈ø≈øe rather to him, then to your owne will. And for this cau≈øe, wee haue thought good to write the ≈øecond time vnto you, and to ≈øignifie vnto you againe, That our Apostolike Letters dated the last yeere on the tenth of the Calends of October, concerning the prohibition of the Oath, were written not only vpon our proper motion, and of our certaine knowledge, but al≈øo after long and weightie deliberation v≈øed concerning all tho≈øe things, which are contained in them; and that for that cau≈øe ye are bound fully to ob≈øerue them, reiecting all interpretation per≈øwading to the contrary. And this is our meere, pure, and perfect will, being alwayes carefull of your ≈øaluation, and alwayes minding tho≈øe things, which are most profitable vnto you. And we doe pray without cea≈øing, that hee that hath appointed our lowline≈ø≈øe to the keeping of the flocke of Chri≈øt, would inlighten our thoughts and our coun≈øels: whom we doe al≈øo continually de≈øire, that he would increa≈øe in you (our beloued Sonnes) faith, constancie, and mutuall charitie and peace one to another. All whom, we doe most louingly ble≈ø≈øe with all charitable affection.
