div.head: THE ANSWERE TO THE ≈øecond BREVE.
div.p: NOw for this Breue, I may iu≈øtly reflect his owne phra≈øe vpon him, in tearming it to be The craft of the Deuill. For if the Deuill had ≈øtudied a thou≈øand yeeres, for to finde out a mi≈øchiefe for our Catholikes heere, hee hath found it in this; that now when many Catholikes haue taken their Oath, and ≈øome Prie≈øts al≈øo; yea, the Arch-prie≈øt him≈øelfe, without compunction or ≈øticking, they ≈øhall not now onely be bound to refu≈øe the profe≈ø≈øion of their naturall Allegiance to their Soueraigne, which might yet haue beene ≈øome way coloured vpon diuers ≈øcruples conceiued vpon the words of the Oath; but they mu≈øt now renounce and for≈øweare their profe≈ø≈øion of obedience alreadie ≈øworne, and ≈øo mu≈øt as it were at the third in≈øtance for≈øweare their former two Oathes, fir≈øt clo≈øely ≈øworne, by their birth in their naturall Allegiance; and next, clearely confirmed by this Oath, which doeth nothing but expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame: ≈øo as no man can now holde the faith, or procure the ≈øaluation of his ≈øoule in ENGLAND, that mu≈øt not abiure and renounce his borne and ≈øworne Allegiance to his naturall Soueraigne.

And yet it is not ≈øufficient to ratifie the la≈øt yeeres Breue, by a new one come forth this yeere; but (that not onely euery yeere, but euery moneth may produce a new mon≈øter) the great and famous Writer of the Controuer≈øies, the late vn-Ie≈øuited Cardinall Bellarmine, mu≈øt adde his talent to this good worke, by blowing the bellowes of ≈øedition, and ≈øharpening the ≈øpurre to rebellion, by ≈øending ≈øuch a Letter of his to the Archprie≈øt here, as it is a wonder how pa≈ø≈øion, and an ambitious de≈øire of maintaining that Monarchie, ≈øhould charme the wits of ≈øo famou≈øly learned a man.
The Copy whereof here followeth.

body.head: TO THE VERY REVEREND Mr. GEORGE BLACKWELL, ARCH-PRIEST of the ENGLISH: ROBERT BELLARMINE Cardinall of the holy Church of Rome, Greeting.
body.p: REuerend Sir, and brother in CHRIST; It is almo≈øt fourtie yeeres ≈øince we did ≈øee one the other: but yet I haue neuer bene vnmindfull of our ancient acquaintance, neither haue I cea≈øed, ≈øeeing I could doe you no other good, to commend your labouring most painfully in the Lords Vineyard, in my prayers to God. And I doubt not, but that I haue liued all this while in your memory, and haue had ≈øome place in your prayers at the Lords Altar. So therfore euen vnto this time we haue abidden, as S. Iohn ≈øpeaketh, in the mutuall loue one of the other, not by word or letter, but in deed and trewth. But alate me≈øsage which was brought vnto vs within the≈øe few dayes, of your bonds and impri≈øonment, hath inforced mee to breake off this ≈øilence; which me≈ø≈øage, although it ≈øeemed heauie in regard of the lo≈ø≈øe which that Church hath receiued, by their being thus depriued of the comfort of your pastorall function amongst them, yet withall it ≈øeemed ioyous, becau≈øe you drew neere vnto the glory of Martyrdome, then the which gift of God there is none more happy; That you, who haue fedde your flocke ≈øo many yeeres with the word and doctrine, ≈øhould now feed it more gloriou≈øly by the example of your patience. But another heauie tidings did not a little di≈øquiet and almost take away this ioy, which immediatly followed, of the aduer≈øaries a≈ø≈øault, and peraduenture of the ≈ølip and fall of your constancie in refu≈øing an vnlawfull Oath. Neither trewly (most deare brother) could that Oath therefore bee lawfull, becau≈øe it was offered in ≈øort tempered and modified: for you know that tho≈øe kinde of modifications are nothing el≈øe, but ≈øleights and ≈øubtilties of Satan, that the Catholique faith touching the Primacie of the Sea Apostolike, might either ≈øecretly or openly be ≈øhot at; for the which faith ≈øo many worthy Martyrs euen in that very England it ≈øelfe, haue re≈øisted vnto blood. For most certaine it is, that in what≈øoeuer words the Oath is conceiued by the aduer≈øaries of the faith in that Kingdome, it tends to this end, that the Authoritie of the head of the Church in England, may bee transferred from the ≈øucce≈ø≈øour of S. Peter, to the ≈øucce≈ø≈øour of King Henry the eight: For that which is pretended of the danger of the Kings life, if the high Priest ≈øhould haue the ≈øame power in England, which hee hath in all other Christian Kingdomes, it is altogether idle, as all that haue any vnderstanding, may ea≈øily perceiue. For it was neuer heard of from the Churches infancie vntill this day, that euer any Pope did command, that any Prince, though an Heretike, though an Ethnike, though a per≈øecutour, ≈øhould be murdered; or did approue of the fact, when it was done by any other. And why, I pray you, doeth onely the King of England ≈øeare that, which none of all other the Princes in Christendome either doeth feare, or euer did feare?

But, as I ≈øaid, the≈øe vaine pretexts are but the traps and ≈øtratagemes of Satan: Of which kinde I could produce not a fewe out of ancient Stories, if I went about to write a Booke and not an Epi≈øtle. One onely for example ≈øake, I will call to your memory. S. Gregorius Nazianzenus in his fir≈øt Oration again≈øt Iulian the Emperour, reporteth, That hee, the more ea≈øily to beguile the ≈øimple Chri≈øtians, did in≈øert the Images of the fal≈øe gods into the pictures of the Emperour, which the Romanes did v≈øe to bow downe vnto with a ciuill kinde of reuerence: ≈øo that no man could doe reuerence to the Emperours picture, but withall hee mu≈øt adore the Images of the fal≈øe gods; whereupon it came to pa≈ø≈øe that many were deceiued. And if there were any that found out the Emperours craft and refu≈øed to wor≈øhip his picture, tho≈øe were mo≈øt grieuou≈øly puni≈øhed, as men that had contemned the Emperour in his Image. Some ≈øuch like thing, me thinkes, I ≈øee in the Oath that is offered to you; which is ≈øo craftily compo≈øed, that no man can dete≈øt Trea≈øon again≈øt the King and make profe≈øsion of his Ciuill ≈øubiection, but he mu≈øt bee constramed perfidiou≈øly to denie the Primacie of the Apostolicke Sea. But the ≈øeruants of Christ, and especially the chiefe Prie≈øts of the Lord, ought to bee ≈øo farre from taking an vnlawfull Oath, where they may indamage the Faith, that they ought to beware that they giue not the lea≈øt ≈øuspicion of di≈øsimulation that they haue taken it, lea≈øt they might ≈øeeme to haue left any example of preuarication to faithfull people. Which thing that worthy Eleazar did most notably performe, who would neither eate ≈øwines fle≈øh, nor ≈øo much as faine to haue eaten it, although hee ≈øawe the great torments that did hang ouer his head; least, as him≈øelfe ≈øpeaketh in the ≈øecond Booke of the Machabees, many young men might bee brought through that ≈øimulation, to preuaricate with the Lawe. Neither did Ba≈øil the Great by his example, which is more fit for our purpo≈øe, cary him≈øelfe le≈ø≈øe worthily toward Valens the Emperour. For as Theodoret writeth in his Historie, when the Deputy of that hereticall Emperour did per≈øwade Saint Ba≈øil, that hee would not re≈øist the Emperour for a little ≈øubtiltie of a few points of doctrine; that most holy and prudent man made an≈øwere, That it was not to be indured, that the lea≈øt ≈øyllable of Gods word ≈øhould bee corrupted, but rather all kind of torment was to be embraced, for the maintenance of the Trewth thereof. Now I ≈øuppo≈øe, that there wants not amongst you, who ≈øay that they are but ≈øubtilties of Opinions that are contained in the Oath that is offered to the Catholikes, and that you are not to ≈øtrius again≈øt the Kings Authoritie for ≈øuch a little matter. But there are not wanting al≈øo amongst you holy men like vnto Ba≈øil the Great, which will openly auow, that the very lea≈øt ≈øyllable of Gods diuine Trewth is not to bee corrupted, though many torments were to bee endured, and death it ≈øelfe ≈øet before you: Amongst whom it is meete, that you ≈øhould bee one, or rather the Standard bearer, and Generall to the re≈øt. And what≈øoeuer hath beene the cau≈øe, that your Con≈øtancie hath quailed, whether it bee the ≈øuddainene≈ø≈øe of your apprehen≈øion, or the bitterne≈ø≈øe of your per≈øecution, or the imbecilitie of your old aage: yet wee tru≈øt in the goodne≈ø≈øe of God, and in your owne long continued vertue, that it will come to pa≈ø≈øe, that as you ≈øeeme in ≈øome part to haue imitated the fall of Peter and Marcellinus, ≈øo you ≈øhall happily imitate their valour in recouering your ≈øtrength, and maintaining the Trewth: For if you will diligently weigh the whole matter with your ≈øelfe, trewly you ≈øhall ≈øee, it is no ≈ømall
matter that is called in que≈øtion by this Oath, but one of the principall heads of our Faith, and foundations of Catholique Religion. For heare what your Apostle Saint Gregorie the Great hath written in his 24. Epi≈øtle of his 11. Booke. Let not the reuerence due to the Apo≈øtolique Sea, be troubled by any mans pre≈øumption; for then the ≈øtate of the members doeth remaine entire, when the Head of the Faith is not brui≈øed by any iniurie: Therefore by Saint Gregories testimonie, when they are bu≈øie about di≈øturbing or dimini≈øhing, or taking away of the Primacie of the Apo≈øtolique Sea; then are they bu≈øie about cutting off the very head of the faith, and di≈ø≈øoluing of the ≈øtate of the whole body, and of all the members. Which ≈øelfe ≈øame thing S. Le ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ th confirme in his third Sermon of his A≈ø≈øumption to the Popedom, when he ≈øaith; Our Lord had a ≈øpecial care of Peter, & praied properly for Peters faith, as though the ≈øtate of others were more ≈øtable, when their Princes mind was not to be ouercome. Whereupon him≈øelfe in his Epi≈øtle to the bi≈øhops of the prouince of Vienna, doth not doubt to affirme, that he is not partaker of the diuine My≈øterie, that dare depart from the ≈øolidity of Peter; who al≈øo ≈øaith, That who thinketh the Primacy to be denied to that Sea, he can in no ≈øort le≈ø≈øen the authority of it; but by being puft vp with the ≈øpirit of his owne pride, doth ca≈øt him≈øelfe headlong into hel. The≈øe and many other of this kind, I am very ≈øure are mo≈øt familiar to you: who be≈øides many other books, haue diligently read ouer the vi≈øible Monarchy of your owne Sanders, a most diligent writer, and one who hath worthily de≈øerued of the Church of England. Neither can you be ignorant, that the≈øe mo≈øt holy and learned men, Iohn bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter, and Tho. Moore, within our memory, for this one mo≈øt weighty head of doctrine, led the way to Martyrdome to many others, to the exceeding glory of the Engli≈øh nation. But I would put you in remembrance that you ≈øhould take heart, and con≈øidering the weightines of the cau≈øe, not to tru≈øt too much to your owne iudgement, neither be wi≈øe aboue that is meet to be wi≈øe: and if peraduenture your fall haue proceeded not vpon want of con≈øideration, but through humane infirmity, & for feare of puni≈øhment and impri≈øonment, yet do not preferre a temporall liberty to the liberty of the glory of the Sonnes of God: neither for e≈øcaping a light & momentanie tribulation, lo≈øe an eternal weight of glory, which tribulation it ≈øelfe doeth worke in you. You haue fought a good fight a long time, you haue wel-neere fini≈øhed your cour≈øe; ≈øo many yeeres haue you kept the faith: do not therefore lo≈øe the reward of ≈øuch labors; do not depriue your ≈øelfe of that crowne of righteou≈ønes, which ≈øo long agone is prepared for you; Do not make the faces of ≈øo many yours both brethren and children a≈øhamed. Vpon you at this time are fixed the eyes of all the Church: yea al≈øo, you are made a ≈øpectacle to the world, to Angels, to men; Do not ≈øo carry your ≈øelfe in this your la≈øt act, that you leaue nothing but laments to your friends, and ioy to your enemies. But rather on the contrary, which we a≈ø≈øuredly hope, and for which we continually powre forth prayers to God, display gloriou≈øly the banner of faith, and make to reioyce the Church, which you haue made heauy; ≈øo ≈øhall you not onely merite pardon at Gods hands, but a Crowne. Farewell. Quite you like a man, and let your heart be ≈øtrengthened. From Rome the 28. day of September 1607.

closer.signed: Your very Reuerend≈øhips brother and ≈øeruant in Chri≈øt, Robert Bellarmine Cardinall.

div.head: THE ANSWERE TO THE CARDINALS LETTER.
div.p: ANd now that I am to enter into the field again≈øt him by refuting his Letter, I mu≈øt fir≈øt v≈øe this prote≈øtation; That no de≈øire of vaine-glory by matching with ≈øo learned a man, maketh me to vndertake this taske; but onely the care and con≈øcience I haue, that ≈øuch ≈ømooth Circes charmes and guilded pilles, as full of exterior eloquence, as of inward vntrewths, may not haue that publike pa≈ø≈øage through the world without an an≈øwere: whereby my reputation might vniu≈øtly be darkened, by ≈øuch cloudie and foggie mi≈øts of vntrewths and fal≈øe imputations, the hearts of vn≈øtayed and ≈øimple men be mi≈ø≈øe-led, and the trewth it ≈øelfe ≈ømothered.

But before I come to the particular an≈øwere of this Letter, A great mi≈øtaking of the ≈øtate of the Que≈øtion, and ca≈øe in hand. I mu≈øt here de≈øire the world to wonder with me, at the committing of ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe an errour by ≈øo learned a man as that he ≈øhould haue pained him≈øelfe to haue ≈øet downe ≈øo elaborate a Letter, for the refutation of a quite mi≈øtaken que≈øtion: For it appeareth, that our Engli≈øh Fugitiues, of who≈øe inward ≈øocietie with him he ≈øo greatly vaunteth, haue ≈øo fa≈øt hammered in his head the Oath of Supremacie, which hath euer bene ≈øo great a ≈øcarre vnto them, as he thinking by his Letter to haue refuted the la≈øt Oath, hath in place thereof onely paied the Oath of Supremacie, which was mo≈øt in his head; as a man that being earne≈øtly caried in his thoughts vpon another matter, then he is pre≈øently in doing, will often name the matter or per≈øon he is thinking of, in place of the other thing he hath at that time in hand.

For as the Oath of Supremacie was deui≈øed for putting a difference betweene Papi≈øts, and them of our profe≈ø≈øion: ≈øo was this Oath, The difference betweene the Oath of Supremacie, and this of Allegiance. which hee would ≈øeeme to impugne, ordained for making a difference betweene the ciuilly obedient Papi≈øts, and the peruer≈øe di≈øciples of the Powder-Trea≈øon. Yet doeth all his Letter runne vpon an Inuectiue again≈øt the compul≈øion of Catholiques to deny the authoritie of S. Peters ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, and in place thereof to acknowledge the Succe≈ø≈øors of King Henry the eight: For in K. Henry the eights time, was the Oath of Supremacie fir≈øt made: By him were Thomas Moore and Roffen≈øis put to death, partly for refu≈øing of it: From his time till now, haue all the Princes of this land profe≈ø≈øing this Religion, ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely in effect maintained the ≈øame: and in that Oath onely is contained the Kings ab≈øolute power, to be Iudge ouer all per≈øons, a≈øwell Ciuill as Eccle≈øia≈øtical, excluding al forraigne powers and Potentates to be Iudges within his dominions; whereas this la≈øt made Oath containeth no ≈øuch
matter, onely medling with the ciuill obedience of Subiects to their Soueraigne, in meere temporall cau≈øes.

And that it may the better appeare, that whereas by name hee ≈øeemeth to condemne the la≈øt Oath; yet indeed his whole Letter runneth vpon nothing, but vpon the condemnation of the Oath of Supremacie: I haue here thought good to ≈øet downe the ≈øaid Oath, leauing it then to the di≈øcretion of euery indifferent reader to iudge, whether he doth not in ≈øub≈øtance onely an≈øwere to the Oath of Supremacie, but that hee giues the child a wrong name.

p.hi: I A B. doe vtterly testifie and declare in my con≈øcience, that the Kings Highne≈ø≈øe is the onely Supreame Gouernour of this Realme, and all other his Highne≈ø≈øe Dominions and Countries, a≈øwell in all Spirituall, or Eccle≈øiasticall things or cau≈øes, as Temporall: And that no forraine Prince, Per≈øon, Prelate, State or Potentate, hath or ought to haue any Iuri≈ødiction, Power, Superioritie, Preeminence or Authoritie Eccle≈øiasticall or Spirituall within this Realme. And therefore I doe vtterly renounce and for≈øake all forraine Iuri≈ødictions, Powers, Superiorities and Authorities; and doe promi≈øe that from hencefoorth I ≈øhall beare faith and trew Allegiance to the Kings Highne≈ø≈øe, his Heires and lawfull Succe≈ø≈øours: and to my power ≈øhall a≈øsist and defend all Iuri≈ødictions, Priuiledges, Preeminences and Authorities granted or belonging to the Kings Highne≈ø≈øe, his Heires and Succe≈ø≈øours, or vnited and annexed to the Imperiall Crowne of the Realme: So helpe me God; and by the Contents of this booke.

div.p: And that the iniu≈øtice, as well as the error of his gro≈ø≈øe mi≈øtaking in this point, may yet be more clearely di≈øcouered; I haue al≈øo thought good to in≈øert here immediatly after the Oath of Supremacie, the contrary conclu≈øions to all the points and Articles, whereof this other late Oath doeth con≈øi≈øt: whereby it may appeare, what vnrea≈øonable and rebellious points hee would driue my Subiects vnto, by refu≈øing the whole body of that Oath, as it is conceiued: For he that ≈øhall refu≈øe to take this Oath, mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie hold all, or ≈øome of the≈øe propo≈øitions following.
That I King IAMES, am not the lawfull King of this Kingdome, and of all other my Dominions.

That the Pope by his owne authoritie may depo≈øe me: If not by his owne authoritie, yet by ≈øome other authoritie of the Church, or of the Sea of Rome: If not by ≈øome other authoritie of the Church and Sea of Rome, yet by other meanes with others helpe, he may depo≈øe me.
That the Pope may di≈øpo≈øe of my Kingdomes and Dominions.
That the Pope may giue authoritie to ≈øome forreine Prince to inuade my Dominions.
That the Pope may di≈øcharge my Subiects of their Allegiance and Obedience to me.
That the Pope may giue licence to one, or more of my Subiects to beare armes again≈øt me.
That the Pope may giue leaue to my Subiects to offer violence to my Per≈øon, or to my gouernement, or to ≈øome of my Subiects.
That if the Pope ≈øhall by Sentence excommunicate or depo≈øe mee, my Subiects are not to beare Faith and Allegiance to me.
If the Pope ≈øhall by Sentence excommunicate or depo≈øe me, my Subiects are not bound to defend with all their power my Per≈øon and Crowne.

If the Pope ≈øhall giue out any Sentence of Excommunication or Depriuation again≈øt me, my Subiects by rea≈øon o ‚Ä¢ that Sentence, are not bound to reueale all Con≈øpiracies and Trea≈øons again≈øt mee, which ≈øhall come to their hearing and knowledge.
That it is not hereticall and dete≈øtable to hold, that Princes being excommunicated by the Pope, may be either depo≈øed or killed by their Subiects, or any other.
That the Pope hath power to ab≈øolue my Subiects from this Oath, or from ≈øome part thereof.
That this Oath is not admini≈øtred to my Subiects, by a full and lawfull authoritie.
That this Oath is to be taken with Equiuocation, mentall eua≈øion, or ≈øecret re≈øeruation; and not with the heart and good will, ≈øincerely in the trew faith of a Chri≈øtian man.

The≈øe are the trew and naturall branches of the body of this Oath. The affirmatiue of all which negatiues, Touching the pretended Councell of Lateran. See Plat. In vita Innocen. III. doe neither concerne in any ca≈øe the Popes Supremacie in Spirituall cau≈øes: nor yet were euer concluded, and defined by any complete generall Councell to belong to the Popes authoritie; and their owne ≈øchoole Doctors are at irreconciliable oddes and iarres about them.

And that the world may yet farther ≈øee ours and the whole States ≈øetting downe of this Oath, The Oath of Allegiance confirmed by the authoritie of ancient Councels. did not proceed from any new inuention of our owne, but as it is warranted by the word of GOD: ≈øo doeth it take the example from an Oath of Allegiance decreed a thou≈øand yeeres agone, which a famous Councell then, together with diuers other Councels, were ≈øo farre from condemning (as the Pope now hath done this Oath) as I haue thought good to ≈øet downe their owne wordes here in that purpo≈øe‚ñ™ whereby it may appeare that I craue nothing now of my Subiects in this Oath, which was not expre≈øly and carefully commaunded then, by the Councels to be obeyed without exception of per≈øons. Nay not in the very particular point of EquiuocatioÃÑ, The ancient Councels prouided for Equiuocation. The difference betweene the ancient Councels, and the Pope coun≈øelling of the Catholiques. which I in this Oath was ≈øo carefull to haue e≈øchewed: but you ≈øhall here ≈øee the ≈øaid Councels in their Decrees, as carefull to prouide for the e≈øchewing of the ≈øame; ≈øo as almo≈øt euery point of that action, & this of ours ≈øhalbe found to haue relation & agreeance one with the other, ≈øaue onely in this, that tho≈øe old Councels were careful and ≈øtrait in coÃÑmanding the taking of the ≈øame: whereas by the contrary, he that now vanteth him≈øelfe to be head of al Councels, is as careful & ≈øtrait in the prohibition of all men from the taking of this Oath of Allegiance.
The words of the Councell be the≈øe:

p.hi: Heare our Sentence.

div.p:
Who≈øoeuer of vs,
Concil. Tolet. 4 can. 47. Anno 633. or of all the people thorowout all Spaine, ≈øhall goe about by any meanes of con≈øpiracie or practi≈øe, to violate the Oath of his fidelitie, which he hath taken for the pre≈øeruation of his Countrey, or of the Kings life; or who ≈øhall attempt to put violent handes vpon the King; or to depriue him of his kingly power; or that by tyrannicall pre≈øumption would v≈øurpe the Soueraigntie of the Kingdome: Let him bee accur≈øed in the ≈øight of God the Father, and of his Angels; and let him bee made and declared a ≈øtranger from the Catholique Church, which hee hath prophaned by his periurie; and an aliant from the companie of all Christian people, together with all the complices of his impietie; becau≈øe it behooueth all tho≈øe that bee guiltie of the like offence, to vnder-lie the like puni≈øhment. Which ≈øentence is three ≈øeuerall times together, and almo≈øt in the ≈øame wordes, repeated in the ≈øame Canon. After this, the Synode de≈øired, That this Sentence of theirs now this third time rehear≈øed, might bee confirmed by the voyce and con≈øent of all that were pre≈øent. Then the whole Clergie and people an≈øwered, Who≈øoeuer ≈øhall cary him≈øelfe pre≈øumptuou≈øly again≈øt this your definitiue ≈øentence, let them be Anathema maranatha, that is, let them bee vtterly destroyed at the Lords comming, and let them and their complices haue their portion with Iudas I≈øcarioth. Amen.

And in the fifth
Concil. Tolet. 5. Can. 7. anno 636. Councell, there it is decreed, That this Acte touching the Oath of Allegiance, ≈øhall bee repeated in euery Councell of the Bi≈øhops of Spaine. The Decree is in the≈øe wordes: In con≈øideration that the mindes of men are ea≈øily inclined to euill and forgetfulne≈ø≈øe, therefore this most holy Synode hath ordained; and doeth enact, That in euery Councell of the Bi≈øhops of Spaine, the Decree of the generall
Synod. Tolet 4. vniuer≈øalis, & magna Synodus dicta, Synod Tolet. 5. cap 2. Councell which was made for the ≈øafetie of our Princes, ≈øhall bee with an audible voyce proclaimed and pronounced, after the conclu≈øion of all other things in the Synode: That ≈øo it beeing often ≈øounded into their eares, at lea≈øt by continuall remembrance, the mindes of wicked men beeing terrified, might bee reformed, which by obliuion and facilitie [to euill] are brought to preuaricate.

And in the ≈øixt
Concil. Tolet. 6. Can. 18. Anno 638. Councell, Wee doe prote≈øt before God, and all the orders of Angels, in the pre≈øence of the Prophets and Apo≈øtles, and all the companie of Martyrs, and before all the Catholique Church, and a≈ø≈øemblies of the Chri≈øtians; That no man ≈øhall goe about to ≈øeeke the de≈øtruction of the King: No man ≈øhall touch the life of the Prince: No man ≈øhall depriue him of the Kingdome: No man by any tyrannical pre≈øumption ≈øhall v≈øurpe to him≈øelfe the Soueraigntie of the Kingdome: No man by any Machination ≈øhall in his aduer≈øitie a≈ø≈øociate to him≈øelfe any packe of Con≈øpirators against him: And that if any of vs ≈øhall be pre≈øumptuous by ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe in any of the≈øe ca≈øes, let him be ≈øtricken with the anatheme of God, and reputed as condemned in eternall iudgement without any hope of recouery.

And in the tenth
Concil. Tolet. 10. Can. 2. Aera 694. Councell (to omit diuers others held al≈øo at Toledo) it is ≈øaid: That if any religious man, euen from the Bi≈øhop to the lowe≈øt Order of the Church-men or Monkes, ≈øhall bee found to haue violated the generall Oathes
made for the pre≈øeruation of the Kings Per≈øon, or of the Nation and Countrey with a prophane minde; foorth with let him bee depriued of all dignitie, and excluded from all place and Honour. The occa≈øion of the Decrees made for this Oath, was, That the Chri≈øtians were ≈øu≈øpected for want of fidelitie to their Kings; and did either equiuocate in taking their Oath, or make no con≈øcience to keepe it, when they had giuen it; as may appeare by ≈øundry ≈øpeeches in the
Concil. Tolet. 4. cap. 74. Councell, ≈øaying, There is a generall report, that there is that perfidiou≈øne≈ø≈øe in the mindes of many people of diuers Nations, that they make no con≈øcience to keepe the Oath and fidelitie that they haue ≈øworne vnto their Kings: but doe di≈ø≈øemble a profe≈øsion of fidelitie in their mouthes, when they hold an impious perfidiou≈øne≈ø≈øe in their mindes. And
Concil. Tolet. 4. cap. 74. againe, They ≈øweare to their Kings, and yet doe they preuaricate in the fidelitie which they haue promi≈øed: Neither doe they feare the Volume of Gods iudgement, by the which the cur≈øe of God is brought vpon them, with great threatning of puni≈øhments, which doe ≈øweare lyingly in the Name of God. To the like effect ≈øpake they in the Councell of
Concil. Aqui≈øgran. ≈øub Ludo Pio, & Greg. 4. Can. 12. anno 836. Aqui≈øgran: If any of the Bi≈øhops, or other Church-man of inferiour degree, hereafter thorow feare or couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, or any other per≈øwa≈øion, ≈øhall make defection from our Lord the Orthodoxe Emperour Lodowicke, or ≈øhall violate the Oath of fidelitie made vnto him, or ≈øhall with their peruer≈øe intention adhere to his enemies; let him by this Canonicall and Synodall ≈øentence bee depriued of what≈øoeuer place hee is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of.

And now to come to a particular an≈øwere of his Letter. Fir≈øt, as concerning the ≈øweet memory hee hath of his old acquaintance with the Arch-prie≈øt; it may indeed be plea≈øing for him to recount: but ≈øure I am, his acquaintance with him and the re≈øt of his ≈øocietie, our Fugitiues (whereof he al≈øo vanteth him≈øelfe in his Preface to the Reader in his Booke of Controuer≈øies) hath prooued ≈øowre to vs and our State: For ≈øome of ≈øuch Prie≈øts and Ie≈øuits, as were the greate≈øt Traitors and fomenters of the greate≈øt con≈øpiracies again≈øt the late Queene, gaue vp Father Rob:
Campian and Hart. See the conference in the Tower. Bellarmine for one of their greate≈øt authorities and oracles: And therfore I do not enuy the great honour he can winne, by his vaunt of his inward familiarity with an other Princes traitors & fugitiues; whom vnto if he teach no better maners then hitherto he hath done, I thinke his fellow≈øhip are litle beholding vnto him.

And for de≈øiring him to remember him in his prayers at the Altar of the Lord: if the Arch-Prie≈øts prayers prooue no more profitable to his ≈øoule, then Bellarmines coun≈øell is like to proue profitable, both to the ≈øoule and bodie of Blackwell (if he would follow it) the authour of this Letter might very well be without his prayers.

Now the fir≈øt me≈ø≈øenger that I can finde which brought ioyfull newes of the Arch-Prie≈øt to Bellarmine, was hee that brought the newes of the Arch-Prie≈øts taking, and fir≈øt appearance of Martyrdome. A great ≈øigne ≈øurely of the Cardinals mortification, that hee was ≈øo reioyced to heare of the apprehen≈øion, impri≈øonment and appearance of putting to death of ≈øo old and deare a friend of his. But yet apparantly he ≈øhould fir≈øt haue beene
≈øure, that hee was onely to bee puni≈øhed for cau≈øe of Religion, before hee had ≈øo triumphed vpon the expectation of his Martyrdome. For fir≈øt, by what rule of charitie was it lawfull for him to iudge mee a per≈øecutour, The Cardinals charitie. before proofe had beene made of it by the ≈øaid Arch-Prie≈øts condemnation and death? What could hee know, that the ≈øaid Arch-Prie≈øt was not taken vpon ≈øu≈øpicion of his guiltine≈ø≈øe in the Powder-Trea≈øon? What certaine information had hee then receiued vpon the particulars, whereupon hee was to bee accu≈øed? And la≈øt of all, by what in≈øpiration could he foretell whereupon hee was to bee accu≈øed? For at that time there was yet nothing layed to his charge. And if charitie ≈øhould not bee ≈øu≈øpicious, what warrant had hee ab≈øolutely to condemne mee of v≈øing per≈øecution and tyrannie, which could not bee but implyed vpon mee, if Blackwel was to bee a Martyr? But ≈øurely it may iu≈øtly be ≈øayd of Bellarmine in this ca≈øe, that our Sauiour CHRIST ≈øaith of all worldly and carnall men, who thinke it enough to loue their Mar. 5.43. friends, and hate their enemies; the limits of the Cardinals charitie extending no farther, then to them of his owne profe≈ø≈øion. For what euer hee added in ≈øuperfluous charitie to Blackwel, in reioycing in the ≈øpeculation of his future Martyrdome; hee detracted as much vniu≈øtly and vncharitably from me, in accounting of me thereby as of a bloody Per≈øecutour. And whereas this ioy of his was interrupted by the next me≈ø≈øenger, that brought the newes of the ≈øaide Arch-Prie≈øt his failing in his con≈øtancie, by taking of this Oath; he needed neuer to haue beene troubled, either with his former ioy or his ≈øecond ≈øorrow, both beeing alike fal≈øly grounded. For as it was neuer my intention to lay any thing vnto the ≈øaid Arch-Prie≈øts charge, as I haue neuer done to any for cau≈øe of con≈øcience; ≈øo was Blackwels con≈øtancie neuer brangled by taking of this Oath; It beeing a thing which he euer thought lawfull before his apprehen≈øion, and whereunto hee per≈øwaded all Catholiques to giue obedience; like as after his apprehen≈øion, hee neuer made doubt or ≈øtop in it; but at the fir≈øt offering it vnto him, did freely take it, as a thing mo≈øt lawfull; neither meanes of threatening, or flatterie being euer v≈øed vnto him, as him≈øelfe can yet beare witne≈ø≈øe.

And as for the temperature and modification of this Oath, except that a rea≈øonable and lawfull matter is there ≈øet downe in rea≈øonable and temperate wordes, agreeing thereunto; I know not what he can meane, by quarelling it for that fault: For no temperatne≈ø≈øe nor modifications in words therein, can iu≈øtly be called the Deuils craft; when the thing it ≈øelfe is ≈øo plaine, and ≈øo plainely interpreted to all them that take it; as the onely trouble≈øome thing in it all, bee the wordes v≈øed in the end thereof, for e≈øchewing Aequiuocation and Mentall re≈øeruation. Which new Catholike doctrine, may farre iu≈øtlier bee called the Deuils craft, then any plaine and temperate wordes, in ≈øo plaine and cleare a matter. But what ≈øhall we ≈øay of the≈øe ≈øtrange countrey clownes, whom of with the Satyre we may iu≈øtly complaine, that they blow both hote & cold out of one mouth? For Luther
and all our bold and free-≈øpeaking Writers are mightily railed vpon by them, as hote-brained fellowes, and ≈øpeakers by the Deuils in≈øtinct: and now if we ≈øpeake moderately and temperately of them, it mu≈øt be tearmed the Deuils craft: And therefore wee may iu≈øtly complaine with CHRIST, that when we Mat. 11.17. mourne, they wil not lament: and when we pipe, they wil not dance. But neither Iohn Baptist his ≈øeueritie, nor CHRIST his meekene≈ø≈øe and lenitie can plea≈øe them, who build but to their owne Monarchie vpon the ground of their owne Traditions; and not to CHRIST vpon the ground of his word and infallible trewth.

But what can bee meant by alleadging, that the craft of the Deuill herein, is onely v≈øed for ≈øubuer≈øion of the Catholique Faith, and euer≈øion of Saint Peters Primacie; had neede bee commented anew by Bellarmine him≈øelfe: For in all this Letter of his, neuer one word is v≈øed, to prooue that by any part of this Oath the Primacie of Saint Peter is any way medled with, except Ma≈øter Bellarmine his bare alleadging; which without proouing it by more cleare demon≈øtration, can neuer ≈øatisfie the con≈øcience of any rea≈øonable man. For (for ought that I know) heauen and earth are no farther a≈øunder, then the profe≈ø≈øion of a temporall obedience to a temporall King, is different from any thing belonging to the Catholique Faith, or Supremacie of Saint Peter: For as for the Catholique Faith; No deci≈øion of any point of Religion in the Oath of Allegiance. can there be one word found in all that Oath, tending or ≈øounding to matter of Religion? Doeth he that taketh it, promi≈øe there to beleeue, or not to beleeue any article of Religion? Or doeth hee ≈øo much as name a trew or fal≈øe Church there? And as for Saint Peters Primacie; I know no Apo≈øtles name that is therein named, except the name of IAMES, it being my Chri≈øten name: though it plea≈øe him not to deigne to name me in all the Letter; albeit, the contents thereof concerne mee in the highe≈øt degree. Neither is there any mention at all made therein, either di≈øertis verbis, or by any other indirect meanes, either of the Hierarchie of the Church, of Saint Peters ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, of the Sea Apo≈øtolike, or of any ≈øuch matter: but that the Author of our Letter doeth brauely make mention of Saint Peters ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, bringing it in compari≈øon with the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Henry the eight. And for the great feare he hath, that the ≈øuddennes of the apprehen≈øion, the bitterne≈ø≈øe of the per≈øecution, the weakne≈ø≈øe of his aage, and other ≈øuch infirmities might haue been the cau≈øe of the Arch-prie≈øts fall; in this, I haue already ≈øufficiently an≈øwered him; hauing declared, as the trewth is, and as the ≈øaid Blackwell him≈øelfe will yet te≈øtifie, that he tooke this Oath freely of him≈øelfe, without any inducement thereunto, either Precibus or Minis.

But among≈øt all his citations, Some of Sanders his worthy ≈øayings remembred. hee mu≈øt not forget holy Sanderus and his vi≈øibilis Monarchia, who≈øe per≈øon and actions I did alreadie a little touch. And ≈øurely who will with vnpartiall eyes reade his bookes, they may well thinke, that hee hath de≈øerued well of his Engli≈øh Romane-Church; but they can neuer thinke, but that hee de≈øerued very ill of his Engli≈øh Soueraigne and State: Witne≈ø≈øe his owne books; whereout I haue made choice to ≈øet downe heere the≈øe fewe ≈øentences following, as flowers pickt out of ≈øo worthy a garland.
Sand de vi≈øib. Monar. lib. 6. cap. 4. Elizabeth Queene of ENGLAND, doeth exerci≈øe the Priestly acte of teaching and preaching the Go≈øpel in ENGLAND, with no le≈ø≈øe authority then Christ him≈øelfe, or Mo≈øes euer did. The ≈øupremacie of a
Sand de clau. Dauid. li. 6. c. 1. woman in
Church matters is from no other, then from the Deuill. And of all things in generall thus he ≈øpeaketh, The
Sand. de vi≈øib. Monar. lib. 2. cap. 4. King that will not inthrall him≈øelfe to the Popes authoritie, be ought not to be tolerated; but his Subiects ought to giue all diligence, that another may be cho≈øen in his place a≈øsoone as may be. A King that is an Ibidem. Heretike, ought to be remooued from the Kingdome that hee holdeth ouer Chri≈øtians; and the Bi≈øhops ought to endeauour to ≈øet vp another, a≈ø≈øoone as po≈øsibly they can. Wee doe con≈øtantly Ibidem. affirme, that all Christian Kings are ≈øo farre vnder Bi≈øhops and Priests in all matters appertaining to faith, that if they ≈øhall continue in a fault against Chri≈øtian Religion, after one or two admonitions, obstinately, for that cau≈øe they may and ought to be depo≈øed by the Bi≈øhops from their temporall authoritie they holde ouer Christians. Ibidem. Bi≈øhops are ≈øet ouer temporall kingdomes, if tho≈øe kingdomes doe ≈øubmit them≈øelues to the faith of Chri≈øt. We doe iu≈øtly
Sand. de clan. Dauid. li. 5. c. 2. affirme, that all Secular power, whether Regall, or any other, is of men. The Ibidem. anoynting which is powred vpon the head of the King by the Priest, doeth declare that hee is inferiour to the Prie≈øt. It is altogether against the will of
Sand. de clan. Dauid. li. 5. c. 4. Chri≈øt, that Christian kings ≈øhould haue ≈øupremacie in the Church.

And whereas for the crowne and conclu≈øion of all his examples, The Cardinals paire of Martyrs weighed. he reckoneth his two Engli≈øh Martyrs, Moore and Roffen≈øis, who died for that one mo≈øt weightie head of doctrine, as he alledgeth, refu≈øing the Oath of Supremacie; I mu≈øt tell him, that he hath not been well informed in ≈øome materiall points, which doe very neerely concerne his two ≈øaid Martyrs: For it is cleare and apparantly to be prooued by diuers Records, that they were both of them committed to the Tower about a yeere before either of them was called in que≈øtion vpon their liues, for the Popes Supremacie; And that partly for their backwardne≈ø≈øe in the point of the e≈øtabli≈øhment of the Kings ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, whereunto the whole Realme had ≈øub≈øcribed, and partly for that one of them, to wit, Fi≈øher, had had his hand in the matter of the holy Called Elizabeth Barton. See the Act of Parliament. maide of Kent; hee being for his concealement of that fal≈øe prophets abu≈øe, found guiltie of mi≈øpri≈øion of Trea≈øon. And as the≈øe were the principall cau≈øes of their impri≈øonment (the King re≈øting ≈øecure of his Supremacie, as the Realme ≈øtood then affected, but e≈øpecially troubled for ≈øetling the Crowne vpon the i≈ø≈øue of his ≈øecond mariage) ≈øo was it ea≈øily to be conceiued, that being thereupon di≈øcontented, their humors were thereby made apt to draw them by degrees, to further oppo≈øition again≈øt the King and his authoritie, as indeede it fell out: For in the time of their being in pri≈øon, the Kings lawfull authoritie in ca≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall being publi≈øhed and promulged, as well by a generall decree of the Clergie in their Synode, as by an Acte of Parliament made thereupon; they behaued them≈øelues ≈øo peeui≈øhly therein, as the olde coales of the Kings anger being thereby raked vp of new, they were againe brought in que≈øtion; as well for this one mo≈øt weighty head of doctrine of the Pope his ≈øupremacy, as for the matter of the Kings mariage and ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, as by the confe≈ø≈øion of one of them≈øelues, euen Thomas Moore, is euident: For being condemned, he v≈øed the≈øe words at the barre before the Lords, Non ignoro cur me
morti adiudicaueritis; videlicet ob id,
Hi≈øtor. aliquet Martyrum no≈øtri ≈øeculi, Anno 1550. qu√≤d nunquam voluerim a≈ø≈øentiri in negotio matrimonij Regis. That is, I am not ignorant why you haue adiudged mee to death: to wit, for that I would neuer con≈øent in the bu≈øine≈øse of the new mariage of the King. By which his owne confe≈øsion it is plaine, that this great martyr him≈øelfe tooke the cau≈øe of his owne death, to be onely for his being refractary to the King in this ≈øaid matter of Marriage and Succe≈øsion; which is but a very fle≈øhly cau≈øe of Martyrdome, as I conceiue.

And as for Roffen≈øis his fellow Martyr (who could haue bene content to haue taken the Oath of the Kings Supremacie, with a certaine modification, which Moore refu≈øed) as his impri≈øonment was neither onely, nor principally for the cau≈øe of Supremacie, ≈øo died hee but a halting and a ≈øingular Martyr or witne≈ø≈øe for that mo≈øt weighty head of doctrine; the whole Church of England going at that time, in one current and ≈øtreame as it were again≈øt him in that Argument, diuers of them being of farre greater reputation for learning and ≈øound iudgement, then euer he was. So as in this point we may well arme our ≈øelues with the Cardinals owne rea≈øon, where he giueth among≈øt other notes of the trew Church, Vniuer≈øalitie for one, wee hauing the generall and Catholique conclu≈øion of the whole Church of England, on our ≈øide in this ca≈øe, as appeareth by their booke ≈øet out by the whole Conuocation of England, called, The Institution of a Chri≈øtian man; the ≈øame matter being likewi≈øe very learnedly handled by diuers particular learned men of our Church, as by Steuen Gardiner in his booke De vera obedientia, with a Preface of Bi≈øhop Boners adioyning to it, De ≈øummo & ab≈øoluto Regis Imperio, publi≈øhed by M. Bekin≈øaw, De vera differentia Regiae Potestatis & Eccle≈øiasticae, Bi≈øhop Ton≈øtals Sermon, Bi≈øhop Longlands Sermon, the letter of Tonstall to Cardinall Poole, and diuers other both in Engli≈øh and Latine. And if the bitterne≈ø≈øe of Fi≈øhers di≈øcontentment had not bene fed with his dayly ambitious expectation of the Cardinals hat, which came ≈øo neere as Calis before he lo≈øt his head to fill it with, I haue great rea≈øon to doubt, if he would haue con≈øtantly per≈øeuered in induring his Martyrdome for that one mo≈øt waighty head of doctrine.

And ≈øurely the≈øe two Captaines and ringleaders to Martyrdome were but ill followed by the re≈øt of their countreymen: for I can neuer reade of any after them, being of any great accompt, and that not many, that euer ≈øealed that weighty head of doctrine with their blood in England. So as the trew cau≈øes of their fir≈øt falling in trouble (whereof I haue already made mention) being rightly con≈øidered vpon the one part, and vpon the other the ≈øcant number of witne≈ø≈øes, that with their blood ≈øealed it, (a point ≈øo greatly accompted of by our Cardinal) there can but ≈ømal glory redound thereby to our Engli≈øh nation, the≈øe onely two, Enoch and Elias, ≈øeruing for witne≈ø≈øes again≈øt our Antichri≈øtian doctrine.

And I am ≈øure the Supremacie of Kings may, The Supremacy of Kings ≈øufficiently warranted by the Scriptures. & wil euer be better maintained by the word of God (which mu≈øt euer be the trew rule to di≈øcerne all waighty heads of doctrine by) to be the trew and proper office of Chri≈øtian
Kings in their owne dominions, then he will be euer able to maintaine his annihilating Kings, and their authorities, together with his ba≈øe and vnreuerend ≈øpeaches of them, wherewith both his former great Volumes, and his late Bookes again≈øt Venice are filled. In the old Te≈øtament, Kings were directly 2. Chron. 19.4. Gouernours ouer the Church within their Dominions, 2. Sam. 5.6. purged their corruptions; reformed their abu≈øes, brought the 1. Chron. 13.12. Arke to her re≈øting place, the King 2. Sam. 6.16 dancing before it; 1. Chron. 28.6. built the Temple; 2. Chron. 6. dedicated the ≈øame, a≈ø≈øi≈øting in their owne per≈øons to the ≈øanctification thereof; 2. King. 22.11. made the Booke of the Law new-found, to bee read to the people; Nehe. 9.38. Dauid. Salomon. renewed the Couenant betweene God and his people; 2. King. 18.4 brui≈øed the bra≈øen ≈øerpent in pieces, which was ≈øet vp by the expre≈ø≈øe commandement of God, and was a figure of Chri≈øt; de≈øtroyed 1. King. 15.12. 2. king. 13.4. all Idoles, and fal≈øe gods; made 2. Chron. 17.8. a publike reformation, by a Commi≈ø≈øion of Secular men and Prie≈øts mixed for that purpo≈øe; depo≈øed 1. King. 2.27 the high Prie≈øt, and ≈øet vp another in his place: and generally, ordered euery thing belonging to the Church-gouernment, their Titles and Prerogatiues giuen them by God, agreeing to the≈øe their actions. They are called the 2. Sam. 7.14 Sonnes of the most High, nay, Gods P≈øal. 82.6. & exod. 22.8. them≈øelues; The 1. Sam. 24.11. Lords anoynted, Sitting 2. Chro. 9.8. in Gods throne; His 2. Chro. 6.15. ≈øeruants; The Angels 2. Sam. 14.20. of God; According to his 1. Sam. 13.14. hearts de≈øire; The light 2. Sam. 21.17. of I≈ørael; The I≈øa. 49.23. nur≈øing fathers of the Church, with innumerable ≈øuch ≈øtiles of honour, wherwith the old Te≈øtament is filled; whereof our aduer≈øary can pretend no ignorance. And as to the new Te≈øtament, Euery ≈øoule is commaunded to be ≈øubiect vnto them, euen for Rom. 13.5. con≈øcience ≈øake. All men 1. Tim. 2.2. mu≈øt be prayed for; but especially Kings, and tho≈øe that are in Authoritie, that vnder them we may leade a godly, peaceable, and an hone≈øt life.

The Rom. 13.4. Magistrate is the mini≈øter of God, to doe vengeance on him that doeth euill, and reward him that doeth well. Ye must obey all higher powers, but 1. Pet. 2.13. e≈øpecially Princes, and tho≈øe that are ≈øupereminent. Giue euery man his due, feare Rom. 13.7. to whom feare belongeth, and honour to whome honour. Giue Mat. 22.21. vnto Cae≈øar what is Cae≈øars, and to God what is Gods. Iohn 18.36. Regnum meum non est huius mundi. Luk. 12.14. Quis me constituit Iudicem ≈øuper vos? Luk. 22.25. Reges gentium dominantur eorum, vos autem non ≈øic. If the≈øe examples, ≈øentences, titles, and prerogatiues, and innumerable other in the Olde and New Te≈øtament doe not warrant Chri≈øtian Kings, within their owne dominions, to gouerne their Church, as well as the re≈øt of their people, in being Cu≈øtodes vtriu≈øque Tabulae, not by making new Articles of Faith, (which is the Popes office, as I ≈øaid before) but by commanding obedience to be giuen to the word of God, by reforming the religion according to his pre≈øcribed will, by a≈ø≈øi≈øting the ≈øpirituall power with the temporall ≈øword, by reforming of corruptions, by procuring due obedience to the Church, by iudging, and cutting off all friuolous que≈øtions and ≈øchi≈ømes, as
Eu≈øeb. lib. 3. de vita Con≈øtantini.
Constantine did; and finally, by making decorum to be ob≈øerued in euery thing, and e≈øtabli≈øhing orders to bee ob≈øerued in all indifferent things for that purpo≈øe, which is the onely intent of our Oath of Supremacie: If this Office of a King, I ≈øay, doe not agree with the power
giuen him by Gods word, let any indifferent man voyd of pa≈ø≈øion, iudge. But how the≈øe honourable offices, ≈øtyles, and prerogatiues giuen by God to Kings in the Old and New Te≈øtament, as I haue now cited, can agree with the braue ≈øtyles and titles that Bellarmine giueth them, I can hardly conceiue.
De laicis cap. 7. That Kings are rather ≈ølaues then Lords.
De Pent. li. 1. cap. 7. That they are not onely ≈øubiects to Popes, to Bi≈øhops, to Priests, but euen to Deacons.
Ibidem. That an Emperour must content him≈øelfe to drinke, not onely after a Bi≈øhop, but after a Bi≈øhops Chaplen.
Ibid. & de Cler. cap. 28. That Kings haue not their Authoritie nor Office immediatly from God, nor his Law, but onely from the Law of Nations.

De Pont. lib. 3. cap. 16. That Popes haue degraded many Emperours, but neuer Emperour degraded the Pope; nay, euen
De Rom. Pontif. lib. 5. cap 8. Bi≈øhops, that are but the Popes va≈ø≈øals, may depo≈øe Kings, and abrogate their lawes.
De laicis cap. 8. That Church-men are ≈øo farre aboue Kings, as the ≈øoule is aboue the body.
De Pont. li. 5. cap. 18. That Kings may be depo≈øed by their people, for diuers respects.
De Pon. lib. 2. cap. 26. But Popes can by no meanes be depo≈øed: for no fle≈øh hath power to iudge of them.
De Pont. lib. 4. cap. 15. That obedience due to the Pope, is for con≈øcience ≈øake.
De Clericis, cap. 28. But the obedience due to Kings, is onely for certaine re≈øpects of order and policie.
Ibidem. That the≈øe very Church-men that are borne, and inhabite in Soueraigne Princes countreys, are notwithstanding not their Subiects, and cannot bee iudged by them, although they may iudge them.

Ibidem. And, that the obedience that Church-men giue to Princes, euen in the meane≈øt and meere temporall things, is not by way of any nece≈ø≈øarie ≈øubiection, but onely out of di≈øcretion, and for ob≈øeruation of good order and custome.

The≈øe contrarieties betweene the Booke of God, and Bellarmines bookes, haue I heere ≈øet in oppo≈øition each to other, Vt ex contrariis iuxta ≈øe po≈øitis, veritas magis eluce≈øcere po≈øsit. And thus farre I dare boldly affirme, that who≈øoeuer will indifferently weigh the≈øe irreconciliable contradictions here ≈øet downe, will ea≈øily confe≈ø≈øe, that CHRIST is no more contrarie to Belial, light to darkne≈ø≈øe, and heauen to hell, then Bellarmines e≈øtimation of Kings, is to Gods.

Now as to the conclu≈øion of his letter, which is onely filled with ≈øtrong and pithie exhortations, to per≈øwade and confirme Blackwell to the patient and con≈øtant induring of martyrdome, I haue nothing to an≈øwere, ≈øaue by way of regrate; that ≈øo many good ≈øentences drawen out of the Scripture, ≈øo well and ≈øo hand≈øomely packed vp together, ≈øhould be ≈øo ill and vntrewly applied: But an euill cau≈øe is neuer the better for ≈øo good a cloake; and an ill matter neuer amended by good wordes: And therefore I may iu≈øtly turne ouer that craft of the diuell vpon him≈øelfe, in v≈øing ≈øo holy-like an exhortation to ≈øo euill a purpo≈øe. Onely I could haue wi≈øhed him, that hee
had a little better ob≈øerued his decorum herein, in not letting ≈ølippe two or three prophane words among≈øt ≈øo many godly mortified Scripture ≈øentences. For in all the Scripture, e≈øpecially in the New Te≈øtament, I neuer read of Pontifex Maximus. And the Pope mu≈øt be content in that ≈øtyle to ≈øucceed according to the Law and in≈øtitution of Numa Pompilius, and not to S. Peter, who neuer heard nor dreamed of ≈øuch an Office.

And for his Caput fidei, which I remembred before, the Apo≈øtles (I am ≈øure) neuer gaue that ≈øtyle to any, but to CHRIST: So as the≈øe ≈øtyles, whereof ≈øome were neuer found in Scripture, and ≈øome were neuer applyed but to CHRIST in that ≈øen≈øe, as hee applieth it, had beene better to haue beene left out of ≈øo holy and mortified a letter.

To conclude then this pre≈øent Di≈øcour≈øe, I heartily wi≈øh all indifferent readers of the Breues and Letter, not to iudge by the ≈øpeciou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the wordes, but by the weight of the matter; not looking to that which is ≈øtrongly alledged, but iudiciou≈øly to con≈øider what is iu≈øtly prooued. And for all my owne good and naturall Subiects, that their hearts may remaine e≈øtabli≈øhed in the trewth; that the≈øe forraine inticements may not ≈øeduce them from their natall and naturall duetie; and that all, a≈øwell ≈øtrangers, as naturall ≈øubiects, to who≈øe eyes this Di≈øcour≈øe ≈øhall come, may wi≈øely and vnpartially iudge of the Veritie, as it is nakedly here ≈øet downe, for clearing the≈øe mi≈øts and cloudes of calumnies, which were iniu≈øtly heaped vpon me; for which end onely I heartily pray the courteous Reader to be per≈øwaded, that I tooke occa≈øion to publi≈øh this Di≈øcour≈øe.

div.p:
To you, I ≈øay, as of right belongeth, doe I con≈øecrate and direct this Warning of mine, or rather Preamble to my reprinted Apologie for the Oath of Allegiance: For the cau≈øe is generall, and concerneth the Authoritie and priuiledge of Kings in generall, and all ≈øupereminent Temporall powers. And if in what≈øoeuer Societie, or Corporation of men, either in Corporations of Cities, or in the Corporation of any mechanicke craft or handie-worke, euery man is carefull to maintaine the priuiledges of that Societie whereunto he is ≈øworne; nay, they will rather clu≈øter all in one, making it a common cau≈øe, expo≈øing them≈øelues to all ≈øorts of perill, then ≈øuffer the lea≈øt breach in their Liberties; If tho≈øe of the ba≈øer ≈øort of people, I ≈øay, be ≈øo curious and zealous for the pre≈øeruation of their common priuiledges and liberties, as if the meane≈øt among≈øt them be touched in any ≈øuch point, they thinke it concerneth them all: Then what ≈øhould wee doe in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, whom GOD hath placed in the highe≈øt thrones vpon earth, made his Lieutenants and Vice-gerents, and euen ≈øeated vs vpon his owne Throne to execute his Iudgements? The con≈øideration hereof hath now mooued mee to expone a Ca≈øe vnto you, which doeth not ≈øo neerely touch mee in my particular, as it doeth open a breach again≈øt our Authoritie, (I ≈øpeake in the plurall of all Kings) and priuiledge in generall. And ≈øince not onely all rankes and ≈øorts of people in all Nations doe inuiolably ob≈øerue this Maxime, but euen the Ciuil Law, by which the greate≈øt part of Chri≈øtendome is gouerned, doeth giue them an intere≈øt, qui fouent con≈øimilem cau≈øam; How much more then haue yee intere≈øt in this cau≈øe, not beeing ≈øimilis or par cau≈øa to yours, but eadem with yours?
and indeed yee all fouetis, or at lea≈øt fouere debetis eandem cau≈øam mecum. And ≈øince this cau≈øe is common to vs all; both the Ciuill Lawes, and the municipall Lawes of all Nations, permit and warne them, that haue a common intere≈øt, to concurre in one for the defence of their common cau≈øe; yea, common ≈øen≈øe teacheth vs with the Poet, Ecquid

A wake then while it is time, and ≈øuffer not, by your longer ≈øleepe, the ≈øtrings of your Authoritie to be cut in ≈øingulis, and one and one to your generall ruine, which by your vnited forces, would rather make a ≈øtrong rope for the enemie to hang him≈øelfe in, with Achitophel, then that hee ≈øhould euer bee able to breake it. As for this Apologie of mine, it is trew, that I thought good to ≈øet it fir≈øt out without putting my name vnto it; but neuer ≈øo, as I thought to denie it, remembring well mine owne words, but taken out of the Scripture, in the beginning of the Preface to the Reader, in my „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that nothing is ≈øo bid, which ≈øhall not bee opened, &c. promi≈øing there, which with GOD his grace I ≈øhall euer performe, neuer to doe that in ≈øecret, which I ≈øhall need to be a≈øhamed of, when it ≈øhall come to be proclaimed in publique.
