For neither in all my Apologie, nor in his pretended Refutation thereof, is there any que≈øtion made anent the Popes power ouer mee in particular, for the excommunicating or depo≈øing of mee: For in my particular; the Cardinall doeth mee that grace, that hee ≈øaith, The Pope thought it not expedient at this time to excommunicate mee by name; our que≈øtion being onely generall, Whether the Pope may lawfully pretend any temporall power ouer Kings, or no?

That no Church-men can by his rule bee ≈øubiect to any Temporall Prince, I haue already ≈øhewed you; And what Obedience any of you may looke for of any of them de facto, hee plainely forewarneth you of, by the example of Gregory the Great his obedience to the Emperour Mauritius: not being a≈øhamed to ≈ølaunder that great Per≈øonages Chri≈øtian humilitie and Obedience to the Emperour, with the title of a con≈øtrained and forced obedience, becau≈øe hee might, or dur≈øt doe no otherwi≈øe. Whereby he not onely wrongs the ≈øaid Gregory in particular, but euen doeth by that meanes lay on an heauie ≈ølaunder and reproach vpon the Chri≈øtian humilitie and patience of the whole Primitiue Church, e≈øpecially in the time of per≈øecution: if the whole glory of their Martyrdome and Chri≈øtian patience ≈øhall bee thus blotted with that vile glo≈ø≈øe of their coacted and con≈øtrained ≈øuffering, becau≈øe they could or dur≈øt doe no otherwi≈øe; like the patience and obedience of the Iewes or Turki≈øh ≈ølaues in our time, cleane contrary to Saint Paul and Saint Peters doctrine of obedience for con≈øcience ≈øake; Rom. 13.5. 1. Pet. 2.13. and as contrary to Tertullians Apologie for Chri≈øtians, and all the prote≈øtations of the ancient Fathers in that ca≈øe. But it was good lucke for the ancient Chri≈øtians in the dayes of Ethnicke Emperours, that this prophane and new conceit was then vnknowen among them: otherwi≈øe they would haue beene vtterly de≈øtroyed and rooted out in that time, and no man to haue pitied them, as mo≈øt dangerous members in a Common-wealth; who would no longer be obedient, then till they were furni≈øhed with ≈øufficient abilitie and power to re≈øi≈øt and rebell.

Thus may ye ≈øee, how vpon the one part our Cardinall will haue all Kings and Monarchs to bee the Popes Va≈ø≈øals; and yet will not on the other ≈øide, allow the meane≈øt of the Pope his va≈ø≈øals, to be ≈øubiect to any Chri≈øtian Prince. But he not thinking it enough to make the Pope our Superior, hath in a late Treati≈øe of his (called the Recognition of his bookes of Controuer≈øies) made the people and Subiects of euery one of vs, our Superiors. For hauing taken occa≈øion to reui≈øite againe his bookes of Controuer≈øies, and to correct or explaine what he findeth ami≈ø≈øe or mi≈øtaketh in them; in imitation of S. Augu≈øtine his retractions (for ≈øo he ≈øaith in his Preface) he doth in place of retracting any of his former errours, or any matter of ≈øub≈øtance; not retract, but recant indeed, I meane ≈øing ouer againe, and ob≈øtinatly confirme a number of the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt of them: Among the which, the exempting of all Church-men from ≈øubiection to any Temporall Prince, and the ≈øetting vp not onely of the Pope, but euen of the People aboue their naturall King; are two of his maine points.

As for the exemption of the Clerickes; he is ≈øo greedy there to proue that point, as he denieth Cae≈øar to haue beene Pauls lawfull Iudge: Acts. 25.10. contrary to the expre≈ø≈øe Text, and Pauls plaine Appellation, and acknowledging him his Iudge; be≈øides his many times claiming to the Roman priuiledges, Actes 22.28. and auowing him≈øelfe a Roman by freedome; and therefore of nece≈ø≈øitie a Subiect to the Roman Emperour. But it is a wonder that the≈øe Romane Catholikes, who vaunt them≈øelues of the ancientie both of their doctrine and Church, and reproch vs ≈øo bitterly of our Nouelties, ≈øhould not be a≈øhamed to make ≈øuch a new inept glo≈ø≈øe as this vpon S. Pauls Text; which as it is directly contrary to the Apo≈øtles wordes, ≈øo is it without any warrant, either of any ancient Councell, or of ≈øo much as any one particular Father that euer interprets that place in this ≈øort: Neither was it euer doubted by any Chri≈øtian in the Primitiue Church, that the Apo≈øtles, or any other degree of Chri≈øtians, were ≈øubiect to the Emperour.

And as for the ≈øetting vp of the People aboue their owne naturall King, he bringeth in that principle of Sedition, that he may thereby proue, that Kings haue not their power and authoritie immediatly from God, as the Pope hath his: For euery King (≈øaith he) is made and cho≈øen by his people; nay, they doe but ≈øo transferre their power in the Kings per≈øon, as they doe notwith≈øtanding retaine their habituall power in their owne hands, which vpon certaine occa≈øions they may actually take to them≈øelues againe. This, I am ≈øure, is an excellent ground in Diuinitie for all Rebels and rebellious people, who are hereby allowed to rebell again≈øt their Princes; and a≈ø≈øume libertie vnto them≈øelues, when in their di≈øcretions they ≈øhall thinke it conuenient.

And among≈øt his other Te≈øtimonies for probation, that all Kings are made and created by the People; he alledgeth the Creation of three Kings in the Scripture, Saul, Dauid and Ieroboam; and though hee bee compelled by the expre≈ø≈øe words of the Text, to confe≈ø≈øe, that God by his
Prophet Samuel annointed both 1. Sam. 10.1 Saul and 1. Sam. 16.12.13. Dauid; yet will he, by the po≈øtcon≈øent of the people, proue that tho≈øe Kings were not immediatly made by God, but mediatly by the people; though he repeat thri≈øe that word of Lott, by the ca≈øting whereof he confe≈ø≈øeth that Saul was cho≈øen. And if the Election by Lott be not an immediate Election from God; then was not Matthias, Actes 1. who was ≈øo cho≈øen and made an Apo≈øtle, immediatly cho≈øen by GOD: and con≈øequently, he that ≈øitteth in the Apo≈øtolike Sea cannot for ≈øhame claime to be immediatly cho≈øen by God, if Matthias (that was one of the twelue Apo≈øtles, ≈øupplying Iudas his place) was not ≈øo cho≈øen. But as it were a bla≈øphemous impietie, to doubt that Matthias was immediatly cho≈øen by GOD, and yet was hee cho≈øen by the ca≈øting of Lots, as Saul was: ≈øo is it well enough knowen to ≈øome of you (my louing Brethren) by what holy Spirit or ca≈øting of Lots the Popes v≈øe to be elected; the Colledge of Cardinals, his electors, hauing beene diuided in two mightie factions euer ≈øince long before my time; and in place of ca≈øting of Lotts, great fat pen≈øions beeing ca≈øt into ≈øome of their greedy mouthes for the election of the Pope, according to the partiall humours of Princes. But I doe mo≈øt of all wonder at the weakene≈ø≈øe of his memorie: for in this place he maketh the po≈øt-con≈øent of the people to be the thing that made both the≈øe Kings, notwith≈øtanding of their preceding inauguration and anoyntment by the Prophet at GODS commandement; forgetting that in the beginning of this ≈øame little booke of his, an≈øwering one that alledgeth a ≈øentence of S. Cyprian, to prooue that the Bi≈øhops were iudged by the people in Cyprians time, he there confe≈ø≈øeth, that by the≈øe words, the con≈øent of the people to the Bi≈øhops Election mu≈øt be onely vnder≈øtood. Nor will he there any wayes be mooued to graunt, that the peoples power, in con≈øenting to or refu≈øing the Election of a Bi≈øhop, ≈øhould be ≈øo vnder≈øtood, as that thereby they haue power to elect Bi≈øhops: And yet do the≈øe words of Cyprian ≈øeeme to bee farre ≈øtronger, for granting the peoples power to elect Churchmen, then any words that he alledgeth out of the Scripture are for the peoples power in electing a King. For the very words of Cyprian by him≈øelfe there cited,
Cyprian. lib. 1. Epi≈øt. 4. are, That the very people haue principally the power, either to chu≈øe ≈øuch Prie≈øts as are worthy, or to refu≈øe ≈øuch as are vnworthie: And, I hope, hee can neuer prooue by the Scripture, that it had beene lawfull to the people of I≈ørael, or that it was left in their choi≈øe, to haue admitted or refu≈øed Saul or Dauid at their plea≈øure, after that the Prophet had anoynted them, and per≈øented them vnto them.

But, Lord, what an impudencie or wilfull ignorance is this, that he, who was ≈øo publikely and ≈øolemnely conuicted and executed, vpon his owne ≈øo cleare, vnforced and often repeated confe≈ø≈øion, of his knowledge and concealing of that horrible Trea≈øon, ≈øhould now be ≈øaid to haue a certaine rumor ≈øpred vpon him of his guiltine≈ø≈øe, by I know not who? with ≈øo many
attributes of godline≈ø≈øe, con≈øtancie and innocencie be≈øtowed vpon him, as if publike Sentences and Executions of Iu≈øtice, were rumors of I know not who. Indeed, I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, the booke it ≈øelfe ≈øheweth a great affection to performe, what is thus promi≈øed in the Preface thereof: for in two or three places therein, is there mo≈øt honorable lying mention made of that ≈øtraw-Saint; wherein, though he confe≈ø≈øe that Garnet was vpon the foreknowledge of the Powder-Trea≈øon, yet in regard it was (as he ≈øaith) onely vnder the Seale of Confe≈ø≈øion, he ≈øticketh not to prai≈øe him for his concealing thereof, and would gladly giue him the crowne of glory for the ≈øame: not being a≈øhamed to proclaime it as a principall head of Catholique doctrine; That the ≈øecret of Sacramentall confe≈øsion ought not to be reuealed, not for the e≈øchewing of what≈øoeuer euill. But how damnable this doctrine is, and how dangerou≈øly preiudiciall to all Princes and States; I leaue it to you to iudge, whom all it mo≈øt highly concerneth. For although it bee trew, that when the Schoolemen came to be Doctors in the Church, and to marre the old grounds in Diuinitie by ≈øowing in among them their Philo≈øophicall di≈øtinctions; though they (I ≈øay) do maintaine, That what≈øoeuer thing is told a Confe≈ø≈øor vnder the vaile of confe≈ø≈øion, how dangerous ≈øoeuer the matter be, yet he is bound to conceale the parties name: yet doe none of them, I meane of the old Schoolemen, deny; that if a matter be reuealed vnto them, the concealing whereof may breed a great or publike danger; but that in that ca≈øe the Confe≈ø≈øor may di≈øclo≈øe the matter, though not the per≈øon, and by ≈øome indirect means make it come to light, that the danger thereof may be preuented. But that no trea≈øon nor deuili≈øh plot, though it ≈øhould tend to the ruine or exterminion of a whole Kingdome, mu≈øt be reuealed, if it be told vnder Confe≈ø≈øion, no not the matter ≈øo farre indirectly di≈øclo≈øed, as may giue occa≈øion for preuenting the danger thereof: though it agree with the conceit of ≈øome three or foure new Ie≈øuited Doctors, it is ≈øuch a new and dangerous head of doctrine, as no King nor State can liue in ≈øecuritie where that Po≈øition is maintained.

And now, that I may as well prooue him a lyar in facto, in his narration of this particular Hi≈øtory; as I haue ≈øhewed him to be in iure, by this his damnable and fal≈øe ground in Diuinity: I will trewly informe you of Garnets ca≈øe, which is farre otherwi≈øe then this An≈øwerer alleadgeth. For fir≈øt, it can neuer be accounted a thing vnder Confe≈ø≈øion, which he that reueals it doth not di≈øcouer with a remor≈øe, accounting it a ≈øinne whereof hee repenteth him; but by the contrary, di≈øcouers it as a good motion, and is therein not di≈ø≈øuaded by his Confe≈ø≈øor, nor any penance enioyned him for the ≈øame: and in this forme was this Trea≈øon reuealed to Garnet, as him≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øed. And next, though he ≈øtood long vpon it, that it was reuealed vnto him vnder the vaile of Confe≈ø≈øion, in re≈øpect it was done in that time, while as the partie was making his Confe≈ø≈øion vnto him; Yet at the la≈øt hee did freely confe≈ø≈øe, that the party reuealed it vnto him as they were walking, and not in the time of Confe≈ø≈øion: But
(he ≈øaid) he deliuered it vnto him vnder the greate≈øt Seale that might bee, and ≈øo he tooke that he meant by the Seale of Confe≈ø≈øion; And it had (as he thought) a relation to Confe≈ø≈øion, in regard that hee was that parties Confe≈ø≈øor, and had taken his Confe≈ø≈øion ≈øometimes before, and was to take it againe within few dayes thereafter. He al≈øo ≈øaid, that he pretended to the partie, that he would not conceale it from his Superior. And further it is to be noted, that he confe≈ø≈øed, that two diuers per≈øons conferred with him anent this Trea≈øon; and that when the one of them which was Catesby, conferred with him thereupon, it was in the other parties pre≈øence and hearing: and what a Confe≈ø≈øion can this be in the hearing of a third per≈øon? And how farre his la≈øt words (whereof our An≈øwerer ≈øo much vaunts him) did di≈øproue it to haue bene vnder Confe≈ø≈øion, the Earle of Northamptons booke doeth beare witne≈ø≈øe.

Now as to the other parties name, that reuealed the Powder-Trea≈øon vnto him, it was Greenewell the Ie≈øuite; and ≈øo a Ie≈øuite reuealed to a Ie≈øuite this Trea≈øonable plot, the Ie≈øuite reuealer not ≈øhewing any remor≈øe, and the Ie≈øuite whom-to it was reuealed not ≈øo much as enioyning him any penance for the ≈øame. And that ye may know that more Ie≈øuits were al≈øo vpon the partie, Owldcorne the other Powder-Martyr, after the mi≈øgiuing and di≈øcouery of that Trea≈øon, preached con≈øolatory doctrine to his Catholique auditorie; exhorting them not to faint for the mi≈øgiuing of this enterpri≈øe, nor to thinke the wor≈øe thereof that it ≈øucceeded not; alleadging diuers Pre≈øidents of ≈øuch godly enterpri≈øes that mi≈øgaue in like maner: e≈øpecially, one of S. Lewes King of France, who in his ≈øecond iourney to the Holy-land died by the way, the greate≈øt part of his armie being de≈øtroyed by the plague; his fir≈øt iourney hauing likewi≈øe mi≈øgiuen him by the Soldans taking of him: exhorting them thereupon not to giue ouer, but ≈øtill to hope that GOD would ble≈ø≈øe their enterpri≈øe at ≈øome other time, though this did faile.

Thus ≈øee ye now, with what boldne≈ø≈øe and impudencie hee hath belied the publiquely knowne veritie in this errand; both in auowing generally that no Ie≈øuite was any wayes guiltie of that Trea≈øon, for ≈øo he affirmeth in his booke; and al≈øo that Garnet knew nothing thereof, but vnder the Seale of Confe≈ø≈øion. But if this were the fir≈øt lye of the affaires of this State, which my fugitiue Prie≈øts and Ie≈øuits haue coyned and ≈øpread abroad, I could charme them of it, as the prouerbe is. But as well the walles of diuers Mona≈øteries and Ie≈øuites Colledges abroad, are filled with the painting of ≈øuch lying Hi≈øtories, as al≈øo the bookes of our ≈øaid fugitiues are farced with ≈øuch ≈øort of ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe ≈øtuffe; ≈øuch are the innumerable ≈øorts of torments and cruell deathes, that they record their Martyrs to haue ≈øuffred here, ≈øome torne at foure Hor≈øes; ≈øome ≈øowed in Beares skinnes, and then killed with Dogges; nay, women haue not bene ≈øpared (they ≈øay) and a thou≈øand other ≈øtrange fictions; the vanities of all which I will in two words di≈øcouer vnto you.

Fir≈øt, as for the cau≈øe of their puni≈øhment, I doe con≈øtantly maintaine that which I haue ≈øaid in my Apologie: That no man, either in my time, or in the late Queenes, euer died here for his con≈øcience. For let him be neuer ≈øo deuout a Papi≈øt, nay, though he profe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame neuer ≈øo con≈øtantly, his life is in no danger by the Law, if hee breake not out into ≈øome outward acte expre≈øly again≈øt the words of the Law; or plot not ≈øome vnlawfull or dangerous practi≈øe or attempt; Prie≈øts and Popi≈øh Church-men onely excepted, that receiue Orders beyond the Seas; who for the manifold trea≈øonable practi≈øes that they haue kindled and plotted in this countrey, are di≈øcharged to come home againe vnder paine of Trea≈øon, after their receiuing of the ≈øaid Orders abroad; and yet, without ≈øome other guilt in them then their bare home-comming, haue none of them bene euer put to death. And next, for the cruell torments and ≈øtrange ≈øorts of death that they ≈øay ≈øo many of them haue bene put vnto; if there were no more but the Law and continually ob≈øerued cu≈øtome of England, the≈øe many hundred yeeres, in all criminall matters, it will ≈øufficiently ≈øerue to refute all the≈øe mon≈øtrous lies: for no tortures are euer v≈øed here, but the Manacles or the Racke, and the≈øe neuer but in ca≈øes of high Trea≈øon; and all ≈øorts of Traitours die but one maner of death here, whether they be Papi≈øt or Prote≈øtant Traitors; Queene Maries time onely excepted. For then indeede no ≈øorts of cruell deathes were ≈øpared vnexecuted vpon men, women and children profe≈ø≈øing our Religion: yea, euen again≈øt the Lawes of God and Nature, women with childe were put to cruell death for their profe≈ø≈øion; and a liuing childe falling out of the mothers belly, was throwen in the ≈øame fire againe that con≈øumed the mother. But the≈øe tyrannous per≈øecutions were done by the Bi≈øhops of that time, vnder the warrant of the Popes authoritie; and therefore were not ≈øubiect to that con≈øtant order and formes of execution, which as they are heere e≈øtabli≈øhed by our Lawes and cu≈øtomes, ≈øo are they accordingly ob≈øerued in the puni≈øhment of all criminals: For all Prie≈øtes and Popi≈øh Traitours here receiue their Iudgements in the temporall Courts, and ≈øo doe neuer exceed tho≈øe formes of execution which are pre≈øcribed by the Law, or approued by continuall cu≈øtome. One thing is al≈øo to bee marked in this ca≈øe that ≈øtrangers are neuer called in que≈øtion here for their religion, which is farre otherwi≈øe (I hope) in any place where the Inqui≈øition domines.

But hauing now too much wearied you with this long di≈øcour≈øe, whereby I haue made you plainely ≈øee, that the wrong done vnto mee in particular fir≈øt by the Popes Breues, and then by the≈øe Libellers, doth as deepely intere≈øt you all in generall, that are Kings, free Princes, or States as it doth me in particular: I will now conclude, with my humble prayers to God, that he will waken vs vp all out of that Lethargike ≈ølumber of Securitie, wherein our Predece≈ø≈øors and wee haue lien ≈øo long; and that wee may fir≈øt grauely con≈øider, what we are bound in con≈øcience to doe for the
planting and ≈øpreading of the trew wor≈øhip of God, according to his reuealed will, in all our Dominions; therein hearing the voice of our onely Pa≈øtor (for his Sheepe will know his Voyce, Iohn 10.27. as him≈øelfe ≈øayeth) and not following the vaine, corrupt and changeable traditions of men. And next, that we may prouidently looke to the ≈øecuritie of our owne States, and not ≈øuffer this incroching Babylonian Monarch to winne ≈øtill ground vpon vs. And if GOD hath ≈øo mercifully dealt with vs, that are his Lieutenants vpon earth, as that he hath ioyned his cau≈øe with our intere≈øt, the ≈øpirituall libertie of the Go≈øpell with our temporall freedome: with what zeale and courage may wee then imbrace this worke: for our labours herein being a≈ø≈øured, to receiue at the la≈øt the eternall and ine≈øtimable reward of felicitie in the kingdome of Heauen; and in the meane time to procure vnto our ≈øelues a temporall ≈øecuritie, in our temporall Kingdomes in this world.

As for ≈øo many of you as are alreadie per≈øwaded of that Trewth which I profe≈ø≈øe, though differing among your ≈øelues in ≈øome particular points; I thinke little per≈øwa≈øion ≈øhould moue you to this holy and wi≈øe Re≈øolution: Our Greatne≈ø≈øe, nor our number, prai≈øed bee GOD, being not ≈øo contemptible, but that wee may ≈øhew good example to our neighbors; ≈øince almo≈øt the halfe of all Chri≈øtian people and of all ≈øorts and degrees, are of our profe≈ø≈øion; I meane, all gone out of Babylon, euen from Kings and free Princes, to the meane≈øt ≈øort of People. But aboue all (my louing Brethren and Co≈øins) keepe fa≈øt the vnity of Faith among your ≈øelues; Reiect 1. Tim. 1.4. que≈øtions of Genealogies and Ibid c. 4.7. Aniles fabulas, as Paul ≈øaith; Let not the fooli≈øh heate of your Preachers for idle Controuer≈øies or indifferent things, teare a≈øunder that My≈øticall Body, whereof ye are a part, ≈øince the very coat of him who≈øe members wee are was without a ≈øeame: And let not our diui≈øion breed a ≈ølander of our faith, and be a word of reproch in the mouthes of our aduer≈øaries, who make Vnitie to be one of the ≈øpeciall notes of the trew Church.

And as for you (my louing Brethren and Co≈øins) whom it hath not yet plea≈øed GOD to illuminate with the light of his trewth; I can but humbly pray with Elizeus, that it would plea≈øe GOD to open your eyes, that yee might ≈øee what innumerable and inuincible armies of Angels are euer prepared and ready to defend the trewth of GOD: Actes. 26.29. and with S. Paul I wi≈øh, that ye were as I am in this ca≈øe; e≈øpecially that yee would ≈øearch the Scriptures, and ground your Faith vpon your owne certaine knowledge, and not vpon the report of others; Abac. 2.4. ≈øince euery Man must bee ≈øafe by his owne faith. But, leauing this to GOD his mercifull prouidence in his due time, I haue good rea≈øon to remember you, to maintaine the ancient liberties of your Crownes and Common-wealthes, not ≈øuffering any vnder GOD to ≈øet him≈øelfe vp aboue you; and therein to imitate your owne noble predece≈ø≈øors, who (euen in the dayes of greate≈øt blindne≈ø≈øe) did diuers times couragiou≈øly oppo≈øe them≈øelues to the incroaching ambition of Popes. Yea,
≈øome of your Kingdomes haue in all aages maintained, and without any interruption enioyed your libertie, again≈øt the mo≈øt ambitious Popes. And ≈øome haue of very late had an euident proofe of the Popes ambitious a≈øpiring ouer your Temporall power; wherein ye haue con≈øtantly maintained and defended your lawfull freedome, to your immortall honour. And therefore I heartily wi≈øh you all, to doe in this ca≈øe the Office of godly and iu≈øt Kings and earthly Iudges: which con≈øi≈øteth not onely in not wronging or inuading the Liberties of any other per≈øon (for to that will I neuer pre≈ø≈øe to per≈øwade you) but al≈øo in defending and maintaining the≈øe lawfull Liberties wherewith GOD hath indued you: For yee, whom GOD hath ordained to protect your people from iniuries, ≈øhould be a≈øhamed to ≈øuffer your ≈øelues to be wronged by any. And thus, a≈ø≈øuring my ≈øelfe, that ye will with a ≈øetled Iudgement, free of preiudice, weigh the rea≈øons of this my Di≈øcour≈øe, and accept my plainne≈ø≈øe in good part, gracing this my Apologie with your fauours, and yet no longer then till it ≈øhall be iu≈øtly and worthily refuted; I end, with my earne≈øt prayers to the ALMIGHTIE for your pro≈øperities, and that after your happie Temporall Raignes in earth, ye may liue and raigne in Heauen with him for euer.

div.head: A CATALOGVE OF THE LYES OF TORTVS, TOGETHER WITH A BRIEFE Confutation of them.

p.label: TORTVS. Edit. Politan. pag. 9.
p.hi: IN the Oath of Allegiance the Popes power to excommunicate euen Hereticall Kings, is expre≈øly denied.

div.p: CONFVTATION. The point touching the Popes power in excommunicating Kings, is neither treated of, nor defined in the Oath of Allegiance, but was purpo≈øely declined. See the wordes of the Oath, and the Praemonition. pag. 292.

TORTVS. pag. 10. 2 For all Catholike writers doe collect from the wordes of Christ, What≈øoeuer thou ≈øhalt loo≈øe vpon earth, ≈øhall be loo≈øed in heauen, that there appertaineth to the Popes authoritie, not onely a power to ab≈øolue from ≈øinnes, but al≈øo from penalties, Cen≈øures, Lawes, Vowes, and Oathes.

CONFVTATION. That all Roman-Catholike writers doe not concurre with this Libeller, in thus collecting from CHRISTS wordes, Matth. 16. To omit other rea≈øons, it may appeare by this that many of them doe write, that what CHRIST promi≈øed there, that hee did actually exhibite to his Di≈øciples, Iohn 20. when hee ≈øaid, Who≈øe ≈øinnes ye remit, they ≈øhall be remitted, thereby re≈øtraining this power of loo≈øing formerly promi≈øed, vnto loo≈øing from ≈øinnes, not mentioning any ab≈øolution from Lawes, Vowes and Oathes in this place. So doe Theophylact, An≈øelme, Hugo Cardin. & Ferus in Matt. 16. So doe the principall Schoolemen, Alexand. Hales in Summa. part. 4. q. 79. memb. 5. & 6. art. 3. Thom. in 4. dist. 24. q. 3. art. 2. Scotus in 4. dist. 19. art. 1. Pope
Hadrian. 6. in 4. di≈øt. q. 2. de clauib. pag. 302. edit. Pari≈øien. anno 1530. who al≈øo alleadgeth for this interpretation, Augu≈øtine and the interlinear Glo≈ø≈øe.
TORTVS. Pag. 18. 3 I abhorre all Parricide, I dete≈øt all con≈øpiracies: yet it cannot be denied but occa≈øions of de≈øpaire were giuen [to the Powder-plotters.]

CONFVTATION. That it was not any iu≈øt occa≈øion of de≈øpaire giuen to the Powder-Traitours, as this Libeller would beare vs in hand, but the in≈øtructions which they had from the Ie≈øuits, that cau≈øed them to attempt this bloody de≈øigne: See the Premonition, pag. 291. & 335. and the booke intituled, The proceedings again≈øt the late Traitours.
TORTVS. Pap. 26. 4 For not onely the Catholiques, but al≈øo the Caluini≈øt puritanes dete≈øt the taking of this Oath.
CONFVTATION. The Puritanes doe not decline the Oath of Supremacie, but daily doe take it, neither euer refu≈øed it. And the ≈øame Supremacie is defended by Caluin him≈øelfe, In≈øtit. lib. 4. cap. 20.

TORTVS. Pag. 28. 5 Fir≈øt of all the Pope writeth not, that he was grieued at the calamities which the Catholikes did ≈øuffer for the keeping of the Orthodox faith in the time of the late Queene, or in the beginning of King Iames his reigne in England, but for the calamities which they ≈øuffer at this pre≈øent time.

CONFVTATION. The onely recitall of the wordes of the Breue will ≈øufficiently confute this Lye. For thus writeth the Pope, The tribulations and calamities which ye haue continually ≈øu≈øteined for the keeping of the Catholique faith, haue alway afflicted vs with great griefe of minde. But for a≈ømuch as we vnder≈øtand, that at this time all things are more grieuous, our affliction hereby is wonderfully increa≈øed.
TORTVS. Pag. 28. 6 In the fir≈øt article [of the Statute] the Lawes of Queene Elizabeth are confirmed.
CONFVTATION. There is no mention at all made of confirming the Lawes of Queene Elizabeth, in the fir≈øt article of that Statute.

TORTVS. Pag. 29. 7 In the 10. Article [of the ≈øaid Statute] it is added, that if the [Catholicks] refu≈øe the third time to take the Oath being tendered vnto them, they ≈øhall incurre the danger of loo≈øing their liues.
CONFVTATION. There is no mention in this whole Statute either of offering the Oath the third time, or any indangering of their liues.

TORTVS. Pag. 30. 8 In the 12. Article, it is enacted, that who≈øoeuer goeth out of the land to ≈øerue in the warres vnder forreine Princes, they ≈øhall fir≈øt of all take this Oath, or els be accounted for Traitours.

CONFVTATION. It is no where ≈øaid in that Statute, that they which ≈øhall thus ≈øerue in the warres vnder forraine Princes, before they haue taken this Oath, ≈øhall be accounted for Traitors, but onely for Felons.
TORTVS. Pag. 35. 9 Wee haue already declared, that the [Popes] Apo≈øtolique power in binding and loo≈øing is denied in that [Oath of Alleageance.]
CONFVTATION. There is no A≈ø≈øertory ≈øentence in that Oath, nor any word but onely conditionall, touching the power of the Pope in binding and loo≈øing.
TORTVS. Pag. 37. 10 The Popes them≈øelues, euen will they, nill they, were constrained to ≈øubiect them≈øelues to Nero and Diocletian.

CONFVTATION. That Chri≈øtians without exception, not vpon con≈øtraint but willingly and for con≈øcience ≈øake, did ≈øubiect them≈øelues to the Ethnicke Emperors, it may appeare by our Apologie, pag. 255, 256. and the Apologetickes of the ancient Fathers.
TORTVS. Pag. 47. 11 In which words [of the Breues of Clement the 8.] not onely Iames King of Scotland, was not excluded, but included rather.

CONFVTATION. If the Breues [of Clement] did not exclude mee from the Kingdome, but rather did include me, why did Garnet burne them? why would he not re≈øerue them that I might haue ≈øeene them, that ≈øo hee might haue obteined more fauour at my hands for him and his Catholikes?
TORTVS. Pag. 60. 12 Of tho≈øe 14. Articles [conteined in the Oath of Alleagiance] eleuen of them concerne the Primacie of the Pope in matters Spirituall.

CONFVTATION. No one Article of that Oath doeth meddle with the Primacie of the Pope in matter Spirituall: for to what end ≈øhould that haue bene, ≈øince we haue an expre≈ø≈øe Oath el≈øewhere again≈øt the Popes Primacie in matters Spirituall?
TORTVS. Pag. 64. 13 Amongst other calumnies this is mentioned, that Bellarmine was priuie to ≈øundry conspiracies again≈øt Q. Elizabeth, if not the author.

CONFVTATION. It is no where ≈øaid [in the Apologie] that Bellarmine was either the Authour, or priuie to any con≈øpiracies again≈øt Queene Elizabeth; but that he was their principall in≈øtructer and teacher, who corrupted their iudgement with ≈øuch dangerous po≈øitions and principles, that it was an ea≈øie matter to reduce the generals into particulars, and to apply the dictates which hee gaue out of his chaire, as opporunitie ≈øerued, to their ≈øeuerall de≈øignes.
TORTVS. Pag. 64. 14 For he [Bellarmine] knoweth, that Campian onely con≈øpired again≈øt Hereticall impietie.

CONFVTATION. That the trew and proper cau≈øe of Campians execution, was not for his con≈øpiring again≈øt Hereticall impietie, but for con≈øpiring again≈øt Queene Elizabeth and the State of this Kingdome, it was mo≈øt euident hy the iudiciall proceedings again≈øt him.

TORTVS. Pag. 65. 15 Why was H. Garnet, a man incomparable for learning in all kindes, and holine≈ø≈øe of life, put to death, but becau≈øe he would not reueale that which he could not doe with a ≈øafe con≈øcience.

CONFVTATION. That Garnet came to the knowledge of this horrible Plot not onely in confe≈ø≈øion as this Libeller would haue it, but by other meanes, neither by the relation of one alone, but by diuers, ≈øo as hee might with ≈øafe-con≈øcience haue di≈øclo≈øed it; See the Premonition, pag. 334, 335, &c. and the Earle of Northamptons booke.
TORTVS. Pag. 71. 16 Pope Sixtus 5. neither commanded the French King to bee murthered, neither approoued that fact, as it was done by a priuate per≈øon.
CONFVTATION. The fal≈øehood of this doeth ea≈øily appeare by the Oration of Sixtus 5.
TORTVS. Pag. 91. 17 That which is added concerning Stanley his Trea≈øon, is neither faithfully nor trewly related: for the Apologer (as his maner is) doeth mi≈øerably depraue it, by adding many lyes.
CONFVTATION. That which the Apologie relateth concerning Stanley his Trea≈øon, is word for word recited out of Cardinall Allens Apologie for Stanleys trea≈øon: as it is to be ≈øeene there.

TORTVS. Pag. 93. 18 It is very certaine that H. Garnet at his arraignement, did alwayes con≈øtantly auouch, that neither hee nor any Ie≈øuite either were authors, or compartners, or adui≈øers, or con≈øenting any way [to the Powder-Trea≈øon.] And a little after. The ≈øame thing hee protested at his death in a large ≈øpeach, in the pre≈øence of innumerable people.
CONFVTATION. The booke of the proceedings again≈øt the late Traitours, and our Premonition, pag. 334, 335, &c. doe clearely prooue the contrary of this to bee trew.
TORTVS. Pag. 97. 19 King Iames ≈øince he is no Catholike, neither is he a Chri≈øtian.

CONFVTATION. Contrary: I am a trew Catholike, a profe≈ø≈øor of the trewly ancient, Catholike, and Apo≈øtolike Faith: and therefore am a trew Chri≈øtian. See the confe≈ø≈øion of my faith in the Premonition, pag. 302. 303, &c.

TORTVS. Pag. 98. 20 And if the reports of them which knew him mo≈øt inwardly, be trew, when hee was in Scotland, he was a Puritane, and an enemie to Prote≈øtants: Now in England he profe≈øseth him≈øelfe a Protestant, and an enemie to the Puritans.
CONFVTATION. Contrary; and what a Puritane I was in Scotland: See my „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ and this my Premonition, pag. 305, 306.

div.head: HIS FALSIFICATIONS IN HIS ALLEDGING OF HISTORIES, together with a briefe declaration of their fal≈øhood
div.p: THE WORDS OF TORTVS. Pag. 70. 1 IT was certaine that he [Henry 4. the Emperour] died a naturall death.

CONFVTATION. It was not certaine: ≈øince ≈øundry Hi≈øtorians write otherwi≈øe, that he died vpoÃÑ his impri≈øonment by his ≈øonne Henry 5. either with the noy≈øomne≈ø≈øe and loath≈øomne≈ø≈øe of the pri≈øon, or being pined to death by hunger. Read Fa≈øciculus temporum at the yeere 1094. Laziardus epitom. vniuer≈øal. Hi≈øtor. c. 198. Paulus Langius in Chronico Citizen≈øi at the yeere 1105. and Iacobus Wimphelingus epitome Rerum Germanic. c. 28.

TORTVS. Pag. 83. 2 Henry 4. The Emperour feared indeed, but not any corporall death, but the cen≈øure of Excommunication, from the which that he might procure ab≈øolution, of his owne accord, he did thus demi≈ø≈øely humble him≈øelfe [before Gregory 7.]

CONFVTATION. That Henry 4. thus deiected him≈øelfe before the Pope, it was neither of his owne accord, neither vpon any feare of the Popes Excommunication, which [in this particular] hee e≈øteemed of no force, but vpon feare of the lo≈ø≈øe of his Kingdome and life, as the records of antiquitie doe euidently te≈øtifie. See Lambertus Schafnaburg at the yeere 1077. Abbas Vr≈øpergen. at the yeere 1075. The Author of the life of Henry 4. Bruno in his Hi≈øtory of the Saxon warre. Laziard in epitom. vniuer≈øal. Hi≈øtor. c. 193. Cu≈øpinian. in Henr. 4. Sigonius de Regno Italiae lib. 9.
TORTVS. Pag. 83. 3 The trewth of the Hi≈øtory [of Alexander 3 treading vpon the necke of Fredericke Barbaro≈ø≈øa with his foot] may beau≈øtly doubted of.

CONFVTATION. But no Hi≈øtorian doubteth of it; and many do auouch it, as Hieronym. Bard. in victor. Naual. ex Be≈ø≈øarion. Chronico apud Baron. ad an. 1177. num. 5. Ger≈øon de pote≈øtate Eccle≈øiae con≈øid. 1. Iacob Bergom. in ≈øupplem. Chronic. ad an. 1160. Nauclerus Gener. 40 Petrus Iu≈øtinian lib. 2. Rerum Venetar. Papirius Ma≈øson. lib. 5. de Epi≈øcop. vrbis. who alledgeth for this Gennadius Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople. Be≈øides Alphon≈øus Ciacconius de vit. Pontif. in Alexand. 3. and Azorius the Ie≈øuite: In≈øtit. Moral. part. lib. 5. c. 43.
TORTVS. Pag. 83. 4 What other thing feared Frederick Barbaro≈ø≈øa but excommunication?

CONFVTATION. That Frederick feared onely Pope Alexander his Excommunication, no ancient Hi≈øtorian doth te≈øtifie. But many do write, that this ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of his was principally for feare of loo≈øing his Empire and Dominions. See for this, Martin Polon. ad an. 1166. Platina in vita Alexan. 3. Laziard. in epitom. Hi≈øtoriae vniuer≈øal. c. 212. Naucler. Generat 40. Iacobus Wimphelingus in epitom. Rerum Germanic. c. 32.

TORTVS. Pag. 88. 5 Adde heereunto, that Cu≈øpinian. [in relating the history of the Turkes brother who was poy≈øoned by Alexander 6.] hath not the con≈øent of other writers to witne≈ø≈øe the trewth of this History.

CONFVTATION. The ≈øame Hi≈øtory, which is reported by Cu≈øpinian, is recorded al≈øo by ≈øundry other famous Hi≈øtorians. See Francis Guicciardin. lib. 2. Hi≈øtor. Ital. Paulus Iouius lib. 2. Hist. ≈øui temporis. Sabellic. Ennead. 10. lib. 9. Continuator Palmerij, at the yeere. 1494.

div.head: THE NOVEL DOCTRINES, WITH A BRIEFE DECLARATION of their Noueltie.
div.p: NOVEL DOCTRINE. Pag. 9. 1 IT is agreed vpon amongst all, that the Pope may lawfully depo≈øe Hereticall Princes, and free their Subiects from yeelding obedience vnto them.

CONFVTATION. Nay, all are ≈øo farre from con≈øenting in this point, that it may much more trewly be auouched, that none entertained that conceit before Hildebrand: ≈øince he was the fir≈øt brocher of this new doctrine neuer before heard of, as many learned men of that aage, and the aage next following (to omit others of ≈øucceeding aages) haue expre≈øly te≈øtified. See for this point, the Epi≈øtle of the whole Clergie of Liege to Pope Pa≈øchal the ≈øecond. See the iudgement of many Bi≈øhops of tho≈øe times, recorded by Auentine in his hi≈øtorie, lib. 5. fol. 579. Al≈øo the ≈øpeech vttered by Conrade bi≈øhop of Vtretcht, in the ≈øaid fifth booke of Auentine, fol. 582. And another by Eberhardus, Archbi≈øhop of Saltzburge. Ibid. lib. 7. p. 684. Al≈øo the iudgement of the Archbi≈øhop of Triers, in con≈øtitut. Imperialib. √† M. Haimensfeldio editis. pag. 47. The Epi≈øtle of Walthram Bi≈øhop of Megburgh which is extant in Dodechine his Appendix to the Chronicle of Marianus Scotus, at the yeere 1090. Benno in the life of Hildebrand. The author of the booke De vnitate Eccle≈øiae, or the Apologie for Henry the fourth. Sigebert in his Chronicle, at the yeere 1088. Godfrey of Viterbio in his Hi≈øtory entituled Pantheon, part. 17. Ottho Fri≈øingen≈øis, lib. 6. c. 35. & praefat. in lib. 7. Frederick Barbaro≈ø≈øa. lib. 6. Gunther. Ligurin. de ge≈øtis Frederici. and lib. 1. c. 10. of Raduicus de ge≈øtis eiu≈ødem Frederici. Vincentius in ≈øpeculo hi≈øtoriali lib. 15. c. 84. with ≈øundry others.

NOVEL DOCTRINE. Pag. 51. 2 In our ≈øupernaturall birth in Bapti≈øme wee are to conceiue of a ≈øecret and implied oath, which we take at our new birth, to yeeld obedience to the ≈øpirituall Prince, which is Chri≈øtes Vicar.

CONFVTATION. It is to bee wondred at, whence this fellow had this ≈øtrange new Diuinitie, which ≈øurely was fir≈øt framed in his owne fanta≈øticall braine. El≈øe let him make vs a Catalogue of his Authors, that hold and teach, that all Chri≈øtians, whether infants or of aage, are by vertue of an oath taken in their Bapti≈øme, bound to yeeld ab≈øolute obedience to CHRISTS Vicar the Pope, or baptized in any but in CHRIST.

NOVEL DOCTRINE. Pag. 94. 3 But ≈øince that Catholike doctrine doth not permit for the auoidance of any mi≈øchiefe what≈øoeuer, to di≈øcouer the ≈øecret of Sacramentall confe≈øsion, he [Garnet] rather cho≈øe to ≈øuffer most bitter death, then to violate the ≈øeale of ≈øo great a Sacrament.

CONFVTATION. That the ≈øecret of Sacramentall confe≈ø≈øion is by no meanes to bee di≈øclo≈øed, no not indirectly, or in generall, ≈øo the per≈øon confe≈ø≈øing bee concealed, for auoydance and preuention of no mi≈øchiefe, how great ≈øoeuer: Be≈øides that it is a po≈øition mo≈øt dangerous to all Princes and Common-wealths, as I ≈øhew in my Praemonition, pag. 333, 334. It is al≈øo a Nouell A≈ø≈øertion, not heard of till of late dayes in the Chri≈øtian world: Since the common opinion euen of the Schoolemen and Canoni≈øts both old and new, is vnto the contrary; witne≈ø≈øe the≈øe Authors following: Alexander Hales part. 4. qu. 78. mem. 2. art. 2. Thom. 4. di≈øt. 21. qu. 3. art. 1. ad 1. Scotus in 4. di≈øt. 21. qu. 2. Hadrian. 6. in 4. di≈øt. vbi de Sacramen. Confe≈ø. edit. Pari≈ø. 1530. pag. 289. Dominic. Sot. in 4. di≈øt. 18. q. 4. art. 5. Franci≈ø. de victor. ≈øumm. de Sacram. n. 189. Nauar. in Enchirid. c. 8. Io≈øeph. Angles in Florib. part. 1. pag. 247. edit. Antuerp. Petrus Soto lect. 11. de confe≈øs. The Ie≈øuites al≈øo accord hereunto, Suarez. Tom. 4. disp. in 3. part. Thom. di≈øp. 33. ¬ß 3. Gregor. de Valentia. Tom. 4. disp. 7. q. 13. punct. 3. who ≈øaith the common opinion of the Schoolemen is ≈øo.
NOVEL DOCTRINE. Pag. 102. 4 I dare boldly auow, that the Catholikes haue better rea≈øon to refu≈øe the Oath [of Allegeance] then Eleazar had to refu≈øe the eating of Swines fle≈øh.

CONFVTATION. This a≈ø≈øertion implieth a ≈øtrange doctrine indeede, that the Popes Breues are to be preferred before Mo≈øes Law: And that Papi≈øts are more bound to obey the Popes decree, then the Iewes were to obey the Law of God pronounced by Mo≈øes.

NOVEL DOCTRINE. Pag. 135. 5 Churchmen are exempted from the Iuri≈ødiction of ≈øecular Princes, and therefore are no ≈øubiects to Kings: yet ought they to ob≈øerue their Lawes concerning matters temporall, not by vertue of any Law, but by enforcement of rea≈øon, that is to ≈øay, not for that they are their Subiects, but becau≈øe rea≈øon will giue it, that ≈øuch Lawes are to be kept for the publike good, and the quiet of the Common-wealth.

CONFVTATION. How trew friends the Cardinall and his Chaplen are to Kings that would haue ≈øo many Subiects exempted from their power: See my Praemonition, Pag. 296, 297. Al≈øo, Pag, 330. 331. &c. But as for this and the like new Aphori≈ømes, I would haue the≈øe cunning Merchants to cea≈øe to vent ≈øuch ≈øtuffe for ancient and Catholike wares in the Chri≈øtian world, till they haue di≈øprooued their owne Venetians, who charge them with Noueltie and forgerie in this point.

div.head: A DECLARATION CONCERNING THE PROCEEDINGS WITH THE STATES GENERALL, OF THE ∆≤NITED PROVINCES OF THE LOW COVNTREYS, Jn the cau≈øe of D. CONRADVS VORSTIVS.

div.p: TO THE HONOVR OF OVR LORD AND SAVIOVR JESVS CHRIST, THE ETERNALL SONNE OF THE ETERNALL FATHER, THE ONELY ŒòŒïŒëŒùŒòŒ°Œ©Œ†ŒüŒ£, MEDIATOVR, AND RECONCILER OF MANKIND, IN SIGNE OF THANKFVLNES, HIS MOST H∆≤MBLE, AND MOST OBLIGED SERVANT, IAMES BY THE GRACE OF GOD, KING OF GREAT BRITAINE, FRANCE AND IRELAND, Defender of the FAITH, Doeth DEDICATE, and CONSECRATE this his DECLARATION.

THat it is one of the principall parts of that duetie which appertaines vnto a Chri≈øtian King, to protect the trew Church within his owne Dominions, and to extirpate here≈øies, is a Maxime without all controuer≈øie; in which re≈øpect tho≈øe honourable Titles of Cu≈øtos & Vindex vtriu≈øque Tabulae, Keeper and Auenger of both the Tables of the Law, and Nutritius Eccle≈øiae, Nur≈øing Father of the Church, do rightly belong vnto euery Emperour, King, and Chri≈øtian Monarch. But what intere≈øt a Chri≈øtian King may iu≈øtly pretend to meddle in alien√¢ Repub. within another State or Common wealth in matters of this nature (where Strangers are not allowed to be too curious) is the point in que≈øtion, and whereof we meane at this time to treate.

For our zeale to the glory of God, being the onely motiue that induced vs (as he who is the ≈øearcher of the heart and reines can witne≈ø≈øe) to make ≈øundry In≈øtances and Reque≈øts vnto the States Generall of the Vnited Prouinces, for the bani≈øhment of a wretched Heretique, or rather Athie≈øt, out of their Dominions, named D. Conradus Vor≈øtius, hath bene ≈øo ill interpreted, or rather wre≈øted to a peruer≈øe ≈øence, by a ≈øort of people, who≈øe corrupted ≈øtomacke turnes all good nouri≈øhment into bad and pernitious humors, (as if it had bene ≈øome vanitie and de≈øire of vaine glory in vs, or el≈øe an Ambition to encroach by little and little vpon the libertie of their State, which had caried vs headlong into the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe) As both to cleare our owne honour from the darke mi≈øts of the≈øe fal≈øe and ≈øcandalous imputations, as al≈øo to make it trewly appeare vnto the Chri≈øtian world, in what ≈øort wee haue proceeded herein; Wee haue thought good to publi≈øh this pre≈øent Declaration, containing as well the di≈øcour≈øe of our whole Negotiation hitherto with the States in this cau≈øe, as al≈øo the rea≈øons which haue mooued vs to take it ≈øo to heart, and to per≈øeuere therein as we haue done, and will doe (God willing) vntill it plea≈øe him, to bring it to ≈øome good and happy end.

In Autumne la≈øt, about the end of Augu≈øt, being in our hunting Progre≈ø≈øe, there came to our hands two bookes of the ≈øaid Vorstius, the one intituled Tractatus Theologicus de Deo, dedicated to the Lantgraue of He≈ø≈øen,
imprinted in the yeere 1610. the other his Exege≈øis Apologetica vpon that booke, dedicated to the States, and printed in the yeere 1611. Which books, a≈ø≈øoone as we had receiued, and (not without much horror and dete≈øtation) ca≈øt our eye onely vpon ≈øome of the principall Articles of his di≈øputations conteined in the fir≈øt booke, and his Commentary thereupon in the ≈øecond, God is our witne≈ø≈øe, that the zeale of his glory did ≈øo tran≈øport vs, as (to ≈øay with S. Paul) We ≈øtayed not one houre, but di≈øpatched a Letter pre≈øently to our Amba≈ø≈øadour re≈øident with the States, to this purpo≈øe following.

body.p:
You ≈øhall repaire to the States Generall, with all po≈øsible diligence in our name, telling them, that wee doubt not, but that their Amba≈ø≈øadours which were with vs about two yeeres ≈øince, did informe them of a forewarning, that we wi≈øhed the ≈øaid Amba≈ø≈øadours to make vnto them in our name, to beware in time, of ≈øeditious and hereticall Preachers, and not to ≈øuffer any ≈øuch to creepe into their State. Our principall meaning was of Arminius, who though him≈øelfe were lately dead, yet had hee left too many of his di≈øciples behinde him. Now according to that care which wee continually haue of the weale of their State, wee haue thought good to ≈øend vnto them a new aduerti≈øement vpon the like occa≈øion, which is this: That there is lately come to our handes a piece of worke of one Vor≈øtius, a Diuine in tho≈øe parts, wherein hee hath publi≈øhed ≈øuch monstrous blasphemie and horrible Athei≈øme, as out of the care that a Chri≈øtian Prince, and Defender of the Faith, (as we haue euer bene) ought to haue of the good of the Church, wee hold not onely ≈øuch a ≈øcandalous booke worthy to bee burnt, but euen the Authour him≈øelfe to bee most ≈øeuerely puni≈øhed. This notwithstanding wee are informed, that the States are ≈øo farre from beeing ≈øen≈øible of ≈øo great a ≈øcandall to the Church, as that the mo≈øt part of them haue already yeelded him their free con≈øents and voyces, for the obteining of the place of Diuinitie Reader in the Vniuer≈øitie of Leyden, which the aboue-named Arminius of little better ≈øtuffe, lately enioyed: and though him≈øelfe be dead, hath left his ≈øting yet liuing among them. Hauing therefore vnder≈øtood, that the time of Election will be about Michaelmas next, and holding our ≈øelues bound in honour and con≈øcience, as a Chri≈øtian Prince, and one who hath vouch≈øafed the States our Royall fauour and ≈øupport in respect of their Religion, to preuent ≈øo great a mi≈øchiefe ≈øo farre as we are able: Wee will and require you to let them vnder≈øtand, how infinitely wee ≈øhall bee displea≈øed if ≈øuch a Mon≈øter receiue aduancement in the Church. And if it bee alleadged, that hee hath recanted his Atheisticall opinions, and that thereupon he may be capable of the place, you ≈øhall tell them, that wee thinke his Recantation ≈øo ≈ølender a ≈øatisfaction for ≈øo fowle an offence, as that wee hold him rather worthy of puni≈øhment, or at lea≈øt to be debarred from all promotion: Wherein though
wee a≈øsure our ≈øelfe, that they will of their owne di≈øcretions e≈øchew ≈øuch a viper, who may make a fearefull rent not onely in their Eccle≈øia≈øticall, but al≈øo in their Politique State, yet notwith≈øtanding all this, if they will continue their re≈øolution to preferre him, you ≈øhall then make a prote≈øtation to them in our name, That wee will not faile to make knowen to the world publikely in print, how much wee dete≈øt ≈øuch abominable Here≈øies, and all allowers and tolerators of them: And becau≈øe the States ≈øhall know vpon what rea≈øons we haue grounded this our Admonition, you ≈øhall receiue herewith a This Catalogue is here purpo≈øely omitted for auoyding a needle≈ø≈øe repetition, ≈øeeing the principall points therof are conteined in a little Collection annexed at the end of our ≈øecond letter written to Wynwood. Catalogue of his damnable Po≈øitions, of which no one page of the booke is free.

div.p: For ob≈øeruing, that ≈øo prodigious a Mon≈øter began to liue among them, We could do no le≈ø≈øe (con≈øidering the infinite obligations which wee owe vnto God) then to make Our zeale appeare again≈øt ≈øuch an enemie to the E≈ø≈øence of the Deity. Be≈øides, the charitie, which Wee beare to the ≈øaid States Our neighbors and Confederates, profe≈ø≈øing the ≈øame Religion that we do, did enforce Vs to admoni≈øh them, to e≈øchew and preuent in time ≈øo dangerous a contagion, which di≈øper≈øing it ≈øelfe, might infect, not onely the bodie of their State, but all Chri≈øtendome al≈øo; the danger whereof was ≈øo much greater to our Dominions then to many others, by how much the Prouinces of the ≈øaid States are neerer vnto Vs in their ≈øituation.

Our Amba≈ø≈øadour therefore hauing ≈øufficiently acquitted him≈øelfe of that which Wee gaue him in charge, by exhorting them in Our Name, timely to preuent the danger which might en≈øue by enterteyning ≈øuch a gue≈øt as VORSTIVS; (which at that time they might ea≈øily haue done, ≈øeeing he was not yet ≈øetled at Leyden, neither was he lodged in the hou≈øe appointed for the publique Reader, nor were his wife and family yet arriued, and therefore much more ea≈øie for them to haue rid him out of their countrey, ≈øending him backe to the place from whence he came, according to the old Prouerbe,

div.p: It is more hone≈øt to refu≈øe a gue≈øt, then when you haue once receiued him, to thru≈øt him out of doores.) Yet notwith≈øtanding all the diligence that Our Amba≈ø≈øadour could v≈øe, and the oportunity which at that time was offered them to di≈øcharge him, all the an≈øwere he could procure from them, was but this, that,

Whereas a Propo≈øition was made on the behalfe of his Maie≈øtie of Great Britaine, in the a≈ø≈øembly of the Lords States Generall of the Vnited Prouinces by Sir Ralph Winwood his Maie≈øties Amba≈ø≈øadour and Councellour in the Councel of State in tho≈øe countreys, exhibited in writing the 21. of the moneth precedent (the ≈øub≈øtance thereof being fir≈øt amply debated by the Deputies of the States of Holland and We≈øt-Frizeland, and thereupon mature deliberation had) The ≈øaid
Lords States Generall in an≈øwere to the ≈øaid Propo≈øition, haue most humbly reque≈øted, and by the≈øe pre≈øents doe humbly reque≈øt his Maie≈øtie to beleeue, that as, for pre≈øeruation of the libertie, rights and priuiledges of the Low-Countreys, again≈øt the vniust, tyrannicall and bloody cour≈øes contrary thereunto, practi≈øed for many yeeres vpon the con≈øciences, bodies and fortunes of the good Inhabitants of all qualities of tho≈øe Countreys by the Spaniards and their Adherents, they haue been con≈øtrained after a long patience, many Remonstrances, Requests and other ≈øubmi≈øsiue proceedings v≈øed in vaine, to take armes for their nece≈ø≈øary defence, (when they ≈øaw no other remedy,) as al≈øo to craue the a≈øsistance of his Maie≈øtie particularly, and of other Kings, Princes and Common wealths, by who≈øe fauor, but principally by his Maiesties they haue ≈øince continually ≈øusteined for many yeeres, with an exceeding great constancie and moderation as well in prosperitie as in aduer≈øity, a heauie, chargeable and bloody warre, many terrible and cruell encounters, notable Battailes both by land and ≈øea, matchle≈ø≈øe Sieges of a number of Townes, Ruines, and deua≈øtation of Cities and Countreys, and other difficulties incident to the warre: So doe their Lord≈øhips alwayes confe≈ø≈øe, that in ≈øpecie the chiefe and principall rea≈øon which hath moued them at first to entertaine, and ≈øince to maintaine the ≈øaid re≈øolution, hath beene the fore≈øaid tyrannie exerci≈øed vpon the con≈øciences, bodies, and goods of their people, by introduction of the Inqui≈øition and con≈øtraint in matter of Religion: For which re≈øpects their Obligation to his Maie≈øtie is greatly increa≈øed, in that after ≈øo many demon≈øtrations of affection, fauours, and a≈øsi≈øtances in the pur≈øuite of their iu≈øt cau≈øe, his Maie≈øtie is yet plea≈øed, like a louing Father, to a≈ø≈øure vnto them the continuance of the ≈øame Royall affection and a≈øsistance, by taking care that the trew Chri≈øtian reformed Religion bee purely and ≈øincerely taught within their Countreys, a≈øwell in Churches as in Schooles; For which the Lords States Generall doe most humbly thanke his Maiestie, and will for their parts by all lawfull meanes, endeuour ≈øo to ≈øecond his ≈øincere and Christian intention in this particular, as his Maiestie ≈øhall receiue all good contentment.

As concerning the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of Doct. Vor≈øtius, principally handled in the fore≈øaid Propo≈øition, the Lords States Generall (to make the matter more plaine) haue informed them≈øelues, First that the Curators of the Vniuer≈øitie of Leyden (according to their duetie, and the ancient cu≈øtome euer ≈øince the foundation of that Vniuer≈øitie,) hauing diligently made inquirie for ≈øome Doctor to bee cho≈øen into the place of Diuinitie Profe≈ø≈øor there, at that time voyd, after mature deliberation were giuen to vnderstand, that at Steinford within the Dominions of the Counts of Tecklenbourg, Bentem, &c. (who were of the first Counts that in Germanie had cast off the yoke of the Papacie, Idolatrie, and impure religion, and imbraced the reformed Religion, which to this day they maintaine) there did remaine one Doct. Conradus Vor≈øtius, who had continued in that place about fifteene yeeres a Profe≈ø≈øor of trew Religion, and a Minister; and that the ≈øaide Conradus Vor≈øtius for his learning and other good parts was much ≈øought after by Prince Maurice, Lantgraue of He≈ø≈øen, with intent to make him Diuinitie Profe≈ø≈øor in ≈øome Vniuer≈øitie of his Countrey. Moreouer, that hee had ≈øufficiently, and to the great contentment, euen of tho≈øe that are now become his greate≈øt aduer≈øaries, ≈øhewed with a Chri≈øtian moderation his learning and puritie
in the holy knowledge of Diuinity, again≈øt the renowned Ie≈øuite Bellarmine: And that the ≈øayd Conradus Vor≈øtius was thereupon ≈øent for by the Curators afore≈øayde, about the beginning of Iuly, 1610. which me≈ø≈øage beeing ≈øeconded by letters of recommendation from his Excellencie, and from the deputy Councelors for the States of Holland and We≈øtfrizeland, vnto the ≈øayd Counts of Tecklenburg, did accordingly take effect. In the moneth of Augu≈øt following, the ≈øaid Election and Calling was countermined by certaine per≈øons, to who≈øe office or di≈øpo≈øition the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe did nothing at all belong: which being perceiued, and the ≈øayd Vor≈øtius charged with ≈øome vn≈øoundne≈ø≈øe of doctrine, the Curators did thereupon thinke fit, with the good liking of Vor≈øtius him≈øelfe, that as well in the Vniuer≈øitie of Leyden, as at the Hage, he ≈øhould appeare in his owne iu≈øtification to an≈øwere all accu≈øers and accu≈øations what≈øoeuer. At which time there was not any one that did offer to charge him. In the moneth of May following, ≈øixe Mini≈øters did vndertake to prooue, that VORSTIVS had publi≈øhed fal≈øe and vn≈øound doctrine, who afterward beeing heard in full a≈ø≈øembly of the States of Holland and We≈øtfrizeland, (in the pre≈øence of the Curators, and ≈øixe other Ministers) on the one part, and Vor≈øtius in his owne defence on the other part; and that which could bee ≈øaid on either ≈øide to the ≈øeuerall points in their ≈øeuer all refutations respectiuely: The ≈øaid Lords States hauing grauely deliberated vpon the allegations as well of the one part as of the other, as al≈øo heard the opinions of the ≈øaid Ministers (after the maner and cu≈øtome of the ≈øayd a≈ø≈øembly) could not ≈øee any rea≈øon, why the execution of that which was done by the Curators lawfully, and according to order, ought to bee hindred for impeached. In Augu≈øt following there being ≈øent ouer hither certaine other Articles, wherewith Vor≈øtius was charged, and di≈øper≈øed in little printed Pamphlets among≈øt the people, the ≈øayd Lords States entred into a new con≈øultation, and there re≈øolued, that Vor≈øtius (according both to Gods Law, the Law of Nature, and the law written; as al≈øo according to the laudable v≈øe and cu≈øtomes of their country,) ≈øhould be heard again≈øt his new accu≈øers, concerning tho≈øe Articles there layed to his charge. And moreouer, it was generally declared by the States of Holland and We≈øtfrizeland there a≈ø≈øembled, (as euery one of them likewi≈øe in his owne particular, and the Curators and Bourgma≈øters of Leyden for their parts did ≈øpecially declare:) That there was neuer any intention to permit other Religion to bee taught in the Vniuer≈øity of Leyden, then the Chri≈øtian Religion reformed and grounded vpon the word of God: And be≈øides, that if the ≈øayd Vor≈øtius ≈øhould bee found guilty in any of the afore≈øayd points whereof hee was accu≈øed, that they would not admit him to the place of Profe≈ø≈øour. The Deputies of the ≈øayd Lords States of Holland and We≈øtfrizeland further declaring, that they doe a≈øsuredly beleeue, that if his Maiesty of Great Britaine were well informed of the trew circum≈øtances of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and of their ≈øincere intention therein, hee would (according to his high wi≈øedome, prudence, and benignitie) conceiue fauourably of them, and their proceedings: whereof the Lords States Generall are no le≈ø≈øe confident; and the rather, for that the ≈øaid Deputies haue a≈øsured them, that the Lords States of Holland and We≈øtfrizeland their Superiors would proceede in this bu≈øine≈øse (as in all others) with all due reuerence, care, and respect vnto his Maie≈øties ≈øerious admonition, as becommeth them.

p.hi: And the Lords States Generall, doe reque≈øt the ≈øaid Lord Amba≈ø≈øadour to recommend this their An≈øwere vnto his Maie≈øtie with fauour.

div.p: BVt before wee had receiued this an≈øwere from the States, ≈øome of Vor≈øtius books were brought ouer into England, and (as it was reported) not without the knowledge and direction of the Authour. And about the ≈øame time one Bertius, a ≈øcholler of the late Arminius, (who was the fir≈øt in our aage that infected Leyden with Here≈øie) was ≈øo impudent, as to ≈øend a Letter vnto the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, with a Booke intituled, De Apo≈øta≈øia Sanctorum. And not thinking it ≈øufficient to auow the ≈øending of ≈øuch a booke, (the title whereof onely, were enough to make it worthy the fire) hee was moreouer ≈øo ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe, as to maintaine in his Letter to the Archbi≈øhop, that the doctrine conteined in his booke, was agreeable with the doctrine of the Church of England. Let the Church of CHRIST then iudge, whether it was not high time for vs to be≈øtirre our ≈øelues, when as this Gangrene had not onely taken holde among≈øt our neere≈øt neighbours; ≈øo as Non≈øol√πm paries proximus iam ardebat: not onely the next hou≈øe was on fire, but did al≈øo begin to creepe into the bowels of our owne Kindome; For which cau≈øe hauing fir≈øt giuen order, that the ≈øaid bookes of Vorstius ≈øhould be publikely burnt, as well in Pauls Church-yard, as in both the Vniuer≈øities of this Kingdome, wee thought good to renew our former reque≈øt vnto the States, for the bani≈øhment of Vor≈øtius, by a Letter which wee cau≈øed our Amba≈ø≈øadour to deliuer vnto them from vs at their A≈ø≈øembly in the Hage, the fifth of Nouember; whereunto they had referred vs in their former an≈øwere, the tenor of which Letter was as followeth:

body.p: Hauing vnderstood by your an≈øwere to that Propo≈øition which was made vnto you in our name by our Amba≈ø≈øadour there re≈øident, That at your A≈øsembly to bee holden in Nouember next, you are re≈øolued then to giue order concerning the bu≈øine≈øse of that wretched D. Vor≈øtius, Wee haue thought good (notwith≈øtanding the declaration which our Amba≈ø≈øadour hath already made vnto you in our name touching that particular,) to put you againe in remembrance thereof by this Letter, and thereby freely to di≈øcharge our ≈øelues, both in point of our duetie towards God, and of that ≈øincere friend≈øhip which wee beare towards you.

Fir≈øt We a≈ø≈øure Our ≈øelues that you are ≈øufficiently per≈øwaded that no worldly re≈øpect could moue Vs to haue thus importuned you in an affaire of this nature, being drawen into it onely through Our zeale to the glory of God, and the care which Wee haue that all occa≈øion of ≈øuch great ≈øcandals as this is, vnto the trew reformed Church
of God, might bee in due time fore≈øeene and preuented. Wee are therefore to let you vnder≈øtand, that Wee doe not a little wonder, that you haue not onely ≈øought to prouide an habitation in ≈øo eminent a place among≈øt you, for ≈øuch a corrupted per≈øon as this Vor≈øtius is, but that you haue al≈øo afforded him your licen≈øe and protection to print that Apologie which he hath dedicated vnto you; A booke wherein he doeth mo≈øt impudently maintaine the execrable blasphemies, which in his former hee had di≈øgorged; The which wee are now able to affirme out of our owne knowledge, hauing ≈øince that Letter which wee wrote vnto our Amba≈øsadour, read ouer and ouer againe with our owne eyes (not without extreme mi≈ølike and horrour) both his bookes, the first dedicated to the Lantgraue of He≈ø≈øen, and the other to you. We had well hoped, that the corrupt ≈øeed which that enemie of God Arminius did ≈øowe among≈øt you ≈øome few yeeres ≈øince (who≈øe di≈øciples and followers are yet too bold and frequent within your Dominions) had giuen you a ≈øufficient warning, afterwards to take heed of ≈øuch infected per≈øons, ≈øeeing your owne Countrey men already diuided into Factions vpon this occa≈øion, a matter ≈øo oppo≈øite to vnitie (which is indeed the onely prop and ≈øafetie of your State next vnder God) as of nece≈øsitie it mu≈øt by little and little bring you to vtter ruine, if wi≈øely you doe not prouide against it, and that in time.

It is trew that it was Our hard hap not to heare of this Arminius before he was dead, and that all the Reformed Churches of Germanie had with open mouth complained of him. But a≈øsoone as Wee vnder≈øtood of that di≈øtraction in your State, which after his death he left behind him, We did not faile (taking the opportunitie when your la≈øt extraordinary Amba≈ø≈øadors were here with Vs) to v≈øe ≈øome ≈øuch ≈øpeeches vnto them concerning this matter, as We thought fitte≈øt for the good of your State, and which we doubt not but they haue faithfully reported vnto you; For what need We make any que≈øtion of the arrogancie of the≈øe Heretiques, or rather Athei≈øticall Sectaries amongst you, when one of them at this pre≈øent remaining in your towne of Leyden, hath not onely pre≈øumed to publi≈øh of late a bla≈øphemous Booke of the Apo≈øta≈øie of the Saints, but hath be≈øides beene ≈øo impudent, as to ≈øend the other day a copie thereof, as a goodly pre≈øent, to Our Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, together with a letter, wherein he is not a≈øhamed (as al≈øo in his Booke) to lie ≈øo gro≈øsely, as to auowe, that his Here≈øies conteined in the ≈øaid Booke, are agreeable with the Religion and profe≈øsion of Our Church of England. For the≈øe re≈øpects therefore haue Wee cau≈øe enough very heartily to reque≈øt you, to roote out with ≈øpeed tho≈øe Here≈øies and Schi≈ømes, which are beginning to bud foorth amongst you, which if you ≈øuffer to haue the reines any longer, you cannot expect any other i≈ø≈øue thereof, then the cur≈øe of God, infamy throughout all the reformed Churches, and a perpetuall rent and di≈øtraction in the whole body of your State. But if peraduenture this wretched Vor≈øtius ≈øhould denie or equiuocate vpon tho≈øe bla≈øphemous poynts of Here≈øie and Athei≈øme, which already hee hath broached, that perhaps may mooue you to ≈øpare his per≈øon, and not cau≈øe him to bee burned (which neuer any Heretique better de≈øerued, and wherein we will leaue him to your owne (bristian wi≈øedome) but to ≈øuffer him vpon any defence or abnegation, which hee ≈øhall offer to make, ≈øtill to continue and to teach among≈øt you, is a thing ≈øo abominable, as we a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues it will not once enter into any of your thoughts: For admit hee would proue him≈øelfe innocent (which neuerthele≈ø≈øe
he cannot doe) in mo≈øt of tho≈øe points wherewith hee is charged; yet were it but the ≈øcandall of his per≈øon, which will ≈øtill remaine, it were cau≈øe more then enough for you to remooue him out of your Dominions. You know what is written of Cae≈øars wife, that it was not ≈øufficient for her to be innocent, but ≈øhe mu≈øt al≈øo bee free from all occa≈øion of ≈øuspicion: how much more then ought you to bee warie and cautious in a matter of ≈øo great importance as this, which concerneth the glory of God, the ≈øaluation of your ≈øoules, the ≈øoules of your people, and the ≈øafetie of your State; and not to ≈øuffer ≈øo dangerous a ≈øparke to lie kindling amongst you? For a man may ea≈øily coniecture, that feare and the horrour of his owne actions will make him boldly denie that poy≈øon which boyleth at his heart: For what will not bee denie, that denieth the Eternitie and Omnipotencie of God? And howbeit hee were innocent (as we haue ≈øaid before) the Church of God is not ≈øo ill furni≈øhed with men of ≈øufficiencie for that place, as that you need bee vnprouided of ≈øome other, who ≈øhall not be ≈øubiect to that ≈øcandall, wherewith hee is ≈øo tainted, as it must bee a long penance, and many yeeres of probation, that mu≈øt weare it away. But especially ought you to bee very carefull, not to hazard the corruption of your youth in ≈øo famous an Vniuer≈øitie by the doctrine of ≈øo ≈øcandalous a per≈øon, who (it is to bee feared) when hee findeth him≈øelfe once well ≈øetled there, will returne againe to his ancient vomite.

We will therefore conclude with this request vnto you, that you will a≈øsure your ≈øelues, that the affection onely which wee beare vnto your State, hath enforced vs to v≈øe this libertie towards you, not doubting for our part, but that, as this which wee haue written vnto you proceedes from the ≈øinceritie of our con≈øcience, ≈øo our good God will bee plea≈øed to giue you a due apprehen≈øion thereof, and that your re≈øolution in a matter of ≈øo great con≈øequence, may tend to his glory, to your owne honour and ≈øafetie, to the extirpation of the≈øe ≈øpringing Athei≈ømes and Here≈øies, and to the ≈øatisfaction, not onely of vs, but of all the reformed Churches, who haue bene hitherto extremely ≈øcandalized therewith: But if on the contrary part, we faile of that wee expect at your hands (which God forbid) and that you ≈øuffer hereafter ≈øuch pe≈øtilent Heretiques to nestle among you, who dare take vpon them that licentious libertie, to fetch againe from Hell the ancient Here≈øies long ≈øince condemned, or el≈øe to inuent new of their owne braine, contrary to the beliefe of the trew Catholike Church, wee ≈øhall then bee con≈øtrained (to our great griefe) publikely to prote≈øt again≈øt the≈øe abominations: and (as God hath honoured vs with the Title of Defender of the Faith) not onely to depart and ≈øeparate our ≈øelues from the vnion of ≈øuch fal≈øe and heretical Churches, but al≈øo to exhort all other reformed Churches to ioyne with vs in a common Councel, how to extingui≈øh and remand to hell the≈øe abominable Here≈øies, that now newly begin to put foorth againe. And furthermore for our owne particular, we ≈øhall be enforced ≈øtrictly to inhibite the youth of our Dominions from repairing to ≈øo infected a place, as is the Vniuer≈øitie of Leyden. div.p:

Vor≈øtius be admitted Profe≈ø≈øor in the Vniuer≈øitie of Leyden, or not? or whether the doctrine of Arminius bee preached in your Churches? ≈øauing that as a Christian Prince, he de≈øires the aduancement of the Gospel, and as your best friend and allye, the ≈øtrengthening of your Commonwealth, who≈øe fir≈øt foundations were cymented with the blood of his ≈øubiects, and which in his iudgement can no way ≈øub≈øi≈øt, if wittingly and willingly you ≈øuffer the Reformed Religion to be either by the practi≈øes of your Doctors ≈øophi≈øticated, or by their malice depraued.

The foole ≈øaid in his heart, There is no God: but hee that with open mouth, of ≈øet purpo≈øe, and of prepen≈øed malice, hath let his penne runne at randome, to di≈øgorge ≈øo many blasphemies again≈øt the Sacred Maie≈øtie of GOD,

div.p: The≈øe are in part the opinions of that great Diuine, whom they haue cho≈øen to domineere in the Chaire at Leyden: In oppo≈øition whereunto, I meane not to ≈øay any thing el≈øe, then that which the Romane Oratour did once pronounce in the like ca≈øe: Mala e≈øt & impia con≈øuetudo contra Deum di≈øputandi, ≈øiu√® ≈øeri√≤ id fit, ≈øiu√® ≈øimulat√® It is an euill and a wicked cu≈øtome (≈øaith hee) to di≈øpute again≈øt God, whether it be in earne≈øt, or in iest.

Now my Lords, I addre≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe vnto your Lord≈øhips, and according vnto the charge which I haue receiued from the King my Ma≈øter, I coniure you by the amitie that is betwixt his Kingdomes and your Prouinces, (the which on his part will continue alwayes inuiolable) to awaken your ≈øpirits, and to haue a carefull eye at this A≈ø≈øembly of Holland, (which is already begunne) ne quid Re≈øpublica detrimenti capiat, That the Common wealth take no harme: which vndoubtedly, at one time or other, will be turned vp≈øide downe, if you ≈øuffer ≈øuch a dangerous contagion to barbour ≈øo neere you, and not remoue it out of your Prouinces a≈øsoone as po≈øsibly you may. The di≈øciples of Socinus (with who≈øe doctrine he hath bene ≈øuckled in his childhood)
doe ≈øeeke him for their Ma≈øter, and are ready to embrace him. Let him goe, bee is a Bird of their owne feather: Et dignum ≈øan√® patell√¢ operculum; A couer fit for ≈øuch a di≈øh.

On the other ≈øide, the Students in Diuinitie at Leyden to the number of 56. by a duetiful Remon≈øtrance pre≈øented vnto the States of Holland the 16. of October the la≈øt yeere, did mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech the ≈øaid States, not to v≈øe their authoritie in compelling them to receiue a Profe≈ø≈øor, who both by the atte≈øtations of the Diuinitie Colledges at Ba≈øil and Heydelberg, as al≈øo by manife≈øt euidence out of his owne writings, is conuinced of an infinite number of Here≈øies.

The≈øe rea≈øons therefore, namely, the proofes of ≈øo many enormous and horrible Here≈øies maintained in his Bookes, the in≈øtance of his Maie≈øtie grounded vpon the welfare and honour of this Countrey, the reque≈øts either of all, or of the mo≈øt part of your Prouinces, the petitions of all the Mini≈øters (excepting tho≈øe onely which are of Arminius Sect) ≈øhould me thinkes preuaile ≈øo farre with my Lords the States of Holland, and (we hope) will ≈øo farre preuaile, as they will at the last apply them≈øelues to the performance of that, which both the ≈øinceritie of Religion, and the ≈øeruice of their Countrey requireth at their hands. Furthermore, I haue commandement from his Maie≈øtie to mooue you in his Name, to ≈øet downe ≈øome certaine Reglement in matters of Religion throughout your Prouinces, that this licentious freedome of disputation, may by that meanes be re≈øtrained, which breeds nothing but Factions, and part-taking; and that you would ab≈øolutely take away the libertie of Prophecying, which Vor≈øtius doeth ≈øo much recommend vnto you in the dedicatorie Epistle of his Anti-Bellarmine, the Booke whereof his Patrons doe boast ≈øo much.

To conclude, his Maie≈øtie doeth exhort you, ≈øeeing you haue heretofore taken Armes for the libertie of your con≈øciences, and haue ≈øo much endured in a violent and bloody warre, the ≈øpace of fourtie yeeres, for the profe≈øsion of the Go≈øpel, that now hauing gotten the vpper hand of your mi≈øeries, you would not ≈øuffer the followers of Arminius, to make your actions an example for them to proclaime throughout the world, that wicked doctrine of the Apo≈øta≈øie of the Saints.

To bee ≈øhort, the account which his Maie≈øtie doeth make of your amitie appeares ≈øufficiently by the Treaties which hee hath made with your Lord≈øhips, by the ≈øuccours which your Prouinces haue receiued from his crownes, by the deluge of blood, which his ≈øubiects haue ≈øpent in your warres. Religion is the onely ≈øowder of this Amitie: For his Maiestie being, by the Grace of GOD, Defender of the Faith, (by which Title hee doeth more value him≈øelfe, then by the Title of King of Great Britaine) doeth hold him≈øelfe obliged to defend all tho≈øe, who profe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame Faith and Religion with him. But our Amba≈ø≈øadour hauing, after a delay for the ≈øpace of diuers

Vpon the coldne≈ø≈øe therefore of this An≈øwere, (which hee feared would giue vs no ≈øatisfaction) hee thought it was now high time to con≈øider what the la≈øt remedy might bee, whereof v≈øe was to bee made for the aduancement of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe: and perceiuing that hee had already performed all the re≈øt of our commandements, excepting onely to Prote≈øt in ca≈øe of refu≈øall, and e≈øteeming ≈øuch a cold an≈øwere, accompanied with ≈øo many delayes, to be no le≈ø≈øe in effect then an ab≈øolute refu≈øall, hee thereupon re≈øolued to make this Prote≈øtation in their publique a≈ø≈øemblie, which hereafter followeth.

MY Lords; The Hi≈øtoriographers, who haue diligently looked into the Antiquities of France, doe ob≈øerue, that the Aduocates there in times past, were accu≈øtomed to begin their pleadings with ≈øome Latine Sentence taken out of the holy Scriptures: I ≈øhall at this time follow their example, and my Sentence ≈øhall be this: Si peccauerit in te frater tuus, argue eum inter te & ip≈øum ≈øolum; ≈øi audiuerit te, lucratus es fratrem tuum; ≈øi non audiuerit te, adhibevnum atque alterum, vt in ore duorum vel trium ≈øtet omne verbum: ≈øi non audiuerit eos, dic Eccle≈øiae. If thy brother tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe again≈øt thee, goe and tell him his fault betweene him and thee alone; if he heare thee, thou ha≈øt wonne thy brother; but if hee heare thee not, take yet with thee one or two, that by the mouth of two or
three witne≈ø≈øes euery word may bee confirmed: and if hee refu≈øe to heare them, tell it vnto the Church.

There is not any one of you (as I ≈øuppo≈øe) in this A≈ø≈øemblie, that will not acknowledge the brotherly loue wherewith the King my Ma≈øter hath alwayes affected the good of your Prouinces, and the fatherly care which hee hath euer had to procure the e≈øtabli≈øhment of your State. In which respect, his Maiestie hauing vnder≈øtood, that my Lords the States of Holland were determined to call vnto the place of Diuinitie Profe≈ø≈øour in the Vniuer ≈øitie of Leyden, one Doctor Conradus Vor≈øtius, a per≈øon attainted by many witne≈ø≈øes, iuris & facti, of a number of Here≈øies (the ≈øhame whereof would light vpon the Church of God, and con≈øequently vpon his Maiesties per≈øon and Crownes) is therewith exceedingly offended: And for the more timely preuention of an infinitie of euils, which nece≈ø≈øarily would thereupon en≈øue, did giue mee in charge by expre≈øse Letters to exhort you (which I did the 21. of September la≈øt) to wa≈øh your hands from that man, and not to fuffer him to come within your Countrey.
