It is moreouer ≈øomewhat ≈øu≈øpicious in ≈øuch a tainted per≈øon as he is, that in an Appendix which hee hath placed at the end of his The≈øes, he taketh occa≈øion to name a number of Heretiques who are aduer≈øaries to the doctrine of his The≈øes, and tho≈øe e≈øpecially who haue erred concerning the Diuinitie, Humanitie, Per≈øon, or Office of CHRIST, as the Ebionites, Cerinthians, Arrians, Praxians, Sabellians, Marcionites, Manichees, Docites, Apollinari≈øts, Mennonites, Swenkfeldians, Ne≈øtorians, Monothelites, Eutychians, Monophy≈øites, Iewes, Millenaries, Papi≈øts. Among≈øt which rabble he doeth not once make mention of Paulus Samo≈øatenus, nor of Photinius, who ≈øucceeded him as well in his Bi≈øhopricke as in his errour: Yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe it is reported, that Vor≈øtius in his heart is not very farre from their erronious opinion.

Now in the Preface of this little booke hee hath taken vpon him very ≈øuccinctly to make an≈øwere to fiue Articles which he confe≈ø≈øeth were layd to his charge, by which an≈øwere, in our opinion, hee di≈øcouers him≈øelfe very plainely.

The fir≈øt point is, That hee was once accu≈øed (as him≈øelfe ≈øaith) of the Samo≈øatenian Here≈øie, becau≈øe he had ≈øometime both written and receiued letters from diuers of that Sect; which he confe≈ø≈øeth he did indeed in his youth, to this end, that by that meanes hee might the more ea≈øily come by ≈øome of their bookes, but that afterward hee did forbeare all corre≈øpondencie with them. Fir≈øt of all then, we would be glad to know why hee forgot the Here≈øie of Samo≈øatenus in his Appendix, where he names ≈øo many others, and yet confe≈ø≈øeth in the Preface of his ≈øaid booke, that he him≈øelfe was accu≈øed of that errour. Secondly, to what end had hee in his youth ≈øo great traffique with the≈øe Heretiques? was it to enable him the better to confute them? We heare him not ≈øay ≈øo much, as indeed it was neuer his end. Surely this fellow would be an excellent clean≈øer of a Pe≈øthou≈øe, for he feares no infection: Picem contrectare non timet, he dares handle any pitch: And yet for all that, the Prouerbe is trew, Qui ambulat in Sole, colorabitur; He that walketh in the Sun-≈øhine, ≈øhall bee Sun-burnt. It followes then, ≈øeeing his intention was not to arme him≈øelfe again≈øt them, that it mu≈øt be of nece≈ø≈øitie to make him≈øelfe worthy of their Schoole, the which hee almo≈øt confe≈ø≈øeth in the la≈øt words of his An≈øwere to that point, where he ≈øaith thus; Non enim (quod multi ≈øolent) alienis ≈øen≈øibus h√Æc fidendum putaui, aut temer√® quidquam in cau≈øa Fidei damnandum: For I doe not thinke it fit (as many others doe) to relie in the≈øe ca≈øes vpon other mens con≈øtructions, or ra≈øhly to condemne any thing which concernes matter of Faith.

To the ≈øecond Article of his Accu≈øation, hee confe≈ø≈øeth that hee gaue ≈øome of his Samo≈øatenian bookes vnto his ≈øchollers; Surely, a goodly gift: But the caution was prettie which he gaue withall vnto them when he deliuered them the bookes; which was that they ought to reade them with iudgement, not ra≈øhly reiecting the doctrine commonly receiued. What an Epithite is heere for our holy Orthodoxe Faith, to terme it no otherwi≈øe then the doctrine commonly receiued? And as for his caution, not ra≈øhly to for≈øake the old doctrine, it is no more then the Turkes would giue vnto any Chri≈øtian, that ≈øhould ≈øuddenly offer to become a Mahometi≈øt. Nay what Chri≈øtian did euer ≈øollicite a Pagan, or Heretique to bee conuerted, but with this caution? Who Would per≈øwade a man to receiue the holy Sacrament ra≈øhly? S. Paul commands euery man to examine him≈øelfe diligently, before hee come to that holy Table. But on the other ≈øide, an Orthodoxe Chri≈øtian would in this ca≈øe haue ≈øaid to his ≈øchollers: If you will reade the≈øe wicked bookes, reade them with horrour and dete≈øtation, and with an intent to arme your ≈øelues again≈øt ≈øuch wiles and ≈øubtilties of Sathan, and withall pray vnto GOD to keepe you con≈øtant in the holy Catholique and Orthodoxe Faith, that the≈øe Here≈øies may haue no power once to mooue you, tru≈øting in his mercy, and not in your owne ≈øtrength.

To the third Article, he confe≈ø≈øeth that his ≈øchollers did publi≈øh bookes of the Socinian Here≈øie; and his excu≈øe is, that it was without his knowledge:
But how≈øoeuer, he condemnes them not for hauing done it onely this he ≈øaith, That they declared vpon their oathes, they did not fauour the Here≈øie.

To the fourth point, he confe≈ø≈øeth that about ten yeeres ≈øince, he wrote a booke De Filiatione Chri≈øti, (for which Title onely, an Authour, ≈øo ≈øu≈øpected as he, is worthy of the fagot,) and all his excu≈øe is, That he wrote an Epitome vpon Bellarmine. Wee doubt not but hee did it for his recreation. For≈øooth, a prety conceit. Yet it appeares not by his wordes, that he dete≈øts the ≈øubiect of that Booke: but ≈øaith, That no man can thereby coniecture what his opinion is of that argument, no more then they can vpon his Epitome of Bellarmine, which was likewi≈øe his worke. For to condemne it, had beene contrary to that which hee auowed in his other booke, neuer to repent him≈øelfe of any thing that he hath once written, as already we haue ob≈øerued.

As for the fift and la≈øt point, he will neither confe≈ø≈øe, nor deny the accu≈øation: onely hee ≈øaith, That a certaine booke intituled Dominicus Lopez, which is (as we haue heard) a very bla≈øphemous Treati≈øe, was ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by him pacis erg√≤, for peace ≈øake; but he is ≈øo farre from condemning it, as that he alleadgeth, the booke hath bene maintained by others, which in time ≈øhall appeare. Two things are here to bee ob≈øerued; Fir≈øt, that hee ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed it pacis erg√≤, for quietne≈ø≈øe ≈øake; Not therefore for the wickedne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øubiect, The next, that in his due time: the trewth thereof ≈øhall appeare. In which la≈øt point onely, we will willingly ioyne with him, be≈øeeching our good GOD, for his CHRISTS ≈øake, that hee will bee plea≈øed to di≈øcouer the trewth of this mans intentions, as well for his owne Glory, as to purge the ≈øcandall, and to auoyd the danger which may en≈øue vnto Chri≈øtendome, by the darnell of Here≈øies which he hath ≈øowne.

It is therefore to bee noted, That to all the≈øe fiue Articles his an≈øweres are ≈øo ≈øilly and weake, as in three of them we haue found him plan√® confitentem reum, plainely pleading guiltie; blanching it onely with ≈øome poore excu≈øes. And to the other two points his an≈øwers are doubtfull; yet neither condemning the act of his ≈øchollers, nor the la≈øt wicked booke called Dominicus Lopez.

Hauing now therefore briefly laied open the ≈øubtilties, friuolous di≈øtinctions, and excu≈øes of the ≈øaid Vor≈øtius, we will conclude this point with this prote≈øtation; That if he had bene our owne Subiect, we would haue bid him Excrea, ≈øpit out: and forced him to haue produced, and confe≈ø≈øed tho≈øe wicked Here≈øies, that are rooted in his heart. And in ca≈øe he ≈øhould ≈øtand vpon his Negatiue, we would enioyne him to ≈øay (according to the ancient cu≈øtome of the Primitiue Church in the like ca≈øes of Heretiques) I renounce and from my ≈øoule detest them: Anathema, Maranatha vpon ≈øuch and ≈øuch Here≈øies; And not to ≈øay For peace ≈øake I cau≈øed this booke to be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, And the≈øe bookes are to bee read with great iudgement and di≈øcretion. S. Hierome liketh not that any man ≈øhould take it patiently, to be ≈øu≈øpected of Here≈øie.

And now to make an end of this Di≈øcour≈øe, we doe very heartily de≈øire all good Chri≈øtians in generall, and My Lords the States in particular (to whom the managing of this affaire doeth mo≈øt ≈øpecially belong) to con≈øider but two things: Fir≈øt what kinde of people they be that ≈ølander vs, and our ≈øincere intention in this cau≈øe: And next, what priuate intere≈øt wee can po≈ø≈øibly haue (in re≈øpect of any worldly honour or aduancement) herein to engage our ≈øelues in ≈øuch ≈øort as we haue done.

Concerning the fir≈øt point, There are but three ≈øorts of people, that ≈øeeke to calumniate vs vpon this occa≈øion: That is to ≈øay; either ≈øuch as are infected with the ≈øame, or the like Here≈øies, wherewith Vor≈øtius is tainted, & ideo fouent con≈øimilem cau≈øam, and therefore doe maintaine the like cau≈øe: or el≈øe ≈øuch as be of the Romane Religion, who in this confu≈øion, and libertie of prophe≈øying would thru≈øt in for a part; conceiuing it more rea≈øonable, that their doctrine ≈øhould be tolerated by tho≈øe of our Religion, then the doctrine of Vor≈øtius: or el≈øe ≈øuch, as for rea≈øon of State enuie peraduenture the good amitie and corre≈øpondencie which is betwixt vs, and the Vnited Prouinces.

Touching our owne intere≈øt, the whole cour≈øe of our life doeth ≈øufficiently witne≈ø≈øe, that we haue alwayes bene contented with that portion which GOD hath put into our hands, without ≈øeeking to inuade the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of any other. Be≈øides, in two of our bookes, as well in our „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , as in the Preface to our Apologie, we haue ≈øhewed the ≈øame inclination. For in the fir≈øt booke, ≈øpeaking of warre, we ≈øay that a King ought not to make any inua≈øion vpon anothers Dominions, vntill Iu≈øtice be fir≈øt denied him. And in the other booke, hauing ≈øhewed the v≈øurpation of the Pope, aboue all the Kings and Princes of Chri≈øtendome, our conclu≈øion is, that we will neuer goe about to per≈øwade them to a≈ø≈øault him within his Dominions, but onely to re≈øume, and pre≈øerue their owne iu≈øt Priuiledges from his violent intru≈øion. So as (thankes be to GOD) both our Theorique and Practique agree well together, to cleare vs from this vniu≈øt and ≈ølanderous imputation. And as for the States in particular, it is very vnlikely that we (who haue all our life time held ≈øo ≈øtrict an amitie with them, as for their defence wee haue bene contented to expo≈øe the liues of many of our Subiects of both Nations,) would now practi≈øe again≈øt then State, and that vpon ≈øo poore a ≈øubiect as Vorstius: e≈øpecially, that ≈øo damnable a thing could euer enter into our heart, as vnder the vaile and pretext of the glory of GOD, to plot the aduancement of our owne priuate de≈øeignes.

The rea≈øons which induced vs to meddle in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, we haue already declared. We leaue it now to his owne proper Iudges to con≈øider what a nur≈øling they fo≈øter in their bo≈øome: A ≈øtranger, bred in the Socinian Here≈øie (as it is ≈øaid;) often times accu≈øed of Here≈øie by the Churches of Germanie; one that hath written ≈øo wicked and ≈øcandalous bookes; maintaining and ≈øeriou≈øly prote≈øting in the preface of his Apologie to the States,
for the libertie of prophecying; and twice or thrice in≈øi≈øting vpon that libertie in the Preface of his Modest An≈øwere (a dangerous and pernitious libertie, or rather licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe, opening a gap to all rupture, Schi≈øme, and confu≈øion in the Church;) yea hauing had ≈øome di≈øciples that be Heretiques them≈øelues, and others that accu≈øe him of Here≈øie. And though there were no other cau≈øe then the ≈øilly and idle ≈øhifts wherewith hee ≈øeekes to defend him≈øelfe in his la≈øt bookes, it were enough to conuince him, either to haue maintained a bad cau≈øe, and in that re≈øpect worthy of a farre greater puni≈øhment then to be put by his place of Profe≈øsour; or at the lea≈øt to be a per≈øon vnworthy of the name of a Profe≈ø≈øour in ≈øo famous an Vniuer≈øitie, for hauing ≈øo weakely maintained a cau≈øe that is iu≈øt. For our part, GOD is our witne≈ø≈øe, we haue no quarrell again≈øt his per≈øon; he is a Stranger, borne farre from our dominions: he is a Germane, and it is well knowen, that all Germanie are our friends, and the mo≈øt part of the great Princes there, be either neerely allied vnto vs, or our Confederates: he doth outwardly profe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame Religion which we do: he hath written again≈øt Bellarmine: and hath not mentioned vs, either in ≈øpeach or writing (for any thing we know) but with all the honour and re≈øpect that may be. GOD knowes, the wor≈øt that we do wi≈øh him is, that he may ≈øincerely returne into the high beaten path-way of the Catholique and Orthodoxall Faith.

And for my Lords the States (≈øeeing wee haue di≈øcharged our con≈øcience) we will now referre the managing of the whole Action vnto their owne di≈øcretions. For wee are ≈øo farre from pre≈øcribing them any rule herein, as we ≈øhall be very well contented (≈øo as the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe be well done) that there be euen no mention at all made of our interce≈ø≈øion, in their publique Acts or Records. Their maner of proceeding, we leaue ab≈øolutely to their owne Wi≈øedomes. Mod√≤ praedicetur Christus, ≈øo as CHRIST bee preached, let them v≈øe their owne formes in the Name of GOD. For we de≈øire that GOD ≈øhould ≈øo iudge vs at the la≈øt Day, as we affect not in this Action any worldly glory, be≈øeeching the Creatour ≈øo to open their eyes, to illuminate their vnder≈øtandings, direct their re≈øolutions, and, aboue all, to kindle their zeale, ≈øanctifie their affections, & at the la≈øt ≈øo to ble≈ø≈øe their Actions and their proceedings in this cau≈øe, as the i≈ø≈øue thereof may tend to his Glory, to the comfort and ≈øolace of the Faithfull, to the honour of our Religion, to the confu≈øion and extirpation (at the lea≈øt, profligation) of Here≈øies, and, in particular, to the corroboration of the Vnion of the ≈øayd Prouinces.

div.head: A REMONSTRANCE FOR THE RIGHT OF KINGS, AND THE INDEPENDANCE OF THEIR CROVVNES, AGAINST AN ORATION OF THE MOST ILLVSTRIOVS CARD. OF PERRON, PRONOVNCED IN THE Chamber of the third E≈øtate. IAN. 15. 1615.
THE PREFACE.
div.p:
I Haue no humour to play the Curious in a forraine Common wealth, or, vnreque≈øted, to carry any hand in my neighbours affaires Jt hath more congruitie with Royall dignitie, whereof God hath giuen mee the honour, to pre≈øcribe Lawes at home for my Subiects, rather then to furni≈øh forraine Kingdomes and people with coun≈øels. Howbeit, my late entire affection to K. Henry IV. of happy memorie, my most honoured brother, and my exceeding ≈øorrow for the most dete≈øtable parricide acted vpon the ≈øacred per≈øon of a King, ≈øo complete in all heroicall and Princely vertues; as al≈øo the remembrance of my
owne dangers, incurred by the practi≈øe of con≈øpiracies flowing from the ≈øame ≈øource, hath wrought mee to ≈øympathize with my friends in their grieuous occurrents: no doubt ≈øo much more dangerous, as they are le≈ø≈øe apprehended and felt of Kings them≈øelues, euen when the danger hangeth ouer their owne heads. ∆≤pon whom, in ca≈øe the power and vertue of my aduerti≈øements be not able effectually to worke, at lea≈øt many millions of children and people yet vnborne, ≈øhall beare me witne≈ø≈øe, that in the≈øe dangers of the highest nature and ≈øtraine, J haue not bene defectiue: and that neither the ≈øubuer≈øions of States, nor the murthers of Kings, which may vnhappily betide hereafter, ≈øhall haue ≈øo free pa≈øsage in the world for want of timely aduerti≈øement before. For touching my particular, my rest is vp, that one of the maynes for which God hath aduanced me vpon the loftie ≈øtage of the ≈øupreme Throne, is, that my words vttered from ≈øo eminent a place for Gods honour, mo≈øt ≈øhamefully traduced and vilified in his owne Deputies and Lieutenants, might with greater facilitie be conceiued.

Now touching France, faire was the hope which J conceiued of the States a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament at Paris: That calling to minde the murthers of their Noble Kings, and the warres of the League which followed the Popes fulminations, as when a great ≈øtorme of haile powreth downe after a Thunder-cracke, and a world of writings addre≈ø≈øed to iustifie the parricides, and the dethronings of kings, they would haue ioyned heads, hearts, & hands together, to hammer out ≈øome apt and whole≈øome remedy against ≈øo many fearefull attempts and practi≈øes. To my hope was added no little ioy, when I was giuen to vnderstand the third E≈øtate had preferred an Article or Bill, the tenor and ≈øubstance whereof was concerning the meanes whereby the people might bee vnwitched of this pernicious opinion; That Popes may to≈ø≈øe the French King his Throne like a tennis ball, and that killing of Kings is an acte meritorious to the purcha≈øe of the crowne of Martyrdome. But in fine, the proiect was encountred with ≈øucce≈ø≈øe cleane coutrary to Expectation. For this Article of the third Estate, like a ≈øigh of libertie breathing her la≈øt,
≈øerued onely ≈øo much the more to inthrall the Crowne, and to make the bondage more grieuous and ≈øen≈øible then before. Euen as tho≈øe medicines which worke no ea≈øe to the patient, doe leaue the di≈øea≈øe in much wor≈øe tearmes: ≈øo this remedy inuented and tendred by the third E≈øtate, did onely exa≈øperate the pre≈øent malady of the State; for ≈øo much as the operation and vertue of the whole≈øome remedy was ouermatched with peccant humours, then ≈øtirred by the force of thwarting and cro≈øsing oppo≈øition. Yea much better had it bene, the matter had not bene ≈øtirred at all, then after it was once on foot and in motion, to giue the Trewth leaue to lye ga≈øping and ≈øprawling vnder the violence of a forraine faction. For the opinion by which the Crownes of Kings are made ≈øubiect vnto the Popes will and power, was then auowed in a mo≈øt Honourable A≈ø≈øembly, by the auerment of a Prelate in great authoritie, and of no le≈ø≈øe learning: He did not plead the cau≈øe as a priuate per≈øon, but as one by repre≈øentation that ≈øtood for the whole body of the Clergie; was there applauded, and ≈øeconded with approbation of the Nobilitie; no re≈øolution taken to the contrary, or in barre to his plea. After prai≈øes and thankes from the Pope, followed the printing of his eloquent harangue or Oration, made in full Parliament: a ≈øet di≈øcour≈øe, maintaining Kings to be depo≈øeable by the Pope, if he ≈øpeake the word. The ≈øaid Oration was not onely Printed with the Kings priuiledge, but was likewi≈øe addre≈ø≈øed to mee by the Author and Orator him≈øelfe; who pre≈øuppo≈øed the reading thereof would for≈øooth driue me to ≈øay, Lord Cardinall, in this high ≈øubiect your Honour hath ≈øatisfied me to the full. All this poy≈øed in the ballance of equall iudgement, why may not J trewly and freely affirme, the ≈øaid E≈øtates a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, haue ≈øet Royall Maie≈øtie vpon a doubtfull chance, or left it re≈øting vpon vncertaine tearmes: and that now if the doctrine there maintained by the Clergie ≈øhould beare any pawme, it may lawfully be doubted, who is King in France? For I make no que≈øtion, hee is but a titular King that raigneth onely at an others di≈øcretion, and who≈øe Princely head the Pope hath power to bare of his Regall Crowne.
In temporall matters, how can one be Soueraigne, that may be fleeced of all his Temporalties by any ≈øuperiour power? But let men at a neere ≈øight marke the pith and marrow of the Article propo≈øed by the third Estate, and they ≈øhall ≈øoone perceiue the skilfull Architects thereof aymed onely to make their King a trew and reall King, to bee recogni≈øed for Soueraigne within his owne Realme, and that killing their King might no longer pa≈ø≈øe the muster of workes acceptable to God.

But by the vehement instance and ≈øtrong current of the Clergie and Nobles, this was borne downe as a pernicious Article, as a cau≈øe of Schi≈øme, as a gate which openeth to all ≈øorts of Here≈øies: yea, there it was maintained tooth and naile, that in ca≈øe the doctrine of this Article might goe for currant doctrine, it mu≈øt follow, that for many aages pa≈øt in ≈øequence, the Church hath beene the kingdome of Antichrist, and the ≈øynagogue of Satan. The Pope vpon ≈øo good i≈ø≈øue of the cau≈øe, had rea≈øon, J trow, to addre≈ø≈øe his Letters of triumph vnto the Nobilitie and Clergie, who had ≈øo farre aprrooued them≈øelues faithfull to his Holine≈ø≈øe; and to vaunt withall, that hee had nipped Christian Kings in the Crowne, that hee had giuen them checke with mate, through the magnanimous re≈øolution of this courageous Nobilitie, by who≈øe braue making head, the third Estate had beene ≈øo valiantly forced to giue ground. Jn a ≈øcornefull reproach hee qualified the Deputies of the third Estate, I haue receiued aduerti≈øement from diuers parts, that in the Popes letters to the Nobitie the≈øe wordes were extant, how≈øoeuer they haue bin left out in the impre≈ø≈øion, & ra≈øed out of the copies of the ≈øaid letters. nebulones ex foece plebis, a ≈øort or a number of knaues, the very dregges of the ba≈øe vulgar, a packe of people, pre≈øuming to per≈øonate well affected Subiects, and men of deepe vnder≈øtanding, and to reade their ma≈øters a learned Lecture. Now it is no wonder, that, in ≈øo good an office and loyall cariage towards their King, the third E≈øtate hath outgone the Clergie. For the Clergie denie them≈øelues to haue any ranke among the Subiects of the King: they ≈øtand for a Soueraigne out of the Kingdome, to whom as to the Lord Paramount they owe ≈øuite and ≈øeruice: they are bound to aduance that Monarchie, to the bodie whereof they properly apperteine as parts or members, as el≈øewhere I haue
written more at large. But for the Nobilitie, the Kings right arme, to prostitute and ≈øet as it were to ≈øale the dignitie of their King, as if the arme ≈øhould giue a thru≈øt vnto the head; J ≈øay for the Nobilitie to hold and maintaine euen in Parliament, their King is liable to depo≈øition by any forreine power or Potentate, may it not pa≈øse among the ≈øtrange≈øt miracles and rare≈øt wonders of the world? For that once granted, this con≈øequence is good and nece≈ø≈øarie; That in ca≈øe the King, once lawfully depo≈øed, ≈øhall ≈øtand vpon the defen≈øiue, and hold out for his right, he may then lawfully be murthered. Let mee then here freely profe≈ø≈øe my opinion, and this it is: That now the French Nobilitie may ≈øeeme to haue ≈øome rea≈øon to di≈ørobe them≈øelues of their titles, and to transferre them by re≈øignation vnto the third E≈øtate. For that body of that third E≈øtate alone hath caried a right noble heart: in as much as the could neither be tickled with promi≈øes, nor terrified by threatnings, from re≈øolute ≈øtanding to tho≈øe fundamentall points and rea≈øons of State, which mo≈øt concerne the honour of their King, and the ≈øecuritie of his per≈øon.

Of all the Clergie, the man that hath most abandoned, or ≈øet his honour to ≈øale, the man to whom France is least obliged, is the Lord Cardinall of Perron: a man otherwi≈øe inferiour to few in matter of learning, and in the grace of a ≈øweete ≈øtyle. This man in two ≈øeuerall Orations, whereof the one was pronounced before the Nobilitie, the other had audience before the third E≈øtate, hath ≈øet his best wits on worke, to draw that doctrine into all hatred and infamie, which teacheth Kings to be indepo≈øeable by the Pope. To this purpo≈øe hee termes the ≈øame doctrine, a breeder of Schi≈ømes, a gate that openeth to make way, and to giue entrance vnto all here≈øies; in briefe, a doctrine to bee held in ≈øo high a degree of dete≈øtation, that rather then he and his fellow-Bi≈øhops will yeeld to the ≈øigning thereof, they will bee contented like Martyrs to burne at a ≈øtake. At which re≈øolution, or ob≈øtinacie rather in his opinion, I am in a manner ama≈øed, more then I can be mooued for the like brauado in many other: fora≈ømuch as hee was many yeeres together, a follower of the late King, euen when
the King followed a contrary Religion, and was depo≈øed by the Pope: as al≈øo becau≈øe not long before, in a certaine A≈ø≈øemblie holden at the Iacobins in Paris, hee with≈øtood the Popes Nuntio to his face, when the ≈øaid Nuntio laboured to make this doctrine, touching the Popes temporall Soueraigntie, pa≈ø≈øe for an Article of Faith. But in both Orations, hee ≈øingeth a contrary ≈øong, and from his owne mouth pa≈øseth ≈øentence of condemnation again≈øt his former cour≈øe and profe≈øsion. J fuppo≈øe, not without ≈øollide iudgemen; as one that heerein hath well accommodated him≈øelfe to the times: For as in the reigne of the late King, hee durst not offer to broach this doctrine (≈øuch was his fore-wit;) ≈øo now he is bold to proclaime and publi≈øh it in Parliament vnder the reigne of the ≈øaid Kings ≈øonne; who≈øe tender yeeres and late ≈øucce≈øsion to the Crowne, doe make him lie the more open to iniuries, and the more facill to be circumuented: Such is now his afterwi≈øedome.

Of the≈øe two Orations, that made in pre≈øence of the Nobilitie he hath, for feare of incurring the Popes di≈øplea≈øure, cautelou≈øly ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed. For therein he hath beene ≈øomewhat prodigall in affirming this doctrine maintained by the Clergie, to bee but problematicall; and in taking vpon him to auouch, that Catholikes of my Kingdome are bound to yeeld me the honour of obedience: Whereas on the other ≈øide, he is not ignorant, how this doctrine of depo≈øing Princes and Kings, the Pope holdeth for meerely nece≈ø≈øarie, and approoueth not by any meanes Alleagiance to bee performed vnto mee by the Catholikes of my Kingdome. Yea if credit may be giuen vnto the abridgement of his other Oration publi≈øhed, wherein he paralells the Popes power in receiuing honours in the name of the Church, with the power of the Venetian Duke in receiuing honours in the name of that mo≈øt renowned Rebublike; no marueile that when this Oration was di≈øpatched to the pre≈ø≈øe, he commanded the ≈øame to be gelded of this clau≈øe and other like, for feare of giuing his Holine≈ø≈øe any offen≈øiue dista≈øte.

His plea≈øure therefore was, and content withall, that his Oration imparted to the third Estate, ≈øhould be put in Print, and of his courte≈øie he vouch≈øafed to addre≈øse vnto me a copie of the ≈øame.
Which after J had peru≈øed, J foorthwith well perceiued, what and how great di≈øcrepance there is betweene one man that perorateth from the ingenuous and ≈øincere di≈øpo≈øition of a ≈øound heart, and an other that flaunteth in flouri≈øhing ≈øpeech with inward checkes of his owne con≈øcience: For euery where he contradicts him≈øelfe, and ≈øeemes to be afraid le≈øt men ≈øhould picke out his right meaning.

First, In 12. ≈øeuerall pa≈ø≈øages the L. Card. ≈øeemeth to ≈øpeake again≈øt his owne con≈øcience. Pag. 85. he grants this Question is not hither to decided by the holy Scriptures, or by the Decrees of the ancient Church, or by the analogie of other Eccle≈øiasticall proceedings: and neuerthele≈øse hee confidently doeth affirme, that who≈øoeuer maintaine this doctrine to be wicked and abhominable, that Popes haue no power to put Kings by their ≈øupreame Thrones, they teach men to beleeue, there hath not bene any Church for many aages past, and that indeed the Church is the very Synagogue of Antichrist.

Secondly, he exhorts his hearers to hold this doctrine at least for problematicall, and not nece≈øsary: and yet herein he calls them to all humble ≈øubmi≈øsion vnto the iudgement of the Pope and Clergie, by whom the cau≈øe hath bene already put out of all question, as out of all hunger and cold.

Thirdly, he doeth auerre, in ca≈øe this Article be authorized, it makes the Pope in good con≈øequence to bee the Antichrist: Pag. 99. and yet he grants that many of the French are tolerated by the Pope to di≈ø≈øent in this point from his Holine≈øse; prouided, their doctrine be not propo≈øed as nece≈ø≈øary, and materiall to faith; As if the Pope in any ≈øort gaue toleration to hold any doctrine contrary to his owne, and mo≈øt of all that doctrine which by con≈øequence inferres him≈øelfe to be the Antichri≈øt.

Fourthly, he prote≈øteth forwardne≈ø≈øe to vndergoe the flames of Martyrdome, rather then to ≈øigne this doctrine, which teacheth Kings Crownes to ≈øit fa≈øter on their heads, then to be ≈øtirred by any Papal power what≈øoeuer: and yet ≈øaith withall, the Pope winketh at the French, by his toleration to hold this dogmaticall point for problematicall. And by this meanes, the Martyrdome that hee affecteth in this cau≈øe, will prooue but a problematicall Martyrdome, whereof que≈øtion might grow very well, whether it were to
be mustered with grieuous crimes, or with phreneticall pa≈øsions of the braine, or with de≈øerued puni≈øhments.

Fiftly, he denounceth Anathema, di≈øchargeth maledictions like haile-≈øhot, again≈øt parricides of Kings: and yet el≈øewhere hee layes him≈øelfe open to ≈øpeake of Kings onely ≈øo long as they ≈øtand Kings. But who doeth not know that a King depo≈øed is no longer King? And ≈øo that limme of Satan, which murthered Henry the III. then vn-king'd by the Pope, did not ≈øtabbe a King to death.
Sixtly, he doeth not allow a King to be made away by murder: and yet he thinks it not much out of the way, to take away al meanes whereby he might be able to ≈øtand in defence of his life.

Seuenthly, Pag. 95.97. hee abhorreth killing of Kings by apposted throatcutting, for feare lest body and ≈øoule ≈øhould peri≈øh in the ≈øame in≈øtant: and yet he doth not mi≈ølike their killing in a pitcht field, and to haue them ≈ølaughtered in a ≈øet battaile: For he pre≈øuppo≈øeth, no doubt out of his charitable mind, that by this meanes the ≈øoule of a poore King ≈øo di≈øpatched out of the way, ≈øhall instantly flie vp to heauen.

Eightly, he ≈øaith a King depo≈øed, retaineth ≈øtil a certaine internal habitude and politike impre≈øsion, by vertue and efficacie whereof he may, being once reformed and become a new man, be restored to the lawfull v≈øe and practi≈øe of Regalitie. Whereby hee would beare vs in hand, that when a forraine Prince hath inuaded and rauenou≈øly ≈øei≈øed the kingdome into his hands, he will not onely take pittie of his predece≈ø≈øour to ≈øaue his life, but will al≈øo proue ≈øo kindhearted, vpon fight of his repentance, to re≈øtore his kingdome without fraud or guile.

Ninthly, he ≈øaith euery where in his Di≈øcour≈øe, that he dealeth not in the cau≈øe, otherwi≈øe then as a problematicall di≈øcour≈øer, and without any re≈øolution one way or other: and yet with might and maine hee contends for the opinion, that leaues the States and Crownes of Kings controulable by the Pope: refutes obiections, propounds the authoritie of Popes and Councils, by name the Lateran Councill vnder Innocent. III. as al≈øo the con≈øent of the Church. And to cro≈ø≈øe the Churches iudgement, is, in his opinion
to bring in ≈øchi≈øme, and to leaue the world without a Church for many hundred yeeres together: which (to my vnderstanding) is to ≈øpeake with re≈øolution, and without all he≈øitation.

Tenthly, he acknowledgeth none other cau≈øe of ≈øufficient validitie for the depo≈øing of a King, be≈øides herefie, aposta≈øie, and infidelitie: neuerthele≈ø≈øe that Popes haue power to di≈øplace Kings for herefie and aposta≈øie, hee proueth by examples of Kings whom the Pope hath curbed with depo≈øition, not for here≈øie, but for matrimoniall cau≈øes, for ciuill pretences, and for lacke of capacitie.

Eleuenthly, hee alledgeth euery where pa≈øsages, as well of holy Scripture, as of the Fathers and moderne hi≈øtories; but ≈øo impertinent, and with ≈øo little trewth, as hereafter wee ≈øhall cau≈øe to appeare, that for a man of his deepe learning and knowledge, it ≈øeemeth not po≈øsible ≈øo to ≈øpeake out of his iudgement.

La≈øtly, whereas all this hath bene hudled and heaped together into one ma≈ø≈øe, to currie with the Pope: yet hee ≈øuffereth diuers points to fall from his lips, which may well dista≈øt his Holine≈ø≈øe in the highest degree. As by name, where he prefers the authoritie of the Councill before that of the Pope, and makes his iudgement inferiour to the iudgement of the French; as in fit place hereafter ≈øhalbe ≈øhewed. Againe, where he repre≈øenteth to his hearers the decrees of Popes and Councils already pa≈ø≈øed concerning this noble ≈øubiect; and yet affirmes that he doth not debate the que≈øtion, but as a Questionist, and without re≈øolution: As if a Cardinal ≈øhould be afraid to be po≈øitiue, and to ≈øpeake in peremptory ≈øtraines, after Popes and Councils haue once decided the Question: Or as if a man ≈øhould perorate vpon hazard, in a cau≈øe for the honour whereof, he would make no difficultie to ≈øuffer Martyrdome. Adde hereunto, that his Lord≈øhip hath alwayes taken the contrary part heretofore, and this totall must needs ari≈øe, that before the third Estate, his lips looked one way, and his con≈øcience another.

J haue no purpo≈øe once to touch many prettie toyes which the ridges of his whole booke are ≈øowen withall: Such are his allegations of Pericles, Age≈øilaus, Ari≈øtotle, Minos, the Druides, the French Ladies, Hannibal, Pindarus, and Poeticall fables: All re≈øembling the red and blew flowers that pester the corne when it ≈øtandeth in the fields, where they are more noy ≈øome to the growing crop, then beautifull to the beholding eye. Such pettie matters, nothing at all be≈øeemed the dignitie of the A≈ø≈øembly, and of the maine ≈øubiect, or of the Orator him≈øelfe: For it was no Decorum to enter the Stage with a Pericles in his mouth, but with the ≈øacred Name of God; nor ≈øhould hee haue mar≈øhalled the pa≈ø≈øage of a Royall
Poet, after the example of an heathen Oratour.

Neither will J giue any touch to his conceit of the Romane conquests, 2 Pag. 4. which the L. Cardinall bestoweth in the list of Gods graces and temporall ble≈øsings, as a recompence of their zeale to the ≈øeruice and wor≈øhip of Idols: As if God were a recompencer of wickednes, or as if the forcible eiecting of Tenants out of their farmes and other po≈ø≈øe≈øsions, might be reckoned among the ble≈ø≈øings of God.

Nor to that of the Mile≈øian ∆≤irgins, Pag. 7. & 8. dragged ≈øtark-naked after they were dead; which the L. Cardinall drawes into his di≈øcour≈øe for an example of the eternall torments denounced by the Lawes Eccle≈øiasticall, to be inflicted after this life.

Nor to his expo≈øition of the word Problematicall; Pag. 13. where he giueth to vnderstand that by Problematicall, hee meaneth ≈øuch things as are of no nece≈øsitie to matter of faith; and in ca≈øe men ≈øhall beleeue the contradictory of the ≈øaid points, they are not bound for ≈øuch beleefe, to vndergoe the ≈øolemne cur≈øe of the Church, and the lo≈øse of communion: Whereas Ari≈øtotle,
Ari≈øtet. 1. top. cap. 4. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øound both one thing, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , prouided the word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or vtr√πm, do ≈øtand before, as, Vtrum homo ≈øit animal. of whom all Schooles haue borrowed their tearmes, hath taught vs that euery propo≈øition is called a Probleme, when it is propounded in a formall doubt, though in it proper nature it containes a nece≈ø≈øary trewth, concerning the matter therof; As for example, to ≈øay in forme of que≈øtion, Whether is there but one God? or, Whether is man a creature indued with rea≈øon? By which examples it is plaine, that propo≈øitions in problematicall forme, doe not forgoe the nece≈ø≈øitie of their nature; and that many times the contradictory binds the beleeuers thereof to Anathema and lo≈ø≈øe of communion. There is a confu≈øed heape or bundle of other like toyes, which my purpo≈øe is to pa≈øse ouer in ≈øilence, that J may now come to cast anchor, as it were in the very bottome and ≈øubstance of the cau≈øe.

div.head: A REMONSTRANCE FOR THE RIGHT OF KINGS, AND THE INDEPENDANCE OF THEIR CROVVNES. Against an Oration of the most Illustrious Cardinall of PERRON, pronounced in the Chamber of the third E≈øtate.
div.p:
THE L. Cardinall euen in the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øage of his Oration, hath laid a firme foundation, That Eccle≈øia≈øtics in France are more deepely obliged to the King, then the Nobilitie, and third Estate: His rea≈øon; Becau≈øe the Clergie doe ≈øweetly enioy their dignities and promotions, with all their infinite wealth, of the Kings meere grace, without all danger, and with faire immunities; whereas the other two Orders hold their offices by a chargeable and burden≈øome title or tenure, euen to the great expence of their blood, and of their ≈øub≈øtance. But ≈øee now, how loo≈øe and weake a frame he hath erected and pinned together, vpon his firme and ≈øolide foundation: Ergo, the third E≈øtate is to lay all care to prouide remedies again≈øt appo≈øted cut-throats, vpon the Clergy; and the ≈øaid remedies (as he boldly affirms) mu≈øt be deriued from the laws of con≈øcience, which may carry an effectuall acting or operatiue efficacie vpon the ≈øoule, and not from ciuil or temporall puni≈øhments. Now this con≈øequence limpeth like a lame creple after the premi≈øes: For it is no v≈øuall and common matter, to ≈øee men that are deepe≈øt in obligation, performe their duties and couenants with mo≈øt fidelity. Againe, were it graunted the Clergie had well hitherto demon≈øtrated their carefull watching ouer the life and honour of their Prince; yet is it not for ≈øpirituall puni≈øhments thundred by Eccle≈øia≈øtics, to bind the hands of the ciuill Magi≈øtrate, nor to ≈øtop the current of temporall
puni≈øhments: which ordinarily doe carrie a greater force and vertue to the bridling of the wicked, then the apprehen≈øion of Gods iudgement.

The third E≈øtate therefore, by whom all the officers of France are properly repre≈øented, as to whom the admini≈øtration of iu≈øtice and protection of the Kings rights and Honour doth appertaine, can de≈øerue no blame in carrying ≈øo watchfull an eye, by their whole≈øome remedie to prouide for the ≈øafetie of the King, and for the dignitie of his Crowne. For if the Clergie ≈øhall not ≈øtand to their tackle, but ≈øhrinke when it commeth to the pu≈øh of their duetie; who ≈øhall charge them≈øelues with carefull fore≈øight and preuention of mi≈øchiefes? Shall not the people? Now, haue not all the calamities, which the third E≈øtate haue ≈øought prouidently to preuent; haue they not all ≈øprung from the Clergie, as from their proper and naturall fountaine? From whence did the la≈øt ciuill warres, wherein a world of blood was not more profu≈øely then prodigiou≈øly and vnnaturally ≈øpilt, and wherein the parricide of King Henrie III. was impiou≈øly and abominably committed: from whence did tho≈øe bloodie warres proceed, but from the depo≈øing of the ≈øaid King by the Head of the Church? Were they not Prelats, Curats, and Confe≈ø≈øours; were they not Eccle≈øia≈øtics, who partly by ≈øeditious preachments, and partly by ≈øecret confe≈ø≈øions, powred many a iarre of oyle vpon this flame? Was not he that killed the forenamed King, was not he one of the Clergie? Was not Guignard a Ie≈øuite? Was not Iohn Chastel brought vp in the ≈øame ≈øchoole? Did not Rauaillac that mon≈øter of men, vpon interrogatories made at his examination; among the re≈øt, by whom he had beene ≈øo diabolically tempted and ≈øtirred vp to his mo≈øt execrable attempt and act of extreme horror: did not he referre his examiners to the Sermons made the Lent next before, where they might be ≈øati≈øfied concerning the cau≈øes of his abominable vndertaking and execution? Are not Bellarmine, Eudaemonoiohannes, Suarez, Becanus, Mariana, with ≈øuch other mon≈øters, who teach the doctrine of parricides, vphold the craft of Ianus-like Equiuocations in Courts of Iu≈øtice, and in ≈øecret confe≈ø≈øions: are they not all Clerics? are not all their bookes approoued and allowed, as it were by a corporation or gro≈ø≈øe companie of Doctors, with their ≈øignes manuel to the ≈øaid bookes? What were the heads, the chiefe promoters, the complices of the powder-con≈øpiracie in my Kingdome? were they not Eccle≈øia≈øtics? Hath not Faux by name, a confederate of the ≈øame damned crew; hath not he ≈øtoutly ≈øtood to the gunners part, which then he was to act in that mo≈øt dolefull Tragedie, with a≈ø≈øeueration of a con≈øcience well a≈ø≈øured and ≈øetled, touching the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of his enterpri≈øe? Did he not yeild this rea≈øon? to wit, becau≈øe he had bin armed with in≈øtruction of musket proofe in the ca≈øe, before he made pa≈ø≈øage ouer from the Low Countries? Is it not al≈øo the generall beleefe of that Order, that Clerics are exempted from the condition of Subiects to the King? Nay, Pag. 7. is it not confe≈ø≈øed by the L. Cardinall him≈øelfe, that King-killers haue ingaged
them≈øelues to vndertake the dete≈øtable act of parricide vnder a fal≈øe credence of Religion, as beeing in≈øtructed by their ≈øchoolema≈øters in Religion? And who were they but Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øons? All this pre≈øuppo≈øed as matter of trewth, I draw this conclu≈øion: How≈øoeuer no ≈ømall number of the French Clergie may perhaps beare the affection of louing Subiects to their King, and may not ≈øuffer the Clericall character to deface the impre≈ø≈øion of naturall allegiance; yet, for ≈øo much as the Order of Clerics is dipped in a deeper die, and beareth a wor≈øe tincture of daungerous practi≈øes then the other Orders; the third E≈øtate had beene greatly wanting to their excellent prouidence and wi≈øedome, if they ≈øhould haue relinqui≈øhed and transferred the care of de≈øignements and proiects for the life of their King, and the ≈øafety of his Crowne, to the Clergiealone. Moreouer, the Clergie ≈øtandeth bound to referre the iudgement of all matters in controuer≈øie, to the ≈øentence of the Pope, in this cau≈øe beeing a partie, and one that pretendeth Crownes to depend vpon his Mitre. What hope then might the third E≈øtate conceiue, that his Holine≈ø≈øe would pa≈ø≈øe again≈øt his owne cau≈øe, when his iudgement of the controuer≈øie had beene ≈øundrie times before publi≈øhed and te≈øtified to the world? And whereas the plot or modell of remedies proiected by the third E≈øtate, and the Kings Officers, hath not prooued ≈øortable in the euent: was it becau≈øe the ≈øaid remedies were not good and lawfull? No verily: but becau≈øe the Clergie refu≈øed to become contributors of their duty and meanes to the grand ≈øeruice. Likewi≈øe, for that after the burning of bookes, addre≈ø≈øed to iu≈øtifie rebellious people, traytors, and parricides of Kings; neuerthele≈ø≈øe the authors of the ≈øaid bookes are winked at, and backt with fauour. La≈øtly, for that ≈øome wretched parricides drinke off the cuppe of publike iu≈øtice; whereas to the firebrands of ≈øedition, the ≈øowers of this abominable doctrine, no man ≈øaith ≈øo much as blacke is their eye.

It ≈øufficiently appeareth, as I ≈øupo≈øe, by the former pa≈ø≈øage, that his Lord≈øhip exhorting the third E≈øtate to referre the whole care of this Regall cau≈øe vnto the Clergie, hath tacked his frame of weake ioynts and tenons to a very worthy but wrong foundation. Page 9. Howbeit, he laboureth to fortifie his exhortation with a more weake and feeble rea≈øon: For to make good his proiect he affirmes, that matters and maximes out of all doubt and que≈øtion, may not be ≈øhuffled together with points in controuer≈øie. Now his rules indubitable are two: The fir≈øt, It is not lawfull to murther Kings for any cau≈øe what≈øoeuer: This he confirmeth by the example of Saul (as he ≈øaith) depo≈øed from his Throne, who≈øe life or limbs Dauid neuerthele≈ø≈øe dur≈øt not once hurt or wrong for his life:
Conc. Con≈øtan. Se≈ø≈ø. 15. Likewi≈øe he confirmes the ≈øame by a Decree of the Councill held at Con≈øtance: His other point indubitable; The Kings of France are Soueraignes in all Temporall Soueraigntie, within the French Kingdome, and hold not by fealtie either of the Pope, as hauing receiued or obliged their Crownes vpon ≈øuch tenure and condition, or of any other Prince in the whole world; Which point,
neuerthele≈ø≈øe he takes not for certaine and indubitable, but onely according to humane and hi≈øtoricall certaintie. Now a third point he makes to be ≈øo full of controuer≈øie, and ≈øo farre within the circle of di≈øputable que≈øtions, as it may not be drawne into the ranke of cla≈ø≈øicall and authenticall points, for feare of making a certaine point doubtfull, by ≈øhuffling and iumbling therewith ≈øome point in controuer≈øie. Now the que≈øtion ≈øo di≈øputable, as he pretendeth, is this: A Chri≈øtian Prince breakes his oath ≈øolemnely taken to God, both to liue and to die in the Catholique Religion: Say this Prince turnes Arrian, or Mahometan, fals to proclaime open warre, and to wage battell with Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: Whether may ≈øuch a Prince be declared to haue lo≈øt his Kingdome, and who ≈øhall declare the Subiects of ≈øuch a Prince to be quit of their oath of allegiance? The L. Cardinall holds the affirmatiue, and makes no bones to maintaine, that all other parts of the Catholique Church, yea the French Church, euen from the fir≈øt birth of her Theologicall Schooles, to Caluins time and teaching, haue profe≈ø≈øed that ≈øuch a Prince may bee lawfully remooued from his Throne by the Pope, and by the Councill: and ≈øuppo≈øe the contrarie doctrine were the very Quinte≈ø≈øence or ≈øpirit of trewth, yet might it not in ca≈øe of faith be vrged and pre≈ø≈øed otherwi≈øe then by way of problematicall di≈øceptation. That is the ≈øumme of his Lord≈øhips ample di≈øcour≈øe: The refuting whereof I am con≈øtrained to put off, and referre vnto an other place; becau≈øe he hath ≈øerued vs with the ≈øame di≈øhes ouer and ouer againe. There we ≈øhall ≈øee the L. Cardinall maketh way to the di≈øpatching of Kings after depo≈øition: that Saul was not depo≈øed, as he hath pre≈øumed: that in the Councill of Con≈øtance there is nothing to the purpo≈øe of murthering Soueraigne Princes: that his Lord≈øhip, ≈øuppo≈øing the French King may be depriued of his Crowne by a ≈øuperiour power, doth not hold his liege Lord to be Soueraine in France: that by the po≈øition of the French Church from aage to aage, the Kings of France are not ≈øubiect vnto any cen≈øure of depo≈øition by the Pope: that his Holine≈ø≈øe hath no iu≈øt and lawfull pretence to produce, that any Chri≈øtian King holds of him by fealtie, or is obliged to doe the Pope homage for his Crowne.

Well then, for the purpo≈øe; he dwelleth onely vpon the third point pretended que≈øtionable, and this hee affirmeth: If any ≈øhall condemne, or wrappe vnder the ≈øolemne cur≈øe, the abettours of the Popes power to vnking lawfull and Soueraigne Kings; the ≈øame ≈øhall runne vpon foure dangerous rocks of apparent incongruities and ab≈øurdities.

Fir≈øt, he ≈øhall offer to force and entangle the con≈øciences of many deuout per≈øons: For he ≈øhall binde them to beleeue and ≈øweare that doctrine,
Pag. 14. the contrary whereof is beleeued of the whole Church, and hath bene beleeued by their Predece≈ø≈øors.

q.p:
Secondly, he ≈øhall ouerturne from top to bottome the ≈øacred authoritie of holy Church, and ≈øhall ≈øet open a gate vnto all ≈øorts of here≈øie, by allowing Lay-per≈øons a bold libertie to be iudges in cau≈øes of Religion and
Faith: For what is that degree of boldne≈ø≈øe, but open v≈øurping of the Prie≈øthood; what is it but putting of prophane hands vpon the Arke; what is it but laying of vnholy fingers vpon the holy Cen≈øor for perfumes?

Thirdly, hee ≈øhall make way to a Schi≈øme, not po≈ø≈øible to bee put by and auoyded by any humane prouidence. For this doctrine beeing held and profe≈ø≈øed by all other Catholiques; how can we declare it repugnant vnto Gods word; how can wee hold it impious; how can wee account it dete≈øtable, but wee ≈øhall renounce communion with the Head and other members of the Church; yea, we ≈øhall confe≈ø≈øe the Church in all aages to haue bene the Synagogue of Satan, and the ≈øpou≈øe of the Deuill?

La≈øtly, by working the e≈øtabli≈øhment of this Article, which worketh an e≈øtabli≈øhment of Kings Crownes; He ≈øhall not onely worke the intended remedy for the danger of Kings, out of all the vertue and efficacie thereof, by weakening of doctrine out of all controuer≈øie, in packing it vp with a di≈øputable que≈øtion; but likewi≈øe in ≈øtead of ≈øecuring the life and e≈øtate of Kings, he ≈øhall draw both into farre greater hazards, by the traine or ≈øequence of warres, and other calamities, which v≈øually waite and attend on Schi≈ømes.

div.p:
The L. Cardinall ≈øpends his whole di≈øcour≈øe in confirmation of the≈øe foure heads, which wee now intend to ≈øift in order, and demon≈øtratiuely to prooue that all the ≈øaid inconueniences are meere nullities, matters of imagination, and built vpon fal≈øe pre≈øuppo≈øitions. But before wee come to the maine, the reader is to be enformed and aduerti≈øed, that his Lord≈øhip ≈øetteth a fal≈øe glo≈ø≈øe vpon the que≈øtion; and propounds the ca≈øe not onely contrary to the trewth of the ≈øubiect in controuer≈øie, but al≈øo to the Popes owne minde and meaning: For he re≈øtraines the Popes power to depo≈øe Kings, onely to ca≈øes of Here≈øie, Apo≈øta≈øie, and per≈øecuting of the Church; whereas Popes extend their power to a further di≈øtance. They depo≈øe Princes for infringing, or in any ≈øort dimini≈øhing the Priuiledges of Mona≈øteries: witne≈ø≈øe Gregorie the fir≈øt in the pretended Charter granted to the Abbey of S. Medard at Soi≈ø≈øons; the ≈øaid Charter beeing annexed to his Epi≈øtles in the rere. The ≈øame hee te≈øtifieth in his Epi≈øtle to Senator, by name the tenth of the eleuenth booke. They depo≈øe for naturall dulne≈ø≈øe and lacke of capacitie, wether in-bred and trew indeed, or onely pretended and imagined: witne≈ø≈øe the glorious vaunt of Gregory VII. that Childeric King of France was hoy≈øted out of his Throne by Pope Zachary,
Cau≈ø. 15. Can. Alius. Qu. 6. Not ≈øo much for his wicked life, as for his vnablene≈ø≈øe to beare the weightie burden of ≈øo great a Kingdome. They depo≈øe for collating of Benefices and Prebends: witne≈ø≈øe the great quarrels and ≈øore contentions betweene Pope Innocent III. and Iohn King of England: as al≈øo betweene Philip the Faire and Boniface VIII. They depo≈øe for adulteries and Matrimoniall ≈øuites: witnes Philip I. for the repudiating or ca≈øting off his lawfull wife Bertha, and marrying in her place with Bertrade wife to the Earle of Aniou.
Paul. Aemil. in Phil. 3. Finally, faine would I learne into what Here≈øie or degree of Apo≈øta≈øie, either
Henry IV. or Frederic Barbaro≈ø≈øa, or Frederic II. Emperours were fallen, when they were ≈ømitten with Papall fulminations, euen to the depriuation of their Imperiall Thrones. What? was it for Here≈øie or Apo≈øta≈øie, that Pope Martin IV. bare ≈øo hard a hand again≈øt Peter King of Arragon, that he acquitted and relea≈øed the Aragonnois from their oath of Alleagiance to Peter their lawfull King? Was it for Here≈øie or Apo≈øta≈øie, for Arriani≈øme or Mahumeti≈øme, that Lewis XII. ≈øo good a King and Father of his Countrey, was put downe by Iulius the II? Was it for Here≈øie or Apo≈øta≈øie, that Sixtus V. v≈øurped a power again≈øt Henrie III. euen ≈øo farre as to denounce him vnkingd; the i≈ø≈øue whereof was the parricide of that good King, and the mo≈øt wofull de≈øolation of a mo≈øt flouri≈øhing Kingdome? But his Lord≈øhip be≈øt liked to worke vpon that ground, which to the outward ≈øhew and appearance, is the mo≈øt beautifull cau≈øe that can be alleaged for the di≈øhonouring of Kings by the weapon of depo≈øition: making him≈øelfe to beleeue that he acted the part of an Orator before per≈øonages not much acquainted with ancient and moderne hi≈øtories, and ≈øuch as little vnder≈øtood the ≈øtate of the que≈øtion then in hand. It had therefore beene a good warrant for his Lord≈øhip, to haue brought ≈øome authenticall in≈øtrument from the Pope, whereby the French might haue beene ≈øecured, that his Holine≈ø≈øe renounceth all other cau≈øes auouchable for the degrading of Kings; and that he will henceforth re≈øt in the ca≈øe of Here≈øie, for the turning of Kings out of their Free-hold: as al≈øo that his Holine≈ø≈øe by the ≈øame or like in≈øtrument might haue certified his plea≈øure, that hee will not hereafter make him≈øelfe Iudge, whether Kings bee tainted with damnable Here≈øie, or free from Hereticall infection. For that were to make him≈øelfe both Iudge and Plaintiffe, that it might be in his power to call that doctrine Hereticall, which is pure Orthodoxe: and all for this end, to make him≈øelfe ma≈øter of the Kingdome, and there to ≈øettle a Succe≈ø≈øour, who receiuing the Crowne of the Popes free gift and grant, might be tyed thereby to depend altogether vpon his Holine≈ø≈øe. Hath not Pope Boniface VIII. declared in his proud Letters all tho≈øe to be Heretiques, that dare vndertake to affirme, the collating of Prebends appertemeth to the King? It was that Popes gro≈ø≈øe errour, not in the fact, but in the right. The like crime for≈øooth was by Popes imputed to the vnhappy Emperour Henrie IV. And what was the i≈ø≈øue of the ≈øaid imputation? The ≈øonne is in≈øtigated thereby to rebell again≈øt his father, and to impeach the interrement of his dead corps, who neuer in his life had beate his braines to trouble the ≈øweet waters of Theologicall fountaines.

The Bull Exurge, marching in the rere of the la≈øt Lateran Councel, ≈øets downe this Po≈øition for one of Luthers here≈øies, A new life is the be≈øt repentance.
Optima poenitentia noua vita. Conc. Con≈øtan. Se≈ø≈ø. 2. Among the crimes which the Councel of Con≈øtance charged Pope Iohn XXIII. withall, one was this, that hee denied the immortalitie of the ≈øoule, and that ≈øo much was publiquely,
manifestly, and notoriou≈øly knowen. Now if the Pope ≈øhall be caried by the ≈øtreame of the≈øe or the like errours, and in his Hereticall prauitie ≈øhall depo≈øe a King of the contrary opinion, I ≈øhall hardly bee per≈øwaded, the ≈øaid King is lawfully depo≈øed.

div.head: THE FIRST INCONVENIENCE EXAMINED.
div.p: THE fir≈øt inconuenience growing (in the Cardinall his conceit) by entertaining the Article of the third E≈øtate (whereby the Kings of France are declared to be indepo≈øeable by any ≈øuperiour power ≈øpirituall or temporall) is this: It offereth force to the con≈øcience, vnder the penaltie of Anathema, to condemne a doctrine beleeued and practi≈øed in the Church, in the continuall current of the la≈øt eleuen hundred yeeres. In the≈øe words he maketh a ≈øecret confe≈ø≈øion, that in the fir≈øt fiue hundred yeeres, the ≈øame doctrine was neither apprehended by faith, nor approoued by practi≈øe. Wherein, to my vnder≈øtanding, the L. Cardinall voluntarily giueth ouer the ≈øuite: For the Church in the time of the Apo≈øtles, their di≈øciples, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, for 500. yeeres together, was no more ignorant what authoritie the Church is to challenge ouer Emperours and Kings, then at any time ≈øince in any ≈øucceeding aage; in which as pride hath ≈øtill flowed to the height of a full Sea, ≈øo puritie of religion and manners hath kept for the mo≈øt part at a lowe water marke. Which point is the rather to be con≈øidered, for that during the fir≈øt 500. yeeres, the Church groned vnder the heauy burthen, both of heathen Emperours, and of hereticall Kings; the Vi≈øigot Kings in Spaine, and the Vandals in Affrica. Of who≈øe di≈øplea≈øure the Pope had ≈ømall rea≈øon or cau≈øe to ≈øtand in any feare, beeing ≈øo remote from their dominions, and no way vnder the lee of their Soueraigntie.

But let vs come to ≈øee, what aide the L. Cardinall hath ama≈ø≈øed and piled together out of latter hi≈øtories: prouided wee ≈øtill beare in mind, that our que≈øtion is not of popular tumults, nor of the rebellion of ≈øubiects making in≈øurrections out of their owne di≈øcontented ≈øpirits and braine≈øicke humors, nor of lawfull Excommunications, nor of Canonicall cen≈øures and reprehen≈øions; but onely of a iuridicall ≈øentence of depo≈øition, pronounced by the Pope, as armed with ordinary and lawfull power to depo≈øe, again≈øt a Soueraigne Prince.

Now then,
Exampl. 1. pag. 18 Enag hi≈øt Eccle≈ø. lib. 3. cap. 32. The L. Cardinall ≈øets on, and giues the fir≈øt charge with Anasta≈øius the Emperour, whom Euphemius Patriarke of Con≈øtantinople would neuer acknowledge for Emperour: (that is to ≈øay, would neuer con≈øent he ≈øhould be created Emperour by the helpe of his voice or ≈øuffrage) except he would fir≈øt ≈øub≈øcribe to the Chalcedon Creed: notwith≈øtanding
the great Empre≈ø≈øe and Senate ≈øought by violent cour≈øes and practi≈øes to make him yeeld. And when afterward the ≈øaid Emperour, contrary to his oath taken, played the relaps by falling into his former here≈øie, and became a per≈øecutor; he was fir≈øt admoni≈øhed, and then excommunicated by Symmachus Bi≈øhop of Rome. To this the L. Cardinall addes, that when the ≈øaid Emperour was minded to choppe the poi≈øon of his hereticall a≈ø≈øertions into the publique formes of diuine ≈øeruice, then the people of Con≈øtantinople made an vproare again≈øt Anasta≈øius their Emperour; and one of his Commanders by force of armes, con≈øtrained him to call backe certaine Bi≈øhops whom he had ≈øent into bani≈øhment before.

In this fir≈øt example the L. Cardinall by his good leaue, neither comes clo≈øe to the que≈øtion, nor falutes it a farre off. Euphemius was not Bi≈øhop of Rome: Anasta≈øius was not depo≈øed by Euphemius; the Patriarch onely made no way to the creating of Ana≈øta≈øius. The ≈øuddaine commotion of the ba≈øe multitude makes nothing, the rebellion of a Greeke Commaunder makes le≈ø≈øe, for the authorizing of the Pope to depo≈øe a Soueraigne Prince. The Greeke Emperour was excommunicated by Pope Symmachus: who knowes whether that be trew or forged? For the Pope him≈øelfe is the onely witne≈ø≈øe here produced by the L. Cardinall vpon the point: and who knowes not how fal≈øe, how ≈øuppo≈øitious, the writings and Epi≈øtles of the auncient Popes are iu≈øtly e≈øteemmed? But graunt it a trewth; yet Ana≈øta ≈øius excommunicated by Pope Symmachus, is not Anasta≈øius depo≈øed by Pope Symmachus. And to make a full an≈øwere, I ≈øay further, that excommunication denounced by a forraine Bi≈øhop, again≈øta party not beeing within the limits of his iuri≈ødiction, or one of his owne flocke, was not any barre to the party from the communion of the Church, but onely a kind of publication, that he the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop in his particular, would hold no further communion with any ≈øuch party.

For proofe whereof, I produce the Canons of the Councils held at Carthage. In one of the ≈øaid Canons it is thus prouided and ordained;
Nomecan. Affric Can. 77. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
If any Bi≈øhop ≈øhall wilfully ab≈øent him≈øelfe from the v≈øuall and accu≈øtomed Synodes, let him not be admitted to the communion of other Churches, but let him onely v≈øe the benefit and libertie of his owne Church. In an other of the ≈øame Canons thus;
Can. 81. eiu≈ød. Nomo.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
If a Bi≈øhop ≈øhall in≈øinuate him≈øelfe to make a conuciance of his Mona≈øterie, and the ordering thereof vnto a Monke of any other Cloi≈øter; let him be cut off, let him be ≈øeparated from the communion with other Churches and content him≈øelfe to liue in the communion of his owne flocke. In the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe Hilarius Bi≈øhop of Poictiers excommunicated Liberius Bi≈øhop of Rome, for ≈øub≈øcribing to the Arrian Confe≈ø≈øion. Anathematibi √† me Liberi. Faber in frag. Hilarij. In the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, Iohn Bi≈øhop of Antioch excommunicated Caele≈øtine of Rome, and Cyrill of Alexandria, Bi≈øhops; for proceeding to ≈øentence again≈øt Ne≈øtorius, without ≈øtaying his comming to an≈øwere in his owne cau≈øe. In the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe likewi≈øe, Victor Bi≈øhop of Rome did cut off all the Bi≈øhops of the Ea≈øt, not from the communion of their owne flocks, but from communion
with Victor and the Romane Church. What re≈øemblance, what agreement, what proportion, betweene this cour≈øe of excommunication, and that way of vniu≈øt fulmination which the Popes of Rome haue v≈øurped again≈øt Kings,
Examp. 2. but yet certaine long cour≈øes of time after that auncient cour≈øe?

And this may ≈øtand for a full an≈øwere likewi≈øe to the example of Clotharius. This ancient King of the French, fearing the cen≈øures of Pope Agapetus, erected the Territorie of Yuetor vnto the title of a Kingdome, by way of ≈øatisfaction for murdering of Gualter, Lord of Yuetot. For this example the L. Cardinall hath ran≈øackt records of 900. yeeres antiquitie and vpward; in which times it were no hard piece of worke to ≈øhew, that Popes would not haue any hand, nor ≈øo much as a finger in the affaires and acts of the French Kings. Gregorie of Tours that liued in the ≈øame aage, hath recorded many acts of exce≈ø≈øe, and violent iniuries done again≈øt Bi≈øhops by their Kings, and namely again≈øt Praetextatus Bi≈øhop of Roan; for any of which iniurious prankes then played, the Bi≈øhop of Rome dur≈øt not reprooue the ≈øaid Kings with due remon≈øtrance. But ≈øee heere the words of Gregorie him≈øelfe to King Chilperic: If any of vs, O King, ≈øhall ≈øwarue from the path of Iu≈øtice, him ha≈øt thou power to puni≈øh: But in ca≈øe thou ≈øhalt at any time tran≈øgre≈øse the lines of equitie, who ≈øhall once touch thee with reproofe? To thee wee ≈øpeake, but are neuer heeded and regarded, except it be thy plea≈øure: and bee thou not plea≈øed, who ≈øhall challenge thy greatne≈øse, but hee that iustly challengeth to bee Iustice it ≈øelfe? The good Bi≈øhop, notwith≈øtanding the≈øe humble remon≈øtrances, was but roughly entreated, and packt into exile, being bani≈øhed into the I≈øle of Guern≈øay. But I am not minded to make any deepe ≈øearch or inqui≈øition, into the titles of the Lords of Yuetot; who≈øe honourable priuiledges and titles are the mo≈øt honourable badges and cognizances of their Ance≈øtours, and of ≈øome remarkeable ≈øeruice done to the Crowne of France: ≈øo farre I take them to differ from a ≈øatisfaction for ≈øinne: And for the purpo≈øe I onely affirme, that were the credit of this hi≈øtorie beyond all exception, yet makes it nothing to the pre≈øent que≈øtion, Wherein the power of depo≈øing, and not of excommunicating ≈øupreme Kings, is debated. And ≈øuppo≈øe the King by Charter granted the ≈øaid priuiledges for feare of Excommunication; how is it prooued thereby, that Pope Agapetus had lawfull and ordinary power to depriue him of his Crowne? Nay, doubtle≈ø≈øe it was rather a meanes to eleuate and aduance the dignitie of the Crowne of France, and to ≈øtyle the French King, a King of Kings, as one that was able to giue the qualitie of King, to all the re≈øt of the Nobles and Gentry of his Kingdome. Doeth not ≈øome part of the Spani≈øh Kings greatne≈ø≈øe, con≈øi≈øt in creating of his, great?

In the next place followeth Gregorie I.
Examp. 3. pag. 22. who in the 10. Epi≈øtle of the 11. booke, confirming the priuiledges of the Ho≈øpitall at Augustodunum in Bourgongne, prohibiteth all Kings and Prelates what≈øoeuer, to infringe or dimini≈øh the ≈øaid priuiledges, in whole or in part. His formall and expre≈ø≈øe
words bee the≈øe: If any King, Prelate, Iudge, or any other Secular per≈øon, informed of this our Con≈øtitution, ≈øhall pre≈øume to goe or doe contrary thereunto, let him bee cast downe from his power and dignitie. I an≈øwere; the Lord Cardinall heere wrongs him≈øel≈øe very much, in taking imprecations for Decrees. Might not euen the meane≈øt of the people v≈øe the ≈øame tenour of words, and ≈øay? If any ≈øhall touch the life, or the mo≈øt ≈øacred Maie≈øtie of our Kings, be he Emperour, or be he Pope, let him bee accur≈øed; let him fall from his eminent place of authoritie; let him lo≈øe his dignitie; let him tumble into beggerie, di≈øea≈øes, and all kindes of calamities? I forbeare to ≈øhew how ea≈øie a matter it is for Monkes, to forge titles after their owne humour, and to their owne liking, for the vpholding and maintaining of their priuiledges. As for the purpo≈øe, the ≈øame Gregorie citeth in the end of his Epi≈øtles another priuiledge, of the like ≈øtuffe and ≈øtampe to the former, granted to the Abbey of S. Medard at Soi≈ø≈øons: It is fenced with a like clau≈øe to the other; But of how great vntrewth, and of how little weight it is, the very date that it beareth, makes manife≈øt proofe: For it runs, Dated the yeere of our Lords Incarnation 593. the 11. Indiction; whereas the 10. Indiction agreeth to the yeere 593. Be≈øides, it was not Gregories maner to date his Epi≈øtles according to the yeere of the Lord. Againe, the ≈øaid priuiledge was ≈øigned by the Bi≈øhops of Alexandria and Carthage, who neuer knew (as may well bee thought) whether any ≈øuch Abbey of S. Medard, or citie of Soi≈ø≈øons, was euer built in the world. Moreouer, they ≈øigned in the thicke≈øt of a crowd as it were of Italian Bi≈øhops. La≈øtly, hee that ≈øhall reade in this Gregories Epi≈øtles, with what ≈øpirit of reuerence and humilitie he ≈øpeaketh of Emperours, will hardly beleeue that euer hee armed him≈øelfe with authoritie to giue or to take away Kingdomes. Hee ≈øtyles him≈øelfe
Epi≈øt. 6. l. 3. Ego antem indignus pietatin tuae ≈øeruils. Ego ver√≤ haec Dominis meis Ioquens, quid ≈øum ni≈øi pulu is & vermis? Ibid. Egc quidem iu≈ø≈øioni ≈øubiectus, &c. Epi≈øt. 61. l. 2. The Emperours vnworthie ≈øeruant: pre≈øuming to ≈øpeake vnto his Lord, when he knowes him≈øelfe to bee but dust and a very worme: Hee profe≈ø≈øeth ≈øubiection vnto the Emperours commands, euen to the publi≈øhing of a certaine Law of the Emperours, which in his iudgement ≈øomewhat iarred and iu≈øtled with Gods Law; as el≈øewhere I haue ≈øpoken more at large.

The L. Cardinall next bringeth vpon the ≈øtage Iustinian II. Hee,
Examp. 4. being in ≈øome choller with Sergius Bi≈øhop of Rome, becau≈øe hee would not fauour the erroneous Synode of Con≈øtantinople, would haue cau≈øed the Bi≈øhop to bee apprehended by his Con≈øtable Zacharias.
