And indeed when di≈ø≈øimulation on the one ≈øide, and ≈øedition on the other, had ≈øugge≈øted the deui≈øes of two contrary extremes, hee brings foorth Di≈øcretion as a Iudge, keeping the meane betweene both extremes, and vttering tho≈øe words which the L. Cardinall alledgeth again≈øt him≈øelfe. If the head, (≈øaith Ger≈øon) or ≈øome other member of the ciuill body, ≈øhould grow to ≈øo desperate a pa≈ø≈øe, that it would gulpe and ≈øwallow downe the deadly poy≈øon of tyrannie; euery member in his place, with all power po≈øsible for him to rai≈øe by expedient meanes, and ≈øuch as might preuent a greater inconuenience, ≈øhould ≈øet him≈øelfe again≈øt ≈øo madde a purpo≈øe, and ≈øo deadly practi≈øe: For if the head be grieued with ≈øome light paine, it is not fit for the hand to ≈ømite the head: no that were but a fooli≈øh and a mad part: Nor is the hand forthwith to chop off or ≈øeparate the head from the body, but rather to cure the head with good ≈øpeach and other meanes, like a skilfull and wi≈øe Phy≈øitian: Yea nothing would be more cruel or more voyd of rea≈øon, then to ≈øeeke to ≈øtop the ≈øtrong and violent ≈øtreame of tyrannie by ≈øedition. The≈øe words, me thinke, doe make very ≈øtrongly and expre≈øly again≈øt butchering euen of Tyrannical Kings. And whereas a little after the ≈øaid pa≈ø≈øage, he teacheth to expell Tyrannie, he hath not a word of expelling the Tyrant, but onely of breaking and ≈øhaking off the yoke of Tyrannie. Yet for all that, he would not haue the remedies for the repre≈ø≈øing of Tyrannie, to be fetcht from the Pope, who pre≈øumeth to degrade Kings, but from Philo≈øophers, Lawyers, Diuines, and per≈øonages of good conuer≈øation. It appeareth now by all that hath bin ≈øaid before, that whereas Ger≈øon in the 7. Con≈øiderat. again≈øt Flatterers, doeth affirme:
When≈øoeuer the Prince doeth manifestly pur≈øue and pro≈øecute his naturall ≈øubiects, and ≈øhew him≈øelfe obstinately bent with notorious iniu≈øtice, to vexe them of ≈øet purpo≈øe, and with full con≈øent, ≈øo farre as to the fact; then this rule and law of Nature doeth take place, It is lawfull to re≈øist and repell force by force; and the ≈øentence of Seneca, There is no ≈øacrifice more acceptable to God, then a tyrant offered in ≈øacrifice; the words, doeth take place, are ≈øo to be vnder≈øtood, as he ≈øpeaketh in another pa≈ø≈øage, to wit, with or among≈øt ≈øeditious per≈øons. Or el≈øe the words, doeth take place, doe onely ≈øignifie, is put in practi≈øe. And ≈øo Ger≈øon there ≈øpeaketh not as out of his owne iudgement.

His Lord≈øhip al≈øo ≈øhould not haue balked and left out Sigebertus, who with more rea≈øon might haue pa≈ø≈øed for French, then Thomas and Occam, whom hee putteth vpon vs for French. Sigebertus in his Chronicle vpon the yeere 1088. ≈øpeaking of the Emperours depo≈øing by the Pope, hath words of this tenour: This Here≈øie was not crept out of the ≈øhell in tho≈øe dayes, that his Prie≈øts, who hath ≈øaid to the King Apo≈øtata, and maketh an hypocrite to rule for the ≈øinnes of the people, ≈øhould teach the people they owe no ≈øubiection vnto wicked Kings, nor any alleagiance, notwithstanding they haue taken the oath of alleagiance.

Now after the L. Cardinal hath cour≈øed in this maner through the hi≈øtories of the la≈øt aages (which in ca≈øe they all made for his purpo≈øe, doe lacke the weight of authority) in ≈øtead of ≈øearching the will of God in the ≈øacred Oracles of his word and ≈øtanding vpon examples of the ancient Church; at la≈øt, leauing the troupe of his owne allegations, he betakes him≈øelfe to the ≈øharpening and rebating of the points of his aduer≈øaries weapons.

For the purpo≈øe, he brings in his aduer≈øaries, the champions of Kings Crownes, & makes them to ≈øpeake out of his own mouth (for his Lord≈øhip ≈øaith it will be obiected) after this maner:
Pag. 52. & ≈øequentibus.
It may come to pa≈øse, that Popes either
caried with pa≈øsion, or mi≈øled by ≈øini≈øter information, may without iu≈øt cau≈øe fasten vpon Kings the imputation of here≈øie or aposta≈øie. Then for King-depo≈øers he frames this an≈øwere: That by here≈øie they vnder≈øtand notorious here≈øie, and formerly condemned by ≈øentence of the Church. Moreouer, in ca≈øe the Pope hath erred in the fact, it is the Clergies part adhering to their King, to make remon≈øtrances vnto the Pope, and to require the cau≈øe may be referred to the iudgement of a full Councel, the French Church then and there being pre≈øent. Now in this an≈øwere, the L. Cardinall is of another mind then Bellarmine his brother Cardinall: Aduer≈ø. Barclaium. For hee goes thus farre, That a Prince condemned by vniu≈øt ≈øentence of the Pope, ought neuerthele≈ø≈øe to quit his Kingdome, and that his Pa≈øtors vniu≈øt ≈øentence ≈øhall not redound to his detriment; prouided that hee giue way to the ≈øaid ≈øentence, and ≈øhew him≈øelfe not refractarie, but ≈øtay the time in patience, vntil the holy Father ≈øhall renounce his error, and reuoke his fore≈øaid vniu≈øt ≈øentence. In which ca≈øe the≈øe two material points are to be pre≈øuppo≈øed: The one, That he who now hath ≈øeized the kingdome of the Prince di≈øplaced, wil forthwith (if the Pope ≈øhall ≈øollicit and intercede) returne the Kingdome to the hand of the late po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor: The other, That in
the interim the Prince vniu≈øtly depo≈øed, ≈øhall not need to feare the bloody murderers mercile≈ø≈øe blade and weapon. But on the other ≈øide, the Popes power of ≈øo large a ≈øize, as Bellarmine hath ≈øhaped, is no whit plea≈øing to the L. Cardinals eye. For in ca≈øe the King ≈øhould be vniu≈øtly depo≈øed by the Pope not well informed, he is not of the minde the Kingdome ≈øhould ≈øtoupe to the Popes behe≈øts, but will rather haue the Kingdome to deale by remon≈øtrance, and to referre the cau≈øe vnto the Council: Wherein he makes the Council to be of more ab≈øolute and ≈øupreme authority then the Pope; a ≈øtraine to which the holy father will neuer lend his eare. And yet doubtle≈ø≈øe, the Council required in this ca≈øe mu≈øt be vniuer≈øall; wherein the French, for ≈øo much as they ≈øtand firme for the King and his cau≈øe, can be no Iudges: and in that regard the L. Cardinal requireth onely the pre≈øence of the French Church. Who ≈øeeth not here into what pickle the French cau≈øe is brought by this meanes? The Bi≈øhops of Italie for≈øooth, of Spaine, of Sicilie, of Germanie, the ≈øubiects of Soueraignes many times at profe≈ø≈øed or priuie enmitie with France, ≈øhall haue the cau≈øe compremitted and referred to their iudgement, whether the Kindome of France ≈øhall driue out her Kings, and ≈øhall kindle the flames of ≈øeditious troubles, in the very heart and bowels of the Realme. But is it not po≈ø≈øible, that a King may lacke the loue of his owne ≈øubiects, and they taking the vantage of that occa≈øion, may put him to his trumps in his owne Kingdome? Is it not po≈ø≈øible, that calumniations whereby a credulous Pope hath beene ≈øeduced, may in like maner deceiue ≈øome part of a credulous people? Is it not po≈ø≈øible that one part of the people may cleaue to the Popes Faction, another may hold and ≈øtand out for the Kings rightfull cau≈øe, and ciuill warres may be kindled by the ≈øplene of the≈øe two ≈øides? Is it not po≈ø≈øible, that his Holine≈ø≈øe will not re≈øt in the remon≈øtrances of the French, and will no further pur≈øue his cau≈øe? And whereas now a dayes a Generall Councill cannot be held, except it be called and a≈ø≈øembled by the Popes authority; is it credible, the Pope will take order for the conuocation of a Council, by whom he ≈øhall be iudged? And how can the Pope be Pre≈øident in a Councill, where him≈øelfe is the party impleaded? and to whom the ≈øifting of his owne ≈øentence is referred, as it were to Committies, to examine whether it was denounced according to Law, or again≈øt Iu≈øtice? But in the meane time, while≈øt all the≈øe remon≈øtrances and addre≈ø≈øes of the Council are on foot; behold, the Royall Maie≈øtie of the King hangeth as it were by loo≈øe gimmals, and mu≈øt ≈øtay the iudgement of the Council to whom it is referred. Well: what if the Councill ≈øhould happe to be two or three yeeres in a≈ø≈øembling, and to continue or hold eighteene yeeres, like the Councill of Trent; ≈øhould not poore France, I be≈øeech you, be reduced to a very bad plight? ≈øhould ≈øhe not be in a very wi≈øe and warme taking? To be ≈øhort; His Lord≈øhips whole ≈øpeach for the vntying of this knot, not onely ≈øurmounteth po≈ø≈øibilitie, but is ≈øtuft with ridiculous toyes. This I make manife≈øt by his addition in the ≈øame pa≈ø≈øage. If the Pope deceiued
in fact, ≈øhall ra≈øhly and vniustly declare the King to be an heretike; then the Popes declaration ≈øhall not be ≈øeconded with actuall depo≈øition, vnles the Realme ≈øhall con≈øent vnto the Kings depo≈øing. What needes any man to bee in≈øtructed in this doctrine? Who doth not knowe, that a King, ≈øo long as he is vpheld and maintained in his Kingdome by his people, cannot actually and effectually be depo≈øed from his Throne? Hee that ≈øpeaketh ≈øuch language and phra≈øe, in effect ≈øaith, and ≈øaith no more then this: A King is neuer depriued of his Crowne, ≈øo long as he can keepe his Crowne on his head: a King is neuer turned and ≈øtript naked, ≈øo long as he can keepe his cloathes on his backe: a King is neuer depo≈øed, ≈øo long as he can make the ≈øtronger partie and ≈øide again≈øt his enemies: in briefe, a King is King, and ≈øhall ≈øtill remaine King, ≈øo long as he can hold the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Kingdome, and ≈øitfa≈øt in his Chaire of E≈øtate. Howbeit, let vs here by the way, take notice of the≈øe words vttered by his Lord≈øhip: That for the depo≈øing of a King, the con≈øent of the people must be obtained: For by the≈øe words the people are exalted aboue the King, and are made the Iudges of the Kings depo≈øing.

But here is yet a greater matter:
Can. Si Papa, Di≈øt. 40. Ni≈øi ≈øit √† ≈øide demins. For that Popes may erre in faith, it is acknowledged by Popes them≈øelues: For ≈øome of them haue condemned Pope Honorius for a Monothelite: S. Hierome, and S. Hilarius, and S. Athana≈øius doe te≈øtifie, that Pope Liberius ≈øtarted a≈øide, and ≈øub≈øcribed to Arriani≈øme: Pope Iohn 23. was condemned in the Councill of Con≈øtance, for maintaining there is neither hell nor heauen: Diuer≈øe other Popes haue been tainted with errour in faith. If therefore any Pope hereticall in him≈øelfe, ≈øhall depo≈øe an Orthodoxe King for here≈øie; can it be imagined, that he which boa≈øts him≈øelfe to beare all diuine and humane lawes in the priuy coffer or casket of his brea≈øt, Omnia ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a in ≈øerinio pectoris. will ≈øtoope to the remon≈øtrances of the French, and vayle to the rea≈øons which they ≈øhall propound, though neuer ≈øo iu≈øtifiable, and of neuer ≈øo great validitie? And how can he, that may be infected with damnable here≈øie (when him≈øelfe is not alwayes free from here≈øie) be a iudge of here≈øie in a King? In this que≈øtion ≈øome are of opinion, that as a man, the Pope may fall into error, but not as Pope. Very good: I demand then vpon the matter, wherefore the Pope doth not in≈øtruct and reforme the man? or wherefore the man doth not require the Popes in≈øtructions? But whether a King be depo≈øed by that man the Pope, or by that Pope the man, is it not all one? is he not depo≈øed? Others affirme, the Pope may erre in a que≈øtion of the fact, but not in a que≈øtion of the right. An egregious gullery and impo≈øture: For if he may be ignorant whether Ie≈øus Chri≈øt died for our ≈øinnes, doubtles he may al≈øo be to ≈øeeke, whether we ≈øhould repo≈øe all our tru≈øt and a≈ø≈øured confidence in the death of Chri≈øt. Con≈øider with me the Prophets of olde: They were all in≈øpired and taught of God, to admoni≈øh and reprooue the Kings of Iudah and I≈ørael: they neither erred in matter of fact, nor in point of right: they were as farre from being blinded and fetcht ouer by deceitfull calumniations, as from beeing ≈øeduced by the painted ≈øhew of corrupt and fal≈øe doctrine: As
they neuer trode awry in matter of faith; ≈øo they neuer whetted the edge of their tongue or ≈øtyle again≈øt the faultle≈ø≈øe. Had it not beene a trimme deuice in their times, to ≈øay, that as E≈øay and as Daniel they might haue ≈øunke into here≈øie, but not as Prophets? For doubtle≈ø≈øe in this ca≈øe, that E≈øay would haue taken coun≈øell of the Prophet which was him≈øelfe. To be ≈øhort; If Kings are onely ≈øo long to be taken for Kings, vntill they ≈øhall be declared heretikes, and ≈øhall be depo≈øed by the Pope; they continually ≈øtand in extreame danger, to vndergoe a very heauy and vniu≈øt ≈øentence. Their ≈øafe≈øt way were to know nothing, and to beleeue by proxie; lea≈øt, if they ≈øhould happen to talke of God, or to thinke of religion, they ≈øhould be drawne for heretikes into the Popes Inqui≈øition.

All the examples hitherto produced by the Lord Cardinall on a rowe, are of a latter date, they lacke weight, are drawne from the time of bondage, and make the Popes them≈øelues witne≈ø≈øes in their owne cau≈øe: They de≈øcant not vpon the point of depo≈øition, but onely ≈øtrike out and ≈øound the notes of excommunication and interdiction, which make nothing at all to the mu≈øicke of the que≈øtion. And therefore hee telleth vs (in kindne≈ø≈øe as I take it) more oftentimes then once or twice, that hee ≈øpeaketh onely of the fact; as one that doeth acknowledge him≈øelfe to bee out of the right: Hee relates things done, but neuer what ≈øhould bee done: which, as the Iudicious know, is to teach nothing.

div.head: THE SECOND INCONVENIENCE EXAMINED.
div.p:
THE ≈øecond Iuconuenience like to grow,
Pag. 86. (as the Lord Cardinall ≈øeemeth to be halfe afraid) if the Article of the third E≈øtate might haue pa≈ø≈øed with approbation, is couched in the≈øe words: Lay-men ≈øhall by authoritie bee ≈øtrengthened with power, to iudge in matters of Religion; as al≈øo to determine the doctrine compri≈øed in the ≈øaid Article to haue requi≈øite conformitie with Gods word: yeathey ≈øhall haue it in their hands to compell Eccle≈øia≈øtics by nece≈øsitie, to ≈øweare, preach, and teach the opinion of the one fide,
as al≈øo by Sermons and publike writings to impugne the other. This inconuenience he aggrauateth with ≈øwelling words, and breaketh out into the≈øe vehement exclamations: O reproach, O ≈øcandall, O gate ≈øet open to a world of here≈øies. He therefore laboureth both by rea≈øons, and by authorities of holy Scripture, to make ≈øuch v≈øurped power of Laics, a fowle, ≈øhameful, and odious practi≈øe. In the whole, his Lord≈øhip toyles him≈øelfe in vaine, & maketh ≈øuppo≈øitions of ca≈øtles in the aire. For in preferring this Article, the third E≈øtate haue born them≈øelues not as iudges or vmpires,
but altogether as petitioners: reque≈øting the ≈øaid Article might be receiued into the number of the Parliament bookes to bee pre≈øented vnto the King and his Coun≈øell, vnto whom in all humilitie they referred the iudgment of the ≈øaid Article; conceiuing all good hope the Clergie and Nobilitie would be plea≈øed to ioyne for the furtherance of their humble petition. They were not ≈øo ignorant of State-matters, or ≈øo vnmindfull of their owne places and charges, to beare them≈øelues in hand, that a petition put vp and preferred by the third E≈øtate, can carry the force of a Law or Statute, ≈øo long as the other two Orders with≈øtand the ≈øame, and ≈øo long as the King him≈øelfe holds backe his Royall con≈øent. Be≈øides, the ≈øaid Article was not propounded as a point of Religious doctrine; but for euer after to remaine and continue a fundamentall Law of the Common-wealth and State it ≈øelfe, the due care whereof was put into their handes, and committed to their tru≈øt. If the King had ratified the ≈øaid Article with Royall con≈øent, and had commanded the Clergie to put in execution the contents thereof; it had bene their duetie to ≈øee the Kings will and plea≈øure fulfilled, as they are ≈øubiects bound to giue him aide in all things, which may any way ≈øerue to procure the ≈øafetie of his life, and the tranquilitie of his Kingdome: Which if the Clergie had performed to the vttermo≈øt of their power, they had not ≈øhewed obedience as vnderlings, vnto the third E≈øtate, but vnto the King alone; by whom ≈øuch command had bene impo≈øed, vpon ≈øugge≈øtion of his faithfull ≈øubiects, made the more watchfull by the negligence of the Clergie; whom they perceiue to be lincked with ≈øtricter bandes vnto the Pope, then they are vnto their King. Here then the Cardinall fights with meere ≈øhadowes, and mooues a doubt whereof his aduer≈øaries haue not ≈øo much as once thought in a dreame: But yet, according to his great dexteritie and nimblene≈ø≈øe of ≈øpirit, by this deuice he cunningly takes vpon him to giue the King a le≈ø≈øon with more libertie; making ≈øemblance to direct his masked Oration to the Deputies of the people, when hee ≈øhooteth in effect, and pricketh at his King, the Princes al≈øo and Lords of his Coun≈øell, whom the Cardinall compri≈øeth vnder the name of Laics; who≈øe iudgment (it is not vnlikely) was apprehended much better by the Clergie, then the iudgement of the third E≈øtate. Now the≈øe are the men whom he tearmes intruders into other mens charges, and ≈øuch as open a gate for I wot not how many legions of here≈øies, to ru≈øh into the Church: For if it be proper to the Clergie and their Head, to iudge in this cau≈øe of the Right of Kings; then the King him≈øelfe, his Princes, and Nobilitie, are debarred and wiped of all iudgement in the ≈øame cau≈øe, no le≈ø≈øe then the repre≈øentatiue body of the people.

Well then, Pag. 61. the L. Cardinall ≈øhowres downe like haile ≈øundry places and te≈øtimonies of Scripture, where the people are commanded to haue their Pa≈øtors in ≈øingular loue, and to beare them all re≈øpects of due ob≈øeruance. Be it ≈øo; yet are the ≈øaid pa≈ø≈øages of Scripture no barre to the people, for their vigilant circum≈øpection, to pre≈øerue the life and Crowne of their Prince,
again≈øt all the wicked enterpri≈øes of men ≈øtirred vp by the Clergie, who haue their Head out of the Kingdome, and hold them≈øelues to be none of the Kings ≈øubiects: a thing neuer ≈øpoken by the ≈øacrificing Prie≈øts and Prelates, mentioned in the pa≈ø≈øages alleadged by the Lord Cardinal. He likewi≈øe produceth two Chri≈øtian Emperours, Pag 62. Constantine and Valentinian by name; the fir≈øt refu≈øing to meddle with iudgement in Epi≈øcopall cau≈øes: the other forbearing to iudge of ≈øubtile Que≈øtions in Diuinity, with prote≈øtation, that Hee would neuer bee ≈øo curious, to diue into the ≈øtreames, or ≈øound the bottome of ≈øo deepe matters. But who doth not know, that working and prouiding for the Kings indemnitie and ≈øafetie, is neither Epi≈øcopall cau≈øe, nor matter of curious and ≈øubtile inqui≈øition? The ≈øame an≈øwere meets with all the re≈øt of the places produced by the L. Orat. ad ciues timme percul≈øos. Cardinal out of the Fathers. And that one for example, out of Gregory Nazianzenus, is not cited by the Cardinall with faire dealing. For Gregory doeth not boord the Emperour him≈øelfe, but his Deputy or L. Pre≈øident, on this maner:
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
For we al≈øo are in authoritie and place of a Ruler, we haue command a≈øwell as your ≈øelfe: wheras the the L. Cardinal with foule play, turnes the place in the≈øe termes, We al≈øo are Emperours. Which words can beare no ≈øuch interpretation, as well becau≈øe he to whom the Bi≈øhop then ≈øpake, was not of Imperiall dignitie; as al≈øo becau≈øe if the Bi≈øhop him≈øelfe, a Bi≈øhop of ≈øo ≈ømall a citie as Nazianzum, had qualified him≈øelfe Emperour, hee ≈øhould haue pa≈ø≈øed all the bounds of mode≈øtie, and had ≈øhewed him≈øelfe arrogant aboue mea≈øure. For as touching ≈øubiection due to Chri≈øtian Emperours, hee freely acknowledgeth a little before,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
that him≈øelfe and his people are ≈øubiect vnto the ≈øuperiour powers, yea bound to pay them tribute. The hi≈øtorie of the ≈øame Gregories life doeth te≈øtifie, that he was drawen by the Arrians before the Con≈øuls iudgement ≈øeate, and from thence returned acquitted, without either ≈øtripes or any other kinde of contumelious entreatie and v≈øe: yet now at la≈øt vp ≈øtarts a Prelate, who dares make this good Father vaunt him≈øelfe to be an Emperour. It is willingly granted, that Emperours neuer challenged, neuer arrogated, to bee Soueraigne Iudges in controuer≈øies of doctrine and faith; neuerthele≈ø≈øe it is clearer then the Sunnes light at high noone, that for moderation at Synods, for determinations and orders e≈øtabli≈øhed in Councils, and for the di≈øcipline of the Church, they haue made a good and a full v≈øe of their Imperiall authoritie.
Vide Canones Graecos √† Tilio editos. The fir≈øt Council held at Con≈øtantinople, beares this title or in≈øcription; The dedication of the holy Synode to the most religious Emperour Theodo≈øius the Great, to who≈øe will and plea≈øure they haue ≈øubmitted the≈øe Canons by them addre≈ø≈øed and establi≈øhed in Councill. And there they al≈øo be≈øeech the Emperour, to confirme and approue the ≈øaid Canons. He ≈øaith el≈øewhere; Conniuence is v≈øed towards the≈øe Heretikes inregard of their multitude, becau≈øe a notable part of the French Nation and State is made all of Heretikes. I ≈øuppo≈øe that out of ≈øpeciall charitie, he would haue tho≈øe Heretikes of his owne making, forewarned what courteous v≈øe and entreaty they are to expect; when he affirmeth that execution of the lawes is but ≈øu≈øpended: For indeed ≈øu≈øpen≈øions hold but for a time. But in a cau≈øe of that nature and importance, I dare promi≈øe my ≈øelfe, that my mo≈øt honoured brother the King of France, will make v≈øe of other coun≈øell: will rather ≈øeeke the amitie of his neighbour Princes, and the peace of his Kingdome: will beare in mind the great and faithfull ≈øeruice of tho≈øe, who in matter of religion di≈ø≈øent from his Maie≈øtie, as of the onely men that haue pre≈øerued and ≈øaued the Crowne for the King his father, of mo≈øt glorious memorie. I am per≈øwaded my brother of France wil beleeue, that his liege people pretended by the L. Cardinall to bee heretikes, are not halfe ≈øo bad as my Romane Catholike ≈øubiects, who by ≈øecret practi≈øes vndermine my life, ≈øerue a forreine Souereigne, are di≈øcharged by his Bulls of their obedience due to me their naturall Souereigne, are bound (by the maximes and rules publi≈øhed and maintained in fauour of the Pope, before this full and famous a≈ø≈øemblie of the E≈øtate at Paris; if the ≈øaid maximes be of any weight and authoritie) to hold mee for no lawfull King, are there taught and in≈øtructed, that Pauls commandemement concerning ≈øubiection vnto the higher Powers, aduer≈øe to their profe≈ø≈øed religion, is onely a proui≈øionall precept, framed to the times, and watching for the opportunitie to ≈øhake off the yoake. All which notwith≈øtanding, I deale with ≈øuch Romane-Catholikes by the rules and wayes of Princely clemencie; their heinous and pernicious error, in effect no le≈ø≈øe then the capitall crime of high trea≈øon, I v≈øe to call ≈øome di≈øea≈øe or di≈øtemper of the mind. La≈øt of all, I beleeue my ≈øaid brother of France will ≈øet downe in his tables, as in record, how little hee ≈øtandeth ingaged to the L. Cardinall in this behalfe: For tho≈øe of the reformed Religion profe≈ø≈øe and proclaime, that next vnder God, they owe their pre≈øeruation and ≈øafetie to the wi≈øedome and benignity of their Kings. But now comes the Cardinall, and he ≈øeekes to ≈øteale this per≈øwa≈øion out of their hearts: He tells them in open Parliament, and without any going about bu≈øhes, that all their welfare and ≈øecuritie ≈øtandeth in their multitude, and in the feare which others conceiue
to trouble the State, by the ≈øtrict execution of lawes again≈øt Heretikes.

He addeth moreouer, Note by the way that here the Church of Rome is called a Sect. that In ca≈øe a third Sect ≈øhould peepe out and growe vp in France, the profe≈ø≈øors thereof ≈øhould ≈øuffer confi≈øcation of their goods, with lo≈ø≈øe of life it ≈øelfe; as hath bene practi≈øed at Geneua against Seruetus, and in England again≈øt Arians. My an≈øwere is this, That puni≈øhments for heretikes, duely and according to Law conuicted, are ≈øet downe by decrees of the ciuill Magi≈øtrate, bearing rule in the countrey where the ≈øaid heretikes inhabite, and not by any ordinances of the Pope. I ≈øay withall, the L. Cardinall hath no rea≈øon to match and parallell the reformed Churches with Seruetus and the Arians: For tho≈øe heretikes were powerfully conuicted by Gods word, and lawfully condemned by the ancient Generall Councils, where they were permitted and admitted to plead their owne cau≈øe in per≈øon. But as for the trewth profe≈ø≈øed by me, and tho≈øe of the reformed Religion, it was neuer yet hi≈ø≈øed out of the Schooles, nor ca≈øt out of any Council, (like ≈øome Parliament bills) where both ≈øides haue bene heard with like indifferencie. Yea, what Council ≈øoeuer hath bene offered vnto vs in the≈øe latter times, it hath bene propo≈øed with certaine pre≈øuppo≈øitions: as, That his Holine≈ø≈øe (beeing a partie in the cau≈øe, and con≈øequently to come vnder iudgement as it were to the barre vpon his triall) ≈øhall be the Iudge of A≈ø≈øize with Commi≈ø≈øion of Oyer and Determiner: it ≈øhall bee celebrated in a citie of no ≈øafe acce≈ø≈øe, without ≈øafe conduct or conuoy to come or goe at plea≈øure, and without danger: it ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øembled of ≈øuch per≈øons with free ≈øuffrage and voyce, as vphold this rule, (which they haue already put in practi≈øe again≈øt Iohn Hus and Hierome of Prage) that faith giuen, and oath taken to an Heretike, mu≈øt not be ob≈øerued.

Now then to re≈øume our former matter; If the Pope hitherto hath neuer pre≈øumed, for pretended here≈øie to confi≈øcate by ≈øentence, either the lands or the goods of priuate per≈øons, or common people of the French Nation, wherefore ≈øhould hee dare to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe Kings of their Royall thrones? wherefore takes he more vpon him ouer Kings, then ouer priuate per≈øons; wherefore ≈øhall the ≈øacred heads of Kings be more churli≈øhly, vnciuilly, and rigorou≈øly handled, then the hoods of the meane≈øt people? Here the L. Cardinal in ≈øtead of a direct an≈øwer, breakes out of the li≈øts, alledging cleane from the purpo≈øe examples of heretikes puni≈øhed, not by the Pope, but by the ciuill Magi≈øtrate of the Countrey: But Bellarmine ≈øpeakes to the point with a more free and open heart: hee is ab≈øolute and re≈øolute in this opinion, that his Holine≈ø≈øe hath plenary power to di≈øpo≈øe all Temporall e≈øtates and matters in the whole world; I am confident (≈øaith Bellarmine) and I ≈øpeake it with a≈ø≈øurance,
Contr. Barclaium, cap. 27. that our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt in the dayes of his mortalitie, had power to di≈øpo≈øe of all Temporall things yea, to ≈øtrip Souereigne Kings and ab≈øolute Lords of their Kingdomes and Seignories: and without all doubt hath granted and left euen the ≈øame power vnto his Vicar, to make v≈øe thereof when≈øoeuer hee ≈øhall thinke it nece≈øsary for the ≈øaluation of ≈øoules. And ≈øo his Lord≈øhip ≈øpeaketh without exception of any thing at all: For who doth not know, that Ie≈øus
Christ had power to di≈øpo≈øe no le≈ø≈øe of priuate mens po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, then of whole Realmes and Kingdomes at his plea≈øure, if it had beene his plea≈øure to di≈øplay the en≈øignes of his power? The ≈øame fulne≈ø≈øe of power is likewi≈øe in the Pope. In good time: belike his Holine≈ø≈øe is the ≈øole heire of Chri≈øt, in whole and in part.
Se≈ø≈ø. 9. The la≈øt Lateran Council fineth a Laic that ≈øpeaketh bla≈øphemie, for the fir≈øt offence (if he be a gentleman) at 25. ducats, and at 50. for the ≈øecond. It pre≈øuppo≈øeth and taketh it for graunted, that the Church may rifle and ran≈øacke the pur≈øes of priuate men, and ca≈øt lots for their goods. The Councill of Trent diggeth as deepe for the ≈øame veine of gold and ≈øiluer. It ordaines; That Emperours, Kings, Dukes Princes,
Se≈ø≈ø. 25. cap. 19. and Lords of cities, ca≈øtles, and territories holding of the Church, in ca≈øe they ≈øhall a≈ø≈øigne any place within their limits or liberties for the duell betweene two Christians, ≈øhall be depriued of the ≈øaid citie, ca≈øtle, or place, where ≈øuch duell ≈øhall be performed, they holding the ≈øaid place of the Church by any kind of tenure: that all other Estates held in fee where the like offence ≈øhall be committed, ≈øhall forthwith fall and become forfeited to their immediate and next Lords: that all goods, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and e≈øtates, as well of the combatants them≈øelues, as of their ≈øeconds ≈øhall bee confi≈øcate. This Councill doeth nece≈ø≈øarily pre≈øuppo≈øe, it lieth in the hand and power of the Church, to di≈øpo≈øe of all the lands and e≈øtates, held in fee throughout all Chri≈øtendome; (becau≈øe the Church for≈øooth can take from one, and giue vnto an other all e≈øtates held in fee what≈øoeuer, as well ≈øuch as hold of the Church, as of ≈øecular Lords) and to make ordinances for the confi≈øcation of all priuate per≈øons goods. By this Canon the Kingdome of Naples hath need to looke well vnto it ≈øelfe. For one duell it may fall into the Exchecquer of the Romane Church; becau≈øe that Kingdome payeth a Reliefe to the Church, as a Royaltie or Seignorie that holdeth in fee of the ≈øaid Church. And in France there is not one Lord≈øhip, not one Mannor, not one farme which the Pope by this meanes cannot ≈øhift ouer to a new Lord. His Lord≈øhip therefore had carried him≈øelfe and the cau≈øe much better, if in ≈øtead of ≈øeeking ≈øuch idle ≈øhifts, he had by a more large a≈ø≈øertion maintained the Popes power to di≈øpo≈øe of priuate mens po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, with no le≈ø≈øe right and authoritie then of Kingdomes: For what colour of rea≈øon can bee giuen, for making the Pope Lord of the whole, and not of the parts? for making him Lord of the forre≈øt in gro≈ø≈øe, and not of the trees in parcell? for making him Lord of the whole hou≈øe, and not of the parlour or the dining chamber?

His Lord≈øhip alleadgeth yet an other rea≈øon, but of no better weight: Betweene the power of priuate owners ouer their goods, and the power of Kings ouer their e≈øtates, there is no little difference: For the goods of priuate per≈øons are ordained for their owners, and Princes for the benefit of their Common-wealths. Heare me now an≈øwere. If this Cardinal-rea≈øon hath any force to inferre, that a King may lawfully be depriued of his Kingdome for here≈øie, but a priuate per≈øon cannot for the ≈øame crime be turned out of his man≈øion hou≈øe; then it ≈øhall follow by the ≈øame rea≈øon, that a Father for the ≈øame cau≈øe may
bee depriued of all power ouer his children, but a priuate owner cannot be depriued of his goods in the like ca≈øe: becau≈øe goods are ordeined for the benefit and comfort of their owners, but fathers are ordeined for the good and benefit of their children: But mo≈øt certain it is, that Kings repre≈øenting the image of God in earth and Gods place, haue a better and clo≈øer ≈øeate in their chaires of E≈øtate, then any priuate per≈øons haue in the ≈øaddle of their inheritances and patrimonies, which are dayly ≈øeene for ≈øleight cau≈øes, to flit and to fall into the hands of new Lords: Whereas a Prince being the Head, cannot bee loo≈øed in the proper ioynt, nor di≈ømounted; like a cannon when the carriage thereof is vnlockt, without a ≈øore ≈øhaking and a mo≈øt grieuous di≈ølocation of all the members, yea, without ≈øubuerting the whole bodie of the State, whereby priuate per≈øons without number are inwrapped together in the ≈øame ruine; euen as the lower ≈øhrubs and other bru≈øh-wood are cru≈øhed in pieces altogether by the fall of a great oake. But ≈øuppo≈øe his Lord≈øhips rea≈øon were ≈øomewhat ponderous and ≈øolide withall, yet a King (which would not bee forgotten) is endowed not onely with the Kingdome, but al≈øo with the ancient De≈ømenes and Crowne-lands, for which none can be ≈øo ≈øimple to ≈øay, The King was ordeined and created King; which neuerthele≈ø≈øe he lo≈øeth when hee lo≈øeth his Crowne. Admit againe this rea≈øon were of ≈øome pith, to make mighty Kings more ea≈øily depo≈øeable then priuate per≈øons from their patrimonies; yet all this makes nothing for the deriuing and fetching of depo≈øition from the Popes Con≈øi≈øtorie. What hee neuer conferred, by what right or power can he claime to take away?

But ≈øee heere no doubt a ≈øharpe and ≈øubtile difference put by the L. Cardinall betweene a Kingdome, and the goods of priuate per≈øons. Goods, as his Lord≈øhip ≈øaith, are without life: they can be con≈øtrained by no force, by no example, by no inducement of their owners to lo≈øe eternall life: Subiects by their Princes may. Now I am of the contrary beliefe, That an hereticall owner, or ma≈øter of a family, hath greater power and meanes withall, to ≈øeduce his owne ≈øeruants and children, then a Prince hath to peruert his owne ≈øubiects; and yet for the contagion of Here≈øie, and for corrupt religion, children are not remoued from their parents, nor ≈øeruants are taken away from their ma≈øters. Hi≈øtories abound with examples of mo≈øt flouri≈øhing Churches, vnder a Prince of contrary religion. And if things without life or ≈øoule are with le≈ø≈øe danger left in an heretikes hands; why then ≈øhall not an hereticall King with more facilitie and le≈ø≈øe danger keepe his Crowne, his Royall charge, his lands, his cu≈øtomes, his impo≈øts, &c? For will any man, except he bee out of his wits, affirme the≈øe things to haue any life or ≈øoule? Or why ≈øhall it bee counted folly, to leaue a ≈øword in the hand of a mad Bedlam? Is not a ≈øword al≈øo without life and ≈øoule? For my part, I ≈øhould rather be of this minde; that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of things without rea≈øon, is more dangerous and pernicious in the hands of an euill ma≈øter, then the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of things endued with life and rea≈øon: For things without
life lacke both rea≈øon and iudgement, how to exempt and free them≈øelues from being in≈øtruments in euill and wicked actions, from being emploied to vngodly and abominable v≈øes. I will not deny, that an hereticall Prince is a plague, a pernicious and mortall ≈øickene≈ø≈øe to the ≈øoules of his ≈øubiects: But a breach made by one mi≈øchiefe, mu≈øt not bee filled vp with a greater inconuenience: An errour mu≈øt not be ≈øhocked and ≈øhouldered with di≈øloialtie, nor here≈øie with periurie, nor impietie with ≈øedition and armed rebellion again≈øt GOD and the King. GOD, who v≈øeth to try and to ≈øchoole his Church, will neuer for≈øake his Church; nor hath need to protect his Church by any proditorious and prodigious practi≈øes of perfidious Chri≈øtians: For he makes his Church to be like the burning bu≈øh: In the midde≈øt of the fire and flames of per≈øecutions, hee will prouide that ≈øhe ≈øhall not be con≈øumed, becau≈øe hee ≈øtandeth in the mid≈øt of his Church. And ≈øuppo≈øe there may be ≈øome iu≈øt cau≈øe for the French, to play the rebels again≈øt their King; yet will it not follow, that ≈øuch rebellious motions are to be rai≈øed by the bellowes of the Romane Bi≈øhop, to who≈øe Pa≈øtorall charge and office it is nothing proper, to intermeddle in the ciuill affaires of forraine Kingdomes.

Here is the ≈øumme and ≈øub≈øtance of the L. Cardinals whole di≈øcour≈øe, touching his pretence of the ≈øecond inconuenience. Which di≈øcour≈øe hee hath clo≈øed with a remarkeable confe≈ø≈øion: to wit, that neither by the authoritie of holy Scripture, nor by the the te≈øtimonie and verdict of the Primitiue Church, there hath bene any full deci≈øion of this que≈øtion. In regard whereof he falleth into admiration, that Lay-people haue gone ≈øo farre in audaciou≈øne≈ø≈øe, as to labour that a doubtfull doctrine might for euer pa≈ø≈øe currant, and be taken for a new article of faith. What a ≈øhame, what a reproach is this? how full of ≈øcandall? for ≈øo his Lord≈øhip is plea≈øed to cry out. This breakes into the ≈øeueralls and inclo≈øures of the Church: this lets in whole herds of here≈øies to gra≈øe in her greene and ≈øweet pastures. On the other ≈øide, without any ≈øuch Rhetoricall outcries, I ≈øimply affirme: It is a reproach, a ≈øcandall, a crime of rebellion, for a ≈øubiect hauing his full charge and loade of benefits, in the new ≈øpring of his Kings tender aage, his King-fathers blood yet reeking, and vpon the point of an addre≈ø≈øe for a double match with Spaine; in ≈øo honourable an a≈ø≈øembly, to ≈øeeke the thraldome of his Kings Crowne, to play the captious in cauilling about cau≈øes of his Kings depo≈øing, to giue his former life the Lye with ≈øhame enough in his old aage, and to make him≈øelfe a common by-word, vnder the name of a Problematicall Martyr; one that offers him≈øelfe to fagot and fire, for a point of doctrine but problematically handled, that is, di≈øtru≈øtfully and onely by way of doubtfull and que≈øtionable di≈øcour≈øe: yea for a point of doctrine, in which the French (as he pretendeth) are permitted to thwart and cro≈ø≈øe his Holines in iudgement, prouided they ≈øpeake in it as in a point, not certaine and nece≈ø≈øary, but onely doubtfull and probable.

div.head: THE THIRD INCONVENIENCE EXAMINED.
div.p: THe third Inconuenience pretended by the L. Pag. 87. Cardinall to grow by admitting this Article of the third E≈øtate, is flouri≈øhed in the≈øe colours: It would breed and bring foorth an open and vnauoydeable ≈øchi≈øme against his Holine≈ø≈øe, and the rest of the whole Eccle≈øiasticall body: For thereby the doctrine long approued and ratified by the Pope and the rest of the Church, ≈øhould now be taxed and condemned of impious and mo≈øt detestable con≈øequence; yea the Pope and the Church, euen in faith and in points of ≈øaluation, ≈øhould be reputed and beleeued to be erroniou≈øly per≈øwaded. Hereupon his Lord≈øhip giues him≈øelfe a large ≈øcope of the raines, to frame his elegant amplifications again≈øt ≈øchi≈ømes and ≈øchi≈ømatikes.

Now to mount ≈øo high, and to flie in ≈øuch place vpon the wings of amplification for this Inconuenience, what is it el≈øe but magnifically to report and imagine a mi≈øchiefe by many degrees greater then the mi≈øchiefe is? The L. Cardinal is in a great errour, if hee make him≈øelfe beleeue, that other nations wil make a rent or ≈øeparation from the communion of the French, becau≈øe the French ≈øtand to it tooth and naile, that French Crownes are not liable or obnoxious to Papall depo≈øition; how≈øoeuer there is no ≈øchi≈øme that importeth not ≈øeparation of communion. The mo≈øt illu≈øtrious Republike of Venice, hath imbarked her≈øelfe in this quarrell again≈øt his Holine≈ø≈øe, hath played her prize, and caried away the weapons with great honour. Doeth ≈øhe, notwith≈øtanding her triumph in the cau≈øe, forbeare to participate with all her neighbours in the ≈øame Sacraments? doeth ≈øhe liue in ≈øchi≈øme with all the re≈øt of the Romane Church? No ≈øuch matter. When the L. Cardinal him≈øelfe not many yeeres pa≈øt, maintained the Kings cau≈øe, and ≈øtood honourably for the Kings right again≈øt the Popes Temporall v≈øurpations, did he then take other Churches to be ≈øchi≈ømaticall, or the rotten members of Antichrist? Beleeue it who li≈øt, I beleeue my Creed. Nay, his Lord≈øhip telleth vs him≈øelfe a little after, that his Holine≈ø≈øe giues the French free ≈øcope, to maintaine either the affirmatiue or negatiue of this que≈øtion. And will his Holine≈ø≈øe hold them ≈øchi≈ømatikes, that di≈ø≈øent from his opinion and iudgement in a ≈øubiect or cau≈øe e≈øteemed problematicall? Farre be it from his Holine≈ø≈øe. The King of Spaine, reputed the Popes right arme, neuer gaue the Pope cau≈øe by any acte or other declaration, to conceiue that he acknowledged him≈øelfe depo≈øeable by the Pope for here≈øie, or Tyrannie, or ≈øtupiditie. But being well a≈ø≈øured the Pope ≈øtandeth in greater feare of his arme, then hee doeth of the Popes head and
≈øhoulders, he neuer troubles his owne head about our que≈øtion. More, when the booke of Cardinall Baronius was come foorth, in which booke the Kingdome of Naples is de≈øcried and publiquely di≈øcredited (like fal≈øe money) touching the qualitie of a Kingdome, and attributed to the King of Spaine, not as trew proprietary thereof, but onely as an E≈øtate held in fee of the Romane Church; the King made no bones to condemne and to bani≈øh the ≈øaid booke out of his dominions. The holy Father was contented to put vp his Catholike ≈øonnes proceeding to the Cardinals di≈øgrace, neuer opened his mouth again≈øt the King, neuer declared or noted the King to be ≈øchi≈ømaticall. He waits perhaps for ≈øome fitter opportunitie; when the Kingdome of Spaine groaning vnder the burthens of inte≈øtine di≈ø≈øentions and troubles, hee may without any danger to him≈øelfe giue the Catholike King a Bi≈øhops mate. Yea, the L. Cardinal him≈øelfe is better ≈øeene in the humors and inclinations of the Chri≈øtian world, then to be gro≈øly per≈øwaded, that in the Kingdome of Spaine, and in the very heart of Rome it ≈øelfe there be not many, which either make it but a iea≈øt, or el≈øe take it in fowle ≈øcorne, to heare the Popes power ouer the Crownes of Kings once named: e≈øpecially ≈øince the Venetian Republike hath put his Holine≈ø≈øe to the wor≈øe in the ≈øame cau≈øe, and ca≈øt him in Law.

What needed the L. Cardinall then, by ca≈øting vp ≈øuch mounts and trenches, by heaping one amplification vpon an other, to make ≈øchi≈øme looke with ≈øuch a terrible and hideous a≈øpect? Who knowes not how great an offence, how heinous a crime it is to quarter not IESVS CHRISTS coat, but his body, which is the Church? And what needed ≈øuch terrifying of the Church with vgline≈ø≈øe of ≈øchi≈øme, whereof there is neither colourable ≈øhew, nor po≈ø≈øibilitie?

The next vgly mon≈øter, after ≈øchi≈øme, ≈øhaped by the L. Cardinall in the third ≈øuppo≈øed and pretended inconuenience, is here≈øie. Pag. 89. His Lord≈øhip ≈øaith for the purpo≈øe: By this Article we are cast headlong into a manifest here≈øie, as binding vs to confe≈ø≈øe, that for many aages pa≈øt, the Catholike Church hath bene bani≈øhed out of the whole world. For if the champions of the doctrine contrary to this Article, doe hold an impious and a detestable opinion, repugnant vnto Gods word, then doubtle≈ø≈øe the Pope for ≈øo many hundred yeeres expired, hath not bene the head of the Church, but an heretike and the Antichrist. He addeth moreouer; That the Church long agoe hath lost her name of Catholike, and that in France there hath no Church flouri≈øhed, nor ≈øo much as appeared the≈øe many and more then many yeeres: for as much as all the French doctors for many yeres together, haue ≈øtood for the contrary opinion. We can erect and ≈øet vp no trophey more honorable for heretikes in token of their victory, then to auow that Chri≈øts vi≈øible Kingdom is peri≈øhed from the face of the earth, and that for ≈øo many hundred yeres there hath not bene any Temple of God, nor any ≈øpou≈øe of Chri≈øt, but euery where, and all the world ouer, the kingdom of Antichri≈øt, the ≈øynagogue of Satan, the ≈øpou≈øe of the diuel, hath mightily preuailed and borne all the ≈øway. La≈øtly, what ≈øtronger engines can the≈øe heretikes wi≈øh or de≈øire, for the battering and the demoli≈øhing of tran≈øub≈øtantiation, of auricular confe≈øsion, and other
like towers of our Catholike Religion, then if it ≈øhould bee granted the Church hath decided the ≈øaid points without any authoritie? &c.

Mee thinkes the L. Cardinal in the whole draught and cour≈øe of the≈øe words doeth ≈øeeke not a little to blemi≈øh the honour of his Church, and to marke his religion with a blacke coale: For the whole frame of his Mother-Church is very ea≈øie to be ≈øhaken, if by the e≈øtabli≈øhing of this Article ≈øhe ≈øhall come to finall ruine, and ≈øhall become the Synagogue of Satan. Likewi≈øe, Kings are brought into a very mi≈øerable ≈øtate and condition, if their Souereigntie ≈øhall not ≈øtand, if they ≈øhall not bee without danger of depo≈øition, but by the totall ruine of the Church, and by holding the Pope, whom they ≈øerue, to be Antichri≈øt. The L. Cardinall him≈øelfe (let him be well ≈øifted) herein doeth not credit his owne words: For doeth not his Lord≈øhip tell vs plaine, that neither by Diuine te≈øtimony, nor by any ≈øentence of the ancient Church, the knot of this controuer≈øie hath bene vntied? againe, that ≈øome of the French, by the Popes fauourable indulgence, are licen≈øed or tolerated to ≈øay their mind, to deliuer their opinion of this que≈øtion, though contrary to the iudgement of his Holine≈ø≈øe; prouided they hold it onely as problematicall, and not as nece≈ø≈øary? What? Can there be any a≈ø≈øurance for the Pope, that hee is not Antichri≈øt; for the Church of Rome, that ≈øhe is not a Synagogue of Satan, when a mans a≈ø≈øurance is grounded vpon wauering and wilde vncertainties, without Canon of Scripture, without con≈øent or countenance of antiquitie, and in a cau≈øe which the Pope by good leaue ≈øuffereth ≈øome to to≈ø≈øe with winds of problematicall opinion? It hath beene ≈øhewed before, that by Gods word, whereof ≈ømall reckoning perhaps is made, by venerable antiquitie, and by the French Church in tho≈øe times when the Popes power was mounted aloft, the doctrine which teacheth depo≈øing of Kings by the Pope, hath bene checked and countermanded. What, did the French in tho≈øe dayes beleeue the Church was then ≈øwallowed vp, and no where vi≈øible or extant in the world? No verely; Tho≈øe that make the Pope of Soueraigne authoritie for matters of Faith, are not per≈øwaded that in this cau≈øe they are bound ab≈øolutely to beleeue and credit his doctrine. Why ≈øo? Becau≈øe they take it not for any decree or determination of Faith; but for a point perteining to the my≈øteries of State, and a pillar of the Popes Temporall Monarchie; who hath not receiued any promi≈øe from God, that in cau≈øes of this nature hee ≈øhall not erre: For they hold, that errour by no meanes can crawle or ≈øcramble vp to the Papall See, ≈øo highly mounted; but grant ambition can ≈øcale the highe≈øt walls, and climbe the loftie≈øt pinacles of the ≈øame See. They hold withall, that in ca≈øe of ≈øo ≈øpeciall aduantage to the Pope, whereby he is made King of Kings, and as it were the pay-ma≈øter or di≈øtributer of Crownes, it is again≈øt all rea≈øon that hee ≈øhould ≈øit as Iudge, to carue out Kingdomes for his owne ≈øhare. To bee ≈øhort, let his Lord≈øhip be a≈ø≈øured that he meeteth with notorious blockeheads, more blunt-witted then a whet≈øtone, when they are drawen to beleeue
by his per≈øwa≈øion, that who≈øoeuer beleeues the Pope hath no right nor power to put Kings be≈øide their Thrones, to giue and take away Crownes, are all excluded and barred out of the heauenly Kingdome.

But now followes a wor≈øe matter: For they whom the Cardinall reproachfully calls heretikes, haue wrought and wonne his Lord≈øhip (as to mee ≈øeemeth) to plead their cau≈øe at the barre, and to betray his owne cau≈øe to the≈øe heretikes: For what is it in his Lord≈øhip, but plaine playing the Praeuaricator, when he crieth ≈øo lowd, that by admitting and e≈øtabli≈øhing of this Article, the doctrine of Cake-incarnation and priuie Confe≈ø≈øion to a Prie≈øt, is vtterly ≈øubuerted? Let vs heare his rea≈øon, and willingly accept the trewth from his lips. The Articles (as his Lord≈øhip granteth) of Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, auricular Confe≈ø≈øion, and the Popes power to depo≈øe Kings, are all grounded alike vpon the ≈øame authoritie. Now he hath acknowledged the Article of the Popes power to depo≈øe Kings, is not decided by the Scripture, nor by the ancient Church, but within the compa≈ø≈øe of certaine aages pa≈øt, by the authoritie of Popes and Councils. Then he goes on well, and inferres with good rea≈øon, that in ca≈øe the point of the Popes power be weakened, then the other two points mu≈øt needs bee ≈øhaken, and ea≈øily ouerthrowen: So that hee doeth confe≈ø≈øe the mon≈øtrous birth of the breaden-God, and the blind Sacrament or vaine fanta≈øie of auricular confe≈ø≈øion, are no more conueyed into the Church by pipes from the ≈øprings of ≈øacred Scripture, or from the riuers of the ancient Church, then that other point of the Popes power ouer Kings and their Crownes. Very good: For were they indeed deriued from either of tho≈øe two heads, that is to ≈øay, were they grounded vpon the foundation of the fir≈øt or ≈øecond authoritie; then they could neuer bee ≈øhaken by the downefall of the Popes power to depo≈øe Kings. I am well a≈ø≈øured, that for v≈øing ≈øo good a rea≈øon, the world will hold his Lord≈øhip in ≈øu≈øpicion, that he ≈øtill hath ≈øome≈ømacke of his fathers di≈øcipline and in≈øtruction, who in times pa≈øt had the honour to be a Mini≈øter of the holy Go≈øpel.

Howbeit he playeth not faire, nor v≈øeth ≈øincere dealing in his proceeding again≈øt ≈øuch as he calls heretikes; when hee ca≈øts in their di≈øh, and beares them in hand they frowardly wrangle for the inui≈øibilitie of the Church in earth: For indeed the matter is nothing ≈øo. They freely acknowledge a vi≈øible Church: For how≈øoeuer the a≈ø≈øembly of Gods elect, doth make a body not di≈øcerneable by mans eye; yet we a≈ø≈øuredly beleeue, and gladly profe≈ø≈øe, there neuer wanted a vi≈øible Church in the world; yet onely vi≈øible to ≈øuch as make a part of the ≈øame. All that are without, ≈øee no more but men, they doe not ≈øee the ≈øaid men to be the trew Church. Wee beleeue moreouer of the vniuer≈øall Church vi≈øible, that it is compo≈øed of many particular Churches, whereof ≈øome are better fined and more cleane from lees and dregs then other: and withall, we denie the pure≈øt Churches to be alwayes the greate≈øt and mo≈øt vi≈øible.

div.head: THE FOVRTH AND LAST INCONVENIENCE EXAMINED.
div.p:
THE Lord Cardinall before he looketh into the la≈øt Inconuenience, v≈øeth a certaine preamble of his owne life pa≈øt, and ≈øeruices done to the Kings, Henry the III. and IIII. Touching the latter of which two Kings, his Lord≈øhip ≈øaith in a ≈øtraine of boa≈øting, after this manner: I, by the grace of God, or the grace of God by mee rather, reduced him to the Catholike religion. I obtained at Rome his ab≈øolution of Pope Clement 8. I reconciled him to the holy See. Touching the fir≈øt of the≈øe points; I ≈øay the time, the occa≈øions, and the fore≈øaid Kings nece≈ø≈øary affaires doe ≈øufficiently te≈øtifie, that he was induced to change his mind, and to alter his religion, vpon the ≈øtrength of other manner of arguments then Theologicall ≈øchooles, or the per≈øwa≈øions of the L. Cardinals fluent Rhetoricke, doe v≈øually afford, or could po≈ø≈øibly ≈øugge≈øt. Moreouer, who doeth not know, that in affaires of ≈øo high nature and con≈øequence, re≈øolutions once taken, Princes are to proceede with in≈øtructions by a formall cour≈øe? As for the Kings ab≈øolution, pretended to bee purcha≈øed of Clement 8. by the L. Cardinals good ≈øeruice; it had beene the part of ≈øo great a Cardinall, for the honour of his King, of the Realme, and of his owne place, to haue buried that piece of his notable ≈øeruice in perpetuall ≈øilence, and in the darke night of eternall obliuion: For in this matter of reconcilement, it is not vnknowne to the world, how ≈øhamefully and ba≈øely hee pro≈øtituted the inuiolable dignity of his King, when his Lord≈øhip repre≈øenting the per≈øon of his King, and couching on the ground by way of ≈øufficient penance, was glad (as I haue noted in the Preface to my Apologie) to haue his venerable ≈øhoulders gracefully ≈øaluted with ≈øtripes, and reuerently wor≈øhipped with ba≈øtonados of a Pontificiall cudgell. Which gracefull, or di≈øgracefull blemi≈øh rather, it plea≈øed Pope Clement of his rare clemencie, to grace yet with a higher degree of ≈øpirituall graces; in giuing the L. Cardinall then Bi≈øhop of Eureux, a certaine quantity of holy graines, cro≈ø≈øes, and medals, or little plates of ≈øiluer, or ≈øome other mettall, to hang about the necke, or to bee borne about again≈øt ≈øome euill: Which trea≈øures of the Popes grace, who≈øoeuer ≈øhould graciou≈øly and reuerently ki≈ø≈øe, they ≈øhould without faile purcha≈øe vnto them≈øelues a pardon for one hundred yeeres. The≈øe feate and prety gugawes for children, were no doubt a ≈øpeciall comfort vnto the good Kings heart, after his Maie≈øtie had beene hand≈øomely ba≈øted vpon the L. Bi≈øhops backe. But with what face can his Lord≈øhip brag, that he preuailed with Pope Clement for the Kings ab≈øolution? The late Duke of Neuers, not long before had ≈øolicited his
Holines, with all earne≈øt and humble in≈øtance to the ≈øame purpo≈øe; how≈øoeuer, the Kings affaires then ≈øeeming de≈øperate in the Popes eye, he was licen≈øed to depart for France, without any due and gracious re≈øpect vnto his errand. But ≈øo ≈øoone as the Pope receiued intelligence, of the Kings fortunes growing to the full, and the affaires of the League to be in the wane, and the principall cities, the ≈øtronge≈øt places of garri≈øon through all France to ≈øtrike tops and tops gallant, and to hale the King; then the holy Gho≈øt in good time in≈øpired the holy Father with a holy de≈øire and tender affection, to receiue this poore wandring ≈øheep againe into the flocke of Chri≈øt, and bo≈øome of holy Church. His Holine≈ø≈øe had rea≈øon: For he feared by his ob≈øtinate ≈øeuerity to prouoke the patience of the French, and to driue that Nation (as they had many times threatned before) then to put in execution their auncient de≈øigne; which was, to ≈øhake off the Pope, and to ≈øet vp ≈øome of their owne tribes or kinreds for Patriarch ouer the French Church. But let his Lord≈øhippe vouch≈øafe to ≈øearch the ≈øecret of his owne bo≈øome, and no doubt he wil not ≈øticke to acknowledge, that before he ≈øtirred one foote out of France, he had good a≈ø≈øurance of the good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe and i≈ø≈øue of his honourable emba≈ø≈øage.

Now the hearers thus prepared by his Preface, the L. Cardinall proceedeth in his purpo≈øe; namely to make proofe, how this Article of the third E≈øtate, wherein doubtfull and que≈øtionable matters are mingled and confounded with certaine and indubitable principles, doth ≈øo debilitate and weaken the ≈øinewes and vertue of any remedy intended for the danger of Kings, as it maketh all remedies and receipts pre≈øcribed for that purpo≈øe, to become altogether vnprofitable, and without effect. He yeelds this rea≈øon, (take it for≈øooth vpon my warrant) a rea≈øon full of pith and ≈øub≈øtance: The onely remedie again≈øt parricides, is to thunder the ≈øolemne cur≈øes of the Church, and the puni≈øhments to be inflicted after death: which points, if they be not grounded vpon infallible authoritie, will neuer be ≈øetled in mens per≈øwa≈øions with any certaine a≈ø≈øurance. Now in the ≈øolemne cur≈øes of the Church, no man can attaine to the ≈øaid a≈ø≈øurance, if things not denied be mingled with points not graunted, and not con≈øented vnto by the Vniuer≈øall Church. By a thing not denied and not conte≈øted, the L. Cardinall meanes prohibiting and condemning of King-killing: and by points conte≈øted, he meanes denying of the Popes power to depo≈øe Kings.

In this whole di≈øcour≈øe, I find neither pith of argument, nor cour≈øe of proofe; but onely a ca≈øt of the L. Cardinalls office by way of coun≈øell: whereunto I make this an≈øwere. If there be in this Article of the third E≈øtate any point, wherein all are not of one mind and the ≈øame iudgement; in whom lieth all the blame, from whence ri≈øes the doubt, but from the Popes and Popi≈øh para≈øites, by whom the certaintie of the ≈øaid point hath bin cunningly remooued and conueied away, and mu≈øt be re≈øtored againe by publike authority? Now the way to re≈øtore certainty vnto a point, which again≈øt rea≈øon is called into doubt and que≈øtion, is to make it vp in one
ma≈ø≈øe, or to tie it vp in the ≈øame bundle, with other certaine points of the ≈øame nature.

Here I am forced to ≈øummon the con≈øciences of men, to make ≈øome ≈øtand or ≈øtay vpon this point, and with me to enter into deepe con≈øideration, how great and vnuanqui≈øhable force is euer found in the trewth: For the≈øe two que≈øtions, Whether Kings may lawfully be made away by a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øins waged and hired for the act; and Whether the Pope hath lawfull power to cha≈øe Kings out of their Thrones, are by the L. Cardinals owne confe≈ø≈øion, in ≈øo full a≈øpect of coniunction, that if either bee brought vnder any degree of doubt, the other al≈øo is fetcht within the ≈øame compa≈ø≈øe. In which words he directly pointeth as with a finger to the very trew ≈øource of the maine mi≈øchiefe, and to the ba≈øilique and liuer veine, infected with pe≈øtilential blood, inflamed to the de≈øtruction of Ba≈øilicall Princes by dete≈øtable parricide: For who≈øoeuer ≈øhall confidently beleeue that Popes are not armed with power to depo≈øe Kings; will beleeue with no le≈ø≈øe confidence and a≈ø≈øurance, it is not lawful by ≈øudden a≈ø≈øaults to flie at their throats. For are not all de≈øperate villaines per≈øwaded, when they are hired to murder Kings, that in doing ≈øo damnable a feate, they doe it for a piece of notable and extraordinary ≈øeruice to the Pope? This maxime therfore is to be held for a principle vnmooueable and indubitable; that, If ≈øubiects de≈øire the life of their Kings to bee ≈øecured; they mu≈øt not yeeld the Pope one inch of power, to depriue their Kings of their Thrones and Crownes, by depo≈øing their Kings.

The Lord Cardinall te≈øtifieth no le≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe in the≈øe words: If tho≈øe mon≈øters of men, and furies of hell, by whom the life-blood of our two la≈øt Kings was let out, had euer beene acquainted with Lawes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, they might haue read them≈øelues adiudged by the Councill of Con≈øtance to expre≈ø≈øe damnation. For in the≈øe words, the L. Cardinall preferreth a bill of inditement to ca≈øt his Holine≈ø≈øe; who, vpon the commencing of the Leaguers warres, in ≈øtead of giuing order for the publi≈øhing of the ≈øaid Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes for the re≈øtraining of all parricidicall practi≈øes and attempts, fell to the terrour of his fulminations, which not long after were ≈øeconded and ratified by the mo≈øt audatious and bloody murder of King Henry III. In like manner, the whole Clergy of France are wrapped vp by the L. Cardinals words, and inuolued in the perill of the ≈øaid inditement: For in ≈øtead of preaching the ≈øaid Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes, by which all King-killing is inhibited; the Prie≈øts taught, vented, and publi≈øhed nothing but rebellion; and when the people in great deuotion came to powre their confe≈ø≈øions into the Prie≈øts eares; then the Prie≈øts, with a kind of counterbuffe in the ≈øecond place when their turne was come, and with greater deuotion, powred blood into the eares of the people; out of which roote grewe the terrour of tho≈øe cruell warres, and the horrible parricide of that good King.

But let vs here take ≈øome neere ≈øight of the≈øe Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes, whereby ≈øubiects are inhibited to kill, or de≈øperately to di≈øpatch their Kings out of the way. The Lord Cardinall, for full payment of all ≈øcores
vpon this reckoning, layeth downe the credit of the Councill at Con≈øtance, which neuerthele≈ø≈øe affoardeth not one myte of trew and currant payment. The trewth of the hi≈øtory may bee taken from this briefe relation. Iohn Duke of Burgundy, procured Lewis Duke of Orleans to be murthered in Paris: To iu≈øtifie and make good this bloody acte, he produced a certaine petima≈øter, one called by the name of Iohn Petit. This little Iohn cau≈øed nine propo≈øitions to be giuen foorth or ≈øet vp, to bee di≈øcu≈ø≈øed in the famous Vniuer≈øitie of Paris: The ≈øumme of all to this purpo≈øe; It is lawfull, iu≈øt, and honourable, for euery ≈øubiect or priuate per≈øon either by open force and violence, or by deceit and ≈øecret lying in waite, or by ≈øome wittie ≈øtratagem, or by any other way of fact, to kil a Tyrant practi≈øing again≈øt his King, and other higher powers; yea the King ought in rea≈øon, to giue him a pen≈øion or ≈øtipend, that hath killed any per≈øon di≈øloyal to his Prince. The words of Petits fir≈øt propo≈øition be the≈øe: It is lawfull for euery ≈øubiect, Ger≈øon. without any command or commi≈øsion from the higher powers by all the Lawes of nature, of man, and of God him≈øelfe, to kill or cau≈øe to be killed any Tyrant, who either by a couetous and greedie de≈øire, or by fraud, by diuination vpon casting of Lots, by double and treacherous dealing, doeth plot or practi≈øe against his Kings corporall health, or the health of his higher powers. In the third propo≈øition: It is lawfull for euery ≈øubiect honourable and meritorious, to kill the ≈øaid Tyrant, or cau≈øe him to be killed as a Traitor, di≈øloyall and trecherous to his King. In the ≈øixt propo≈øition: The King is to appoint a ≈øalarie and recompence for him that hath killed ≈øuch a Tyrant, or hath cau≈øed him to bee killed. The≈øe propo≈øitions of Iohannes Paruus, were condemned by the Councill of Con≈øtance, as impious, and tending to the ≈øcandall of the Church. Now then, whereas the ≈øaid Councill no doubt vnder≈øtood the name or word Tyrant in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, wherein it was taken by Iohannes Paruus; certaine it is, the Councill was not of any ≈øuch iudgement or mind, to condemne one that ≈øhould kill a King or Soueraigne Prince; but one that by trea≈øon, and without commandement ≈øhould kill a ≈øubiect, rebelling and practi≈øing again≈øt his King. For Iohn Petit had vndertaken to iu≈øtifie the making away of the Duke of Orleans to be a lawfull acte, and calls that Dukea Tyrant, albeit hee was no Soueraigne Prince; as all the aboue recited words of Iohn Petit doe te≈øtifie, that he ≈øpeaketh of ≈øuch a Tyrant, as being in ≈øtate of ≈øubiection, rebelleth again≈øt his free and ab≈øolute Prince: So that who≈øoeuer ≈øhall narrowly ≈øearch and looke into the mind and meaning of the ≈øaid Council, ≈øhal ea≈øily perceiue, that by their decrees the ≈øafetie of Kings was not confirmed but weakened, not augmented but dimini≈øhed; for as much as they inhibited priuate per≈øons to kill a Subiect, attempting by wicked coun≈øels and practi≈øes to make away his King.

But be it granted, the Councill of Con≈øtance is flat and altogether direct again≈øt King-killers; For I am not vnwilling to be per≈øwaded, that had the que≈øtion then touched the murdering of Soueraigne Princes, the ≈øaid Councill would haue pa≈ø≈øed a ≈øound and holy decree: But, I ≈øay, this granted,
what ≈øheild of defence is hereby reached to Kings, to ward or beat off the thru≈øt of a murderers weapon, and to ≈øaue or ≈øecure their life? ≈øeeing the L. Cardinall, building vpon the ≈øubtile deui≈øe and ≈øhift of the Ie≈øuites, hath taught vs out of their Schooles, that by Kings are vnder≈øtood Kings in e≈ø≈øe, not yet fallen from the ≈øupreame degree of Soueraigne Royaltie: For being once depo≈øed by the Pope, (≈øay the Ie≈øuites) they are no longer Kings, but are fallen from the rights of Soueraigne dignitie; and con≈øequently to make ≈øtrip and wa≈øt of their blood, is not for≈øooth to make ≈øtrip and wa≈øt of Royall blood. The Ie≈øuiticall ma≈øters, in the file of their words are ≈øo ≈øupple and ≈øo limber, that by leauing ≈øtill in their ≈øpeech ≈øome ≈øtarting hole or other, they are able by the ≈øame, as by a po≈øterne or backdoore, to make an e≈øcape.

Meane while the Readers are here to note (for well they may) a tricke of mon≈øtrous and mo≈øt wicked cunning. The L. Cardinall contends for the bridling and hampering of King-killers by the Lawes Eccle≈øia≈øticall. Now it might be pre≈øumed, that ≈øo reuerend and learned a Cardinal intending to make v≈øe of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes, by vertue whereof the life of Kings may be ≈øecured, would fill his mouth and garni≈øh the point with diuine Oracles, that wee might the more gladly and willingly giue him the hearing, when hee ≈øpeakes as one furni≈øhed with ≈øufficient weight and authoritie of ≈øacred Scripture. But behold, in ≈øtead of the authenticall and mo≈øt ancient word, hee propounds the decree of a lateborne Councill at Con≈øtance, neither for the Popes tooth, nor any way comming neere the point in controuer≈øie. And ≈øuppo≈øe it were pertinent vnto the purpo≈øe, the L. Cardinall beareth in his hand a forke of di≈øtinction, with two tines or teeth to beare off, nay to ≈øhift off and to auoid the matter with meere dalliance. The ≈øhorte≈øt and neere≈øt way (in ≈øome ≈øort of re≈øpects) to e≈øtabli≈øh a fal≈øe opinion, is to charge or ≈øet vpon it with fal≈øe and with ridiculous rea≈øons. The like way to worke the ouerthrow of trew doctrine, is to re≈øt or ground it vpon friuolous rea≈øons or authorities of ≈øtubble-weight. For example; if we ≈øhould thus argue for the immortalitie of the ≈øoule with Plato: In Phaedone. The ≈øwan ≈øingeth before her death; ergo, the ≈øoule is immortall. Or thus with certaine ≈øeduced Chri≈øtians: The Pope hath ordained the word of God to be authenticall: ergo, all credit mu≈øt be giuen to diuine Scripture. Vpon the ≈øpurkies or hookes of ≈øuch ridiculous arguments and friuolous rea≈øons, the L. Cardinall hangs the life and ≈øafetie of Kings.

With like artificiall deui≈øes hee pretendeth to haue the infamous murders, and appo≈øted cutting of Kings throats in extreame dete≈øtation; and yet by depo≈øing them from their Princely dignities, by degrading them from their ≈øupreame and Soueraigne authorities, hee brings their ≈øacred heads to the butchers blocke: For a King depo≈øed by the Pope, (let no man doubt) will not leaue any ≈øtone vnremooued, nor any meanes and wayes vnattempted, nor any forces or powers of men vnleuied or vnhired, to defend him≈øelfe and his Regall dignitie, to repre≈ø≈øe and bring vnder his rebellious
people, by the Pope di≈øcharged of their alleagiance.
