The≈øe be the maximes and principles, which made way for the warres of the la≈øt League into France; by which the very bowels of that mo≈øt famous and flouri≈øhing Kingdome were ≈øet on ≈øuch a combu≈øtion, that France her ≈øelfe was brought within two fingers breadth of bondage to another Nation, and the death of her two la≈øt Kings mo≈øt villenou≈øly and traiterou≈øly accompli≈øhed. The L. Cardinall then giuing the≈øe diabolicall maximes for meanes to ≈øecure the life and E≈øtate of Kings, ≈øpeaketh as if he would giue men coun≈øell to dry them≈øelues in the riuer, when they come as wet as a water ≈øpaniell out of a pond; or to warme them≈øelues by the light of the Moone, when they are ≈øtark-naked, and well neere frozen to death.

div.head: THE CONCLVSION OF THE LORD OF PERRON EXAMINED.
div.p:
AFter the L. Cardinal hath ≈øtoutly ≈øhewed the ≈øtrength of his arme, and the deepe skill of his head in fortification; at la≈øt he leaues his loftie ≈øcaffolds, and falls to worke neerer the ground, with more ea≈øie tooles of humble praiers and gentle exhortations. The ≈øumme of the whole is this: He adiures his auditors neuer to forge remedies, neuer ≈øo to prouide for the temporall ≈øafetie of Kings, as thereby to worke their finall falling from eternall ≈øaluation: neuer to make any rent or rupture in the vnitie of the Church, in this corrupt aage infected with pe≈øtilent Here≈øies, which already hauing made ≈øo great a breach in the walles of France, will no doubt double their ≈øtrength by the di≈ø≈øentions, diui≈øions, and ≈øchi≈ømes of Catholikes. If this infectious plague ≈øhall ≈øtill increa≈øe and grow to a carbuncle, it can by no meanes poy≈øon Religion, without bringing Kings to their winding ≈øheetes and wofull hear≈øes. The first rowlers of that ≈øtone of offence, aimed at no
other marke, then to make an ignominious and lamentable rent in the Church. Hee thinks the Deputies of the third E≈øtate, had neither head nor first hand in contriuing this Article; but holds it rather a new deuice and ≈øubtile inuention, ≈øugge≈øted by per≈øons, which beeing already cut off by their owne practi≈øes from the body of the Romane Church, haue likewi≈øe inueigled and in≈ønared ≈øome that beare the name of Catholiks, with ≈øome other Eccle≈øia≈øtics; and vnder a faire pretence and goodly cloake, by name, the ≈øeruice of the King, haue ≈øurpri≈øed and played vpon their ≈øimplicitie. The≈øe men (as the Cardinall ≈øaith) doe imitate Iulian the Apo≈øtata, who to bring the Chri≈øtians to idolatrous wor≈øhip of fal≈øe gods, commaunded the idols of Iupiter and Venus to be intermingled with Imperiall ≈øtatues, and other Images of Chri≈øtian Emperours, &c. Then after certaine Rhetoricall flouri≈øhes, his Lord≈øhip fals to pro≈øecute his former cour≈øe, and cries out of this Article; A mon≈øter hauing the tayle of a fi≈øh, as if it came cutting the narrow Seas out of England: For in full effect it is downright the Engli≈øh oath; ≈øauing that indeed the oath of England runneth in a more mild forme, and a more moderate ≈øtraine. And here he ≈øuddenly takes occa≈øion to make ≈øome digre≈ø≈øion: For out of the way, and cleane from the matter, he entreth into ≈øome purpo≈øe of my prai≈øe and commendation: He courteou≈øly for ≈øooth is plea≈øed to grace mee with knowledge of learning, and with ciuill vertues: He ≈øeemeth chiefly to reioyce in his owne behalfe, and to giue me thanks, that I haue done him the honour to enter the li≈øts of Theologicall di≈øpute again≈øt his Lord≈øhip. Howbeit he twitches and carpes at me withall, as at one that ≈øoweth ≈øeeds of di≈ø≈øention and ≈øchi≈øme among≈øt Romane Catholiks: And yet he would ≈øeeme to qualifie the matter, and to make all whole againe, by ≈øaying, That in ≈øo doing I am per≈øwaded I doe no more then my duetie requires. But now (as his Lord≈øhip followes the point) it ≈øtandeth neither with godline≈ø≈øe, nor with equity, nor with rea≈øon, that Acts made, that Statutes, Decrees, and Ordinances ratified for the State and Gouernement of England, ≈øhould be thrust for binding Laws vpon the Kingdome of France: nor that Catholikes, and much le≈øse that Eccle≈øia≈øtics, to the ende they may liue in ≈øafetie, and freely enioy their priuiledges or immunities in France, ≈øhould be forced to beleeue, and by oath to ≈øeale the ≈øame points, which Engli≈øh Catholikes to the end they may purcha≈øe libertie onely to breath, nay ≈øorrowfully to ≈øigh rather, are con≈øtrained to allow and to aduow be≈øides. And where as in England There is no ≈ømall number of Catholikes, that lacke not constant and re≈øolute minds to endure all ≈øorts of puni≈øhment, rather then to take that oath of allegiance; will there not be found an other manner of number in France, armed with no le≈ø≈øe constancie and Chri≈øtian re≈øolution? There will, most honourable Auditors, there will without all doubt: and we all that are of Epi≈øcopall dignity will ≈øooner ≈øuffer Martyrdome in the cau≈øe. Then out of the ≈øuper-abundance and ouerweight of his Lord≈øhips goodnes, he clo≈øely coucheth and conuayeth a certaine di≈øta≈øtfull oppo≈øition betweene mee and his King; with prai≈øes and thanks to God, that his King is not delighted, & takes no plea≈øure to make Martyrs.

All this Artificiall and ≈øwelling di≈øcour≈øe like vnto puffe-pa≈øt, if it be viewed at a neere di≈øtance, will be found like a bladder full of wind, without any ≈øoliditie of ≈øub≈øtantiall matter. For the Deputies of the third
E≈øtate were neuer ≈øo voide of vnder≈øtanding, to beleeue that by prouiding for the life and ≈øafety of their King, they ≈øhould thru≈øt him headlong into eternall damnation. Their braines were neuer ≈øo much bla≈øted, ≈øo farre benummed, to dreame the ≈øoule of their King cannot mount vp to heauen, except he be di≈ømounted from his Princely Throne vpon earth, when≈øoeuer the Pope ≈øhall hold vp his finger.

And whereas he is bold to pronounce, that heretikes of France doe make their benefit and aduantage of this diui≈øion; that ≈øpeech is grounded vpon this propo≈øition; That profe≈ø≈øors of the Chri≈øtian Religion reformed (which is to ≈øay, purged and clean≈øed of all Popi≈øh dregs) are heretikes in fact, and ought ≈øo to bee reputed in right: Which propo≈øition his Lord≈øhip will neuer ≈øoundly and ≈øufficiently make good, before his Holine≈ø≈øe hath compiled an other Go≈øpell, or hath forged an other Bible at his Pontificiall anuile. The L. Cardinall vndertooke to reade mee a lecture vpon that argument; but euer ≈øince hath played Mum-budget, and hath put him≈øelfe to ≈øilence, like one at a Non-plus in his enterpri≈øe. There be three yeeres already gone and pa≈øt, ≈øince his Lord≈øhip beganne to ≈øhape ≈øome an≈øwere to a certaine writing di≈øpatched by mee in few daies: With forming and reforming, with filing and poli≈øhing, with labouring and licking his an≈øwere ouer and ouer againe, with reiterated extractions and calcinations, it may be coniectured that all his Lord≈øhips labour and co≈øt is long ≈øince evaporated and vani≈øhed in the aire. Howbeit, as well the friendly conference of a King, (for I will not call it a contention) as al≈øo the dignitie, excellencie, and importance of the matter, long ≈øince de≈øerued, and as long ≈øince required the publi≈øhing of ≈øome or other an≈øwere. His Lord≈øhips long ≈øilence will neuer be imputed to lacke of capacity, wherewith who knoweth not how abundantly he is furni≈øhed; but rather to well adui≈øed agnition of his owne working and building vpon a weake foundation.

But let vs returne vnto the≈øe heretikes, that make ≈øo great gaine by the di≈øagreement of Catholikes. It is no part of their dutie to aime at ≈øowing of di≈ø≈øentions; but rather to intend and attend their faithfull performance of ≈øeruice to their King. If ≈øome be plea≈øed, and others offended, when ≈øo good and loyall duties are ≈øincerely di≈øcharged; it is for all good ≈øubiects to grieue and to be ≈øory, that when they ≈øpeake for the ≈øafetie of their King & honour of the trewth, it is their hard hap to leaue any at all vn≈øatisfied. But ≈øuppo≈øe the ≈øaid heretiks were the Authors of this article preferred by the third E≈øtate: What need they to conceale their names in that regard? What need they to di≈øclaime the credit of ≈øuch a worthy act? Would it not redound to their perpetuall honour, to be the onely ≈øubiects that kept watch ouer the Kings life and Crowne, that ≈øtood centinell, and walked the rounds for the pre≈øeruation of his Princely diademe, when all other had no more touch, no more feeling thereof then ≈øo many ≈øtones? And what neede the Deputies for the third E≈øtate, to receiue in≈øtructions from forraine Kingdomes, concerning a cau≈øe of that nature; when there was
no want of dome≈øticall examples, and the French hi≈øtories were plentifull in that argument? What neede they to gape for this reformed doctrine, to come ≈øwimming with a fi≈øhes tayle out of an I≈øland to the mayne continent, when they had before their eyes the murders of two Kings, with diuer≈øe ciuill warres, and many Arre≈øts of Court, all tending to in≈øinuate and ≈øugge≈øt the introduction of the ≈øame remedy? Sugge≈øtions are needle≈ø≈øe from abroad, when the mi≈øchiefe is felt at home. it ≈øeemes to me that his Lord≈øhip in ≈ømoothing and tickling the Deputies for the third E≈øtate, doth no le≈ø≈øe then wring and wrong their great ≈øufficiencie with contumely and outragious abu≈øe; as if they were not furni≈øhed with ≈øufficient fore≈øight, and with loyall affection towards their King, for the pre≈øeruation of his life and honour, if the remedie were not beaten into their heads by tho≈øe of the Religion, reputed heretikes.

Touching my ≈øelfe, ranged by his Lord≈øhip in the ≈øame ranke with ≈øowers of di≈ø≈øention; I take my God to witnes, and my owne con≈øcience, that I neuer dream'd of any ≈øuch vnchri≈øtian proiect. It hath beene hitherto my ordinary cour≈øe to follow hone≈øt coun≈øells, and to walke in open waies. I neuer wonted my ≈øelfe to holes and corners, to crafty ≈øhifts, but euermore to plaine and open de≈øignes. I neede not hide mine intentions for feare of any mortall man, that puffeth breath of life out of his no≈øtrils. Nor in any ≈øort doe I purpo≈øe, to ≈øet Iulian the Apo≈øtata before mine eyes, as a patterne for me to follow. Iulian of a Chri≈øtian became a Pagan: I profe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame faith of Chri≈øt ≈øtill, which I haue euer profe≈ø≈øed: Iulian went about his de≈øignes with crafty conueiances; I neuer with any of his captious and cunning ≈øleights: Iulian forced his ≈øubiects to infidelitie again≈øt I e≈øus Chri≈øt; I labour to induce my ≈øubiects vnto ≈øuch tearmes of loyalty towards my ≈øelfe, as Ie≈øus Chri≈øt hath pre≈øcribed and taught in his word. But how farre I differ from Iulian, it is to be ≈øeene more at large in my an≈øwere to Bellarmines Epi≈øtles written to Blackwell; from whence the Lord Cardinall borrowing this example, it might well haue be≈øeemed his Lord≈øhip to borrow likewi≈øe my an≈øwere from the ≈øame place.

Now as it mooues me nothing at all, to be drawne by his Lord≈øhip into ≈øu≈øpitions of this nature and qualitie: ≈øo by the pray≈øes, that he rockes me withall, I will neuer be lulled a≈øleepe. To commend a man for his knowledge, and withall to take from him the feare of God, is to admire a ≈øouldier for his goodly head of haire or his curled locks, and withall to call him ba≈øe coward, faint-hearted and fre≈øh-water ≈øouldier. Knowledge, wit, and learning in an hereticke, are of none other v≈øe and ≈øeruice, but only to make him the more culpable, & con≈øequently obnoxious to the more grieuous puni≈øhments. All vertues turne to vices, when they become the ≈øeruants of impietie. The hand-maids which the Soueraigne Lady Wi≈øedome calleth to be of her traine in the 9. Prouerb. are morall vertues, and humane ≈øciences; which then become pernicious, when they run away from their Soueraigne Lady-Mi≈øtris, and put ouer them≈øelues in ≈øeruice to the
diuel. What difference is betweene two men, both alike wanting the knowledge of God; the one furni≈øhed with arts and ciuill vertues, the other bruti≈øhly barbarous and of a deformed life, or of prophane maners? What is the difference betweene the≈øe two? I make this the onely difference: the fir≈øt goeth to hell with a better grace, and falleth into perdition with more facilitie, then the ≈øecond: But hee becommeth exceedingly wicked, euen threefold and fourefold abominable, if he wa≈øt his trea≈øure and ≈øtocke of ciuill vertues in per≈øecuting the Church of CHRIST: and if that may be layd in his di≈øh which was ca≈øt in Cae≈øars teeth, that in plaine ≈øobernes and well-≈øetled temper, he attempts the ruine of the Common-wealth, which from a drunken ≈øot might receiue perhaps a more ea≈øie fall. In briefe, I ≈øcorne all garlands of prai≈øes, which are not euer greene; but being dry and withered for want of ≈øap and radicall moy≈øture, doe flagge about barbarous Princes browes. I defie and renounce tho≈øe prai≈øes, which fit mee no more then they fit a Mahumetane King of Marocco. I conte≈øt again≈øt all prai≈øes which grace me with petie acce≈ø≈øories, but rob me of the principall, that one thing nece≈ø≈øary; namely, the feare and knowledge of my GOD: vnto who≈øe Maie≈øtie alone, I haue deuoted my Scepter, my ≈øword, my penne, my whole indu≈øtrie, my whole ≈øelfe, with all that is mine in whole and in part. I doe it, I doe it in all humble acknowledgement of his vn≈øpeakable mercie and fauour, who hath vouch≈øafed to deliuer me from the erroneous way of this aage, to deliuer my Kingdome from the Popes tyrannicall yoke, vnder which it hath lyen in times pa≈øt mo≈øt grieuou≈øly oppre≈ø≈øed: My Kingdom where God is now purely ≈øerued, and called vpon in a tongue which all the vulgar vnder≈øtand: My Kingdome, where the people may now reade the Scriptures without any ≈øpecial priuiledge from the Apo≈øtolike See, and with no le≈ø≈øe libertie then the people of Ephe≈øus, of Rome, and of Corinth did reade the holy Epi≈øtles, written to their Churches by S. Paul: My Kingdome, where the people now pay no longer any tribute by the poll for Papall indulgences,
Aliquot annis post, Apo≈øtolicae ≈øedis nuncius in Angliam ad colligendum S. Petri vectigal mi≈ø≈øus. O nuphri. in vit. Paul. 4. Vide & Math. Paris. as they did about an hundred yeeres pa≈øt, and are no longer compelled to the mart, for pardons beyond the Seas and mountaines, but haue them now freely offered from God, by the doctrine of the Go≈øpel preached at home within their owne ≈øeuerall pari≈øhes and iuri≈ødictions. If the Churches of my Kingdome, in the L. Cardinals accompt, bee mi≈øerable for the≈øe cau≈øes and the like; let him dreame on, and talke his plea≈øure: for my part I will euer auow, that more worth is our mi≈øery then all his felicitie. For the re≈øt, it ≈øhal by Gods grace be my daily endeauour and ≈øerious care, to pa≈ø≈øe my daies in ≈øhaping to my ≈øelfe ≈øuch a cour≈øe of life, that without ≈øhamefull calumniating of my per≈øon, it ≈øhall not re≈øt in the tip of any tongue, to touch my life with iu≈øt reprehen≈øion or blame. Nor am I ≈øo priuie to mine owne guiltine≈ø≈øe, as to thinke my ≈øtate ≈øo de≈øperate, ≈øo deplorable, as Popes haue made their owne: For ≈øome of them haue bene ≈øo open-hearted and ≈øo tongue-free, to pronounce that Popes them≈øelues, the key-bearers of Heauen and hell, cannot
be ≈øaued. Two Popes,
O ‚Ä¢ up. de vitis Ponti≈øan vit. Mar. 2. doeth te≈øtifie, that Marcel. al≈øo after Adr. an the 4. v≈øed the≈øe words: Non video quo modo qui Incum hunc arti≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ tenent, ≈øaluati po≈ø≈øint. reckoned among the be≈øt of the whole bunch or packe, namely, Adrian the IV. and Marcelline the II. haue both ≈øung one and the ≈øame note; that in their vnder≈øtanding they could not conceiue any rea≈øon why, or any meanes how tho≈øe that ≈øway the Popedome can be partakers of ≈øaluation; But for my particular, grounding my faith vpon the promi≈øes of God contained in the Go≈øpel, I doe confidently and a≈ø≈øuredly beleeue, that repenting me of my ≈øinnes, and repo≈øing my whole tru≈øt in the merits of IESVS CHRIST, I ≈øhall obtaine forgiuene≈ø≈øe of my ≈øinnes through his Name. Nor doe I feare, that I am now, or ≈øhall be hereafter ca≈øt out of the Churches lap and bo≈øome; that I now haue or hereafter ≈øhall haue no right to the Church as a putrified member thereof, ≈øo long as I do or ≈øhall cleaue to CHRIST IESVS, the Head of the Church: the appellation and name whereof, ≈øerueth in this corrupt aage, as a cloake to couer a thou≈øand new inuentions; and now no longer ≈øignifies the a≈ø≈øembly of the faithfull or ≈øuch as beleeue in IESVS CHRIST according to his word, but a certaine glorious o≈øtentation and temporall Monarchie, whereof the Pope for≈øooth is the ≈øupreame head.

But if the L. Cardinall by a≈ø≈øured and certaine knowledge (as perhaps he may by common fame) did vnder≈øtand the horrible con≈øpiracies that haue bin plotted and contriued, not again≈øt my per≈øon and life alone, but al≈øo again≈øt my whole ≈øtocke: if he rightly knew & were inly per≈øwaded, of how many fowle periuries & wicked trea≈øons, diuers Eccle≈øia≈øtical per≈øons haue bene lawfully conuicted: in ≈øtead of charging me with fal≈øe imputations, that I ≈øuffer not my Catholiks to fetch a ≈øigh, or to draw their breath; and that I thru≈øt my Catholikes vpon the ≈øharpe edge of puni≈øhment in euery kinde; he would, and might well, rather wonder, how I my ≈øelfe, after ≈øo many dangers run, after ≈øo many proditorious ≈ønares e≈øcaped, do yet fetch my owne breath, and yet practi≈øe Princely elemencie towards the ≈øaid Catholiks, notorious traÃÑ≈øgre≈ø≈øors of diuine & humane lawes. If the French king in the heart of his kingdom, ≈øhould nouri≈øh and fo≈øter ≈øuch a ne≈øt of ≈øtinging hornets and bu≈øie wa≈øps, I meane ≈øuch a pack of ≈øubiects, denying his ab≈øolute Soueraignty, as many Romane Catholiks of my Kingdome do mine: It may wel be doubted, whether the L. Cardinal would adui≈øe his king ≈øtil to feather the ne≈øt of the ≈øaid Catholiks, ≈øtil to keep them warme, ≈øtil to beare them with an ea≈øie and gentle hand: It may wel be doubted, whether his Lord≈øhip would extol their con≈øtancie, that would haue the courage to ≈øheath vp their ≈øwords in his Kings bowels, or blow vp his King with gun-powder, into the neather ≈øtation of the lowe≈øt regioÃÑ: It may wel be doubted, whether he would indure that Orator, who (like as him≈øelfe hath done) ≈øhould ≈øtir vp others to ≈øuffer Martyrdome after ≈øuch examples, and to imitate parricides & traitors in their con≈øtancy. The ≈øcope then of the L. Cardinall, in ≈øtriking the ≈øweet ≈øtrings, and ≈øounding the plea≈øant notes of prai≈øes, which faine he would fil mine eares withal; is only by his excellent skil in the mu≈øick of Oratory, to bewitch the harts of my ≈øubiects, to infatuate their minds, to ≈øettle them in a
re≈øolution to depriue me of my life. The rea≈øon: Becau≈øe the plotters and practi≈øers again≈øt my life, are honoured and rewarded with a glorious name of Martyrs: their con≈øtancie (what els?) is admired, when they ≈øuffer death for trea≈øon. Wheras hitherto during the time of my whole raigne to this day, (I ≈øpeake it in the word of a King, and trewth it ≈øelfe ≈øhall make good the Kings word) no man hath lo≈øt his life, no man hath indured the Racke, no man hath ≈øuffered corporall puni≈øhment in other kinds, meerely or ≈øimply, or in any degree of re≈øpect, for his con≈øcience in matter of religion; but for wicked con≈øpiring again≈øt my life, or E≈øtate, or Royall dignitie; or els for ≈øome notorious crime, or ≈øome ob≈øtinate and wilfull di≈øobedience: Of which traiterous and viperous brood, I commanded one to be hanged by the necke of late in Scotland; a Ie≈øuite of intolerable impudencie, who at his arraignment and publike triall, ≈øtiffely maintained, that I haue robbed the Pope of his right, and haue no manner of right in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of my Kingdome. His Lord≈øhip therefore in offering him≈øelfe to Martyrdome, after the rare example of Catholiks, as he ≈øaith, ≈øuffering all ≈øort of puni≈øhment in my Kingdome, doeth plainely profe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe a follower of traytors and parricides. The≈øe be the Worthies, the≈øe the heroicall ≈øpirits, the≈øe the honourable Captaines and Coronels, who≈øe vertuous parts neuer ≈øufficiently magnified and pray≈øed, his Lord≈øhippe propoundeth for imitation to the French Bi≈øhops. O the name of Martyrs, in olde times a ≈øacred name! how is it now derided and ≈øcoffed? how is it in the≈øe daies filthily prophaned? At la≈øt his Lord≈øhip commeth to the clo≈øe of his Oration, and bindes vp his whole harangue with a feate wreath of prai≈øes, proper to his King. He ≈øtyles the King the elde≈øt Sonne of the Church, a young ≈øhoot of the lilly, which King Salomon in all his Royaltie was not able to match. He leades vs by the hand into the plea≈øant meadowes of Hi≈øtories, there to learne vpon the very fir≈øt ≈øight and view, That ≈øo long ≈øo oft as the Kings of France embraced vnion, and kept good tearmes of concord with Popes and the Apo≈øtolike See; ≈øo long as the ≈øpou≈øe of the Church was pa≈øtured and fed among the lillies, all ≈øorts of ≈øpirituall and temporall graces abundantly ≈øhowred vpon their Crownes, and vpon their people: On the contrary, when they made any rent or ≈øeparation from the mo≈øt holy See; then the lillies were pricked and almo≈øt choaked with ≈øharpe thornes; they beganne to droope, to ≈øtoope, and to beare their beautifull heads downe to the very ground, vnder the ≈øtrong flawes and gu≈øts of boy≈øtrous windes and tempe≈øts.

My an≈øwere to this flouri≈øhing clo≈øe and vp≈øhot, ≈øhall be no le≈ø≈øe apert then apt. It ≈øauours not of good and faithfull ≈øeruice, to ≈ømooth and ≈øtroake the Kings head with a ≈øoft hand of oyled ≈øpeech, and in the meane time to take away the Crowne from his head, and to defile it with dirt. But let vs
try the cau≈øe by euidence of Hi≈øtorie, yea by the voice and verdict of experience; to ≈øee whether the glorious beauty of the French lillies hath beene at any time bla≈øted, and thereupon hath faded, by ≈øtarting a≈øide, and making ≈øeparation from the holy See. Vnder the raigne of King Philip the Faire, France was ble≈ø≈øed with peace and pro≈øperity, notwith≈øtanding ≈øome outragious acts done again≈øt the Papall See, and contumelious crying quittance by King Philip with the Pope. Lewis 12. in ranged battell defeated the armies of Pope Iulius 2. and his Confederates: proclaimed the ≈øaid Pope to be fallen from the Popedome: ≈øtamped certaine coynes and pieces of gold with a di≈øhonourable mot, euen to Rome it ≈øelfe, Rome is Babylon: yet ≈øo much was Lewis loued and honoured of his people, that by a peculiar title he was called, the Father of the Country. Greater ble≈ø≈øings of God, greater outward peace and plenty, greater inward peace with ≈øpirituall and cele≈øtiall trea≈øures, were neuer heaped vpon my Great Brittaine, then haue beene ≈øince my Great Brittaine became Great in the greate≈øt and chiefe≈øt re≈øpect of all; to wit, ≈øince my Great Brittaine hath ≈øhaken off the Popes yoke; ≈øince ≈øhe hath refu≈øed to receiue and to entertaine the Popes Legats, employed to collect S. Peters tribute or Peter-pence; ≈øince the Kings of England, my Great Brittaine, haue not beene the Popes va≈ø≈øals to doe him homage for their Crowne, and haue no more felt the la≈øhings, the ≈øcourgings of ba≈øe and beggarly Monkes. Of Holland, Zeland, and Fri≈øeland, what neede I ≈øpeake? yet a word and no more. Were they not a kinde of naked and bare people, of ≈ømall value, before God lighted the torch of the Go≈øpel, and aduanced it in tho≈øe Nations? were they not an ill fedde and ≈øcragged people, in compari≈øon of the ine≈øtimable wealth and pro≈øperity (both in all military actions and mechanicall trades, in trafficke as merchants, in marting as men of warre, in long nauigation for di≈øcouerie) to which they are now ray≈øed and mounted by the mercifull ble≈ø≈øing of God, ≈øince the darknes of Poperie hath beene ≈øcattered, and the bright Sunne of the Go≈øpel hath ≈øhined in tho≈øe Countryes? Behold the Venetian Republique: Hath ≈øhee now le≈ø≈øe beautie, le≈ø≈øe glory, le≈ø≈øe peace and pro≈øperitie, ≈øince ≈øhe lately fell to bicker and contend with the Pope? ≈øince ≈øhe hath wrung out of the Popes hand, the one of his two ≈øwords? ≈øince ≈øhe hath plumed and ≈øhaked his Temporall dominion? On the contrarie; after the French Kings had honoured the Popes, with munificent graunts and gifts of all the cities and territories, lands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, which they now hold in Italy, and the auncient Earledome of Auignon in France for an ouer-plus; were they not rudely recompenced, and homely handled by their mo≈øt ingratefull fee-farmers and copy-holders? Haue not Popes forged a donation of Constantine, of purpo≈øe to blot out all memory of Pepins and Charlemaignes donation? Haue they not vexed and troubled the State? haue they not whetted the ≈øonnes of Lewis the Courteous again≈øt their owne Father, who≈øe life was a patterne and example of innocencie? Haue they not by their infinite exactions, robbed and ≈øcoured
the Kingdome of all their trea≈øure? Were not the Kings of France, driuen to ≈øtoppe their violent cour≈øes by the pragmaticall ≈øanction? Did they not ≈øundry times interdict the Kingdome, degrade the Kings, ≈øolicite the neighbour-Princes to inuade and lay hold on the Kingdome, and ≈øtirre vp the people again≈øt the King, whereby a gate was opened to a world of troubles and parricides? Did not Rauaillac render this rea≈øon for his mon≈øtrous and horrible attempt, That King Henry had a de≈øigne to warre with God, becau≈øe he had a de≈øigne to take armes again≈øt his Holine≈ø≈øe, who is God? This makes me to wonder, what mooued the L. Cardinall to mar≈øhall the la≈øt ciuill warres and motions in France, in the ranke of examples of vnhappy ≈øeparation from the Pope, when the Pope him≈øelfe was the trumpetor of the ≈øame trouble≈øome motions. If the Pope had bene wronged and offended by the French King, or his people, and the Kingdome of France had been ≈øcourged with pe≈øtilence, or famine, or ≈øome other calamitie by forraine enemies; it might haue beene taken in probabilitie, as a vengeance of God for ≈øome iniurie done vnto his Vicar: But his Holine≈ø≈øe being the roote, the ground, the ma≈øter-workeman and artificer of all the≈øe mi≈øchiefes; how can it be ≈øaid, that God puni≈øheth any iniurie done to the Pope? but rather that his Holine≈ø≈øe doth reuenge his owne quarrell, and which is wor≈øt of all, when his Holine≈ø≈øe hath no iu≈øt cau≈øe of quarrell or offence. Now then; to exhort a Nation (as the L. Cardinall hath done) by the remembrance of former calamities, to curry fauour with the Pope, and to hold a ≈øtrict vnion with his Holine≈ø≈øe, is no exhortation to beare the Pope any re≈øpect of loue, or of reuerence, but rather a rubbing of memory, and a calling to minde of tho≈øe grieuous calamities, whereof the Pope hath been the only occa≈øion. It is al≈øo a threatning and obtruding of the Popes terrible thunder-bolts, which neuer ≈øcorched nor parched any skinne, (except crauens and meticulous bodies) and haue brought many great ≈øhowres of ble≈ø≈øings vpon my Kingdome.

As for France, if ≈øhe hath enioyed pro≈øperity in the times of her good agreement with Popes, it is becau≈øe the Pope ≈øeekes the amity of Princes that are in pro≈øperitie, haue the meanes to curbe his preten≈øions, and to put him to ≈øome plunge. Kings are not in pro≈øperity, becau≈øe the Pope holds amitie with Kings; but his Holine≈ø≈øe v≈øeth all deui≈øes, & ≈øeeketh all meanes to haue amitie with Kings, becau≈øe he ≈øees them flouri≈øh & ≈øayle with pro≈øperous winds. The ≈øwallow is no cau≈øe, but a companion of the ≈øpring: the Pope is no worker of a Kingdoms felicity, but a wooer of kings when they ≈øit in felicities lap: he is no founder, but a follower of their good fortunes. On the other ≈øide: let a Kingdome fall into ≈øome grieuous di≈øa≈øter or calamitie, let ciuill warres boile in the bowels of the Kingdom; ciuil wars no le≈ø≈øe dangerous to the State, then fearefull and grieuous to the people; who ri≈øeth ≈øooner then the Pope, who ru≈øheth ≈øooner into the troubled ≈øtreames then the Pope, who thru≈øteth him≈øelfe ≈øooner into the heate of the quarrell then the Pope, who runneth ≈øooner to rai≈øe his gaine by the publike wrack then the
Pope, and all vnder colour of a heart wounded and bleeding for the ≈øaluation of ≈øoules? If the lawfull King happen to be foyled, to be oppre≈ø≈øed, and thereupon the State by his fall to get a new ma≈øter by the Popes practi≈øe; then the ≈øaid new ma≈øter mu≈øt hold the Kingdome as of the Popes free gift, and rule or guide the ≈øterne of the State at his becke, and by his in≈øtruction. If the fir≈øt and right Lord, in de≈øpite of all the Popes fulminations and fireworkes, ≈øhall get the honourable day, and vpper hand of his enemies; then the holy Father with a cheerfull and plea≈øant grace, yea with fatherly gratulation, opens the rich cabinet of his iewells, I meane the trea≈øurie of his indulgences, and falls now to dandle and cocker the King in his fatherly lap, who≈øe throat if he could, he would haue cut not long before.

This pe≈øtilent mi≈øchiefe hath now a long time taken roote, and is growne to a great head in the Chri≈øtian world, through the ≈øecret, but iu≈øt iudgement of God; by whom Chri≈øtian Kings haue beene≈ømitten with a ≈øpirit of dizzine≈ø≈øe: Chri≈øtian Kings, who for many aages pa≈øt haue liued in ignorance, without any ≈øound in≈øtruction, without any trew ≈øen≈øe and right feeling of their owne right and power, while≈øt vnder a ≈øhadow of Religion and fal≈øe cloake of pietie, their Kingdomes haue beene ouer-burdened, yea ouer-borne with tributes, and their Crownes made to ≈øtoope euen to mi≈øerable bondage. That God in who≈øe hand the hearts of Kings are poi≈øed, and at his plea≈øure turned as the water-cour≈øes; that mighty God alone, in his good time, is able to rouze them out of ≈øo deepe a ≈ølumber, and to take order (their drowzy fits once ouer and ≈øhaken off with heroicall ≈øpirits) that Popes hereafter ≈øhall play no more vpon their patience, nor pre≈øume to put bits and ≈ønaffles in their noble mouthes, to the binding vp of their power with weake ≈øcruples, like mighty buls lead about by litle children with a ≈ømall twi≈øted thred. To that God, that King of Kings I deuote my ≈øcepter; at his feet in all humblenes I lay downe my Crowne; to his holy decrees and commaunds I will euer be a faithfull ≈øeruant, and in his battels a faithfull champion. To conclude; in this iu≈øt cau≈øe and quarrell, I dare ≈øend the challenge, and will require no ≈øecond, to maintaine as a defendant of honour, that my brother-Princes and my ≈øelfe, whom God hath aduanced vpon the Throne of Soueraigne Maie≈øtie and ≈øupreame dignity, doe hold the Royall dignitie of his Maie≈øtie alone; to who≈øe ≈øeruice, as a mo≈øt humble homager and va≈ø≈øall, I con≈øecrate all the glory, honour, ≈øplendor, and lu≈øtre of my earthly Kingdomes.

div.head: A SPEACH, AS IT WAS DELIVERED IN THE VPPER HOVSE OF THE PARLIAMENT TO THE LORDS SPIRITVALL AND Temporall, and to the Knights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes there a≈ø≈øembled, ON MVNDAY THE XIX. DAY OF MARCH 1603. BEING THE FIRST DAY OF THE fir≈øt Parliament.
div.p:
IT did no ≈øooner plea≈øe God to lighten his hand, and relent the violence of his deuouring Angel again≈øt the poore people of this Citie, but as ≈øoone did I re≈øolue to call this Parliament, and that for three chiefe and principall rea≈øons: The fir≈øt whereof is, (and which of it ≈øelfe, although there were no more, is not onely a ≈øufficient, but a mo≈øt full and nece≈ø≈øary ground and rea≈øon for conuening of this A≈ø≈øembly) This fir≈øt rea≈øon I ≈øay is, That you who are here pre≈øently a≈ø≈øembled to repre≈øent the Body of this whole Kingdome, and of all ≈øorts of people within the ≈øame, may with your owne eares heare, and that I out of mine owne mouth may deliuer vnto you the a≈ø≈øurance of my due thankefulnes for your ≈øo ioyfull and generall applau≈øe to the declaring and receiuing of mee in this Seate (which GOD by my Birthright and lineall de≈øcent had in the fulne≈ø≈øe of time prouided for me) and that, immediatly after it plea≈øed God to call your late Soueraigne of famous memory, full of dayes, but fuller of immortall trophes of Honour, out of this tran≈øitorie life. Not that I am able to expre≈ø≈øe
by wordes, or vtter by eloquence the viue Image of mine inward thankfulnes, but onely that out of mine owne mouth you may re≈øt a≈ø≈øured to expect that mea≈øure of thankefulnes at my hands, which is according to the infinitenes of your de≈øerts, and to my inclination and abilitie for requitall of the ≈øame. Shall I euer? nay, can I euer be able, or rather ≈øo vnable in memorie, as to forget your vnexpected readine≈ø≈øe and alacritie, your euer memorable re≈øolution, and your mo≈øt wonderfull coniunction and harmonie of your hearts in declaring and embracing mee as your vndoubted and lawfull King and Gouernour? Or ≈øhall it euer bee blotted out of my minde, how at my fir≈øt entrie into this Kingdome, the people of all ≈øorts rid and ran, nay rather flew to meet mee? their eyes flaming nothing but ≈øparkles of affection, their mouthes and tongues vttering nothing but ≈øounds of ioy, their hands, feete, and all the re≈øt of their members in their ge≈øtures di≈øcouering a pa≈ø≈øionate longing, and earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe to meete and embrace their new Soueraigne. Quid ergo retribuam? Shall I allow in my ≈øelfe, that which I could neuer beare with in another? No I mu≈øt plainely and freely confe≈ø≈øe here in all your audiences, that I did euer naturally ≈øo farre mi≈ølike a tongue to ≈ømoothe, and diligent in paying their creditors with lip payment and verball thankes, as I euer ≈øu≈øpected that ≈øort of people meant not to pay their debtors in more ≈øub≈øtantiall ≈øort of coyne. And therefore for expre≈ø≈øing of my thankefulne≈ø≈øe, I mu≈øt re≈øort vnto the other two rea≈øons of my conuening of this Parliament, by them in action to vtter my thankefulne≈ø≈øe: Both the ≈øaid rea≈øons hauing but one ground, which is the deedes, whereby all the dayes of my life, I am by Gods grace to expre≈ø≈øe my ≈øaid thankfulne≈ø≈øe towards you, but diuided in this, That in the fir≈øt of the≈øe two, mine actions of thankes, are ≈øo in≈øeparably conioyned with my Per≈øon, as they are in a maner become indiuidually annexed to the ≈øame: In the other rea≈øon, mine actions are ≈øuch, as I may either doe them, or leaue them vndone, although by Gods grace I hope neuer to be weary of the doing of them.

As to the fir≈øt: It is the ble≈ø≈øings which God hath in my Per≈øon be≈øtowed vpon you all, wherein I prote≈øt, I doe more glorie at the ≈øame for your weale, then for any particular re≈øpect of mine owne reputation, or aduantage therein.

THe fir≈øt then of the≈øe ble≈ø≈øings, which God hath ioyntly with my Per≈øon ≈øent vnto you, is outward Peace: that is, peace abroad with all forreine neighbours: for I thanke God I may iu≈øtly ≈øay, that neuer ≈øince I was a King, I either receiued wrong of any other Chri≈øtian Prince or State, or did wrong to any: I haue euer, I prai≈øe God, yet kept Peace and amitie with all, which hath bene ≈øo farre tyed to my per≈øon, as at my comming here you are witne≈ø≈øes I found the State embarqued in a great and tedious warre, and onely by mine arriuall here, and by the Peace in my Per≈øon, is now amitie kept, where warre was before, which is no ≈ømal
ble≈ø≈øing to a Chri≈øtian Common-wealth: for by Peace abroad with their neighbours the Townes flouri≈øh, the Merchants become rich, the Trade doeth encrea≈øe, and the people of all ≈øorts of the Land enioy free libertie to exerci≈øe them≈øelues in their ≈øeuerall vocations without perill or di≈øturbance. Not that I thinke this outward Peace ≈øo vn≈øeparably tyed to my Per≈øon, as I dare a≈ø≈øuredly promi≈øe to my ≈øelfe and to you, the certaine continuance thereof: but thus farre I can very well a≈ø≈øure you and in the word of a King promi≈øe vnto you, That I ≈øhall neuer giue the fir≈øt occa≈øion of the breach thereof, neither ≈øhall I euer be moued for any particular or priuate pa≈ø≈øion of mind to interrupt your publique Peace, except I be forced thereunto, either for reparation of the honour of the Kingdom, or el≈øe by nece≈ø≈øitie for the weale and pre≈øeruation of the ≈øame: In which ca≈øe, a ≈øecure and honourable warre mu≈øt be preferred to an vn≈øecure and di≈øhonourable Peace: yet doe I hope by my experience of the by-pa≈øt ble≈ø≈øings of Peace, which God hath ≈øo long euer ≈øince my Birth be≈øtowed vpon mee, that hee wil not be weary to continue the ≈øame, nor repent him of his grace towards me, transferring that ≈øentence of King Dauids vpon his by-pa≈øt victories of warre, to mine of Peace, That, that God who pre≈øerued me from the deuouring iawes of the Beare and of the Lion, and deliuered them into my hands, ≈øhall al≈øo now grant me victory ouer that vncircumci≈øed Philistine.

BVt although outward Peace be a great ble≈ø≈øing; yet is it as farre inferiour to peace within, as Ciuill warres are more cruell and vnnaturall then warres abroad. And therefore the ≈øecond great ble≈ø≈øing that GOD hath with my Per≈øon ≈øent vnto you, is Peace within, and that in a double forme. Fir≈øt, by my de≈øcent lineally out of the loynes of Henry the ≈øeuenth, is reunited and confirmed in mee the Vnion of the two Princely Ro≈øes of the two Hou≈øes of LANCASTER and YORKE, whereof that King of happy memorie was the fir≈øt Vniter, as he was al≈øo the fir≈øt ground-layer of the other Peace. The lamentable and mi≈øerable euents by the Ciuill and bloody di≈ø≈øention betwixt the≈øe two Hou≈øes was ≈øo great and ≈øo late, as it need not be renewed vnto your memories: which, as it was fir≈øt ≈øetled and vnited in him, ≈øo is it now reunited and confirmed in me, being iu≈øtly and lineally de≈øcended, not onely of that happie coniunction, but of both the Branches thereof many times before. But the Vnion of the≈øe two princely Hou≈øes, is nothing comparable to the Vnion of two ancient and famous Kingdomes, which is the other inward Peace annexed to my Per≈øon.

And here I mu≈øt craue your patiences for a little ≈øpace, to giue me leaue to di≈øcour≈øe more particularly of the benefits that doe ari≈øe of that Vnion which is made in my blood, being a matter that mo≈øt properly belongeth to me to ≈øpeake of, as the head wherein that great Body is vnited. And fir≈øt, if we were to looke no higher then to naturall and Phy≈øicall rea≈øons, we may ea≈øily be per≈øwaded of the great benefits that by that Vnion do redound
to the whole I≈øland: for if twentie thou≈øand men be a ≈øtrong Armie, is not the double thereof, fourtie thou≈øand, a double the ≈øtronger Armie? If a Baron enricheth him≈øelfe with double as many lands as hee had before, is he not double the greater? Nature teacheth vs, that Mountaines are made of Motes, and that at the fir≈øt, Kingdomes being diuided, and euery particular Towne or little Countie, as Tyrants or V≈øurpers could obtaine the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, a Segniorie apart, many of the≈øe little Kingdomes are now in proce≈ø≈øe of time, by the ordinance of God, ioyned into great Monarchies, whereby they are become powerfull within them≈øelues to defend them≈øelues from all outward inua≈øions, and their head and gouernour thereby enabled to redeeme them from forreine a≈ø≈øaults, and puni≈øh priuate tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions within. Do we not yet remember, that this Kingdome was diuided into ≈øeuen little Kingdomes, be≈øides Wales? And is it not now the ≈øtronger by their vnion? And hath not the vnion of Wales to England added a greater ≈øtrength thereto? Which though it was a great Principalitie, was nothing comparable in greatne≈ø≈øe and power to the ancient and famous Kingdome of Scotland. But what ≈øhould we ≈øticke vpon any naturall appearance, when it is manife≈øt that God by his Almightie prouidence hath preordained it ≈øo to be? Hath not God fir≈øt vnited the≈øe two Kingdomes both in Language, Religion, and ≈øimilitude of maners? Yea, hath hee not made vs all in one I≈øland, compa≈ø≈øed with one Sea, and of it ≈øelfe by nature ≈øo indiui≈øible, as almo≈øt tho≈øe that were borderers them≈øelues on the late Borders, cannot di≈øtingui≈øh, nor know, or di≈øcerne their owne limits? The≈øe two Countries being ≈øeparated neither by Sea, nor great Riuer, Mountaine, nor other ≈øtrength of nature, but onely by little ≈ømall brookes, or demoli≈øhed little walles, ≈øo as rather they were diuided in apprehen≈øion, then in effect; And now in the end and fulne≈ø≈øe of time vnited, the right and title of both in my Per≈øon, alike lineally de≈øcended of both the Crownes, whereby it is now become like a little World within it ≈øelfe, being intrenched and fortified round about with a naturall, and yet admirable ≈øtrong pond or ditch, whereby all the former feares of this Nation are now quite cut off: The other part of the I≈øland being euer before now not onely the place of landing to all ≈øtrangers, that was to make inua≈øion here, but likewi≈øe moued by the enemies of this State by vntimely incur≈øions, to make inforced diuer≈øion from their Conque≈øts, for defending them≈øelues at home, and keeping ≈øure their backe-doore, as then it was called, which was the greate≈øt hinderance and let that euer my Predece≈ø≈øors of this Nation gat in di≈øturbing them from their many famous and glorious conque≈øts abroad: What God hath conioyned then, let no man ≈øeparate. I am the Husband, and all the whole I≈øle is my lawfull Wife; I am the Head, and it is my Body; I am the Shepherd, and it is my flocke: I hope therefore no man will be ≈øo vnrea≈øonable as to thinke that I that am a Chri≈øtian King vnder the Go≈øpel, ≈øhould be a Polygami≈øt and husband to two wiues; that I being the Head, ≈øhould haue a diuided and mon≈øtrous
Body; or that being the Shepheard to ≈øo faire a Flocke (who≈øe fold hath no wall to hedge it but the foure Seas) ≈øhould haue my Flocke parted in two. But as I am a≈ø≈øured, that no hone≈øt Subiect of what≈øoeuer degree within my whole dominions, is le≈ø≈øe glad of this ioyfull Vnion then I am; So may the friuolous obiection of any that would bee hinderers of this worke, which God hath in my Per≈øon already e≈øtabli≈øhed, bee ea≈øily an≈øwered, which can be none, except ≈øuch as are either blinded with Ignorance, or els tran≈øported with Malice, being vnable to liue in a well gouerned Commonwealth, and onely delighting to fi≈øh in troubled waters. For if they would ≈øtand vpon their reputation and priuiledges of any of the Kingdomes, I pray you was not both the Kingdomes Monarchies from the beginning, and con≈øequently could euer the Body bee counted without the Head, which was euer vn≈øeparably ioyned thereunto? So that as Honour and Priuiledges of any of the Kingdomes could not be diuided from their Soueraigne; So are they now confounded & ioyned in my Per≈øon, who am equall and alike kindly Head to you both. When this Kingdome of England was diuided into ≈øo many little Kingdoms as I told you before; one of them behooued to eate vp another, till they were all vnited in one. Two e≈øpeciall cau≈øes moued mee to be ≈øo open handed: whereof the one was rea≈øonable and honourable; but the other I will not bee a≈øhamed to confe≈ø≈øe vnto you, proceeded of mine owne infirmitie.
