The other which proceeded out of mine owne infirmitie, was the multitude and importunitie of Sutors. But although rea≈øon come by infu≈øion in a maner, yet experience groweth with time and labour: And therefore doe I not doubt, but experience in time comming will both teach the particular Subiects of this Kingdome, not to be ≈øo importune and vndi≈øcreete in crauing: And mee not to be ≈øo ea≈øily and lightly mooued, in granting that which may be harmefull to my E≈øtate, and con≈øequently to the whole Kingdome.

And thus hauing at length declared vnto you my minde in all the points, for the which I called this Parliament: My conclu≈øion ≈øhall onely now be to excu≈øe my ≈øelfe, in ca≈øe you haue not found ≈øuch Eloquence in my Speech, as peraduenture you might haue looked for at my hands. I might, if I li≈øt, alledge the great weight of my Affaires and my continuall bu≈øine≈ø≈øe and di≈øtraction, that I could neuer haue lea≈øure to thinke vpon what I was to ≈øpeake, before I came to the place where I was to ≈øpeake: And I might al≈øo alledge that my fir≈øt ≈øight of this ≈øo famous and Honourable an A≈ø≈øembly, might likewi≈øe breede ≈øome impediment. But
leauing the≈øe excu≈øes, I will plainely and freely in my maner tell you the trew cau≈øe of it, which is; That it becommeth a King, in my opinion, to v≈øe no other Eloquence then plainne≈ø≈øe and ≈øinceritie. By plainene≈ø≈øe I meane, that his Speeches ≈øhould be ≈øo cleare and voyd of all ambiguitie, that they may not be throwne, nor rent a≈øunder in contrary ≈øences like the old Oracles of the Pagan gods. And by ≈øinceritie, I vnder≈øtand that vprightne≈ø≈øe and hone≈øtie which ought to be in a Kings whole Speeches and actions: That as farre as a King is in Honour erected aboue any of his Subiects, ≈øo farre ≈øhould he ≈øtriue in ≈øinceritie to be aboue them all, and that his tongue ≈øhould be euer the trew Me≈ø≈øenger of his heart: and this ≈øort of Eloquence may you euer a≈ø≈øuredly looke for at my hands.

div.head: A SPEACH IN THE PARLIAMENT HOVSE, AS NEERE THE VERY WORDS AS COVLD BE GATHERED at the in≈øtant.
div.p: MY Lords Spirituall and Temporall, and you the Knights and Burge≈ø≈øes of this Parliament, It was farre from my thoughts till very lately before my comming to this place, that this Subiect ≈øhould haue bene mini≈øtred vnto mee, whereupon I am now to ≈øpeake. But now it ≈øo falleth out, That whereas in the preceding Se≈ø≈øion of this Parliament, the principall occa≈øion of my Speach was, to thanke and congratulate all you of this Hou≈øe, and in you, all the whole Common-wealth (as being the repre≈øentatiue body of the State) for your ≈øo willing, and louing receiuing and embracing of mee in that place, which GOD and Nature by de≈øcent of blood, had in his owne time prouided for me: So now my Subiect is, to ≈øpeake of a farre greater Thanke≈øgiuing then before I gaue to you, being to a farre greater per≈øon, which is to GOD, for the great and miraculous Deliuery he hath at this time granted to me, and to you all, and con≈øequently to the whole body of this E≈øtate.

I mu≈øt therefore begin with this old and mo≈øt approued Sentence of Diuinitie, Mi≈øericordia Dei ≈øupra omnia opera eius. For Almightie God did not furni≈øh ≈øo great matter to his glory by the Creation of this great World, as he did by the Redemption of the ≈øame. Neither did his generation of the little world in our old & fir≈øt Adam, ≈øo much ≈øet forth the prai≈øes of God in his Iu≈øtice and Mercy, as did our Regeneration in the la≈øt & ≈øecond Adam.

And now I mu≈øt craue a little pardon of you. That ≈øince Kings are in the word of GOD it ≈øelfe called Gods, as being his Lieutenants and Vicegerents on earth, and ≈øo adorned and furni≈øhed with ≈øome ≈øparkles of the Diuinitie; to compare ≈øome of the workes of GOD the great KING, towards the whole and generall world, to ≈øome of his workes towards mee, and this little world of my Dominions, compa≈ø≈øed and ≈øeuered by the Sea from the re≈øt of the earth. Foras GOD for the iu≈øt puni≈øhment of the fir≈øt great ≈øinnes in the originall world, when the ≈øonnes of GOD went in to the daughters of men, and the cup of their iniquities of all ≈øorts was filled, and heaped vp to the full, did by a generall deluge and ouerflowing of waters, baptize the world to a generall de≈øtruction, and not to a generall purgation (onely excepted NOAH and his family, who did repent and beleeue the threatnings of GODS iudgement:) So now when the world ≈øhall waxe old as a garment, and that all the impieties and ≈øinnes that can be deui≈øed again≈øt both the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Table, haue and ≈øhall bee committed to the full mea≈øure; GOD is to puni≈øh the world the ≈øecond time by fire, to the generall de≈øtruction and not purgation thereof: Although as was done in the former to NOAH and his family by the waters; So ≈øhall all we that beleeue be likewi≈øe purged, and not de≈øtroyed by the fire. In the like ≈øort, I ≈øay, I may iu≈øtly compare the≈øe two great and fearefull Dome≈ø-dayes, wherewith GOD threatned to de≈øtroy mee and all you of this little world that haue intere≈øt in me. For although I confe≈ø≈øe, as all mankinde, ≈øo chiefly Kings, as being in the higher places like the high Trees, or ≈øtaye≈øt Mountaines, and ≈øteepe≈øt Rockes, are mo≈øt ≈øubiect to the dayly tempe≈øts of innumerable dangers; and I among≈øt all other Kings haue euer bene ≈øubiect vnto them, not onely euer ≈øince my birth, but euen as I may iu≈øtly ≈øay, before my birth: and while I was yet in my mothers belly: yet haue I bene expo≈øed to two more ≈øpeciall and greater dangers then all the re≈øt.

The fir≈øt of them, in the Kingdome where I was borne, and pa≈ø≈øed the fir≈øt part of my life: And the la≈øt of them here, which is the greate≈øt. In the former I ≈øhould haue bene baptized in blood, and in my de≈øtruction not onely the Kingdom wherein I then was, but ye al≈øo by your future intere≈øt, ≈øhould haue ta≈øted of my ruine: Yet it plea≈øed GOD to deliuer mee, as it were from the very brinke of death, from the point of the dagger, and ≈øo to purge me by my thankefull acknowledgement of ≈øo great a benefite. But in this, which did ≈øo lately fall out, and which was a de≈øtruction prepared not for me alone, but for you all that are here pre≈øent, and wherein no ranke, aage, nor ≈øexe ≈øhould haue bene ≈øpared; This was not a crying ≈øinne of blood, as the former, but it may well bee called a roaring, nay a thundring ≈øinne of fire and brim≈øtone, from the which GOD hath ≈øo miraculou≈øly deliuered vs all. What I can ≈øpeake of this, I know not: Nay rather, what can I not ≈øpeake of it? And therefore I mu≈øt for horror ≈øay with the Poet, Vox faucibus haeret.

In this great and horrible attempt, Three miraculous euents be to be ob≈øerued in the Attempt. whereof the like was neuer either heard or read, I ob≈øerue three wonderfull, or rather miraculous euents.

FIr≈øt, in the crueltie of the Plot it ≈øelfe, The crucltie of the Plot. wherein cannot be enough admired the horrible and fearefull crueltie of their deuice, which was not onely for the de≈øtruction of my Per≈øon, nor of my Wife and po≈øteritie onely, but of the whole body of the State in generall; wherein ≈øhould neither haue bene ≈øpared, or di≈øtinction made of yong nor of old, of great nor of ≈ømall, of man nor of woman: The whole Nobilitie, the whole reuerend Clergie, Bi≈øhops, and mo≈øt part of the good Preachers, the mo≈øt part of the Knights and Gentrie; yea, and if that any in this Societie were fauourers of their profe≈ø≈øion, they ≈øhould all haue gone one way: The whole Iudges of the land, with the mo≈øt of the Lawyers, and the whole Clerkes: And as the wretch him≈øelfe which is in the Tower, doeth confe≈ø≈øe, it was purpo≈øely deui≈øed by them, and concluded to be done in this hou≈øe; That where the cruell Lawes (as they ≈øay) were made again≈øt their Religion, both place and per≈øons ≈øhould all be de≈øtroyed and blowne vp at once. Three wayes how mankind may come to death. And then con≈øider therewithall the cruel fourme of that practi≈øe: for by three different ≈øorts in generall may mankinde be put to death.

The fir≈øt, by other men, and rea≈øonable creatures, which is lea≈øt cruell: By Man. for then both defence of men again≈øt men may be expected, and likewi≈øe who knoweth what pitie God may ≈øtirre vp in the hearts of the Actors at the very in≈øtant? be≈øides the many wayes and meanes, whereby men may e≈øcape in ≈øuch a pre≈øent furie.

And the ≈øecond way more cruell then that, By vnrea≈øonable creatures. is by Animal and vnrea≈øonable creatures: for as they haue le≈ø≈øe pitie then men, ≈øo is it a greater horror and more vnnaturall for men to deale with them: But yet with them both re≈øi≈øtance may auaile, and al≈øo ≈øome pitie may be had, as was in the Lions, in who≈øe denne Daniel was throwne; or that thankefull Lion, that had the Romane in his mercie.

But the third, which is mo≈øt cruel and vnmercifull of all, By in≈øen≈øible things. is the de≈øtruction by in≈øen≈øible and inanimate things, and among≈øt them all, the mo≈øt cruell are the two Elements of Water and Fire; and of tho≈øe two, the fire mo≈øtraging and mercile≈ø≈øe.

SEcondly, The ≈ømall ground the Con≈øpirators had to moue them. how wonderfull it is when you ≈øhall thinke vpon the ≈ømall, or rather no ground, whereupon the practi≈øers were enti≈øed to inuent this Tragedie. For if the≈øe Con≈øpirators had onely bene bankrupt per≈øons, or di≈øcontented vpon occa≈øion of any di≈øgraces done vnto them; this might haue ≈øeemed to haue bene but a worke of reuenge. But for my owne part, as I≈øcarcely euer knew any of them, ≈øo cannot they alledge ≈øo much as a pretended cau≈øe of griefe: And the wretch him≈øelfe in hands doeth confe≈ø≈øe, That there was no cau≈øe moouing him or
them, but meerely and only Religion. And ≈øpecially that chri≈øtian men, at lea≈øt ≈øo called, Engli≈øhmen, borne within the Countrey, and one of the ≈øpecials of them my ≈øworne Seruant in an Honourable place, ≈øhould practi≈øe the de≈øtruction of their King, his Po≈øterity, their Countrey and all: Wherein their following ob≈øtinacie is ≈øo ioyned to their former malice, as the fellow him≈øelfe that is in hand, cannot be moued to di≈øcouer any ≈øignes or notes of repentance, except onely that he doeth not yet ≈øtand to auow, that he repents for not being able to performe his intent.

THirdly, Miraculous euent, the di≈øcouerie. the di≈øcouery hereof is not a little wonderfull, which would bee thought the more miraculous by you all, if you were a≈øwell acquainted with my naturall di≈øpo≈øition, as tho≈øe are who be neere about me: For as I euer did hold Su≈øpition to be the ≈øicknes of a Tyrant, ≈øo was I ≈øo farre vpon the other extremity, as I rather contemned all aduerti≈øements, or apprehen≈øions of practi≈øes. And yet now at this time was I ≈øo farre contrary to my ≈øelfe, as when the Letter was ≈øhewed to me by my Secretary, wherein a generall ob≈øcure aduerti≈øement was giuen of ≈øome dangerous blow at this time, I did vpon the in≈øtant interpret and apprehend ≈øome darke phra≈øes therein, contrary to the ordinary Grammer con≈øtruction of them, (and in an other ≈øort then I am ≈øure any Diuine, or Lawyer in any Vniuer≈øitie would haue taken them) to be meant by this horrible forme of blowing vs vp all by Powder; And thereupon ordered that ≈øearch to be made, whereby the matter was di≈øcouered, and the man apprehended: whereas if I had apprehended or interpreted it to any other ≈øort of danger, no worldly proui≈øion or preuention could haue made vs e≈øcape our vtter de≈øtruction.

And in that al≈øo was there a wonderfull prouidence of God, that when the party him≈øelfe was taken, he was but new come out of his hou≈øe from working, hauing his Fireworke for kindling ready in his pocket, wherewith as he confe≈ø≈øeth, if he had bene taken but immediatly before when he was in the Hou≈øe, he was re≈øolued to haue blowen vp him≈øelfe with his Takers.

One thing for mine owne part haue I cau≈øe to thanke GOD in, That if GOD for our ≈øinnes had ≈øuffered their wicked intents to haue preuailed, it ≈øhould neuer haue bene ≈øpoken nor written in aages ≈øucceeding, that I had died ingloriou≈øly in an Ale-hou≈øe, a Stews, or ≈øuch vile place, but mine end ≈øhould haue bene with the mo≈øt Honourable and be≈øt company, and in that mo≈øt Honourable and fitte≈øt place for a King to be in, for doing the turnes mo≈øt proper to his Office. And the more haue We all cau≈øe to thanke and magnifie GOD for this his mercifull Deliuery; And ≈øpecially I for my part, that he hath giuen me yet once leaue, what≈øoeuer ≈øhould come of me hereafter, to a≈ø≈øemble you in this Honourable place; And here in this place, where our generall de≈øtruction ≈øhould haue bene, to magnifie and prai≈øe him for Our generall deliuery: That I may iu≈øtly now ≈øay of mine
Enemies and yours, as Dauid doeth often ≈øay in the P≈øalme, Inciderunt in foueam quam fecerunt. And ≈øince Scipio an Ethnick, led onely by the light of Nature, That day when he was accu≈øed by the Tribunes of the people of Rome for mi≈øpending and wa≈øting in his Punick warres the Cities Trea≈øure, euen vpon the ≈øudden brake out with that diuer≈øion of them from that matter, calling them to remembrance how that day, was the day of the yeere, wherein God had giuen them ≈øo great a victory again≈øt Hannibal, and therefore it was fitter for them all, leauing other matters, to runne to the Temple to prai≈øe God for that ≈øo great deliuery, which the people did all follow with one applau≈øe: How much more cau≈øe haue we that are Chri≈øtians to be≈øtow this time in this place for Thanke≈ø-giuing to God for his great Mercy, though we had had no other errant of a≈ø≈øembling here at this time? wherein if I haue ≈øpoken more like a Diuine then would ≈øeeme to belong to this place, the matter it ≈øelfe mu≈øt plead for mine excu≈øe: For being here commen to thanke God for a diuine worke of his Mercy, how can I ≈øpeake of this deliuerance of vs from ≈øo helli≈øh a practi≈øe, ≈øo well as in language of Diuinitie, which is the direct oppo≈øite to ≈øo damnable an intention? And therefore may I iu≈øtly end this purpo≈øe, as I did begin it with this Sentence, The Mercie of God is aboue all his workes.

It re≈øteth now that I ≈øhould ≈øhortly informe you what is to bee done hereafter vpon the occa≈øion of this horrible and ≈øtrange accident. As for your part that are my faithfull and louing Subiects of all degrees, I know that your hearts are ≈øo burnt vp with zeale in this errant, and your tongues ≈øo ready to vtter your duetifull affections, and your hands and feete ≈øo bent to concurre in the execution thereof, (for which as I neede not to ≈øpurre you, ≈øo can I not but prai≈øe you for the ≈øame:) As it may very well be po≈ø≈øible that the zeale of your hearts ≈øhall make ≈øome of you in your ≈øpeaches ra≈øhly to blame ≈øuch as may bee innocent of this attempt; But vpon the other part I wi≈øh you to con≈øider, That I would be ≈øorie that any being innocent of this practi≈øe, either dome≈øticall or forraine, ≈øhould receiue blame or harme for the ≈øame. For although it cannot be denied, That it was the onely blinde ≈øuper≈øtition of their errors in Religion, that led them to this de≈øperate deuice; yet doth it not follow, That all profe≈ø≈øing that Romi≈øh religion were guiltie of the ≈øame. For as it is trew, That no other ≈øect of heretiques, not excepting Turke, Iew, nor Pagan, no not euen tho≈øe of Calicute, who adore the deuill, did euer maintaine by the grounds of their religion, That it was lawfull, or rather meritorious (as the Romi≈øh Catholickes call it) to murther Princes or people for quarrell of Religion. And although particular men of all profe≈ø≈øions of Religion haue beene ≈øome Theeues, ≈øome Murtherers, ≈øome Traitors, yet euer when they came to their end and iu≈øt puni≈øhment, they confe≈ø≈øed their fault to bee in their nature, and not in their profe≈ø≈øion, (The≈øe Romi≈øh Catholicks onely excepted:) Yet it is trew on the other ≈øide, that many hone≈øt men blinded peraduenture with ≈øome opinions of Popery, as if they be not ≈øound in the que≈øtions of the
Reall pre≈øence, or in the number of the Sacraments, or ≈øome ≈øuch Schooleque≈øtion: yet doe they either not know, or at lea≈øt not beleeue all the trew grounds of Popery, which is in deed The my≈øterie of iniquitie. And therefore doe we iu≈øtly confe≈ø≈øe, that many Papi≈øts, e≈øpecially our forefathers, laying their onely tru≈øt vpon CHRIST and his Merits at their la≈øt breath, may be, and often times are ≈øaued; dete≈øting in that point, and thinking the crucltie of Puritanes worthy of fire, that will admit no ≈øaluation to any Papi≈øt. I therefore thus doe conclude this point, That as vpon the one part many hone≈øt men, ≈øeduced with ≈øome errors of Popery, may yet remaine good and faithfull Subiects: So vpon the other part, none of tho≈øe that trewly know and beleeue the whole grounds, and Schoole conclu≈øions of their doctrine, can euer proue either good Chri≈øtians, or faithfull Subiects. And for the part of forraine Princes and States, I may ≈øo much the more acquite them, and their Mini≈øters of their knowledge and con≈øent to any ≈øuch villanie, as I may iu≈øtly ≈øay, that in that point I better know all Chri≈øtian Kings by my ≈øelfe, That no King nor Prince of Honour will euer aba≈øe him≈øelfe ≈øo much, as to thinke a good thought of ≈øo ba≈øe and di≈øhonourable a Treachery, wi≈øhing you therefore, that as God hath giuen me an happie Peace and Amitie, with all other Chri≈øtian Princes my neighbours (as was euen now very grauely told you by my L. Chancellor) that ≈øo you will reuerently iudge and ≈øpeake of them in this ca≈øe. And for my part I would wi≈øh with tho≈øe ancient Philo≈øophers, that there were a Chri≈øtall window in my bre≈øt, wherein all my people might ≈øee the ≈øecrete≈øt thoughts of my heart, for then might you all ≈øee no alteration in my minde for this accident, further then in the≈øe two points. The fir≈øt, Caution and warine≈ø≈øe in gouernment, to di≈øcouer and ≈øearch out the my≈øteries of this wickedne≈ø≈øe as farre as may be: The other, after due triall, Seueritie of puni≈øhment vpon tho≈øe that ≈øhall bee found guilty of ≈øo dete≈øtable and vnheard of villanie. And now in this matter if I haue troubled your eares with an abrupt ≈øpeach, vndige≈øted in any good methode or order; you haue to con≈øider that an abrupt, and vnadui≈øed ≈øpeach doeth be≈øt become in the relation of ≈øo abrupt and vnorderly an accident.

And although I haue ordained the proroguing of this Parliament vntil after Chri≈øtmas vpon two nece≈ø≈øary re≈øpects: whereof the fir≈øt is, that neither I nor my Councell can haue lei≈øure at this time both to take order for the Apprehen≈øion and triall of the≈øe Con≈øpiratours, and al≈øo to wait vpon the dayly affaires of the Parliament, as the Councell mu≈øt doe: And the other rea≈øon is, the nece≈ø≈øitie at this time of diuers of your pre≈øences in your Shires that haue Charges and Commandements there. For as the≈øe wretches thought to haue blowen vp in a maner the whole world of this I≈øland, euery man being now commen vp here, either for publike cau≈øes of Parliament, or el≈øe for their owne priuate cau≈øes in Law, or otherwi≈øe: So the≈øe Rebels that now wander through the Countrey, could neuer haue gotten ≈øo fit a time of ≈øafetie in their pa≈ø≈øage, or what≈øoeuer vnlawfull Actions,
as now when the Countrey by the fore≈øaid occa≈øions is in a maner left de≈øolate, and wa≈øte vnto them. Be≈øides that, it may be that I ≈øhall de≈øire you at your next Se≈ø≈øion, to take vpon you the Iudgement of this Crime: For as ≈øo extraordinary a Fact de≈øerues extraordinary Iudgement, So can there not I thinke (following euen their owne Rule) be a fitter Iudgement for them, then that they ≈øhould be mea≈øured with the ≈øame mea≈øure wherewith they thought to mea≈øure vs: And that the ≈øame place and per≈øons, whom they thought to de≈øtroy, ≈øhould be the iu≈øt auengers of their ≈øo vnnaturall a Parricide: Yet not knowing that I will haue occa≈øion to meete with you my ≈øelfe in this place at the beginning of the next Se≈ø≈øion of this Paliament, (becau≈øe if it had not been for deliuering of the Articles agreed vpon by the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Vnion, which was thought mo≈øt conuenient to be done in my pre≈øence, where both Head and Members of the Parliament were met together, my pre≈øence had not otherwi≈øe been requi≈øite here at this time.) I haue therefore thought good for conclu≈øion of this Meeting, to di≈øcour≈øe to you ≈øomewhat anent the trew nature and definition of a Parliament, which I will remit to your memories till your next ≈øitting downe, that you may then make v≈øe of it as occa≈øion ≈øhall bee mini≈øtred.

For albeit it be trew, that at the fir≈øt Se≈ø≈øion of my fir≈øt Parliament, which was not long after mine Entrie into this Kingdome, It could not become me to in orme you of any thing belonging to Law or State heere: (for all knowledge mu≈øt either bee infu≈øed or acquired, and ≈øeeing the former ≈øort thereof is now with Prophecie cea≈øed in the world, it could not be po≈ø≈øible for me at my fir≈øt Entry here, before Experience had taught it me, to be able to vnder≈øtand the particular my≈øteries of this State:) yet now that I haue reigned almo≈øt three yeeres among≈øt you, and haue beene carefull to ob≈øerue tho≈øe things that belong to the office of a King, albeit that Time be but a ≈øhort time for experience in others, yet in a King may it be thought a rea≈øonable long time, e≈øpecially in me, who, although I be but in a maner a new King heere, yet haue bene long acquainted with the office of a King in ≈øuch another Kingdome, as doeth neere≈øt of all others agree with the Lawes and cu≈øtomes of this State. Remitting to your con≈øideration to iudge of that which hath beene concluded by the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Vnion, wherein I am at this time to ≈øignifie vnto you, That as I can beare witne≈ø≈øe to the fore≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, that they haue not agreed nor concluded therein any thing, wherein they haue not fore≈øeen as well the weale and commodity of the one Countrey, as of the other; So can they all beare mee record, that I was ≈øo farre from pre≈ø≈øing them to agree to any thing, which might bring with it any preiudice to this people; as by the contrary I did euer admoni≈øh them, neuer to conclude vpon any ≈øuch Vnion, as might cary hurt or grudge with it to either of the ≈øaid Nations: for the leauing of any ≈øuch thing, could not but be the greate≈øt hinderance that might be to ≈øuch an Action, which God by the lawes of Nature had prouided
to be in his owne time, and hath now in effect perfected in my Per≈øon, to which purpo≈øe my Lord Chancellour hath better ≈øpoken, then I am able to relate.

And as to the nature of this high Court of Parliament, It is nothing el≈øe but the Kings great Councell, which the King doeth a≈ø≈øemble either vpon occa≈øion of interpreting, or abrogating old Lawes, or making of new, according as ill maners ≈øhall de≈øerue, or for the publike puni≈øhment of notorious euill doers, or the prai≈øe and reward of the vertuous and well de≈øeruers; wherein the≈øe foure things are to be con≈øidered.
Fir≈øt, whereof this Court is compo≈øed.
Secondly, what matters are proper for it.
Thirdly, to what end it is ordeined.
And fourthly, what are the meanes and wayes whereby this end ≈øhould bee brought to pa≈ø≈øe.

As for the thing it ≈øelfe, It is compo≈øed of a Head and a Body: The Head is the King, the Body are the members of the Parliament. This Body againe is ≈øubdiuided into two parts; The Vpper and Lower Hou≈øe: The Vpper compounded partly of Nobility, Temporall men, who are heritable Councellors to the high Court of Parliament by the honour of their Creation and Lands: And partly of Bi≈øhops, Spirituall men, who are likewi≈øe by the vertue of their place and dignitie Councellours, Life Renters, or Ad vitam of this Court. The other Hou≈øe is compo≈øed of Knights for the Shire; and Gentry, and Burge≈ø≈øes for the Townes. But becau≈øe the number would be infinite for all the Gentlemen and Burge≈ø≈øes to bee pre≈øent at euery Parliament, Therefore a certaine number is ≈øelected and cho≈øen out of that great Body, ≈øeruing onely for that Parliament, where their per≈øons are the repre≈øentation of that Body.

Now the matters whereof they are to treate ought therefore to be generall, and rather of ≈øuch matters as cannot well bee performed without the a≈ø≈øembling of that generall Body, and no more of the≈øe generals neither, then nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhall require: for as in Corrupti≈øsima Republica ≈øunt plurimae leges: So doeth the life and ≈øtrength of the Law con≈øi≈øt not in heaping vp infinite and confu≈øed numbers of Lawes, but in the right interpretation and good execution of good and whole≈øome Lawes. If this be ≈øo then, neither is this a place on the one ≈øide for euery ra≈øh and harebrained fellow to propone new Lawes of his owne inuention: nay rather I could wi≈øh the≈øe bu≈øie heads to remember that Law of the Lacedemonians, That who≈øoeuer came to propone a new Law to the people, behooued publikely to pre≈øent him≈øelfe with a rope about his necke, that in ca≈øe the Law were not allowed, he ≈øhould be hanged therwith. So warie ≈øhould men be of proponing Nouelties, but mo≈øt of all not to propone any bitter or ≈øeditious Laws, which can produce nothing but grudges and di≈øcontentment betweene the Prince and his people. Nor yet is it on the other ≈øide a conuenient place for priuate men vnder the colour of general Lawes,
to propone nothing but their owne particular gaine, either to the hurt of their priuate neighbours, or to the hurt of the whole State in generall, which many times vnder faire and plea≈øing Titles, are ≈ømoothly pa≈ø≈øed ouer, and ≈øo by ≈øtealth procure without con≈øideration, that the priuate meaning of them tendeth to nothing but either to the wrecke of a particular partie, or el≈øe vnder colour of publike benefite to pill the poore people, and ≈øerue as it were for a generall Impo≈øt vpon them for filling the pur≈øes of ≈øome priuate per≈øons.

And as to the end for which the Parliament is ordeined, being only for the aduancement of Gods glory, and the e≈øtabli≈øhment and wealth of the King and his people: It is no place then for particular men to vtter there their priuate conceipts, nor for ≈øatisfaction of their curio≈øities, and lea≈øt of all to make ≈øhew of their eloquence by tyning the time with long ≈øtudied and eloquent Orations: No, the reuerence of God, their King, and their Countrey being well ≈øetled in their hearts, will make them a≈øhamed of ≈øuch toyes, and remember that they are there as ≈øworne Councellours to their King, to giue their be≈øt adui≈øe for the furtherance of his Seruice, and the flori≈øhing Weale of his E≈øtate.

And la≈øtly, if you will rightly con≈øider the meanes and wayes how to bring all your labours to a good end, you mu≈øt remember, That you are heere a≈ø≈øembled by your lawfull King to giue him your be≈øt adui≈øes, in the matters propo≈øed by him vnto you, being of that nature, which I haue already told, wherein you are grauely to deliberate, and vpon your con≈øciences plainely to determine how farre tho≈øe things propounded doe agree with the weale, both of your King and of your Countrey, who≈øe weales cannot be ≈øeparated. And as for my ≈øelfe, the world ≈øhall euer beare mee witne≈ø≈øe, That I neuer ≈øhall propone any thing vnto you, which ≈øhall not as well tend to the weale publike, as to any benefite for me: So ≈øhall I neuer oppone my ≈øelfe to that, which may tend to the good of the Common-wealth, for the which I am ordeined, as I haue often ≈øaid. And as you are to giue your adui≈øe in ≈øuch things as ≈øhall by your King be propo≈øed: So is it on your part your dueties to propone any thing that you can after mature deliberation iudge to be needefull, either for the≈øe ends already ≈øpoken of, or otherwi≈øe for the di≈øcouery of any latent euill in the Kingdome, which peraduenture may not haue commen to the Kings eare. If this then ought to bee your graue maner of proceeding in this place, Men ≈øhould bee a≈øhamed to make ≈øhew of the quickne≈ø≈øe of their wits here, either in taunting, ≈øcoffing, or detracting the Prince or State in any point, or yet in breaking ie≈øts vpon their fellowes, for which the Ordinaries or Ale-hou≈øes are fitter places, then this Honourable and high Court of Parliament.

In conclu≈øion then ≈øince you are to breake vp, for the rea≈øons I haue already told you, I wi≈øh ≈øuch of you as haue any charges in your Countreys, to ha≈øten you home for the repre≈ø≈øing of the in≈øolencies of the≈øe Rebels, and apprehen≈øion of their per≈øons, wherin as I heartily pray to the Almightie
for your pro≈øperous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: So doe I not doubt, but we ≈øhall ≈øhortly heare the good newes of the ≈øame; And that you ≈øhall haue an happie returne, and meeting here to all our comforts.
div.q: Here the Lord Chancellor ≈øpake touching the proroguing of the Parliament: And hauing done, his Maiestie ro≈øe againe, and ≈øaid,
div.p: SInce it plea≈øed God to graunt mee two ≈øuch notable Deliueries vpon one day of the weeke, which was Tue≈øday, and likewi≈øe one day of the Moneth, which was the fifth; Thereby to teach mee, That as it was the ≈øame deuill that ≈øtill per≈øecuted mee; So it was one and the ≈øame GOD that ≈øtill mightily deliuered mee: I thought it therefore not ami≈ø≈øe, That the one and twentieth day of Ianuary, which fell to be vpon Tue≈øday, ≈øhould bee the day of meeting of this next Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, hoping and a≈ø≈øuring my ≈øelfe, that the ≈øame GOD, who hath now granted me and you all ≈øo notable and gracious a deliuerie, ≈øhall pro≈øper all our affaires at that next Se≈ø≈øion, and bring them to an happie conclu≈øion. And now I con≈øider GOD hath well prouided it, that the ending of this Parliament hath bene ≈øo long continued: For as for my owne part, I neuer had any other intention, but onely to ≈øeeke ≈øo farre my weale, and pro≈øperitie, as might coniunctly ≈øtand with the flouri≈øhing State of the whole Common-wealth, as I haue often told you; So on the other part I confe≈ø≈øe, if I had bene in your places at the beginning of this Parliament, (which was ≈øo ≈øoone after mine entry into this Kingdome, wherein ye could not po≈ø≈øibly haue ≈øo perfect a knowledge of mine inclination, as experience ≈øince hath taught you,) I could not but haue ≈øu≈øpected, and mi≈ø-interpreted diuers things, In the trying whereof, now I hope, by your experience of my behauiour and forme of gouernment, you are well ynough cleared, and re≈øolued.

div.head: A SPEACH TO BOTH THE HOVSES OF PARLIAMENT, DELIVERED IN THE GREAT CHAMBER AT WHITE-HALL, THE LAST DAY OF March 1607.
div.p:
MY Lords of the higher Hou≈øe, and you Knights and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Lower hou≈øe, All men at the beginning of a Fea≈øt bring foorth good Wine fir≈øt, and after, wor≈øe. This was the ≈øaying of the Gouernour of the Fea≈øt at Cana in Galile, where CHRIST wrought his fir≈øt miracle by changing water into Wine. But in this ca≈øe now whereof I am to ≈øpeake vnto you, I mu≈øt follow that Gouernours rule, and not CHRISTS example, in giuing you the wor≈øt and ≈øowre≈øt Wine la≈øt. For all the time of this long Se≈ø≈øion of the Parliament you haue bene ≈øo fed and cloy'd, (≈øpecially you of the Lower hou≈øe) with ≈øuch banquets, and choi≈øe of delicate ≈øpeeches, and your eares ≈øo ≈øea≈øoned with the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of long precogitate Orations; as this my Speach now in the breaking vp of this A≈ø≈øembly, cannot but appeare vnto your ta≈øte as the wor≈øt Wine propo≈øed in the end of the Banquet, ≈øince I am onely to deliuer now vnto you matter without curious forme, ≈øub≈øtance without ceremonie, trewth in all ≈øinceritie. Yet con≈øidering the Per≈øon that ≈øpeaketh, the parties to whom I ≈øpeake, the matter whereof I meane to ≈øpeake; it fits better to vtter matter,
rather then wordes, in regard of the greatne≈ø≈øe of my place who am to ≈øpeake to you, the grauitie of you the Auditorie, which is the high Court of Parliament; the weight of the matter, which concernes the ≈øecuritie and e≈øtabli≈øhment of this whole Empire, and litle world. Studied Orations and much eloquence vpon little matter is fit for the Vniuer≈øities, where not the Subiect which is ≈øpoken of, but the triall of his wit that ≈øpeaketh, is mo≈øt commendable: but on the contrary, in all great Councels or Parliaments, fewe≈øt wordes with mo≈øt matter doeth become be≈øt, where the di≈øpatch of the great errands in hand, and not the prai≈øe of the per≈øon is mo≈øt to bee looked vnto: like the garment of a cha≈øte woman, who is onely ≈øet forth by her naturall beautie, which is properly her owne: other deckings are but en≈øignes of an harlot that flies with borrowed feathers. And be≈øides the conueniencie, I am forced hereunto by nece≈ø≈øitie, my place calling me to action, and not leauing me to the libertie of contemplation, hauing alwayes my thoughts bu≈øied with the publique care of you all, where euery one of you hauing but him≈øelfe, and his owne priuate to thinke of, are at more lei≈øure to make ≈øtudied ≈øpeeches. And therefore the matter which I deliuer you confu≈øedly as in a ≈øacke, I leaue it to you when you are in your chambers, and haue better ley≈øure then I can haue, to ranke them in order, euery one in their owne place.

Thus much by way of Preface. But I proceed to the matter: Whereof I might ≈øay with S. Paul, I could ≈øpeake in as many tongues as you all, but I had rather ≈øpeake three wordes to edification, then talke all day without vnder≈øtanding. In vaine (≈øaith the P≈øalmist) doeth the builder build the hou≈øe, or the watchman watch the Citie, vnle≈ø≈øe the Lord giue his ble≈ø≈øing thereunto. And in the New Te≈øtament S. Paul ≈øaith, That hee may plant, Apollo may water, but it is GOD onely that mu≈øt giue the increa≈øe. This I ≈øpeake, becau≈øe of the long time which hath bene≈øpent about the Treatie of the Vnion. For my ≈øelfe, I prote≈øt vnto you all, When I fir≈øt propounded the Vnion, I then thought there could haue bene no more que≈øtion of it, then of your declaration and acknowledgement of my right vnto this Crowne, and that as two Twinnes, they would haue growne vp together. The errour was my mi≈øtaking; I knew mine owne ende, but not others feares: But now finding many cro≈ø≈øings, long di≈øputations, ≈øtrange que≈øtions, and nothing done; I mu≈øt needs thinke it proceeds either of mi≈øtaking of the errand, or el≈øe from ≈øome iealou≈øie of me the Propounder, that you ≈øo adde delay vnto delay, ≈øearching out as it were the very bowels of Curio≈øitie, and conclude nothing. Neither can I condemne you for being yet in ≈øome iealou≈øie of my intention in this matter, hauing not yet had ≈øo great experience of my behauiour and inclination in the≈øe few yeeres pa≈øt, as you may peraduenture haue in a longer time hereafter, and not hauing occa≈øion to con≈øult dayly with my ≈øelfe, and heare mine owne opinion in all tho≈øe particulars which are debated among you.

But here I pray you now mi≈øtake mee not at the fir≈øt, when as I ≈øeeme to finde fault with your delayes and curio≈øitie, as if I would haue you to re≈øolue in an houres time, that which will take a moneths adui≈øement: for you all know, that Rex est lex loquens; And you haue oft heard mee ≈øay, That the Kings will and intention being the ≈øpeaking Law, ought to bee Luce clarius: and I hope you of the Lower hou≈øe haue the proofe of this my clearene≈ø≈øe by a Bil ≈øent you downe from the Vpper hou≈øe within the≈øe few dayes, or rather few houres: wherein may very well appeare vnto you the care I haue to put my Subiects in good ≈øecuritie of their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions for all po≈øterities to come. And therefore that you may clearely vnder≈øtand my meaning in that point, I doe freely confe≈ø≈øe, you had rea≈øon to adui≈øe at lea≈øure vpon ≈øo great a cau≈øe: for great matters doe cuer require great deliberation before they be well concluded. Deliberandum est diu quod ≈øtatuendum est ≈øemel. Con≈øultations mu≈øt proceed lento pede, but the execution of a ≈øentence vpon the re≈øolution would be ≈øpeedie. If you will goe on, it matters not though you goe with leaden feet, ≈øo you make ≈øtill ≈øome progre≈ø≈øe, and that there be no let or needle≈ø≈øe delay, and doe not Nodum in ≈øcirpo quaerere. I am euer for the Medium in euery thing. Betweene fooli≈øh ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe and extreame length, there is a middle way. Search all that is rea≈øonable, but omit that which is idle, curious and vnnece≈ø≈øary; otherwi≈øe there can neuer be a re≈øolution or end in any good worke.

And now from the generall I wil de≈øcend to particulars, and wil onely for the ea≈øe of your memories diuide the matter that I am to ≈øpeake of, into foure heads, by opening vnto you, Fir≈øt, what I craue: Secondly, in what maner I de≈øire it: Thirdly, what commodities will en≈øue to both the Kingdomes by it: Fourthly, what the ≈øuppo≈øed inconueniencie may be that giues impediments thereunto.

For the fir≈øt, what I craue, I prote≈øt before GOD who knowes my heart, and to you my people before whom it were a ≈øhame to lie, that I claime nothing but with acknowledgement of my Bond to you; that as yee owe to me ≈øubiection and obedience: So my Soueraigntie obligeth mee to yeeld to you loue, gouernment and protection: Neither did I euer wi≈øh any happine≈ø≈øe to my ≈øelfe, which was not conioyned with the happine≈ø≈øe of my people. I de≈øire a perfect Vnion of Lawes and per≈øons, and ≈øuch a Naturalizing as may make one body of both Kingdomes vnder mee your King, That I and my po≈øteritie (if it ≈øo plea≈øe God) may rule ouer you to the worlds ende; Such an Vnion as was of the Scots and Pictes in Scotland, and of the Heptarchie here in England. And for Scotland I auow ≈øuch an Vnion, as if you had got it by Conque≈øt, but ≈øuch a Conque≈øt as may be cemented by loue, the onely ≈øure bond of ≈øubiection or friend≈øhip: that as there is ouer both but vnus Rex, ≈øo there may be in both but vnus Grex & vna Lex: For no more po≈ø≈øible is it for one King to gouerne two Countreys Contiguous, the one a great, the other a le≈ø≈øe, a richer and a poorer, the greater drawing like an Adamant the le≈ø≈øer to the Commodities
thereof, then for one head to gouerne two bodies, or one man to be husband of two wiues, whereof Chri≈øt him≈øelfe ≈øaid, Ab initio non fuit ≈øic.

But in the generall Vnion you mu≈øt ob≈øerue two things: for I will di≈øcouer my thoughts plainly vnto you; I ≈øtudy clearenes, not eloquence, And therefore with the olde Philo≈øopers, I would heartily wi≈øh my bre≈øt were a tran≈øparent gla≈ø≈øe for you all to ≈øee through, that you might looke into my heart, and then would you be ≈øatisfied of my meaning. For when I ≈øpeake of a perfect Vnion, I meane not confu≈øion of all things: you mu≈øt not take from Scotland tho≈øe particular Priuiledges that may ≈øtand as well with this Vnion, as in England many particular cu≈øtomes in particular Shires, (as the Cu≈øtomes of Kent, and the Royalties of the Countie Palatine of Che≈øter) do with the Common Law of the Kingdome: for euery particular Shire almo≈øt, and much more euery Countie, haue ≈øome particular cu≈øtomes that are as it were naturally mo≈øt fit for that people. But I meane of ≈øuch a generall Vnion of Lawes as may reduce the whole Iland, that as they liue already vnder one Monarch, ≈øo they may all bee gouerned by one Law: For I mu≈øt needs confe≈ø≈øe by that little experience I haue had ≈øince my comming hither, and I thinke I am able to prooue it, that the grounds of the Common Law of England, are the be≈øt of any Law in the world, either Ciuil or Municipall, and the fitte≈øt for this people. But as euery Law would be cleare and full, ≈øo the ob≈øcuritie in ≈øome points of this our written Law, and want of fulne≈ø≈øe in others, the variation of Ca≈øes and mens curio≈øitie, breeding euery day new que≈øtions, hath enforced the Iudges to iudge in many Ca≈øes here, by Ca≈øes and pre≈øidents, wherein I hope Lawyers them≈øelues will not denie but that there mu≈øt be a great vncertaintie, and I am ≈øure all the re≈øt of you that are Gentlemen of other profe≈ø≈øions were long agoe wearie of it, if you could haue had it amended: For where there is varietie and vncertaintie although a iu≈øt Iudge may do rightly, yet an ill Iudge may take aduantage to doe wrong; and then are all hone≈øt men that ≈øucceede him, tied in a maner to his vniu≈øt and partiall conclu≈øions. Wherefore, leaue not the Law to the plea≈øure of the Iudge, but let your Lawes be looked into: for I de≈øire not the aboli≈øhing of the Lawes, but onely the clearing and the ≈øweeping off the ru≈øt of them, and that by Parliament our Lawes might be cleared and made knowen to all the Subiects. Yea rather it were le≈ø≈øe hurt, that all the approued Ca≈øes were ≈øet downe and allowed by Parliament for ≈øtanding Lawes in all time to come: For although ≈øome of them peraduenture may bee vniu≈øt as ≈øet downe by corrupt Iudges; yet better it is to haue a certaine Law with ≈øome ≈øpots in it, nor liue vnder ≈øuch an vncertaine and arbitrarie Law, ≈øince as the prouerbe is, It is le≈ø≈øe harme to ≈øuffer an inconuenience then a mi≈øchiefe. And now may you haue faire occa≈øion of amending and poli≈øhing your Lawes, when Scotland is to bee vnited with you vnder them for who can blame Scotland to ≈øay, If you will take away our owne Lawes, I pray you giue vs a better and cleerer in place thereof.

But this is not po≈ø≈øible to bee done without a fit preparation. Hee that buildeth a Ship, mu≈øt fir≈øt prouide the timber; and as Chri≈øt him≈øelfe ≈øaid, No man will build an hou≈øe, but he will fir≈øt prouide the materials: nor a wi≈øe King will not make warre again≈øt another, without he fir≈øt makeproui≈øion of money: and all great workes mu≈øt haue their preparation: and that was my end in cau≈øing the In≈øtrument of the Vnion to be made. Vnion is a mariage: would he not bee thought ab≈øurd that for furthering of a mariage betweene two friends of his, would make his fir≈øt motion to haue the two parties be laid in bedde together, and performe the other turnes of mariage? mu≈øt there not precede the mutuall ≈øight and acquaintance of the parties one with another, the conditions of the contract, and Ioincture to be talked of and agreed vpon by their friends, and ≈øuch other things as in order ought to goe before the ending of ≈øuch a worke? The vnion is an eternall agreement and reconciliation of many long bloody warres that haue beene betweene the≈øe two ancient Kingdomes. Is it the readie≈øt way to agree a priuate quarell betweene two, to bring them at the fir≈øt to ≈øhake hands, and as it were ki≈ø≈øe other, and lie vnder one roofe or rather in one bedde together, before that fir≈øt the ground of their quarell be communed vpon, their mindes mitigated, their affections prepared, and all other circum≈øtances fir≈øt v≈øed, that ought to be v≈øed to proceed to ≈øuch a finall agreement? Euery hone≈øt man de≈øireth a perfect Vnion, but they that ≈øay ≈øo, and admit no preparation thereto, haue mel in ore, fel in corde. If after your ≈øo long talke of Vnion in all this long Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, yee ri≈øe without agreeing vpon any particular; what will the neighbour Princes iudge, who≈øe eyes are all fixed vpon the conclu≈øion of this Action, but that the King is refu≈øed in his de≈øire, whereby the Nation ≈øhould bee taxed, and the King di≈øgraced? And what an ill preparation is it for the mindes of Scotland toward the Vnion, when they ≈øhall heare that ill is ≈øpoken of their whole Nation, but nothing is done nor aduanced in the matter of the Vnion it ≈øelfe? And as to their meaning and interpretation of that word, I will not onely deliuer it vnto you out of mine owne conceipt, but as it was deliuered vnto mee by the be≈øt Lawyers of Scotland, both Coun≈øellours and other Lawyers, who were at the making thereof in Scotland, and were Commi≈ø≈øioners here for performance of the ≈øame.

Their meaning in the word of Fundamentall Lawes, you ≈øhall perceiue more fully hereafter, when I handle the obiection of the difference of Lawes: For they intend thereby onely tho≈øe Lawes whereby confu≈øion is auoyded, and their Kings de≈øcent mainteined, and the heritage of the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion and Monarchie, which hath bene a Kingdome, to which I am in de≈øcent, three hundreth yeeres before CHRIST: Not meaning it as you doe, of their Common Law, for they haue none, but that which is called IVS REGIS: and their de≈øire of continuing a free Monarchie, was onely meant, That all ≈øuch particular Priuiledges (whereof I ≈øpake before) ≈øhould not bee ≈øo confounded, as for want either of Magi≈øtrate, Law, or Order, they might fall in ≈øuch a confu≈øion, as to become like a naked Prouince, without Law or libertie vnder this Kingdome. I hope you meane not I ≈øhould ≈øet Garri≈øons ouer them, as the Spaniards doe ouer Sicily and Naples, or gouerne them by Commi≈ø≈øioners, which are ≈øeldome found ≈øucceedingly all wi≈øe and hone≈øt men.

This I mu≈øt ≈øay for Scotland, and I may trewly vaunt it; Here I ≈øit and
gouerne it with my Pen, I write and it is done, and by a Clearke of the Councell I gouerne Scotland now, which others could not doe by the ≈øword. And for their auer≈øen≈ø≈øe in their heart again≈øt the Vnion, It is trew indeede, I prote≈øt they did neuer craue this Vnion of me, nor ≈øought it either in priuate, or the State by letters, nor euer once did any of that Nation pre≈ø≈øe mee forward or wi≈øh mee to accelerate that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. But on the other part, they offered alwayes to obey mee when it ≈øhould come to them, and all hone≈øt men that de≈øire my greatne≈ø≈øe haue beene thus minded, for the per≈øonall reuerence and regard they beare vnto my Perion, and any of my rea≈øonable and iu≈øt de≈øires.

I know there are many Piggots among≈øt them, I meane a number of ≈øeditious and di≈øcontented particular per≈øons, as mu≈øt be in all Common-wealths, that where they dare, may peraduenture talke lewdly enough: but no Scotti≈øh man euer ≈øpake dishonourably of England in Parliament. For here mu≈øt I note vnto you the difference of the two Parliaments in the≈øe two Kingdomes; for there they mu≈øt not ≈øpeake without the Chauncellors leaue, and if any man doe propound or vtter any ≈øeditious or vncomely ≈øpeeches, he is ≈øtraight interrupted and ≈øilenced by the Chauncellors authoritie: where as here, the libertie for any man to ≈øpeake what hee li≈øt, and as long as he li≈øt, was the onely cau≈øe he was not interrupted.

It hath bin obiected, that there is a great Antipathy of the Lawes and Cu≈øtomes of the≈øe two Nations. It is much mi≈øtaken: for Scotland hath no Common Law as here, but the Law they haue is of three ≈øorts.

All the Lawe of Scotland for Tenures, Wards and Liueries, Seigniories and Lands, are drawen out of the Chauncerie of England, and for matters of equitie and in many things el≈øe, differs from you but in certaine termes: Iames the fir≈øt, bred here in England, brought the Lawes thither in a written hand. The ≈øecond is Statute lawes, which be their Acts of Parliament, wherein they haue power as you, to make and altar Lawes: and tho≈øe may be looked into by you, for I hope you ≈øhall be no more ≈øtrangers to that Nation. And the principall worke of this Vnion will be, to reconcile the Statute Lawes of both Kingdomes. The third is the Ciuill Law: Iames the fift brought it out of France by e≈øtabli≈øhing the Se≈ø≈øion there, according to the forme of the Court of Parliament of Fraunce, which he had ≈øeene in the time of his being there: who occupie there the place of Ciuill! udges in all matters of Plee or controuer≈øie, yet not to gouerne ab≈øolutely by the Ciuill Law as in Fraunce. For if a man plead that the Law of the Nation is otherwi≈øe, it is a barre to the Ciuill, and a good Chauncellor or Pre≈øident, will oftentimes repell and put to ≈øilence an Argument that the Lawyers bring out of the Ciuill Law, where they haue a cleare ≈øolution in their owne Law. So as the Ciuil Law in Scotland is admitted in no other ca≈øes, but to ≈øupply ≈øuch ca≈øes wherein the Municipall Law is defectiue. Then may you ≈øee it is not ≈øo hard a matter as is thought, to reduce that Countrey to bee vnited with you vnder this Law, which neither are
≈øubiect to the Ciuill Lawe, nor yet haue any olde Common Law of their owne, but ≈øuch as in effect is borrowed from yours. And for their Statute Lawes in Parliament, you may alter and change them as oft as occa≈øion ≈øhall require, as you doe here. It hath likewi≈øe beene obiected as an other impediment, that in the Parliament of Scotland the King hath not anegatiue voice, but mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe all the Lawes agreed on by the Lords and Commons. Of this I can be≈øt re≈øolue you: for I am the elde≈øt Parliament man in Scotland, and haue ≈øit in more Parliaments then any of my Predece≈ø≈øors. I can a≈ø≈øure you, that the forme of Parliament there, is nothing inclined to popularitie. About a twentie dayes or ≈øuch a time before the Parliament, Proclamation is made throughout the Kingdome, to deliuer in to the Kings Clearke of Regi≈øter (whom you heere call the Ma≈øter of the Rolles) all Bills to be exhibited that Se≈ø≈øion before a certaine day. Then are they brought vnto the King, and peru≈øed and con≈øidered by him, and onely ≈øuch as I allowe of are put into the Chancellors handes to bee propounded to the Parliament, and none others; And if any man in Parliament ≈øpeake of any other matter then is in this forme fir≈øt allowed by mee, The Chancellor tells him there is no ≈øuch Bill allowed by the King.

Be≈øides, when they haue pa≈ø≈øed them for lawes, they are pre≈øented vnto me, and I with my Scepter put into my hand by the Chancellor, mu≈øt ≈øay, I ratifie and approue all things done in this pre≈øent Parliament. And if there bee any thing that I di≈ølike, they ra≈øe it out before. If this may bee called a negatiue voyce, then I haue one I am ≈øure in that Parliament.

The la≈øt impediment is the French liberties: which is thought ≈øo great, as except the Scots far≈øake Fraunce, England cannot bee vnited to them. If the Scotti≈øh Nation would bee ≈øo vnwilling to leaue them as is ≈øaid, it would not lye in their hands: For the League was neuer made betweene the people, as is mi≈øtaken, but betwixt the Princes onely and their Crownes. The beginning was by a Me≈ø≈øage from a King of Fraunce, Charlemaine I take it (but I cannot certainely remember) vnto a King of Scotland, for a League defen≈øiue and offen≈øiue betweene vs and them again≈øt England, Fraunce being at that time in Warres with England.

The like at that time was then de≈øired by England again≈øt Fraunce, who al≈øo ≈øent their Amba≈ø≈øadours to Scotland. At the fir≈øt, the Di≈øputation was long maintained in fauour of England, that they being our neere≈øt Neighbours ioyned in one continent, and a ≈øtrong and powerfull Nation, it was more fitte for the weale and ≈øecuritie of the State of Scotland, to be in League and Amitie with them, then with a Countrey, though neuer ≈øo ≈øtrong, yet diuided by Sea from vs: e≈øpecially Englandlying betwixt vs and them, where we might be ≈øure of a ≈øuddaine mi≈øchiefe, but behooued to abide the hazard of wind and weather, and other accidents that might hinder our reliefe.

But after, when the contrary part of the Argument was maintained: wherein allegation was made, that England euer ≈øought to conquer Scotland, and therefore in regarde of their pretended intere≈øt in the Kingdoome, would neuer keepe any ≈øound Amitie with them longer, then they ≈øaw their aduantage; whereas France lying more remote and clayming no intere≈øt in the Kingdome, would therefore bee found a more con≈øtant and faithfull friend: It was vnhappily concluded in fauour of the la≈øt partie, through which occa≈øion Scotland gate many mi≈øchiefes after: And it is by the very tenour thereof ordered, to bee renewed and confirmed from King to King ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely, which accordingly was euer performed by the mediation of their Amba≈ø≈øadours, and therefore meerely per≈øonall, and ≈øo was it renewed in the Queene my mothers time, onely betweene the two Kings, and not by a≈ø≈øent of Parliament or conuention of the three E≈øtates, which it could neuer haue wanted if it had beene a League betweene the people. And in my time when it came to be ratified, becau≈øe it appeared to be in odium tertii, it was by me left vnrenewed or confirmed as a thing incompatible to my Per≈øon, in con≈øideration of my Title to this Crowne. Some Priuiledges indeede in the Merchants fauour for point of Commerce, were renewed and confirmed in my time: wherein for my part of it, there was ≈øcarce three Coun≈øellours more then my Secretarie, to who≈øe place it belonged, that medled in that matter.

It is trew, that it behooued to be enterteined, as they call it, in the Court of Parliament of Paris: but that onely ≈øerues for publication, and not to giue it Authoritie: That Parliament (as you know) being but a Iudiciall Seate of Iudges and Lawyers, and nothing agreeing with the definition or office of our Parliaments in this I≈øle. And therefore that any fruites or Priuiledges po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the League with Fraunce is able now to remaine in Scotland, is impo≈ø≈øible: For ye may be ≈øure, that the French King ≈øtayes onely vpon the ≈øight of the ending of this Vnion, to cut it off him≈øelfe. Otherwi≈øe when this great worke were at an end, I would be forced for the generall care I owe to all my Subiects, to craue of France like Priuiledges to them all as Scotland alreadie enioyes, ≈øeeing the per≈øonall friend≈øhip remaines as great betweene vs as betweene our Progenitors; and all my Subiects mu≈øt be alike deare vnto me: which either hee will neuer grant, and ≈øo all will fall to the ground; or el≈øe it will turne to the benefite of the whole I≈øland: and ≈øo the Scotti≈øh Priuiledges cannot hold longer then my League with France la≈øteth.

And for another Argument to prooue that this league is only betweene the Kings, and not betweene the people: They which haue Pen≈øions, or are priuie Intelligence giuers in France without my leaue, are in no better ca≈øe by the Law of Scotland, then if they were Pen≈øioners to Spaine.

As for the Scotti≈øh Guard in France, the beginning thereof was, when an Earle of Boghan was ≈øent in aide of the French with tenne thou≈øand men, and there being made Con≈øtable, and hauing obtained a victorie,
was murthered with the mo≈øt of the Scotti≈øh Armie. In recompen≈øe whereof, and for a future ≈øecuritie to the Scotti≈øh Nation, the Scotti≈øh Guard was ordeined to haue the priuiledge and prerogatiue before all other Guards in guarding the Kings per≈øon.

And as for the la≈øt point of this ≈øubdiui≈øion concerning the gaine that England may make by this Vnion, I thinke no wi≈øe nor hone≈øt man will aske any ≈øuch que≈øtion. For who is ≈øo ignorant, that doeth not know the gaine will bee great? Doe you not gaine by the Vnion of Wales? And is not Scotland greater then Wales? Shall not your Dominions bee encrea≈øed of Landes, Seas, and per≈øons added to your greatne≈ø≈øe? And are not your Landes and Seas adioyning? For who can ≈øet downe the limits of the Borders, but as a Mathematicall line or Idaea? Then will that backe doore bee ≈øhut, and tho≈øe portes of Ianus be for euer clo≈øed: you ≈øhall haue them that were your enemies to mole≈øt you, a ≈øure backe to defend you: their bodies ≈øhall bee your aides, and they mu≈øt bee partners in all your quarrels: Two ≈ønow-balls put together, make one the greater: Two hou≈øes ioyned, make one the larger: two Ca≈øtle walles made in one, makes one as thicke and ≈øtrong as both. And doe you not ≈øee in the Low countreys how auaileable the Engli≈øh and the Scotti≈øh are being ioyned together? This is a point ≈øo plaine, as no man that hath wit or hone≈øtie, but mu≈øt acknowledge it feelingly.

And where it is obiected that the Scotti≈øhmen are not tyed to the ≈øeruice of the King in the warres aboue forty dayes; It is an ignorant mi≈øtaking. For the trewth is, That in re≈øpect the Kings of Scotland did not ≈øo abound in Trea≈øure and money to take vp an Armie vnder pay, as the Kings of England did; Therefore was the Scotti≈øh Army wont to be ray≈øed onely by Proclamation, vpon the penaltie of their breach of alleageance; So as they were all forced to come to the Warre like Snailes who carry their hou≈øe about with them; Euery Nobleman and Gentleman bringing with him their Tents, money, proui≈øion for their hou≈øe, victuals of all ≈øorts, and all other nece≈ø≈øaries, the King ≈øupplying them of nothing: Nece≈ø≈øitie thereupon enforcing a warning to be giuen by the Proclamation of the ≈øpace of their attendance, without which they could not make their proui≈øion accordingly, e≈øpecially as long as they were within the bounds of Scotland, where it was not lawfull for them to helpe them≈øelues by the ≈øpoile or wa≈øting of the Countrey. But neither is there any Law Pre≈øcribing preci≈øely ≈øuch a certaine number of dayes, nor yet is it without the limits of the Kings power to keepe them together, as many more dayes as hee li≈øt, to renew his Proclamations from time to time ≈øome rea≈øonable number of dayes, before the expiring of the former, they being euer bound to ≈øerue and waite vpon him, though it were an hundreth yeere if need were.

Now to conclude, I am glad of this occa≈øion, that I might Liberare animam meam; You are now to recede: when you meete againe, remember
I pray you, the trewth and ≈øincerity of my meaning, which in ≈øeeking Vnion, is onely to aduance the greatne≈ø≈øe of your Empire ≈øeated here in England; And yet with ≈øuch caution I wi≈øh it, as may ≈øtand with the weale of both States. What is now de≈øired, hath oft before bene ≈øought when it could not bee obteined: To refu≈øe it now then, were double iniquitie. Strengthen your owne felicitie, London mu≈øt bee the Seate of your King, and Scotland ioyned to this kingdome by a Golden conque≈øt, but cymented with loue, (as I ≈øaid before) which within will make you ≈øtrong again≈øt all Ciuill and inte≈øtine Rebellion, as without wee will bee compa≈ø≈øed and guarded with our walles of bra≈ø≈øe. Iudge mee charitably, ≈øince in this I ≈øeeke your equall good, that ≈øo both of you might bee made fearefull to your Enemies, powerfull in your ≈øelues, and auaileable to your friendes. Studie therefore hereafter to make a good Conclu≈øion, auoyd all delayes, cut off all vaine que≈øtions, that your King may haue his lawfull de≈øire, and be not di≈øgraced in his iu≈øt endes. And for your ≈øecuritie in ≈øuch rea≈øonable points of re≈øtrictions, whereunto I am to agree, yee need neuer doubt of my inclination: For I will not ≈øay any thing which I will not promi≈øe, nor promi≈øe any thing which I will not≈øweare; What I ≈øweare I will ≈øigne, and what I ≈øigne, I ≈øhall with GODS grace euer performe.

div.head: A SPEACH TO THE LORDS AND COMMONS OF THE PARLIAMENT AT WHITE-HALL, ON WEDNESDAY THE XXI. OF MARCH. ANNO 1609.
div.p: WE being now in the midde≈øt of this ≈øea≈øon appointed for penitence and prayer, it hath ≈øo fallen out, that the≈øe two la≈øt dayes haue bene ≈øpent in a farre other ≈øort of exerci≈øe, I meane in Euchari≈øticke Sacrifice, and gratulation of thankes, pre≈øented vnto mee by both the parts of this body of Parliament: and therefore to make vp the number of three, (which is the number of Trinitie, and perfection) I haue thought good to make this the third Day, to be ≈øpent in this exerci≈øe.

As ye made mee a faire Pre≈øent indeed in pre≈øenting your thankes and louing dueties vnto mee: So haue I now called you here, to recompence you againe with a great and a rare Pre≈øent, which is a faire and a Chri≈øtall Mirror; Not ≈øuch a Mirror wherein you may ≈øee your owne faces, or ≈øhadowes; but ≈øuch a Mirror, or Chri≈øtall, as through the tran≈øparantne≈ø≈øe thereof, you may ≈øee the heart of your King. The Philo≈øophers wi≈øh, That euery mans brea≈øt were a Chri≈øtall, where-through his heart might be ≈øeene, is vulgarly knowne, and I touched it in one of my former Speaches vnto you: But though that were impo≈ø≈øible in the generall, yet will I now performe this for my part, That as it is a trew Axiome in Diuinitie,
That Cor Regis is in manu Domini, So wil I now ≈øet Cor Regis in oculis populi. I know that I can ≈øay nothing at this time, whereof ≈øome of you that are here, haue not at one time or other, heard me ≈øay the like already: Yet as corporall food nouri≈øheth and mainteineth the body, ≈øo doeth Remini≈øcentia nouri≈øh and mainteine memory.
I Will reduce to three generall and maine grounds, the principall things that haue bene agitated in this Parliament, and whereof I will now ≈øpeake.
Fir≈øt, the Arrand for which you were called by me; And that was, for ≈øupporting of my ≈øtate, and nece≈ø≈øities.

The ≈øecond is, that which the people are to mooue vnto the King: To repre≈øent vnto him ≈øuch things, whereby the Subiects are vexed, or wherein the ≈øtate of the Common wealth is to be redre≈ø≈øed: And that is the thing which you call grieuances.

The third ground that hath bene handled among≈øt you, and not onely in talke among≈øt you in the Parliament, but euen in many other peoples mouthes, a≈øwell within, as without the Parliament, is of a higher nature then any of the former (though it be but an Incident?) and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe it concernes a higher point; And this is a doubt, which hath bene in the heads of ≈øome, of my Intention in two things.

Fir≈øt, whether I was re≈øolued in the generall, to continue ≈øtill my gouernment according to the ancient forme of this State, and the Lawes of this Kingdome: Or if I had an intention not to limit my ≈øelfe within tho≈øe bounds, but to alter the ≈øame when I thought conuenient, by the ab≈øolute power of a King.

The other branch is anent the Common Law, which ≈øome had a conceit I di≈øliked, and (in re≈øpect that I was borne where another forme of Law was e≈øtabli≈øhed) that I would haue wi≈øhed the Ciuill Law to haue bene put in place of the Common Law for gouernment of this people. And the complaint made among≈øt you of a booke written by doctour Cowell, was a part of the occa≈øion of this incident: But as touching my cen≈øure of that booke, I made it already to bee deliuered vnto you by the Trea≈øurer here ≈øitting, which he did out of my owne directions and notes; and what he ≈øaid in my name, that had he directly from me: But what hee ≈øpake of him≈øelfe therein without my direction, I ≈øhal alwayes make good; for you may be ≈øure I will be loth to make ≈øo hone≈øt a man a lyer, or deceiue your expectations: alwayes within very few dayes my Edict ≈øhall come forth anent that matter, which ≈øhall fully di≈øcouer my meaning.

There was neuer any rea≈øon to mooue men to thinke, that I could like of ≈øuch grounds: For there are two qualities principally, or rather priuations that make Kings ≈øubiect to flatterie; Credulitie and Ignorance; and I hope none of them can bee iu≈øtly obiected to mee: For if Alexander the great, for all his learning, had bene wi≈øe in that point to haue con≈øidered the
≈øtate of his owne naturall body and di≈øpo≈øition, hee would neuer haue thought him ≈øelfe a god. And now to the matter. As it is a Chri≈øtan duety in euery man, Reddere rationem fidei, and not to be a≈øhamed to giue an account of his profe≈ø≈øion before men, and Angels, as oft as occa≈øion ≈øhall require: So did I euer hold it a nece≈ø≈øitie of honour in a iu≈øt and wi≈øe King, though not to giue an account to his people of his actions, yet clearely to deliuer his heart and intention vnto them vpon euery occa≈øion. But I mu≈øt inuert my order, and begin fir≈øt with that incident which was la≈øt in my diui≈øion (though highe≈øt of nature) and ≈øo goe backward.

THe State of MONARCHIE is the ≈øupreme≈øt thing vpon earth: For Kings are not onely GODS Lieutenants vpon earth, and ≈øit vpon GODS throne, but euen by GOD him≈øelfe they are called Gods. There bee three principall ≈øimilitudes that illu≈øtrate the ≈øtate of MONARCHIE: One taken out of the word of GOD; and the two other out of the grounds of Policie and Philo≈øophie. In the Scriptures Kings are called Gods, and ≈øo their power after a certaine relation compared to the Diuine power. Kings are al≈øo compared to Fathers of families: for a King is trewly Parens patriae, the politique father of his people. And la≈øtly, Kings are compared to the head of this Microco≈øme of the body of man.

Kings are iu≈øtly called Gods, for that they exerci≈øe a manner or re≈øemblance of Diuine power vpon earth: For if you wil con≈øider the Attributes to God, you ≈øhall ≈øee how they agree in the per≈øon of a King. God hath power to create, or de≈øtroy, make, or vnmake at his plea≈øure, to giue life, or ≈øend death, to iudge all, and to bee iudged nor accomptable to none: To rai≈øe low things, and to make high things low at his plea≈øure, and to God are both ≈øoule and body due. And the like power haue Kings: they make and vnmake their ≈øubiects: they haue power of rai≈øing, and ca≈øting downe: of life, and of death: Iudges ouer all their ≈øubiects, and in all cau≈øes, and yet accomptable to none but God onely. They haue power to exalt low things, and aba≈øe high things, and make of their ≈øubiects like men at the Che≈ø≈øe; A pawne to take a Bi≈øhop or a Knight, and to cry vp, or downe any of their ≈øubiects, as they do their money. And to the King is due both the affection of the ≈øoule, and the ≈øeruice of the body of his ≈øubiects: And therefore that reuerend Bi≈øhop here among≈øt you, though I heare that by diuers he was mi≈øtaken or not wel vnder≈øtood, yet did he preach both learnedly and trewly annent this point concerning the power of a King: For what he ≈øpake of a Kings power in Ab≈øtracto, is mo≈øt trew in Diuinitie: For to Emperors, or Kings that are Monarches, their Subiects bodies & goods are due for their defence and maintenance. But if I had bene in his place, I would only haue added two words, which would haue cleared all: For after I had told as a Diuine, what was due by the Subiects to their Kings in general, I would then haue concluded as an Engli≈øhman, ≈øhewing this people,
That as in generall all Subiects were bound to relieue their King; So to exhort them, that as wee liued in a ≈øetled ≈øtate of a Kingdome which was gouerned by his owne fundamentall Lawes and Orders, that according thereunto, they were now (being a≈ø≈øembled for this purpo≈øe in Parliament) to con≈øider how to helpe ≈øuch a King as now they had; And that according to the ancient forme, and order e≈øtabli≈øhed in this Kingdome: putting ≈øo, a difference betweene the generall power of a King in Diuinity, and the ≈øetled and e≈øtabli≈øhed State of this Crowne, and Kingdome. And I am ≈øure that the Bi≈øhop meant to haue done the ≈øame, if hee had not bene ≈øtraited by time, which in re≈øpect of the greatne≈ø≈øe of the pre≈øence preaching before me, and ≈øuch an Auditory, he dur≈øt not pre≈øume vpon.

As for the Father of a familie, they had of olde vnder the Law of Nature Patriam pote≈øtatem, which was Pote≈øtatem vitae & necis, ouer their children or familie, (I meane ≈øuch Fathers of families as were the lineall heires of tho≈øe families whereof Kings did originally come:) For Kings had their fir≈øt originall from them, who planted and ≈øpread them≈øelues in Colonies through the world.
