Secondly, I would not haue you meddle with ≈øuch ancient Rights of mine, as I haue receiued from my Predece≈ø≈øors, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing them, More Maiorum: ≈øuch things I would bee ≈øorie ≈øhould bee accounted for Grieuances. All nouelties are dangerous as well in a politique as in a naturall Body: And therefore I would be loth to be quarrelled in my ancient Rights and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions: for that were to iudge mee vnworthy of that which my Predece≈ø≈øors had, and left me.

And la≈øtly, I pray you beware to exhibite for Grieuance any thing that is e≈øtabli≈øhed by a ≈øetled Law, and whereunto (as you haue already had a proofe) you know I will neuer giue a plau≈øible an≈øwere: For it is an vndutifull part in Subiects to pre≈ø≈øe their King, wherein they know beforehand he will refu≈øe them. Now, if any Law or Statute be not conuenient, let it be amended by Parliament, but in the meane time terme it not a Grieuance: for to be grieued with the Law, is to be grieued with the King, who is ≈øworne to bee the Patron and mainteiner thereof. But as all men are fle≈øh, and may erre in the execution of Lawes; So may ye iu≈øtly make a Grieuance of any abu≈øe of the Law, di≈øtingui≈øhing wi≈øely betweene the faults of the per≈øon, and the thing it ≈øelfe. As for example, Complaints may be made vnto you of the high Commi≈ø≈øioners: If ≈øo be, trie the abu≈øe, and ≈øpare not to complaine vpon it, but ≈øay not there ≈øhall be no Commi≈ø≈øion, For that were to abridge the power that is in me: and I will plainely tell you. That ≈øomething I haue with my ≈øelfe re≈øolued annent that point, which I meane euer to keepe, except I ≈øee other great cau≈øe which is, That in regard the high Commi≈ø≈øion is o ‚Ä¢ ≈øo high a nature, from which there is no appellation to any other Court, I haue thought good to re≈øtraine it onely to the two Archbi≈øhops, where before it was common among≈øt a great part of the Bi≈øhops in England. This Law I haue ≈øet to my ≈øelfe, and therefore you
may be a≈ø≈øured, that I will neuer finde fault with any man, nor thinke him the more Puritane, that will complaine to me out of Parliament, a≈øwell as in Parliament, of any error in execution thereof, ≈øo that hee prooue it; Otherwi≈øe it were but a calumnie. Onely I would bee loath that any man ≈øhould grieue at the Commi≈ø≈øion it ≈øelfe, as I haue already ≈øaid. Yee haue heard (I am ≈øure) of the paines I tooke both in the cau≈øes of the Admiralty, and of the Prohibitions: If any man therefore will bring me any iu≈øt complaints vpon any matters of ≈øo high a nature as this is, yee may a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelues that I will not ≈øpare my labour in hearing it. In faith you neuer had a more painefull King, or that will be readier in his per≈øon to determine cau≈øes that are fit for his hearing. And when euer any of you ≈øhall make experience of me in this point, ye may be ≈øure neuer to want acce≈ø≈øe, nor ye ≈øhall neuer come wrong to me, in, or out of Parliament.

And now to conclude this purpo≈øe of Grieuances, I haue one generall grieuance to commend vnto you, and that in the behalfe of the Countreys from whence ye come. And this is, to pray you to beware that your Grieuances ≈øauour not of particular mens thoughts, but of the generall griefes ri≈øing out of the mindes of the people, and not out of the humor of the propounder. And therefore I would wi≈øh you to take heede carefully, and con≈øider of the partie that propounds the grieuance: for ye may (if ye li≈øt) ea≈øily di≈øcerne whether it bee his owne pa≈ø≈øion, or the peoples griefe, that makes him to ≈øpeake: for many a man will in your hou≈øe propound a Grieuance out of his owne humour, becau≈øe (peraduenture) he accounts highly of that matter: and yet the countrey that imployes him, may perhaps either be of a contrary minde, or (at lea≈øt) little care for it. As for example, I a≈ø≈øure you, I can very well ≈ømell betweene a Petition that mooues from a generall Grieuance, or ≈øuch a one as comes from the ≈øpleene of ≈øome particular per≈øon, either again≈øt Eccle≈øia≈øticall gouernment in generall, or the per≈øon of any one Noble man, or Commi≈ø≈øioner in particular.

ANd now the third point remaines to bee ≈øpoken of; which is the cau≈øe of my calling of this Parliament. And in this I haue done but as I v≈øe to doe in all my life, which is to leaue mine owne errand hindmo≈øt.

It may bee you did wonder that I did not ≈øpeake vnto you publikely at the beginning of this Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, to tell you the cau≈øe of your calling, as I did (if I bee rightly remembred) in euery Se≈ø≈øion before. But the trewth is, that becau≈øe I call you at this time for my particular Errand, I thought it fitter to bee opened vnto you by my Trea≈øurer, who is my publike and mo≈øt principall Officer in matters of that nature, then that I ≈øhould doe it my ≈øelfe: for I confe≈ø≈øe I am le≈ø≈øe naturally eloquent, and haue greater cau≈øe to di≈øtru≈øt mine elocution in matters of this nature, then in any other thing. I haue made my Trea≈øurer already to giue you a very cleere and trew accompt both of my hauing and expen≈øes: A fauour I
confe≈ø≈øe, that Kings doe ≈øeldome be≈øtow vpon their Subiects, in making them ≈øo particularly acquainted with their ≈øtate. If I had not more then cau≈øe, you may be ≈øure I would be loth to trouble you: But what he hath affirmed in this, vpon the honour of a Gentleman, (whom you neuer had cau≈øe to di≈øtru≈øt for his hone≈øtie,) that doe I now confirme and auow to be trew in the word and honour of a King; And therein you are bound to beleeue me. Duetie I may iu≈øtly claime of you as my Subiects; and one of the branches of duetie which Subiects owe to their Soueraigne, is Supply: but in what quantitie, and at what time, that mu≈øt come of your loues. I am not now therefore to di≈øpute of a Kings power, but to tell you what I may iu≈øtly craue, and expect with your good wills. I was euer again≈øt all extremes; and in this ca≈øe I will likewi≈øe wi≈øh you to auoyd them on both ≈øides. For if you faile in the one, I might haue great cau≈øe to blame you as Parliament men, being called by me for my Errands: And if you fall into the other extreme, by ≈øupply of my nece≈ø≈øities without re≈øpectiue care to auoyd oppre≈ø≈øion or partialitie in the Leuie, both I and the Countrey will haue cau≈øe to blame you.

When I thinke vpon the compo≈øition of this body of Parliament, I doe well con≈øider that the Vpper hou≈øe is compo≈øed of the Seculer Nobilitie, who are hereditary Lords of Parliament; and of Bi≈øhops, that are liue Renter Barons of the ≈øame: And therefore what is giuen by the Vpper hou≈øe, is giuen onely from the trew body of that Hou≈øe; and out of their owne purpo≈øes that doe giue it; whereas the Lower hou≈øe is but the repre≈øentatiue body of the Commons, and ≈øo what you giue, you giue it a≈øwell for others, as for your ≈øelues: and therefore you haue the more rea≈øon to e≈øchew both the extreames. On the one part, ye may the more ea≈øily be liberall, ≈øince it comes not all from your ≈øelues; and yet vpon the other part, if yee giue more then is fit for good and louing Subiects to yeeld vpon ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary occa≈øions, yee abu≈øe the King, and hurt the people; And ≈øuch a gift I will neuer accept: For in ≈øuch a ca≈øe you might deceiue a King, in giuing your flattering con≈øent to that which you know might moue the people generally to grudge and murmure at it, and ≈øo ≈øhould the King find him≈øelfe deceiued in his Caloule, and the people likewi≈øe grieued in their hearts; the loue and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of which (I prote≈øt) I did, and euer will accompt the greate≈øt earthly ≈øecuritie (next the fauour of GOD) to any wi≈øe or iu≈øt King. For though it was vainely ≈øaide by one of your Hou≈øe, That yee had need to beware, that by giuing mee too much, your throats were not in danger of cutting at your comming home: yet may ye a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelues, that I will euer bee lothe to pre≈ø≈øe you to doe that which may wrong the people, and make you iu≈øtly to beare the blame thereof. But that yee may the better bee acquainted with my inclination, I will appeale to a number of my Priuie Councell here pre≈øent, if that before the calling of this Parliament, and when I found that the nece≈ø≈øitie of my e≈øtate required ≈øo great a ≈øupply, they found me more de≈øirous to obtaine
that which I was forced to ≈øeeke, then carefull that the people might yeeld me a ≈øupply in ≈øo great a mea≈øure as my nece≈ø≈øities required, without their too great lo≈ø≈øe. And you all that are Parliament men, and here pre≈øent of both Hou≈øes can beare me witne≈ø≈øe, if euer I burthened or imployed any of you for any particular Sub≈øidies, or ≈øummes by name, further then my laying open the particular nece≈ø≈øities of my ≈øtate, or yet if euer I ≈øpake to any Priuie Councellour, or any of my learned Councell, to labour voyces for me to this end; I euer dete≈øted the hunting for Emendicata Suffragia. A King that will rule and gouerne iu≈øtly, mu≈øt haue regard to Con≈øcience, Honour and Iudgement, in all his great Actions, (as your ≈øelfe M. Speaker remembred the other day.) And therefore ye may a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelues, That I euer limitall my great Actions within that compa≈ø≈øe. But as vpon the one ≈øide, I doe not de≈øire you ≈øhould yeeld to that extreame, in giuing me more then (as I ≈øaid formerly) vpon ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary occa≈øions are fit for good and louing Subiects to yeeld; For that were to giue me a pur≈øe with a knife: So on the other ≈øide, I hope you will not make vaine pretences of wants, out of cau≈øele≈ø≈øe apprehen≈øions, or idle excu≈øes, neither cloake your owne humours (when your ≈øelues are vnwilling) by alledging the pouertie of the people. For although I will be no le≈ø≈øe iu≈øt, as a King, to ≈øuch per≈øons, then any other: (For my Iu≈øtice with Gods grace, ≈øhalbe alike open to all) yet ye mu≈øt thinke I haue no rea≈øon to thanke them, or gratifie them with any ≈øuits or matters of grace, when their errand ≈øhall come in my way; And yet no man can ≈øay, that euer I quarrelled any man for refu≈øing mee a Sub≈øidie, if hee did it in a moderate fa≈øhion, and with good rea≈øons. For him that denies a good Law, I will not ≈øpare to quarrell: But for graunting or denying money, it is but an effect of loue: And therefore for the point of my nece≈ø≈øities, I onely de≈øire that I be not refu≈øed in that which of duety I ought to haue: For I know if it were propounded in the generall among≈øt you, whether the Kings wants ought to be relieued or not, there is not one of you, that would make que≈øtion of it. And though in a ≈øort this may ≈øeeme to be my particular; yet it can not bee diuided from the generall good of the Common wealth; For the King that is Parens Patriae, telles you of his wants. Nay, Patria ip≈øa by him ≈øpeakes vnto you. For if the King want, the State wants, and therefore the ≈øtrengthening of the King is the pre≈øeruation and the ≈øtanding of the State; And woe be to him that diuides the weale of the King from the weale of the Kingdome. And as that King is mi≈øerable (how rich ≈øoeuer he bee) that raines ouer a poore people, (for the hearts and riches of the people, are the Kings greate≈øt trea≈øure;) So is that Kingdome not able to ≈øub≈øi≈øt, how rich and potent ≈øoeuer the people be, if their King wants meanes to mainaine his State: for the meanes of your King are the ≈øinewes of the kingdome both in warre and peace: for in peace I mu≈øt mini≈øter iu≈øtice vnto you, and in warre I mu≈øt defend you by Armes: but neither of the≈øe can I do without ≈øufficient means, which mu≈øt come from
your Aide and Supply. I confe≈ø≈øe it is farre again≈øt my nature to be burthen≈øome to my people: for it cannot but grieue me to craue of others, that was borne to be begged of. It is trew, I craue more then euer King of England did; but I haue farre greater and iu≈øter cau≈øe and rea≈øon to craue, then euer King of England had. And though my Trea≈øurer hath at length declared the rea≈øons vnto you of my nece≈ø≈øities, and of a large ≈øupply that he craued for the ≈øame, wherein he omitted no arguments that can be v≈øed for that purpo≈øe; yet will I my ≈øelfe now ≈øhortly remember you ≈øome of the weightie≈øt rea≈øons that come in my head, to proue the equitie of my demaund.

Fir≈øt, ye all know, that by the acce≈ø≈øion of more Crownes, which in my Per≈øon I haue brought vnto you, my charge mu≈øt be the greater in all rea≈øon: For the greater your King be, both in his dominion and number of Subiects, he cannot but be forced thereby to be at the more charge, and it is the more your honour, ≈øo to haue it.

Next, that po≈øteritie and i≈ø≈øue which it hath plea≈øed God to ≈øend me for your v≈øe, cannot but bring nece≈ø≈øarily with it a greater proportion of charge. You all know that the late Queene of famous memory (notwith≈øtanding her orbitie) had much giuen vnto her, and more then euer any of her predece≈ø≈øors had before her.

Thirdly, the time of creation of my Sonne doeth now draw neere, which I chu≈øe for the greater honour to bee done in this time of Parliament. As for him I ≈øay no more; the ≈øight of him≈øelfe here ≈øpeakes for him.

Fourthly, it is trew I haue ≈øpent much; but yet if I had ≈øpared any of tho≈øe things, which cau≈øed a great part of my expen≈øe, I ≈øhould haue di≈øhonored the kingdome, my ≈øelfe, and the late Queene. Should I haue ≈øpared the funerall of the late Queene? or the ≈øolemnitie of mine and my wiues entrie into this Kingdome, in ≈øome honourable ≈øort? or ≈øhould I haue ≈øpared our entrie into London, or our Coronation? And when mo≈øt of the Monarches, and great Princes in Chri≈øtendome ≈øent their Amba≈ø≈øadours to congratulate my comming hither, and ≈øome of them came in per≈øon, was I not bound, both for my owne honour, and the honour of the Kingdome, to giue them good entertainement? But in ca≈øe it might be obiected by ≈øome, that it is onely vpon occa≈øions of warre, that Kings obtaine great Supplies from their Subiects: notwith≈øtanding my interne Peace, I am yet in a kinde of warre, which if it bee without, the more is your ≈øafetie: For (as the Trea≈øurer tolde you at large) I am now forced both in re≈øpects of State, and my promi≈øe, and for the generall cau≈øe of Religion, to ≈øend a Supply of forces to Cleues, and how long that occa≈øion may la≈øt, or what greater ≈øupply the nece≈ø≈øitie of that Errand may draw mee vnto, no man can yet tell. Be≈øides that, although I haue put downe that forme of warlike keeping of Barwicke; yet are all tho≈øe commaunders my pen≈øioners that were the late Queenes ≈øouldiers. And I hope I ≈øu≈øtaine a prettie Seminarie of Souldiers in my Forts within this Kingdome, be≈øides
the two cautionary Townes in the Low-countreys, Flu≈øhing and Brill. And as for Ireland, yee all know how vncertaine my charges are euer there, that people being ≈øo ea≈øily ≈øtirred, partly through their barbaritie, and want of ciuilitie, and partly through their corruption in Religion to breake foorth in rebellions. Yee know, how vnlooked for a Rebellion brake foorth there the la≈øt yeere, which could not but put mee to extraordinary charges. Be≈øides I doe maintaine there continually an Armie, which is a goodly Seminarie of expert and old Souldiers. And I dare neuer ≈øuffer the ≈øame to be dimini≈øhed, till this Plantation take effect, which (no doubt) is the greate≈øt moate that euer came in the Rebels eyes: and it is to be looked for, that if euer they will bee able to make any ≈øtirre, they will pre≈ø≈øe at it by all meanes, for the preuenting and di≈øcouraging this Plantation. Now it is trew, that be≈øides all the≈øe honourable and nece≈ø≈øary occa≈øions of my charge, I haue ≈øpent much in liberalitie: but yet I hope you will con≈øider, that what I haue giuen, hath bene giuen among≈øt you; and ≈øo what comes in from you, goes out againe among≈øt you. But it may be thought that I haue giuen much among≈øt Scotti≈øhmen. Indeed if I had not beene liberall in rewarding ≈øome of my old ≈øeruants of that Nation, ye could neuer haue had rea≈øon to expect my thankefulne≈ø≈øe towards any of you that are more lately become my Subiects, if I had beene ingrate to the old: And yet yee will find, that I haue dealt twice as much among≈øt Engli≈øh men as I haue done to Scotti≈øhmen. And therefore he that in your Hou≈øe was not a≈øhamed to affirme, that the ≈øiluer and gold did ≈øo abound in Edenburgh, was very farre mi≈øtaken; but I wi≈øh him no wor≈øe puni≈øhment, then that hee ≈øhould onely liue vpon ≈øuch profit of the money there. But I hope you will neuer mi≈ølike me for my liberalitie, ≈øince I can looke very few of you this day in the face, that haue not made ≈øuits to mee, at lea≈øt for ≈øome thing, either of honour or profit. It is trew, a Kings liberalitie mu≈øt neuer be dried vp altogether: for then he can neuer maintaine nor oblige his ≈øeruants and well de≈øeruing Subiects: But that va≈øtne≈ø≈øe of my expence is pa≈øt, which I v≈øed the fir≈øt two or three yeeres after my comming hither: And, as I oft v≈øed to ≈øay, that Chri≈øtmas and open tide is ended: For at my fir≈øt comming here, partly ignorance of this State (which no man can acquire but by time and experience) and partly the forme of my comming being ≈øo honourable and miraculous, enforced me to extend my liberalitie ≈øo much the more at the beginning. Ye ≈øaw I made Knights then by hundreths, and Barons in great numbers: but I hope you find I doe not ≈øo now, nor minde not to doe ≈øo hereafter. For to conclude this point anent expences, I hold that a Kings expence mu≈øt alwayes bee honourable, though not wa≈øtefull, and the charges of your King in maintaining tho≈øe ancient honourable formes of liuing that the former Kings of England my Predece≈ø≈øours haue done, and his liuing to bee ruled according to the proportion of his greatne≈ø≈øe, is a≈øwell for the honour of your Kingdome,
as of your King. Now this cannot be ≈øupplied out of the ayre or liquid elements, but mu≈øt come from the people. And for remouing of that diffidence which men may haue, that I minde not to liue in any wa≈øtefull ≈øort hereafter, will you but looke vpon my ≈øelfe and my po≈øteritie; and if there were no more but that, it will teach you that if I were but a naturall man, I mu≈øt needs bee carefull of my expences: For as for my owne per≈øon, I hope none that knowes me well, can thinke me but as little inclined to any prodigall humours of vnnece≈ø≈øary things, as any other rea≈øonable man of a farre meaner e≈øtate. Therefore ≈øince (as I haue ≈øaid) I cannot be helped but from the people; I a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelfe that you will well allow mee ≈øuch mea≈øure of Supplie, as the people may beare, and ≈øupport him with more Honourable meanes then others haue had, that (as I may ≈øay without vaunting) hath brought you more Honour then euer you had: For I hope there are no good Subiects either within, or out of the Parliament Hou≈øe, that would not be content for ≈øetting ≈øtreight once and ≈øetling the Honourable State of their King, to ≈øpare ≈øo much euery one of them out of their pur≈øes, which peraduenture they would in one night throw away at Dice or Cards, or be≈øtow vpon a hor≈øe for their fancies, that might breake his necke or his legge the next morning: Nay I am ≈øure euery good Subiect would rather chu≈øe to liue more ≈øparingly vpon his owne, then that his Kings State ≈øhould be in want.

For conclu≈øion then of this purpo≈øe, I wi≈øh you now to put a ≈øpeedie end to your bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. Freene≈ø≈øe in giuing graceth the gift, Bis dat, qui cit√≤ dat; The longer I want helpe, the greater will my debt ≈øtill ri≈øe: and ≈øo mu≈øt I looke for the greater helpes. And now I would pray you to turne your eyes with mee from home, and looke vpon forreine States. Con≈øider that the eyes of all forreine States are vpon this affaire, and in expectation what the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe thereof will be; And what can they thinke, if ye depart without relieuing mee in that proportion that may make me able to maintaine my State, but that either ye are vnwilling to helpe mee, thinking me vnworthy thereof, or at lea≈øt that my State is ≈øo de≈øperate, as it cannot be repaired, and ≈øo that the Parliament parts in di≈øgrace with the King, and the King in di≈øta≈øte with the Parliament, which cannot but weaken my reputation both at home and abroad? For of this you may be a≈ø≈øured, that forreine Princes care the more one for an other, if they may haue rea≈øon to expect that they may bee able to doe them good or harme in Retribution. And ye know, that if a King fall to be contemned with his neighbours, that cannot but bring an oppre≈ø≈øion and warre by them vpon him, and then will it be too late to ≈øupport the King, when the cure is almo≈øt de≈øperate. Things fore≈øeene and preuented, are euer ea≈ølie≈øt remedied: And therefore I would adui≈øe you now ≈øo to ≈øettle your bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, as ye may not take in hand ≈øo many things at once, as may both cro≈ø≈øe my errand, and euery one of them cro≈ø≈øe another. Yee remember the French Prouerbe, Qui trop embra≈ø≈øe, rien e≈øtreint; We are not in this
Parliament to make our Te≈øtament, as if wee ≈øhould neuer meete againe, and that all things that were to be done in any Parliament, were to be done at this time: and yet for filling vp of your vacant houres, I will recommend to your con≈øideration ≈øuch nature of things, as are to bee ≈øpecially thought vpon in the≈øe times. Fir≈øt I will beginne at GOD: for the beginning with him makes all other actions to bee ble≈ø≈øed: And this I meane by the cau≈øe of Religion. Next I will ≈øpeake of ≈øome things that concerne the Common-wealth. And thirdly, matters of Plea≈øure and ornament to the Kingdome.

As for Religion, we haue all great cau≈øe to take heed vnto it; Papi≈øts are waxed as proud at this time as euer they were, which makes many to think they haue ≈øome new plotin hand. And although the poore≈øt ≈øort of them bee (God be thanked) much decrea≈øed, yet doeth the greater ≈øort of them dayly increa≈øe, e≈øpecially among the foeminine Sexe; nay they are waxed ≈øo proud, that ≈øome ≈øay, no man dare pre≈øent them, nor Iudges meddle with them, they are ≈øo backed and vpholden by diuers great Courtiers. It is a ≈øurer and better way to remooue the materials of fire before they bee kindled, then to quench the fire when once it is kindled.

div.p: I doe not meane by this to mooue you to make ≈øtronger Lawes then are already made, but ≈øee tho≈øe Lawes may bee well executed that are in force; otherwi≈øe they cannot but fall into contempt and become ru≈øtie. I neuer found, that blood and too much ≈øeueritie did good in matters of Religion: for, be≈øides that it is a ≈øure rule in Diuinitie, that God neuer loues to plant his Church by violence and blood≈øhed, naturall rea≈øon may euen per≈øwade vs, and dayly experience prooues it trew, That when men are ≈øeuerely per≈øecuted for Religion, the gallantne≈ø≈øe of many mens ≈øpirits, and the wilfulnes of their humors, rather then the iu≈øtne≈ø≈øe of the cau≈øe, makes them to take a pride boldy to endure any torments, or death it ≈øelfe, to gaine thereby the reputatiom of Martyrdome, though but in a fal≈øe ≈øhadow.

Some doubts haue beene conceiued anent the v≈øing of the Oath of Allegiance, and that part of the Acte which ordaines the taking thereof, is thought ≈øo ob≈øcure, that no man can tell who ought to bee pre≈ø≈øed therewith. For I my ≈øelfe, when vpon a time I called the Iudges before mee at their going to their Circuits, I mooued this que≈øtion vnto them; wherein, as I thought they could not re≈øolutely an≈øwere me: And therefore if there bee any ≈øcruple touching the mini≈øtring of it, I would wi≈øh it now to bee cleared. And ≈øince I haue with my owne pen brought the Popes quarell vpon mee, and proclaimed publique defiance to Babylon in maintaining it; ≈øhould it now ≈øleepe, and ≈øhould I ≈øeeme (as it were) to ≈øteale from it againe?

As for Recu≈øants, let them bee all duely pre≈øented without exception: for in times pa≈øt there hath beene too great a conniuence, and forbearing
of them, e≈øpecially of great mens wiues, and their kinne and followers. None ought to be ≈øpared from being brought vnder the danger of Law, and then it is my part to v≈øe mercie, as I thinke conuenient. To winke at faults, and not to ≈øuffer them to bee di≈øcouered, is no Honour, nor Mercy in a King, neither is he euer thanked for it; It onely argues his dulne≈ø≈øe: But to forgiue faults after they are confe≈ø≈øed, or tried, is Mercie. And now I mu≈øt turne me in this ca≈øe to you, my Lords the Bi≈øhops, and euen exhort you earne≈øtly, to be more carefull, then you haue bene, that your Officers may more duely pre≈øent Recu≈øants, then heretofore they haue done, without exception of per≈øons; That althought it mu≈øt be the worke of GOD that mu≈øt make their mindes to bee altered, yet at lea≈øt by this cour≈øe they may be ≈øtayed from increa≈øing, or in≈øulting vpon vs.

And that yee all may know the trewth of my heart in this ca≈øe, I diuide all my Subiects that are Papi≈øts, into two rankes: either olde Papi≈øts, that were ≈øo brought vp in times of Poperie, like old Queene Mary Prie≈øts, and tho≈øe, that though they bee younger in yeeres, yet haue neuer drunke in other milke, but beene ≈øtill nu≈øled in that blindne≈ø≈øe: Or el≈øe ≈øuch as doe become Apo≈øtats; hauing once beene of our Profe≈ø≈øion, and haue for≈øaken the trewth, either vpon di≈øcontent, or practi≈øe, or el≈øe vpon a light vaine humour of Noueltie, making no more ≈øcruple to ≈øeeke out new formes of Religion, then if it were but a new forme of Garment, or a new cut or court≈øey after the French fa≈øhion.

For the former ≈øort, I pitie them; but if they bee good and quiet Subiects, I hate not their per≈øons; and if I were a priuate man, I could well keepe a ciuill friend≈øhip and conuer≈øation with ≈øome of them: But as for tho≈øe Apo≈øtates, who, I know, mu≈øt be greate≈øt haters of their owne Sect, I confe≈ø≈øe I can neuer ≈øhew any fauourable countenance toward them, and they may all of them be ≈øure without exception, that they ≈øhall neuer finde any more fauour of mee, further then I mu≈øt needs in Iu≈øtice afford them. And the≈øe would I haue the Law to ≈øtrike ≈øeuerelie≈øt vpon, and you carefulle≈øt to di≈øcouer. Yee know there hath beene great ≈øtirre kept for begging Concealements the≈øe yeeres pa≈øt; and I pray you, let mee begge this concealement both of the Bi≈øhops, and Iudges, That Papi≈øts be no longer concealed.

Next, as concerning the Common wealth, I doe ≈øpecially recommend vnto you the framing of ≈øome new Statute for pre≈øeruation of woods. In the end of the la≈øt Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, ye had a Bill among≈øt you of that ≈øubiect; but becau≈øe you found ≈øome faults therein, you ca≈øt out the whole Bil: But I could haue rather wi≈øhed that yee had either mended it, or made a new one; For to ca≈øt out the whole Bill becau≈øe of ≈øome faults, was euen as if a man, that had a new garment brought him, would chu≈øe rather to go naked, then haue his garment made fit for him: But on my co≈øcience, I cannot
imagine why you ≈øhould ≈øo lightly haue e≈øteemed a thing, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary for the Common wealth, if it were not out of a litle frowardne≈ø≈øe among≈øt you at that time, that what I then recommended earne≈øtly vnto you, it was the wor≈øe liked of. The maintenance of woods is a thing ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary for this Kingdome, as it cannot ≈øtand, nor be a Kingdome without it: For it concernes you both in your E≈ø≈øe, Bene e≈ø≈øe, and in plea≈øures. Your E≈ø≈øe: for without it you want the v≈øe of one of the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarie Elements (which is Fire and fewell to dre≈ø≈øe your meate with; for neither can the people liue in the≈øe colde Countries, if they want fire altogether, nor yet can you dre≈ø≈øe your meate without it; and I thinke you will ill liue like the Cannibals vpon raw fle≈øh: for the education of this people is farre from that. As to your bene e≈ø≈øe; The decay of woods will nece≈ø≈øarily bring the decay of Shipping, which both is the ≈øecurity of this Kingdome, ≈øince God hath by nature made the Sea to bee the wall of this Iland; and the rather now, ≈øince God hath vnited it all in my Per≈øon and Crowne; As al≈øo by the decay of Shipping will you loo≈øe both all your forraine commodities that are fit for this countrey, and the venting of our owne, which is the lo≈ø≈øe of Trade, that is a maine pillar of this kingdome. And as for Plea≈øure, yee know my delight in Hunting and Hawking, and many of your ≈øelues are of the ≈øame minde; and all this mu≈øt needes decay, by the decay of Woods: Ye haue rea≈øon therefore to prouide a good Law vpon this Subiect.

Now as to the la≈øt point concerning matters of Plea≈øure, it con≈øi≈øts in the pre≈øeruing of Game, which is now almo≈øt vtterly de≈øtroyed through all the Kingdome. And if you offer not now a better Law for this, then was made in the la≈øt Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, I will neuer thanke you for it: For as for your Law anent Partridge and Phe≈øant, you haue giuen leaue to euery man how poore a Farmour that euer hee bee, to take and de≈øtroy them in his owne ground how he li≈øt. But I pray you, how can the Game bee maintained, if Gentlemen that haue great Lord≈øhips ≈øhall breed and pre≈øerue them there, and ≈øo ≈øoone as euer they ≈øhall but flie ouer the hedge and light in a poore fellowes Clo≈øe, they ≈øhall all be de≈øtroyed? Surely I know no remedie for pre≈øeruing the Game that breedes in my grounds, except I ca≈øt a roofe ouer all the ground, or el≈øe put veruels to the Partridges feet with my Armes vpon them, as my Hawkes haue: otherwi≈øe I know not how they ≈øhall bee knowen to be the Kings Partridges, when they light in a Farmours Clo≈øe.

And by your Lawe again≈øt ≈øtealing of Deere or Conies, after a long di≈øcour≈øe and prohibition of ≈øtealing them, you conclude in the end with a re≈øtriction, that all this puni≈øhment ≈øhall bee vnder≈øtood to bee v≈øed again≈øt them that ≈øteale the Game in the night: Which hath much encouraged all the loo≈øer ≈øort of people, that it is no fault to ≈øteale Deere, ≈øo they doe it not like theeues in the night. As was that Law of the Lacedemonians
again≈øt theft, that did not forbid theft, but onely taught them to doe it cunningly, and without di≈øcouerie: Whereupon a fooli≈øh boy ≈øuffered a Foxe to gnaw his heart through his brea≈øt. And this doctrine is like that Le≈ø≈øon of the Cannon Law, Si non ca≈øt√®, tamen caut√®. I knowe you thinke that I ≈øpeake partially in this ca≈øe like a Hunter; But there is neuer a one of you that heares mee, that cares the lea≈øt for the ≈øport, for pre≈øeruation of the Game, but he would be as glad to haue a pa≈øtie of Veni≈øon if you might get it, as the be≈øt Hunter would: And if the Game be not pre≈øerued, you can eate no Veni≈øon. As for Partridge and Phe≈øant, I doe not denie that Gentlemen ≈øhould haue their ≈øport, and ≈øpecially vpon their owne ground. But fir≈øt I doe not thinke ≈øuch Game and plea≈øures ≈øhould be free to ba≈øe people. And next I would euen wi≈øh that Gentlemen ≈øhould v≈øe it in a Gentlemanlike fa≈øhion, and not with Nets, or Gunnes, or ≈øuch other vngentlemanlike fa≈øhions that ≈øerue but for vtter de≈øtruction of all Game, nor yet to kill them at vn≈øea≈øonable times, as to kill the Phe≈øant and Partridges when they are no bigger then Mice, when as for euery one their Hawkes kill, ten will be de≈øtroyed with their Dogs and Hor≈øe feet; be≈øides the great and intolerable harme they doe to Corne in that ≈øea≈øon.

And now in the end of all this fa≈øchious Speach, I mu≈øt conclude like a Grey Frier, in ≈øpeaking for my ≈øelfe at la≈øt. At the beginning of this Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, when the Trea≈øourer opened my nece≈ø≈øities vnto you, then my Pur≈øe onely laboured; But now that word is ≈øpread both at home and abroad of the demaunds I haue made vnto you; my Reputation laboureth a≈øwellas my Pur≈øe: For if you part without the repairing of my State in ≈øome rea≈øonable ≈øort, what can the world thinke, but that the euill will my Subiects beare vnto mee, hath bred a refu≈øe? And yee can neuer part ≈øo, without apprehending that I am di≈øta≈øted with your behauiour, and yet to be in feare of my di≈øplea≈øure. But I a≈ø≈øure and promi≈øe my ≈øelfe farre otherwi≈øe.
THus haue I now performed my promi≈øe, in pre≈øenting vnto you the Chri≈øtall of your Kings heart.
Yee know that principally by three wayes yee may wrong a Mirrour.
Fr≈øt, I pray you, looke not vpon my Mirrour with a fal≈øe light: which yee doe, if ye mi≈øtake, or mi≈ø-vnder≈øtand my Speach, and ≈øo alter the ≈øence thereof.

But ≈øecondly, I pray you beware to ≈øoile it with a foule breath, and vncleane hands: I meane, that yee peruert not my words by any corrupt affections,
turning them to an ill meaning, like one, who when hee heares the tolling of a Bell, fancies to him≈øelfe, that it ≈øpeakes tho≈øe words which are mo≈øt in his minde.

And la≈øtly, (which is wor≈øt of all) beware to let it fall or breake; (for gla≈ø≈øe is brittle) which ye doe, if ye lightly e≈øteeme it, and by contemning it, conforme not your ≈øelues to my per≈øwa≈øions.

To conclude then: As all the≈øe three dayes of Iubile haue fallen in the mid≈øt of this ≈øea≈øon of penitence, wherein you haue pre≈øented your thanks to me, and I the like againe to you: So doe I wi≈øh and hope, that the end of this Parliament will bee ≈øuch, as wee may all haue cau≈øe (both I your Head, and yee the Body) to ioyne in Euchari≈øticke Thanks and Prai≈øes vnto God, for our ≈øo good and happie an end.

div.head: A SPEACH IN THE STARRE-CHAMBER, THE XX. OF JVNE. ANNO 1616.
div.p: GIVE THY IVDGEMENTS TO THE KING, O GOD, AND THY RIGHTEOVSNES TO THE KINGS SONNE.

The≈øe be the fir≈øt words of one of the P≈øalmes of the Kingly Prophet Dauid, whereof the literall ≈øen≈øe runnes vpon him, and his ≈øonne Salomon, and the my≈øticall ≈øen≈øe vpon GOD and CHRIST his eternall Sonne: but they are both ≈øo wouen together, as ≈øome parts are, and can onely bee properly applied vnto GOD and CHRIST, and other parts vnto Dauid and Salomon, as this Ver≈øe, Giue thy Iudgements to the King, O God, and thy Righteou≈øne≈øse to the Kings Sonne, cannot be properly ≈øpoken of any, but of Dauid and his ≈øonne; becau≈øe it is ≈øaid, Giue thy Iudgements, &c. Now God cannot giue to him≈øelfe. In another part of the ≈øame P≈øalme, where it is ≈øaid, that Righteou≈ønes ≈øhall flouri≈øh, and abundance of Peace, as long as the Moone endureth, it ≈øignifieth eternitie, and cannot be properly applied but to GOD and CHRIST: But both ≈øen≈øes, a≈øwell literall as my≈øticall, ≈øerue to Kings for imitation, and e≈øpecially to Chri≈øtian Kings: for Kings ≈øit in the Throne of GOD, and they them≈øelues are called Gods.

And therefore all good Kings in their gouernment, mu≈øt imitate GOD
and his Chri≈øt, in being iu≈øt and righteous; Dauid and Salomon, in being godly and wi≈øe: To be wi≈øe, is vnder≈øtood, able to di≈øcerne, able to iudge others: To be godly is, that the fountaine be pure whence the ≈øtreames proceed: for what auailes it though all his workes be godly, if they proceed not from godline≈ø≈øe: To bee righteous, is to a mans ≈øelfe: To bee iu≈øt, is towards others. But Iu≈øtice in a King auailes not, vnle≈ø≈øe it be with a cleane heart: for except he bee Righteous a≈øwell as Iu≈øt, he is no good King; and what≈øoeuer iu≈øtice he doeth; except he doeth it for Iu≈øtice ≈øake, and out of the purene≈ø≈øe of his owne heart, neither from priuate ends, vaine-glory, or any other by-re≈øpects of his owne, all ≈øuch Iu≈øtice is vnrighteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and no trew Iu≈øtice. From this imitation of GOD and CHRIST, in who≈øe Throne wee ≈øit, the gouernment of all Common-wealths, and e≈øpecially Monarchies, hath bene from the beginning ≈øetled and e≈øtabli≈øhed. Kings are properly Iudges, and Iudgement properly belongs to them from GOD: for Kings ≈øit in the Throne of GOD, and thence all Iudgement is deriued.

In all well ≈øetled Monarchies, where Law is e≈øtabli≈øhed formerly and orderly, there Iudgement is deferred from the King to his ≈øubordinate Magi≈øtrates; not that the King takes it from him≈øelfe, but giues it vnto them: So it comes not to them Priuatiu√®, but cumulatiu√®, as the Shoolemen ≈øpeake. The ground is ancient, euer ≈øithence that Coun≈øell which Iethro gaue to Mo≈øes: for after that Mo≈øes had gouerned a long time, in his owne per≈øon, the burthen grew ≈øo great, hauing none to helpe him, as his father in law comming to vi≈øite him, found him ≈øo cumbred with mini≈øtring of Iu≈øtice, that neither the people were ≈øatisfied, nor he well able to performe it; Therefore by his aduice, Iudges were deputed for ea≈øier que≈øtions, and the greater and more profound were left to Mo≈øes: And according to this e≈øtabli≈øhment; all Kings that haue had a formall gouernement, e≈øpecially Chri≈øtian Kings in all aages haue gouerned their people, though after a diuers maner.

This Deputation is after one manner in France, after another here, and euen my owne Kingdomes differ in this point of gouernment: for Scotland differs both from France and England herein; but all agree in this, (I ≈øpeake of ≈øuch Kingdomes or States where the formalitie of Law hath place) that the King that ≈øits in Gods Throne, onely deputes ≈øubalterne Iudges, and he deputes not one but a number (for no one ≈øubalterne Iudges mouth makes Law) and their office is to interprete Law, and admini≈øter Iu≈øtice. But as to the number of them, the forme of gouernement, the maner of interpretation, the di≈øtinction of Benches, the diuer≈øitie of Courts; the≈øe varie according to the varietie of gouernment, and in≈øtitution of diuers Kings: So this ground I lay, that the ≈øeate of Iudgement is properly Gods, and Kings are Gods Vicegerents; and by Kings Iudges are deputed vnder them, to beare the burden of gouernement, according to the fir≈øt example of Mo≈øes by the aduice of Iethro, and
≈øithence practi≈øed by Dauid and Salomon, the wi≈øe≈øt Kings that euer were; which is in this P≈øalme ≈øo interlaced, that as the fir≈øt ver≈øe cannot be applied properly but to Dauid and Salomon, in the words, Giue thy Iudgements to the King, &c. So the other place in the ≈øame P≈øalme, Righteou≈øne≈øse ≈øhall flouri≈øh, and abundance of peace ≈øhall remaine as long as the Moone endureth, properly ≈øignifieth the eternitie of CHRIST. This I ≈øpeake, to ≈øhew what a neere coniunction there is betweene God and the King vpward, and the King and his Iudges downewards: for the ≈øame coniunction that is betweene God and the King vpward; the ≈øame coniunction is betweene the King and his Iudges downewards.

As Kings borrow their power from God, ≈øo Iudges from Kings: And as Kings are to accompt to God, ≈øo Iudges vnto God and Kings; and both Kings and Iudges by imitation, haue two qualities from God and his Chri≈øt, and two qualities from Dauid and his Salomon: Iudgement and Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, from God and Chri≈øt: Godline≈ø≈øe and Wi≈øedome from Dauid and Salomon. And as no King can di≈øcharge his accompt to God, vnle≈ø≈øe he make con≈øcience not to alter, but to declare and e≈øtabli≈øh the will of God: So Iudges cannot di≈øcharge their accompts to Kings, vnle≈ø≈øe they take the like care, not to take vpon them to make Law, but ioyned together after a deliberate con≈øultation, to declare what the Law is; For as Kings are ≈øubiect vnto Gods Law, ≈øo they to mans Law. It is the Kings Office to protect and ≈øettle the trew interpretation of the Law of God within his Dominions: And it is the Iudges Office to interprete the Law of the King, whereto them≈øelues are al≈øo ≈øubiect.

Hauing now perfourmed this ancient Prouerbe, A Ioue principium; which though it was ≈øpoken by a Pagan, yet it is good and holy: I am now to come to my particular Errand, for which I am heere this day; wherein I mu≈øt handle two parts: Fir≈øt, the rea≈øon why I haue not the≈øe fourteene yeeres, ≈øithence my Coronation vntill now, ≈øatisfied a great many of my louing ≈øubiects, who I know haue had a great expectation, and as it were a longing, like them that are with child, to heare mee ≈øpeake in this place, where my Predece≈ø≈øors haue often ≈øitten, and e≈øpecially King Henry the ≈øeuenth, from whom, as diuers wayes before, I am lineally de≈øcended, and that doubly to this Crowne; and as I am neere≈øt de≈øcended of him, ≈øo doe I de≈øire to follow him in his be≈øt actions.

The next part is the rea≈øon, Why I am now come: The cau≈øe that made mee ab≈øtaine, was this: When I came into England, although I was an old King, pa≈øt middle aage, and practi≈øed in gouernment euer ≈øithence I was twelue yeeres olde; yet being heere a ≈øtranger in gouernement, though not in blood, becau≈øe my breeding was in another Kingdome; I re≈øolued therefore with Pythagoras to keepe ≈øilence ≈øeuen yeeres, and learne my ≈øelfe the Lawes of this Kingdome, before I would take vpon mee to teach them vnto others: When this Apprenti≈øhip was ended, then another impediment came, which was in the choice of that cau≈øe, that ≈øhould fir≈øt
bring me hither. I expected ≈øome great cau≈øe to make my fir≈øt entry vpon: For I thought that hauing ab≈øtained ≈øo long, it ≈øhould be a worthy matter that ≈øhould bring mee hither. Now euery cau≈øe mu≈øt be great or ≈ømall: In ≈ømall cau≈øes I thought it di≈øgracefull to come, hauing beene ≈øo long ab≈øent: In great cau≈øes, they mu≈øt be either betwixt the King and ≈øome of his Subiects, or betwixt Subiect and Subiect.

In a cau≈øe where my ≈øelfe was concerned, I was loath to come, becau≈øe men ≈øhould not thinke I did come for my owne priuate, either Prerogatiue or profit; or for any other by-re≈øpect: And in that ca≈øe I will alwayes abide the triall of men and Angels, neuer to haue had any particular end, in that which is the Maine of all things, Iu≈øtice.

In a great cau≈øe al≈øo betweene partie and partie, great in re≈øpect either of the que≈øtion, or value of the thing, my comming might ≈øeeme, as it were obliquely, to be in fauour of one partie, and for that cau≈øe this Coun≈øellour, or that Courtier might be thought to mooue me to come hither; And a meane cau≈øe was not worthy of mee, e≈øpecially for my fir≈øt entrance: So lacke of choice in both re≈øpects kept mee off till now: And now hauing pa≈ø≈øed a double apprenti≈øhip of twice ≈øeuen yeeres, I am come hither to ≈øpeake vnto you. And next as to the rea≈øons of my comming at this time, they are the≈øe.

I haue ob≈øerued in the time of my whole Reigne here, and my double Apprenti≈øhip, diuers things fallen out in the Iudicatures here at We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, that I thought required and vrged a reformation at my hands; whereupon I re≈øolued with my ≈øelfe, that I could not more fitly begin a reformation, then here to make an open declaration of my meaning. I remember Chri≈øts ≈øaying, My ≈øheepe heare my voyce, and ≈øo I a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelfe, my people will mo≈øt willingly heare the voyce of me, their owne Shepheard and King; whereupon I tooke this occa≈øion in mine owne per≈øon here in this Seate of Iudgement, not iudicially, but declaratorily and openly to giue tho≈øe directions, which, at other times, by piece-meale, I haue deliuered to ≈øome of you in diuers le≈ø≈øe publike places; but now will put it vp in all your audience, where I hope it ≈øhall bee trewly caried, and cannot be mi≈øtaken, as it might haue bene when it was ≈øpoken more priuately: I will for order ≈øake take mee to the methode of the number of Three, the number of perfection, and vpon that number di≈øtribute all I haue to declare to you.

FIr≈øt, I am to giue a charge to my ≈øelfe: for a King, or Iudge vnder a King, that fir≈øt giues not a good charge to him≈øelfe, will neuer be able to giue a good charge to his inferiours; for as I haue ≈øaid, Good riuers cannot flow but from good ≈øprings; if the fountaine be impure, ≈øo mu≈øt the riuers be.
